title: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 1, 1983 International
description: The Peronist party was defeated in Argentina for the first time in nearly 40 years as Raul Alfonsin, the leader of a middle-class party, unexpectedly won a presidential election. Mr. Alfonsin received 52 percent of the vote to 40 percent for the Peronist, Italo Luder. Ten smaller parties split the balance. (Page A1, Column 6.) At least 12 people were killed early in the invasion of Grenada last week when an American Navy plane bombed a building that turned out to be a civilian hospital, the Penatagon acknowledged. Officials said the building was not marked as a hospital and was situated in a military complex from which gunfire was being directed at American troops. (A1:1.)

title: Indiana Utility's Rating Reduced
description: Moody's Investors Service yesterday downgraded $1.2 billion of debt and $285 million of preferred stock of the Public Service Company of Indiana, citing delays and price increases in construction of the utility's Marble Hill nuclear plant.

title: TIME FOR AN ARMS ROLLBACK
description: The tragedies in Lebanon and Grenada, the downing of the South Korean airliner, moves that Moscow will make to counter the Pershing 2 and cruise missiles, and in general stronger nations' interventions in weaker ones serve notice that this is a time of international anarchy and that virtually any events could ignite nuclear war. Is there a way out?

title: SwastikaScrawled On Wall of Center
description: A community center here was broken into over the weekend and a swastika and anti-Semitic writing were left on a wall, the Nassau County police said today. The police said they were investigating the incident.

title: Bombing in Colombia
description: A bomb that a guerrilla group said it set to protest the United States-led invasion of Grenada exploded early today at the Colombia- American Center, the police said. No one was hurt in the blast.

title: CITY OPERA: 'ARIADNE AUF NAXOS'
description: RICHARD STRAUSS'S gently touching ''Ariadne auf Naxos'' returned to the New York City Opera Sunday night. It is a chamber work both in its musical dimensions and in its muted dramatic qualities. The blend of serious opera and harlequinade in ''Ariadne'' is at once sad and absurd. With a quiet eloquence, Strauss takes delight in rubbing the painful idealism of art against the direct, untroubled joys of popular entertainment.

A.M.C. Seeks Cuts
description: The American Motors Corporation said that it plans to cut costs by 10 percent during the next year, but that the program will focus on areas other than widespread layoffs or efforts to squeeze concessions from hourly workers in the United Automobile Workers union. ''There are many other ways of cutting costs without laying people off,'' said Jerry Sloan, vice president of public relations, adding that the company will not seek concessions when A.M.C.'s contract with the union expires in 1985. A.M.C. posted a third- quarter loss of $9.1 million, but company officials said they expect A.M.C. will become profitable again in the fourth quarter and remain in the black through 1984.

title: DANCE: JOELLE BALLONZOLI'S WORK AT SCHONBERG
description: JOELLE BALLONZOLI is a French performer who has been working in New York for the last five years in the performance art, the theatrical form that mixes movement, speech and visual material. Presented Friday at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater, her new ''Performance Historique: A Good Recipe to End on the Moon'' combined familiar elements of performance art with native wit and a tough and sultry personal presence. The result was an unusually well-integrated, hourlong collage that depicted the surrealistic excesses that war and militarism can encourage in the most ordinary of populations.

It buried the myth of Peronist omnipotence at the polls by giving a solid majority to Raul Alfonsin, an able and committed democrat. By reaching out to a working-class electorate, Mr. Alfonsin's Radical Civic Union has won the broad mandate it needs to govern. This is inspiring news for Argentina, South America and the democratic cause.

KEY QUESTION ON BOND ISSUE
description: In campaigning for the proposed $1.25 billion New York State transportation bond issue, proponents have gone to great lengths to argue that this one is different from all previous bond issues because of what they say are guarantees that the money will not be squandered or diverted. They are seeking to overcome the resistance to bond issues that has been generated by unfullfilled promises of the past, and they are making some sweeping claims of their own. ''This bond issue is unigue - uniquely specific,'' Governor Cuomo has said repeatedly in recent weeks. ''We've never had a bond issue that said as clearly as this one says, and legally, how you spend the money.''

A new collection called Geoffrey Beene Part Two, focusing on moderately priced dresses, was introduced, and the Mollie Parnis Studio has a new designer and a less expensive collection.

title: No Headline
description: Cruelty and Baby Jane The standard response to that old query, ''Do you want a boy or a girl?'' is ''I don't care, as long as it's healthy.'' Three weeks ago a Long Island couple had a girl, and she was not healthy. Baby Jane Doe had spina bifida, an abnormally small skull, hydrocephalus or excess fluid on the brain, and other deformities. Even if operated on, she would remain severely retarded and bedridden for life - in her case, about 20 years.

title: TEAM DISPELS SHERLOCK HOLMES MYSTERY

But few people, except for a handful of scientists, have known much about the reclusive and seldom-seen rodent.

title: THE CIVILIAN CALLED TO COMMAND ARGENTINA
description: During his more than 30 years in politics, Raul Alfonsin, the successful candidate in Argentina's presidential election, has been an outsider and, at crucial moments, a loser. But his image as a maverick served him well when Argentina, after seven years of military rule, began looking for leaders not associated with the failures of the past. In his campaign, Mr. Alfonsin proved to be a master of consensus and a vigorous advocate for democracy and social justice. He pledged to wipe out illiteracy and malnutrition, increase the money spent on education to 30 percent of the total budget and suspend the purchase of arms.

title: Petty Switches Team
description: Richard Petty , seven times the national stock-car driving champion, announced yesterday that he would drive for a newly formed team, Curb Associates, but that he would retain the presidency of Petty Enterprises. Petty, who is 46 years old, said that good business sense dictated the change.

title: CURATOR OF MUSEUM HELD AQUARIUM POST
description: Charles Marcus Breder Jr., former director of the New York Aquarium and a curator at the American Museum of Natural History, died last Friday at the Englewood (Fla.) Hospital. He was 86 years old and had lived in Manasota Key, Fla., since his retirement in 1965.

title: TO FIGHT ACID RAIN
description: Gerry Sikorski, Minnesota Democrat, is a sponsor of the National Acid Rain Deposition Act. is national cost-sharing, as is proposed in the National Acid Deposition Control Act of 1983. The bill would add a fee of one-tenth of a cent for each electric kilowatt generated by every utility in the continental United States. This would cost an average American family 50 to 75 cents a month. The money collected would pay up to 90 percent of the onetime cost of installing scrubbers at the 50 dirtiest plants in the nation. Sulfur dioxide emissions would be cut by seven million tons a year while allowing the utilities to continue burning high-sulfur Eastern coal, protecting thousands of mining jobs.

title: South African Homeland Detains a Black Cleric
description: The police in the homeland known as Ciskei have detained the secretary general of the Southern African Catholic Bishops Conference, church and security officials said today.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: WHILE the newest and most interesting collections in Europe were those with a masculine proportion and a markedly androgynous feeling (Giorgio Armani, Yohji Yamamoto and Jean-Paul Gaultier come immediately to mind), it seems that more than ever American designers are going to be pushing a refined, traditional ladylike silhouette in their spring collections. That, anyway, is the surprising word from Perry Ellis, long known for clothing anything but traditional or ladylike.

title: HEROES, VILLAINS AND WARY TEXTBOOK PUBLISHERS
description: HOW will Martin Luther King Jr. be treated in future high school history texts? Gingerly, if the record of American textbooks is any indication. How will Senator Joseph R. McCarthy be treated in future high school history texts? Noncommittally, if current scholarly revisionism of his career is any indication. These questions arise at a time when the social studies curriculum is under scrutiny. For example, the New York State Education Department has suggested putting greater stress in the teaching of history on sociological, political and economic issues instead of on the more traditional chronological approach. But many critics of the way history is taught feel that the major obstacle to creating an accurate picture of the past is overt or covert interference by partisans who prevent textbook publishers from dealing forthrightly with vital figures and ideas because they are afraid of controversy. Such fear also intimidates teachers. In its recent report on the high schools, the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching pointed out that 17 states use centralized selection of textbooks for all students in all schools. To lose sales in those states is a matter of serious concern to publishers. Therefore, the foundation says, ''most textbooks present students with a highly simplified view of reality.'' In her analysis of history texts, ''America Revised,'' Frances FitzGerald observed that textbooks ''have become the lightning rods of American society,'' exposed to the wrath of special interest groups. Quite naturally, therefore, controversial ideas are often expunged.

The restructuring, attributed to lower demand for steel, will reduce Inland's work force by 330 employees.

description: Children usually outgrow their anger about the divorce of their parents and come to understand the reasons for the split but still wish their parents had made their decision before having children, according to a lengthy study.

title: Ernesto Bitetti In Guitar Recital
description: One half of Ernesto Bitetti's guitar recital in Alice Tully Hall Monday night was written for the guitar. The rest was music taken from elsewhere in the instrumental repertory and reshaped to fit the guitar's gentler voice.

title: O'BRIEN ENTERS DISPUTE
description: Commissioner Larry O'Brien, who helped avert a player strike last year, was present for the first time yesterday in negotiations between the National Basketball Association and the union representing its 29 regular referees. But after three and a half hours of talks at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, the session ended in much the same way as those that preceded it - with little apparent movement.

title: Congress Honors Rickover
description: Adm. Hyman G. Rickover became the second American in history to be honored with two Congressional gold medals today when he was presented the award again by Strom Thurmond, president pro tem of the Senate, and Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House, in ceremonies at the Capitol's Staturary Hall.

title: MURDOCH BUYS CHICAGO SUN-TIMES
description: Rupert K. Murdoch, the Australian newspaper executive who owns newspapers ranging from The Times of London to The New York Post, announced yesterday that he had bought The Chicago Sun-Times for $90 million in cash.

title: Afghan Rebels Reported To Down 2 Soviet Planes
description: Afghan guerrillas fighting the Soviet-backed Government have shot down two Soviet transport planes trying to resupply a besieged town in eastern Afghanistan, Western diplomats said today.

title: A Stake in GAF
description: A Dallas businessman, Harold C. Simmons, said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that through companies he controls he has acquired 1.07 million shares, or 7.5 percent, of the common stock of the GAF Corporation. Mr. Simmons said that amount includes 623,100 shares acquired on the open market between Oct. 6 and Oct. 21. The shares were acquired at prices of $14.75 to $16.50 each, as an investment, Mr. Simmons said in the filing. GAF, which has been trying to sell its two principal remaining businesses, closed at $16.25, up 12.5 cents, in trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.

title: WNYC-TV Plans To Sell More Time
description: Mayor Koch announced yesterday that the city-owned television station, WNYC-TV, would expand its practice of leasing air time commercially next year in an effort to make the station financially self-sufficient.

title: No Headline
description: Insure Against Sex Discrimination A bill to prohibit sex discrimination in insurance and annuities faces a tough test this week in the House, where the insurance industry is working hard to bury it. The industry's objections are understandable, for this is an issue on which people of good will disagree. On balance, though, there's a very strong case for the compromise now before the Commerce Committee.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: JO had been a proofreader for 30 years, driving 18 miles each way to her job. Although she had perfect vision, she had to give up the job two years ago because she could no longer see well enough to drive or to read. Jo had become one of a small group of frustrated people afflicted with a strange neuromuscular disorder that periodically locks their eyelids shut.

title: Mesa's Gulf Fee
description: T. Boone Pickens Jr., chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, has agreed to pay Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb a $1 million fee - and possibly as much as $7.5 million - for advice in a proxy fight against the Gulf Oil Corporation, filings with the Securities and Exchange Commission showed. A 15-page agreement disclosed that Mesa would pay the first $1 million as a retainer by next July. The rest would become due, among other reasons, if a group headed by Mr. Pickens makes a profit on a nearly 18-million-share block of Gulf stock it owns or if Mesa is taken over.

title: BLOOD PLASMA IS WITHDRAWN AS AIDS LINK
description: An official of the Federal Food and Drug Administration said yesterday that a California blood product company withdrew 16 lots of a blood clotting factor used by hemophiliacs after it was discovered that it contained plasma drawn from a commercial blood donor in Texas who died last month of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS.

title: SENATE UNIT CUTS MONEY FOR JORDAN STRIKE FORCE
description: The Reagan Administration's effort to obtain $220 million in secret funding for a Jordanian strike force in the Middle East was dealt a major setback today when the Senate Appropriations Committee deleted the money for Jordan from the 1984 military spending bill.

title: Many Offers Expected
description: Warren Moon, the former University of Washington quarterback who has passed for 30 touchdowns and more than 5,500 yards in his six years in the Canadian Football League, is ready to try his hand in the United States and expects offers from teams in all three professional leagues. Moon, who led the Edmonton Eskimos to five Grey Cup victories in his first five years, becomes a free agent in March. Although he expects offers from all three leagues, including the new International Football League, Moon has reportedly narrowed his choices to four teams in the National Football League, the Houston Oilers, the New Orleans Saints, the Los Angeles Raiders and the Seattle Seahawks, and one in the United States Football League, the Los Angeles Express.

title: Strike May Halt Chrysler

They were always ''launched,'' in the term of one of the more overworked cliches stocked in a big studio publicity department that was charged with luring customers to the box office in a rush of word and picture that sometimes overshadowed in lavishness the work of art it was memorializing.

That is why they are trying to lure him back to New York as their pitching coach.

description: Instead of reaching for the salt shaker, consumers are reaching for their wallets to buy salt substitutes that cost more but are not necessarily healthier, an Iowa State University nutritionist says.

From the point of view of his children, father knows worst.

title: Choral Society Offers Verdi Requiem
description: In a curious way, the New York Choral Society's performance of the Verdi Requiem in Carnegie Hall last Saturday night worked because of its shortcomings, not despite them. Unlike Mozart's Requiem, which emanates serenely from the other side of the grave, Verdi's music represents death as seen by the living - with all the turmoil, fear and wonder that this vision entails.

description: The Cuban Government said tonight that American troops had surrounded its embassy in Grenada and that the island's Governor General had ordered all Cuban diplomatic personnel off the island by midday Wednesday.

title: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 2, 1983 International
description: The War Powers Resolution would apply to the fighting in Grenada under a bill approved overwhelmingly by the House in a broadly bipartisan vote. The vote was 403 to 23, as 256 Democrats and 147 Republicans backed the measure. Under the resolution, United States troops engaged in hostilities abroad must be removed within 60 days - 90 days if the President requests an extension - unless Congress authorizes their continued presence. (Page A1, Column 6.) A Marine force looking for Cubans landed on a tiny island 20 miles north of Grenada, but returned to United States ships several hours later without having found any Cubans, American military officials said. Officials said the force of 300 marines reportedly detained 17 Grenadian revolutionary soldiers and uncovered an arms cache, but met no opposition and fired no shots on Carriacou, a dependency of Grenada. (A1:5.)

title: Oil Line Costs an Issue
description: The Justice Department recommended today that the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission hold down the rates charged for transporting crude oil on the Trans-Alaska Pipeline System, which the department's antitrust division portrayed as a monopoly. title: ON BALANCE, '83 SEEMS A GOOD YEAR FOR FRANCE
description: -THORINS, France, Oct. 31 - Wine growers in this country are a conservative lot. They are adept at blaming everything but the grape-eating birds on the Socialist Government. If there was some way to blame a bad vintage on the Socialists they would do that too. But there have been good vintages since they came to power two years ago, and it looks like 1983 is going to be a good one too.

Before the halt in trading, Chock Full shares stood at $19.

description: An amendment to a State Department spending bill that would have cut the United States contribution to the United Nations by nearly $500 million was eliminated today by a House-Senate conference committee.

title: THE ARGENTINE RESULT: A VOTE FOR DEMOCRACY
description: The election Sunday of Raul Alfonsin as President appears to reflect a desire among Argentines to end decades of alternating military coups and union violence under Peronist governments. In an election called by the ruling military, Mr. Alfonsin of the Radical Civic Union won an upset victory over the Peronist candidate, Italo Luder, by a resounding margin of 52 percent to 40 percent.

description: The Court of Appeals today upheld the disbarment of Joseph M. Margiotta, the former Nassau County Republican leader who was convicted on Federal mail-fraud and extortion charges.

title: SINGING COWBOYS RIDE THE RANGE AGAIN
description: DALLAS IT is safe to say there are surer paths to fame and fortune these days than a career as a singing cowboy. Men on horseback strumming guitars have been all but extinct since 1954, when a film called ''The Phantom Stallion'' brought to an end one of Hollywood's most colorful eras, a time when dozens of singing cowboys turned out literally hundreds of now-all-but-forgotten films.

title: JACKSON FORESEES NO INDEPENDANT CANDIDACY
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, who has said he will formally announce his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination tomorrow in Washington, said yesterday that he did not intend at this time to mount an independent candidacy if he failed to get the nomination but he stopped short of pledging that he would not run independently at some later date.

title: Missile Accident Exercise
description: The Strategic Air Command will conduct an off-base ''accident response exercise'' near a Titan 2 missile site in southern Arizona, the Davis-Monthan Air Force Base announced Monday. The exercise will be held in the civilian community ''sometime during the next seven days,'' an Air Force spokesman said.

title: Chamber Trio Plays Works by Brahms
description: The pianist Peter Frankl and Gyorgy Pauk, the violinist, have been performing together since childhood, and it sounds that way, for they play with mutual understanding and shared purchase. At the 92d Street Y last Saturday night, Mr. Frankl and Mr. Pauk were joined by the cellist Ralph Kirshbaum for a program of chamber music by Johannes Brahms.

title: REFUGEES ARE HOSTAGES OF LEBANON TALKS /L
description: Naef Saad, 87 years old, stood in front of Bus No. 1, waiting to be evacuated from this Christian town under siege. In his right hand he clutched a plastic bag containing all he had left in the world: a Sony portable radio and a clump of earth from Ramhala, his home village some 15 miles from here.

description: The General Electric Company will sell China 220 of its largest diesel electric locomotives in a deal that may add several hundred jobs at G.E.'s locomotive plant here next year, company officials announced.

title: A DRY TOWN DEBATES HOW DRY IS SHOULD BE
description: There are no liquor stores here, no bars, no neon signs promising Budweiser or Miller or Heineken. In short, there's no alcohol for sale in Wilton. It is a dry and thirsty land.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: THE Senate opened hearings last week on legislation that pits record companies and music publishers against tape and electronics manufacturers and people who tape music at home. The legislation is called the Home Recording Act, and it would require manufacturers and importers of tape recorders and blank tapes to ''contribute to a royalty pool that would be distributed among copyright holders'' of recorded music - a ''contribution'' whose cost would probably be passed on to consumers.

title: FOUR-PIECE STRAINER SET
description: KITCHEN strainers and sifters (often called sieves) come in all shapes and sizes, and hardly a day goes by when I don't use one or more in my kitchen, for straining soups and stocks, draining vegetables or sifting flour or sugar. Many of the strainers on the market today are made of inexpensive metals that rust and warp over time and need to be replaced. The four-piece set pictured below, in cone and bowl shapes, is exceptionally well made. The strainers have stainless steel rims and extra-fine mesh interiors. They will last for years.

description: The Minneapolis financier Irwin L. Jacobs said he had purchased shares of the RCA Corporation, but would not disclose the amount. ''My holdings are under 5 percent,'' he said, declining to say whether he intended to purchase more.

title: UPDATE LEBANON'S SYSTEM
description: A major source of the protracted cycles of violence that have gripped Lebanon since 1975 is the obsolesence of the Lebanese political system. Americans and Lebanese alike are thinking now - and the Lebanese are discussing it at the peace conference in progress in Geneva - about a new political arrangement that would readjust the balance of power between contending religious communities. Such reform is not only possible: It is necessary for stability in Lebanon.

THE BEAR WHO REALLY WAS ONE

Walter Payton had rushed the previous Sunday for 275 yards, still the one- game record in the National Football League, and now the Bears were awaiting a Thanksgiving Day game in Detroit.

title: THE DANCE: GROUP PIECE
description: SALLY SILVERS is a representative of the ''wild child school of dance,'' as one member of the audience put it during a performance by Miss Silvers and company Sunday in the Merce Cunningham Studio. A fearlessly anarchistic performer and choreographer, she reveals herself and her very good dancers emotionally and physically. But it is work conceived with wit and compassion. ''The body is the agent of social relations,'' Miss Silvers has written - a thought peculiarly applicable to her new group piece, ''And Find Out Why.''

title: Books of The Times
description: When the great stampede of Salman Rushdie's new novel has passed and its hooves are no longer beating along one's synapses, a voice inside one's head asks timidly, What did we do to deserve all this revenge and violence? What did Mr. Rushdie's characters do? What did Pakistan do? Or not precisely Pakistan: ''The country in this story is not Pakistan, or not quite,'' writes Mr. Rushdie. ''There are two countries, real and fictional, occupying the same space, or almost the same space. My story, my fictional country exist, like myself, at a slight angle to reality. I have found this off-centring to be necessary; but its value is, of course, open to debate. My view is that I am not writing only about Pakistan.'' <TD WIDTH=2

title: GRENADA NEIGHBOR IS SEARCHED BY U.S.
description: Three hundred United States marines looking for Cubans landed today on a tiny island 20 miles north of Grenada, but they returned to their ships several hours later without having found any, United States military officials said.

title: No Headline
description: New Cars, Used Buyers It's been a hard week for car buyers. Pressed by the American auto industry, the Reagan Administration has forced Japan to swallow another ''voluntary'' quota on imported cars, through April 1985. The quota will rise from 1.68 million this year to 1.85 million next, but there'll still be shortages of Japanese models. Experts believe the Japanese could easily sell an additional half-million cars in a total American market of 10 million. As a result, customers who want imports - or their American counterparts - will pay more.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: LUDWIG, AT LENGTH Ten years ago, ''Ludwig,'' an ambitious 1972 film by Luchino Visconti about the last king of Bavaria, opened in New York. It ran 173 minutes, the English-language version having been cut at the behest of the producers. For those who might then have felt that something was missing, the full-length ''Ludwig'' will be shown in its 257-minute grandeur in two showings today (1 and 6:30 P.M.) at the Museum of Modern Art, 18 West 54th Street.

description: The unfinished Zimmer Nuclear Power Station has come under scrutiny by the Nuclear Regulatory Commission and members of the public as the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company defended its plans to complete the facility.

description: CONTEMPORARY couples grapple with a complex set of personal considerations when they tackle the decison to become parents. For Jewish couples, there is an additional imperative: their sense of obligation to halt the decline in population that demographers say poses a threat to the survival of Judaism in this country.

title: COUNCILMAN AND 2 OTHERS INDICTED IN PAYOFF CASE

title: GIANTS ACQUIRE QUARTERBACK
description: The Giants added a player and lost one today. They signed Tom Owen, a 31-year-old free agent, as backup quarterback to Scott Brunner and placed Jim Burt, the starting nose tackle, on injured reserve with continuing back problems.

South African Report
description: According to newspaper reports in South Africa, Calvin Peete , the black American golf professional, has agreed to compete in the 1983 Sun City Golf Challenge in the South African tribal homeland of Bophuthatswana. Neither Peete nor his representatives could be reached yesterday but, according to newspapers in Johannesburg, he is among a number of leading golf professionals who have signed up for the tournament next month, including Lee Trevino , Seve Ballesteros , Craig Stadler , Johnny Miller , Nicky Price , Nick Faldo , David Graham , Fuzzy Zoeller and last year's Sun City champion, Ray Floyd .

title: No Headline
description: The National Googol Limit ''Googol'' is a mathematician's term for the numeral 1 followed by 100 zeros - a very big number indeed. It's derived from baby talk. The national debt isn't a googol yet, but the Senate's childish behavior over raising the statutory debt limit makes the word seem shamefully appropriate.

title: JAPANESE TURN ARKANSAS PLANT INTO A SUCCESS

It is just what this mysterious theater- piece needs and did get in the season's first performance Tuesday night at the City Center.

ON CANADA'S NORTHERN RIM, HOPE FOR 'THE PEOPLE'
description: John Amagoalik was five years old when the Canadian Government moved his family here in 1953. ''It was like landing on the moon,'' he recalled over coffee recently. It is not easy to get people to come to Resolute. In the early 1950's, the Government helped Eskimos like Mr. Amagualik and other Canadians to move here, largely in an effort to demonstrate to other Arctic nations that Canadians indeed live in the region. That, people here say, supposedly underlined claims of sovereignty.

description: ''INNOVATION,'' which begins its second season tonight, opens with a picture of a 5-week-old fetus. Ever so slightly, its hand moves. The fetus ''is a patient even before it has an identity,'' we are told, and ''Innovation'' is off on an intelligent essay about the time between conception and birth. The program will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 o'clock tonight.

title: Bills Lose Butler
description: The Buffalo Bills will have to play the rest of the season without Jerry Butler , their outstanding pass receiver. Butler was first believed to have suffered torn cartilage in his left knee in last Sunday's game against New Orleans, but arthroscopic surgery yesterday showed ligament damage that will require surgery. Butler, who had grabbed 36 passes for 385 yards and three touchdowns, will be replaced in the starting lineup by Mike Mosley . . . . Another wide receiver, Danny Pittman, was claimed by the St. Louis Cardinals only four days after being released by the Giants.

The Police Blotter
description: Fifty police officers raided 24 suspected illegal gambling sites in northern Manhattan yesterday morning and afternoon, arresting 33 people and seizing 54 slot machines and three handguns. . . . Noxious fumes forced the evacuation of an 18-story commercial building on Eighth Avenue at 15th Street from 10:30 A.M. to 12:30 P.M. The odor was traced by the Department of Environmental Protection to a sewer. . . . Kenneth Welsh, a security guard, foiled a robbery at 9:30 A.M. at a Bowery Savings Bank branch at Lexington Avenue at 54th Street when a teller triggered an alarm after a man displayed a gun-shaped cigarette lighter. Joseph Smith, 25 years old, of South Jamaica, Queens, was arrested.

title: REAGAN'S ATTACKS ON RIGHTS
description: His unhappiness with the commission stems from its biting criticisms of his Administration's civil rights and social policies, especially as they pertain to affirmative action and busing for school desegregation. So to remove a burr from under the saddle, Mr. Reagan is seeking to remake the commission in his own image. Yet the civil rights struggle was not waged to create a commission that would be a public-relations agency for the executive branch.

title: No Headline
description: How to Let Prisoners Loose Jail administrators call it ''managing population,'' and that's not just a euphemism for letting inmates go. It means relieving crowding by reducing the number of inmates. But that is done best at the front door, before defendants go to jail - a well-accepted practice elsewhere, where judges are willing to be flexible. They aren't in New York City, which is why inmates suddenly are being pushed out the back door.

title: MUSIC: BL LACERTA PRESENTS VARIETY
description: THE quartet BL Lacerta has diverse abilities and high aims. Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall, the four members of this Texas-based troupe - David Anderson on percussion, flute and electronics; Les Gay of tuba and low brass; Robert Price on clarinet and woodwinds, and Tom Green on cello - played with vigor and imagination, drawing from classical, Eastern, jazz and folk traditions.

title: U.S. Aid to Chad Reviewed
description: The head of the State Department's Central African division, Pierre States aid to Chad in separate talks today with President Hissen Habre and Foreign Minister Idriss Miskine. He told journalists that he had discussed military, economic and food assistance but declined to talk about the possibility of increased military aid. There has been little fighting in Chad since France and Zaire sent in an estimated 5,000 troops to stop further progress southward.

title: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1983 International
description: ''Hostilities have ceased'' in Grenada and a withdrawal of the American troops on the island and a repatriation of about 600 Cuban prisoners will begin soon, the Defense Department announced. In a two-sentence announcement, the department said that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger ''has directed that U.S. forces begin a pullout within a few days.'' (Page A1, Columns 5-6.) The American paratroopers' role in Grenada is now primarily policing duty - guarding checkpoints, making house-to-house and car checks for weapons and patroling the capital and some northern sectors of the island, where some snipers are still active, according to United States military officials. (A1:5.)

title: STRUGGLNIG TO CRACK WRITER'S BLOCK
description: As Diane Johnson reminds us in her recently published biography, ''Dashiell Hammett: A Life,'' Hammett was more or less blocked as a writer from 1933, when he completed ''The Thin Man,'' until his death in 1960. As Miss Johnson observes at one point in her book, ''He could not write, it seemed to him, because he had nothing to write about. His life, in some sense, had ended when he left San Francisco and obscurity, and his work and family, and the social class to which he owed allegiance but was uncomfortable in. He could no longer make any sense of his life, but he also couldn't bring himself to put an end to it more directly than by drinking.''

title: Reporters Told Not to Enter Angola With South Africans
description: Southern African countries meeting here on information issues today told foreign reporters that they would be considered enemies if they entered Angola with South African troops or Angolan insurgents.

title: COMMODITIES Trading Likely to Begin In Aluminum Contracts

Gerrie Coetzee , the World Boxing Association's heavyweight champion who has undergone four operations on his right hand in an effort to curb a persistent inflammation, had minor surgery on his right shoulder in Pretoria, South Africa, after doctors decided a shoulder ailment might be triggering the hand inflammation.

George McGovern, who made a late entry into the 1984 Democratic Presidential race against the advice of friends and family, is getting an affectionate and at times emotional reception to his reappearance on the national political scene.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1983
description: Companies Merrill Lynch said it would no longer sell annuities issued by a unit of Charter and four other insurers. It thus became the second brokerage in two weeks to question the unit's soundness. The other insurers were Capital Life, Old Republic Life, John Alden Life and Executive Life. However, Merrill Lynch is telling owners of their annuities that they are safe. (Page D1.)

title: Nation's Cup Is Captured by U.S. Riders;  Canada Finishes Second; U.S. Riders Win
description: The United States Equestrian Team won the most important team jumping event of the National Horse Show last night, the Nation's Cup. But the Americans needed clean rounds from their final two riders to edge past the surprisingly sharp Canadian team.

title: MUSIC: CONTINUUM, SOVIET BILL
description: -music organization, is filling a valuable role with its concerts acquainting us with the contemporary Soviet musical avant-garde. The most recent took place Tuesday night in Symphony Space, and it proved not just instructive in the didactic sense - although Continuum certainly does stress the didactic - but simply pleasurable from a musical standpoint, as well.

title: Chile Debt Extension
description: Chile has formally asked its creditor banks to extend a moratorium on principal repayments for $3.4 billion of foreign debt repayable in 1983 and 1984, a central bank spokesman said today. He said telexes were sent last week to extend the moratorium, which expired at the end of October, for another 90 days.

title: EDWIN DENBY, DANCE CRITIC, IS REMEMBERED
description: Edwin Denby, the poet and influential dance critic, was a familiar sight to most New York dancegoers. They may not have been sure of the name of the white-haired man with the inviting smile and slightly daunting look of asceticism. But they knew him as a quiet fixture at a surprising range of cultural events. And the variety of the speakers and performers who honored the late Mr. Denby last night at St. Mark's Church on Second Avenue and Tenth Street, in the first of three free public tributes to be held through Friday, suggested the breadth of his interests.

title: Court Allows Patient To Refuse Solid Food
description: A cerebral palsy victim who wants to starve to death in a hospital won a temporary restraining order today preventing doctors from giving her solid food or discharging her pending a full court hearing.

title: Former Bronco Sues
description: When Otis Armstrong , the former Denver Bronco running back, hurt his neck in a game against Houston in November 1980, Dr. James F. McElhinney , the team orthopedist, and six other doctors examined him and concluded that Armstrong suffered from a congenital deformity of the spine that could lead to permanent paralysis if he continued to play. Armstrong expressed doubts about the diagnosis, but he took the doctors' advice and retired.

title: Texas Barges Hit by Blasts
description: A series of explosions ignited the contents of two petrochemical barges Tuesday night, rattling windows as far as 20 miles away and producing billowing black clouds of smoke. The authorities said no injuries were reported, and the explosions and fire on the Victoria Barge Canal, an artery of the Intercoastal Waterway, did not threaten residents.

title: THEATER: 'SISTER GEORGE'
description: THE Roundabout Theater Company is increasingly providing a home for revivals of London plays from the recent past, reliving a period when the English reflexively duplicated their West End successes on Broadway. Although some of the company's choices, such as Shelagh Delaney's ''A Taste of Honey,'' have survived, the current revival, Frank Marcus's ''The Killing of Sister George,'' a more recent play, already seems like a theatrical curio.

title: Students in South Korea Protest Reagan's Visit
description: Riot policemen today broke up a demonstration by more than 1,000 South Korean students against President Reagan's planned visit later this month, witnesses said.

title: AROUND THE NATION
description: Talks Resume in StrikeAt Ohio Chrysler PlantTWINSBURG, Ohio, Nov. 3 (AP) - Negotiations resumed today in a strike here that has resulted in the closing of four Chrysler plants in the United States and Canada.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Beatrice Foods Co. agreed to pay the state of Arizona $5 million in settlement of a lawsuit involving charges of bid-rigging in the sale of milk to school cafeterias. Arizona has settled identical claims against Borden Inc., Shamrock Foods Inc. Foremost-McKesson Inc. and the Carnation Co.

title: BOND ISSUES THAT NEW JERSEY CAN'T AFFORD
description: To the Editor:

title: U.N. Official to Assess Situation in Grenada
description: Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar has decided to send an Under Secretary General to Grenada in response to a General Assembly request for him to issue a report on the situation on the island.

title: 2 SUSPECTS' STORIES OF KILLINGS CULLED
description: When Sgt. Jay Via talks about Henry Lee Lucas and Ottis Elwood Toole, his voice tightens with emotion and he breaks off.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: DARKNESS AND LIGHT ON THE ISLE OF SP
description: ICE BY BERNARD WEINRAUB

title: Japan Expresses Regret
description: The House passage of the auto-content bill is regrettable, International Trade and Industry Minister Sosuke Uno said today. However, he told a news conference, he is confident the Reagan Administration will continue to oppose the bill. The legislation has been strongly criticized by Japanese car makers as protectionist.

title: No Headline
description: The U.S. Sugar Corporation said it had secured a $260 million mortgage to finance a new employee-stock ownership plan.

title: Dispute in Arbitration
description: Arthur Stark , an arbitrator, conducted a hearing yesterday into the dispute between the Seattle SuperSonics and the National Basketball Association over Seattle's right to sign David Thompson to a contract that would put the club over its $4.6- million salary cap. His ruling is expected in a few days. Seattle contends that it is free to sign Thompson under a provision of the collective bargaining agreement that allows a team to exceed the salary ceiling when it re- signs one of its free agents.

title: A SMOKY BLAZE ON IRT DELAYS SUBWAY RIDERS
description: The trip to work was fouled up for thousands of subway riders yesterday because of a smoky fire on the tracks just north of the IRT station at 96th Street and Broadway.

title: NANCY FIELDING, COLLABORATOR ON TRAVEL GUIDES TO EUROPE
description: Nancy Parker Fielding, the widow of Temple Fielding and his collaborator on his numerous travel guides, died of cancer Oct. 31 in Madison, Wis. She was 60 years old.

title: GOVERNOR OF PUERTO RICO SUPPORTS REAGAN ON INVASION OF GRENADA
description: The Governor of Puerto Rico yesterday strongly defended the United States invasion of Grenada and said it would serve as a check on the expansion of Cuban influence in the Caribbean.

title: Helmsley-Spear Accused of Bias
description: The NAACP Legal Defense and Educational Fund Inc. has filed a class action suit against Helmsley- Spear Inc., charging that the real estate concern routinely discriminates against blacks who seek to rent apartments at the 3,200-unit Fresh Meadows housing complex in Queens.

title: No Headline
description: Research Firm Cancels Offer Global Analytics Inc., a

title: LEBANESE FACTIONAL LEADERS PUT ASIDE ISSUE OF MAY 17 ACCORD
description: Lebanon's factional leaders agreed tonight that they would neither ratify nor abrogate the May 17 Israel-Lebanon withdrawal accord, but rather have President Amin Gemayel open new discussions with Washington and other powers to see if he could find an acceptable formula for getting Israeli troops out of Lebanon.

title: ALLEGHENY BEVERAGE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NORTEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Economic Scene; Good Reasons To Lend More
description: WALTER B. WRISTON, chairman of Citicorp, likes to quote a dictum of the economist G. Warren Nutter: ''Good judgment comes from experience, and experience comes from bad judgment.''

title: Money Fund Assets Climb
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds rose in the week ended Wednesday, the fifth consecutive weekly rise, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: ART: SHOW OF SCULPTURES BY HEIZER AT FOURCADE
description: IT'S almost nine years since Michael Heizer announced that he

title: MANAGERS' DEBACLE
description: From left to right, policy proposals for industrial renewal share a core assumption: that American managers as a group are interested in and capable of restoring competence in production. This assumption, once unchallengeable, is obsolete.

title: HOOVER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OLIVIA RECORDS IS A SUCCESS IN 'WOMEN'S MUSIC'
description: ONE of the record industry's most solid success stories of the last decade has been the flourishing of Olivia Records, the small independent women's label based in Oakland, Calif. Last year, Olivia, which is owned and operated entirely by women for women artists, celebrated its 10th anniversary at Carnegie Hall. And tomorrow night, the label's leading lights - Meg Christian and Cris Williamson - will perform at the Beacon Theater in a program that will also feature Tret Fure, Teresa Trull and Barbara Higbie.

title: EASED EVACUATION RULE NEAR REACTORS IS URGED
description: Senior officials at the Nuclear Regulatory Commission have proposed changing the requirements for the emergency plans around nuclear plants to stress the evacuation of residents within a 2-mile radius of a reactor in the event of a serious accident.

title: Northern Propane
description: Internorth Inc. said it had signed a definitive agreement to sell its Northern Propane Gas Company subsidiary to the Penn Central Corporation in a transaction valued at about $100 million. The agreement supersedes a previously acquired option to purchase the subsidiary by Penn Central. Northern Propane, which serves 330,000 customers, will be combined with Penn Central's Buckeye Gas Products Company, which serves 220,000 customers, to form the largest domestic retail propane operation.

title: JUDGE ORDERS U.S. INQUIRY ON NICARAGUA PLANS
description: A Federal district judge here has ordered Attorney General William French Smith to conduct a preliminary investigation of charges that President Reagan and other Government officials violated the Neutrality Act by supporting the activities of paramilitary groups seeking to overthrow the Nicaraguan Government.

title: No Headline
description: I.B.M. System For Graphics The International Business

title: U.S. CLAIMS A RIGHT TO HOLD CIVILIANS
description: The State Department is insisting that the United States had the legal right to ''detain'' Grenadian civilians ''as necessary for security reasons,'' as well as Grenadians and Cubans ''who have actively participated in the fighting against United States forces or who are members of armed groups that have done so pending the cessation of active hostilities.''

title: DOLE'S EFFORTS ON DEFICIT STIR BUT BAFFLE SENATORS
description: Senate Republicans and Democrats say they are baffled but bestirred by Senator Bob Dole's proposal to reduce the Federal deficit by $150 billion.

title: HYDROPOWER: MISGUIDED CALL TO 'ALLOCATE SCARCITY'
description: To the Editor:

title: Merrill Analyst Ousted For Using Rival Firm
description: Merrill Lynch & Company has dismissed one of its research analysts yesterday for failing to disclose that he had maintained securities accounts at another brokerage firm before late 1982.

title: ENTEX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SCOUTING
description: Pine-Tar Affair Won't Go Away

title: SCOUTING
description: Rumor Deflated

title: ADVERTISING
description: WHT Shifts to Ogilvy

title: No Headline
description: A Prudent Wave at Poland With a measured step toward easing sanctions, the Reagan Administration properly begins to extricate itself from mostly empty protest against Poland's repressive regime. Conceivably, such cautious moves can gain leverage for actual influence over Polish affairs.

title: THEATER: 'TO GILLIAN,' ON THE DEATH OF A WIFE
description: DAVID, the central character in Michael Brady's new play at the Ensemble Studio Theater, is a man without hope. He stands on a Nantucket beach under a starry sky, makes a wish and then adds: ''I'm certain I won't have the wish I wish tonight.'' His pessimism is well-founded. Precisely two years after his wife, Gillian, died in a boating accident on her 35th birthday, David wishes only for one impossible miracle - that the woman he loved will come back to life.

title: FILM: COMEDY SET IN WALES
description: PETER DUFFELL'S ''Experience Preferred . . . but Not Essential,'' which opens today at the Embassy 72d Street Theater, is a gentle British comedy with a lot of charm. Set in a Welsh coastal hotel in the summer of 1962, it follows a waitress named Annie (Elizabeth Edmonds) through certain rites of passage. Annie is sweet, soft-spoken and a good listener, which is convenient, since the hotel's employees are a colorful lot and there's plenty for her to observe. Everyone else has a past, Annie decides, and she has none - which is a situation that has certainly been remedied by the time the film is over.

title: SALE BY CHEMICAL BANK
description: In a move reflecting changing strategies in the banking industry, the Chemical Bank said yesterday that it would sell its stock transfer business to the Harris Bancorp.

title: SCOUTING
description: Counted Out

title: Gas Filibuster Ends
description: The Senate, voting 86-7, today ended a filibuster against an Administration-supported bill to end Federal price controls on natural gas. But the bill's prospects seemed dimmed when parliamentary maneuvering by opponents prompted the Republican leadership to put it aside, probably until Nov. 14, the week Congress plans to adjourn. ''It's much more difficult now than it was before, but it's not impossible,'' said Senator James A. McClure of Idaho, the bill's floor manager.

title: Help for Osborne
description: Lanpar Technologies Inc., the Canadian distributor for the bankrupt Osborne Computer Corporation, said it had made several proposals to aid Osborne but does not want to buy the company. Osborne has identfied Lanpar as one of two concerns that have offered to buy the struggling computer maker, but declined to name the other. Lanpar's chairman, Rene Pardo, said that if a deal was concluded, his company would like to begin manufacturing the Osborne Executive 1 computer and perhaps also produce the long-discussed Executive 2 computer and other models.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1983

title: WORKERS INDICTED IN PATIENT ABUSE
description: Issuing a warning to mental hospitals around the nation, Justice Department officials today obtained indictments against nine present and former aides at a Pennsylvania state institution for the mentally retarded on charges of beating and abusing patients.

title: NEW GOVERNMENT FOR GRENADA DUE EARLY NEXT WEEK
description: The Governor General of Grenada, Sir Paul Scoon, announced today that he would be appointing members of a broad-based nonpolitical interim government early next week.

title: U.S. SAYS STATE LAGS IN ORDERING OF BUTTER AVAILABLE FOR ITS POOR
description: New York State has taken only minimal advantage of a Federal program to distribute surplus butter to the poor, Federal officials said yesterday.

title: GENSTAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
MAN SAVES GRANDCHILD, THEN DIES ON TRACKS
description: A 62-year-old Queens man was crushed to death by a subway train in Manhattan yesterday, moments after he pushed his 3-year-old granddaughter to safety under the overhang of the station platform.

title: FREDERICK T. CHAPMAN
description: Frederick T. Chapman, a book and magazine illustrator, died Saturday at Hilton Head, S.C. He was 96 years old. Mr. Chapman illustrated numerous stories for Woman's Home Companion, Collier's and American magazines and was best known for illustrations of children's books such as ''Joan, Maid of France,'' ''White Falcon'' and ''Luther Burbank, Nature's Helper.''

title: No Headline
description: The U.N. Today Nov. 4, 1983 GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: AQUINO HEARING OPENS IN MANILA
description: The mother of the accused killer of Benigno S. Aquino Jr. wept hysterically today as she identified her son's bullet-riddled body at the end of the first public hearing of a new inquiry commission.

title: A DISABLED SOVIET SUB SURFACES OFF ATLANTIC COAST
description: United States Navy officials reported today that a nuclear-powered Soviet attack submarine had surfaced 470 miles off the South Carolina coast, apparently because of mechanical problems.

title: New Delay Feared At Shoreham
description: Operation of the Long Island Lighting Company's $3.5 billion nuclear generating plant in Shoreham will be delayed until 1986 if repairs cannot be made on three emergency generators, a Lilco official said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Wednesday about cruise lines inaccurately located the headquarters of Cruise Lines International Association. It is based in New York.

title: SECRET U.S. ACTION IN NICARAGUA GETS SENATE APPROVAL
description: The Senate, by voice vote, today approved continued aid for covert operations in Nicaragua.

title: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 4, 1983 International
description: Covert operations in Nicaragua were conditionally backed by the Senate. By voice vote, the Senators approved continued aid for the operations, but only if the Intelligence Committee is informed of the goals and risks of specific covert projects. The action would provide only $19 million of the $50 million sought by the Reagan Administration for covert operations in Central America, mostly in Nicaragua. (Page A1, Column 6.) Salvadoran leftist rebels have taken the initiative in the four-year civil war, killing more than 800 soldiers, capturing 400 and greatly extending the country's contested zone, according to United States military advisers there. They said that since the summer the guerrillas had launched attacks against more than 60 towns and that Government troops often offered little resistance. (A1:3-4.)

title: PRESS VOICES CRITICISM OF 'OFF-THE-RECORD WAR'
description: The Government's decision to restrict news coverage in the first days of the invasion of Grenada has created a highly visible confrontation between the Reagan Administration and the press.

title: THEATER: A REVIVAL OF JEROME KERN'S 1917 'OH, BOY!'
description: ''OH, BOY!,'' the 1917 Jerome Kern musical that's enjoying a sumptuous revival at the Goodspeed Opera House in East Haddam, Conn., is not a major landmark of the American musical theater. But in its time this urbane comedy about amorous mixups among Long Island's horsy set was credited with helping to bring a dash of realism into a musical theater awash with dizzy operettas and vaudevillian extravaganzas.

title: ...AND ONE MAN'S NEW BEIRUT VIEW
description: A little more than a month ago, Representative Samuel S. Stratton, looking as spry in green Army fatigues and combat boots as the military commanders he admires, strode into the Marine base in Beirut for an inspection.

title: NATIONAL LUMBER & SUPPLY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ALBERT J. MEYER
description: Prof. Albert J. Meyer, a faculty member of Harvard University for 28 years, died here of leukemia Monday.

title: POWER CORP OF CANADA LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes special gains of $433,000 for the quarter and $3,788,000 for the 9 months. c-Includes special gains of $4,189,000 for the quarter and $5,648,000 for the 9 months.

title: FILM: ARMS RACE SATIRE
description: ''DEAL OF THE CENTURY,'' which opens today at the RKO Warner and other theaters, fails as a satire, partly because it seems to think that all it has to do to win an audience is to announce its good intentions, and partly because it's terrible. Its heart is in the right place. Its mind is some place else, perhaps at a fat farm.

title: FOUNDED BALL IN CITY TO FETE DEBUTANTES
description: Beatrice Joyce Gilmore, founder of the International Debutante Ball, died at Lenox Hill Hospital Wednesday of complications related to a kidney ailment. She was 72 and lived in Manhattan.

title: BROADWAY
description: NewplaybyKopit, End of the World,' is about arms race.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Hail and Farewell

title: NETS HOLD OFF BULLS, 112-107
description: During his three seasons as coach of the San Antonio Spurs, Stan Albeck was tagged with the nickname ''Stanley Screamer'' for his volatile sideline behavior. Tonight, four games into the season, Albeck's new team, the Nets, finally endured his full wrath as they squandered most of a 27-point second-half lead before defeating the Chicago Bulls, 112-107, at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: No Headline
description: Football Players Arrested in Raid

title: MCDERMOTT INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Comings and Goings
description: Ken Daneyko , a rookie defenseman for the Devils, will be out indefinitely after suffering a cracked right fibula in Wednesday's loss to the Whalers at Hartford. . . . The Baseball Writers Association of America, announcing its manager-of-the-year awards, named Tony LaRussa of the Chicago White Sox as the top manager in the American League and picked Tom Lasorda of the Los Angeles Dodgers for the National League honor. LaRussa, whose club won the American League's Western Division championship, received 17 of 28 votes cast in the American League poll.

title: REDEMPTION RATE JUMPS FOR CHARTER'S ANNUITIES
description: The Charter Company said yesterday that adverse publicity about its annuities had increased the rate at which they are being cashed in - to at least $6 million a day from $1.5 million - and had slowed the sale of new policies.

title: Mrs. Reagan Has Tip For Reporters on Trip
description: Nancy Reagan's press office has laid down the law: reporters covering the First Lady's visit to a Japanese art exhibit in Tokyo must wear clean socks with no holes in them.

title: MARSH SUPERMARKETS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct. 15
CONSOLIDATED NATURAL GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

CREDIT MARKETS;
RATES UP AMID DEBT ANXIETY
description: Continued anxiety over the impact of the Treasury's cancellation of its debt package pushed interest rates higher yesterday.

title: BSN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EXECUTIVES
description: Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta, has elected M. Douglas Ivester senior vice president-finance and Philip J. Carswell vice president and controller.

title: TROVE OF CITY MEMORABILIA GOES ON THE AUCTION BLOCK
description: On the theory that an archivist's jetsam may be an antiquary's gem, New York City sold off some colorful pieces of its past last night.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: New Honor for Walesa

title: AMERICAN INTERNATIONAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted retoractively for a 5-for-4 stock split in April.

title: BENEFICIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $85.9 million for the quarter and $109.7 million for the 9 months.

title: No Headline
description: Transactions

title: BEHIND U.N. VOTE: HOW MUCH ANTI-AMERICANISM? News Analysis
description: Early this week, when the United States failed in its challenge to the credentials of a delegate from Grenada, the General Assembly burst into what seemed a kind of gleeful, derisive, anti-American applause. The incident reminded some delegates of other such outbursts - including dancing in the aisles - that apparently showed general pleasure at American embarrassments, such as the time in 1974 when Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, was allowed to address the Assembly and the vote in 1980 electing Nicaragua to the Security Council.

title: Asbestos Ruling Challenged
description: An asbestos industry group said today that it had filed a suit challenging emergency action by the Labor Department to toughen Federal limits on exposure of workers to cancer-causing asbestos.

title: STOCKS FALL AS TRADING SLOWS
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday in slower trading despite some favorable economic developments. The biggest losers were some of the technology and blue-chip issues.

title: Pacific Island Rulers Apparently Win Vote
description: The Government of Prime Minister Walter Lini has apparently retained power in Vanuatu, but with a reduced majority in the South Pacific nation's first general election since independence three years ago.

title: Digital Equipment
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation's administrative problems, which caused a large drop in the company's fiscal-first-quarter earnings, will take months to correct, Kenneth Olsen, the company's president, told the annual meeting. Mr. Olsen said that he hopes the problems will not affect future results. In its first quarter ended Oct. 1, Digital's net income dropped to $15.9 million, or 28 cents a share, from $56.8 million, or $1.02 a share, last year. At the time the earnings were released, Digital said it had temporary problems caused by changes in the company's administrative system.

title: Ex-New York Officer Enters Guilty Plea in Florida Murder
description: A former New York City police officer pleaded guilty Wednesday to second- degree murder in the shooting of another man over a parking space at a Little League baseball game.

title: AMERICAN CAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss including tax credits of $42.3 million for the quarter and $36.6 million for the 9 months.

title: SUNAIR ELECTRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
EAST GERMAN HELD IN ESPIONAGE CASE
description: An East German physicist was arrested in Boston today on charges of attempting to obtain classified information on military technology from a civilian employee of the United States Navy, the Federal Bureau of Investigation announced.

title: Turkey Expands Plan For Nuclear Power
description: President Kenan Evren said today that his Government had decided to start construction on three nuclear power plants in 1984, instead of one as originally planned.

title: HALAS IS BURIED AND REMEMBERED
description: George Halas, the founder, president, and former player and coach of the Chicago Bears who died at the age of 88 Monday night, was buried at St. Adalbert's Cemetery in nearby Niles today. The ceremony was held in what has come to be known here as Halas weather - a chilly, blustery afternoon suitable for watching the game he helped build into a multimillion-dollar industry.

title: BAYSWATER REALTY & CAPITAL CORP reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: Year-ago results include extraordinary net income of $424,622, or 47 cents a share, relating to the company's repurchase of $2,630,900 in principal amount of debentures.

title: HAUSERMAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a tax credit of $196,000. c-Net loss.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt Issues

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: War or Peace?

title: BRIEFING
description: Overheard on Capitol Hill

title: LIZ CLAIBORNE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NIELSEN, A.C., CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes gain on sale of building of $1,644,000.

title: G.M.'S NEW ANSWER TO JAPAN
description: The General Motors Corporation today displayed the prototype of a small car intended to someday match similar Japanese cars in cost and match or exceed them in quality.

title: PRODUCTION PROBLEMS DELAY TIMES EDITIONS
description: Problems in the production of metal printing plates by stereotypers Wednesday night delayed the publication of Thursday's early editions of The New York Times and reduced the number of copies printed, the newspaper said yesterday.

title: Chileans Reportedly Say Democracy Is Inevitable
description: A Reagan Administration official said today, after meeting leaders of the 10- year-old military Government and their political opponents, that a transition to democracy was ''inevitable.''

title: CHINA IS NOWHERE NEAR THE 'CAPITALIST ROAD'
description: To the Editor: It is amusing that Jude Wanniski, the supply-sider, writes so exuber

title: HORSEBACK RIDING IN WONDERLAND
description: Dirt was spread over the floor of Madison Square Garden for the National Horse Show Wednesday afternoon. And for the competition called Amateur-Owner Working Hunter, Formal Attire, there had been set up a simulated chicken coop, a simulated grass knoll, a simulated fallen tree, and a couple of simulated garden gates with and without simulated shrubbery, among other simulations.

title: COMMONWEALTH SAVINGS & LOAN (FLA.) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MEHTA'S CONTRACT EXTENDED TO 1990
description: The New York Philharmonic announced yesterday that Zubin Mehta's contract as music director has been extended for four years past the expiration of his current contract, binding him to the orchestra through the 1989-90 season.

title: UNIVERSAL TELEPHONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Article 018345 -- No Title
description: Who is the second-best 2-year-old in the country? That is the question likely to be answered by the Young America Stakes tomorrow night at the Meadowlands, where 16 colts and geldings will be chasing a $400,000 purse.

title: U.S. LABOR MEDIATOR TAUGHT LAW
description: Nathan P. Feinsinger, emeritus professor of law at the University of Wisconsin who was a leading labor mediator for a quarter of a century, died Wednesday at the Glen Valley Nursing Home in Glenwood Springs, Colo., where he had lived since suffering a stroke 18 months ago. He was 81 years old.

title: LYSIAK WINS DELAY OF 20-GAME BAN
description: Tom Lysiak, a center for the Chicago Black Hawks, was granted a 10-day temporary restraining order today that allowed him to resume playing hockey despite a 20-game suspension levied against him by a National Hockey League referee last Monday.

title: CARTER-WALLACE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest periods include income of about $950,000, or 12 cents a share, from the net settlements of two lawsuits.

title: ALOHA AIRLINES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including gains of $3.4 million for the quarter and $6.6 million from the sale of tax credits and a gain of $1.3 million for the 9 months from foreign currency translations.

title: SALVADOR REBELS MAKE GAINS AND U.S. ADVISERS ARE GLUM
description: Leftist insurgents have taken the initiative in the four-year-old civil war, killing more than 800 Salvadoran soldiers in the last two months, capturing 400 and greatly extending the country's contested zone, according to United States military advisers here.

title: Profit for American Can
description: The American Can Company reported yesterday that it had net income in the third quarter of $31.6 million, or $1.20 a share, compared with a loss the year before of $159.5 million. The 1982 loss was due almost entirely to an after-tax provision for restructuring and divestitures.

title: MOORE PRODUCTS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Condec Faces Proxy Fight
description: The Condec Corporation said a group of dissident shareholders had proposed a slate of directors in opposition to management nominees.

title: Dome Meeting Set
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. said it had called a meeting with its Canadian and international bankers for Dec. 1, at which a plan for rescheduling Dome's debt will be presented. The company owes about $6.3 billion (Canadian) to 50 financial institutions. Dome also said John P. Gallagher, former chief exeuctive, had retired from the board of directors, ending 33 years with the company.

title: ISRAELI QUARTERS IN LEBANON HIT BY 'HUGE' BLAST
description: The Israeli Army announced today that ''a huge explosion'' had occurred at dawn at two buildings used by Israeli security forces in the Lebanese coastal city of Tyre.

title: SOUTH AFRICA WHITES APPROVE A LIMITED SHARING OF POWER
description: The South African Prime Minister, P. W. Botha, has won a mandate from the country's all-white electorate to go ahead with a program of limited and ambiguous political liberalization. The program will offer brown minorities - but not the black majority - a voice in national life alongside whites for the first time in almost 30 years.

title: MARITIME TELEGRAPH & TELEPHONE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A TALENT FOR TAKING CHARGE: DONALD HAROLD RUMSFELD
description: Somewhere in his bulging files, Donald H. Rumsfeld keeps a list of anecdotes, aphorisms and personal laws under the heading ''Rumsfeld's Rules.'' They represent some of the collected wisdom of his 15 years in Government as a Congressman, White House official and Defense Secretary and of his last six years as a highly-paid business executive.

title: SCREEN: 'TESTAMENT,' AFTER A NUCLEAR BLAST
description: THE strategy of Lynne Littman's disturbing ''Testament'' is to depict the most enormous of disasters - a nuclear holocaust - in terms that are comparatively banal. In her effort to drive home the human cost of such a calamity, Miss Littman concentrates on the most ordinary details of life in a California town. For the Wetherly family, around whom the film revolves, the quintessentially humdrum day before the catastrophe is full of errands and squabbles and dirty laundry. Yet the very drabness of this day takes on poignancy when seen in the light of what follows.

title: THEORY ON DINOSAURS' DEATH SUPPORTED BY NEW EVIDENCE
description: New evidence has been found supporting the view that 65 million years ago the earth was struck by an asteroid whose explosive disintegration spread debris over much, if not all, of the planet. Such an event has been blamed for mass extinctions that occurred about that time, including the demise of the dinosaurs.

title: NATIONAL MEDICAL CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bayswater Settles Case With S.E.C.
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission said charges were settled against the Bayswater Realty and Capital Corporation, a company headed by Carl Icahn, involving unsuccessful attempts to gain control of the Simplicity Pattern Company and Marshall Field & Company.

title: TECHNICAL TAPE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $486,000 from discontinued operatons.

title: PEKING FINDS A NEW ENEMY: 'SPIRITUAL POLLUTION'
description: China has begun a major campaign against what it disparagingly calls ''spiritual pollution'' - the influx of unwelcome Western trends and liberal values that have been attributed to China's open-door policy toward the West.

title: Addenda
description: * Family Weekly magazine increasing its circulation rate base 1.6 percent, to 12.8 million, from 12.6 million, and its advertising rates 8.3 percent, starting Jan. 1.

title: GULF WAR FIGHTING SAID TO FLARE
description: Heavy fighting was reported today on the northern front of the Iran-Iraq war, with Iran saying it had captured more territory but with Iraq saying its forces had repulsed a new attack.

title: ASAMERA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-1 stock split in August 1983. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect adoption of full cost method of accounting for explorations and development costs mainly related to Indonesia operaions.

title: Another Hearing On Brutality Set
description: A congressional committee has scheduled another hearing into allegations of racially motivated police brutality for Nov. 14 in the United States Courthouse in Brooklyn. Mayor Koch and police representatives have been invited, and the Mayor said last night that it was ''open'' on whether he would attend.

title: CAPITOL HILL OUTCRY SOFTENS AS PUBLIC'S SUPPORT SWELLS
description: A week after the invasion of Grenada, most members of Congress have either sided with President Reagan or muted their criticism, according to Democrats and Republicans here.

title: Mexico's Loan Needs
description: A senior official of Citibank said yesterday that Mexico would ask commercial banks for a new $3.5 billion medium-term loan in December or January.

title: Views Vary on N.B.A. Fill-Ins
description: He spent 29 years in professional basketball as a referee and a supervisor of officials, so Norm Drucker is more than a casual observer. On Wednesday night, he was at his Long Island home watching the telecast of the Knicks' game against the Seattle SuperSonics. Unlike most fans, Drucker was watching the referees more closely than he was the players.

title: GASTINEAU RECALLS YEAR WITH KUSH
description: Mark Gastineau admits he used to think his career might have been better if he had not left Arizona State after playing for only one year under Coach Frank Kush.

title: POLAND CALLS SANCTION MOVE INADEQUATE
description: The Polish Government denounced as inadequate today the United States' announcement on Wednesday of ''two limited steps'' toward easing economic sanctions imposed after the 1981 declaration of martial law.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: American flavor, past and present.

title: Spain Institutes Moves To Combat Terrorism
description: Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez announced today that he was instituting a series of measures to combat terrorism in the Basque region, including longer prison sentences for people convicted of terrorist crimes.

title: 'PHILANTHROPIST' STAR, RETURN OF A NATIVE
description: -Raphaelite face surrounded by masses of pale, wispy ringlets. But despite her wide eyes and angelic countenance, Celia's style is acid.

title: U.S. ADMIRAL DEFENDS DUAL COMMAND
description: Adm. Wesley L. McDonald, who commands all United States military forces in the Atlantic region, said today that having two separate commanders for ground forces in the invasion of Grenada was ''not unique.''

title: No Headline
description: Protest Lodged On 12th Tackler

title: Learjet Callback
description: The lack of orders for civilian aircraft has prompted the Gates Learjet Corporation to reduce its planned recall laid-off workers at its Wichita plant. The company had announced in September that it would recall 1,100 workers by the end of the year to build 80 business jets to be leased to the Air Force under a $175.4 million contract. But Jim Greenwood, senior vice president for communications, said the recall would involve only 550 workers and that it would be completed by March 31 instead of by the end of the year.

title: HOUSE 219-199, VOTES TO REQUIRE U.S. MADE PARTS IN IMPORTED CARS
description: In an expression of concern over extensive imports of Japanese cars, the House of Representatives approved a bill today that would require imported cars to be built with a substantial component of American parts and labor.

title: ARAFAT SAYS SYRIA AND LIBYA HAVE JOINED TRIPOLI BATTLE
description: Heavy artillery and rocket fire broke out shortly after dawn today in the outskirts of Tripoli, and Yasir Arafat said dissident Palestinians backed by Syrian and Libyan forces had begun an attack on his guerrillas based there.

title: SUPERIOR FOODS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 26
2 Children Killed In Queens Fire
description: Children playing with a cigarette lighter started a fire yesterday that swept through a Queens home, killing a 5-year-old boy and his 3-month-old sister, the Fire Department said.

title: U.S. CONCERNED AT FATE OF ISRAEL-LEBANON PACT
description: The Reagan Administration expressed concern today that the Lebanese leaders meeting in Geneva not take any action that might jeopardize the Israeli-Lebanese security agreement on the terms for Israel's withdrawal from Lebanon.

title: RECITAL: ROBERT TAUB, PIANIST
description: ROBERT TAUB is an unusual young pianist, possessing a technique that makes the knottiest of passages crystalline, accompanied by a musical intelligence that is both serious and gracious. That was the impression at Alice Tully Hall Tuesday night, when this young pianist, who has studied with Jacob Lateiner at Juilliard, was presented as the winner of the Peabody Mason Award of Boston.

title: A Lawyer Is Elected to Lead Foreign Policy Association
description: Archie E. Albright Jr., a lawyer and investment banker, was elected yesterday as president and chief executive officer of the Foreign Policy Association.

title: CORPORATION'S BID TO BUY HOSPITAL IN BOSTON IS BLOCKED BY THE STAFF
description: The Harvard Medical School has rejected a proposal by the Hospital Corporation of America to buy the nonprofit McLean psychiatric hospital, which is associated with it, the school announced today. It took the stand because McLean's staff is overwhelmingly opposed to the move.

title: THE VIEW FROM A CAPITAL COLORED BY GRENADA...
description: Some say the war ended for all intents and purposes the night the American medical students were shown on television, stepping off the plane from Grenada and stooping to kiss United States soil.

title: THEATER: BRENDAN BEHAN'S 'HOSTAGE'
description: ''The Hostage'' was a collaboration between an intuitive dramatist, Brendan Behan, and an inspired director, Joan Littlewood. In England and on Broadway, it was as much a public event as a work of theater, and, through the concerted efforts of the playwright, it also became a public spectacle. I remember seeing the play soon after its Broadway opening on one of the evenings that the author interrupted the action and became an uninvited member of his own cast. His appearance on stage was both an enrichment and an intrusion. With Behan in the play, ''The Hostage'' was almost dangerously alive.

title: CORRECTION
description: A news analysis article Oct. 17 on troubles in the airline industry incorrectly reported the flight experience of pilots at two lines. Those at Continental average about 9,000 hours, those at Muse Air about half that.

title: Red Sox Talks Set
description: The squabble among the three general partners of the Boston Red Sox may be moving toward a resolution. Jean Yawkey and Haywood Sullivan , who have been allied against the third general partner, Buddy LeRoux , and the club's limited partners, have agreed to begin negotiations with the LeRoux group in an effort to buy out its 40 percent minority interest. The talks are scheduled to begin in two to three weeks, according to Sullivan, who declined to comment on a report in The Boston Globe that he and Mrs. Yawkey would offer $14 million and that the LeRoux group would be demanding $20 million.

EXHIBITION RECALLS NEW YORK'S SILENT FILM ERA
description: When a movie studio was transformed into an elaborate London locale for John Barrymore's ''Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde'' in 1920, the studio wasn't in Hollywood - it was at 130 West 56th Street. When W. C. Fields made his film debut in ''Pool Sharks'' in 1915, the movie wasn't shot in Hollywood - it was made at a studio in Flushing, Queens.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES Salomon Warrants On Deutsche Mark
description: Salomon Brothers International offered a new series of one-year warrants to buy and sell Deutsche marks.
