description: The collapse of a 60-ton suspended ceiling at a PATH station in Jersey City last summer was caused by contractors' ignoring design specifications and making an improper installation, according to an interim report released yesterday.

title: BRIDGEPORT: A 'CACTUS' HOPING TO BLOSSOM
description: To the south lies Stamford, where the sound of construction is seldom absent. To the north lies Hartford, home of state politics and insurance companies.

title: No Headline
description: The sidewalks of New York have been a recital hall for street musicians since before sidewalks. In a city where even hawkers of sweet potatoes and corn had their own ''singing commercials,'' street music crested with succeeding waves of immigration and poverty.

title: AUCTIONS

Included are works from the collections of three dealers, Ben Heller, the late Robert Elkon and the late Betty Parsons and several major collectors.

title: YANKEES RETAIN NETTLES
description: Graig Nettles, who has been a Yankee longer than any other member of the current team, will continue to be a Yankee. Just as last night's midnight deadline passed for signing free agents before Monday's draft, the Yankees announced that Nettles had agreed to a new contract.

title: BRINGING GRENADA DEMOCRACY
description: Grenada was one invasion we can justify. But it was also the culmination of a three- year policy of confrontation that helped undermine the stability and the civility of the Government whose people we now rescue. And it may be the prelude to a difficult - not a speedy - transition to democracy.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Trail Blazers , at Portland, Ore. The Knicks have not won at Portland in three years, since Nov. 29, 1980. Ray Williams was the top scorer that night, and now, after his travels to Kansas City and New Jersey, he returns in a New York uniform. (Television - Channel 9, 10:30 P.M.)

title: Market PlaceMichael Quint Bond Ratings And Tax Cuts
description: WHEN voters in California and Massachusetts approved propositions to reduce real estate taxes in 1978 and again in 1980, their action was hailed as a sign of the American public's discontent with high taxes - a sentiment that helped carry Ronald Reagan to the White House.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''JOHNNY was a genius,'' Faith Hubley says, ''so part of what I want to do at Yale is make sure that anybody who's interested in what he did can come there and find out about it.'' Mrs. Hubley is talking of her husband, who died in 1977. A retrospective of animated films made by the Hubleys - they worked together for more than 20 years - will be presented in New Haven next Thursday to Saturday, Nov. 12, and eventually the Hubley Studio Archive at Yale will house not only movies but also John Hubley's papers, notebooks and art from as long ago as the 1930's.

title: GRENADA ISN'T LEBANON
description: It was startling in the tense Middle East, where I spent last month, to hear the voice of President Reagan on the radio saying the situations in Lebanon and Grenada were ''closely related.''

title: COUNTRY TOWN HOUSES IN WESTCHESTER
description: In the view of Robert A. Schulman, a developer of office space, there is a market in Westchester County for expensive town houses among well-to-do people who no longer want the burden of a large suburban house but still want to enjoy a country-like setting.

description: President Reagan said today that he had conducted a rescue mission, not an invasion of Grenada, and that no comparision was possible with the warfare being waged in Afghanistan by the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. COMPOSERS FEATURED
description: Near death last spring, the American Composers Orchestra seems to have made a dramatic recovery. Sunday and Monday evenings, New York will have the chance to help celebrate this unusual group's return to health. There will be two programs of music by seven American composers at Lincoln Center - Sunday at 8 P.M. in Avery Fisher Hall and the next evening at Alice Tully Hall next door.

No Headline
description: Baby Jane's Big Brothers ''He's not going to get better'' is the gentle phrase people often use to describe someone who's hopelessly ill. It applies, tragically, to Baby Jane Doe, a deformed baby born on Long Island last month. Spina bifida is only one of her handicaps. Even if she underwent an operation to correct that and gained perhaps 20 years of life, what a life it would be: severely retarded and bedridden. Her parents, after considerable medical consultation, decided against the operation. Baby Jane, everyone agreed, is not going to get better.

title: Haynes Obtains Writ
description: Mike Haynes , the holdout New England Patriot cornerback, won a temporary Federal restraining order allowing him to practice with the Los Angeles Raiders pending a further hearing on his suit against the National Football League. Haynes is challenging an N.F.L. ruling that blocked his trade to Los Angeles on the ground that it wasn't completed until a few minutes after the league's 4 P.M. trading deadline on Oct. 11. Under the order signed by a district court judge in Los Angeles, Haynes is barred from appearing in any games for at least two weeks.

title: 213 ARE INMATES FREED SO FAR IN CITY'S JAIL RELEASE PLAN
description: More than 200 prisoners have been freed from overcrowded city jails since an inmate release began earlier this week and others were to be sent home today, city officials said yesterday.

title: 'PRINCESS DAISY' BEGINS
description: ''PRINCESS DAISY'' is like a vast, meticulously arranged mound of cotton candy. It looks gorgeous, at least from a distance, and is deliciously insubstantial. The adaptation of Judith Krantz's novel (the television title is ''Judith Krantz's 'Princess Daisy' '') was written with no doubt painful fidelity by Diana Hammond. The four-hour production will appear on Channel 4 in two parts, from 9 to 11 P.M., Sunday and Monday.

title: I.M.F. Funds Still Snagged
description: Fernand J. St Germain, chairman of the House Banking Committee, said today that he and Jake Garn, Senate Banking Committee chairman, were ''ready to move quickly'' on a bill to increase the American contribution to the International Monetary Fund and that ''the hangup - I am sorry to report - - is the Administration.''

title: CORMAN EXPLORES HIS BRONX
description: ''I passed by here once around Halloween and noticed the same jack-o'- lanterns pasted to the school windows,'' Avery Corman, the author of ''Kramer vs. Kramer,'' said the other day. ''It looked as if they'd never taken mine down.'' The school was Public School 33, which Mr. Corman attended. And ''here'' was the West Bronx, where he grew up in the 1940's and 50's.

title: MANY SEEKING LINE'S JOBS
description: Greyhound bus passengers turned to railroads, airlines and other bus lines yesterday as a nationwide strike of drivers and terminal employees forced the company to shut down operations.

title: CELEBRATING MILES DAVIS AT MUSIC HALL
description: -age trumpeter when he showed up in New York in 1945. A month later, he was a Juilliard dropout. But within the next year, jazz listeners had started to pay attention to the trumpeter from East St. Louis, Ill., who was already making his own way through the modern-jazz language.

title: Advertising; Y.& R.'s Focus on Cable TV

That meant expanding the New Electronic Media group and bringing Timothy V. Conner from Burson-Marsteller, Y.& R.'s public relations company, to run it.

title: Small Plutonium Leak Contaminates Technician

BALLET: JOFFREY PREMIERE
description: AND so William Forsythe has produced another nasty spectacular, this time a world premiere for the Joffrey Ballet. Fast and furious and certainly not a ballet in any conventional sense, ''Square Deal'' left its black- tie audience at the City Center Wednesday night barely able to register a reaction.

title: No Headline
description: Civil Rights: The Movement Moves In barely 24 hours, America has witnessed a pivotal transition. On Wednesday President Reagan signed the law establishing a Federal holiday in honor of Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., thus fixing the highest seal of public approval on the long first- stage struggle, the achievement of civil rights. Yesterday brought a welcome milestone in the second stage, the exercise of those rights.

title: EXILES IN MIAMI PORTRAY CUBAN PLOT ON GRENADA
description: The United States invasion of Grenada may have prevented Cubans from trying to force out the military regime of Gen. Hudson Austin, which a few days earlier jailed and later killed Prime Minister Maurice Bishop, according to Cuban exiles here.

No Headline
description: Windjammer of Yore On a New York Visit Crew members pulled in a foresail while Julia Brotherton manned helm and Capt. Dan Morland kept watch yesterday as the schooner Ernestina glided into the harbor and past the Manhattan skyline. The 103-foot-long ship, built in 1894 and berthed in New Bedford, Mass., is undergoing restoration. She will be on display at the South Street Seaport until tomorrow, when she sails for Rye, N.Y.

title: CONCERT: STEPHANIE CHASE
description: AT her Tuesday afternoon concert at the Abraham Goodman House, the violinist Stephanie Chase showed once again that at the age of 24 she is already a first-rate artist. Whether in the virtuosic fireworks of Eugene Ysaye's Sonata for Violin Solo ''Ballade,'' (Op. 27, No. 3), the temperate romanticism of the Sonato No. 3 in D Minor (Op. 108) by Johannes Brahms, the eclectic modernism of Leos Janacek's Sonata No. 3 (1921) or the magnificent Baroque structures of J. S. Bach's Sonata in G minor, Miss Chase played with taste, accuracy and unfailing musicality.

title: CITY REPORTS ACCORD WITH DEVELOPER FOR EAST RIVER COMPLEX
description: A new agreement to build a huge housing and commercial project along the East River in Manhattan was reported by the city yesterday.

title: 36 Die in India Train Blast
description: Two railroad tank cars loaded with gasoline exploded today at a station in Dhulwari, in northeast India, killing 36 people and injuring more than 100, the United News of India reported.

title: Jersey Drivers Get Inspection Option
description: Starting Nov. 14, New Jersey motorists will have the option of having their cars inspected for safety defects and air- pollution violations by either state examiners or certified, private garage mechanics, officials said today.

title: No Headline
description: Radio Grand Forks GRAND FORKS, N.D., Nov. 3 (AP) - Radio Grand Forks Associates said it had sold radio stations KNOX-AM and KYTN-FM for $3 million to Red River Associates, a group of businessmen in Ithaca, N.Y. Radio Grand Forks Associates, based in Peoria, Ill., is owned by The Peoria Journal Star newspaper. The transfer is subject to regulatory approval.

title: PUBLISHING: NEW LIFE FOR AMERICAN BOOK AWARDS
description: THE American Book Awards, which came close to expiring from lack of support by the publishing industry several months ago, received a new lease on life yesterday from the board of directors of the Association of American Publishers. But the awards ceremony in November 1984 will be far different in size and scope from those of the last few years.

title: LIBERTY HOMES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: Nina Starr Photos

title: SCOUTING
description: Doubts on Replay

title: BACKUP PASSERS MOSTLY ON TARGET
description: The thought of an injury to Joe Theismann frightens Bobby Beathard.

title: COLLECTOR'S ITEMS: DUSTY, USELESS KITCHEN GADGETS
description: Every fall, when the postman arrives with another shipment of mail- order catalogues, I have to remind myself of the second kitchen I have been outfitting in my attic almost from the day I set up housekeeping. But the kitchen equipment so artfully displayed with mouth-watering food on the catalogues' full-color pages beckons me to fill in the order blank so that I too can have an ice-cream machine, a pasta machine, an espresso machine, a utensil with which to flute mushrooms and another to make lemon zest.

title: N.A.S.L. LOSES ANOTHER CLUB
description: The North American Soccer League was dealt another severe setback yesterday when Molson Breweries, the owner of the Montreal Manic, announced that the team had folded because of a lack of fan support and millions of dollars in losses.

title: JET RUN TRIUMPHS IN WORLD CUP CLASS
description: Jet Run is an old campaigner, as horses go. And his rider, Michael Matz, is campaigning hard for the veteran jumper to get one of the very few prizes Jet Run has not already won: a berth on the United States Olympic team.

title: DENTAL WORLD CENTER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
CAN PRIVACY AND COMPUTER COEXIST?
description: Should a Federal agency have the right to search an employee's personal material filed in a Government computer?

title: MEDICARE ADVISORY UNIT SEEKING MAJOR CHANGES
description: A Federal advisory committee voted today to recommend major changes in Medicare, including raising the age of eligibility to 67 and increasing the premiums paid by beneficiaries. The changes are part of a comprehensive package intended to avert the bankruptcy of the Government's health-care program for the elderly.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ID DAY There is a whole terminal moraine of vacations long gone, a moraine in the shape of rocks and shells and whoknows what now moldering in drawers and on table tops. These are items that were collected by people on vacation because they appealed to the eye or served as a souvenir. If you want to know what these natural history items mean in the natural order of things, the place to go today, from 2 to 5:30 P.M., is the American Museum of Natural History, 81st Street and Central Park West.

title: LEBANESE TALKS ADJOURN FOR 10 DAYS
description: The Lebanese peace conference was recessed today to give President Amin Gemayel 10 days to explore alternatives to the Israel-Lebanon withdrawal accord.

title: NAVCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Operating loss. c-Net loss.

title: Canuck Suspended
description: Dave (Tiger) Williams , a Vancouver Canuck right wing, was given an eight-day suspension after National Hockey League officials found him guilty of ''an unacceptable and potentially dangerous'' attack on Paul Baxter of the Calgary Flames in a game Oct. 30. Brian O'Neill , the league's executive vice president, said it was evident that Williams ''made no effort to restrain himself and had to be removed by other players and officials from Baxter, who was completely defenseless at the time.''

title: ISRAELI WARPLANES STRIKE AT PALESTINIAN TARGETS
description: Israeli warplanes attacked Palestinian positions in the hills east of Beirut today hours after a truck bomb attack on an Israeli compound in Tyre. Some reports said the planes also attacked Syrian positions.

title: BRIEFING
description: Fraternally Yours

title: Sister Sues California For Misplacing Brother
description: A deaf man who has spent his entire life in mental institutions is the focus of a lawsuit his sister has filed against state and Orange County officials. The sister, Lupe Caudillo, contends their misplacement of him in mental institutions denied him proper care.

title: SEAWAY FOOD TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
CETUS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: SRI CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
No Headline
description: Changing Apartheid's Color South Africa's Government has correctly gauged the mood of its white constituency. Whites have voted, 2 to 1, for a Constitution that gives the appearance of reform by creating separate chambers of Parliament for 800,000 Asians and 2.5 million people of mixed blood. With unseemly haste the State Department acclaims this as a step away from apartheid, foreshadowing political rights for South Africa's 22 million blacks.

title: CITY COUNCIL EQUITY
description: The New York City Charter Revision Commission, appointed last year, has developed three proposals for submission to the voters on Election Day. All are designed to improve city government. One - repeal of the provision for City Council members at large - has been widely commented on. A second - elimination of the minimum population requirement for community districts - is universally supported.

title: ARUNDEL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $372,000 for the quarter and $747,000 for the 9 months. c-After a loss of $89,000 for the quarter and income of $390,000 for the 9 months from discontinued operations and extraordinary gains of $392,000 for the quarter and $842,000 for the 9 months.

title: 2 Are Found Dead InParkLaneHotel
description: A couple from Ontario were found dead Thursday night in their room at the Park Lane Hotel, 36 Central Park South, after spending Wednesday night partying at a Manhattan discoth eque and an after-hours club, according to the police.

title: Trade Deficit Seen Growing
description: Commerce Secretary Malcolm Baldrige predicted today that the United States current account deficit would reach $35 billion this year, instead of the $30 million he had estimated in August. The deficit last year came to $11.2 billion.

title: Navy Task Force Holds Exercises Off Virginia
description: The Navy said today that a nine-ship task force, bound for the Caribbean, was conducting training exercises off the Virginia coast and was likely to reach its destination by early next week.

title: BRITISH COLUMBIA FOREST PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: VOLUME OFF
description: Stock prices fell broadly again yesterday in slower trading as investors showed their growing nervousness over the course of interest rates. After dropping 10.17 points on Thursday, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.84 points more yesterday, to 1,218.29.

title: DIMIS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Police in Boston Hunt For 'Phantom Voters'
description: City police were knocking on doors today trying to find hundreds of phantom voters, or people who registered illegally by giving addresses of vacant lots, boarded- up buildings and loading docks.

title: Iran Marks 4th Anniversary Of Seizure of U.S. Embassy
description: Iranian newspapers published special supplements today to mark the fourth anniversary of the seizure of the United States Embassy in Teheran by Islamic militants.

title: SOVIET EXPELS U.S. PROFESSOR WHO TALKED WITH DISSIDENTS
description: An American mathematician who had been in Moscow on a scientific exchange program has been expelled, apparently for meeting with dissident Jewish scientists.

title: No Headline
description: WBAI Harmonica Concert

title: No Headline
description: Once-Tainted Clam Bed Reopens in New Jersey Commercial clam boats crowding water near shoreline in Barnegat, N.J., where tongs were used to harvest clams.

description: b-Net income.

title: TV: 'SPECIAL' PROGRAMS ON CABLE CHANNELS
description: As cable television frantically searches for the ''packaging'' that will bring it a profitable future, viewers are left with a sometimes bewildering array of programming. Forget the movies, new and old, that have always been a staple of the television schedule. Just look, for the moment, at some of the ''special'' material that is available in the current week. Depending on which cable system and which pay-television channels are available to you, the ''menu,'' a favorite word in cable circles these days, can include everything from Bette Midler to Bernini, from Pat Benatar to, shades of network programming of old, Dean Martin.

title: DEFENSE DEPT. SAYS SOVIET SUB MAY HAVE HIT A U.S. SONAR DEVICE
description: Defense Department officials said today that a disabled Soviet submarine floating nearly 500 miles off the South Carolina coast may have been forced to the surface by a collision with a sonar device towed by a United States destroyer.

title: Peeters to Miss a Week
description: Pete Peeters , the Boston Bruin goalie who was knocked unconscious in a game against the St. Louis Blues Thursday night, suffered a concussion and will be out of action for a week to 10 days, the club said yesterday. ''He took a pretty good whack on the head,'' said a spokesman for Massachusetts General Hospital, where Peters was taken for treatment after he was knocked against his goal's crossbar in the third period of the Bruins' 9-5 victory.

title: Gold Cup Stolen From Navy
description: A solid gold loving cup worth $300,000 that was given to Adm.

title: NEWBERY ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TOXIC WASTE RULES STIFFENED IN HOUSE
description: The House of Representatives ended a stalemate over environmental legislation Thursday night by voting to strengthen the law regulating the handling, shipping and disposal of hazardous wastes.

title: Ford Car Imports
description: The Ford Motor Company plans to import 20,000 to 30,000 of its European-made Sierra model cars into the United States each year, starting in the fall of 1984, a Ford official said. Robert Lutz, executive vice president-overseas automotive operations of Ford, said that Kharmann G.m.b.h. of West Germany would complete assembly of the units before shipment to the United States.

title: A RENEWAL AT HAMMACHER
description: Hammacher Schlemmer, Manhattan's renowned purveyor of bizarre gadgetry and elegant gifts, has enticed maharajahs and kings, business executives and browsers for generations. But for the past decade or so, sales have been so flat that last year the company decided to close six of its seven retail floors and sell only from the main floor of its store at 147 East 57th Street.

title: MATRIX SCIENCE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CONTINENTAL ILLINOIS IS CITED ON TAXES
description: The Internal Revenue Service is seeking $58.5 million in back taxes from the Continental Illinois Corporation, the nation's seventh-largest banking organization, according to documents on file with the United States Tax Court.

description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $326,000 for costs associated with the separation of Biltrite Corp. from American Biltrite Inc.

title: BEVERLY HILLS SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results for the quarter and 9 months relfect a pretax gain of $13.4 million from the sale of branch offices and year-ago 9 months results reflect a pretax gain of $8.8 million from the sale of the associations's loan servicing portfolio. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in August.

title: TELL INDIA NO ON ATOMS
description: This month, the Senate will consider legislation prohibiting the Nuclear Regulatory Commission from approving the export of sensitive nuclear materials to countries that do not have nuclear weapons and that have refused to open their nuclear facilities to international inspection. This legislation would directly affect the question of whether the United States should accede to India's urgent request for spare parts for two American-built nuclear power reactors at the Tarapur Atomic Power Station, near Bombay.

title: Henderson Charged
description: Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson , the former Dallas Cowboys linebacker, was arrested in Long Beach, Calif., after two teen-age girls told the police he had lured them to his apartment, held them at gunpoint for three hours, beat both of them and forced one of them to commit a sex act. Lieut. Jim Reed of the Long Beach Police Department said Henderson, who is 30 years old, was taken into custody at his apartment early Thursday morning.

title: MOORE CORP LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'WE'LL HIT BACK,' ISRAEL'S DEFENSE MINISTER VOWS
description: Israel reacted to the bombing of its headquarters in Tyre, Lebanon, today with a series of military steps and statements designed to regain a posture of determination and resolve.

title: GREYHOUND IS HOPING TO RESUME SERVICE IN WEEKS
description: Greyhound officials said yesterday that they expected many of their striking employees to return to their jobs by mid- or late November, when the bus line hopes to resume operations. But Greyhound officials in major cities around the country continued to receive and process job applications from thousands of people who the company says could serve as replacements for strikers who do not return.

title: Judge Frees Reveling Jogger
description: A judge released a man who was arrested as he jogged home from a bachelor party, agreeing that it was better to run than to take a chance on drunken driving. Joseph Mueller was arrested Sept. 16 on a charge of being ''under the influence of alcohol and a roadway hazard'' but explained he had been jogging home to avoid driving with friends who had been drinking. Judge Clayton Shea said, ''I'd certainly rather have him jogging home than driving home.''

title: WEST BANK IS UNEASY OVER LE CARRE FILMING
description: Deep in a wadi, surrounded by the bare beige mountains above Jericho, an American film company has recreated a Palestine Liberation Organization training camp, a strange sight in an area populated by goats, Bedouins and Israeli soldiers.

title: IBH ASKS PROTECTION FROM CREDITORS
description: IBH Holding A.G., the world's third-argest construction machine group, said today that it had sought bankruptcy protection, as the impact of irregularities at a prestigious private bank widened.

title: No Headline

title: New Aerial Spraying Set To Combat Fruit Flies
description: For the second time in 14 months, an airborne war is being waged against an infestation of fruit flies that could wreck Los Angeles County's $2.5 billion fresh fruit industry.

title: JETS STRIKE PALESTINIAN SITES
description: A truck loaded with explosives crashed through the entrance to an Israeli headquarters compound here today and detonated near the main building, killing at least 39 people and wounding 32.

title: JAIL RELEASE: WHY?
description: More than 300 prisoners, accused of everything from jostling to robbery, walked out of New York City jails this week after paying only 10 percent of their bail, freed by a Federal District Court order to cut jail crowding. Only a last-minute change yesterday in the order prevented the release of five men accused of murder, attempted murder or rape.

title: U.S. MAKES PUBLIC ARMS PACTS IT SAYS GRENADIANS MADE
description: The Reagan Administration made public today copies of what it said were five secret military cooperation agreements concluded by the former Government of Grenada with Cuba, the Soviet Union and North Korea.

title: THE REGION ;  Acquittal in Case At Nursing Home
description: A leader of the state's nursing- home industry was acquitted yesterday of charges that he had conspired to blow up a union trailer during a 1980 strike at a Brooklyn nursing home. The trailer, being used as a strike headquarters, was never bombed.

title: JAILED POLE COMPLAINS OF FORGERY
description: An imprisoned Polish dissident contends that the Polish Government is using a forged document outlining an American plan to destabilize the political situation in Poland as evidence against him.

title: HUNDREDS OF JOBLESS LINE UP AT GREYHOUND
description: At the door of the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown yesterday, angry Greyhound workers walked a picket line. Downstairs, at the darkened departure gates, where signs still read New Orleans, Norfolk, Charleston, Los Angeles and other points far and near, there was another kind of line - one for the hundreds of people wanting jobs as baggage handlers, ticket agents, janitors and clerks.

description: Alfred Zehe, an East German scientist accused of espionage, was held without bail today after a prosecutor told Robert B. Collings, a United States Magistrate, that Mr. Zehe would try to flee if released.

description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation announced today the arrest of a Tarrytown physician, Dr. Kailash Pani, on charges of Medicare fraud.

CUT IN CITY WATER FORESEEN
description: Water fell to the drought-warning level yesterday in New York City's Delaware River reservoir system. Authorities said the city's water supply would be cut by 120 million gallons a day starting next Wednesday unless enough rain falls to raise the reservoir levels.

description: The Federal Reserve reported yesterday that the basic measure of the money supply rose by $900 million, to $518.3 billion, in the week ended Oct. 26.

title: FOR SPRING, A WIDE CHOICE
description: In none of the world's fashion centers are the offerings as varied as those in New York. A single day's showings will include play clothes and casual sportswear as well as couture-caliber collections approaching in both price and quality the standards of French made-to-order styles. The differences in taste levels and ways of life in this country partially account for the multitude of choices.

title: REAGAN ASKS VOTE FOR RIGHTS PANEL
description: President Reagan urged the Senate today to approve a House-passed bill extending the life of the United States Civil Rights Commission instead of a rival proposal that would make the panel an creature of Congress.

description: Last Shot at the Deficit It's minutes to midnight for the Federal deficit. If nothing is done in the few weeks before Congress adjourns, megadeficits will burden the economy through 1985, probably longer. President Reagan's failure to address the crisis has been appalling. Senator Dole's last-minute effort is heroic.

title: MARINES' SECURITY POSES HARD QUESTIONS
description: As investigations of the Oct. 23 bombing at Marine headquarters in Beirut get under way, members of Congress, military officials and urban-terrorism experts say investigators are likely to address several troubling questions about the marines' security precautions.

title: MOMENT OF SILENCE: PART OF DAILY SCHOOL ROUTINE

description: Billie Jean King said today that women would not be able to reach their full potential in sports until they began to compete against men.

title: POP-FUNK: KOOL AND GANG
description: Kool and the Gang, the 10-man pop- funk aggregation, is one of only a handful of bands whose music establishes solid connections between styles as dissimilar as synthesizer- oriented funk, big-band jazz and 1950's rock-and-roll. Appearing in Radio City Music Hall Wednesday through last night, the ensemble illustrated the interconnectedness of these idioms in a show that had theatrical flash to match its musical coordination.

title: Five Paintings Stolen
description: Three men posing as plumbers forced their way into an art museum in Rosario while it was closed Wednesday and stole five valuable paintings, including one each by the Spanish masters Goya, Murillo and El Greco, the police said Thursday. The thieves held up three cleaners and cut the five paintings out of their frames before fleeing in a waiting car.

title: LEADER OF STRIKE AT KEY CHRYSLER PLANT SEES PROGRESS IN TALKS
description: The president of a local of the United Automobile Workers said today that progress was being made in talks to end a strike at a Chrysler Corporation plant here that has begun to cripple the company.

title: U.S. PRESSES SALVADOR TO ACT ON MEN TIED TO DEATH SQUADS
description: The United States Embassy here is pressing the Government to take action against a number of army and security officers who are said to be ''highly suspected'' of involvement in assassination squads, according to high-ranking embassy officials.

title: Marcos Allows Military To Join Cabinet Sessions
description: Philippine military leaders attended a Cabinet meeting today, and President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced that they would do so from now on whenever important issues were to be discussed. On the agenda today was the question of presidential succession.

title: S.E.C. PALNNING TO TEST ELECTRONIC REGISTRATION
description: The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that the agency would begin a pilot program within a year that would allow companies to file information with the commission electronically. When the system is complete, the S.E.C. will make the information available to the public almost instantaneously through its computers.

title: PHILHARMONIC: BEETHOVEN
description: With this weekend's subscription concerts, Zubin Mehta ends his current round of concerts with the New York Philharmonic. He will be gone until January, but he takes with him a four-year contract extension as the Philharmonic's music director. Friday afternoon's concert in Avery Fisher Hall - a day after the contract announcement - found both Mr. Mehta and his players in exceptionally good spirits.

title: FOR THEATER OWNERS, MANY FLAVORS OF PROFIT
description: There was popcorn, popcorn everywhere, and Orange Whip to drink.

title: Postal Union Re-elects Chief
description: Moe Biller, president of the 320,000-member American Postal Workers union, won re-election for a second three-year term in nationwide voting, the union announced Thursday.

title: Body From Plane Is Found
description: The body of Wilmer W. Stillman, the 26-year-old man who jumped out of a 30-seat passenger plane owned by his former employer, Pennsylvania Airlines, on Oct. 28, was found by an unidentified hunter this afternoon in a wooded area about two miles southwest of Newberrytown, state police said.

title: COVERING GRENADA: HOST OF PROBLEMS
description: The bombing of Fort Frederick in St. George's, Grenada, on the first day of the invasion and the occupation of Pearls Airport, the only functioning airfield on the island before the invasion, has created a host of problems for the 200 to 400 reporters trying to cover the action.

title: INQUIRY IS BEGUN OF MANAGEMENT AT NAVY YARD
description: City officials said yesterday they were investigating the management practices of the agency that operates the Brooklyn Navy Yard, and an allegation of criminal conduct against one official.

title: Bombing in West Germany
description: A bomb set off by suspected terrorists ripped through the offices of an armaments factory today, causing $300,000 in damage but injuring no one, the state prosecutor's office said.

description: Marcia Lewis, the singer and comedienne, has constructed a cabaret act based on shrill musical slapstick that has an abrasive vaudevillian appeal.

title: British Car Sales Rise
description: New car sales in Britain rose to 134,792 units last month, up 3.4 percent from 130,397 in October 1982, the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders said today.

title: CORRECTION
description: A review Thursday of ''Innovation,'' a public-television program, incorrectly reported a treatment for Down's syndrome. The syndrome can be diagnosed in the fetus, but there are no surgical techniques for treating it.

title: Nissan-VW Pact
description: The Nissan Motor Company and Volkswagenwerk A.G. are considering widening their ties, a Nissan spokesman said, but he stressed that nothing specific had yet been decided between the Japanese and West German auto makers. During meetings this week in Tokyo, Nissan's president, Takeshi Ishihara, and the VW chairman, Carl Hahn, discussed the possibility of Nissan supplying VW with its V-design six-cylinder engines, possible cooperation in diesel-engine development, and whether the two concerns might supply each other with auto parts, the spokesman said. Nissan has already agreed to produce VW's Santana- Car in Japan under license, with production expected to begin in December.

Ed Vargo , the senior major league umpire with 23 years service, who has worked in both leagues, announced his retirement after completing his career with the National League. . . . Gordon Hudson , Brigham Young's all-America tight end who suffered a severe knee injury last week, has been cleared to begin running next week and may be back in the lineup before the end of the season. It had been feared that the injury would require major surgery that would keep him out the rest of the year.

title: Canada to End Aeroflot Ban

Canada was the first to act after the Russians downed a South Korean airliner on Sept. 1, killing 269 people. Aeroflot previously flew twice-weekly flights to Montreal, its only direct air link with North America.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1983
description: The Economy The jobless rate fell in October , to 8.7 percent, from 9.1 percent, the Labor Department reported. While the seasonally adjusted number of people employed was slightly lower, officials said, payroll jobs were strongly higher in durable goods manufacturing and construction, the two sectors hit hard by the recession, suggesting that employers were turning from longer work hours to larger work forces. The figures indicated the rapid recovery is continuing, and analysts said the jobless rate would drop below 8 percent next year. (Page 1.) In New York City, the jobless rate fell to 9.2 percent. (16.) Companies will file data with the S.E.C. electronically under a new pilot program, and the agency will make the data public almost instantaneously. Officials said the program will enable investors at home computers to go directly to S.E.C. files for the latest information on companies they are interested in. (35.)

title: A LEADER OF G.O.P.

title: Japan Capital Spending
description: Companies' spending on plant and equipment in the year ending March 31, 1984, is expected to rise 3.5 percent from the previous year, the smallest growth in 11 years, according to a survey released today by the Ministry of International Trade and Industry. The rise would bring the total to the equivalent of $49.4 billion at current exchange rates. The survey, covering 1,880 companies, showed spending by manufacturing industries will fall 2.2 percent, to $22.6 billion, but that by nonmanufacturing industries will rise 8.9 percent, to $26.8 billion.

title: Soviet Icebreaker Is Halted By Pack Ice in Bering Strait
description: The Soviet icebreaker Yermak, on its way from the Far East to help iced-in freighters north of eastern Siberia, has been halted by pack ice in the Bering Strait close to Alaska, the official Tass press agency said today.

description: Prime Minister Edward Seaga of Jamaica has urged President Reagan to pardon the Jamaican-born pan- African leader Marcus Garvey, who died in 1940, 13 years after deportation from the United States. Mr. Garvey had been convicted in New York City of mail fraud in 1923, imprisoned in 1925 and deported to Jamaica in 1927.

description: Since John W. Teets took the reins at the Greyhound Corporation two years ago, he has been racing to reshape the Phoenix-based conglomerate.

title: Lanier Fined $5,000
description: It was a powerful left hook that knocked down his opponent and broke his nose, and would probably have drawn praise if Bob Lanier had been in a boxing ring when he delivered the punch to Bill Laimbeer Tuesday night. But Lanier, the Milwaukee Bucks' center, and Laimbeer, the Detroit Pistons' center, are basketball players, and after investigating the incident officials of the National Basketball Association fined Lanier $5,000. According to the league, Lanier told investigators he had had ''no reason'' to lose his temper and ''no justification for throwing the punch.''

title: No Headline
description: The Mouse That Grinned Grenada has certainly done better than Grand Fenwick. Like the Grand Duchy of Grand Fenwick in the movie ''The Mouse That Roared,'' Grenada must have decided that the only remedy for its poverty was to become the enemy of the United States, in the expectation of being quickly defeated and then rehabilitated by American aid.

title: NOT CRITICIZE PRODUCTS? SERVICES?
description: The following may become endangered species: book, theater, movie, concert and restaurant reviews; preview criticism of television and art- gallery shows; shoppers' guides, consumer affairs columns and articles featuring ''the best'' and ''the worst'' of those things vying for our time and money.

title: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1983 International
description: A bomb at an Israeli headquarters compound in Tyre, Lebanon killed at least 39 people and injured 32. The explosion happened after a truck loaded with explosives crashed through the compound's entrance. Later, Israeli jets struck at Palestinian targets along the Beirut-Damascus Highway, hitting a command post and several tanks and artillery pieces. The Beirut radio said responsibility for the incident was claimed by the so-called Moslem Jihad, or Moslem Holy War, one of the groups that claimed responsibility for the truck bombings of the U.S. Marine headquarters and a French barracks. (Page 1, Col.6.) Israel vowed to fight back, reacting to the bombing with a series of military steps and statements designed to regain a posture of determination and resolve. (1:3-5.)

title: YOUNG VOLUNTEERS LEARN TO CARE FOR AGED
description: THE day room of the nursing home was filled with activity. The residents, all incapacitated enough to require specialized care, sat in wheelchairs, worked their way slowly across the room in walkers or were being gently led to a variety of activities provided for them. Each was accompanied by a youthful volunteer, and each seemed grateful for the help and encouragement provided by these companions.

title: CALIFORNIA DATE HARVEST HURT BY RAINSTORMS

title:

description: MONTCLAIR CURRENTLY on view at the Montclair Art Museum are more than 100 paintings of flowers. With one exception, a Monet, they are American paintings from the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

title: JACKSON POSES SOME DIFFICULT QUESTIONS FOR OTHER DEMOCRATS
description: Sprinkled through every campaign season are a few moments that seem genuinely rich in emotion and political portent. Such a moment occurred here on Thursday when the Rev. Jesse Jackson - born poor, black and illegitimate 42 years ago in South Carolina - rose at the Washington Convention Center to announce his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination. ''I don't sympathize with the poor,'' roared Mr. Jackson. ''It's all in the blood. We're talking about a campaign for the poor and abused and the locked out.''

title: FIRST CYSTIC FIBROSIS HEART-LUNG TRANSPLANT DONE
description: A team of surgeons at Presbyterian- University Hospital in Pittsburgh has performed a heart-and-lung transplant on a Buffalo man whose own organs had been deteriorated by cystic fibrosis.

title: PLANS FOR AN UNBUILT MONASTERY
description: THE main attraction now at the William Benton Museum of Art is not art at all, at least not in the usual sense. It is more an investigation, by means of placards, plans and models, into a Benedictine monastery that never existed.

title: TAPE CAPER
description: If he's just a public-spirited citizen, Larry Flynt has lately been a little too public and spirited for Federal District Judge Robert M. Takasugi. Mr. Flynt, the publisher of Hustler magazine, recently told reporters that he had audiotapes of a Government informant threatening John Z. DeLorean for trying to back out of a purported drug deal for which Mr. DeLorean was subsequently indicted. After Mr. Flynt twice defied orders to appear in court and explain the purported tapes, Judge Takasuki had him arrested at his Los Angeles home last week.

title: CHAMBER ENSEMBLES SHOW OFF A WIDE SPECTRUM OF MUSIC
description: The term ''chamber music'' means, quite literally, any music intimate enough to be played in someone's chamber. People have been playing together in small groups since time began, of course. But the term is further circumscribed these days to mean classical music from the late 18th to the early 20th century played on unamplified instruments in modern concert halls far grander than any mere chamber.

title: HAVES HELPING HAVE-NOTS

In a world so marked by the terrible disparities between wealth and poverty, what can the comfortable do to ease the plight of the discomfited?

title: ONE ECCENTRIC'S VISION GIVES RISE TO A MUSEUM
description: The great grim city of Glasgow, Scotland, is not much loved. In this, as in all else, it contrasts abruptly with its neighbor, the city of Edinburgh. Edinburgh has class, coherence, an incomparable skyline, a royal palace and an august history. People the world over will pack their bags and take off for Edinburgh at the drop of an engraved invitation.

However, it seems to me that she did not give sufficient attention to the significance of the Actors Studio.

GARDENING;
AUTUMN LEAVES AND HOW TO USE THEM
description: ONE might well look around at this time of year and wonder if the name for the season was not derived from the fact that this is the season of falling leaves. With the arrival of the first heavy frost, and even before, the leaves of deciduous trees and shrubs begin to fall.

Maybe it's having the evidence to bring down a corrupt official, perhaps we finally succeed in getting our money back from a store's errant computer, or maybe one succeeds in striking a blow against racial stereotyping by changing another's mind.

title: OPERA: STARS PERFORM FOR BENEFIT OF COMPANY
description: It pays to have friends - especially if you are a small opera company with financial difficulties. Thursday night, a good crowd found its way to the auditorium at the Marymount Manhattan College to show support for New York's struggling Chamber Opera Theater and, not so incidentally, to hear two great artists - the soprano Elisabeth Soderstrom and the tenor Nicolai Gedda - present a program of arias and songs.

title: 'SPANISH ART TOMORROW' REALLY REFLECTS TODAY
description: One of the more interesting things about the traveling exhibition of current art sent here by the Spanish Government is its title. It is not called, as it should be in terms of fact, ''A Glimpse of Spanish Art Today,'' or even - perhaps - ''Some Aspects of Contemporary Spanish Art.'' No, the show - now appearing on the last leg of its tour at the Bronx Museum of the Arts, 1040 Grand Concourse (at 165th Street), through Jan. 5 - bears the bold appellation ''Spanish Art Tomorrow,'' a piece of fortune-telling that conveys a vague promise of vanguard excitements. It's a heavy title to live up to, because since the stir created in the 50's and early 60's (during the Fascist Franco regime) by such now established artists as Antoni Tapies, Eduardo Chillida, Antonio Saura and the late Manuel Millares, we haven't seen a ''Spanish art'' of any significant invention.

title: INDUSTSRIAL NOISE STIRS DEBATE
description: TEN years ago, Claudette Telfair recalled, she was a refugee, so to speak, from the Bronx, sitting in the bedroom of her new home in Medford, listening for the sound of crickets.

title: Middlebury Ends Union Streak, 24-21
description: The nation's second-longest college football winning streak ended today as the Middlebury quarterback Tom Mahon threw 3 touchdown passes for a 24-21 victory over Union.

title: SHERRY LANSING'S NEW ROLE IN MOVIES
description: Sherry Lansing caused quite a commotion in Hollywood last December when she abruptly announced plans to quit her $300,000-a-year job as president of 20th Century-Fox Productions. After three years at the helm as the first woman president of a movie studio, she broke away, teamed up with Stanley Jaffe and formed a production group within the Paramount empire.

title: HAPPINESS CAN BUY MONEY
description: Regardless of what he learned as a student at the Peddie School in the 1920's, Walter H. Annenberg apparently had big fun there. Last week, in announcing a gift of $12 million to the Hightstown, N.J., prep school, the founder of TV Guide magazine recalled spending ''the happiest school years'' of his life at Peddie. His contribution was thought to be the largest single pledge ever made to a precollegiate institution. Mr. Annenberg said there were ''no strings'' attached to the gift, which went to a fund raising-campaign for increasing teachers' salaries, expanding academic programs and physical facilities and increasing financial aid to needy pupils, who accound for about 19 percent of Peddie's 510 students.

title: 8 STRUGGLING TOWNS GET 'A SHOT IN THE ARM'
description: NORTH CANAAN'S First Selectman, Henry E. Pozzetta, says he is ''jumping for joy'' and Winsted's Town Manager, Jay A. Gsell, reports he is feeling ''elated.''

description: To the Editor: Your readers might be interested in an update on ''Taking Tea in London Town'' (Travel, Jan. 23). My husband and I went to Brown's Hotel in London in August and found it less than elegant.

description: ''Puppetplay,'' a play by Pearl Cleage, will open the 17th season of the Negro Ensemble Company Nov. 15, at Theater Four, 424 West 55th Street.

description: VETERANS DAY will be especially somber this year in Connecticut, as tributes are paid to the men from the state who were killed or wounded recently in Lebanon and Grenada, as well as to those who have served their country in previous conflicts.

title: COOPERATIVE 'COS I'
description: The Washington Opera's new liaison with the Orchestre de Paris is producing its first results on our side of the Atlantic this weekend at the Kennedy Center. Last night the Washington Opera was scheduled to give the first of five performances of Mozart's ''Cos i Fan Tutte.'' The event marks the beginnings in America of a three-year, three-opera series of co-productions between the American company and the French orchestra, which has undertaken limited opera production at the Theatre des Champs-Elysees in the French capital. The project began in June 1982 in Paris with an Orchestre de Paris production of ''Don Giovanni,'' and its ''Cos i'' had a run of performances in Paris this past June.

DEATH BY DIALYSIS

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: AMID continuing economic and administrative uncertainty, the Eglevsky Ballet is going ahead with its ''Nutcracker'' season. Katherine Healy, the 14-year-old ballerina who won the junior gold medal at the International Ballet Competition in Varna, will appear with the company Dec. 26 through 28 in the role of the Sugar Plum Fairy.

title:
DINING OUT;
BARGAINS AMID THE GREENERY

The greenhouse-atrium look couldn't be hotter. But Sweetwater's has an edge on the competition in the odd-shaped dining areas - a small center room wrapped with a veranda - that allow for some semiprivate alcoves and glassed views.

title: GIRLS ENCOURAGED TO STUDY TRADES
description: YVONNE POPE, a petite 12th grader, is not fully dressed for school unless she has donned her hard hat and buckled her leather tool pouch around her waist. In it she keeps her classroom supplies - three kinds of pliers, a hacksaw, rulers, hammer, voltage tester, screwdrivers and a pair of safety glasses.

title: JAPAN'S CAR MAKERS ARE SENT A MESSAGE
description: The House sent a strong protest signal to Japan and its auto makers by passing a ''domestic content'' bill on imported automobiles for the second year in a row. Despite a gesture by Japan earlier in the week of agreeing to new import quotas, the legislation passed on a 219-to-199 vote. If approved by the Senate and signed by President Reagan, the bill would require that most foreign cars sold in this country be built mostly with American parts and labor. But the bill's prospects in the Senate are grim, and are even worse with Mr. Reagan, who has threatened to veto any domestic content legislation. Japanese imports currently hold almost 20 percent of the American market and supporters of the bill see it as a way to create more jobs in this country, as well as open up the Japanese market to more American goods. Opponents fear the protectionist legislation would spark equally strong reactions by United States trade partners. Auto sales continued strong through October, though they have not broken the 7-million- a-year mark. One Merrill Lynch analyst called the pattern ''pretty boring.'' Sales in October were up 25.5 percent for the Big Three, with Ford setting the pace with a 33.5 percent gain.

title: JERSEY TO STUDY RIVER REGION

Experimental in its aims, the company is based at La Fenice, Venice's elegant opera house, and Miss Carlson, an American, is a former soloist with the Nikolais Dance Theater. After leaving that company to choreograph in 1971, she has repeatedly brought new ideas to old institutions.

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: SCHINDLER'S LIST. By Thomas Keneally. (Penguin, $5.95.) The versatile Australian novelist Thomas Keneally tells the true story of Oskar Schindler, a young German with a reputation for womanizing and high living who - in the words of our reviewer, Paul Zweig - ''became a possessed man, ready to risk everything in a daring, almost flaunted mission of rescue'' that saved the lives of 1,300 Jews during World War II. A remarkable book, ''Schindler's List'' ''has the immediacy and the almost unbearable detail of a thousand eyewitnesses who forgot nothing.''

title:
THE REGION;
NEW FINDINGS IN A DISPUTED DEATH
description: Passion and rhetoric have often overwhelmed the few unassailable facts in the dispute over whether New York City's police have used excessive force against black and Hispanic residents. They may be found asking embarrassingly basic questions about belief in God and the meaning of life, or committing religious gaffes - such as trying to turn on lights on Saturday - that display ignorance of the most fundamental rules of Orthodox Judaism.

Among other things, the cost of a first-class stamp would rise to 23 cents from 20 cents and a postal card to 15 cents from 13 cents.
