title: QUAKE STIRS TURKS LIVING IN NEW YORK AREA
description: In homes, in meetings and at worship, Turkish-Americans in the New York metropolitan area have shared their sorrows and pooled their efforts to aid the survivors of the earthquake that struck eastern Turkey last Sunday, killing more than 1,300 people.

title: TURNING BACK THE CLOCK Their Own Sweet Time
description: Besides public transportation, New York City's subway system offers public time. In theory, a rider need never wear a watch, since 1,425 clocks are plainly visible on station platforms and from car windows. Too often, however, those clocks don't provide time, but times, especially in large stations like Grand Central and Times Square. A stroll through such a station at any time reveals that it's a horological nightmare, or perhaps an Einsteinian underworld, where all is relativity. When one side of a clock reads 10 o'clock, the other side reads 10:15. Sometimes three clocks in a row are keeping separate times, differing by 5, 15 or 30 minutes. For the chronically late rider, the experience is torture: One moment he's almost on time, the next he's dismayingly late again.

title: No Headline
description: Kent St. Ends 21-Loss Streak KENT, Ohio, Nov. 5 (AP) -

title: CUBA LOSES A FOOTHOLD BUT KEEPS ITS COOL
description: HAVANA HAVING watched the revolution it had nurtured in Grenada collapse under internal divisions and then get swept aside by the American invasion, the Cuban Government last week turned its attention to containing the damage to its prestige and influence. Havana seemed to be seeking to portray itself as a country whose stake in Grenada, aside from the safety of its citizens there, was limited - that it could afford to be unconcerned about events on the island save as evidence of the ''imperialist Yankee aggression'' it says is threatening the Caribbean and Central America.

title: FAIRFIELD COUNTY SEEKING A CURE TO TRAFFIC CRUSH
description: LAST year Jerome and Marie Gilmartin used to leave their home in Fairfield at 7:30 A.M. in order to arrive at their jobs in Stamford on time. ''This year the traffic is noticeably heavier,'' said Mr. Gilmartin, ''so we leave at 7:15. Traffic is lighter then, and we save 10 minutes.''

title: A BIG DAY DOWN AT THE POND
description: ACELEBRATION has been going on down at the Stony Brook Mill Pond: the gosl ings have learned to fly.

title: SHARING JUST A LITTLE IN HOPE OF AVOIDING SHARING A LOT
description: A referendum on a new Constitution last week left blacks in South Africa as they were before - without a share of political power.

title: FOR GRENADA, A SMALL, SAD REVOLUTION
description: Ten years ago, just as Grenada was becoming independent, Bernard Coard, a Brandeis University-trained economist, sat in the house of his old friend, Maurice Bishop, a London-trained lawyer, and told a reporter from New York that Eric M. Gairy, the man about to become Prime Minister of this tiny island state, was ''clinically mad.''

title: WHAT'S DOING IN BOSTON
description: This month marks the 20th anniversary of President John F. Kennedy's assassination, and the timing of that tragic anniversary makes the Kennedy Library an excellent starting point for a tour of Boston.

title: Last Week's Tally of Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: Istanbul
description: To the Editor: The article on Istanbul (''The City of Gold,'' Travel, Sept. 25) was a pleasure to read. The author, Marvine Howe, failed to mention that the city is the repository of hundreds of cars made in the United States dur

title: WITNESSES DISCUSS VIEWS OF PRELATE
description: One by one, men and women are being ushered this week into a small conference room here to speak about Raymond G. Hunt- hausen, the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Seattle. Although they are participating in a theological process that is centuries old, they are discussing 20th century issues: thermonuclear weapons and modern attitudes toward sex and society.

title: VANITIES TO BE TAMED
description: Carey Winfrey is editor in chief of Cuisine magazine. OW, IN RETROSPECT, I trace the first glimmerings to the source of the Nile. There, on the shores of Uganda's Lake Victoria of an April dawn in 1979, I found myself with the Tanzanian Army in hot pursuit of a rapidly retreating Idi Amin.

title: WOMEN WARNED ON SETBACKS
description: A women's conference was warned today that a case before the Supreme Court threatened virtually to end Federal financing equality for women in college athletics.

title: HOUSTON: MAKING THE MOST OF MOTHER NATURE
description: HOUSTON HOUSTON has suffered three disasters in two years,'' says full-page ad by Bill Wright in The Houston Post. There are three photographs: A squashed automobile, a collapsed house and Mayor Kathy Whitmire. In case anybody misses the point, the ad goes on to list a spring windstorm, a summer hurricane, and ''the election of Kathy Whitmire.''

title: Anne Beltz Is Wed to Philipp Rimmler
description: Anne Mitchell Beltz, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul William Beltz of Orchard Park, N.Y., and North Palm Beach, Fla., was married in Buffalo yesterday to Philipp Lee Rimmler, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philipp M. H. Rimmler of Smithtown, L.I., and Scottsdale, Ariz. The ceremony at St. Louis Roman Catholic Church was performed by the Rev. John Loftus, assisted by the Rev. William A. Schwinger and the Rev. Thomas J. Beasley.

title: GOOD LANDSCAPE DESIGN BEGINS WITH BASIC PRICIPLES
description: Eugene W. Jackson is a professional writer who gardens as a hobby.

title: ANDROPOV, REPORTED ILL, MISSES FETE
description: Yuri V. Andropov was absent today from a major Kremlin ceremony usually attended by all senior officials, and a Government spokesman said the Soviet leader was suffering from a cold.

title: JAZZ: BRAFF AND HYMAN IN SERIES
description: Ruby Braff and Dick Hyman are, individually, two of the most distinctive musicians in jazz - Mr. Braff because of a trumpet style that involves dark, somber plunges into the lower register mixed with growls, murmurs and sudden rising shouts, all delivered with closely controlled precision; Mr. Hyman because of the awesome range of musical idioms that he has at his fingertips.

title: OPERA: 'THE LIGHTHOUSE' BY DAVIES
description: The English composer Peter Maxwell Davies has only written three operas, but they have been much admired. And this season, Boston will see two of them. In May, Sarah Caldwell will stage ''Taverner.'' She will have to go a long way to surpass the impact of the Boston Shakespeare Company's production of ''The Lighthouse,'' which received its American premiere with a beaming Mr. Davies in attendance on Wednesday, and which will run in repertory until Dec. 4.

title: FICTION
description: 1110 POLAND, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Seven centuries of history in fictional form. 239 CHANGES, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $15.95.) The crises that arise when a television anchorwoman and a glamorous physician fall in love. 3220 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 4 1

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: FLATLANDS
description: IN the 1630's, the Dutch farmers who

title: MISSOURI, BY 10-0, UPSETS OKLAHOMA
description: A scrambling Marlon Adler passed 20 yards for a touchdown and a swarming Missouri defense stymied Oklahoma for a 10-0 upset victory today in a Big Eight Conference game.

title: ON THE STREET FOR 10 CENTS ON THE DOLLAR
description: Reluctant Correction Department officials held a clearance sale last week, offering 90 percent discounts on bail as a way to get more than 300 inmates out of New York City jails. A Federal judge had ordered that overcrowding be eased by releasing prisoners awaiting trial.

title: UNION TRIUMPHS BY 20-6
description: Keith Peace, a senior fullback, ran for 141 yards on 19 carries and scored a touchdown to lead highly regarded Union (7-0) past Scotch Plains, 20-6, yesterday in Scotch Plains.

title: Salem's 'Witches'
description: To the Editor: I was upset by a state

title:
ANTIQUES;
A BENEFIT SHOW OF HIGH QUALITY
description: -running and most-successful North Jersey antiques shows is the one sponsored each year by the College Club of Ridgewood. This year's event, the 15th, will be held Thursday through Saturday at Benjamin Franklin Junior High School.

title: PENTAGON AHEAD IN MANEUVERS ON CAPITOL HILL
description: The Administration's plans for cranking up production of chemical- warfare weapons may have been shelved, but otherwise the Pentagon didn't lose many on Capitol Hill last week.

title: THE REORGANIZATION OF LOMBARD-WALL
description: When Lombard-Wall Inc. collapsed over a year ago and was forced into reorganization, Harold W. Kurtz, chairman of the government securities firm, said he expected the company would pay its debts and stay in business, ''if we can keep everybody in place.'' As he said in August 1982, ''We're going to reorganize this firm, not liquidate.''

title: Kathleen Ann Monahan Is the Bride Of Chase Whitcher Ashley, a Lawyer
description: Kathleen Ann Monahan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Urban J. Monahan of Darien, Conn., was married yesterday to Chase Whitcher Ashley, son of Mrs. Martin A. Mortensen, also of Darien, and William V. Ashley of Brooklyn Heights. The Rev. John M. McConnell performed the ceremony at St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Predicting the success of any venture before it has materialized is a risky business. But ''The Gospel at Colonus,'' which will play at the Brooklyn Academy of Music from Tuesday through Nov. 20 as part of the Next Wave Festival, has some fascinating ingredients that could very well cohere into an exciting musical- theatrical experience.

title: PERSONAL INDICATORS OF A HARD WINTER
description: IT is going to be a hard winter. I

title: INDIAN PAGENT SEEKS A HOME
description: The National Miss Indian America Pageant ''has fallen on hard times'' and is seeking a new sponsor and location after 30 years in this Wyoming city, a pageant official says.

title: NEW ORCHESTRA PLANS DEBUT
description: ARECENTLY formed professional symphony orchestra will make its county debut next Sunday at the Center for the Arts on the Purchase campus of the State University of New York.

title: MISSING PAPERS STALL FIRST JERSEY
description: The court proceedings were slow enough before someone lost 220,000 pages of company records. Now, it appears that the five-year legal battle between First Jersey Securities and the Securities and Exchange Commission may go on indefinitely.

title: HECTOR GETS START FOR MCNEIL
description: Freeman McNeil stared angrily at Johnny Hector.

title: RACIAL-BALANCE PROBLEM SEEN IN SOEM CONNECTICUT SCHOOLS
description: Some Connecticut cities such as Hartford and New Haven face a ''near impossible'' task of complying with a law that requires them to balance their schools racially, a state education official told the State Board of Education this week.

title: BUREACRATS IN BLUE
description: VARNISHED BRASS

title: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 6, 1983;  International
description: Israel clamped a tight security net over southern Lebanon, sealing off bridges and highways and searching for those responsible for Friday's truck-bomb attack on an Israeli military headquarters in Tyre, which killed 60 people. (Page 1, Column 6.) Israel is ready to ''confront'' Syria to deter further acts of agression against Israeli troops in Lebanon by Damascus and its Palestinian proxies, a senior Israeli official said in Geneva. He said that if the Syrians thought Israel was preoccupied with its internal affairs and unwilling to fight, they were badly ''misreading'' the mood in Jerusalem. (1:4.)

title: Wedding Planned By Miss Andreoli
description: Christine Lucille Andreoli and Philip Michael Cannella, third-year students at the Fordham University Law School, plan to be married in January.

title: Restoration of Benefits For Mentally Ill Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld a judge's order requiring the Social Security Administration to restore benefits to more than 6,000 mentally ill people in six states.

title: CITY OPERA VERY SPECIAL FOX CHALLENGES THE TV CAMERAS
description: ''We are approaching a new and exciting era for opera telecasts. Too often in the past, television has simply preserved isolated star peformances. But now we are learning to re-create the dramatic vitality of the theater.''

title: CHECK YOUR HEATING SYSTEM BEFORE THE BIG COLD COMES
description: FOR the prudent homeowner, the arrival of cold weather signals the need to give his home heating system a quick checkup to make certain that it is operating at its maximum efficiency and getting the most heat possible out of every dollar spent for fuel.

title: URBAN ISSUES, ODD ALLIANCES IN THE NEW HAVEN ELECTION
description: Biagio DiLieto was chief of the New Haven police in 1971 when thousands of demonstrators assembled daily on the green across from the courthouse to protest the murder trial of Bobby Seale, the leader of the Black Panthers. Told that his detectives needed to keep a closer watch on potential troublemakers, Mr. DiLieto authorized wiretaps until the end of the trial.

title: NEW STATE REAL-ESTATE TAX DISRUPTING TRANSACTIONS
description: IN only 96 hours last March, Governor Cuomo's staff

title: BOOKS
description: OPTIMISM clings to the pages of ''Atlantic City: 125 Years of Ocean Madness'' by Vicky Gold Levi and Lee Eisenberg (Clarkson N. Potter, New York, $15.95; paper, $8.95), a fun- filled picture album brimming with snapshots of Ziegfeld girls, clam-eating tournaments, multi-storied, balconied hotels, the Flying Zachinis blasting out of a cannon, high-diving horses, Miss Americas, honeymooners in rolling chairs, Steel Pier stars and baby parades.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Mastervision 60 minutes. $59.95

title:
SPORTS;
ARROWS SEEK TO REGAIN FANS
description: -84 Major Indoor Soccer League season at 5 P.M. today at the Nassau Coliseum in Uniondale.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
BRAND SALE LEADS NEW ROUND OF AUCTIONS
description: For coin collectors being ''where the action is'' during 1983 has generally meant one thing, being where the auction is. Without a doubt this has been the year of the auction - an image that will be reinforced in the week ahead as dealers, collectors and investors gather in New York for another round of public auction sales.

title: A TOURNAMENT OF ONLYY GRUENFELDS?
description: During one of the rounds of the Alekhine Memorial Tournament at the Palace of Railroad Workers in Moscow in 1971, David Bronstein (who had drawn the 1951 world championship match and therefore failed to take Mikhail Botvinnik's title) pointed to the spectators and said:

title: FROM TOKYO TO POMONA
description: The Tokyo String Quartet, one of the world's best, will perform this evening in Stockton State College's Guest Artists Series, playing works by Schubert, Beethoven and Bartok.

title: FILM BUFF NOW PRODUCER
description: ''IWAS a fanatic moviegoer as a kid,'' said Michael Phillips. ''I used to spend my entire allowance every week on going to the movies.''

title:
DINING OUT;
THE POPULARITY OF PEKING DUCK
description: BECAUSE Peking duck is a lengthy and complicated dish to prepare, most restaurants used to require that it be ordered 24 to 48 hours in advance. However, because of its popularity, many restaurants now serve it without prior notice. The one-year-old Peking Duck House in the Bergen County community of Closter is the latest to offer this convenience.

title: Lowest-Paid Teacher Finds Solace in Work
description: A widow who runs a one-room school and owns the town saloon says she is happy with her work and does not mind the fact that her $6,300 salary makes her possibly the lowest-paid teacher in the nation.

title: PHILADELPHIA: BATTLE FOR SECTORS OF AN AGING AND TROUBLED CITY
description: PHILADELPHIA THE employment picture here is a lot like

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: GLEN COVE VOTE FOCUSES ON LOCAL ISSUES
description: THE mayoral race in Glen Cove has chased the dispute over Killenworth, the Soviet diplomatic residence, off the front page and focused on such familiar local issues as taxes, downtown renewal and a $10 million municipal garage.

title: Gail L. Boorstein and Gary Palmucci Are Married
description: The marriage of Gail Louise Boorstein, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Allen L. Boorstein of New York, to Gary J. Palmucci, son of Mr. and Mrs. Remo Palmucci of Concord, Mass., took place last evening. Rabbi Martin Zion performed the ceremony in the chapel at Columbia University.

title: Page Jones Is Engaged To Randolph C. Frantz
description: Announcement has been made by Col. Frank Phelps Jones, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Jones of Arlington, Va., of the engagement of their daughter, Mary Page Jones, to Randolph Cochrane Frantz, son of Mr. and Mrs. William Henry Frantz of Southern Pines, N.C., and New York.

title: ABOUT CARSMarshall Schuon A New Convertible From Ferrari
description: OF all the production cars in the world, only a handful have that true electrical snap, that shape or sound or just that name that sets the blood afire. Ferrari certainly is one of those, however, and the Italian company keeps turning up the juice.

title: Army Beaten, 34-14, By Boston College
description: The game was not the same after Doug Flutie left midway through the third quarter, but by that time the junior quarterback had put the game beyond reach in Boston College's 34-14 victory over Army today at Michie Stadium.

title: ISRAEL TO CUT RELIANCE ON HADDAD TROOPS
description: Israel intends to reduce its reliance in southern Lebanon on the militia led by Maj. Saad Haddad, the former Lebanese Army officer whom it has supported since 1978, Israeli Government officials said today.

title: No Headline
description: Jane Trapnell Is Wed

title:
GARDENING;
AUTUMN LEAVES AND HOW TO USE THEM
description: ONE might well look around at this time of year and wonder if the name for the season was not derived from the fact that this is the season of falling leaves. With the arrival of the first heavy frost, and even before, the leaves of deciduous trees and shrubs begin to fall.

title: VOTERS TO DECIDE ON 8 QUESTIONS
description: TRENTON VOTERS will face an array of eight ballot questions on Tuesday, including three calling for authorization to issue $320 million in bonds to acquire land for recreation and conservation purposes, to protect the shore and to repair and improve bridges.

title: A FISH PLACE THAT BROILS TO TASTE
description: AS seafood restaurants go, the pleasures outweigh the disappointments at Lure of the Sea in Cedarhurst. Definite efforts are made to serve mostly fresh fish, sometimes obtained from local waters. Overcooking is not a serious flaw. In fact, if you order your fish ''not too well done,'' the waitress may nod understandingly in approval, rather than expressing puzzled incomprehension.

title: SHOW STARTS ASBESTOS DISPUTE
description: MANVILLE ATELEVISION documentary designed to assess the emotional and psychological effects of asbestos-related diseases on the young people of this Somerset County community has set off a dispute among local health authorities and raised questions about the extent of public awareness concerning the operation of the Johns- Manville Sales Corporation here.

title: Hundreds of Ghanaians Expelled From Nigeria
description: Hundreds of Ghanaians have been arriving daily at the border town of Aflao in the last few days after being expelled from Nigeria, the Accra radio reported today.

title: YOUTH-AID AGENCY HELPS MORE ADULTS
description: THE Smith Haven Ministries, widely known during its 15 years in Lake Grove's Smith Haven Mall for helping teen- agers, is now serving an increasing number of adults.

title: SENATOR ON COAST FIGHTING FOR SEAT
description: As the political campaign goes into its last round, Daniel J. Evans, a Republican, is ahead in the polls in his race to defeat Mike Lowry, a Democrat, and retain the United States Senate seat he got by appointment two months ago.

title: STRESS EXCELLENCE IN TEACHING, SCHOOLS URGED
description: At a time of a growing debate over the quality of secondary education in the United States, nearly 300 teachers and administrators from around the country met yesterday to share their conviction that the best way to improve the system is to encourage excellence in classroom teaching.

title: BEHIND THE BIG COLLAPSE AT OSBORNE
description: TO venture capital firms in mid-1982, the financing

title: 'YES' FOR TRANSPORTATION BONDS
description: Does anyone believe New York's transportation network should be left to decay, burdening the economy and frustrating, even endangering, travelers? Not even opponents of the $1.25 billion transportation bond issue - Proposal 1 on Tuesday's ballot - argue that. They urge its rejection because they claim there must be easier ways to reach the same goal. They have produced none, and conscientious citizens will vote ''yes.''

title: OPERA: 3 JOIN 'P^ECHEURS' CAST
description: Three singers new to the City Opera production of ''Les P^echeurs de Perles'' joined the cast Wednesday night in the company's fourth performance of the work this season.

title: KEEPING UP WITH THE GENETIC REVOLUTION
description: THE LOS ALAMOS NATIONAL Laboratory in New Mexico, biophysicist Walter Goad punches a few keys on a computer terminal. Moments later, glowing green type illuminates the monitor in front of him. ''ATGGCTACAGGTAAG . . . '' begins the message, which goes on and on for almost 2,000 repetitions of A, T, C and G. Dr. Goad, director of the Government-sponsored Genetic Sequence Data Bank, known as GenBank, can read the cryptic language easily. It is an example of the genetic code, this particular procession of characters being the recipe for making a specific protein, the hormone that controls human growth.

title: IN LONDON, A PLAY OF POLITICAL IDEAS
description: Robert Cushman is theater critic of The Observer. LONDON The most eagerly awaited new play of the year in London has been David Edgar's ''Maydays.'' There are several reasons. It is the first serious work to be given its world premiere by the Royal Shakespeare Company on their new main stage in the Barbican. Mr. Edgar's last original piece, ''Destiny,'' was the most widely praised political play of recent years, and since then, he has been the adaptor of the RSC's phenomenally successful ''Nicholas Nickleby.''

title: Miss Niles Plans To Marry Dec. 3
description: Diana Bradford Niles, a vice president and creative director at Revlon Inc. in New York, plans to be married Dec. 3 to Timothy Parker King, advertising director for consumer products at J. P. Stevens, the textile company in New York.

title: NORTH KOREA REJECTS BURMA'S CHARGE IN BOMBING
description: North Korea today dismissed as ''sheer fabrication'' an official Burmese finding that it was responsible for the Oct. 9 bombing in Rangoon that killed 21 people, including four South Korean Cabinet ministers.

title: STATE LACKS DATA ON TOXIC WASTES
description: SIGNED into law on Sept. 10, 1981, the Major Hazardous- Waste Facilities Siting Act took serious note of New Jersey's problem with ''indiscriminate and illegal'' disposal of chemical wastes that posed dangers to the environment and human health.

title: STUDYING LIFE AT THE COASTLINE
description: ON a drizzly, foggy fall afternoon, some 45 students from Clark Lane Junior High School in Waterford lugged shovels, buckets, sieves, seine and plankton nets, a pH testing kit, oxygen and salinity meters onto the beach at Smith Cove on the Thames River.

title: THE LEDFORDS AND ALL OF US
description: GENERATIONS

title: TREATMENT OF GRIEF EXPLORED
description: ''PEOPLE grieve in different ways,'' said Patricia Werlau, director of social services at United Hospital in Port Chester. ''Everyone shares the common feelings of shock and disbelief at the loss of a loved one, but people perceive the nature of their loss and the depth of their despair according to their individual characteristics and areas of vulnerability.''

title: A MATTER OF LIFE AND DEATH IN THE COURTROOM
description: IN HER Opinion Page article of

title: POULTRY FARMS IN PENNSYLVANIA QUARANTINED
description: The Agriculture Department announced Friday it had placed parts of Berks, Dauphin, Lancaster and Lebanon counties in Pennsylvania under quarantine to stop the spread of an avian influenza outbreak in the state's chicken flocks.

title: A FAILED 'HIDDEN AGENDA' ON THE AMERICAS
description: To the Editor:

title: Wedding Planned By Milbry C. Polk
description: Announcement has been made by Joan Cooledge Nemser of Arlington, Mass., and Dr. William Roe Polk of Vence, France, of the engagement of their daughter, Milbry Catherine Polk of New York, to Dr. Phillip Allen Bauman, son of Dr. and Mrs. William Bauman of South Salem, N.Y. A summer wedding is planned.

title: EXCERPTS FROM SOVIET-BLOC PACTS WITH GRENADA
description: Following are excerpts from the documents found in Grenada by American forces and made public by the State Department on Friday:

title: U.S. IS TRYING SAFETY 'BRIBES'
description: The Federal Government is spending a total of $82,000 here to find out if bribery is the best way to make motorists wear seat belts.

title: MISS BURR CAPTURES TOP RIDER HONORS
description: Riding despite a broken collarbone, Leslie Burr swept to three separate victories with one breathtaking ride last night at Madison Square Garden.

title: ANTI-MARCOS, ANTI-U.S. PARTY DRAWS CROWD
description: A new leftist opposition party with strong anti-American overtones held its first formal gathering today, drawing a crowd that filled a 35,000-seat boxing arena.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
Confessions of a Star
description: He was a heavy user of marijuana in college and had brief experiences with cocaine and LSD, and if he were anybody else, he might have been expected to omit those experiences from his autobiography, ''Giant Steps.''

title: HUMANITIES FUNDS RECEIVE SCRUTINY
description: Projects in Oregon, Idaho and Arizona have come under criticism from Federal officials who question whether they are appropriate recipients of funds from the National Endowment for the Humanities.

title: Landon Hall, D. F. Dickey Are Engaged
description: The engagement of Elizabeth Landon Hall to Donald Faulkner Dickey has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Spotswood Braxton Hall Jr. of Richmond, parents of the bride-to-be. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Whitney Dickey of Lebanon, N.H. A June wedding is planned.

title: Miss Powers Weds on L.I.
description: At St. John's of Lattingtown Episcopal Church in Locust Valley, L.I., yesterday, Devon Powers, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Augustin Jay Powers Jr. of Locust Valley, was married to Christopher Michael Delaney, son of Mr. and Mrs. James E. Delaney of Seoul, South Korea, and Potomac, Md. The Rev. Charles G. Newbery performed the ceremony.

title:
THE WORLD;
ZIMBABWE TRIES U.S. PATIENCE
description: Zimbabwe and the United States may differ on international issues, Presidents Robert Mugabe and Ronald Reagan said when they met last month, but even so, they can stay friendly on bilateral matters. By last week, however, the international end of the seesaw was uppermost and Administration conservatives were reportedly pressing for deep cuts in $75 million in aid proposed for Zimbabwe next year.

title: NO THANKS FOR SMALL FAVORS
description: The United States eased up slightly on sanctions against Poland last week - so slightly in fact that Poland denounced Washington's ''unfriendly and unlawful'' attitude.

title: Miss Gilleaudeau Engaged to Marry Physician in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Alfred Gilleaudeau Jr. of Rye, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Aimee Larkin Gilleaudeau, to Dr. Mark Walden Lundy, son of Dr. and Mrs. Burdette Walden Lundy of Canandaigua, N.Y.

title: Susan Stupin Plans to Wed Next March
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Matthew Allen of Bel Air, Calif., of the engagement of Mrs. Allen's daughter, Susan Lee Stupin, to Theodore Robert Gamble Jr., son of Mrs. Gamble of St. Louis and the late Mr. Gamble. A March wedding is planned at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York.

title: LANDFILL LEAKAGE CROSSES TOWN LINE
description: IN less enlightened times, people

title: 14 KURT WEILL MANUSCRIPTS SURFACE
description: Fourteen manuscripts of early compositions by Kurt Weill, most of them unknown to scholars and musicians, have come into the possession of the Kurt Weill Foundation for Music, it was announced yesterday.

title: Woolfolk Progress Impresses Parcells
description: Week in and week out, as the Giants have lost fumbles and thrown interceptions and failed to pick up blitzes and missed tackles, Coach Bill Parcells has found the same bit of silver lining.

title: MURDOCH BUYS INTO CHICAGO
description: Rupert K. Murdoch owns a few newspapers that don't exactly reflect journalism's noblest instincts. He also owns a few that do.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Sequel For Mr. Rooney

title: Goalie's Decline
description: Jim Craig had said that the game would be a ''no win'' situation, and he was right. Craig, the star goalie on the United States hockey team that won the gold medal in the 1980 Winter Olympics, was in goal for the Salt Lake Golden Eagles Friday night when the Eagles faced the 1984 Olympic team. Peppered with 31 shots by the Olympians, Craig managed to save only 23 as the Eagles lost, 8-4.

title: ON BUSES, POLICY FITS THE REALITY
description: The New York City Transit Authority decided last week that passengers on some buses would have to get their air conditioning the old- fashioned way - by opening windows. The authority said it would no longer try to repair air conditioners on 1,400 older-model buses, so unreliable had the units become.

title: JACKSON SEES PALESTINIAN STATE IN U.S. INTEREST
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson, in a speech to an Arab- American group, said tonight that the United States had an interest in both a secure Israel and the creation of a Palestinian state.

title: KUSH'S TOUGH STYLE IS SUCCEEDING WITH 5-4 COLTS
description: PERHAPS the most significant thing that happened to Coach Frank Kush this season was not that an angry Baltimore Colt player had poured soda over his head, but that 60 other players had chosen not to.

title: REV. SULLIVAN STEPS UP HIS ANTI-APARTHEID FIGHT
description: ON Wednesday morning representatives of more than 100 United States corporations will meet in closed session at Exxon's New York headquarters.

title: LARGE FARMS GET MILLIONS FROM AID PROGRAM
description: Almost three dozen large farms are receiving Government-owned commodities worth millions of dollars in return for not growing crops this year under the Reagan Administration's program to reduce crop surpluses, Congressional investigators say.

title: WITNESS IN SENTRY TRIAL SAYS HE SAW TWO BAGS OF MONEY
description: A witness testified last week in Federal District Court in Manhattan that a friend showed him a garbage bag and a duffel bag containing as much as $250,000 shortly after an $11 million theft from an armored-car company in the Bronx.

title: Data Bank; November 6, 1983
GOOD OPERA LIBRETTISTS ARE HARD TO FIND--AND HOLD
description: When a great opera composer finds a gifted librettist with whom he can work happily and productively, it is like the conjunction of two stars. The light of each amplifies the other, sometimes with dazzling effect. Verdi's meeting with Boito in ''Otello'' and ''Falstaff'' and Mozart's with da Ponte in ''The Marriage of Figaro,'' ''Cos i Fan Tutte'' and ''Don Giovanni'' shine out as the happiest examples. We sometimes forget, however, that at times during their composing careers, Verdi and Mozart endured dry spells when they had to struggle with modestly talented librettists, spending immense amounts of energy in the process of grinding and hammering tinny prose into shapes they could deal with.

title: PLAY OFFERS DIFFERENT LUTHER
description: WHEN he was a youngster in Sunday school, John Ahrens thought of Martin Luther as ''this big fat guy who nailed some documents on a church door.'' Later, in a college humanities class, he came to regard the Christian reformer as an admirable but austere figure. Now, Mr. Ahrens is portraying Luther in a documentary musical, and his views of the man have changed once more:

title: JAZZ: BALABAN'S OTHER CATS PLAY AT CONDON'S
description: Since mid-September the brassy sounds that are usually heard at Eddie Condon's, the club at 144 West 54th Street named for the late jazz guitarist, have been replaced on Tuesday evenings by softer, more subdued music.

title: WHERE IS N.F.L. DEFENSE?
description: DAVE ANDERSONSports of The Times NONE of the deep thinkers in the National Football League appear to be alarmed at the rise in scoring this season. Tex Schramm, the Dallas Cowboy president who is chairman of the N.F.L.'s competition committee, is sure that the defense will catch up to the offense sooner or later.

title: BALLET: A 'CAKEWALK' BY THE JOFFREY
description: Ruthanna Boris's ''Cakewalk'' returned to the Joffrey Ballet repertory on Friday at City Center, where the company plays through Nov. 13, and it suddenly seemed like spring.

title: Memorial Mass for Kennedy
description: The Kennedy family is planning to mark the 20th anniversary of the assassination of President Kennedy with a memorial mass in the nation's capital. Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, the surviving Kennedy brother, said Wednesday that the mass would be held Nov. 22 at Holy Trinity Church in Washington and would be celebrated by Archbishop James Hickey.

description: HARTFORD IT would be nice if the statue of

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE General Assembly is not due back in session until February, but legislators are already squabbling about one issue - video lottery machines in Connecticut bars.

title: SOVIET'S PRESS LOOSES SATIRE OVER GRENADA
description: In the criticism directed by the Soviet press at President Reagan over the Grenada invasion, Tass has introduced a new weapon - bitterly personal satire.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: PULITZER COMPOSER

title: GRENADIANS' DATA SHOW PARTY RIFTS
description: Documents seized in Grenada by United States forces show that the island's Marxist rulers were engaged in such disarray and factional struggles in the months before the Oct. 25 invasion that they feared ''possible disintegration of the party.''

description: Dry History

title: A NEW OPERATIC IMPMRESARIO
description: Harold C. Schonberg, formerly senior music critic, is cultural correspondent of The New York Times.
