title: Soviet Said to Continue Aid To Hanoi for Oil Exploration
description: The Soviet Union will continue to help Vietnam with oil and gas exploration off its southern continental shelf under a long-term cooperation agreement signed Oct. 31, the Hanoi radio reported today.

title: HOUSING THE AGED
description: When classes at Bennet Junior High School in Manchester, Conn., were recessed for the last time in the spring of 1981, the town was left with an architecturally significant but unneeded school building. Rather than sell the 79-year-old red-brick and slate-roofed school to a private concern, local officials formed a partnership with the Community Development Corporation of West Hartford to develop it as a 45-unit rental residence for the town's middle-income elderly citizens.

title: Inez E. D'Arcangelo the Bride of Alfred F. Thoben
description: Inez Elizabeth D'Arcangelo, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rick A. D'Arcangelo of Mamaroneck, N.Y., was married yesterday to Alfred Francis Thoben, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alerich Thoben of Brooklyn. The Rev. Leonard DiFalco performed the ceremony at St. Gregory's Roman Catholic Church in Harrison, N.Y.

title: Bank Shuts a Branch After Third Holdup
description: An attempted robbery that left a customer and a teller wounded was the last straw for the Wilkesville branch of the Vinton County National Bank.

title: AS TURKEY TAKES A 'CAUTIOUS STEP IN THE RIGHT DIRECTION'
description: To the Editor:

title: ISRAEL CLAMPS DOWN IN AREA AND GIVES WARNING TO SYRIA
description: A senior Israeli official said here today that Israel was prepared to confront Syria to deter acts of aggression against Israeli troops in Lebanon by Damascus and its Palestinian allies.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
DON'T DISRUPT A MECHANISM THAT WORKS
description: BEFORE jumping too quickly at a new mechanism for subsidizing mortgages for low-income home buyers, it would be best to consider the benefits of our current program of tax-exempt mortgage financing as it pertains to the Government, the economy and the people of this country.

title: WILL WILLIAM CLARK PICK UP WHERE JAMES WATT LEAPT OFF?
description: William P. Clark, President Reagan's nominee to succeed James G. Watt as Secretary of the Interior, was a model of consistency at last week's confirmation hearing before the Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee. To virtually every question about his plans to change policy and staff, Mr. Clark politely replied that such issues were all ''under review.''

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Pavarotti in London RCA/Columbia 75 minutes. $29.95

title: Q/A Willful Overcharges Question:
description: I recently read that landlords will be required to pay triple damages if they are found to have overcharged a tenant on their rent. Does this law take effect immediately? . . . J. G. L., Manhattan

title: CHILDREN'S BOOK
description: When Death crooks a finger at Billy-be-damn Bangtry, who's been wounded in a shootout, he doesn't know he'll soon have to answer to Maude Applegate. Maude's a Western woman, red-haired besides, and she doesn't take kindly to Billy's departing this world.

title: BRIGHAM YOUNG: A SPECIAL STYLE ON AND OFF THE FIELD
description: PROVO, Utah

title: No Headline
description: ROBERT R. MAYER

title: REAGAN GAINS BY GRENADA, BUT MOSTLY ON HIS OWN TURF
description: WASHINGTON WITH the fighting in Grenada over and the American troops on their way home, the Reagan Administration was exulting last week over what it regarded as a major foreign policy success.

title: HOME AUDIT IS A CRUCIAL MEASURE
description: EVER since fuel costs began to rise in the

title: FINE MEALS FOR FEWER FRANCS
description: For the American traveler, Paris is full of good buys these days. Still, a budget is a budget, and those in search of a good, moderately priced meal have no reason to go hungry, or to limit their luncheon to a croque monsieur or a hot dog. There are still dozens of solid Parisian bistros, brasseries and restaurants big and small where one can enjoy a satisfying, three-course meal for anywhere from $5 to $20 a person, including an inexpensive wine. You won't be eating foie gras or drinking La T^ache, but who can complain about platters of fresh, briny oysters washed down with a bit of Muscadet, or a hearty serving of cassoulet with a young, fruity red?

title: OPERA'S DON JUAN SET TO PLAY SHAW
description: ON the world's stages, there are two notable Don Juans: Mozart's pleasure-loving libertine in ''Don Giovanni'' and Shaw's pretentious philosopher in ''Don Juan in Hell.'' The Metropolitan Opera Company baritone Gene Boucher, having sung the former role many times (although not at the Met, where he customarily appears as Masetto), will get to act the latter this week when the East Hampton Theater Company presents a dramatic reading of the witty Shavian piece.

title: Stephen Holland Marries Claudia Lee in Stamford
description: Claudia Lee, daughter of Paul Lee of Whitestone, Queens, and Elsie Lee of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Stephen Holland, son of Mr. and Mrs. James Holland of Waterford, Conn.

title: MIAMI WINS IN LAST 1:04
description: Bernie Kosar passed 52 yards to Eddie Brown and then scored on a 1-yard sneak with 64 seconds to play today as Miami rallied for a 12-7 victory over East Carolina.

title: RIDGEFIELD EYES THE PLAYOFFS
description: As the Thanksgiving Day championship game of the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference gets nearer, players from the playoff candidates begin to watch each other's games with greater interest.

title: China's First Jetliner Makes Long Test Flight
description: The first jetliner designed in China has made its longest test flight so far, flying 1,860 miles from Shanghai to Urumqi, the official New China News agency said today.

title: COMPUTER'S ROLE IN RENT VOTE
description: THE recent action by the Westchester Rent Guidelines Board, in which rents were frozen on one- and two-year leases, was based on a computer study by Alan H. Stutz, the board's new chairman. His use of a computer to predict landlords' profits was an innovation for the board, which in previous years had relied solely on pages of figures drawn from questionnaires submitted by landlords.

title: Fairleigh Dickinson Wins in Cross-Country
description: Fairleigh Dickinson took the first 3 individual places and scored 19 points to retain its title in the Collegiate Track Conference cross-country championships yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

title: SIX CENTURIES OF TOLSTOYS
description: THE TOLSTOYS

title: TRAMMELL CROW COMES TO TOWN
description: DALLAS TRAMMELL CROW is 69 years

title: GALLERY EXHIBITIONS WORTH SEEING
description: THE term ''gallery'' normally implies an exhibition space where one can look at works of art and, with no compunction, walk away without a purchase. The meaning often is extended to include shops stocked with items strictly for commercial purposes.

title: Veteran Coach Retires
description: After recording 231 victories in a 31- year football coaching career, John Merritt said yesterday that he was retiring to give Tennessee State's new athletic director, Bob Lee, a free hand when Lee takes over Jan. 1. Merritt, who is 57 years old, has had heart, kidney and blood-pressure problems for three years.

title: Virginia Sutro Is Bride Of David Allen Morse
description: Virginia Egleston Sutro, daughter of Mr.and Mrs. Ogden Winne Sutro of Hamden, Conn., and Monticello, N.Y., was married yesterday to David Allen Morse, son of Eleanor A. Morse of Concord, Mass., and the late Arnold Francis Morse. The Rev. Richard Jordan performed the cermony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New Haven.

title: RANGERS TIED BY QUEBEC
description: The Rangers may no longer be winning, but they are working hard and long in their defeats and ties. Tonight, in their third consecutive overtime game, the Rangers had to settle for a 4-4 tie with the Quebec Nordiques to extend their slump to five games.

title: 'NO FORWARDING ADDRES' --AND A SEARCH BEGINS
description: ''EQUALITY for All - We Say, More Pay - Let's Go CIO and Strike!'' said the red, white and blue placards strewn all over the living room floor when I was a little girl.

title: MIDWOOD ADVANCES IN PLAYOFFS, 10-0
description: There was so little time, none could be wasted on worrying, or even huddling. So Midwood got quickly to the line of scrimmage, Anthony Siggia snapped the ball, Robert Cammarato held it, and with one second left in the half, Scott Arbuse sent it sailing through the posts for a 3-0 lead over New Dorp yesterday..

title: WITH FREUD IN MIND
description: First, there was literature before Freud. In it, passions seethed with unconstrained fervor and all the twists, conflicts and perversities that passions often lead to. But no matter what the depth of the author's understanding, emotions seethed with a pre- Freudian innocence; they were not seen as signifying something other than themselves. Hamlet, before John Gielgud and Laurence Olivier endowed him with a moony Oedipal melancholia, could be jealous of his stepfather without being suspected of deep- seated complexes rooted in the pre-Oedipal phase. Mr. Rochester could lose his eyesight in ''Jane Eyre'' without misgivings on Charlotte Bront"e's part that she had a need to castrate her hero before offering him to her heroine. And before modern critics took to explaining them psychoanalytically, such strange cases as Poe's teeth-loving necrophiliacs must have seemed . . . well, simply weird.

title: THREE IN TIRBECA
description: For decades, part of the Manhattan neighborhood now known as Tribeca served as a fresh-food warehouse district where produce dealers, dairymen and wholesale butchers stored their goods. Among the companies that did business in this area was Blue Grass Farms, a cheese importing company.

title: Dawn Williams and Steven Bock, Lawyers, Marry
description: Dawn A. Williams, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis D. Williams of Briarcliff Manor, N.Y., was married yesterday to Steven L. Bock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin H. Bock of New York. The Rev. David H. C. Reed, minister of the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, performed the ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: PITT DOWNS NOTRE DAME, 21-16
description: Pittsburgh scored twice in a span of 46 seconds during the first period today and went on to defeat Notre Dame, 21-16, seriously weakening the Irish's chance of reaching a major bowl game this season.

title:
ART;
NOTED WORKS HIGHLIGHT SCULPTURE SHOW
description: PLEASANT fall days are ideal for visiting the 145-acre outdoor-indoor installation of ''Sculpture: The Tradition in Steel,'' the major new offering at the Nassau County Museum of Fine Art. Those familiar with the development of modern sculpture over the last 50 years will applaud the comprehensiveness and the quantity of important pieces, while others should find this to be an introduction that is both engaging and informative.

title: THE HARD CODE OF THE SUPERCHIEFS
REBELS APPROACH AN ARAFAT REFUGE
description: After three days of heavy shelling, rebel Palestinian guerrillas today approached one of the last strongholds of Yasir Arafat in northern Lebanon and with bull horns urged the defenders to abandon their positions, the police in the northern city of Tripoli said.

title: Pope Sees U.S. Arms Envoy
description: Pope John Paul II held a private audience today with Edward L. Rowny, who heads the United States delegation at the Geneva talks with the Soviet Union on limiting strategic nuclear arms. No details of the meeting, which lasted 20 minutes, were announced.

title: UNCLE SAM AND BABY JANE
description: Even after New York's highest court ruled unanimously that the parents of Baby Jane Doe, an infant born on Long Island last month with severe birth defects, had the right to withhold surgery that would prolong her life, hospital officials and the baby's parents were defending their actions yet again last week - this time in a Federal courtroom.

title: COUNTY TEEN-AGERS COMPETE IN A MAJOR RIDING EVENT
description: ALTHOUGH she just recently turned 15 years old, Francesca Mazella of Mount Kisco plans to jump at a chance to retird today. Not once, but a number of times, over three-and- a-half-foot-high fences while riding a 13-year-old bay named Rugged Rule in front of scores of spectators.

title: POLKA DOTS
description: PHOTOGRAPHS BY ALEXANDER AGOR

title: Mary T. Stowell and Andrew W. Nelson to Marry
description: The engagement of Mary Thayer Stowell to Andrew William Nelson has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Curtis Stowell of Riverside, Conn., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Dr. and Mrs. William James Nelson of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Litchfield, Me.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE CELERY STALKS AT MIDNIGHT By James Howe. Illustrated by Leslie Morrill. 111 pp. New York: Atheneum. $10.95. (Ages 9 to 12)

title: SAVING LOCAL HOUSING GROUPS
NAVY YARD STRUGGLES TO OVERCOME A DISMAL PAST
description: As an economic enterprise, the Brooklyn Navy Yard reached one low point 17 years ago, when the United States Navy packed up and left. It had sunk even lower about two years ago, when City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin said an attempt to redevelop the complex as an industrial park had resulted in ''an economic disaster'' plagued by ''widespread mismanagement and fraud.''

title: BILLS EASE MOBILE-HOME RULES
description: TRENTON THE State Legislature has approved five bills aimed at making manufactured and mobile homes a viable source of affordable housing in New Jersey.

title: STRICTER TEACHER RULES BID
description: education teacher in North Haven, is discouraging his daughter in the 10th grade from becoming a teacher, because, he said, ''teachers are low-paid peons.''

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: SEVENTH and eighth graders from White Plains celebrated the city's 300th anniversary by burying a time capsule they said they hoped would be opened in another 300 years.

title:
CAMERA;
EDITING PRODUCES A MORE INTERESTING SHOW
description: Lou Jacobs Jr. is a freelance photographer who is the author of several books on photography.

title: ATTORNEY GENERAL SAYS HOUSE BLOCKS REFORM
description: In a broadside against the Democratic Party leadership, Attorney General William French Smith has accused House lawmakers of obstructing vital legislation to reform Federal bankruptcy, immigration and criminal laws.

title:
STAMPS;
ISSUE PAYS TRIBUTE TO A CHURCHMAN AND SCHOLAR
description: Acommemorative for the 500th anniversary of the birth of Martin Luther is being issued by the United States this Friday in Washington, D.C., although the issue date had originally been scheduled for Nov. 10, a day earlier.

title:
GARDENING;
AUTUMN LEAVES AND HOW TO USE THEM
description: ONE might well look around at this time of year and wonder if the name for the season was not derived from the fact that this is the season of falling leaves. With the arrival of the first heavy frost, and even before, the leaves of deciduous trees and shrubs begin to fall.

title: CHILDREN'S RADIO TALKS BACK
description: To the Editor:

title: RESORT WASTELAND: CHANGE IS IN SIGHT
description: ATLANTIC CITY TWO decades ago, this resort was a decaying city with little hope for substantial recovery. No section was more blighted than the uptown area near Absecon Inlet, at the northeastern end of town.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Scandinavia to End Bahamas Cruises

title: NO TIME TO INVITE A CRITICAL PRESS
description: To the Editor:

title: CHICAGO WRITERS WINCE AT THEIR REGIONAL LABEL
description: Chicago novelists complain that they are still classified as regional writers even though their city continues to have a rich literary life built on the traditions of Theodore Dreiser, Nelson Algren, James T. Farrell, Ben Hecht and Richard Wright.

title: Penn State Beats Brown, 38-21
description: Touchdown runs of 61 yards by Jon Williams, 55 yards by Kenny Jackson and 44 yards by D. J. Dozier highlighted Penn State's 38-21 victory over Brown today.

title: No Headline
description: Butler Wins 20th Straight Butler, behind the running of

title: TURKS ELECTING FIRST PARLIAMENT SINCE COUP
description: Turks vote Sunday in what some officials think could be a surprisingly close contest between the right-wing Nationalist Democracy Party favored by the military rulers, and the more independent conservative Motherland Party, which has led all the opinion polls and generated the most public enthusiasm.

title: ISLANDERS WIN 5TH IN ROW, 4-0
description: The Islanders, on the mend from a sluggish start this season, won their fifth straight game tonight, beating the Buffalo Sabres, 4-0, and diverting for the moment talk that this will be the season of their dethroning.

title: NEW YORKERS GET APPEAL ON ARSON
description: A subway poster depicting warning signs for arson sent a shiver up Christian Peacock's spine as he traveled uptown recently on the A train. What startled him was a photo of a building that looked strikingly similar to the one he and his wife, Linda, live in.

title: REAGAN MAY EASE NAKASONE'S BLUES
description: It may not be what he had in mind, but when President Reagan arrives for a state visit this week he will probably find himself caught up in a political campaign. No election has been called yet, but signs point to one sometime in the last two weeks of December and that means the politicking is under way.

title: Virginia Mallory Married To Ward Heeth Grantham
description: Virginia Rice Gibbud Mallory of Greenwich, Conn., widow of Henry Rogers Mallory, and Ward Heeth Grantham of Rye, N.Y., a widower, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's son-in-law and daughter, Mr. and Mrs. Bruce S. Beresford, in New Canaan, Conn.

title: IS THERE A FUTURE FOR CULTURAL FARE?
description: When the history of cable television is written, it is likely to be filled with tales of failed visionaries, the people who saw a future that never really worked.

title: CHILDREN'S RADIO TALKS BACK
description: To the Editor:

title: CROSSHATACHED AND WEIRD
description: Edward Gorey (a.k.a. Waredo Dyrge, Dogear Wryde, Deary Rewdgo and D. Awdrey Gore) is master of the macabre picture tale. His idiosyncratic, darkly crosshatched drawings evoke Victorian England.

title: SOME DRUG USE HELD TO LEVEL OFF, BUT CVONGRESSMEN DISPUTE REPORT
description: Marijuana and cocaine use in America have leveled off, the director of the National Institute on Drug Abuse says, although the abuse of heroin and other opiates has not. However, some Congressmen scoffed at the statement and disputed the statistics.

title: No Headline
description: CHARLES P. IANNACONE

title: HOW TV'S ROLE CAN EASE THE CRISIS IN COLLEGE SPORTS
description: ONE of the most amazing things I have ever seen over the years of covering sports happened on a September Sunday at Forest Hills when 19-year-old Martina Navratilova sought political asylum from her homeland and defected to the United States. This was at the United States Open Tennis championships, and this young Czechoslovak girl, in a language not her own, faced the press of the world and later a national television audience with a calm and poise that was astonishing to behold.

title: IN PURSUIT OF HIGH TECHNOLOGY
description: AN INTERESTING series of articles in the New Jersey Weekly described the state's efforts to stimulate the high-technology industry. These policies, involving tax incentives, educational reforms and collaboration among universities and industry, are certainly welcome and should have many benefits to the state beyond the creation of jobs.

title: Muriel W. Camitta Marries
description: Muriel W. Camitta of New York, widow of Herbert S. Camitta, was married yesterday to Dr. Milton Henry Teitel of Springfield, Mass. Rabbi Herbert Schwartz performed the ceremony at Beth El Temple in Springfield. The bridegroom, whose previous marriage ended in divorce, practices psychosomatic medicine.

title: THE HARD CODE OF SUPERCHIEFS
Israel
description: To the Editor:

title: GLASGOW'S TREASURES BELIE ITS GRITTY IMAGE
description: R. W. APPLE Jr. is chief of the London bureau of The New York Times.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: TO HELP establish a framework for monitoring ports and overseeing waterfront development, Borden R. Putnam, Commissioner of the state's Department of Commerce and Economic Development, has named New Jersey's first Coordinator of Maritime Development and appointed its first Maritime Advisory Council.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Who ever said that the art world's Neo- Expressionist bandwagon had passed photography by? Not Allan Chasanoff, whose love of the medium was manifested first as a passionate collector and now as a photographer. His hotly colored still lifes look like photographs to which a runaway Neo-Expressionist painter has added a kind of freewheeling scribble.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Miss Hewett discovered the secret of musical parody six years ago when, at a party celebrating the closing of a musical in which she was appearing on Fire Island, she applied her trained and professionally experienced voice to such songs as ''Indian Love Call'' and ''Romany Life'' and ''Totally Believed Every Word I Sang.'' The result was a gently mad kind of humor that she developed in an act with the gleamingly bald, fiercely mustachioed tenor Norman Rollings and the cellist Faun Stacy.

title: SWALE TRIUMPHS IN YOUNG AMERICA
description: Everyone knew that Woody Stephens trains the best 2-year-old in the country, but now it appears that he has the second-best as well. With his star, Devil's Bag, waiting for the Remsen Stakes next Saturday, Stephens saddled Swale to the narrowest of victories over Disastrous Night tonight in the $412,300 Young America Stakes at Meadowlands Race Track.

title: IRA BERKOWSports of The Times Refs Whistle A Different Tune
description: ONE of the problems with the substitute referees in the National Basketball Association is not that they're so bad, but that they're so good.

title: Record Kicking Wins for East Islip
description: Ken Kanzler kicked two extra points, including his 51st consecutive, and two field goals, including the longest of his career, to help East Islip defeat Hauppauge, 20-11, and clinch the League II title.

title: NEW JERSEY BRIEFS
description: THE Rev. T. James Snodgrass admits to no sympathy with the Reagan Administration, but he concedes grudgingly that ''there's something in this public-private partnership thing that smacks of truth.''

title: North Rockland Streak Ends
description: North Rockland's bubble burst yesterday. The Red Raiders, who had won 25 consecutive games and were ranked second in the state, were upset, 10-0, by their host, Ramapo.

title: ELECTION WILL CAST LONG SHADOW
description: An article on the Green Acres bond issue is on Page 13.

title: BROOKHAVEN GOAL: 'A BIT OF KENTUCKY
description: BROOKHAVEN TOWN has started rezoning existing horse farms under its new horse farm ordinance as part of a program intended to preserve open space in the pine barrens and stimulate economic growth at the same time.

title: EXCERPTS FROM MEETINGS OF NEW JEWEL MOVEMENT
description: Following are excerpts from a typewritten document dated September 20, 1983, that summarizes meetings of the Marxist New Jewell Movement, which controlled the revolutionary Government that ruled Grenada until the Oct. 25 invasion by the United States and Caribbean nations. The document was one of several captured party records that were made public by the State Department late Friday. Comrade Bernard is Bernard Coard, who was Deputy Prime Minister and was detained after the invasion. He helped lead the coup that led to the death of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop. The ''C.C.'' is the party's Central Committee.

title: MULLINS SETS MARK
description: Mike Mullins raced 50 yards for a touchdown en route to setting a school single-game rushing record of 246 yards and leading undefeated Hofstra to a 24-14 victory over Hobart yesterday at rain-soaked Boswell Field in Geneva, N.Y.

title: ACADEMIC FREEDOM AND STONY BROOK RIFT
description: Four letters to the editor in the Oct. 23 issue focus on so-called anti-Semitism at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. Much of what these people, understandably aroused by various - mostly erroneous - reports of anti-Semitism, object to is not correct.

title: Coast Enrollments Down
description: Enrollment in Los Angeles's junior colleges has dropped nearly 12 percent this year, the sharpest decline in the system's 15-year history. Final census figures released Tuesday showed that there were 119,569 students on the nine Los Angeles community college campuses this fall, as against 135,644 a year ago, a decline of 11.9 percent. School officials attributed the enrollment losses to budget cuts, which caused elimination of more than 600 classes this fall.

title: PRIVATE BODY SEEKS $300,000 TO SAVE 3 FORT SUMTER FLAGS
description: A private group headed by Gen. William C. Westmoreland of the Army, retired, is trying to raise $300,000 for the preservation of three flags that flew over Fort Sumter at the beginning and at the end of the Civil War.

title: James T. Farrell
description: To the Editor:

title: CATHOLIC LEAGUE YIELDS 2 STANDOUTS
description: Perhaps it's only logical to expect a run-oriented conference like the Catholic High Schools' Football League to produce exceptional ball carriers each season. Since its formation in 1954, the league has supplied colleges in all divisions with hundreds of halfbacks and fullbacks.

title: Leonard Is Still Boxing's Mr. Nice Guy
description: THE question was written out for

title: REDEEMED IN THE TELLING
description: ARCADIO

title: CUTTING DOWN ON ASBESTOS
description: Industrial use of asbestos began in the United States around 1880, but new things - mostly bad - are being learned about it all the time. Last week, the Labor Department issued an emergency standard to cut exposure to the carcinogenic mineral by 75 percent.

title: 100 Cuban Prisoners Return From Grenada
description: One hundred Cubans who had been taken prisoner came home from Grenada today to a rousing welcome from Fidel Castro, a Communist Party honor guard and a military band.

title: DEMOCRATIC CANDIDATES DISAGREE OVER ADEQUACY OF NUCLEAR FORCE
description: Seven of the eight candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination say they support a nuclear freeze, but they define it differently, partly because they disagree over the adequacy of the nation's nuclear arsenal.

title: BRINGING ARTISTS AND AUDIENCES CLOSER
description: Barry Laine writes frequently on the performing arts.

title: Perplexed Latinist
description: To the Editor:

title: SINISTER BEAUTY INHABITS A NEW ALBUM BY THE STONES
description: The Rolling Stones have the world's hardest act to follow - their own past. Over the past two decades, they have been callow, rude, raucous, perverse, jaded, ironic, decadent, self-important and calmly professional. One thing they haven't been is humble - until now.

title: VOLUNTEERS' CALLS EASE LONLINESS OF ELDERLY
description: Bolton D. Melliss says that despite his 89 years, he still feels ''like hopping around'' with some frequency, still likes to listen to jazz and classical music as he always has and still likes to visit the friends he has in Manhattan, friends who, he says, treat him ''like family.''

title: ARGENTINE LEADER'S FIRST CRISIS WILL BE CASH
description: For Argentina's President-elect, Raul Alfonsin, winning the election may have been the easy part. Now he must govern the nation, and he is under pressure to get started fast. The former congressman who defeated the Peronist candidate, Italo A. Luder, last Sunday, could take over as early as Dec. 10, if he accepts an offer last week by the military Government of President Reynaldo B. Bignone. The offer would move up his scheduled inauguration by nearly two months, a reflection of how much the military wants to get out from under the many pressing crises, after nearly eight years in power.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
NEW CONTROLS FOR LEVERAGED BUYOUTS
description: MANAGEMENT buyouts have suddenly come into vogue. Hardly a week passes without an announcement that a group of top executives, sometimes with an investor group, has decided to take their company private. The typical strategy, also called a leveraged buyout, is to use the corporate assets as collateral for loans to finance the purchase of at least a majority of the company's stock.

title: PINE-TAR ISSUE TO GO TO COURT
description: For two months, George Steinbrenner has been trying to avoid a hearing before Commissioner Bowie Kuhn regarding the Yankee principal owner's behavior during the pine-tar affair last summer. Now Steinbrenner has gone to court as the latest step in his effort to block the hearing.

title: DISAPATCHING THE MARINES
description: INEVITABLE REVOLUTIONS

title: LEIPZIG: BACH, BAROQUE - AND BONSAI
description: MICHAEL H. LEVIN is a lawyer and writer who lives in Washington.

title: OYSTER BAY STILL FIRST
description: Oyster Bay managed a precarious hold on first place in Conference C-Division B yesterday after the intercepting a pass in the fourth quarter and settling for a 14-14 tie with Locust Valley. With two games remaining in the season, Oyster Bay (5-0-1) narrowly leads Locust Valley (4-0-2) in the standing.

title: BEEF AND PORK IN MILK: TENDER RESULTS
description: THE idea of cooking pork or beef in milk is not as strange as it sounds. In Tuscany it has been a common practice for years. Even chicken can be cooked this way. The flesh becomes extraordinarily tender and the milk combines with the cooking juices to form a sauce which has a subtle caramelized flavor.

title: RIVERDALE TROUNCES CARDINAL HAYES
description: Frank Bertino retires this season after 40 years as head coach at the Riverdale School, and his 1983 team is making sure he is going out with happy memories. Yesterday, the undefeated Indians captured their seventh victory this season with a 42-6 trouncing of Cardinal Hayes as Mike Bowman, the star quarterback, scored twice and passed for three touchdowns and a 2-point conversion.

title: CONDO PLAN RUFFLES A HAMLET
description: FROM the lawn of his house in New Suffolk, Jim Pugsley can squint across the North Race of Great Peconic Bay to Robins Island, where he was born, the son of the island's caretaker, 64 years ago.

title: YORKVILLE TURNS CHIC AND COSTLY
description: -class neighborhood of German, Irish and Hungarian immigrants, is gradually becoming part of the Upper East Side to which it had long been attached more by geography than character. The changes are perhaps best revealed not by the impact studies of urban planners, but by taking a walk.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Soft Rental Market

title: Ann Adams Gregory Weds
description: At St. Barnabas Episcopal Church in Irvington, N.Y., yesterday, Ann Adams Gregory was married to Michael A. Cefola by the Rev. Neal Brown, assisted by the Rev. Charles R. Colwell. The bride is the daughter of Macleone T. Gregory of Hartsdale, N.Y., and Alfred L. Gregory of Wilmington, Del. The bridegroom is the son of Alice Cefola of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Dr. Michael Cefola.

title: FLEXIBILITY IS THIS ORCHESTRA'S HALLMARK
description: Nicholas Kenyon is a music critic for The Times of London.

title: YALE COPES WITH FOOTBALL SEASON
description: NO other college football team has won more games than the 722 Yale has over the last 107 years. But as of last Saturday, more than two-thirds of the way through the current season, none of those triumphs had been recorded this fall. The Bulldogs lost their first seven games, something no other Yale football team had done in more than 100 years.

title: Pollution Prompts Warning To Limit Eating of Bluefish
description: Pollution in the Northeast has infected the bluefish population, which is ready for its annual migration to warm Florida waters, and environmental officials are warning people to limit amounts of the fish that they eat.

title: Plea for Disabled
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: SUBURBAN PUPILS WRITE BEST IN A JERSEY EXAM
description: Students in vocational, urban and rural schools cannot write as well as youngsters in suburban and regional districts, according to the results of a State Education Department test.

title: OLDEST OYSTER BOAT IN THE STATE, TOO
description: DORCHESTER NEW JERSEY'S Delaware Bay oyster fleet not only has the newest oyster dredgeboat, it also has the oldest.

title: A TULIP TREE, MORE THAN A TREE, THE STUFF OF LORE
description: THE Indians had the right idea, I try to tell myself. They said you never really owned the land, you merely held the right during your own lifetime to enjoy it, use it, be nourished by it and nourish it in return.

title: No Headline
description: East Side Halts Losing Streak The state's longest current

title: Lab Animals' Blood Pressure Reported Cut by Sweetener
description: NutraSweet, the new sugar substitute used in diet drinks, will lower blood pressure in laboratory animals and may someday be used as a ''medical food'' in people, according to researchers.

title: RACIAL BIAS IS CHARGED IN TRIAL OF TEXAS ENGINEER
description: When Lenell Geter, a young black engineer, was given a life sentence last October after being convicted of robbing a fried- chicken restaurant, the trial did not even make the local newspapers.

title: TO GOOD TO BE TRUE
description: LYDIA ROWE is a New York matron who would seem to be nothing if not well brought up. The family she comes from and the friends she makes value the inner life more than anything - more than parents, love, children, even a career. Ideas and how they are imprinted on the soul and grow from it, are Lydia's sort of people's concerns, as if the inner life were a greenhouse or a first-class restaurant.

title: THE WINTER AFTER THE BOMB
description: Even a limited exchange of nuclear weapons will so blot out the sun with smoke and soot, a group of scientists asserted last week, that life for the survivors will be almost impossible in the ensuing dark and cold. . . . Paramount Pictures has just released ''The Testament,'' a movie about life after The Bomb. . . . In two weeks, ABC will broadcast ''The Day After,'' a movie about a typical American city following a nuclear strike.

title: ERVING LEADS 76ERS OVER NETS, 119-112
description: Stan Albeck, the Nets' coach, figured he had the right idea on how to stop the Philadelphia 76ers: Give his most talented player the responsibility of guarding Julius Erving to try to eliminate the decisive edge he might provide.

title: Hilary Branton Becomes Bride Of B.A. Pellicer
description: Hilary Claire Branton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Branton of Lexington, Mass., was married in Bedford, Mass., yesterday to Baldo Alfredo Pellicer, son of Mr. and Mrs. Luis A. Pellicer of Caracas, Venezuela. The ceremony was performed at Stouffer's Bedford Glen Hotel by Thomas Ferrick, the Humanist chaplain at Memorial Church at Harvard University.

title: TWO REPUBLICANS PLAY THE HEAVY ON DEFICITS
description: ''My role is to remind the President and the Senate leadership of the facts,'' said Senator Pete V. Domenici, New Mexico Republican and chairman of the Budget Committee.

title: Ulster Terrorist Attacks Kill 3 and Wound 49
description: Terrorist violence killed three policemen and wounded 35 other officers and 14 civilians in a period of less than 24 hours ending early today, the police reported.

title: PROGRAM TEACHING ENERGY OPTIONS FOR DEVELOPING COUNTRIES
description: To help developing countries with no domestic oil production lessen their dependence on foreign oil, a Federal agency is sponsoring a program at the University of Florida here to train people to use the sun, the wind and other sources of energy.

title: CLINTON 18-12 OVERTIME VICTOR
description: DeWitt Clinton, which entered the playoffs yesterday as the Public Schools Athletic League's best defensive team, overcame a two-touchdown deficit and defeated Susan Wagner of Staten Island in overtime, 18- 12, on the losers' field.

title: PAST RE-CREATED IN DOG PORTRAITS
description: It was one of those things that seemed to work out exactly right. Nancy Stoddart Huang, an interior designer, was interested in forming a group of artists and artisans called ''The Nineteenth Century'' to make furnishings that would reflect the period style.

title: DANCE: CHANG MU TROUPE FROM KOREA
description: The Chang Mu Dance Company, a group of Korean dancers and Korean- born dancers now living in New York, came to the Theater of the Riverside Church Wednesday night with a program of traditional Korean dances. All were stately in manner and sweet in choreographic flavor.

title: 'A HAPPY ENDING'
description: When the Upper East Side Historic District was created by the Landmarks Preservation Commission in 1981, the owners of three pieces of property on East 62d Street were forced to scrap their plan to add floors to two existing dwellings and put up an apartment building on the vacant lot next to the Knickerbocker Club. But now, under a new plan, the owners, Viewpoint Industries, have started construction at the properties, which have the address 4-6 East 62d Street.

title: MUSIC: CEDAR WALTON ON PIANO
description: The pianist Cedar Walton's quartet played fast and loose with tempos Thursday as it opened a four-night stand at Seventh Avenue South.

title: ILLEGAL BODEGAS FACE CRACKDOWN
description: The customers come from upstairs, down the block and around the corner at the Diaz and Garcia Superette in the Fordham section of the Bronx.

title: Illinois Passes Law on Data
description: Illinois has become the last state in the nation to pass a law guaranteeing the public and journalists access to Government records. The decision came Wednesday as the Senate voted, 55 to 0, to accept changes Gov. James R. Thompson made in the bill on freedom of information approved by the State Legislature in June.

title: photos of Mata Layne Collins, Jim Bunning; KENTUCKIANS EXPECT A NEW LOOK IN POLITICS, WHOEVER WINS GOVERNORSHIP
description: Voters here expect Kentucky politics to have a much different look over the next four years no matter who is elected Governor Tuesday.

title: Communication Links Into Grenada Restored
description: Telephone communications from Grenada were restored today after a communications blackout of nearly two weeks caused by equipment damage sustained in the Oct. 25 United States landing on the island.

title: HOUSING IN BROWNSVILLE PROGRESSES
description: AFTER months of bureaucratic delays, the Nehemiah Plan - an ambitious undertaking to build 1,000 single-family homes for low-income families on 20 nearly vacant blocks in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn - is moving ahead at last and construction is in progress, according to I.D. Robbins, who is developing the project with his cousin.

title: WOMEN AND THE CHURCH
description: Kenneth A. Briggs is the religion editor of The New York Times. GNES MARY MANSOUR LISTENED intently as the Vatican's ultimatum was read to her at the Sisters of Mercy provincial house in Detroit: resign her post as director of social services for the State of Michigan or become subject to a canonical process that would lead to an imposed dismissal from the religious order she had been a member of for 30 years. At issue was her position on abortion. Although she had personally disavowed the practice before her appointment, she had indicated that she would ''tolerate the use of Federal funds for abortion'' in the performance of her secular duties. Such an action, she said, would be ''a vote for the poor rather than a vote for abortions.''

title: GRENADIANS WELCOMED INVASION, A POLL FINDS
description: An overwhelming majority of the people of Grenada welcomed the United States invasion of their island, according to a poll conducted Thursday by CBS News. They felt that American troops had come to free them from the Cubans and prevent the construction of a military base.

title: Detroit Audit Finds Misuse
description: An audit submitted to the City Council says payroll padding and misuse of police money may have cost Detroit taxpayers millions of dollars. The audit submitted by Marie Farrell-Donaldson, auditor-general for the city, said Wednesday that time sheets might have been padded so officers were paid at retirement for time they did not work. Mrs. Farrell- Donaldson said her office made 17 recommendations to the police and waited for a reply for a year before releasing the study under Council pressure. Comdr. William Dwyer of the polcie said the department did respond in writing to all items in the audit.

title: ACADEMIC FREEDOM AND STONY BROOK RIFT
description: The academic-freedom issues raised by the inquiry into State University at Stony Brook Prof. Ernest Dube's allegedly racist stance must trouble both scholars and citizens concerned about preserving cherished values. An inquiry by colleagues of Professor Dube resulted in a finding that he had not violated any principle of academic conduct. There the matter should have ended, and it would have but for the unnecessary and harmful intervention by a former law professor, Governor Cuomo.

title: DRILLING RIGHTS SOUGHT
description: ANATURAL GAS prospector, Mark Burke, calls the Connecticut Valley ''the most rank wildcat situation I've ever heard of.'' But Mr. Burke's exploration company, under contract for a major American oil company, will drill for oil and natural gas there if enough landowners agree to lease their mineral rights, and seismic tests prove promising.

title:
ABOUT WESTCHESTER;
COLLEGE ADMISSIONS: THE INS AND OUTS
description: IT is early November, and what

title: THE GRANDEST OF THE GRAND HOTELS
description: SUSAN HELLER ANDERSON is a reporter for The New York Times.

title: HARTFORD TRADITION: 'ELECTION CAKE'
description: HARTFORD WHILE Hartford lays claim to producing one of the first foods identified with American politics, relatively few ''Hartford Election Cakes'' are expected to be served in the state's capital this Tuesday, compared with two centuries ago.

title: ROLLE-SKATING STARS SEEKING RESPECT FOR THEIR SPORT
description: With horns blaring and passengers screaming, waving and peering from sunroofs, eight cars and a custom van snaked through East Meadow and Levittown last Sunday.

title: Linda L. Cornelius and E. H. Vick Jr., Advertising Executives, Are Married
description: Linda Louise Cornelius, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adam E. Cornelius Jr. of Buffalo and Jupiter, Fla., was married yesterday to Edward Hoge Vick Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Vick of Haverford, Pa. The Rev. Thomas P. Stewart performed the ceremony at the Westminster Presbyterian Church in Buffalo.

title: SMOKING WITHOUT THE LABEL
description: In a year marked by sharp price increases, fierce marketing and sagging sales, the tobacco industry has, perhaps unwillingly, made one thing clear: Consumers are more than happy to pay less for cigarettes.

title: LOOK BACK, LOOK FORWARD
description: One year from now, the American people will choose a President for the last years of the 1980's. Nobody can foretell their answer, but at the beginning it might be useful to get the questions straight.

title: ; THE HARD CODE OF THE SUPERCHIEFS
description: Barbara Gelb's article ''The Hard Code of the Superchiefs'' (Oct. 9) disturbed me greatly. As a sociologist, I have long been interested in the human toll of bureaucratic work, and I was saddened by the picture of psychological and emotional wreckage which it portrayed. I felt for Milton Schwartz and Daniel Courtenay and for the dozens and probably hundreds of cops who have had their bodies and their psyches ground up by the bureaucratic machinery and the nature of their particular bureaucratic work. It is sad because, as human beings, we are all so vulnerable to similar pressures.

title: KAFAVIAN SISTERS, MARLBORO COMING
description: COME next weekend, the extraordinarily rich harvest of chamber music in Connecticut will be richer still: music from Marlboro begins its annual series at Stamford's Trinity Episcopal Church Saturday at 8, while the Wilton Candlelight series opens at 4 Sunday afternoon at the Congregational Church. Both programs are scheduled within a few days of duplicate concerts at Alice Tully and Carnegie Halls, so you can get New York City quality without New York City prices or parking problems.

title: SCORELESS ON THE YEAR
description: The perfect Christmas gift for a sportscaster, as all fans of sports cliches know, is a scoreless tie. The Squad Squad frowns on that locution, insisting that all scoreless games are tied, but those less finicky about redundancy argue that not all ties are scoreless: After the gift of a scoreless tie, what ensues is the eagerly sought ''sudden death.''

title: 'THE' GAME IS TOO GREAT TO BE MISSED
description: ON this page a few weeks ago was an article by David Halohan, a Yale graduate, explaining why he would not be attending the Yale-Harvard football game on Nov. 19. This is an open letter to him, and to all other Yale graduates who are thinking of staying home.

title: CAN CARROLL O'CONNOR SHAKE OFF ARCHIE BUNKER?
description: PHILADELPHIA

title: RAISING THE CHILD MAKES THE PARENT
description: SURRENDERING a child for adoption can only be one of life's greatest losses. The mother who gives up her child does so for many reasons. Among them, the fact that she cannot provide for the physical, economic and emotional needs of her infant. In an agency setting, the natural mother is counseled and supported and informed of all alternatives. Only then does she painfully make her decision with the aid of a social worker. In most private adoptions, she surrenders her child to a lawyer who places the child with the adoptive family. She may or may not know in what part of the country the child will be placed or something of the adoptive parent's background. She is left alone with her loss and her questions.

title: Suspect Found Guilty Of Second Coast Killing
description: Angelo Buono Jr. was convicted today of a second murder in the 10 killings in the late 1970's that the police called the hillside stranglings.

title: Nohilly Wins Title Race
description: Racing along the straightaway toward the finish line in yesterday's Catholic High Schools Athletic Association cross-country championships in Van Cortlandt Park, Msgr. McClancy's Tom Nohilly ''was wondering when he was going to pass me.''

title: U.S. Envoy's Home Attacked
description: Unidentified gunmen in a speeding car fired on the residence of the United States Ambassador here Friday night. An embassy spokesman said today that no one was hurt and that the Ambassador, Frederic L. Chapin, had been out of the country for a week.

title: STEEL AND PATIENCE
description: To the Business Editor:

title: 3 Arrested in Brick-Throwing At Virginia Anti-Nazi Protest
description: Demonstrators threw bricks and bottles at about two dozen members of a Nazi group who held their annual ''White Pride Day'' at a public school tonight.

title: OBJECTIONS TO AN UNWITNESSED WAR
description: Journalists and Congressional leaders, including many who approved of the invasion, were outraged by what some saw as an assault on the public's right to know. The Senate voted, 53 to 18, that the restrictions should ''cease.''

title: PUBLIC ADVOCATE RUNS A TIGHT SHIP
description: THE state's Department of the Public Advocate has been directed for the last year and a half by Joseph H. Rodriguez, who replaced Stanley C. Van Ness. In that time, a debate has arisen over the effectiveness of the department.

title: CHANNEL 34: JOHN Q. CITIZEN'S STATION
description: WITH the recent debut of Channel 34 on local cable television, the City of White Plains has become the first municipality in the state to own a public-access channel.

title: COLUMBIA IS TIED ON DARTMOUTH KICK
description: A 32-yard field goal by Craig Saltzgaber on the game's last play gave Dartmouth a 17-17 tie with Columbia at Giants Stadium today.

title: THE QUANTUM MECHANICS OF POLITICS
description: Flora Lewis writes the Foreign Affairs column for The New York Times. This essay is based on a speech delivered at Johns Hopkins University.

title: No Headline
description: LEO J. M. PIERRE Leo J. M. Pierre, Marine Midland Bank's representative for United Nations and consular affairs, died of a heart attack last Monday at Roosevelt Hospital.

title: BIAS AWARD THROWN OUT
description: In the view of Federal District Judge Joseph E. Stevens Jr., a Kansas City jury didn't really know what it was doing three months ago when it awarded Christine Craft $500,000 in a fraud and sex-discrimination suit against her former employer.

title: 'AMERICAN BUFFALO' PROVES ITS QUALITY
description: One of the surest ways of ending up with a minor play is to strive to write a major play. On the other hand, a dramatist who seems determined to be minor may sometimes produce major work. His or her play looks weightless, sounds weightless, even feels weightless; and then you find that it has inexplicably but indisputably tipped your mental and emotional scales. It shrugs its way onto the stage, apologetically shuffles off it, and won't be forgotten. An example from the 1960's would be Harold Pinter's ''The Caretaker,'' which is, on the face of it, about nothing more than an elderly tramp battening off two brothers. One from the 70's would be the two-hour trifle just returned to Broadway: David Mamet's ''American Buffalo.''

title: GENERAL FOODS DIGESTS A BIG MEAL
description: Almost a year after the General Foods Corporation paid $315 million for the big Entenmann's Inc. bakery, any fears analysts nursed that General Foods might suffer pangs of indigestion seem to have disappeared.

title: INVENTOR SAYS HE'S IGNORED
description: WALDWICK THE head of a pharmaceutical company in this Bergen County community said last week that state and Federal environmental agencies are ignoring a process he has patented for the safe and inexpensive cleanup of hazardous-waste dumps.

title: DISK SPAN CENTURIES OF BRITISH MUSIC
description: Edward Schneider writes frequently on music.

title: L.I. RIDERS VIE FOR A TOP TROPHY
description: EARLY this morning, hours before most New Yorkers had groped their way out of bed, 100 of the nation's best teen- age equestrians were set to assemble at Madison Square Garden.

title: CRIME
description: Almost 10 years ago the British writer Christopher Leach wrote ''The Send Off,'' the plot of which centered around the bleeding body of a Christ-like figure. All kinds of parables and interpretations suggested themselves. Now comes TEXAS STATION (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $14.95), and again there are religious connotations swirling around another Christ figure.

title: Jeanine Love and Charles E. Dropkin Are Married
description: At the Fifth Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan yesterday, Jeanine Love, daughter of Drs. Sidney and Shirley Love of the Riverdale section of the Bronx, was married to Charles Edward Dropkin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Dropkin of Lake Worth, Fla.

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: TWO state advisory councils are preparing a report for Governor Kean on acid rain. It will be a basis for the Governor's first concrete proposal on the subject, which he will present to the Council of Northeast Governors (CONEG) next month.

title: WHO ARE THIS MOVIE'S REAL HEROES?
description: When Tom Wolfe wrote about the Mercury astronauts in ''The Right Stuff,'' he redefined their heroism in terms that a whole new generation could understand. The astronauts' ''own'' (they worked closely with the staff of Life magazine) account of their exploits, ''We Seven,'' was written in 1962 and presents an outstandingly bland portrait geared to the American temperament of that time. ''What kind of man,'' the Life writers' introduction asks, ''would be strong enough physically to sustain the tremendous stresses and strains of a flight through space, and then be wise enough - and strong enough in other ways - to sustain the pressures of public adulation when he returned home?'' The answers prove to be as upbeat and unsurprising as the question is rhetorical.

title: AGENCIES SEEKING JOBS FOR 145 JOLTED BY THE CLOSING OF A PLANT
description: Some had worked at the Brooklyn plant for more than 20 years. Some had never worked anywhere else. Their pay averaged more than $300 a week, and many were paying to give their children better educations than they themselves had received.

title: PAPERBACK BESTSELLERS MASS MARKET Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. title: 2-MONTH U.S. STAY ON GRENADA SEEN
description: The head of the first Congressional delegation to visit Grenada since the American invasion said today that it was possible that American troops might be needed on the Caribbean island ''into the next year.''

title: FINANCING FOR LAND IS SOUGHT
description: TRENTON PROCEEDS from the Green Acres Opportunities Bond Issue, if approved by the voters Tuesday, would be used to create a revolving trust fund for the state's Green Acres program.

title: LINCOLN NEVER JOGGED
description: At dinner this woman is telling me about her weight. She is up to 105 pounds and wonders whether she dare eat dessert. I think she should eat five or six desserts because she looks as if a quick whisk of my napkin could blow her off her chair, but naturally I keep quiet.

title: THERE'S MORE THAN ONE WAY OF VIEWING DANCE
description: Two dancer-choreographers have just created pieces in which a ''double front'' concept played a prominent role. In each case, the audience was supposed to be divided into two parts - one with a frontal view, the other to one side, at right angles to the first. Each choreographer tended to keep her dancers moving on a diagonal path. And yet surprisingly and tellingly, the result of this ''double front'' concept was different for each choreographer.

title: HALF-POINT DENT IN UNEMPLOYMENT
description: It can't have been much consolation for the 9.9 million Americans who are still out of work, but the Government reported last week that joblessness among the civilian work force had dropped to its lowest level in 20 months.

description: Mr. and Mrs. David Smahl of Brooklyn and Palm Beach, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Nancy Ann Smahl, to Dr. Steven B. Syrop, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard C. Syrop of Brooklyn. The wedding is to be in April.

description: PETER SHARPE is a writer based in New York; his book of verse, ''Lost Goods & Stray Beasts,'' is to be published by Rowan Tree Press.

description: The proposed $1.25 billion transportation bond issue in New York State, the election of the entire Legislature in New Jersey and mayoral contests in Connecticut's three largest cities will highlight off- year elections Tuesday in the New York metropolitan region.

title: THE LIFE OF A TOWN MANAGER'S WIFE
description: DAYS dwindling down to a precious few can be as true of a career as of a summer season. My husband, Stephen, came to Farmington as its second Town Manager in 1955 and 28 1/2 years later we are still here. He had always planned on retiring after 30 years, when he will be 63 years old. Somebody told me the other day that 30 minus 28 1/2 equals 1 1/2. It cannot be true.

title: OPERA: ENSEMBLE IN 'SCARF' AND 'BOOR'
description: The Opera Ensemble of New York's double bill at the Lillie Blake School Friday night began with enough common characteristics to bind both halves together. The two pieces are ''The Scarf'' by Lee Hoiby and ''The Boor'' by Dominick Argento. Both are one-act plays by American composers in their middle 50's, and both are based on stories by Chekhov.

title: SUCCESS MAKES REBELS BOLDER IN EL SALVADOR
description: The United States has provided nearly $1 billion in economic and military aid to El Salvador since the guerrilla war began in 1979, but American military advisers last week found small cause for satisfaction. In the past two months, they said, leftist insurgents have regained the initiative, attacking more than 60 towns in nine of the country's 14 provinces and killing more than 800 Salvadoran soldiers.

title: Dr.MinoruAraki,63,IsDead; Medical Examiner in Nassau
description: Dr. Minoru Araki, deputy chief medical examiner of Nassau County, died of a heart attack last Thursday at his office in East Meadow, L.I. He was 63 years old and lived in Syosset, L.I.

title: Blue Ridge

title: FOR A MUSICIAN, WORK CAN BE THE PITS
description: THEY perform in relative anonymity, known only to each other, to relatives, friends and a handful of producers and contractors.

title: PIANO: DANIEL BLUMENTHAL
description: Daniel Blumenthal is completing work for a doctorate at the Juilliard School, but he is already an accomplished pianist, with several recordings to his credit and a series of awards.

title: RIGHTS CHAIRMAN FEELING WRONGED
description: As Congress lurched its way toward saving his agency last week, the chairman of the United States Commission on Civil Rights objected to the terms of the prospective rescue. Clarence M. Pendleton Jr., the chairman, maintained that it was no answer to transform the commission - 26 years old, and due to die on Nov. 29 - into an arm of Congress, as some propose to do.

title: MAJOR NEWS IN SUMMARY
description: WITH the blasting of an Israeli command post, sustained attacks on Yasir Arafat's last defenses and more sniping against the Marines, violence in Lebanon continued unabated last week. Israel retaliated against Palestinian positions in the central mountains and threatened follow-up action against Syria, which the Israelis blamed for permitting terrorist attacks. Damascus denied it was responsible.

title: U.S. AND SOVIET VIE AT JERSEY PARLEY
description: The official Soviet and American positions on arms control were brought to New Jersey today in what turned out to be a competition of diplomatic, or undiplomatic, styles.

title: Schlichter Ruling Due
description: Ohio athletic officials expect to rule on Nov. 18 whether Art Schlichter, the suspended Baltimore Colt quarterback, will be allowed to play basketball for Ohio University-Chillicothe. Schlichter, who never graduated from Ohio State, wants to play for Chillicothe while working toward his degree.

title: Ann Larkin Wed To Keith J. Smith
description: Ann Therese Larkin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Francis X. Larkin of Montclair and Point Pleasant, N.J., was married yesterday to Keith J. Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Smith of Lincoln, R.I. Msgr. Vincent P. Coburn, assisted by the Rev. Daniel A. Danik, performed the ceremony at St. Thomas the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Bloomfield, N.J.

title: EX-NATIONAL LEAD CHAIRMAN
description: Joseph A. Martino, former chairman of the National Lead Company and former vice chairman of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, died Friday at the Ozanam Nursing Home in Bayside, Queens. He was 83 years old and lived in Manhasset, L.I.

title: WARSAW BARS SCHOLARS' TRIP
description: The Polish Government has barred nine scholars from attending an academic conference in Chicago in retaliation for the United States invasion of Grenada, according to a University of Illinois professor.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
TRACKING ONE'S LIFE THROUGH SONG
description: MY stereo receiver went on the fritz last month. Before taking it to be repaired I asked my-son-the-engineer's advice.

title: EXCERPTS FROM LETTER
description: Following are excerpts from Pope John Paul II's letter on Martin Luther, dated Oct. 31, and addressed to Johannes Cardinal Willebrands, Archbishop of Utrecht. The letter, which was written in German, was translated by The Associated Press from a text in Italian released today by the Vatican.

title: Celtics Top Bullets
description: Larry Bird scored 28 points tonight to lead the Boston Celtics to their fourth straight victory, 120-114, over the Washington Bullets.

title: TV WILL RECALL THE KENNEDY YEARS
description: It is likely that John F. Kennedy was elected President because of television; it is certain that once in office he used

title: THOUGH ISSUES ARE LOCAL, CONTESTS ARE HARD-FOUGHT
description: BRIDGEPORT CHARLES B. TISDALE, the Democratic mayoral candidate, had just finished urging a group of elderly people to ''give me a chance'' on Election Day when a woman asked if John C. Mandanici, the former Mayor of Bridgeport, would be on the ballot.

title: NEW VCR DOUBLES AS A HOMEBODY OR A FOOTLOOSE TRAVELER
description: Amachine to watch television for you would greatly simplify one's life. That is exactly the conclusion reached by some five million Americans who have already bought a video cassette recorder - VCR for short. To say that this gadget watches television for you isn't just speaking metaphorically. It will turn itself on at preset times, switch itself to the proper channel, and tune in whatever program you want to see even if you are not there to see it. What the machine watches all gets taped for you so you can watch the program whenever you want. In addition, the device is capable of playing all the movies and other ''software'' now available on prerecorded tape, turning your home into a permanent film festival.

title: Denise Johnston Becomes a Bride
description: Denise Ann Johnston, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William S. Johnston of Tarrytown, N.Y., and Robert Soaff Cypher Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Cypher of White Plains, were married yesterday. The Rev. Matthias DesLauriers performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Church of the Transfiguration in Tarrytown.

title: A HOSPITAL LIBRARY FOR CHILDREN
description: Tucked away in a hospital on a shelf in a children's library - seats four inches off the ground, tables not quite knee high - are two books by Deborah and James Howe.

title: COHALAN-HALPIN: QUIET CAMPAIGN NEARS END
description: GOING into the final two days of the Suffolk County Executive's race, there's clearly a contrasting mood in the two major camps. Peter F. Cohalan's people have never sounded more confident since the race began. The Republican incumbent ''had a big lead going into this campaign, and there's every evidence he's been able to hold it,'' said Howard DeMartini, Mr. Cohalan's campaign manager.

title: SOVIET'S GRIP ON AFGHANS CALLED TIGHT
description: MilitaryAnalysis

title: Settlement Reached In Key Chrysler Strike
description: A tentative settlement was reached today in the fifth day of a strike by 3,200 Chrysler Corporation workers that idled 20,000 other employees nationwide and threatened the company's financial standing.

title: THE HARD CODE OF THE SUPERCHIEFS --
description: Commissioner McGuire is quoted in Barbara Gelb's article as saying, ''Before Knapp and Commissioner Murphy, the Police Department was rotten to the core.''

title: Aston Villa Upsets Manchester United, 2-1
description: Aston Villa upset Manchester United, 2-1, today in an English League First Division soccer match and ended Manchester United's seven-game winning streak.

title: A RUSSIAN TUG TOWS SUB TOWARD CUBA
description: A Soviet tugboat began towing a disabled Soviet submarine toward Cuba today from the point about 500 miles off the South Carolina coast where the submarine had been stranded, Navy officials said.

title: Fodor Robbed in City; He Cancels a Concert
description: Eugene Fodor, the violinist, was robbed at knifepoint and punched in the stomach Friday evening as he walked along West 78th Street near his apartment, the police said yesterday.

title: TWO YALE STUDENTS VIE FOR CITY OFFICE
description: ONE of the more unusual political battles in Connecticut this year has been fought on the Yale University campus. Two Yale seniors, beneficiaries of a New Haven redistricting quirk that created a ward composed almost entirely of Yale students, are running against each other for First Ward alderman.

title: E.P.A. TICKS OFF SOME BIG ITEMS ON ITS AGENDA
description: The Environmental Protection Agency and its new Administrator, William D. Ruckelshaus, had something for almost everybody last week. They pleased the chemical industry by delaying revision of the Federal pesticide control laws, made environmentalists happy by reversing a policy to ease water quality rules, and gave sheep ranchers a lift by ending an 11-year ban on coyote poison.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: Gerald Jonas writes about science fiction for The Book Review. DRAMOCLES

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Quality Wares Created By an Ancient Craft Louis Sclafani Design is a single- minded business in Port Chester: the creation of hand-blown glassware as Christmas tree ornaments, seethrough Thanksgiving pumpkin- shaped vases, decorative ''pillows,'' ''bag'' vases, capacious serving plates or bowls and munchy containers. Mr. Sclafani has a photograph on the wall of his display room showing his Venetian master, Loredano Rosin, executing a glass sculpture using methods, tools and techniques thousands of years old.

title: Trenton Girl Is Second In National Track Poll
description: Clinton Davis, a sprinter from Pennsylvania, and Lisa Bernhagen, a high jumper from Idaho, have been named 1983 high school athletes of the year by Track & Field News.

title: SENATORS WARNED OF DAMAGE FACING HISTORIC SHIPWRECKS
description: Reagan Administration officials have testified in support of legislation to protect historic shipwrecks from plundering, a bill that could put a celebrated Florida salvage specialist out of business.

title:
INVESTING;
NOT MANY GRANDMAS BUY NEW CARS
description: The rich are getting richer and more numerous. But the ranks of the poor are growing,

title: THE INTERNATIONAL SCENE HAS RENEWED ALLURE FOR TRUDEAU
description: For months, Canadian politicians have expected Pierre Elliott Trudeau to announce his retirement, after nearly 15 years as Prime Minister, at a big Liberal Party fund-raising dinner in December. But this ''Last Supper,'' as it has been irreverently dubbed in Canada, has lost some of its luster. Mr. Trudeau is now expected to delay his decision at least until January, and speculation is mounting that he may not quit after all.

title: A RICH HARVEST OF MARITIME HISTORY
description: WILLIAM L. TAZEWELL, a lifelong resident of Norfolk, Va., is the author of ''Norfolk's Waters'' (Windsor).

title: Boddicker's Ordeal
description: He is, according to his mother, ''just a common, plain boy,'' and when he stood up to address a crowd of neighbors representing almost half the population of his hometown at a dinner in his honor Friday night, he was understandably nervous. ''The only time I shook this bad,'' Mike Boddicker told 300 people gathered in the community building in Norway, Iowa, ''was my first at-bat in the World Series.''

title: IS HIGHER EDUCATION IN THE DARK AGES?
description: Arnold Beichman has taught political science at several universities in the United States and Canada and is now a Visiting Scholar at the Hoover Institution on War, Revolution and Peace at Stanford University. By Arnold Beichman OMETHING BEAUTIFUL HAS disappeared from American academic life. With its departure, the quality of teaching and the will to learn have diminished and the sense of the university as an adventure in ideas has gone, perhaps forever.

title: GUILFORD MAKES RECYCLING PROFITABLE
description: IT was a chilly, overcast October

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Syrians are moving at a very rapid rate in a direction which can only lead, if it continues, toward confrontation.'' - David Kimche, Director General of the Israeli Foreign Ministry. (1:4.)

title: U.S. LOOKING INTO COMPLAINT OF HOUSING BIAS IN NORWALK
description: Federal officials are investigating accusations that the city has discriminated against poor people by concentrating subsidized housing in one section of Norwalk.

title: WARS' FORGOTTEN EDDIES
description: Countries have been wrong before without being dishonest. We are being dishonest wanting to be both a democracy and an imperial center (nowadays called a world power). Although seemingly the best of both worlds, the combination - democracy and world power - is finally corrupting. Rome discovered as much, as more recently did Britain. Democracy lives by negotiation, empire by imposition. Combining them breeds hypocrisy.

title: Adrienne Rivers Weds Frank Pappas
description: Adrienne Stevens Rivers, daughter of Wayland Coats Rivers Jr. and Jo Ellen Finley, both of Austin, Tex., was married yesterday to Frank Richard Pappas, son of Billie Pappas of San Bernardino, Calif., and the late George Frank Pappas. The Rev. Stephen Whitfield performed the ceremony at St. David's Episcopal Church in Austin.

title: THE NEW AMERICAN ACTOR
TELLING PICKENS THAT IT WON'T BE EASY
description: ONE of the proudest possessions of James E. Lee, the mild- mannered chairman of the Gulf Oil Corporation, is a pair of fine Browning shotguns. Once or twice a year, Mr. Lee, a distant kin of Civil War General Robert E. Lee, disappears into the wilds of Texas or Georgia to shoot game birds, taking the catch home to Pittsburgh for mounting over the fireplace.

title: U.S. CALLS OFF SEARCH FOR KOREAN PLANE WRECKAGE
description: The Defense Department announced today that the search had been called off for wreckage of the Korean Air Lines 747 shot down over the Sea of Japan Sept. 1 by a Soviet fighter plane.

title: TEXAS FIELD GOALS OVERCOME HOUSTON
description: Jeff Ward, a freshman, made field goals of 20, 51 and 47 yards, the last with 4 minutes 37 seconds to play, to help Texas defeat Houston, 9-3, today in a Southwest Conference game.

title: PRACITCAL TRAVELER
description: Americans shopping for bargains abroad - beware. There's a quirky little mechanism used in many countries that looks like a bargain and sounds like a bargain and may even be a bargain, if it doesn't prove to be more trouble for you than it's worth.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Sidney Johnson is a baritone of taste, refinement and innate musicality. A native New Yorker, Mr. Johnson is a graduate of the High School of Music and Art, who later studied at the Hartt College of Music in Hartford and recently completed a master's degree in musicology at Brooklyn College. Last Sunday afternoon, accompanied by Paul Liljestrand, Mr. Johnson made his debut at Carnegie Recital Hall.

title: OIL PRICES DECLINE AS SUPPLIES HOLD
description: FOR the more than 600,000 Long Island homeowners who use fuel oil, the price is expected to be lower this season, with ample supplies on hand, according to oil industry officials.

title: LEHMAN'S HARRIS A TRIPLE THREAT
description: He can run, he can pass, he can kick. He plays football, basketball, baseball and runs track. But it isn't only his athletic ability that helps Kevin Harris move the football down the field.

title: AN UPSTATE FOCUS FOR ELEANOR ROOSEVELT CENTENNIAL
description: A yearlong centennial observance of the birth of Eleanor Roosevelt will begin next Thursday at 6 P.M. with an ecumenical religious service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in Manhattan.

title: LETTER FROM AN EX-TENANT IN HOBOKEN
description: DEAR MR. LANDLORD:

title: U.S. ENVOYS WARN SALVADOR ON DEATH SQUADS
description: As part of an effort to press the Salvadoran Army to discipline officers suspected of involvement in rightist assassination squads, United States diplomats here have warned the Government that further resistance could result in substantial aid cutbacks.

title: STUDIES OF THE EAR MAY LEAD TO IMPORVED AUDIO
description: The only vital audio component is usually taken for granted and given little thought even though it is a superb design - dating back millions of years - whose origin is debated by biologists and theologians.

title: Iran Says 11 Died In Iraqi Missile Strikes
description: Iraqi missiles bombarded the Iranian city of Andimishk today, killing 11 people, wounding 87 and damaging hundreds of homes and shops, the Iranian press agency said.

title: POPE PRAISES LUTHER IN AN APPEAL FOR UNITY ON PROTEST ANNIVERSARY
description: Pope John Paul II, in a letter issued today, praised Martin Luther, the father of the Reformation who was excommunicated from the Roman Catholic Church, saying the world is still ''experiencing his great impact on history.''

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: Gandhi Starring Ben Kingsley, directed by Richard Attenborough, 1983 RCA/Columbia 188 minutes. $79.95

title: Airport Security
description: To the Editor: I don't know where John Brannon Albright (Practical Traveler, Oct. 9) got the idea that travelers have a right to ''hand'' in

title: TREES IN BLACK FOREST SHOWING SWIFT DECLINE
description: The fabled Black Forest of southwest Germany, whose dark wooded hills have exerted an almost mystical hold on human imagination since Roman times, is subtly but rapidly declining.

title: AT A CROSSROAD IN SOUTH AFRICA
description: JOHANNESBURG NEARLY seven years have passed since the Rev. Leon H. Sullivan, civil rights activist and director of the General Motors Corporation, hammered out a set of principles designed to garner equality for blacks at the South African subsidiaries of American companies. Though these concerns have invested only $2.5 billion in the Republic of South Africa - one-fifth of all foreign investment in the nation - they loom large in several key sectors, and Mr. Sullivan hoped that the labor policies they established would ripple through the economy.

title: NEW BOAT FOR OYSTERING
description: DORCHESTER ZADA L. MORGAN had a bottle of champagne ready, and relatives, friends and a gaggle of politicians were standing by for a special event in this tiny Cumberland County hamlet.

title:
ART ;
FACETS OF NEO-EXPRESSIONISM
description: EXPRESSIONISM, one of the dominant impulses in 20th- century art, has been characterized by an overriding concern with the subjective and the impulsive, giving form to what the painter Max Beckmann called ''the terrible fury of the senses.''

title:
ANTIQUES;
GIFTS FOR GIVING AT NORWALK SHOW
description: NORMAL people, as collectors refer to their friends who like Swedish and modern and other 20th-century furnishings, have no trouble shopping for holiday gifts. If they see an attractive item, they can order six or a dozen for friends and acquaintances.

title: REVIVAL OF THE PORTRAIT
description: A portrait is a likeness in which there is something wrong about the mouth. - John Singer Sargent.

title: FROM THE BATTLEFIELD OF BEIEFS
description: IN THE LAND OF ISRAEL

title: Nuptials Planned By Miss Nicholas
description: Dr. and Mrs. William Nicholas of New Hyde Park, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Gillian Nicholas, to Thomas Gilbert Gabriel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert R. Gabriel of White Plains.

title: A DEVICE TO SUMMON HELP
description: ON a recent fall day, Kate Hammerling was wearing bluejeans, a gingham shirt, and, hanging from a chain around her neck, a plastic medallion that could save her from serious injury. Miss Hammerling, a 20-year-old student at Manhattanville College, has cerebral palsy, and the disk she wears is a remote-control device that summons help if she is alone and has an accident.

title: FAROAM LINCOLN LETTERS TO INDIAN BLANKETS
description: Americana continues to skyrocket in price, setting records at auction and commanding the same or higher prices in shops and galleries. Last month's sales of period furniture, folk art, historical autographs and American Indian art chalked up some stunning sales successes in several categories for at least three excellent reasons: a noticeable resurgence of buying attributed to a restored confidence in the economy; the major material up for bidding, and the presence of more than a few serious collectors and dealers actively buying.

title: THE TULSA BALLET LEAPS INTO NEW YORK
description: The Tulsa Ballet came into being as an accident of fate. ''I became pregnant,'' Moscelyne Larkin explains cheerfully. She and her husband, Roman Jasinski, the founders and directors of the company, have left little else to chance in the 27 years since the Tulsa Ballet danced its first performances. The troupe that audiences will see on Friday through next Sunday in New York debut performances at the Brooklyn Center at Brooklyn College, is now a leading American regional ballet company with a distinctive look and style and an unusually well-rounded repertory of ballets.

title: ZAIRE DETAINS 2 U.S. REPORTERS
description: Two reporters for The Baltimore Sun were detained for eight days in Zaire and interrogated by security police, the newspaper reported today.

title: TROUBLE FROM BOTH SIDES IN EL SALVADOR
description: American Embassy officials, concerned over the Government's lagging battle against leftist guerrillas, are also increasingly worried about the shadowy war launched by right-wing terrorists against democratic institutions. Embassy officials said last week they had been unsuccessfully pressing the Government to remove army and security officers ''highly suspected'' of involvement with right- wing death squads.

title: U.C.L.A. HOLDS OFF OREGON RALLY, 24-13
description: Kevin Nelson ran for 131 yards and 3 touchdowns, and U.C.L.A. held off a late threat by Oregon for a 24-13 victory today.

title: Sally A. Roffman To Wed in Spring
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Emil Roffman of Richmond of the engagement of their daughter, Sally Anne Roffman, to Brock Holmes, son of Mr. and Mrs. George Burgwin Holmes of Washington. A spring wedding is planned.

title: OLYMPICS EFFORT UNDER WAY
description: -raising efforts to benefit the United States Olympic Athletes, which began last month during what County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke proclaimed ''Olympic Week in Westchester,'' continued last week with an ''Olympics Night'' benefit scheduled at Yonkers Raceway.

title: SCRIPT TO SCREEEN: A ROCKYPATH
description: Stephen Farber is a freelance writer based in Los Angeles.

title: PART OF STATE EMPLOYEE PENSION LAW VOIDED
description: A New York State judge has struck down a key portion of a new pension law covering 300,000 employees of state and local governments.

title: Campaign by Shaller For Tinted Soft Lenses
description: In March, Shaller, Rubin & Winer became agency for Custom Tint Laboratories, which makes tinted soft lenses. Since then it was work, work, work, and wait for the Food and Drug Administration to approve the product.

title: BUCCANEERS POST FIRST VICTORY, 17-12
description: James Wilder rushed for 219 yards and scored on a 75-yard run today to lift the Tampa Bay Buccaneers to a 17-12 upset over the Minnesota Vikings. It was the Buccaneers first victory this season after nine defeats.

title: Mubarak Defends Law On Emergency Powers
description: President Hosni Mubarak today defended the extension of an emergency-powers law and said that opposition figures were criticizing the measure because they wanted insurrection.

title: ISLANDERS REGAIN CONFIDENCE
description: In these, their dynasty years, the Islanders take each winning streak in stride, but they contemplate each losing streak as a portent of the inevitable: that one day they will not be the Stanley Cup champions.

title: CONGRESS DEBATES WHAT TO REQUIRE OF TV STATIONS
