description: Members of Congress are attempting to devise a legislative response to a two-and- a-half-year drive by the National Association of Broadcasters to eliminate the requirement that television stations must periodically renew their Federal licenses to broadcast over the public air waves.

title: COURT DRAMA FOR PHILBIN
description: WHILE his onetime Jet teammate, Joe Namath, has been acting in a courtroom drama on Broadway, Gerry Philbin has been living an actual courtroom drama about 75 miles east in the Suffolk County Criminal Courthouse at Riverhead, L.I.

title: CITY FINDING NEW WAYS TO HELP 'OLDEST ELDERLY'
description: The number of the ''oldest elderly'' - those at least 85 years of age - more than doubled in New York City in the last two decades, and city officials are finding new ways to help this dependent population.

title: Dutch Inflation Steady
description: The Dutch cost-of-living index rose 2.5 percent, to a provisional 117.6, with the base year 1980, in the year to mid-October, unchanged from the rise in the year to mid-September.

title: Oilers 8, Jets 5
description: Wayne Gretzky scored four goals and made three assists to lead an Edmonton comeback victory. The Jets, who had led, 3-0, at one point, held a 5-4 margin entering the final period, but Gretzky tied the score with his third goal of the game and 18th of the season at 12:39, then set up Mark Messier to put the Oilers ahead for the first time at 14:16.

title: The Dance of the Euromissiles
description: The approaching December deadline for deploying American mid-range missiles in Europe has concentrated Moscow's mind. It has elicited Soviet threats to make the present Geneva tango the last and to move missiles of lesser range into Eastern Europe. It has evoked a flood of Soviet propaganda about trigger-happy Americans in Grenada. And it has brought yet another arms control proposal from Yuri Andropov.

title: DUQUE BANKRUPTCY: MIAMI BANK INSISTS IT WASN'T DAMAGED
description: It is business as usual in the main office of City National Bank of Miami. From the activity there, a bystander would never guess that the bank is a pawn in a game in which the chief player, Alberto Duque Rodriguez, a Colombian coffee importer, could win some or lose all.

title: Compton Officer Joins Muppets' Organization
description: Robert H. Savage, who when last seen was president of Compton Advertising, has suddenly reappeared surrounded by Muppets as managing director and chief operating officer of Henson Associates.

title: U.S. Invasion Said to Harden Opposition to New Missiles
description: The United States invasion of Grenada has hardened opposition in Europe to deployment of new medium-range American nuclear missiles there, the European Parliament President Pieter Dankert says.

title: BUS STRIKE ISOLATES CLE ELUM, WASH.
description: King Mus, 72 years old, and his family own the Mus Motel and Antique Shop here and serve as agents for Greyhound Lines Inc. He stoked the fire in a potbellied stove Saturday and explained how the bus strike had forced him to cancel a trip to Mexico he had planned.

title: DANCE: DONALD BYRD TROUPE AT BESSIE SCHONBERG THEATER
description: SOMETHING is going on here, an audience member said on Saturday at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater during a performance by Donald Byrd and the Group II. It may often have been hard to put into tidy categories, but something certainly was going on.

title: North Koreans Fly Home From Burma
description: North Korean diplomats flew home today aboard a special jetliner. They had been expelled by Burma for what Burmese officials charged was their country's involvement in the Oct. 9 bomb blast that killed 21 people.

title: 2 States Seek to Block Waste Burning at Sea
description: Lawyers for environmentalists, shrimp fishermen, farm workers and the states of Texas and Louisiana said today they would file a suit in an attempt to block Federal permits allowing incineration of 80 million gallons of toxic wastes at sea.

title: INFLATION RETURNS AS A BOND FACTOR
description: The uncertainty and delays in the Treasury's three-part note and bond financing scheduled for this week may have raised interest rates slightly, but even without that disruption, yields would have been sharply higher than earlier this year.

title: LAROUCHE, AT LAST, MAY BE SERIOUS
description: THIS is nothing new for Pierre Larouche, really. He has always had this talent and this charm. But for all his career goals, 284, and all his points, 600, the little man with the boyish grin has built a reputation of immaturity.

title: SHOREHAM NUCLEAR PLANT IS THE UNSEEN CANDIDATE ON SUFFOLK BALLOT
description: The campaign for Suffolk County executive is ending just as it began, quietly but with one overwhelming issue - the fate of the Shoreham nuclear power plant. Indeed, both candidates agree that the election Tuesday is, more than anything else, a referendum on the plant.

title: Miss Kirkland to Dance In Mayer-Carter Event
description: Gelsey Kirkland will appear with 14 other dancers in a week of programs choreographed by Ruth Mayer and Bill Carter, beginning on Nov. 29 at the Joyce Theater.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Performing Arts Treasures Go on the Block

title: Bird Breaks Windshield; Co-pilot Lands Plane By The Associated Press
description: A Republic Airlines pilot was injured yesterday when a goose smashed through the windshield of his plane. In unrelated incidents, two Eastern Airlines jets developed problems on takeoff yesterday, but no one was hurt.

title: Miss Lyons, Musician, Weds Philip Davidson
description: The marriage of Tracey Anne Lyons, daughter of Mrs. Patrick Sheridan Hernon of Pelham Manor, N.Y., and Quogue, L.I., and the late William J. Lyons, to Philip Davidson took place yesterday in the chapel at the Church Center for the United Nations. The Rev. Sean Cooney, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Roy Rosenberg officiated.

title: NICARAGUAN PRELATE DENOUNCES SANDINISTA ATTACKS
description: Archbishop Miguel Obando y Bravo said today that Sandinista demonstrations at Roman Catholic churches were ''a sad spectacle'' that had forced worshipers to endure ''an afternoon of hell.''

title: INDEPENDENT PARTY LEADS IN TURKEY
description: An independent conservative party took a commanding lead early today over the military-backed party in Turkey's first general election since the armed forces seized power three years ago.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Accounts

title: Executive Path Has Swerved If recent history is any guide,
description: William L. Weiss had ample

title: U.S. OFFICIAL ORDERED TO PAY FOR PARIS STAFF SALARY RAISES
description: The State Department has ordered one of its top- ranking Foreign Service officers to pay the Government $17,899.89, saying that this was the amount he cost the United States when he improperly promoted 25 French employees of the American Embassy in Paris.

title: Ski Group Asks Ban on Stenmark
description: The executive committee of the International Skiing Federation voted today to recommend to the International Olympic Committee that Ingemar Stenmark be banned from next year's Winter Games.

title: STUDENTS' VIEWS ON CHEATING
description: A survey of 2,000 teen-age achievers has found that nearly a third of them said that at times they cheated in school. A majority said parents, teachers and religious leaders should share the responsibility for teaching children not to cheat.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Apache Corp., Minneapolis, has named J. W. Cunningham executive vice president-production.

title: Macklin Sees Life Beyond Knicks
description: Rudy Macklin lives in the insecure world of pro basketball and is preparing for a career in banking when his playing days are over. Lending a helping hand is Bob Pettit, the former St. Louis Hawks star and basketball Hall of Famer, who owns two banks in New Orleans and another in Lafayette, La. Macklin broke several of Pettit's scoring records at Louisiana State University.

title: Jane Feinberg Married To Charles W. Stotter
description: Jane Ellen Feinberg, daughter of Shirley O. Feinberg of Scotch Plains, N.J., and the late Bernard Feinberg, was married yesterday to Charles W. Stotter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold H. Stotter of Jamaica, Queens, and Southampton, L.I. Rabbi Gerald Goldman performed the ceremony at the Shackamaxon Country Club in Scotch Plains.

title: CONTROL OF LEGISLATURE IS PRIZE IN JERSEY ELECTION
description: The control of the New Jersey Legislature will be at stake tomorrow in the most expensive off- year election in the state's history.

title: FIESTA BOWL SCOUTS EYE BOSTON COLLEGE
description: Boston College took a big step last weekend toward a bowl game Jan. 2. The Eagles have become a contender for the Fiesta Bowl, according to Bruce Skinner, executive director of that event.

title: STRESSES OF POLITICAL CAMPAIGNS
description: MANY of the candidates in this municipal election year have been finding out that running for office can become a time of testing in more than just local politics. ''Campaigning puts tremendous stress on a family,'' said Jacqueline O'Brien, a social psychologist and family life coordinator for Catholic Family Services in New Britain, Conn. ''And it doesn't necessarily end when the results are in.''

title: Topics Good Moves
description: Right of Way

title: At Lintas's SSC&B, New Titles, Promotions
description: Kenneth L. Robbins, 48, already chief executive of SSC&B, has become chairman, succeeding William V. Weithas, who remains chairman and chief executive where it really counts, at the parent company, SSC&B: Lintas Worldwide. But there is an executive who is even more chief, and he is Philip H. Geier, chairman at the Interpublic Group of Companies, the holding company over all.

title: Economic Problems of Utilities Cited
description: Many nuclear power plants under construction will produce electricity at costs that will be double or triple the price of OPEC oil, an energy consulting firm said today.

title: CARTER AND FORD OPPOSE U.S. STRIKE
description: Former Presidents Jimmy Carter and Gerald R. Ford said today that the United States should avoid military retaliation at this time for the suicide bombing attack that killed more than 230 Marines two weeks ago in Beirut.

title: Financial Diagnostics Is Aiming at Physicians
description: Dennis W. Conlin, president of Conlin Communications in Birmingham, Mich., knows his physicians. So he is joining the highly successful Medical Economics magazine in publishing a magazine that will appeal to the doctor at about wallet or purse level.

title: Gas Prices Fall Further
description: Retail gasoline prices fell last week for the 12th consecutive week, an oil industry analyst said today.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: On the Rise

title: SHULTZ WITH TOUGH LINE, IS NOW KEY VOICE IN CRISIS
description: After more than two months of international crises, beginning with the Soviet downing of a Korean airliner on Sept. 1 and extending to last month's bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut and the invasion of Grenada, Secretary of State George P. Shultz has emerged as the paramount voice in the Reagan Administration's foreign policy.

title: PEKING AIDE ADMITS ERRORS OF IDEOLOGY
description: A prominent cultural official has offered an apology for his own ideological shortcomings in a move interpreted here as a signal that stricter ideological conformity is again being demanded of China's writers and artists.

title: DEPUTY TO REPLACE RUMSFELD AT SEARLE
description: The departure of Donald H. Rumsfeld for the Middle East as President Reagan's special envoy has caused almost no stir at G. D. Searle & Company where, in Mr. Rumsfeld's absence, his high school friend and deputy, John E. Robson, will operate the company.

title: Health Aide Visits Israel
description: Secretary of Health Margaret Heckler arrived on a five-day official visit to Israel today and said she hoped to strengthen ties between the two countries. She will confer with health officials and visit health centers. She will also meet President Chaim Herzog.

title: Partisan Indeed, for Democracy
description: Can America's political parties be a foreign policy asset? The belief that they are is embodied in a Senate bill creating a National Endowment for Democracy. Among other things, it would help Republicans and Democrats reach out to democratic parties abroad. The House favors the endowment, but not the party proposal, fearing it would degenerate into a ''travel slush fund'' for idle politicians. This Congressional squabble may weaken a good idea - President Reagan's idea - whose time has long since come.

title: BUCKS WIN BY 97-84
description: Sidney Moncrief scored 27 points and Marques Johnson 14, all in the first half, as the Milwaukee Bucks defeated the Atlanta Hawks tonight, 97-84.

title: G.M.-Fujitsu Link
description: The G.M.F. Robotics Corporation, a joint venture between the General Motors Corporation and Fujitsu Fanuc Ltd. of Japan, said it plans to delay for several more months the selection of a site in Michigan or another Middle Western state for the assembly of robots. No reason for the delay was given.

title: Milton Rakove Is Dead; Political Historian, 65
description: Milton Rakove, an expert on city politics here, died Saturday at Weiss Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 65 years old.

title: Fear of Tighter Rations Prompts Panic in Poland
description: Fears of stricter rationing of food and other essential items has caused panic buying of soap, detergent and cigarettes in provincial towns, the official Polish press agency said today.

title: REAGAN'S TRIP TO JAPAN: TIES REMAIN STRONG
description: News Analysis

title: SEAFIRST AND RAINIER FIGHT FOR MARKET SHARE
description: Richard P. Cooley, chairman, president and chief executive officer of the Seafirst Corporation, wears a pin on his lapel that says: Expect Excellence.

title: Arrows Defeated
description: Steve Doerr scored with 4 minutes 54 seconds remaining to give the Memphis Americans a 4-3 victory today over the Arrows in the Arrows' season opener in the Major Indoor Soccer League before a crowd of 10,341 at Nassau Coliseum.

title: Quakers Offer Sanctuary To Salvadoran Family
description: A religious group has pledged to defy United States immigration officials and provide sanctuary for a Salvadoran family of five.

title: CONCERT: STRAUSS'S 'LIEBE DER DANAE'
description: NOT many pieces of music labor under greater burdens than ''Die Liebe der Danae,'' the next-to-last of Richard Strauss's 15 operas. Written in Germany during World War II by an opportunist who let himself be used by the Nazis as a cultural exhibit, it has been under a political cloud ever since. Its libretto, a piece of muddled mythology worked up by the pedantic Josef Gregor and painfully hammered into shape by the composer and others, is weak and contorted. The score is incredibly complex and fiercely difficult to sing, representing Strauss in his late, almost too luxuriant mood. His infatuation with his own orchestral technique led him in this work as in others, early and late, to pack in the notes at times when lean simplicity might have been more powerful.

title: SOLAR PLANT DUE ON LINE SOON
description: The first phase of the world's largest solar energy plant will start generating electricity this month in sunny central California, according to an Arco Solar Industries official.

title: 2 Brink's Defendants To Go on Trial Today
description: Two defendants in the 1981 Brink's armored car holdup - Kathy Boudin and Samuel Brown - are scheduled to go on trial Monday on 13 counts of robbery and murder.

title: Susan Schwalb Becomes Bride
description: Susan A. Schwalb, daughter of Acting Supreme Court Justice Morris Schwalb, who is retired, and Evelyn C. Schwalb of New York, was married yesterday to Prof. Martin Boykan, who holds the Irving Fine Chair of Music Composition at Brandeis University. The bridegroom is the son of Matilda Boykan of New York and the late Dr. Joseph Boykan.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: With a man on third base and one out, the batter walks and heads for first. The catcher, still holding the ball, asks for and receives a timeout as the batter reaches first. The batter, never really stopping at the bag, dashes for second; the catcher, having received a timeout, does not throw there. The umpire rules that the batter is entitled to second base. Is that correct?

title: STEELERS TROUNCE CHARGERS BY 26-3
description: Gary Anderson kicked four field goals today and the cornerback Mel Blount returned a fumble for a touchdown to lead the Pittsburgh Steelers to their sixth straight triumph, a 26-3 decision over the struggling San Diego Chargers.

title: Governor-Elect of Louisiana Offers a Trip to Repay Debts
description: Edwin Edwards, Louisiana's Governor-elect, is proposing to pay off his campaign debts with a weeklong trip to Paris for those who made big loans to his campaign.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1983 International
description: Yasir Arafat's troops lost one of his two remaining strongholds in Lebanon to Syrian-backed Palestinian insurgents after three days of intense shelling and rocket fire. Mr. Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said he was regrouping his forces to continue the fight. (Page A1, Column 6.) More than 100 bodies have been found on the southern tip of Grenada, according to a United States official in the capital. He said that one of the bodies was presumed to be that of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop, who was slain on Oct. 19. The official said that virtually all of the victims were also believed to have been fatally shot at a rally on Oct. 19. (A1:4-5.)

title: UNSETTLING QUESTIONS
description: The great American military victory over Grenada and about 700 Cubans (''We blew them away,'' boasted Vice Adm. Joseph Metcalf 3d, who commanded the Grenadian task force) has focused attention on two questions of deep importance to the nation's future foreign policy:

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Bloch on Horseback

title: ADVERTISING
description: New Publisher For Gourmet As soon as he completed the

title: MEXICO'S BORROWING MAY DROP
description: Mexico's net borrowing abroad in 1984 should be less than the $5 billion raised in 1983, Commerce Minister Hector Hernandez said here today.

title: RECORD OF S.E.C. CHIEF DRAWS MIX OF OPINIONS
description: When John S. R. Shad took over as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission in 1981, he served notice that he would not dawdle in carrying out President Reagan's mandate to lighten up on business.

title: BRITISH AND IRISH PRIME MINISTERS MEET TODAY
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher is scheduled to meet with Prime Minister Garret FitzGerald of Ireland on Monday under heavy security. Neither side will reveal the location of the meeting.

title: ; BLARING RADIOS: WHAT LONG-TERM HARM?
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * National Convertible Stores Inc., Houston, said that its capital expenditures for its fiscal year ending June 30, 1984, will be $86 million, a 16 percent increase over last year.

title: Latin Industry Gets Aid Fund
description: The Inter-American Development Bank has set up a $200 million investment fund to help finance small and medium-size companies in Latin America.

title: STEPHENS TRAINING THREE TOP HORSES
description: It has been 35 years since Ben Jones trained a pair of Calumet Farm colts named Citation and Coaltown, who carved up most of the major stakes for 2-year-olds between them, along with Bewitch, who won most of the prizes for 2-year-old fillies. It was the peak of Calumet's success, in an era when that stable dominated American racing as none before or since. Nowadays, with four times as many horses bred each year and top pedigrees spread out among thousands of stables, no trainer figured ever again to hold so many aces at one time.

title: OHIO CHRYSLER WORKERS BACK PACT, FREEING 7 OTHER PLANTS TO REOPEN
description: Striking automobile workers at a Chrysler Corporation stamping plant in Twinsburg today ratified a contract that puts them and about 20,000 other workers nationwide back to work.

title: ISSUES NO ISSUE IN RACE FOR WESTCHESTER CHIEF
description: In the race for Westchester County Executive, Andrew P. O'Rourke, the Republican-Conservative incumbent, and Ogden R. Reid, his Democratic challenger, have debated 35 times and spent a total of nearly $1 million for a post that pays $81,500 a year.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: BEIRUT'S ARTILLERY PARROT
description: Anything and anyone, it seems, can be bought here: information, hashish, cocaine, transit visas, passports, loyalty.

title: Sub Being Towed at 5 Knots Off Florida's Northern Coast
description: A Navy spokesman said a disabled Soviet submarine was off the coast of northern Florida today, heading south at about five knots, apparently being towed to Cuba.

title: LLOYD MCBRIDE, STEELWORKERS' CHIEF, DIES AT 67 AFTER HEART SURGERY
description: Lloyd McBride, president of the United Steelworkers of America since 1977 and the union's leader in the most troubled times in the American steel industry since the Depression, died yesterday at his apartment in Whitehall, Pa., a Pittsburgh suburb. He was 67 years old.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Addendum

title: MULTIPLEXES ADD 2,300 MOVIE SCREENS IN 5 YEARS
description: Despite the inroads of video cassettes and pay television, there are more movie screens in theaters across America than there were 35 years ago and in most places they are proliferating dramatically.

title: MARSHALL FILLS GAP FOR GIANTS
description: IN training camp, Leonard Marshall often seemed like a joke, a

title: MRS. FENWICK APPLIES SKILLS TO WORLD ARGRICULTUREAL POST
description: ''I don't find it very different, to tell you the truth,'' said the new United States representative at the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization. ''Maybe I'm not doing it right.''

title: BRIEFING
description: Commemorating a Stamp

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: President Reagan leaves Tuesday for a six-day trip to Japan and South Korea. While in Japan, he is to meet with Emperor Hirohito and Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone. In Korea, he is to hold talks with President Chun Doo Hwan and visit troops of the United States Second Infantry Division at Camp Liberty Bell.

title: SENATE DEMOCRATIC INCUMMBNTS LEADING IN FUNDS FOR 1984 ELECTION
description: A year before the 1984 elections, Senate Democratic incumbents have been able to raise more money than Republicans in their drive for re-election, according to reports filed with the Federal Election Commission.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: LIFE STORY There are some people you will avoid at any cost for an evening because you know that they will do nothing but talk about themselves. But there are others you might pay any price to hear do just that, and it is from such a group that the Poetry Center at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue (427-4410), has drawn from for a new series, whose price is $6 an evening.

title: Leadership Is Key To Women's Gains
description: Donna Shalala, the president of Hunter College, said today that women would gain opportunities in sports equal to those enjoyed by men because of the strong leadership being taken by world-class athletes.

title: 'HURRY UP AND SPEND'
description: As any bureaucrat worthy of the name knows, the waning days of a fiscal year are a time for that old Washington game known variously as ''hurry up and spend'' and ''use it or lose it.''

title: HOW THE ROSENBERGS FACED THEIR 'SUPREME CRISIS'
description: To the Editor:

title: DON'T TAMPER WITH LOCAL CONTROL OF EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. OFFICIALS CITE KEY SUCCESSES IN WAR AGAINST ORGANIZED CRIME
description: Justice Department officials say they have won many significant battles in the last two or three years in a decades-old war against organized crime. In all major cities where traditional organized crime exists, they say, most of the top leaders are either in prison or facing charges.

title: GENERAL HOPES GRENADA G.I.'S WILL BE OUT BY THANKSGIVING
description: Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said today that he hoped United States forces would be withdrawn from Grenada by Thanksgiving.

title: A Marine Wins Marine Marathon
description: Sgt. Farley Simon, a native of Grenada, became the first Marine to capture the annual Marine Corps Marathon when he beat a field of more than 11,000 runners today in 2 hours 17 minutes 45 seconds.

title: Andropov Isn't Present At Revolution Parade
description: Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, was absent today from the group of Politburo members reviewing the traditional Revolution Day parade, heightening speculation that he may be seriously ill.

title: GLENN AIDES SPUR CAMPAIGN IN IOWA
description: Robert J. Keefe, a jocular type, walked into the Savery Hotel lobby here Saturday and waved a speeding ticket at some political reporters. ''This,'' he said, ''is proof that John Glenn's campaign is gaining speed in Iowa.'' He had received the ticket a few minutes earlier.

title: 3D-QUARTER EARNINGS UP SHARPLY
description: Earnings of the nation's leading corporations in the third quarter appear, at first glance, to have exceeded the expectations of even the most optimistic shareholder.

title: A Guilty Plea In Bid-Rigging
description: One of six companies charged in June with bid-rigging in the construction of two nuclear plants pleaded guilty Friday.

title: SPLIT IN FARM BLOC IMPERILS MILK BILL
description: A new split in the once-solid farm bloc is imperiling passage in the House this week of a compromise milk price support bill that would, for the first time, pay dairy farmers to reduce production.

title: Marcos to Allow Party To Settle Succession
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos, under increasing pressure to establish a clear line of succession if he cannot complete his term in office, will let ruling party leaders decide the issue, officials said today.

title: OUTDOORS: LURING DUCKS WITHIN RANGE
description: USING decoys to lure waterfowl within range is a practice that began in North America more than a thousand years ago, but many sportsmen, particularly country boys with their first shotguns, begin duck hunting by jump shooting or flight shooting.

title: THE LOVE OF FORCE
description: As military actions go, the American move into Grenada was limited in scope and purpose. But some people have welcomed it in far larger terms: as a sign that the United States is now ready generally to deal with political problems by using military force. Before that lesson is drawn, it would be well to look at an example weightier than Grenada.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ABOUT ROTHKO. By Dore Ashton. 225 pages. Oxford University Press. $19.95.

title: Ralph Owen, 78, Dies; Led American Express
description: Ralph Owen, former chairman of the American Express Company, died of a heart ailment Friday night at Vanderbilt Hospital in Nashville. He was 78 years old.

title: ART: ALFRED LESLIE'S BLACK-AND-WHITE WATERCOLORS
description: BLACK and white make one of the world's oldest dichotomies; but on the other hand, like yin and yang, they also complement each other. The perfect relationship between them - the ''ideal balance'' of ''just so much black related to just so much white'' - is the theme of a spectacular show, ''100 Views Along the Road,'' a selection from 100 black-and-white landscape watercolors by Alfred Leslie at the Oil & Steel Gallery, 157 Chambers Street, through Dec. 3.

title: A FRENCH CARDINAL DENOUNCES ANTI-SEMITISM
description: In the month of speeches by the cardinals, archbishops and bishops during the recent Synod of Bishops, most dealt in general terms with the theme set by Pope John Paul II of penance and reconciliation.

title: 100 BODIES ARE REPORTED FOUND AT A TRAINING CAMP IN GRENADA
description: A United States official said tonight that more than 100 bodies had been found on the southern tip of Grenada.

title: Sangue Is Winner
description: The favored Irish-bred Sangue rallied from last place today to win the $400,000 Yellow Ribbon invitational stakes for fillies and mares at Santa Anita.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Farley Industries Head Confident on Condec Bid

title: Louise May Is Married To William T. Gruber
description: Louise Elizabeth May, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick David May of Brooklyn and Scottsdale, Ariz., was married at the Hampshire House in New York yesterday to William Tschirn Gruber, son of Mrs. Jack London Gruber of Valley Cottage, N.Y., and the late Mr. Gruber. The Rev. Robert Pollard 3d, an Episcopal priest, and Rabbi Abraham Krantz officiated.

title: Debt Ratings
description: * Pennzoil Co. 's senior debt rating was lowered to BBBx, from A-, by Standard & Poor's, which also lowered the company's preferred stock rating to BBB-, from A-, and affirmed its commercial paper rating at A2; the rating on the debentures issued by Pennzoil Overseas Finance N.V., guaranteed by the parent company, was lowered to BBBx, from A-.

title: A PROPER BOND ISSUE PROPERLY PROPOSED
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge:Italian Blue Team Lacks Touch of Its Glory Days
description: In the great days of the Italian Blue team two decades ago, its players regularly bid to aggressive slam contract and brought them home by skillful play. They still bid aggressively, but the magic touch in their play seems to have deserted them.

title: 2d Football Title To Maria Regina
description: Maria Regina clinched its second consecutive Catholic High Schools' Football League Division II title yesterday with a 37-15 victory over Nazareth.

title: CSX Application
description: The CSX Corporation said that it had filed an application with the Interstate Commerce Commission to assume control of American Commercial Liners Inc., one of the largest marine transportation companies serving the inland waterways. American Commercial Lines is a former subsidiary of the Texas Gas Resources Corporation, which CSX acquired last August. Current law prohibits ownership of a barge line by a railroad, a point used by opponents of the original Texas Gas-CSX merger.

title: IBH BLAMES BANKS FOR FAILURE
description: Somehow, Horst- Dieter Esch did not really fit into the understated pin-striped world of West German banking, where Ferdinand Graf von Galen was at home.

title: The President's Priorities
description: Judging from the President's recent schedule, one could be excused for believing Mr. Reagan's heart still belongs to Hollywood.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Persistence Personified

title: FRAUD: DECIDING WHEN TO PROSECUTE
description: When it was disclosed in testimony at a Senate hearing the other day that the Pentagon had paid $9,609 for a wrench, outraged Senators cried, ''It's criminal!''

title: DEVILS END 10-GAME SLILDE, 6-3
description: With Glenn Resch turning aside 43 shots, the Devils ended a 10-game losing streak with a 6-3 victory tonight over the Chicago Black Hawks, who scored their goals in a 51-second span.

title: STOLEN ETCHINGS ARE RECOVERED IN MANHATTAN
description: The F.B.I. said yesterday that what appeared to be five Rembrandt etchings stolen earlier this year from collections in Syracuse and Canada were discovered over the weekend at Grand Central Terminal.

title: MAJOR ART THEFT IN HUNGARY
description: Thieves have stolen seven Italian Renaissance masterpieces from Budapest's Museum of Fine Arts in what Hungary's best-known art critic said today was a robbery of indescribable proportions.

title: Barbaro Jumps
description: To the Generals

title: TREASURY GOING AHEAD WITH SALES
description: Treasury officials decided Friday to proceed with $16 billion of note and bond auctions this week, even though Congress has not yet increased the debt ceiling. Although an increase in the ceiling is still needed, Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said, ''It appears likely that the Treasury can reschedule and settle the refunding issues in their original amounts on Nov. 15 without exceeding the debt limit.''

title: Wilander Victor Over Gerulaitis
description: Mats Wilander topped Vitas Gerulaitis, 6-3, 6-3, today and reached the final of the $215,000 Stockholm Open tennis championships.

title: MAJOR LINK IN MIAMI RAIL TRANSIT SYSTEM TO OPEN
description: Two decades after Dade County residents began seriously considering their transportation needs, the finishing touches are being put on an 11-mile stretch of a 21-mile elevated railway system here. The Metrorail, as it is called, is the centerpiece of the county's new mass transit plan.

title: THEATER: 'SOUND AND BEAUTY,' TWO ONE-ACT PLAYS
description: WHATEVER David Henry Hwang is doing in ''Sound and Beauty,'' his rather elusive new pair of one- act plays, he is not standing still. A hugely gifted, Los Angeles-born Chinese-American writer, Mr. Hwang has in the past focused on Chinese immigrants at sea in the New World of California - whether in a 19th-century frontier labor camp (''The Dance and the Railroad'') or glitzy present-day Bel Air (''Family Devotions''). In ''Sound and Beauty,'' Mr. Hwang moves away from California and China entirely. His new plays are about sex and death, and their setting is Japan.

title: Hanna Mining
description: The Hanna Mining Company, the nation's only combined nickel mining and smelting operation, said that new labor and power agreements would enable it to end an 18-month shutdown and that it would reopen its Nickel Mountain operation on Monday. The announcement came after Hanna signed a two-year agreement with the Bonneville Power Administration to use lower-cost ''off-peak'' power while operating mostly at night. The mining and smelting operation has been shut down since April 1982.

title: ACID RAIN AND POLLUTION CURBS
description: The acid-rain controversy may provide a much-needed boost for the nation's depressed air-pollution control industry. If the present momentum in Congress is maintained, companies such as Combustion Engineering, General Electric, Babcock & Wilcox and Research-Cottrell could wind up competing for $5 billion or more in new business.

title: PANEL TO REVIEW CURB ON THE PRESS
description: Gen. John W. Vessey Jr., Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said yesterday that he would create a panel of officers and journalists to review the news restrictions imposed in the initial days of the Grenada invasion and to suggest rules for press coverage of military actions.

title: CLERIC'S TEACHING ON MEDICINE IS CITED IN 57 INDIANA DEATHS
description: The founder and leader of a religious group with members so faithful to his teachings that they allow spouses and children to die rather than seek medical help preaches that medicine is evil and doctors are little better than magicians.

title: ARABS, JACKSON AND JEWS: NEW PAGE OF TENSE RELATIONS
description: News Analysis

title: BUYERS SEE ECONOMIC MOMENTUM
description: The nation's economy improved in October at a faster rate than in September, according to a report being released today by the National Association of Purchasing Management.

title: DALLAS FIGHTING '63 SPECTER AS CONVENTION APPROACHES
description: To David Fox, chairman of the Dallas Welcoming Committee for the Republican National Convention next summer, there is nothing unusual about the spate of civic preening that is going on here.

title: Czech's Play to Open At the Public Theater
description: ''A Private View,'' an autobiographical play by the Czechoslavak playwright Vaclav Havel, begins performances Wednesday in the New York Shakespeare Festival Public Theater, at 425 Lafayette Street.

title: URBANITES JOIN MONKS AT RETREAT
description: The bells were rung this morning at 4:25, hours before sunrise. Many of the monks were already awake. The rest rose from their beds, as did a few lodgers sleeping in the monastery's four guest houses.

title: DELOREAN CASE'S VARIOUS INCONGRUTIES INCLUDE LARRY FLYNT
description: Most evenings here, just after the Federal District Court has adjourned for the day, a woman shows up outside the imposing white granite courthouse and begins a modified striptease. A regular there for months if not years, she performs her bizarre bumps and grinds to the utter astonishment of first-time passers-by.

title: Yount's Pact
description: Robin Yount, the 1982 most valuable player in the American League, would not be in line to be a free agent until 1984, but the Milwaukee Brewers have already protected their investment by negotiating a new contract with him.

title: WHEN A SUSPECT'S PRETRIAL DETENTION IS A MUST
description: To the Editor:

title: Montclair State Triumphs, 45-0
description: Mark Casale and Walter Briggs, the first- and second-string quarterbacks, each threw a pair of touchdown passes as Montclair State routed Jersey City State, 45-0, Saturday night in a New Jersey State Conference game.

title: REFORMER OF CITY JAILS
description: During a hearing on sanitary conditions in New York City's Tombs jail in the mid-1970's, Judge Morris E. Lasker was approached by an inmate holding what he contended was a mouse, found in a bowl of soup. The judge, who had grown accustomed to hearing such complaints, was not fazed. He nonchalantly placed the evidence in a bag, put it in his pocket and took it to a mammologist at the American Museum of Natural History for analysis. It turned out to be a piece of beef.

title: Tot Beaten to Death; Man, 39, Is Charged
description: A 2-year-old girl died Saturday night after being beaten by a man who lived with her baby sitter, the police said.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the planned release dates for major economic indicators to be reported this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Retail Sales Oct. Producer Prices Oct. Friday None

title: PRIDE AND REDEMPTION: TWIN SPURS FOR DURAN
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

title: CURRENCY INTEREST RATES
description: rates Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.79

title: Firmani to Coach Cosmos
description: Eddie Firmani will be named the new head coach of the Cosmos, replacing Julio Mazzei, according to sources close to the North American Soccer League club.

title: Washington WatchClyde H. Farnsworth China, Soviet Trade Cases
description: WASHINGTON THE Commerce Department and the United

title: HUNGER COMES TO FAMILY'S TABLE AT MONTH'S END
description: Like countless others who live in poverty across the country, the three children of Jerry and Betty Elkins know all too well what it is like to sit down to meager meals.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Biltrite Officers Shifted After Its Chief Resigns

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Praise From a French Chef

title: A VOTE TO MODERNIZE APARTHEID'S EDIFICE
description: South Africa's whites have given their verdict - only whites voted in the referendum held Wednesday - endorsing a new constitution, but the fundamental question remains unanswered: Is this reform a sophisticated way of modernizing rather than dismantling the racial edifice of apartheid? Alas, it seems to be just that - a way of co- opting Indians and coloreds, or people of mixed race, and shutting out blacks more decisively than ever.

title: Coastal Corp. Net Rises
description: The Coastal Corporation said Friday that its third-quarter net income climbed 13.7 percent, to $24.1 million, or $1.04 a share, from $21.2 million, or 88 cents a share, a year ago. The company said its operating revenues increased 3.8 percent, to $1.37 billion, from $1.32 billion a year ago.

title: U.S. ROLE IN 'BABY DOE' CASE DEFENDED BY SURGEON GENERAL
description: The Surgeon General of the United States, Dr. C. Everett Koop, said yesterday that the legal battle over the treatment of a severely deformed Long Island baby was a fight for the principle that every life is ''uniquely sacred.'' And he denied that the Federal Government was intruding unduly in the private life of the baby's family.

title: Bonnett Captures Atlanta Race
description: Neil Bonnett, taking advantage of Bobby Allison's bad luck late in the race, outran Buddy Baker to win the Atlanta Journal 500 today at Atlanta International Raceway.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, NOVEMBER 7, 1983
description: The Economy Corporate earnings outperformed the most optimistic shareholder expectations in the third quarter. But analysts are gloomy because of the failure of the stock market to respond. (Page D1.) The economy grew at a faster pace in October than in September, according to purchasing managers. Lower unemployment and a rise in orders lead them to expect a strong fourth quarter. (D1.)

title: CANDIDATES IN TUESDAY'S RACES IN NEW YORK AREA AND JERSEY
description: NEW YORK

title: Persian Gulf Nations Will Confer Today
description: Six Persian Gulf leaders open talks in Doha on Monday to fashion joint policies on issues ranging from Iran's threat to block the Strait of Hormuz and the Iran-Iraq war to the Lebanese crisis and disputes beteen Arab countries.

title: THE IMPACT ON CHILDREN OF 'THE DAY AFTER'
description: ''In the issue of nuclear war, the therapist is just as vulnerable to fear and denial as the family he's treating,'' said Dr. Robert Simon to an utterly silent auditorium of 120 therapists and psychological professionals. ''Usually, the problem of the patient isn't shared by the therapist.''

title: PHONE SALES TO JAPAN INCH UP
description: Slowly and reluctantly, Japan's telephone monopoly is opening up to sales of foreign equipment.

title: 3 Killed While Changing Tire
description: A car swerved off Interstate 95, mowed down four men who had stopped to change a tire, and crashed into a parked van today, killing three people and injuring 13. The accident occurred south of the Interstate 695 interchange in eastern Baltimore County. Two vans had stopped, one to help the other, when a car driven by Hiren Patel, 20 years old, Walpole, Mass., ran up an embankment, avoided the rear van, but ran over four pedestrians and struck the front van, the police said.

title: GOSSAGE IS BIG PRIZE ON FREE AGENT LIST
description: RICH GOSSAGE, his mind focusing more on the deer and the elk he would be hunting the next day, thought for a moment about the differences between his first experience as a free agent and the one he is about to undertake.

title: D.D.B. Creativity Split; Bernbach Art Honor
description: From 1979 to last August, Roy Grace, now chairman of Doyle Dane Bernbach-U.S., was creative director of the whole show. In August, the responsibility for the main office here in New York was divided between him and Marvin I. Honig, vice chairman, D.D.B./N.Y.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We will continue. We have no choice but to continue.'' - Yasir Arafat.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Hanes Unit Goes SouthAbout a week ago it was Fotomat that discovered Henderson Advertising in Greenville, S.C. Now the Hanes Printable T-Shirt division, which has had its account with Leber Katz Partners in the big city of New York, is goin' on down. Billings will be $3 million and will cover some advertising on television. Hanes, a division of Consolidated Foods, sells its plain T-shirts to companies that add the art before selling to the consumer.

title: COURT DECIDES MAINE INDIANS MUST END HIGH-STAKES GAME
description: Minerva Dinsmore said Friday that she was ''certainly disappointed'' that she cannot play beano on Indian Island any longer.

title: SPAIN GROWS LESS PRUDISH, BUT NOT YET LIBERTINE
description: A bent, elderly woman dressed entirely in black, from her stockings to her head scarf, was moving slowly down the street when she came upon a piece of paper on the sidewalk. It was a page from a popular magazine, a photo of a naked couple in amorous embrace.

title: CITY MEETS COURT ORDER IN FREEING 423 INMATES
description: The number of prisoners released under a reduced-bail program reached 423 yesterday, bringing New York City into compliance with a Federal court order to reduce crowding in the city's jails.

title: GRENADIAN AIDE OF U.N. SAYS HE WILL FORM AN INTERIM GOVERNMENT
description: A Grenadian United Nations official said today that he had accepted a request by Sir Paul Scoon, Governor General of Grenada, to head an interim government until elections are possible.

title: CHEAP NUCLEAR POWER
description: To the Editor:

title: Cowboys Defeat Eagles
description: It would be difficult to play any better than the Philadelphia Eagles did at the beginning of their game today with the Dallas Cowboys.

title: Market PlaceMichael Blumstein Rising Fears, Falling Stocks
description: WHEN stock prices began taking off in August 1982, the economy was a shambles. Now, with the economy on the move, the stock market seems to be at a standstill. Even Friday's report of an unexpectedly sharp drop in the unemployment rate - to 8.7 percent, from 9.1 percent - failed to lift the market's spirits.

title: JETS FINDING WAY TO FAIL
description: HE had four sacks, but Mark Gastineau was not dancing. Not even arm-wrestling. Instead, the Jets' 265-pound defensive end, his long black mink coat hanging on the wall outside his locker, was slumped on a stool in the Shea Stadium locker room after yesterday's 17-14 loss to the Baltimore Colts that dropped the Jets into last place in the American Conference East.

title: Allianz and B.A.T
description: Allianz Versicherungs A.G. said it had not yet decided whether to respond to B.A.T Industries' raised bid for Eagle Star Holdings P.L.C., and discussions are expected to last several days. An Allianz managing board member, Detlev von der Burg, said there is no pressure to make a quick decision. Eagle Star has rejected an Allianz bid of about $7.42 a share and recommended that its shareholders accept the $8.53-a-share bid by B.A.T.

title: PLAN TO INSURE BANKS' LOANS
description: Henry Wallich, a governor of the United States Federal Reserve Board, proposed that loan rescheduling fees charged by banks be used to set up an insurance fund for banks' loan portfolios.

title: MUSIC: WORKS BY CARTER AND BARBER
description: ''THE Great American Symphony'' was played in Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night - not of course that singular work the nation is waiting for, to be listened to while reading an appropriate novel, but the New York premiere of Curtis O. B. Curtis- Smith's ''The Great American Symphony,'' a work which playfully attempts to suggest some of the ingredients that should be included in that yet-to-be composed masterpiece.

title: Advertising; SmithKline Unit Shifts Accounts
description: CHUNKS of business have been moved by Menley & James Laboratories to Batten, Barton, Durstine & Osborn and MCA Advertising; some accounts had been at Ogilvy & Mather and one assignment was at Grey Advertising's Grey Medical.

title: BRAZIL BATTLES INFLATION NOW AT 200% RATE
description: The maid enters the Copacabana Hotel room and replaces the rate card under the tabletop glass. The room just went up 15 percent, to $84. The maid says nothing. The management says nothing. It happens all the time.

title: VOW TO FIGHT ON
description: After three days of intense shelling and rocket fire, one of Yasir Arafat's two remaining guerrilla strongholds in Lebanon has fallen to Syrian-backed Palestinian insurgents.

title: Dr. Judith S. Mausner Dies; Author of Epidemiology Text
description: Dr. Judith S. Mausner, author of an epidemiology textbook, has died of cancer in Munich, West Germany, which she was visiting.

title: TV: 'LAND OF SLEEPING MOUNTAINS''
description: ''THE Land of Sleeping Mountains,'' the second in the three-part series ''The Making of a Continent,'' is best when it deals with particulars: one mountain, one valley, one pinyon pine forest. The series is up to nothing less than an explanation of how movements in the earth's crust affect all living things, and how turbulence at earth's core has shaped the North American continent. It is an ambitious project. The segment tonight will be seen on Channel 13 at 8 o'clock.

title: CommoditiesH. J. Maidenberg Taxing Futures Options
description: EVER since trading in options based on futures contracts resumed on Oct. 1, 1982, after a hiatus of 40 years, investors, their accountants and the Internal Revenue Service have faced an unusual problem: how should the profits on these options be treated?

title: Bayer A.G. Sales Up 6%
description: Sales at the Bayer A.G. group rose about 6 percent in the first nine months of 1983, from $3.84 billion in the period a year earlier, a company spokesman said today.

title: JETS DEFEATED BY COLTS, 17-14
description: The Jets had believed yesterday's game was virtually the last chance to salvage their season, but instead they collapsed in front of the more eager, unheralded Baltimore Colts.

title: Miss Sharp Weds Rev. Brewster Beach
description: At All Saints Episcopal Church in Manhattan yesterday, Sandra Sexton Sharp, a promotion writer for M. L. Falcone Public Relations, was married to the Rev. Brewster Yale Beach, a Jungian analyst in private practice in New York and an Episcopal priest. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. R. DeWitt Mallary, rector of the church, assisted by the Rev. James Byrne, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: 6 DEMOCRATS, IN REPLIES TO KOCH, AGREE ON ARMS
description: Six of the eight candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination say they believe that United States conventional forces, especially those that are part of NATO, should be improved to create a greater deterrent against a possible Soviet invasion of Western Europe.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: Giants vs. Detroit Lions , at Pontiac, Mich. Scott Brunner is back at quarterback for the Giants after being benched for two games.

title: ISRAEL AGAIN LINKS SYRIA TO BOMBING
description: A senior Government official, speaking after today's weekly Cabinet meeting, said that it was ''inconceivable'' that Syria had not known about and given at least tacit support to the terrorist attack against an Israeli military installation outside Tyre, Lebanon.

title: Gap Chain at Wells; 2 New Clients for Ally
description: Other account news in the Big Apple involved Wells, Rich, Greene and Ally & Gargano.

title: DERELICT TENEMENTS IN THE BRONX TO GET FAKE LIVED-IN LOOK
description: Scores of crumbling, abandoned tenements in the Bronx - part of a swath of blight that has become a national symbol of urban decay - will soon sport vinyl decals over their gaping windows depicting a lived-in look of curtains, shades, shutters and flowerpots.

title: BALLOT CONFUSION UPSTATE
description: When is a ballot proposal not a proposal? When it is an amendment. In four upstate counties, the proposals on the ballot Tuesday will be listed not as proposals but as amendments, and some voters may be confused by the difference.

title: Computer Data Arrests
description: Two Americans, two Bulgarians and a Dutchman have been charged with shipping advanced computer technology to Bulgaria in violation of United States export controls, the United States Attorney's office here said Saturday. The Americans, Edward King and Louis Klement, who purportedly ran an export company called Printemps in Yorba Linda, Calif., were arrested Friday. Warrants were issued for Henrik Wasnoeth of Alkmaar, the Netherlands, and Ognian Bozarov and Assen Koinov of Sofia, Bulgaria, the attorney's office said.

title: U.S. TEAM WINS EQUESTRIAN TITLE
description: For the first time in a decade, the United States Equestrian Team had to come from behind in the final event to win the international team championship at the National Horse Show at Madison Square Garden.

title: QUARTERLY ROUNDUP OF SALES AND EARNINGS OF 284 COMPANIES
ASSAILANT OF POPE IS QUESTIONED
description: Italian police officers took the Turk who shot Pope John Paul II to a Rome neighborhood today to see if he could point out the building where he says he met with Bulgarians to plot the assassination of John Paul.

title: AIRBAGS' LIMITS AS CRASH PROTECTORS
description: To the Editor:

title: SCREEN: 'MONKEY GRIP,' COUPLES IN MELBOURNE
description: SOAP operas come in all shapes and sizes, but they rarely have either the solemnity or the setting of ''Monkey Grip.'' Situated in a section of Melbourne, among what seems to be a group of aging hippies who are active in the Australian rock scene, it tells of a freewheeling single mother named Nora (Noni Hazlehurst), who looks a lot tougher and more independent than she sounds.

title: HEAD OF CARIBBEAN TROOPS DISCOUNTS GRENADA THREAT
description: The Jamaican officer who heads the Caribbean contingent backing up United States forces on Grenada says that he is dubious that the former Government was planning to use the arms it was acquiring to export revolution, subvert its neighbors or train terrorists.

title: CORRECTION
description: A Finance Brief in Business Day Friday incorrectly reported the date on which the Southmark Corporation will redeem all shares of its Series A cumulative convertible preferred stock. The redemption date is Dec. 21.

title: GRENADA WAS TOLD OF INVASION PLAN
description: Prime Minister Edward Seaga of Jamaica said today after a meeting with President Reagan that Gen. Hudson Austin, the leader of Grenada before the United States-led invasion of the island, had been told of the invasion plan nearly 36 hours before it was carried out.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Centennial Mass

title: UNION'S BOARD MIGHT NAME NEXT PRESIDENT
description: Yesterday, leaders of the United Steelworkers Union of America, who were gathering at the union's headquarters in downtown Pittsburgh, were considering constitutional provisions that might allow the executive board to name a successor to Lloyd McBride to serve until the union's next regular election, Nov. 26. 1985.

title: Joyce S. Knoller Becomes Bride of Barry J. Cohen
description: Joyce S. Knoller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Knoller of Boca Raton, Fla., and Barry J. Cohen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elias S. Cohen of Philadelphia, were married yesterday at Temple Emanu-El in New York. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony.

title: FARMERS NEED THE I.M.F.
description: I've usually opposed an increase in United States contributions to the International Monetary Fund, and voted against one last June. Many of us did not want to vote for what looked like an increase in foreign aid funding when vital domestic programs were suffering funding cutbacks. But when the House-Senate conference committee proposal reaches the Senate floor, I will support increased participation. My primary reason can be summed up in one simple sentence: American agriculture needs the I.M.F.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 7, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Caterpillar Patent
description: The Caterpillar Tractor Company said that a Federal appellate court had upheld a lower court ruling that Berco S.p.A., an Italian undercarriage manufacturer, infringed on Caterpillar's United States patent involving sealed and lubricated track. Caterpillar sued Berco and the Wortham Machinery Company, Berco's dealer in Cheyenne, Wyo., in 1980. The suit charged that Berco was making and selling crawler undercarriages with a specially designed seal that is a critical component of Caterpillar's sealed and lubricated track.

title: SPEEDY START FOR AMERITECH
description: At Ameritech's executive offices on the 28th floor of Illinois Bell's headquarters, the fresh carpets and new furniture still have a faint chemical smell. The bookcases are barren except for a few scattered folders. Dozens of recently hired managers are getting used to the surroundings.

title: ADVERTISING
description: * Ray Werner of Ketchum Advertising/Pittsburgh and William S. Harrington of Ketchum Advertising/ Washington, elected executive vice presidents.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Going for the Title

title: Law School Dean Quits In Sex Harassment Case
description: The dean and president of the William Mitchell College of Law has resigned amid charges of sexual harassment and what he calls ''unceasing harassment by the press.''

title: BUGGING BY U.S. PRODUCES BIG CASES AGAINST LAS VEGAS CRIME
description: Electronic surveillance has been the main tool of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and of Department of Justice prosecutors in two major organized crime cases in the Middle West aimed at breaking the underworld's grip on some elements of Nevada gambling.

title: MURDOCH DELAYING SATELLITE PLANS
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian who heads a publishing empire, has decided to postpone his plans for the start of a satellite-to- home TV system next year, an executive of the service said today.

title: ST. LOUIS GLOBE-DEMOCRAT ANNOUNCES IT WILL CLOSE THIS YEAR
description: The St. Louis Globe-Democrat, the oldest newspaper in Missouri, will cease publication Dec. 31, its publisher announced today.

title: THE MUSCULAR DOLLAR
description: According to an argument prematurely accepted as valid in much of Western Europe and the United States, high American interest rates and the overvalued dollar, which they ostensibly cause, are preventing economic recovery in Europe and threatening to abort it in America. The near-unanimity with which certain commentators on both sides of the Atlantic have adopted this view suggests that it may be flawed. It is.

title: CENTRAL RESERVE LIFE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Coaching Casualty
description: Not long ago, the beleaguered coach of the Winnipeg Jets brushed aside reports that he was about to be discharged, saying, ''Obviously, reports of my death were premature.'' Premature but ultimately correct, it turns out. Yesterday Tom Watt was removed by General Manager John Ferguson, who installed himself behind the bench as the interim replacement.

title: FILM: BUNUEL'S 'SUSANA,' MADE IN '51
description: LUIS BUNEL'S ''Susana,'' which opens at the Public Theater today, is a most engaging potboiler made by the master in Mexico in 1951. Though Bunuel never for a minute attempts to disguise the film's intentions to entertain a large, undiscriminating Latin American audience, ''Susana'' is full of the sort of Bunuelian touches that forever separate all of Bunuel's films, the potboilers as well as the classics, from those of everyone else.

title: RIBLET PRODUCTS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A Commissioner Who Is Black
description: All other things being equal, we've been thinking, this would sure be a healthy time to appoint a black as New York City's Police Commissioner. Robert McGuire has done a commendable job in his six years, but minorities express unease, even anger about police conduct. Blacks and Hispanics constitute almost half the population, but few are visible high in city government. And Mayor Koch's sensitivity to minorities could stand a high-voltage recharge.

title: HEALTH CARE FUND INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Mourning Period Ends
description: The official mourning period for Terence Cardinal Cooke ended with a mass yesterday in St. Patrick's Cathedral.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The RTE Corporation, a maker of transformers and other electrical equipment, announced yesterday a shuffling of management, with the naming of a new chairman and a new president.

title: ANDROPOV ILLNESS IS BELIEVED GRAVE
description: Senior American officials believe that Yuri V. Andropov is seriously ill and they suspect that political maneuvering over his succession may be under way.

title: Marcos Approves Raises And Tightens Security
description: The Government of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, hoping to calm mounting unrest, authorized a wage increase today and said crack troops will enforce anti- riot security in Manila.

title: INTEK DIVERSIFIED reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AROUND THE NATION Greyhound Gives Strikers a Deadline
description: Greyhound Bus Lines, which has interviewed more than 45,000 job applicants since announcing it might need to replace employees who went on strike last Thursday, told the strikers in a letter today that it wants to know by next Monday whether they were coming back to work.

title: British Retail Sales
description: The British retail sales index rose by 4 percent, to a record 117.3, in September, from 112.8 in August, the Department of Trade and Industry said today.

title: FIRMANI TO LAUNCH COSMOS OVERHAUL
description: The Cosmos hired Eddie Firmani as coach again yesterday because, they said, they needed instant success indoors and outdoors and he was the most qualified to provide both.

title: SCOUTING
description: A Track Bonus

title: ARAFAT'S ROLE FADING AWAY
description: NewsAnalysis

title: Lilco Coal Plan Rejected by Court
description: Plans by the Long Island Lighting Company to build an 800-megawatt coal-fired electric generating plant at Jamesport, L.I., have been nullified by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court.

description: Philemon Muzorewa, a son of the detained former Zimbabwean Prime Minister, Bishop Abel Muzorewa, was reportedly arrested today, a spokesman for the bishop's United African National Council party said.

description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $177,000 for the quarter and $542,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: Diagram Chess: Soviet Union's Team Wins World Youth Championship
description: The highly touted Soviet team romped to victory in the World Youth Team Championship at the University of Chicago. The grandmasters Artur Yusupov, Lev Psakhis and Sergei Dolmatov, along with Zurab Azmayparashvili and the international masters Smbat Lputian and Jan Ehlvest, scored 34-10 in the 11-round, Swiss-system tournament.

title: COHERENT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net loss. c-Including a net gain of $1,302,000 on the sale of Tropel.

title: 2,000 Schools Studying The Nuclear Arms Race By The Associated Press
description: Students in 2,000 schools in 25 states began a weeklong study of the nuclear arms race yesterday.

title: Trial Is Delayed In Brink's Case
description: Jury selection was delayed a week today in the trial of Kathy Boudin and her co-defendant, Samuel Brown, in the Brink's murder and robbery case.

title: Witnesses Testify On Ceiling's Fall
description: Witnesses told a Congressional hearing here today that human error led to the collapse of a ceiling at the Journal Square Transportation Center on Aug. 8.

title: A NEW GALAXY IS SIGHTED IN THE EARTH'S 'BACKYARD'
description: An Australian astronomer said Saturday he and his co-workers have discovered a new galaxy so close to earth that in scientific terms, it's ''almost part of our backyard.''

title: Playboy Loss Is Narrowed
description: Playboy Enterprises yesterday reported a loss for the fiscal first quarter, ended Sept. 30, of $1.4 million - less than the $2.4 million loss of a year earlier.

description: To the Editor:

TV: THE TET OFFENSIVE IN VIETNAM
description: ''VIETNAM: A TELEVISION HISTORY'' shows the seventh of its 13 episodes tonight. It is ''Tet 1968,'' an examination of what was, and still is, the least understood, most argued about, military action of the Vietnam War. It will be shown at 9 P.M. on Channel 13.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The St. Louis Cardinals have signed Manager Whitey Herzog to a new three-year contract to take effect in the 1984 season. Herzog, who became the Cardinals' manager in 1980, was working under a three-year contract that would have expired after next season. . . . Michael Spinks, the undisputed world light-heavyweight boxing champion, will defend his title Nov. 25 against top-ranked Oscar Rivadeneyra of Peru at the Pacific Coliseum in Vancouver, British Columbia.

DAMASCUS ORDERS MILITARY CALL-UP
description: Syria put its armed forces on alert and declared a general military mobilization today.

title: Harold K. Kramer, 82, Dead; Former Insurance Executive
description: Harold K. Kramer, a retired insurance executive and former president of the Greater New York Safety Council, died Oct. 30 at North Ridge Hospital in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 82 years old and lived in Lauderdale-by-the-Sea, Fla.

title: KROY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
JAPANESE AWAIT REAGAN: EVEN ARCHERY IS SUSPECT
description: Despite the autumn chill, nearby mountains are still green. Batches of newly harvested rice hang over wooden horses to dry, and farmers sit in vegetable patches pulling up ginger root and keeping an eye on the cucumber plants.

title: Yanks Seek Ban On Kuhn Action
description: With George Steinbrenner facing a potentially hefty fine and severe suspension, one of his lawyers yesterday challenged Commissioner Bowie Kuhn's ability to act fairly and objectively toward him.

title: Jessica Savitch Scholarship
description: A journalism scholarship fund has been established as a memorial to Jessica Savitch, the television newscaster who drowned Oct. 26 in an auto accident.

title: U.S. IS CAUTIONED BY MRS. THATCHER
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher warned today that American retaliatory action in Lebanon or a decision by the United States to lift its embargo on arms sales to Argentina could further damage British- American relations, which she said had already been harmed by the invasion of Grenada.

title: Kodak-Mead Pact
description: The Eastman Kodak Company said it agreed to acquire Mead Digital Systems, a producer of ink-jet printing equipment, from the Mead Corporation. Terms were not disclosed. In Dayton, Ohio, Mead said it is trying to sell technology developed by Mead Office Systems, its remaining ink-jet business, and is scaling down operations there as part of a plan to withdraw from ink-jet development and concentrate on the company's electronic publishing and forest products businesses.

title: TRANSCANADA PIPELINES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Figures were not given.

title: SELAS CORP OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Pacific Analysis
description: Helionetics Inc. said it entered into an agreement to acquire the Pacific Analysis Corporation, a Honolulu- based high-technology company involved in alternative energy. The terms of the deal were not disclosed. Pacific Analysis has an agreement in principle to design and build a prototype generating electrical plant using a combination of solar and biomass power for a major hotel chain.

title: TRUMPET CONCERT: ROLF SMEDVIG AT Y
description: ALTHOUGH he is still in his early 30's, Rolf Smedvig is already one of our finest trumpeters, capable of spinning a cantabile melodic line one moment and filling an auditorium with brilliantly assertive blasts of pure sound the next. His Sunday evening concert at the 92d Street Y was dazzling.

WELBILT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24

Pope to Visit South Korea
description: Pope John Paul II will visit Seoul next May 3-6 to commemorate the 200th anniversary of the introduction of Christianity into Korea. The South Korean news agency Yonhap, quoting a Foreign Ministry report, said today that the Pope was likely to celebrate mass at Seoul's Yoido Plaza. There was no announcement from the Foreign Ministry itself.

title: SALEM NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SPAN-AMERICA MEDICAL SYSEMS reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
WAXMAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cone Sues to Block Western Pacific
description: The Cone Mills Corporation sued Western Pacific Industries yesterday to prevent it from buying more Cone Mills shares. The move follows a promise by Cone Mills's former chairman to sell his 10.9 percent stake to Western Pacific.

title: Talking Businesswith Lorenzo of Continental Air A Painful Adjustment
description: Frank Lorenzo, chairman and chief executive of Continental Air Lines, set off a controversy by having the airline file for protection from creditors under the Federal bankruptcy code last Sept. 24. Three days later, the airline resumed operations after reducing its work force by one-third and reducing wage scales by about half.

title: Jordanian Is Killed in Attack By Gunman on Athens Street
description: A gunman shot two security guards from the Jordanian Embassy today in a street near the Acropolis, the police said. One of the vicitms died five hours later.

title: Uniguard Mutual Gets New Chief Executive
description: Richard S. L. Roddis says he will miss teaching tort and insurance law at the University of Washington in Seattle because ''I love law and my students are very bright.''

title: A LAW-ENFORCEMENT VETERAN FOR TOP POLICE POST
description: When Benjamin Ward was attending high school in Brooklyn 40 years ago, he won a citywide essay contest and was appointed ''police commissioner for a day.''

title: LINKS AIDING EUROPEAN BANKS
description: Hundreds of European banks will start linking their automatic cash dispenser systems next summer in a move that will eventually enable travelers carrying small blue plastic cards marked Eurocheque to draw cash from money machines 24 hours a day, seven days a week throughout Europe.

title: ROCK: SHADOWFAX AT BOTTOM LINE
description: SHADOWFAX, a jazzy sextet featuring a lyricon, an electric guitar, an electric violin and a rock rhythm section is a quintessential ''crossover'' group in the way it blends rock energy, a classical harmonic density and compositional feel, with some jazz improvisation.

title: COUNTRY TOWER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Freed Rikers Inmate Seized in Rape Case
description: A Rikers Island prisoner released Wednesday under the city's new bond program designed to ease jail overcrowding was arrested last night and charged with raping a woman on Friday, the police said.

title: West German Orders
description: The index of orders at West German manufacturing plants rose 1 percent in September, seasonally adjusted, after a 3.2 percent gain in August, the Economics Ministry said today.

title: HARSCO CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SENATE APPROVES FUNDS FOR THE MX
description: The Republican-controlled Senate today gave final approval of funds for the MX missile, clearing the way for full-scale production after rejecting a final effort by Democrats to thwart the project.

title: APPLE SEES FLAT PROFIT OUTLOOK
description: Apple Computer Inc. said yesterday that its earnings in the next two quarters probably would not improve from the 8 cents a share reported for its fiscal fourth quarter, ended Sept. 30. That was down sharply from 32 cents a share a year earlier.

title: JERSEY'S SUPREME COURT TO REVIEW BREATHALYZER
description: The state's highest court has decided to rule on the reliability of the Breathalyzer, a device that measures alcohol in the blood.

description: The chief United States Government spokesman on Grenada today denied reports that more than 100 bodies had been discovered in a mass grave on the island.

title: A QUIET DAY AT THE DRAFT
description: Thirteen round tables covered

title: OFF-PRICE RETAILERS GO PUBLIC
description: For at least three well-known off- price clothing merchandisers, the time was right for taking their family-owned businesses public over the last six months. But that window on Wall Street may be closing, analysts say, as the retailing industry moves into a recovery.

description: Two fashion cultures - the East and the West - clashed yesterday morning as the second week of intensive spring openings began.

title: BRIEFS

description: A State Supreme Court justice today temporarily blocked Westchester County from removing a 1-year-old girl from the home of her foster mother and placing her with a Schenectady couple who wish to adopt the child.

title: BOND ISSUE HEADS THE BALLOT FOR NEW YORK VOTERS TODAY
description: Governor Cuomo, acting as if he himself were running, ended the campaign for the $1.25 billion transportation bond issue yesterday at a traditional pre-election rally in the garment center.

description: As scientists ponder the possible causes of earthquakes, the only obvious link appears to be the churning of the earth's deep interior. Page C1.

British Producer Prices
description: British producer prices, led by higher costs for food, rose five-tenths of 1 percent in October after an increase of six-tenths of 1 percent in September, the Trade and Industry Department said today. The producer price index rose last month to 126.3, with a 1980 base of 100. Manufacturers' costs fell four-tenths of 1 percent in October, after a 1.4 percent rise in September.

title: URGES RESTRAINT
description: Against a background of American, Israeli and Syrian military buildups in the Middle East, the Reagan Administration said today that the United States had no plans to attack Syria and urged the Damascus Government to show ''restraint and prudence.''

title: GAZ METROPOLITAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MCA Down 37.7%; Loews Up
description: MCA Inc. reported yesterday that its net income in the third quarter plunged 37.7 percent from the 1982 period, which was bolstered by the strong revenues generated by its box- office hit ''E.T., the Extra-Terrestrial.''

title: OPTO MECHANIK reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Ruling Ends Potvin's Streak
description: Denis Potvin's attempt to tie a National Hockey League record for assists was stopped yesterday - not on the ice, but in the league's Montreal headquarters.

title: THE COMPLEX ORGAN KNOWN AS SKIN CONTINUES TO SURPRISE
description: THE skin may seem little more than a husk; just an expanse of surface to be covered and uncovered, tanned, shaved, painted, tattooed and otherwise assaulted for reasons of beauty, comfort, vanity or current style.

title: California Bonds
description: The California Department of Veterans Affairs sold $100 million of home purchase revenue bonds which were priced with a top yield of 9 7/8 percent for bonds due in 2008 through underwriters led by Shearson/ American Express Inc. The Aa-rated issue also included serial bonds yielding from 6 1/2 percent in 1985 to 9 1/2 percent in 1998, as well as 9 3/4 percent term bonds due in 2002.

title: ARAFAT AIDE ASKS PERSIAN GULF STATES FOR HELP
description: A high-ranking Palestinian official met tonight with leaders of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council to plead for support for Yasir Arafat, the chief of the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: DOYLE DANE BERNBACH INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results are restated to include operations of Kallir, Philips, Ross Inc., Ecom Consultants Inc. and Brignull Le Bas Gould Ltd.

title: Quarterback Toll
description: Two pro quarterbacks who began the season on the bench and were then promoted are back where they started, a result of shoulder injuries. The Denver Broncos' Steve DeBerg , who lost his job to the highly touted rookie John Elway in training camp and then regained it after five games, is expected to be out the rest of the season with a separated left shoulder that he suffered in the loss to Seattle Sunday.

description: The share earnings reflect 2-for-1 stock splits paid July 29 and Oct. 22, 1982.

title: EAST CARIBBEAN LEADERS SAY SUBVERSION THREAT PERSISTS
description: Leaders of eastern Caribbean nations told a group of Congressmen today that they remained worried about Cuban, Libyan and North Korean subversion in their region despite the downfall of the radical regime in Grenada.

title: N.B.A. Talks Resumed
description: Negotiators for the National Basketball Association and its 29 regular referees met for three hours in Philadelphia yesterday, but, though there was some progress, neither side expressed optimism that an early settlement could be reached. No new talks were scheduled.

title: PRATT & LAMBERT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures were adjusted to reflect a 3-for2 stock split on Oct. 3.

title: Election Day Choices
description: State and local offices and important policy questions are at stake in today's elections. Here is a summary of our recommendations in selected races and on public questions. Polls in New York are open from 6 A.M. to 9 P.M.; in New Jersey from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M.; in Connecticut from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. New York State Proposals

description: b-Net income. c-Net loss.

title: Roosevelt Opens
description: A crowd of 9,000 turned out for the opening of the fall meet at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, and Garmor Elite, the favorite, took the featured B-3 Pace by a half-length.

title: NEWMAN TESTIFIES FOR ACTORS STUDIO
description: Paul Newman, president of the Actors Studio, testified in Manhattan Surrogate's Court for two and a half hours yesterday afternoon, maintaining that the studio owned the tapes of sessions conducted by its artistic director, the late Lee Strasberg.

title: DENELCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Canadian Lifters Are Suspended
description: The Quebec Weightlifting Federation today issued eight-month suspensions to three members of Canada's national team who are charged with illegally importing anabolic steroids and testosterone.

description: The share earnings reflect 5-for-4 stock split paid June 20.

title: No Mandate for Secrecy
description: To the Editor:

title: ANDROPOV MISSES MOSCOW PARADE, STIRRING RUMORS
description: An ailing Yuri V. Andropov did not appear atop the Lenin Mausoleum today for the annual Revolution Day parade, breaking a Soviet tradition. Questions about his condition and its consequences spread through the diplomatic community.

title: HERMAN G. WEINBERG, WRITER AND FOREIGN FILM TRANSLATOR
description: Herman G. Weinberg, who translated major foreign films for 40 years, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 75 years old.

title: Vatican Paper Backs Surgery for Baby Doe
description: The Vatican newspaper today endorsed attempts to prolong the life of a severely handicapped Long Island baby girl whose parents have chosen to reject corrective surgery.
