description: b-Net loss

title: BARTON VALVE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net writeoff of $3.1 million due to an inventory writeoff of certain products and component parts. c-Net income.

title: MUSIC: THE YALE'S VARIED BILL
description: THE Yale School of Music presented an unusual concert in the Abraham Goodman House on Saturday night. Although the composers represented - Bach, Vivaldi, Beethoven, Villa- Lobos and the contemporary Donald Martino - were well known, the music selected was generally obscure.

title: TIDEWATER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW PLAN REALTY TRUST reports earnings for Year to July 31
ISRAEL TELLS SYRIA IT HAS NO INTENTION OF ATTACKING
description: Israel assured Syria today that it had no intention of mounting an attack against Syrian forces despite the increased tension in Lebanon.

title: Dispute Over Referee
description: Guy Jutras, whose assignment as referee for the Marvelous Marvin Hagler-Roberto Duran middleweight title fight here Thursday has been questioned by both camps, may be reassigned as a judge, an official of the World Boxing Association said today.

title: ELBIT COMPUTERS LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wilson Loses Appeal Of Gun-Sale Conviction
description: A Federal appellate court today upheld the conviction of Edwin P. Wilson on charges of illegally transporting arms to Libya, but said his 15-year sentence must be changed.

title: HIGH COURT LIFTS AN EXECUTION STAY
description: The Supreme Court, acting against three bitter dissents, today overturned a stay of execution that a Federal appeals court granted two weeks ago to a condemned Louisiana killer.

title: CENVILL INVESTORS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in May 1983.

title: TURKISH MILITARY LOSES IN ELECTION
description: In a setback for Turkey's military rulers, an independent conservative party led by an economist won a comfortable Parliamentary majority Sunday in the first elections since the generals seized power more than three years ago.

title: POWER CONVERSION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Campbell Irked
description: Earl Campbell, the Houston Oiler running back, accused his coach of mistreating him by removing him in the third quarter of the 55-14 trouncing at the hands of Cincinnati. ''I wouldn't treat my dog this badly,'' said Campbell, whose team was trailing by 41-0 when Coach Chuck Studley made the substitution.

title: Israel Trims Its Budget
description: The Israeli Government today cut the current budget by $2 billion and increased the cost to citizens of schools and health care in an effort to slow the inflation of 130 percent a year and to curb the growth of foreign debt.

title: OPERA: 'COSI' AT THE KENNEDY CENTER
description: The Washington Opera opened its season at the Kennedy Center on Saturday with a beautifully conceived and generally well-executed ''Cos i Fan Tutte.'' Its foremost success lay in the striking production by Jean- Pierre Ponnelle, which elegantly expressed traditional Classical values by means of unusual vocabulary.

title: British Parley On Recovery
description: Britain's largest business group said today that the nation's shaky economic recovery could end next year if the Government fails to cut business costs and stimulate capital investment.

title: Article 025512 -- No Title
description: To the Editor:

title: SCOUTING
description: Big Ten Leads

title: A CALF ON TH UTAH OPERATING TABLE
description: ANYWHERE I poke a finger into the hide of the Hereford calf, I leave an imprint. This calf is so sick from heart disease it is soggy inside, swollen with edema, excess body fluid its failing heart could not manage. Because of the heart failure, caused by an unusual disorder of cattle called brisket disease, the 3-month-old calf is getting an artificial heart.

title: Key Vote on Poison Gas
description: The Senate will decide today whether to preserve a 14-year moratorium on poison gas production or to finance a new competition in abhorrent and unnecessary weapons.

title: I.T.C. SEES INJURY FROM EUROPEAN STEEL
description: The International Trade Commission said today there are indications that the domestic steel industry is being injured by underpriced imports of carbon steel plate from West Germany and Belgium.

title: ENERGY MINERALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Sudanese to Meet Reagan
description: President Gaafar al-Nimeiry of the Sudan will meet President Reagan Nov. 21 during an official visit to Washington, the White House announced today. It will be Mr. Nimeiry's first visit to Washington in two years.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You may say that the Americanscould not have this in their backyard.

title: A REPORT TO RUMSFELD
description: America's new Middle East negotiator, Donald Rumsfeld, is yet another beginner who will have to find his way through the world's most intricately patterned minefield. It is a handicap in an area of short fuses and long memories. Yet he can turn fresh eyes to advantage.

title: Charlotte Curtis
description: The David Rockefeller Touch

title: MUSIC: SAN FRANCISCANS
description: THERE are strains of American music that are quite distinct from or even deliberately opposed to the European intellectual musical tradition. ''Serious'' works by such idiosyncratic inventors as Charles Ives or Harry Partch and John Cage, for example, brashly map out their own territories. But there has also developed in this century a distinctly American music that is heir to the European musical tradition, that accepts its strictures and works within it, approaching it without the anxiety of an innocent abroad, feeling free to alter it in striking, unexpected ways.

title: ANALYST FOR CITY GETS A JOB BACK AND AN APOLOGY
description: An analyst for New York City who was demoted after documenting mismanagement in the city's Medicaid Assistance Program will be restored to his former job and be given an apology by the city, the Mayor's office announced yesterday.

title: Suspect Is Arrested In Hollywood Slayings
description: A convicted rapist was arrested today in connection with the murders of two of 32 older women killed in the last two years in Hollywood.

title: Mattel Bid to Sell Western Reported
description: Mattel Inc., which has been beset by losses of more than $200 million in its home computer and video games division, declined to comment on reports that it is seeking to sell its profitable Western Publishing Company subsidiary for about $100 million.

title: FIBRONICS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: EXAMINATION OF LIBEL LAW WILL BROADEN
description: The Supreme Court, expanding its examination of libel law, agreed today to decide whether the Constitutional protection of the press against libel suits by private individuals protects other organizations to the same extent.

title: Flaherty Service Nov. 18
description: A memorial service for Joe Flaherty, the author and newspaperman, will be held at noon Nov. 18 at the New School Auditorium at 66 West 12th Street. Mr. Flaherty, the author of four books and a former staff member at The Village Voice, died last week of cancer at the age of 47. He will be eulogized at the service by Mayor Koch and the novelist Wilfrid Sheed.

title: BRIEFING
description: Switch by Georgia O'Keeffe

title: Q & A
description: Q.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: LANDMARK It is one of the most beautiful buildings in New York, the old Federal Custom House at the foot of Broadway, opposite Bowling Green Park, a birthday cake of classical architecture framed by cloud-reaching monoliths that make up much of lower Manhattan. On the outside, this lush 1907 edifice, designed by Cass Gilbert, is a cascade of marble and sculpture. Inside, the rooms are no less ornate, from the gilt-edged ceiling with paintings of old ships and harborscapes in the collector's office, to the marvelous mural of a working port in the rotunda.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Milwaukee Bucks , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. This is the Knicks' first meeting of the season with the Bucks, who won four of six games from them last season.

title: MISSOURI PUBLIC SERVICE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 8, 1983 International
description: Washington urged Syria to show ''restraint and prudence'' and said the United States had no plans to attack Syrian forces. The comments by senior officials came as Israel and Syria called up reservists and the United States strengthened its naval forces in the eastern Mediterranean. Still, a senior State Department official said that the United States and Israel were concerned and uncertain over the consequences of what he said was ''an increasingly hard line'' on the part of Syria. (Page A1, Column 6.) Israel assured Syria it had no intention of mounting an attack against Syrian forces. Israel has announced plans for a mobilization of its forces later this week, but officials said it was a routine, semiannual maneuver that was ''in no way connected with events in Lebanon.'' (A15:2-4.)

title: CRUTCHER RESOURCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: INTEREST RATES ARE STABILIZED
description: Interest rates stabilized yesterday, as government securities dealers, who make the markets in Treasury issues, estimated that the increases in rates last week were enough to attract investors for this week's heavy schedule of Treasury financings.

title: KEANE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
British Plane-Ship Deal
description: British Airways today signed its biggest charter contract yet for the Concorde to fly passengers one-way over the Atlantic after they cross on the Queen Elizabeth 2. The $8.25 million deal with Cunard is for 65 London-New York flights, starting in April 1985.

title: LAW ALLOWS GIVING GOODS SEIZED FROM PEDDLERS TO NEEDY
description: Property that the city confiscates from illegal peddlers could go to the poor, the homeless, the elderly and schoolchildren instead of being auctioned, under a bill signed yesterday by Mayor Koch.

title: CALIFORNIA REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains on the sale of real estate of $951,000 for the quarter and $1,078,000 for the 9 months. c-Including a gain of $279,000 on the sale of real estate.

PLAYSRoy S. Johnson; Kicker Gets Tall Order
description: Bruce Kallmeyer, a senior place- kicker for the University of Kansas, looked down the field just before a kick attempt late in the third quarter against Colorado last Saturday and saw the goalposts swaying in the distance 55 yards away. He then looked down and thought to himself, ''sombody is out to get me or something.''

title: VULCAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes nonrecurring realized gains from the sale of assets of $118,581 for the quarter and $624,735 for the 9 months, and a loss from the sale of a unit of $191,614 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Includes nonrecurring realized gains from the sale of assets of $517,491 for the quarter and $729,005 for the 9 months, and a $37,597 reversal of a writedown for the quarter.

title: U.S. RELIEF AID IN GRENADA SEEN AS LONG-RANGE EFFORT
description: A United States relief and rehabilitation program in Grenada, initiated after the United States-led invasion, appears to be unfolding as a long-range assistance effort.

title: PHILADELPHIA AND OTHERS VOTE TODAY
description: Philadelphians are expected to elect their first black Mayor Tuesday in one of the most widely watched of many off-year elections scattered across the country.

title: Jury Expected to Get Case on Illegal Entry
description: A Federal jury here is expected to receive the case Tuesday of two Irish nationalists and a Canadian accused of trying to help them enter the United States illegally in January 1982.

title: 4 NAMED TO JURY IN FEMINIST'S TRIAL
description: The first four members of the jury were picked today in the murder trial of Ginny Foat, the California feminist accused of killing an Argentine businessman in a robbery near here 18 years ago.

title: HOMOSEXUALS INCREASINGLY FLEX POLITICAL MUSCLE
description: Here on the rolling farmland of the Midwest, where Grant Wood painted ''American Gothic'' and other commentaries on plain values and the upright life, the streets of San Francisco and Greenwich Village seem far away.

title: IBH'S TEREX TAKES CHAPTER 11 STEP
description: The Terex Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest construction equipment maker, has filed for bankruptcy protection, following the lead of its parent company, IBH Holding A.G. of West Germany.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Bethlehem Corp., Easton, Pa., has named Niel C. Cavanaugh president and chief operating officer.

title: AN AUTHOR THRUSTS INTO THE COSMOS
description: FEW people give gravity a thought. Their feet are on the ground, always have been, and that is that. Only its absence in the ordinary sense, as in space flight, elevates gravity from the feet to the mind, where it must linger as a memory of what has been left behind. Gravity, in the mind of Hortense Calisher, is part of the ''dowry we give up when we go into outer space.''

title: Advertising; Lingerie Campaign Reshaped
description: AMONG the questions to be answered this week as New York's garment trade begins to show its spring lines to visiting buyers will be, ''Where will the Maidenform Woman turn up next, if at all?''

description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $386,000 for the quarter and $878,000 for the 9 months.

title: PITTWAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Girl Back in Hospital
description: Cancer-stricken Pamela Hamilton returned to East Tennessee Children's Hospital today to resume court-ordered chemotherapy despite her religious beliefs after a restful 11 days at home, officials said. She entered the hospital Sept. 12. Dennis Prewitt, director of the Campbell County Human Services Department, said the family did not interfere with the 12-year-old girl's return.

title: Manville Gets 10th Extension United States Bankruptcy
description: Judge Burton R. Lifland gave the Manville Corporation two more weeks to try to agree with its creditors on a reorganization plan. Yesterday's extension was the tenth in the 14 months since Manville filed for protection from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws, citing the financial burden of thousands of lawsuits filed by workers with asbestos- related diseases.

title: G.M. RAISES DIVIDEND 40 CENTS, TO $1 A SHARE
description: The General Motors Corporation yesterday raised its quarterly dividend to $1 dollar a share, up from the 60 cents a share it has been paying since the second quarter of 1980.

title: U.N. PUTS OFF DECISION ON CREDENTIALS OF GRENADA
description: The credentials committee of the General Assembly adjourned today without a decision on a United States challenge to the credentials of Grenada.

title: DR. ARTHUR I. BLIEDEN
description: Dr. Arthur I. Blieden, an orthopedic surgeon in Manhattan for more than 40 years, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 72 years old.

title: GIANTS' EVANS CHOSEN TOP FREE AGENT
description: Forty-five players tested the talent market yesterday in baseball's eighth annual free-agent draft, and the hottest property was Darrell Evans, the power-hitting infielder from the San Francisco Giants, who was named by 17 teams.

title: UNITED PRESIDENTIAL LIFE INSURANCE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INTRIGUE AND ACCUSATIONS IN A CURIOUS LANDFILL CASE
description: Behind a locked gate, a desolate tract containing landfill and rotting piers on the Queens waterfront in College Point has set off a strange and bitter struggle that has engulfed a State Senator and those he accuses of a ''political blackmail scheme.''

title: Polish Liner Cancels Cruise
description: A Caribbean winter cruise by the Polish liner Stefan Batory has been canceled because of the United States invasion of Grenada and tension in the region, the Polish press agency said today. The vessel, owned by Polish Ocean Lines, will make a cruise to the Canary Islands, it added.

title: THE COST OF SAVING MONEY ON EMBASSIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Shultz to Attend NATO Talks Due in Brussels Next Month
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will attend a meeting of foreign ministers of North Atlantic Treaty Organization countries in Brussels Dec. 8 and 9, the State Department announced today.

title: COMMODITIES Strength in Blue Chips Weakens Index Spread
description: Because blue-chip stocks held steady in yesterday's relatively modest market decline, one of the most popular index futures spreads became a bit less attractive. The spread, which has been extremely profitable since the market shot up in August 1982, involved buying the Value Line index and selling the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index short.

title: Market Place; Vartan Picking Stocks Based on Value
description: WHILE many money managers nervously eye the erratic swings of the stock market, Leonard M. Heine Jr. patiently goes about managing $375 million for clients with an investment approach geared to value.

title: Law Firm Embraces Bankruptcy Business
description: A newly formed and little known law firm, McCabe/Gordon of Boston, has been finding its share of business in the growing field of bankruptcy proceedings and company reorganization.

description: To the Editor:

title: TELEPHONE RATE RISE REVIEWED
description: Requests for $6.7 billion in higher local telephone rates are pending before state public service commissions across the country, and $1.5 billion of local phone rate increases have already approved this year, an Associated Press survey shows.

title: Trial of Secretary In Slaying Begins
description: Mary Barbara Austin, a secretary who shot and killed her employer, a Manhattan lawyer, ''knew what she was doing, knew the consequences, knew it was wrong, and we will prove that she simply didn't care,'' said Sarah Jo Hamilton, an assistant district attorney, on the first day of Miss Austin's trial in State Supreme Court in Manhattan yesterday.

title: INTELLIGENCEWISE
description: Greatly stirred by the newest heroic naval rhetoric from an American admiral, I fell to musing on the great antecedents in this gallant line. At once, I was startled to realize that none of these historic gems has been translated into contemporary English, and so a whole generation of American teachers, and God knows how many generations of children, have been denied access to this part of their heritage.

title: WISER OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Curtis Benjamin Dies; Led McGraw-Hill Unit
description: Curtis G. Benjamin, who spent a 38-year publishing career with the McGraw-Hill Book Company before retiring as its chairman in 1966, died Saturday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.

title: AT THE A.F.L.-C.I.O., BLUE NOTEBOOKS FOR MONDALE
description: At a meeting in a Washington hotel this morning, a group of 37 employees of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. received blue plastic notebooks with the word ''Confidential'' stamped on their covers. Inside each notebook was a manual titled ''Organizing for Delegate Selection.''

A PSYCHOLOGY OF LIFE IN SPACE IS URGED
description: THE time is fast approaching, according to two psychologists, when behavioral scientists should give greater attention to the potential effects of long-duration space travel on the human psyche.

title: Suspect in 165 Murders Goes on Trial for One
description: Henry Lee Lucas, a drifter who claims to have killed 165 people, went on trial today in the slaying of a 15-year-old girl he says he cut into ''little teeny pieces.''

title: Strike Could Hurt Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation's auto workers headed back to work after a five-day local strike against forced overtime and poor working conditions that analysts say could cost the company up to $75 million in profits.

title: CORRECTION
description: A candidate listing in Metropolitan Report yesterday omitted the name of a Republican countywide candidate for Civil Court in Manhattan. He is Lloyd R. Targer.

description: President Kim Il Sung of North Korea may be visiting Chinese leaders in Peking on a secret mission, diplomatic sources reported today.

description: Grey Advertising and Doyle Dane Bernbach announced third-quarter earnings yesterday. Grey was up 23.1 percent, while D.D.B. showed a net loss, as it did in the same period a year ago.

title: GREYHOUND THREATENS TO REPLACE ITS STRIKERS
description: Greyhound Lines told its striking employees today to say by Monday whether they planned to come back to work, and threatened to replace them with newly hired employees.

title: 4,000 APARTMENTS PLANNED FOR HOMELESS CITY FAMILIES
description: New York City's Housing Commissioner said yesterday that the city would provide more than 4,000 permanent apartments for homeless families and individuals over the next 18 months.

title: AN ATTACK CLOSES BEIRUT'S AIRPORT
description: The Beirut airport was closed tonight after the runways and nearby positions of the American Marines came under fire from unidentified gunmen that killed a Lebanese civilian and wounded a marine and a Lebanese soldier.

title: A CAP FOR THE NUCLEAR ARMS RACE IN EUROPE
description: To the Editor:

title: BRITISH AND IRISH PREMIERS DISCUSS ULSTER
description: The Prime Ministers of Britain and Ireland met today in an effort to remove a chill in relations between the two countries that has developed since the last such meeting more than two years ago.

title: AT 50, ESQUIRE MAGAZINE GIVES A TRAVELING PARTY
description: Esquire magazine threw itself a traveling 50th birthday party yesterday and at the first stop, breakfast at Gracie Mansion, it announced the names of those Americans that it dubbed ''50 who made the difference.''

title: DEBATE OVER ENGINEERING COUSRSES
description: ABATTLE over the creation of two new engineering programs at the State University of New York's College at New Paltz is focusing attention on several issues that face higher education across the country as colleges struggle to allocate scarce resources.

title: CANNIBALISM AMONG THE FIREFLIES
description: ON a balmy summer's evening, the sight of fireflies carving their graceful illuminated arcs over dark lawns and fields adds a peaceful benediction to the scene. Male fireflies blink the luminescent code of their species while females of the same species respond to it with their own code, usually followed by mating. The visual pattern seems to be one of nature's rhapsodies.

title: OPERA: RICHARD STRAUSS, 'DIE LIEBE DER DANAE'
description: NOT many pieces of music labor under greater burdens than ''Die Liebe der Danae,'' the next-to-last of Richard Strauss's 15 operas. Written in Germany during World War II by an opportunist who let himself be used by the Nazis as a cultural exhibit, it has been under a political cloud ever since. Its libretto, a piece of muddled mythology worked up by the pedantic Josef Gregor and painfully hammered into shape by the composer and others, is weak and contorted. The score is incredibly complex and fiercely difficult to sing, representing Strauss in his late, almost too luxuriant mood. His infatuation with his own orchestral technique led him in this work as in others, early and late, to pack in the notes at times when lean simplicity might have been more powerful.

title: TV: A MOTHER-SON BOND
description: LINDSAY WAGNER, once best known as the Bionic Woman, seems bent these days on developing the art of the quick exit. Although she had top billing in ''Princess Daisy'' a couple nights ago, she hung around only long enough, before being disposed of in an off-camera car accident, for the title character to reach the tender age of 6. Now, early on in ''Two Kinds of Love,'' this evening's television movie on CBS-TV at 9 o'clock, she enters a hospital and becomes a disembodied voice over a telephone before disappearing permanently. Again she gets top billing. It is, as the song says, nice work if you can get it.

description: The United Nations ought to get out of New York for its own good. New York is a hard place to live. It can corrode the purest soul, sour the sweetest spirit, drive the sanest mind to madness and make the most civil gentleman behave like an untutored lout.

description: Rabbi Mordecai M. Kaplan, founder of the Jewish Reconstructionist movement and an emeritus professor at the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, died yesterday at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He was 102 years old.

description: the Greyhound Corporation has stopped making health and welfare trust fund payments for 2,200 retired employees and will cut off benefits to 4,000 more unless a new labor contract is signed by Nov. 15, a company spokesman said today.

title: Denial by Pruitt
description: Greg Pruitt, the Los Angeles Raiders kick returner, was named in court testimony as a onetime customer of a slain suspected cocaine dealer. But Pruitt, acknowledging that he had experimented with cocaine, denied that he had ever purchased any from the man, Edward Hanna , a former insurance broker who was shot to death in Ohio last March.

description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos and his ruling party decided today to set up a seven-member parliamentary committee to study the question of whether to restore the office of Vice President.

title: AN UNSUNG 'GOOD GERMAN': FAME COMES AT LAST
description: In the aftermath of World War II, many Germans came forward to proclaim that they had been secretly against the Nazis, or had carried out ''inner resistance'' to Hitler's dictatorship. But Eduard Schulte kept his secret.

title: DON'T TILT TOWARD IRAQ
description: Delivery in the past month of five French Super Etendard aircraft to Iraq has prompted a re-evaluation of American neutrality in the Iran-Iraq war. At the same time, evidence of Iranian complicity in the truck-bombing of Marines in Beirut might help tilt the United States toward Iraq. Such a realignment would serve no useful American purpose and might indeed be a grave mistake.

Barnes, 61 years old, as ''a rusty wire twister in pin stripes,'' an allusion to his early days with the Bell System in Ohio when he was a repairman and a lineman and his father was wire chief.

title: Confessed Killer Makes Not-Guilty Plea in Texas
description: Henry Lee Lucas, a drifter who has admitted killing more than 165 people, pleaded not guilty today to a murder charge stemming from the mutilation- slaying of his 15-year-old traveling companion.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1983
description: The Economy The House opens debate today on a measure that could have a broad impact on telephone rates. The fate of the bill, opposed by A.T. &T. but supported by consumer groups, is considered too close to call. It would repeal an F.C.C. order requiring phone users to begin paying a new monthly fee for ''access'' to long-distance networks. (Page D1.) The S.E.C. is expected to issue a ban today on premature trading in stock of the streamlined A.T.& T. and the seven regional companies that it is spinning off. (D1.) State and local governments may not regulate television programming distributed via satellite to private homes, the F.C.C. ruled. The decision involved a small but growing service that many communities regard as a threat to cable TV service. (D10.)

title: G.M. Board Backs Nigeria Truck Tie
description: The General Motors Corporation's board has approved an agreement with the Nigerian Government to begin assembling Isuzu light commercial trucks at a new plant near the Chad border starting in late 1985.

Jordania Will Conduct
description: The conductor Giuseppe Patane will not appear with the American Symphony on Nov. 13 at Carnegie Hall, due to illness. Taking his place for the all-Tchaikovsky program will be the Russian conductor Vato Jordania, who defected to the United States in July; this marks Mr. Jordania's debut with an American group.

title: Generals Say No to Sipe
description: It's been more than a month since the Generals first expressed an interest in signing the Cleveland Browns quarterback, Brian Sipe, and when Sipe came to New York yesterday to talk things over with the Generals' owner, Donald Trump, he was apparently either a few days too late or a few dollars too expensive. Following the meeting, Trump issued a two-sentence statement saying that the Generals were ''not interested in Brian Sipe'' because the Generals are now interested in ''someone else.'' Trump, who has said he has three or four prospective quarterbacks in mind, did not identify the ''someone else,'' but there have been reports he has his eyes on Steve DeBerg of the Denver Broncos.

title: Earthquake in Belgium Kills 2 and Injures 26
description: An earthquake struck this east Belgian city early today, killing 2 people and causing considerable damage to buildings.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday on election contests gave an incorrect date for the Boston mayoral election. It is next Tuesday.

description: President Reagan arrived here this afternoon as he began a seven-day trip to Japan and South Korea designed to strengthen economic and political ties with both countries.

Ad Director Resigns From Woman's Day
description: Jay Burzon, vice president, advertising director and associate publisher of Woman's Day magazine, having been passed over for the publisher's job three times, resigned this week from CBS Publications, the parent. He is being replaced as ad director by Robert Mate, 37-year-old former advertising manager.

title: OHIO VOTERS DECISIVELY TURN BACK TWO MEASURES TO CURB STATE TAXES
description: Two measures that would have cut Ohio income taxes almost in half and required a three-fifths approval by both houses of the Legislature for any future tax increases were soundly defeated today.

title: U.S. SEES PROSPECT FOR MIDEAST TALKS
description: Reagan Administration officials said today that the deepening rebellion in the Palestine Liberation Organization could provide an opportunity to renew efforts to bring King Hussein of Jordan and West Bank Palestinians into negotiations with Israel.

description: The Justice Department today began actively seeking a buyer for The St. Louis Globe-Democrat, which announced Monday that it planned to cease publication Dec. 31.

F.C.C. BARS LOCAL SATELLITE-TV RULES

title: RESEARCHERS REPORT GENETIC TEST DETECTS HUNTINGTON DISEASE
description: The first genetic test for detecting one of the most frightening and serious of hereditary diseases was reported here today by a team of scientists at the Massachusetts General Hospital.

title: IT BEGAN AS A RATHER ORDINARY PIECE OF LEGISLATION
description: It began last spring as a rather ordinary piece of legislation: some emergency highway money for states suffering flood damage.

title: COHALAN WINS RE-ELECTION IN SUFFOLK
description: The Suffolk County Executive, Peter F. Cohalan, a strong opponent of the Shoreham nuclear power plant, won re- election yesterday in a race that was widely considered to be a referendum on the plant.

title: Mets' Farm Aide Linked to Bribe
description: John Tamargo, the manager of the Mets' farm club at Columbia, S.C., in the South Atlantic League, has been indicted with his father on charges of lying to a Federal grand jury about what authorities say was a $75,000 bribery offer to a state prosecutor.

title: TO DELAY GLOBAL WARMING
description: ,0 studies by the Environmental Protection Agency and the National Academy of Sciences suggest that a strange new world is in our future. An atmospheric greenhouse effect caused primarily by the burning of fossil fuels will make the Earth a hotter and more difficult place to live during the next century. The E.P.A. report states explicitly and the Academy report implies that little can be done to forestall this climatic change, and that Government efforts should focus on adaptation. For an energy- guzzling nation whose serious attempts to control pollution are barely a decade old, this amounts to throwing in the towel in round one.

description: The revenue figures for the latest and year-earlier quarters included $1.5 billion from insurance finance and the revenue for both 9-month periods included $4.5 billion from insurance finance.

title: ART: 'JUDAIC TREASURES' OPENS IN WASHINGTON
description: ''The Precious Legacy: Judaic Treasures From the Czechoslovak State Collections,'' an exhibition opening Wednesday in the Smithsonian Institution's Museum of Natural History here, contains two big stories. One is the history and culture of Czechoslovak Jewry, the oldest continuous Jewish community in Europe. The other is the fate of that community during the Holocaust, when its members were deported and killed and their possessions sent to a Jewish museum in Prague that the Nazis hoped would become a research and propaganda center on an extinct people.

title: ANGOLA JET CRASH SAID TO KILL 150
description: An Angolan jetliner crashed shortly after takeoff from an airport in southern Angola today, killing as many as 150 passengers and crew members, according to news reports from Yugoslavia and Angola.

title: DELTONA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a pretax charge of $22.7 million for permit costs on the Marco Island community.

description: Southwestern Bell is proud, almost to the point of arrogance, of its heritage as the largest and the fastest-growing of the 22 Bell operating companies. As a reward, the company feels, it will be one of only two Bell operating subsidiaries to be left intact at divestiture on Jan. 1.

title: Cone Mills Studies Takeover Defense
description: The Cone Mills Corporation said its board has instructed management to continue to study alternatives available to the company in the wake of a takeover attempt by the Western Pacific Corporation.

title: ON WEST COAST THE CITI SLEEPS
description: In many ways, Betty Sue Peabody does not fit the Citicorp image. Although she is president and chief execuive officer of a Citicorp subsidiary, she speaks quietly and is almost self- effacing. And she says ''we'' when she talks about the savings and loan industry, traditionally the bitter rival of all commercial banks.

title: STIFFER RULES APPROVED FOR LEGAL AID TO POOR
description: The board of directors of the Federal Legal Services Corporation voted Monday to approve new regulations that critics say will make it more difficult for low- income people to get help with legal problems.

description: Continental Air Lines, which has been operating under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Act since Sept. 24, said yesterday that it had a third-quarter loss of $77.2 million, compared with earnings of $4.6 million in the period a year earlier.

description: Whether tournaments in general are getting bigger is not clear, but particular ones certainly are. The District 4 Regional Championships, which ended Sunday in Lancaster, Pa., was apparently the biggest regional tournament ever played anywhere: 4,500 tables were in play during five days, a 900-a-day average that stems from many years of effort by Eleanor Alboum, the tournament chairman.

description: A prominent St. Louis banker, Richard F. Ford, announced his resignation yesterday as president, chief operating officer and a director of the Centerre Bank and its parent, the Centerre Bancorporation.

title: MGM FALLS
description: The ITT Corporation reported yesterday that its third-quarter net income slipped 10.9 percent compared with the period last year, largely because of a one-time gain last year of $33 million.

title: COAST'S LATEST: 'FRANCASIAN' CUISINE
description: LOS ANGELES LIKE many things here, cuisine gets a face lift every few years. And the latest wrinkle is a blend of French and Oriental cuisines, which, for lack of a existing term, might be called ''FrancAsian,'' pronounced ''FrongKasian.''

description: Ex-G.E. Officer to Head A Unit of John Brown

title: STATE DEPT. CITES CONFUSION FOR FALSE REPORT ON MASS GRAVE
description: The assertion that more than 100 bodies had been discovered on Grenada, and the denial a day later, were the result of confusion and a lack of communication among officials in Washington and others on the Caribbean island, State Department officials said today.

title: Charter Annuities Being Cashed In
description: The Charter Company said its annuities continue to be cashed in faster than usual, but it said it has enough cash to meet the demands.

title: PACKAGING SYSTEMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings reflect a 25 percent stock dividend declared in August.

title: SPECIAL PASSENGERS, SPECIAL SERVICE
description: In the last six weeks, Maj. Gregory P. Ulrich of the Air Force has flown to Honolulu, Midway Island, Tokyo, Peking, Hong Kong, Colombo, Sri Lanka, Islamabad and Peshawar in Pakistan, Cairo, Rome, Shannon Airport in Ireland, San Juan, P.R., Kingston and Montego Bay in Jamaica, Frankfurt, Naples and Beirut. His passengers have included Vice President Bush, Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger, William P. Clark, the former national security adviser, and Gen. Paul X. Kelley, the Commandant of the Marine Corps.

title: CELTICS DEFEAT PACERS, 99-97
description: Robert Parish scored off a rebound as time expired, giving the Boston Celtics a 99-97 victory over the Pacers tonight.

title: GTE Settles Iran Contract Dispute
description: The GTE Corporation said it had settled a contract dispute with Iran stemming from the taking of American hostages in November 1979 and the resulting breakoff of diplomatic relations.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Bell Canada's Steady Climb
description: WHILE tremendous investor attention has focused on the Jan. 1 target date for the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, shares of another telephone company, based north of the border, have been climbing steadily on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: HOUSE VOTES ON SYNDICATION
description: The House, virtually without debate, approved a bill today that would temporarily bar ABC, CBS and NBC from acquiring an ownership interest in the programs they broadcast.

title: HIGH COURT FOCUSES ON 3 LIBEL CASES
description: The Supreme Court, which has taken a particular interest in libel cases in recent months, heard arguments today in three cases, raising issues that ranged from the circumstances under which publications and their employees can be sued in distant states to the proper function of Federal appeals courts in reviewing libel judgments.

title: RMS ELECTRONICS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CHECKS AND BALANCES
description: TO say that Barry Kaplan is compulsive about keeping a tidy, well-ordered checkbook doesn't begin to state the case. But perhaps that's just the attitude one would expect from a tax lawyer.

title: ANDERSON FOUNDS A POLITICAL PARTY
description: John B. Anderson, an independent Presidential candidate in 1980, announced Monday that he was forming a new political party and said he would run for the White House again ''if the party were to ask me to be a standard bearer.''

title: Biggs and Breland Gain in Boxing
description: Tyrell Biggs of Philadelphia outpointed Craig Payne of Livonia, Mich., in a super-heavyweight bout today and advanced to the quarterfinals of the United States Amateur Boxing Championships.

title: A Lion Faces Fine For Hitting Referee
description: Referee Dick Jorgensen has a swollen lip and a stitch beneath it, and Larry Lee has a wallet that may soon be $200 lighter. But those were the only casualties of a mistaken forearm blow in the last four minutes of the game between the Giants and the Detroit Lions Monday night.

title: Arrest in Shooting Of Officer on S.I.
description: A suspect in the Staten Island shooting of an off-duty New York City police officer on Nov. 1 was arrested yesterday in Lawrence, Mass.

title: The Debt Limit Backfires
description: Thanks to Senate dawdling, interest on the national debt jumped up by a needless $45 million Monday. It will probably jump more today, and again tomorrow by a still larger amount. This is the cost of playing games with the national debt limit, and good reason to stop right now.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Election Day

title: Court Approves of Testifying By Children Against Parents
description: The Massachusetts Supreme Court, in a split opinion, ruled Monday that a minor could be compelled to testify against a parent in a grand jury investigation of a murder case.

title: Article 029298 -- No Title
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company, in a major move to improve its competitive position,, said yesterday that it would invest $1.7 billion over the next five years to modernize more than 600 of its existing stores and open 62 new ones to compete more strongly with department stores.

title: Democrat Chief Hails Gains As Good News for 1984 Vote
description: Charles Manatt, the Democratic National chairman, today hailed gains in off-year elections as ''good news'' for the party's hopes in 1984.

title: Economic Scene; Expectations And Forecasts
description: FORECASTING is the bane of economists, but it is also their bread and butter. Business executives, investors, politicians and the general public turn to economists for their predictions as a basis for decisions, then blast them as charlatans when the predictions go wrong. But, after every downfall, the economists pick themselves up, dust themselves off and start all over again, as do most of their customers - those who survived.

title: Issue of Lie Detectors Posed in DeLorean Case
description: A hearing on the admissibility of conflicting polygraphic, or lie detector, tests in the John Z. DeLorean drug trafficking case resumed today, two weeks after it was delayed by a nationwide telecast of videotaped evidence.

title: WINE TALK
description: Georges Duboeuf, who is a kind of one-man General Motors of Beaujolais, was lunching at a restuarant called the Auberge du Cep here in the Rhone Valley the other day with his son Frank and two friends. Frank Duboeuf, 23 years old, had just joined his father in the wine business after 18 months of military service.

title: MGM-UA ENTERTAINMENT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary gain of $2,511,000.

title: SLOW-COOKED, SPICY FARE OF ETHIOPIA
description: ''EVERY young woman in Ethiopia must know how to cut up a chicken,'' Sarah Wolde Selassie said as she propped a plump Cornish hen on the work counter of her kitchen. With swift, efficient motions she removed the skin (including the crinkled edge on the wings), cut the bird in 12 nearly bite-size serving pieces, neatly trimming off every bit of fat.

title: TELERATE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFING
description: Results From Muskingum

title: Japan Machine Orders
description: Japanese machinery orders in the private sector, excluding ships, fell by 5.5 percent in September to the equivalent of $2.14 billion, seasonally adjusted, from $2.27 billion in August, the Economic Planning Agency said today. Unadjusted September orders were off 3.1 percent from a year ago.

title: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 9, 1983 International
description: A Democratic shift on Grenada was signaled by House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. Reversing his criticism of President Reagan for practicing ''gunboat diplomacy'' in the invasion of Grenada, Mr. O'Neill said that a 14- member House fact-finding mission had convinced him that the action was ''justified'' to rescue endangered Americans. (Page A1, Column 6.) A shallow grave containing four burned bodies was found by United States soldiers acting on a tip from a Grenadian cook. The Grenadian said that one body was that of the ousted Prime Minister Maurice Bishop, who was slain. (A12:3.)

title: CHURCH'S STOCK UP ON RUMORS
description: Church's Fried Chicken Inc.'s stock jumped 2 1/8, to 28 7/8, yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange amid unconfirmed reports that the company was a takeover target.

title: BAKER, MICHAEL, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Net income. Revenue figures represent contract income.

title: HYDROMER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OGILVY & MATHER INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest 9 months are restated to reflect the acquisition of Dudley-Anderson-Yutzy Public Relations Inc. accounted for as a pooling of interest.

title: JUDGE IS ASKED TO DROP SUIT FOR BABY'S RECORDS
description: The New York State Attorney General and the parents of Baby Jane Doe yesterday asked a Federal judge to dismiss a suit seeking the confidential medical records of the severely handicapped infant.

description: U.C.L.A. Facing Early Game Day

title: People
description: * John Costello, Renee Summer and Richard Wysocki have been appointed senior vice presidents of Ted Bates Advertising/New York.

Zimbabwe Court Orders Release of Nkomo Aid
description: A High Court judge ruled today that the detention of Dumiso Dabengwa, a top aide of Joshua Nkomo, the opposition leader, was illegal and ordered his released within 24 hours.

title: LIMITED INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: The year-earlier share earnings were restated for 2-for-1 stock splits in November 1982 and June 1983. The year-earlier 9-month period includes operations of Lane Bryant Inc. subsequent to May 1982.

title: MATRIX CORP reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Includes loss from discontinued operations. Corrected from Tuesday's editions.

description: b-Net income.

title: U.S. OFFICERS GIVE INVASION DETAILS
description: United States officers who served in Grenada described the invasion today as an operation mounted by a larger force than was eventually needed. They also provided new details on how news of the inadvertent bombing of a mental hospital reached the command.

title: COASTAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV: MICKEY ROONEY IN 'BILL' SEQUEL
description: LAST year, Mickey Rooney deservedly won several awards for his performance in the television movie ''Bill,'' the true story of a mentally retarded man who, after spending 44 years in an institution, begins trying to establish a life in the outside world. Never at a loss to milk a good thing, television has now come up with a sequel, ''Bill: On His Own,'' which can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on CBS.

title: NATURE'S BOUNTY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STEINBRENNER: FAN VS. OWNER
description: One Sunday afternoon last summer, George Steinbrenner, the principal owner of the Yankees, was sitting behind the large tan circular desk in his office at Yankee Stadium. Nearby was a leather chair in the shape of a baseball glove. His office, his position and even the chair are a fan's dream. And Steinbrenner luxuriates in it.

title: IRAQ HINTS AT NEW MOVE TO FORCE IRAN TO TALK
description: Iraq appears to be moving toward an attempt to force Iran to the conference table by striking at its oil-exporting capacity, Western diplomats and other analysts of the region here said today.

title: Oh Becomes Manager
description: Sadaharu Oh , the Babe Ruth of Japanese baseball, is getting a chance the Babe never had - to manage the club he played for. Oh, who retired in 1981 after 22 years and 868 home runs with the Tokyo Yomiuri Giants, was named manager of the Giants yesterday, a day after the Central League club lost the last game of Japanese World Series to the Pacific League's Seibu Lions.

title: REACTOR FUELING IS APPROVED
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission voted today to allow the Pacific Gas and Electric Company to load fuel at its Diablo Canyon nuclear plant in California, thereby partly restoring the license the commission suspended nearly two years ago after the discovery of a construction blunder.

title: Noisy Restaurants
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:In response to Marian Burros's article (''Restaurant Noise: Does It Spoil a Good Meal?'' Oct. 29) I can only say ''Bravo.''

title: MSR EXPLORATION LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
APPLIED MAGNETICS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $128,000 for the quarter and $370,000 for the year. c-After a loss of $198,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $395,000 on the sale of Key ElectroSonic Corp.

title: DON'T BLAME JAPAN FOR DETROIT'S TROUBLES
description: To the Editor:

title: Hagler Enjoying Long-Delayed Acclaim
description: Across the street from the Caesars Palace outdoor arena where Marvelous Marvin Hagler will defend his undisputed middleweight boxing title against Roberto Duran on Thursday night, the preliminary rounds in the battle of the nerves took place on the 18-hole golf course at the Dunes Hotel.

title: Daily Shekel Changes
description: Israel will devalue its currency on a day-to-day basis to compensate for the effects of inflation, the Israeli central bank governor, Moshe Mandelbaum, said today.

title: Wage Curb Vote Due in Brazil
description: Brazil's Congress votes today on a law to limit wage increases for salaried employees to 87 percent of the inflation rate - a key demand of the International Monetary Fund if it is to help Brazil refinance its huge foreign debt.

title: O'NEILL WRITES APOLOGY
description: House Speaker Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. has written a letter of apology to Nancy Reagan for what he admitted was a facetious remark about her in an interview with James Reston of The New York Times.

title: Basques Kidnap Executive
description: Basque separatist guerrillas posed as house painters to kidnap Jose Cruz Larranaga, 42 years old, the manager of an electrical equipment plant, at his home outside San Sebastian on Monday, the police said today.

title: E & B MARINE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
F.C.C. LETS BROADCASTERS HOLD POLITICAL DEBATES
description: The Federal Communications Commission ruled today that radio and television broadcasters were free to stage political debates between candidates of their own choosing without violating Federal law.

title: SCOUTING
description: A Year to Forget

title: CELLU-CRAFT INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $70,000 for the quarter and $212,000 for the 9 months.

title: STAGE: 'BABY,' NEW DURANG COMEDY
description: ''IJUST don't want to make the child insane, that's all,'' says the mother, Helen, to her husband, John, as they contemplate their newborn baby in its shiny wicker bassinet. Given that these parents inhabit Christopher Durang's new comedy at Playwrights Horizons, ''Baby With the Bathwater,'' need I tell you that they soon drive their child absolutely bonkers?

title: 4 Accused of Plot To Smuggle Drug
description: The four-man crew of a freighter seized off the New Jersey coast last week was indicted today on a charge of plotting to smuggle almost 15 tons of hashish, worth $100 million, into the United States.

title: A Worthy Errand in Asia
description: It should be obvious what takes President Reagan to Japan. Ponder these wise words by Mike Mansfield, the United States Ambassador there: ''The Japanese-American bond is the most important bilateral relationship in the world, bar none. The Japanese have no doubts about America's importance to them in many spheres - economics, diplomacy and security, to name a few - but I sometimes think that we Americans do not fully appreciate Japan's importance to the United States.''

title: KOCH VS. THE COURTS: NEW YORK CITY'S CROWDED JAILS AND THE INMATE RELEASE
description: ''As you can see,'' said Mayor Koch, striding through an empty cell block on Rikers Island as cell doors clanged shut, ''if you've got the gun, we've got the room.''

title: CONCERT: DAVIS TRIBUTE
description: GIVEN four hours of stage time at Radio City Music Hall and the resources of the Black Music Association, one could imagine a stunning tribute to Miles Davis's impact on music. It would trace his career from be-bop to electric jazz, with music by Mr. Davis's colleagues over the years plus informed, historical commentary.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Chicken Prices to Rise

title: Vatican Urges Negotiations To End Palestinian Fighting
description: The Vatican, a day after receiving an appeal from Yasir Arafat, called today for negotiations to end ''the struggle among the Palestinians'' now raging in Tripoli.

description: b-Net loss. Corrected from Tuesday's editions.

Conoco Sees Demand Rise
description: Conoco Inc. expects domestic demand for petroleum products to increase 2.5 percent next year, Ralph Bailey, the company's chairman, said today.

title: Semiconductor Race in Europe
description: Competition between Japanese and American companies for dominance of the semiconductor industry is likely to focus on Western Europe, Motorola Inc.'s European marketing director, Dedy Saban, said today.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Chase Manhattan Corp.'s $350 million issue of floating rate notes due in 1995, which was offered last week at 99.60 through Salomon Brothers Inc., was assigned an initial coupon rate of 10.06 percent. The rate is to be reset quarterly based on an average of four major banks' three-month Libor rates.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Jon Saxton of Greenwich, Conn., has been named the Metropolitan Golf Association's 1983 player of the year. Saxton, 22, won the Westchester Amateur, the Connecticut Amateur and the Ike Championship last summer. . . . Nancy Lopez , the golf professional, gave birth to an 8-pound-12- ounce baby girl in Albany, Ga., where her husband, Ray Knight, the Houston Astros' infielder, operates a sporting-goods store. . . . Keith Lee , the Memphis State basketball star, and Diane Jones , a guard on the school's women's team, were married in West Memphis, Ark., Monday night. . . . Ed Luther , the San Diego Chargers quarterback who has been filling in for the injured Dan Fouts , is skipping practice this week with a strained neck and may be replaced in Sunday's game against the Dallas Cowboys by a rookie, Bruce Mathison . . . . Todd Proffitt, a sophomore walk-on at Nebraska, will start at linebacker in Saturday's game against Kansas in place of Mark Daum , who has a knee injury. . . . Ivan Lendl , the defending champion, and Mats Wilander have clinched berths in the $400,000 Masters Tennis Championships at Madison Square Garden in January.

title: U.S. IS FACING NEW DANGERS IN THE MIDEAST
description: Military sources in Washington and in NATO capitals in Europe agree that there has been a rapid deterioration of the general military situation in the Middle East resulting from a number of seemingly unrelated events. The worst possibility, according to analysts studying the region, runs something like this:

title: 'SCARFACE' GETS R RATING ON APPEAL
description: The X rating given to ''Scarface'' last week by the rating board of the Motion Picture Association of America was overturned on appeal today.

title: FOR SHAMIR IN LEBANON, SOLDIERS' HARD QUERIES
description: -E-LUZ, Lebanon, Nov. 8 - Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir took a tour of Israeli positions in Lebanon today and encountered challenging questions from some of his soldiers about Israel's continuing role in the country.

title: CHECKER MOTORS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ARAFAT PLEDGES HE'LL TRY TO AVERT A 'BLOOD BATH' IN LEBANESE CITY
description: The Mayor of Tripoli and other local leaders, fearful that fighting between Palestinian factions will sweep into their city, met today with Yasir Arafat, who promised he would do ''everything in my power to avert a blood bath.''

title: STAGE: 'HARD TO BE A JEW'
description: ''IT'S HARD TO BE A JEW'' is not, as readers of English might presume, a theme for which Philip Roth holds the franchise. It is an ancient Yiddish saying and, as such, was taken for the title of a play, a wry comedy by Sholom Aleichem. It was first produced in 1920 on Second Avenue, in Yiddish, by the Yiddish Art Theater and starred Maurice Schwartz and a young Yiddish actor who later worked in the movies under the name of Paul Muni.

WEDNESDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Washington Bullets, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. This is New Jersey's first game this season against Washington, a club that could benefit from the addition of 4 teams to the playoffs, for a total of 16.

title: Article 028725 -- No Title
description: Alaska Airlines Inc. sold $25 million of 9 percent convertible subordinated debentures due in 2003 at a price of 100, through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: PILLS TO AID THE DIETER: HOW SAFE ARE THEY?
description: ''LOSE Weight Fast Without Going Hungry.'' This advertising claim for a popular diet pill promises to fulfill every dieter's dream: painless weight loss. All you have to do is take one time-release capsule a day to curb your appetite and you'll have no trouble sticking to that low-calorie diet.

title: MCDONALD'S WIDOW LOSES RUNOFF FOR GEORGIA CONGRESSIONAL SEAT
description: State Representative George Darden upset Kathryn McDonald today in a nonpartisan runoff election to fill the Congressional seat of her husand, Larry McDonald, the Democratic conservative who was killed in the shooting down of a Korean airliner.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: IBH Unit May Halt Production Friday

title: CARIBBEAN AIRLINE RESUMES REGULAR SERVICE TO GRENADA
description: Regular air service resumed today to a small commercial airport in Grenada, ending a three-week period in which the only access to the island was by boat or United States military aircraft.

title: Teamster Leader Undergoes Triple Bypass Heart Surgery
description: Jackie Presser, the president of the 1.3 milllion-member International Brotherhood of Teamsters, was reported in fair condition tonight after undergoing triple bypass heart surgery at the Cleveland Clinic Hospital.

title: Nothing Quite Like Death
description: ''Death is different,'' the Supreme Court said in 1976. So different that the death penalty had to be treated like no other. Special procedures were necessary to prevent execution by whim, prejudice or arbitrary decree.

description: Jefferies Broker Persists And Wins Cone's Sale

title: Freed Prisoner Accused of Rape
description: A Rikers Island prisoner freed last week under a program to ease jail overcrowding was ordered held on $100,000 bail yesterday after he was accused of raping a woman two days following his release.

title: Allianz May Raise Its Eagle Star Bid
description: Allianz Versicherungs A.G. said it may raise its $7.42 a share bid for Eagle Star Holdings P.L.C., but added that the decision is not expected to be made until a number of conditions have been met, including a promise from Britain's Office of Fair Trading that it would not refer the bid to the Monopolies Commission.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: MARCOVALDO or The Seasons in the City. By Italo Calvino. Translated from the Italian by William Weaver. A Helen & Kurt Wolff book. Harcourt, Brace, Jovanovich. 121 pages. $9.95 hard cover; $3.95 paperback. WHILE Umberto Eco has been on the best-seller list for 20 weeks with ''The Name of the Rose,'' Italo Calvino is the Italian writer who seems to cause the most excitement among American readers. With three books especially - ''Cosmicomics,'' ''Invisible Cities'' and ''If on a winter's night a traveler'' - Mr. Calvino has earned comparisons with Jorge Luis Borges and Gabriel Garcia Marquez. After decades of Italian neo- realism in the works of authors like Alberto Moravia, Elio Vittorini and Cesare Pavese, Mr. Calvino's fictions appear to be closer to the fantastic Italy of a Fellini film or a painting by Giorgio de Chirico.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Cosmos Sign Green
description: Alan Green , a striker who ranks 10th among outdoor scorers in North American Soccer League history, signed with the Cosmos yesterday and immediately joined their workouts in preparation for the indoor season. Green, a 29-year-old free agent, has scored 77 goals and added 33 assists in his six years in the league, and his indoor experience includes 15 goals and 9 assists for Jacksonville in 1981-82 and 7 goals and 4 assists in half a season with Golden Bay last winter.

title: PITTSBURGH & WEST VIRGINIA RR reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHITE TEXANS ACQUIT A BLACK
description: A jury today acquitted a black engineer of armed robbery, a charge that had brought accusations of racism and shoddy police work.

title: TURKISH ALLY OF CAPITALISM
description: Turkey's champion of free enterprise, whose party won the parliamentary elections on Sunday, irritated the ruling generals during the campaign with what they viewed as his brash promises. He said that as Prime Minister he could even sell shares in the bridge over the Bosporus to citizens to raise money for development projects.

title: FRANCE EXPRESSES MIDEAST CONCERN
description: France expressed concern today about the situation in the Middle East, singling out what Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson described as ''fleet movements and singularly aggressive statements.''

description: The correspondence began last August with an ''I was appalled. . .'' letter from Mayor Koch to Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger.

title: Careers; Jobs Rising In Rural Sections
description: IN the 1850's, Horace Greeley, the newspaper publisher, told a generation of young people to ''go west.'' Within the past 30 years, his advice might have been modified to ''go southwest.'' And now, according to one economist, people with management ambitions should forget North, South, East or West and go rural.

title: ROLL CALL IN SENATE ON NERVE GAS BILL
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate voted today, 47 to 46, to include money for the production of nerve gas weapons in a $252.5 billion military spending bill. When the Senators were tied, 46 to 46, Vice President Bush, as president of the Senate, cast the tie-breaking vote for the bill.

title: Signal Trading
description: The Signal Companies said it is not planning any acquisitions at present and added it knows of no reason for the heavy trading in its stock. Signal, which recently increased its credit line, has long been rumored to be in the market for acquisitions. The most recent market rumor, which Signal has denied, was that it is interested in the Western Union Corporation.

description: The Traveler, By Geographic The 96-year-old National

description: ''The delegation has now returned with the information that at the very minimum a potentially life-threatening situation existed on the island with regard to American citizens.

title: ACTOR WHO PLAYED AN ADDICT DIES, APPARENTLY OF OVERDOSE
description: James Hayden, an acclaimed young actor who was portraying a drug addict in the Broadway play ''American Buffalo,'' died yesterday, apparently of a heroin overdose, the police said.

title: No Comment(s)
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:Until the Wine Talk column of Oct. 19, I had understood Frank J. Prial to be a wine critic and had read his column regularly to increase my knowledge concerning wine.

title: EDMONTON PASSER IN SPECIAL DEMAND
description: If one happens to have a craving for chocolate chip cookies in Edmonton, Alberta, five varieties are available at the W. Moon Chocolate Chippery, including the top-of-the-line Warren Moon Special, which contains raisins, walnuts, rolled oats and semisweet chocolate.

description: Two political activists from Northern Ireland were convicted by a Federal jury tonight of trying to enter the United States illegally.

title: Dr. Paul F. Russell, 89; Specialist on Malaria
description: Dr. Paul F. Russell, a specialist in malaria and tropical diseases who served on Gen. Douglas MacArthur's senior staff in World War II, died last Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital in Richmond. He was 89 years old.

title: BOOM IN COMPUTER MAGAZINES
description: When the International Business Machines Corporation finally lifted the lid on one of the computer industry's worst- kept secrets and introduced its PCjr home computer last week, at least three publishers were ready with magazines aimed at users of the new machine.

title: A PARTY RAISES MONEY FOR MISS LIBERTY
description: MEN in tweeds and women in raincoats rubbed shoulders with men in black tie and women in black velvet Monday night at the New York State Theater. Those who paid $10 and those who paid $1,000 all got a chance to see ''The Stars Shine for Liberty,'' the inaugural fund-raising event for restoration of the Statue of Liberty and Ellis Island.

title: AMERICAN KEEPS 727'S, RECALLS PILOTS
description: American Airlines, preparing to expand after reaching a cost-cutting wage pact with pilots, yesterday deferred plans to retire any more Boeing 727's and called back 50 furloughed pilots.

title: WESTBURNE INTERNATIONAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FASHION'S FAST TRACK: SPORTSWEAR
description: SPORTSWEAR, it is becoming increasingly clear, is emerging as the hero of the spring fashion collections in New York. It should come as a surprise to nobody who has followed this city's fashion fortunes in the last decade or so. Of course there have been setbacks some seasons, when sportswear designers have seemed as confused as anyone else about what path they should pursue. But they're off on a fast track and Calvin Klein is in the lead.

title: SUMMER & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $2,870 from discontinued operations. c-After a loss of $77,919 from discontinued operations.

title: MISSISSIPPI DEMOCRAT SURMOUNTS SEX CHARGE
description: Bill Allain, a Democrat, overcame last- minute charges of soliciting sex from black men and easily swept to victory today in his bid for Governor of this conservative Southern state.

title: HOUSE 206-203, DEFEATS EMERGENCY FUNDS BILL
description: In a surprise move, the House of Representatives tonight defeated legislation that would provide stop-gap financing for various sectors of the Government after their authority to spend money runs out Thursday night.

title: CAPITOL SECURITY A LONGTIME PROBLEM
description: For much of this century, Congress has fretted over allowing free access to the Capitol while at the same time providing adequate security.

title: Pratt Student, 21, Found Slain in Tub
description: A 21-year-old student at Pratt Institute was found slain last night, bound hand and foot and submerged in the bathtub of her Broooklyn apartment, according to the police, who said that the apartment had apparently been robbed.

description: President-elect Raul Alfonsin named an eight-member Cabinet Tuesday night that includes the installation of personal confidants in key ministries.

description: The House of Representatives voted today to deny funds for the continued operation of the United States Commission on Civil Rights. The move was designed to protest President Reagan's action dismissing three members of the agency.

CUOMO ASSURES VOTERS ON PLANS FOR BOND FUNDS
description: Governor Cuomo promised New Yorkers yesterday that they would get what they voted for in the $1.25 billion bond issue to finance roads and bridges throughout the state for the next five years.

title: N.B.A. Releases Referee Salaries
description: The salary range of the regular National Basketball Association referees ranged from a high of $78,259 to a low of $18,146 last season, according to figures released by the league yesterday.

description: An air force colonel said today that he knew the man who the Government says assassinated the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr.

description: Leading judges in New York State have proposed a number of increases in court fees designed to obtain money so that judges' salaries can be raised, Governor Cuomo said today.

description: Charges against Paul Godbey, one of several current and former Nevada- Las Vegas football players arrested last week and accused of possession of illegal drugs with intent to sell, have been dropped by the police for lack of evidence.

title: ALAMCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PERSIAN GULF LEADERS FAIL TO STOP PALESTINIAN STRIFE
description: The six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council ended a conference here today without obtaining the cease-fire agreement it had sought between warring Palestinian factions in northern Lebanon.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: SOUTH STREET The South Street Seaport's newest adornment goes on view today, a flashing, thumping, rapid-fire new multiscreen presentation called ''South Street Venture.'' This less- than-an-hour-long epic traces the history of South Street and the world it served and it tells its story in the completely renovated confines of a landmark building at 210 Front Street, corner of Beekman, on the Seaport's newly redeveloped museum block.

title: ACCORD REPORTED IN LEBANON TALKS
description: Lebanese factions meeting here reported tonight that they had reached agreement on key principles of constitutional and political changes, officials close to the talks said.

title: Advertising; Beatrice Settles On 7 Shops
description: HAVING completed the enormous task of consolidating advertising assignments at more than a hundred agencies into seven, the Beatrice Foods Company yesterday called a news conference in its Chicago hometown to explain its rationale, describe its selection methods and announce the winners.

title: EARLY DELOREAN TAPE PLAYED
description: John Z. DeLorean said in a videotape played in court today that he knew drug money was involved in a deal to rescue his failing automobile company but cared only about saving the concern, his children and his life.

title: Grenada, by O'Neill, by Orwell
description: With the surrender of Speaker O'Neill, President Reagan's triumph in Grenada seems complete. The evacuated students kissed American soil and cheered at the White House. Grenadians express relief, even delight. Most Americans not only approve but feel positively invigorated; they are furious at a press that wanted to witness the action or question its premises. Although 1984 is at hand, hardly anyone dares confront the Orwellian arguments by which this grave action has been justified.

title: $40,030 in Silver Stolen From Vault
description: Hundreds of pieces of sterling silver flatware, trays, bowls and other items valued at $40,030 were stolen from a State Capitol vault where they were being held for public auction, officials said today.

title: POWER MEMORIAL SCHOOL TO CLOSE
description: Power Memorial Academy, a small Catholic high school on the West Side that gained national recognition in the early 1960's through the basketball exploits of a quiet, lanky student named Lewis Alcindor, now known as Kareem Abdul-Jabbar, will close in June, school officials have announced.

title: Canada Trade Surplus
description: Canada's trade surplus fell to $1.12 billion in September, from $1.4 billion in August, Statistics Canada said today.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: ALAN TURING: The Enigma. By Andrew Hodges. 587 pages. Illustrated. Simon & Schuster. $22.50.
