title: JERSEY FINDS CHARTER SOUND
description: The New Jersey Insurance Department, which supervises the sale of Charter Company annuities in every state except New York, said yesterday that Charter's New Jersey operation was ''financially sound and able to meet all its contractual obligations.''

title: WOMEN'S WORTH
description: To the Editor:

title: KEAN AND ASSEMBLY SPEAKER TO TRY BIPARTISAN APPROACH
description: Governor Kean and the Democratic Speaker of the State Assembly, Alan J. Karcher, pledged today to try to cooperate during the next legislative session after the Democrats retained control of both houses Tuesday.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: The Arabian American Oil Company has named its first Saudi president. He is Ali Ibrahim Naimi, who started work for Aramco when he was 11 years old - claiming to be 16 so he could take an office-boy job.

title: TO PROTECT MINI-STATES AGAINST 'HIJACKERS'
description: To the Editor:

title: DURAN'S HOPES BOLSTERED BY HIS WILL TO WIN
description: The caps and T-shirts tell half the story: ''Duran Is Duran.''

title: A CHILL IN COURT
description: Watching an argument in the Supreme Court has always seemed to me a way to strengthen one's faith in the American system. The openness of the process, the direct access to those who make the decisions, the attention to principle - it all makes that courtroom an oasis in bureaucratic Washington.

title: Judge Says Trump 'Harassed' Tenant
description: A judge said yesterday that Donald Trump, the New York real-estate developer, had tried to ''harass'' a tenant into moving out of a Central Park South building Mr. Trump owns.

title: SCREEN: 'STAR 80,' A SEX-SYMBOL'S LIFE AND DEATH
description: ON Aug. 14, 1980, Dorothy Stratten, a pretty, fresh- faced model from Vancouver, British Columbia, was shot to death by her estranged husband, Paul Snider, a small-time promoter, in the house they once shared in Los Angeles. After murdering Miss Stratten, Mr. Snider turned the shotgun on himself. Miss Stratten had acquired a certain amount of fame as Playboy magazine's ''1980 Playmate of the Year,'' and had just finished production on her first major film, Peter Bogdanovich's ''They All Laughed.''

title: Striking Teachers Fined in Bergen
description: A Bergen County judge today fined striking Ridgefield Park teachers $50 a day and threatened to raise the penalty starting Monday if they did not return to work.

title: TechnologyAndrew Pollack Electronic Trespassers
description: NEWS reports about whiz kids trampling through corporate computers has focused attention on steps that can be taken to prevent such breaches of computer security in the future. Actually, the equipment and techniques needed to foil all but the most sophisticated ''hackers'' already exist. They just haven't been used.

title: AETNA'S TROUBLED MOVE: MANY WON'T GO
description: In theory, it seemed simple enough: The Aetna insurance company wanted to consolidate some of its offices in Hartford and move them to a new site here.

title: OXFORD FIRST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $331,000 for the quarter and $150,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $160,000 for the quarter and $222,000 for 9 months. All share earnings have been adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend distributed to shareholders of record as of June 30, 1983.

title: AIR FLORIDA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago 9 months results include $4.7 million from the sublease of aircraft to another carrier and $5 million of excess insurance proceeds from the loss of an aircraft.

title: 2IrishNationalists Put on Probation
description: Two Irish nationalists were sentenced today to one year of probation on their conviction for lying to Federal officers in an attempt to enter the country illegally.

title: Kuhn Puts Off Action on Howe
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn said yesterday he was delaying until Dec. 15 his announcement on what action he would take in the case of Steve Howe, the Los Angeles pitcher, whose season was curtailed by an acknowledged drug problem.

title: CINCINNATI MILACRON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. Results for the year-ago third quarter include a nonrecurring net charge of $10 million from the consolidation of the company's British machine tool operations.

title: WESTERN WASTE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MUSIC: KLAUS TENNSTEDT LEADS BRUCKNER WORK
description: ANTON BRUCKNER'S expansive symphonies could be called filibusters set to music were it not that, unlike the senatorial ramblings that are one of the 19th century's gifts to our representative system, the Austrian composer's works are marvels of formal excellence and logic.

title: 4 Jailed 30 Days In Trident Protest
description: Four protesters arrested at the Oct. 15 launching of the Trident submarine Henry M. Jackson received 30-day jail terms today in Superior Court.

title: Former Tribal Chief Captured in Canada
description: A former Indian leader who became a fugitive last year after being convicted of racketeering and embezzlement was captured this afternoon in Canada, Federal officials here said.

title: 2 NUCLEAR UNITS TO BE DELAYED
description: The Consumers Power Company, which has been building a two-unit nuclear power plant in Midland, Mich., said yesterday that the completion of one unit may be delayed for more than a year and the construction schedule for a second would be revised.

title: SQUIRE INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
WHITE HOUSE ATTACKS PHONE FEE BILL
description: The House of Representatives began debate tonight on a bill that would prohibit the Federal Communications Commission from requiring all households and small businesses to pay a new monthly access fee for connection to the nation's long-distance telephone networks.

title: INSITUFORM OF NORTH AMERCA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Senate Panel Supports Clark to Succeed Watt
description: The Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee today approved the nomination of William P. Clark as Secretary of the Interior, clearing the way for a vote by the full Senate.

title: RAIL CARRIER SETTLES LAWSUIT ON DISCRIMINATION
description: Burlington Northern Inc., a major rail carrier, has agreed to provide $10 million in back pay to the victims of past discrimination by the carrier, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission said today.

title: ; AN 'IRRITATING' U.S. FREEDOM ABRIDGED
description: To the Editor:

title: VOTE TOTALS FOR THE ELECTIONS IN THE NEW YORK AREA AND JERSEY
description: NEW YORK

title: RATE DROP SPURS RISE IN STOCKS
description: After almost daily declines over the past month, stock prices rose sharply yesterday, reacting in part to a drop in interest rates.

title: No Survivors Reported In Angolan Air Crash
description: The official Angolan press agency said today that all 126 people, most of them civilian passengers, died aboard an Angolan Boeing 737 that crashed Tuesday on takeoff at Lubango Airport. Reports on Tuesday said as many as 150 people died.

title: FIRST EXECUTIVE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including realized gains of $28,331,000 for the quarter and $94,405,000 for the 9 months. c-Including realized gains of $7,880,000 for the quarter and $10,206,000 for the 9 months.

title: JET USES TAXIWAY TO LAND IN DENVER
description: A Continental Airlines DC-9 jet, with Frank Lorenzo, the line's chairman, among the passengers, landed by mistake on a taxiway between two runways at Denver's Stapleton Airport yesterday.

title: A Top Sears Executive Plans to Retire March 1
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company announced yesterday that its president, Archie R. Boe, would retire Mar. 1.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Hoist & Derrick Co., St. Paul, has elected Robert H. Hassau chief executive officer, succeeding Robert P. Fox, who will continue as chairman.

title: ADOBE OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $17,807,000 from the sale of North Sea interest.

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
LIGHTING PICTURES
description: AN unobtrusive brass picture light attached to a frame used to be essential for those who owned paintings. Today spotlights in the ceiling directed at walls are more common. Where a ceiling renovation is not possible or has not yet been completed, or if you like the old-time look, a picture light may still be necessary.

title: VICTOR IN MISSISSIPPI OPTIMISTIC ABOUT IMPACT OF SEX CHARGE
description: After burying his opponent in a landslide, Governor-elect Bill Allain said today that he believed the charges of paying for sex with black men leveled at him in the campaign would have no lasting impact.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: No More Grumbling As Coast Awaits Ballet

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Koch Looks at Reality

title: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1983 International
description: Backers of Yasir Arafat repelled a three-pronged attack by Syrian- backed Palestinians on the loyalists' last stronghold in Lebanon. Lebanese leaders and Arab diplomats pressed efforts to arrange a cease-fire, apparently to get Mr. Arafat and his backers away from the densely-populated city of Tripoli, but there was no sign that any agreement had been reached. (Page A1, Column 6.) Washington urged Mideast nations to halt the fighting between rival Palestininan factions around Tripoli. The State Department said the United States was contributing $1 million to the International Committee of the Red Cross for relief work in the port city. (A1:5.)

title: HINDERLITER INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: SANMARK-STARDUST INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $368,400.

title: U.S. OFFICIALS LINK CASTRO AND DRUGS
description: The head of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration said today that President Fidel Castro and other officials of the Cuban Government were involved in distributing narcotics to the United States to raise money for subversive activities in Latin America.

title: 2 Missing in F-14 Crash
description: An F-14A jet fighter carrying two Navy fliers attached to the aircraft carrier John F. Kennedy crashed into the Mediterranean Sea on Tuesday, Navy officials said. A spokesman said the pilot, Lieut. (j.g.) Cole P. O'Neil, 26 years old, of Lake Villa, Ill., and the radar intercept officer, Comdr. John C. Scull, 37, of Newport News, were missing and presumed dead.

title: Bank of Boston
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation, in a move that continues its program of New England investments, said it had reached an agreement in principle to make a $12 million capital investment in the Chittenden Corporation, a bank holding company based in Burlington, Vt. Chittenden, with assets of $682 million, is the parent of the Chittenden Trust Company, Vermont's largest bank. The Bank of Boston, the nation's 18th-largest bank company, with $18.7 billion in assets, has been aggressively expanding in the New England banking market with acquisitions and investments since reciprocal laws allowing such activities were enacted last year.

title: OFFICIAL TIES DEFEAT TO BRIDGE COLLAPSE
description: The collapse of the Mianus River bridge on the Connecticut Turnpike here last June 28 helped defeat Greenwich's Republican First Selectman, Rebecca S. Breed, in Tuesday's election, the town's Republican chairman said today.

title: CONCERT: WEISSENBERG
description: ALEXIS WEISSENBERG is such an accomplished piano virtuoso, that disagreeing with his musical image of Robert Schumann, which he presented in an all-Schumann recital at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night, involves more than just pointing out where the instrumentalist went wrong. Mr. Weissenberg did indeed go wrong at certain times - he barrelled through the opening movements of the Fantasy in C and the Fifth of the Symphonic Etudes was muddled; he quashed the nuances of some of the ''Kinderszenen'' and he left the music with no room to breathe even when Schumann deliberately indicated subtle gestures in the score.

title: ACMAT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CATHOLIC-LUTHERAN TALKS: CAUTIOUS OPTIMISM ON WARMER TIES
description: NewsAnalysis

title: Sun Banks Merger
description: The Federal Reserve Board said it had approved the application of Sun Banks Inc. in Orlando, Fla., to merge with Flagship Banks Inc. of Miami. Although the merger will result in Sun becoming the largest banking organization in Florida, the Fed said the deal, valued at about $335 million, ''would not have any significantly adverse effects on the concentration of commercial banking'' in the state. Sun has 17 subsidiary banks that control aggregate deposits of $4 billion; Flagship has 28 subsidiaries that control $2.4 billion.

title: Moscow Says Reagan Seeks Closer Arms Ties With Japan
description: The Soviet Government press agency, Tass, said today that President Reagan would seek to strengthen military ties with Japan during his visit.

title: Olympics Aides Pledge To Send Out Refunds
description: Acknowledgements and refunds on the 2.1 million tickets sold so far to the 1984 Olympic Games will be mailed this week, informing the 279,000 customers who sent in applications by Aug. 15 of their status in the scramble for next summer's seats.

title: MEMBERS OF HOUSE DIFFER ON INVASION
description: Two Congressmen, dissenting from the majority of a congressional fact-finding delegation to Grenada, today challenged statements that United States citizens on the island were in clear danger and declared that the invasion of the island was not justified on those grounds.

title: CASCADE NATURAL GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
GULF APPLIED TECHNOLOGIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PROBLEMS OF THE YEN'S VALUE
description: The interrelated problems of trade and the value of the yen relative to the dollar are expected to be two of the dominant topics during President Reagan's discussions this week in Japan with Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone.

title: Stake in GAF May Rise
description: The Amalgamated Sugar Company said yesterday that it may increase its stake in the GAF Corporation to 25 percent of the voting stock. Amalgamated's chairman, Harold C. Simmons of Dallas, reported a week ago that companies he controlled had acquired 1.07 million shares, or 7.5 percent, of GAF as an investment. GAF, a building materials and chemical company, has been trying to sell its two principal remaining businesses.

title: COMMODITIES A.T.&T.'s New Weight In Stock Index Futures
description: Prices of stock index futures rose sharply yesterday, reflecting the strong advance of the underlying market. While prices of the index futures always move with their underlying averages, the size of the index gains or losses usually depends on the performance of key stocks.

title: SUFFOLK CONTEST SHOWS NO CONSENSUS ON SHOREHAM
description: If the race for Suffolk County Executive was the referendum that had been expected on the Shoreham nuclear power plant, the closeness of the result indicates no clear consensus has emerged among voters, politicians from both parties said yesterday.

title: OFFICE BOOM IN LOS ANGELES
description: The International Business Machines Corporation is moving 1,500 employees into 25 floors of this city's newest high-rise office building, the 45-story south tower of Crocker Center.

title: CENTEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Jessica Savitch Memorial

title: HOME BEAT
description: WHEN the Musee des Arts Decoratifs in Paris started reproducing some of the 18th- and 19th- century pieces in its collections, it also decided to revive some of France's traditional craft objects. Many of the wares are now in a boutique on the seventh floor at Bergdorf Goodman, at the top of the store's new escalators.

title: DRUG PROCESS DISCOVERER GETS $100,000 PRIZE
description: Dr. Robert J. Lefkowitz of Duke University, an expert on cellular receptors and their influence on drug and hormone action, was named yesterday as the 1983 winner of the $100,000 Lita Annenberg Hazen Award for excellence in clinical research.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Accounts

title: DEFICITS: A NOOSE
description: For the first time since 1787, delegates of all the states may join in a convention to amend the United States Constitution. The impetus for this constitutional earthquake, whose size and scope judicial scholars are debating, is the failure of the President and the Congress to take meaningful steps to reduce the Federal deficit. Only the votes of two more legislatures may be necessary to set off this seismic shock.

title: Bears Cut James Scott
description: In a little more than 6 seasons as a wide receiver with the Chicago Bears, James Scott caught 177 passes for 3,202 yards and 20 touchdowns, making him one of the top-10 receivers in the club's history. But after rejoining the Bears last year, following a season in the Canadian Football League, where he caught 81 passes for the Montreal Alouettes, Scott had trouble catching on with Coach Mike Ditka .

title: Postal Officials Assailed For Private Jet Travel
description: The Postal Service, which wants to raise the cost of mailing letters and packages next year, is paying nearly $48,000 a month to lease and operate a seven- passenger private jet to fly its executives around the country.

title: A LIGHT AND AIRY TOUCH FROM BEENE FOR SPRINGTIME
description: ''WEIGHTLESS'' is the word Geoffrey Beene uses most frequently to describe his apparently airborne clothes. For his spring collection, introduced Tuesday afternoon at the Manhattan Flower Works, this most contemporary designer made clothes that seemed to defy gravity. In fact, they looked as if they required the occasional bands of quilting - lightweight, of course - or silvery binding just to keep them earthbound.

title: Moody's Raises Its Ford Ratings
description: Moody's Investors Service increased the long-term bond ratings of the Ford Motor Company and some subsidiaries - the Ford Motor Credit Company, Ford Overseas Finance and Ford Credit Overseas Finance - to A-3, from Baa-2. Ratings for subordinated debt of Ford Motor Credit was also raised to Baa-1, from Baa-3, while its commercial paper rating was unchanged, at Prime 2.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Tuesday about the bankruptcy filing of the Terex Corporation misstated the amounts of loans that the General Motors Corporation agreed to forgive IBH Holding A.G. They were 100 million West German marks in 1982 and 120 million marks in 1983.

title: Peril Seen in Teen-Age Fad Of Sniffing Correction Fluid
description: A meeting of physicians has been alerted to a new peril facing American teen-agers, sniffing typewriter correction fluid, a lethal form of substance abuse that doctors say is gaining nationwide popularity.

description: IT has taken a long time, but New

title: Flight Attendants at Eastern Decide to Approve New Pact
description: Flight attendants at Eastern Airlines have approved a new contract with a 93 percent favorable vote, their union said today.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Late yesterday, the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company said it also would be consolidating all of its major domestic advertising - at J. Walter Thompson, whose Broulliard Communications is already doing its corporate advertising. Trade sources think the billings involved so far could be as much as $50 million, and the Goodyear announcement said this was only a first step in a worldwide consolidiation.

title: JAMES BOOKER, 'PIANO PRINCE'
description: James Booker, the self-described ''Piano Prince of New Orleans,'' died Tuesday of a heart attack in his New Orleans apartment. He was 43.

title: AnnenbergProjectGets College-Program Chief
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting and the Annenberg School of Communications have appointed Mara Mayor as director of their joint project to produce college-level educational programs for presentation by television, radio and publications.

title: NICARAGUAN FEARS FOREIGNERS WILL AID REBELS
description: A Nicaraguan official says that foreign troops might be sent to assist antigovernment rebels, who he said are failing in their campaign to seize a portion of Nicaraguan territory.

title: A Pre-Selection Election
description: Is there a general point to be mined from the miscellaneous results of Tuesday's off-year election - other than that voter turnout was generally low? Yes, and it can be stated in a word: responsible. That's how voters behaved, in race after race, in New York and elsewhere. The reason, perversely, may have been the low turnout.

JENSEN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Supporters of Yasir Arafat today beat back attacks by Syrian- backed Palestinians on three sides of his last stronghold outside this northern city.

title: NICARAGUA REBEL, IN U.S., WARNS AGAINST INVASION
description: A top Nicaraguan rebel leader appealed to Americans yesterday to aid his forces while warning the Reagan Administration against direct military intervention in Nicaragua.

title: ROOF AND TERRACE AUTUMN CLEANUP
description: EXPERIENCED city gardeners view autumn's lengthening shadows and crisp mornings as mixed blessings. Fewer hours of sunlight and grayer skies give plants a winter respite - but a myriad of end- of-season chores remain.

title: IBH COLLAPSE WORRIES WEST GERMANY'S BANKS
description: West German banks, fearing legislative curbs on their wide-reaching activities after a $235 million bank bailout last week, today warned against overreactions to irregularities at one of the nation's most prestigious private banks.

THURSDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Indiana Pacers , at Indianapolis. Having opened the season with two victories, the Knicks have now lost four straight games, squandering leads in three of the four.

title: BIW CABLE SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FURNITURE MAKING FROM TUBE TO CHAIR
description: THE bicycle that Marcel Breuer bought when he was teaching at the Bauhaus in the 1920's proved to be not only transportation for the architect but also the inspiration for the tubular steel furniture he designed from 1925 to 1928. A friend remarked to Breuer that in bicycle factories, ''they bend those steel tubes like macaroni.'' The comment became the idea behind the chairs.

title: Westinghouse
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said it has signed an agreement to sell small hydroelectric turbine-generators manufactured in China. J. J. Sherman, vice president of the industry services division, said a memorandum of intent was signed with the China National Machinery and Equipment Export Corporation. Westinghouse does not manufacture hydro turbines, but will focus on contracts for installed equipment, and be responsible on a project management basis for installation, construction, the balance of plant equipment, plant startup and maintenance.

title: CURB ON COAST RESORT LOSES
description: A ballot issue designed to thwart a hillside resort in this exclusive community southeast of Palm Springs was defeated Tuesday by a 10 percent margin.

description: FOR those interested in new

title: MOODY'S LIFTS CITY BONDS TO AN INVESTMENT GRADE
description: For the first time since the height of the fiscal crisis in 1975, New York City's long-term bonds have been raised from speculative to investment grade by Moody's Investors Service.

title: SPACE TELESCOPE ADDING MYSTERIES
description: Scanning the heavens through a newly opened ''clean window,'' the Infrared Astronomy Satellite has provided a revolutionary new view of the universe, revealing swirling ''cirrus'' clouds of dust, galaxies of a previously unsuspected nature and a giant dust ring beyond the orbit of Mars that is possibly produced by recurring asteroid collisions.

title: MIDLAND DOHERTY FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: REAGAN PLAN ON LABELING HAZARDS IS DRAWING FIRE
description: The Reagan Administration's effort to give the Federal Government authority over labeling the contents of hazardous substances in the workplace is running into opposition from environmentalists, union representatives and state legislators, who say the move would weaken public protection.

title: Water for City Is Cut By Drought Warning
description: Drought warning conditions were declared in the Delaware River Basin today when storage in New York City's three large reservoirs remained below 40.6 percent capacity for the fifth consecutive day.

title: GENESCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Including a tax credit of $639,000. c-Net loss.

title: PRESIDENTIAL TIMBER: DID IT SHOW EARLY?
description: They were boys then, not too different from lads down the block or around the corner.

description: NewsAnalysis

title: Fined for Weight
description: The Washington, D.C., Boxing and Wrestling Commission disclosed that it had fined Eddie Mustafa Muhammad $1,000 and banned him from fighting in Washington for a year because of his refusal to lose excess weight before a scheduled bout against Michael Spinks last July. The commission, which noted that Muhammad, a light heavyweight, had also been denied licenses in New Jersey and Nevada, said it had taken the action Oct. 17 but delayed making it public until he had had a chance to receive written notification.

title: MRS. HECKLER, AS SEEN BY BOTH SIDES
description: When Margaret M. Heckler took over as Secretary of Health and Human Services last March, many people, including some at the White House, said they assumed she would be a figurehead and that the real authority would lie with John A. Svahn, the Social Security Commissioner who was promoted to Under Secretary by President Reagan.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Baxter Travenol Laboratories Inc. announced that it had completed a 125 million Swiss franc-U.S. dollar bond offering by its overseas finance unit, through the Swiss Bank Corp. The bonds, which mature in 1993, have an aggregate principal amount of $75 million, payable in dollars. Interest, at a rate of 7 percent, is payable in francs.

title: ELECTION OF 2 BLACK MAYORS IS EVALUATED BY COLLEAGUES
description: Members of the National Conference of Black Mayors meeting here today hailed the elections of black Mayors in Charlotte, N.C., and Philadelphia as examples of the capacity of black candidates to attract white support.

title: RANGERS END FLAMES' UNBEATEN STREAK
description: The defenseman Reijo R"uotsalainen scored a power-play goal that proved to be the winner and assisted on another goal last night as the Rangers beat the Calgary Flames, 4-3, at Madison Square Garden.

title: Devil's Bag Injures Heel
description: Devil's Bag, the undefeated 2-year- old colt who was scheduled to close out the year in the Remsen Stakes at Aqueduct Saturday, bruised his heel yesterday and may be forced to miss the race.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Military intervention in Nicaragua would be the biggest mistake that Reagan could make.

title: QUEBECOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $118,000 and a special tax credit of $194,000. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $968,000. d-After a loss of $2,559,000 from discontinued operations and a special gain of $245,000. The year-ago results were restated to reflect discontinued operations of Etco Photo.

title: BRITONS SUE U.S. TO BAR ARMS
description: Twelve British women filed a Federal suit in New York yesterday to stop the deployment of nuclear cruise missiles in England next month.

title: NEC Tax Case
description: Subsidiaries of the NEC Corporation, the Japanese computer and electronics company, have been asked by California authorities to submit financial documents for a tax assessment under the so-called unitary method, a company official said. The assessment could amount to as much as $100,000, the official said. Under the unitary tax method, California and 13 other states determine taxes on the basis of a company's worldwide profit.

title: ELECTION OF BLACK MAYOR IN PHILADELPHIA REFLECTS A DECADE OF CHANGE IN CITY
description: Little evidence of change was visible this morning, the day after Philadelphians broke a centuries-old barrier and gave a resounding victory to W. Wilson Goode to make him their first black Mayor.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last Friday on the General Assembly's approval of a resolution deploring the invasion of Grenada incorrectly described the vote by the Philippines. It abstained.

title: ELRON ELECTRONICS INDUSTRIES LTD (ISRAEL)(O) reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TUCKER DRILLING CO., INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Money Market Funds' Ads
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission gave its final approval today to a plan that lets the more than 300 money market funds advertise their performance in terms of compound yields.

title: ACADEMY INSURANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in September.

title: WHY CONE MILLS IS A TAKEOVER TARGET
description: Despite competition from imports, labor problems and the latest economic downturn, textile companies continue to be popular takeover targets. The Cone Mills Corporation, a century-old denim and corduroy maker, has recently become the latest target in a trend that is bringing much of the nation's textile manufacturing under the ownership of a wide variety of nontextile corporations.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 10, 1983
description: Markets Stock prices rose sharply in what analysts called a technical advance. The Dow Jones industrial average soared 17.58 points, to 1,233.52, its biggest daily gain since Oct. 6, when it was up 18.60 points. Turnover climbed to 83.1 million shares from 64.9 million shares during Tuesday's slow Election Day trading. (Page D1.) Interest rates were stable to slightly lower for Treasury notes and bonds. (D10.) The dollar fell in foreign currency trading, while gold prices rose 50 cents an ounce, to $381.50, in New York. (D16.) Prices of stock index futures were sharply higher. (D16.)

title: HOME HEALTH UNIT THRIVES UPSTATE
description: Jean Sweeney Dunn and Edith R. Reidy are registered nurses who make house calls. Their two-woman nonprofit health agency has helped hundreds of elderly people in the Elmira area stay out of hospitals and nursing homes.

title: Greek Leftist Balks At Visiting Berlin Wall
description: Ioannis Alevras, President of the Greek Parliament, refused to visit the Berlin wall during his current official visit to West Germany.

title: Article 032628 -- No Title
description: A 1939 photograph of a steam locomotive was sold at auction Wednesday for $67,000 - the highest price ever paid for a photograph.

title: SCOUTING
description: Medical Reports Help the Clippers

title: INTEGRATED RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
A NEW INGREDIENT SPICES 'GOULASH COMMUNISM'
description: A big covered produce market next to Karl Marx University here bulges with stalls piled high with vegetables and draped in ropes of garlic and bright red peppers, all grown on private garden plots.

title: Cardinal Gets Award And Makes Peace Plea
description: Appealing for ''cold realism,'' Joseph Cardinal Bernardin of Chicago said today that differences between the United States and the Soviet Union should not be allowed to interfere with efforts to control nuclear weapons.

title: HOUSE AGAIN GETS SPENDING MEASURE
description: After a startling defeat Tuesday night, House Democrats scrambled today to salvage a stop-gap appropriation bill that would keep sizable segments of the Government running after their spending authority runs out Thursday night. Party leaders said they would bring the legislation back to the floor on Thursday, and they predicted its passage.

title: ALFRED HEINEKEN, DUTCH BREWER, KIDNAPPED ON AMSTERDAM STREET
description: Three people kidnapped the chairman of the giant Heineken brewery as he walked to his limousine tonight, the police reported.

title: Arms Negotiators Meet
description: United States and Soviet negotiators met today in the talks on limiting medium- range nuclear missiles in Europe. It was the 102d session since the talks began Nov. 31, 1981. The next meeting was set for Tuesday.

title: ERB LUMBER CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CLASSIC CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Patience Pays

title: ACCORD ON OLYMPIC DRUG TESTS REACHED
description: The International Olympic Committee and the Los Angeles Olympic Organizing Committee apparently have settled differences on testing for high levels of testosterone and caffeine in athletes at next summer's Olympic Games.

title: Kodak Net Slumps; Rockwell Up 33.4%
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, citing a $60 million pre-tax inventory write-off, reported yesterday that earnings in the third quarter plunged 44.4 percent.

title: SOME STEP UP TO OFFER HELP FOR ABANDONED AIDS BABY
description: Nearly 30 people have responded to a public plea and offered to take in a homeless 14- month-old girl suffering acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, health officials said today. She has no more than three years to live.

title: CALENDAR: AFRICAN COLLECTABLES
description: Africafest, African Tribal Arts Gallery, 84 East 10th Street, 212-982-4556.

title: COMPROMISE I.M.F. BILL IS SEEN GAINING GROUND
description: Fernand J. St Germain, chairman of the House Banking Committee, today signaled that the logjam was breaking up around a bill that would increase the American contribution to the International Monetary Fund.

description: b-Including tax credits of $4,970 for the quarter and $9,939 for the 6 months. c-Including tax credits of $1,675 for the quarter and $1,950 for the 6 months.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: New York City Bonds Receive a Higher Rating

title: Bridge:Jacoby Matches Blackwood In the Literary Marketplace
description: A recent book by one 80-year-old expert, Easley Blackwood, has now been matched by another, Oswald Jacoby. However, the effort involved was perhaps less great, for Jacoby is co-author with his equally famous son, Jim, in a collection of their excellent syndicated columns.

title: Pope Prays for Lebanon
description: Pope John Paul II today dedicated the Lord's Prayer to peace in ''tormented'' Lebanon, the second such appeal by the Vatican in as many days.

title: Dade County, Fla.
description: A $90 million issue of Dade County, Fla., special obligation and refunding bonds was tentatively priced with yields ranging from 6 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9 1/2 percent in 1996 and 9 7/8 percent in 2003 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The bonds are rated A by Moody's and AAA by S.& P.'s because of an insurance policy covering interest and principal by the Muncipal Bond Insurance Association. The bonds are backed by utilities service

title: Devils Lose, 2-1
description: Dale McCourt scored a short-handed goal in the first period and set up Jim Benning for Toronto's other goal in the third period to lead the Maple Leafs to a 2-1 victory tonight over the New Jersey Devils.

title: Piniella's Cousin
description: Dave Magadan , who signed with the Mets last June, was named the country's outstanding amateur baseball player and received the Golden Spikes Award from the United States Baseball Federation at a Manhattan restaurant yesterday.

title: Suspect in 165 Killings Convicted in 2d Murder
description: A jury found Henry Lee Lucas guilty today of murdering his 15-year-old common-law wife in the second conviction arising from his assertion that he had killed about 165 people around the country.

title: THE THEATER: 'LEFTOVERS'
description: AMERICA'S insatiable appetite for dieting is certainly a suitable subject for satiric treatment, but the new revue ''Leftovers'' merely lives down to its name. In terms of taste and humor, it is a doggy bag of table scraps.

title: SAME STORYLINE AS ZAIRE
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

title: TEXAS OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
Quake Jolts Northern Italy
description: Earth tremors jolted wide areas of northern Italy for several seconds today, causing buildings to sway, the police reported. The tremors were felt in Milan, Venice, Turin and Bologna.

title: A MANAGER FOR MAYOR: W. WILSON GOODE
description: After W. Wilson Goode had become the first black to serve as Philadelphia's Managing Director, he told a magazine writer that one of his chief concerns was the impression he might make on young people. ''It's important for all of them,'' he said, ''young white people as well as young black people, to see black men and women in influential positions.''

title: CLARA WINSTON, 61, TRANSLATOR
description: Clara Winston, who with her husband translated more than 150 books from the German, died of leukemia on Monday in Cooley Dickinson Hospital in Northampton, Mass. She was 61 years old.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Holding Cash In Bull Market
description: UNLIKE some money managers who keep their equity portfolios fully invested, Charles Allmon, of Chevy Chase, Md., is not adverse to carrying a large cash position if he does not like the looks of the stock market.

title: U.S. ASKS ARAB AID TO END P.L.O. FIGHT
description: The United States called on Middle East Governments today to end the fighting between rival Palestine Liberation Organization groups around Tripoli.

title: PETRO-LEWIS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid in August 1983. There were lower share earnings in the latest quarter despite the rise in net income because of increased preferred share dividend requirements.

title: GENERAL BINDING CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $427,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the repurchase of outstanding debt.

title: Shock Therapy for Crowded Jails
description: What does New York City say to a woman allegedly raped by a man shortly after a court required his release from an overcrowded jail? Mayor Koch asserts only frustration: ''I can't explain to you the lunacy of what we are being required to do.''

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: QUESTIONS IN CUBA, TOO
description: ''Comrade Commander in Chief,'' said Col. Comas Pedro Tortolo, the highest- ranking Cuban officer in Grenada, ''the mission proposed by the party, the Government and the people of Cuba has been completed!''

title: WARD APPOINTS A POLICE CHIEF AS TOP DEPUTY
description: Benjamin Ward, who will become the city's new Police Commissioner Jan. 1, held individual meetings with the department's top officials yesterday and announced the appointment of Chief Patrick J. Murphy as the department's new first deputy commissioner.

title: COMPUTER REPAIR: SERVICE CONTRACTS
description: AS Wayne M. Gura sat in his West Side apartment one Saturday preparing an important business project on his personal computer, it stopped functioning. Since his presentation was due in only a few days, it was imperative that the device be back in service at once.

title: ART EXPLOSION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STATE DRAFTS PLANS TO USE NEW ROAD-BOND FUNDS
description: The campaign to ''Rebuild New York'' moved from the voting booth to the drafting table yesterday, as state transportation officials drew plans to use the $1.25 billion transportation bond issue.

title: O'ROURKE HINTS HE WILL RETAIN MANY OFFICALS
description: Hours after he had defeated Ogden R. Reid at the polls, Andrew P. O'Rourke was back shaking hands this morning on the North White Plains railroad station platform.

title: BRIEFING
description: Fill in the Blanks

title: ANDERSON BALKS AT PLAN TO SELL CONVENTION CENTER
description: The Republicans, who control the State Senate, have raised a series of objections to the Cuomo administration's plan to sell the New York City Convention Center to private investors.

title: GREYHOUND SAYS EMPLOYEES ARE ABANDONING THE WALKOUT
description: Several hundred Greyhound strikers have returned to work and others have indicated they would also abandon the walkout as the nation's largest bus system prepared to resume operations, company officials said today.

title: U.S. AIDE WARNS SOVIET ABOUT MISSILE STOCKPILE
description: A senior Defense Department official warned the Soviet Union today against taking advantage of a NATO decision to remove 1,400 nuclear warheads from Western Europe.

title: O'BRIEN STEPS DOWN AS COMMISSIONER OF N.B.A.
description: Larry O'Brien, saying that ''there comes a time when you have to move on,'' resigned yesterday as the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, effective with the expiration of his contract on Feb. 1.

title: PRODUCER AND CULTURAL CENTER FOUNDER
description: Hazel J. Bryant, producer of more than 200 musicals and plays, founder of the Richard Allen Center for Culture and Art and also of several other institutions to aid black theater companies, died at her home in Manhattan Monday. Miss Bryant, who had a history of heart disease, was 44 years old.

title: GIT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: FUNDS FOR FILM DISPUTED
description: A United States Senator and the chairman of the National Endowment for the Humanities have clashed over the expenditure of Federal funds for a documentary film on the environment that is to be broadcast next week on public television.

title: AN ULTRAMODERN KITCHEN OF THE 1670'S
description: HAM HOUSE, in Richmond near London, is unusual among Britain's great houses. Furnished by Elizabeth, Countess of Dysart, in the 1670's, it was in its time an opulent example of Restoration fashion. Lady Dysart's descendants were content to live in these luxurious surroundings for the next 275 years, changing very little. And so in 1948, when Ham House was given to the National Trust, the trust and the Victoria and Albert Museum, which administers the house, acquired a fine Restoration building complete with the original furnishings, to open to the public.

title: RECITAL: RENE JACOBS SINGS
description: THE Mannes College of Music began its weeklong investigation of Baroque music Monday with a master class and evening concert by the countertenor, Rene Jacobs. Mr. Jacobs's recital divided itself between France and Italy and spent most of its time in the first half of the 16th century.

title: CIGNA CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net loss of $11,330,000 from Hurricane Alicia.

title: Wilton Stays Dry
description: Fifty years after the repeal of Prohibition, the voters in Wilton, Conn., have decided to keep their town dry.

title: ENERGY RESERVES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,119,000 for the quarter and $7,760,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect an accounting change and discontinued operations.

title: Shelf Rule Likely to Stay
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission is expected to vote Thursday to extend its shelf registration procedure, a 1982 device intended to give corporations quicker and easier access to the capital markets.

title: Cigna Reports Steep Decline
description: The Cigna Corporation, citing weakness in its property-casualty operations, reported yesterday that its operating income in the third quarter fell 18.8 percent, to $125.6 million, or $1.65 a share, from $154.7 million, or $2.02 a share, a year earlier.

title: EVANS VICTORY BOLSTERS REPUBLICANS IN SENATE
description: In a result that reinforced Republican efforts to retain control of the United States Senate, Daniel J. Evans was elected easily Tuesday to the Senate seat he had held for two months by appointment.

title: FREDERICK'S OF HOLLYWOOD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 4
IMPORTANT DATES IN O'BRIEN TERM
description: Following are the highlights of Larry O'Brien's eight and a half years as the commissioner of the National Basketball Association:

title: GRENADIANS NAMED TO A RULING PANEL
description: Nine Grenadians were named today by Sir Paul Scoon, the Governor General, to serve as an interim government and to prepare for elections.

title: 'Doonesbury' Opening Is Postponed to Nov. 21
description: The opening of the new musical ''Doonesbury,'' based on Garry Trudeau's popular comic strip, has been postponed from next Sunday to Nov. 21 at the Biltmore Theater.

title: MEXICANS RALLY AGAINST THE U.S.
description: Thousands of young people shouted ''Murderers, murderers!'' as they marched to the United States Embassy Tuesday evening to protest the invasion of Grenada and United States policy in Central America.

title: FILM: 'BORN IN FLAMES,' RADICAL FEMINIST IDEAS
description: THE futuristic feminism of Lizzie Borden's ''Born in Flames'' is livelier than might be expected, with its militancy even accompanied by a modicum of topical humor. Set 10 years after a socialist revolution in the United States, it tells of a society in which armed bands of whistle- blowing female bicyclists swoop down on would-be rapists, and of male construction workers who protest that their female colleagues are monopolizing the best jobs.

title: Henderson Charged
description: Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson , the former Dallas Cowboy linebacker, was charged yesterday with five sex and drug felony counts involving two teen-age girls, one of whom is confined to a wheelchair. Henderson, who claims the girls solicited him, was ordered to appear Thursday in Long Beach Municipal Court for arraignment. He was free on $16,000 bail following his arrest last Thursday.

title: CURB ON DEVELOPMENT BONDS IS STALLED
description: Representative Martin Frost, the point man in an intense campaign, now at the showdown stage, to keep Congress from restricting the sale of industrial development bonds, began to get the word last summer.

title: Beirut Toll Now 237, Pentagon Aide Says
description: The death toll in the Oct. 23 bombing of the Marine compound in Beirut has risen to 237, a Pentagon spokesman said today.

title: Chapman Offer
description: Chapman Energy Inc. said it has withdrawn its unsolicited offer to merge with the Vanderbilt Energy Corporation after Vanderbilt officials told Chapman that the $8.50-a-share offer was unacceptable. Vanderbilt, based in Denver, said last week that it had agreed to be acquired by a unit of Madison Fund Inc. in a deal valued at $26.1 million. Chapman's proposal, which would have been a tax-free merger, was valued at $31 million.

title: HICKORY FURNITURE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income of $128,000 for the quarter and 9 months from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $245,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Including an extraordinary credit of $926,000.

description: Oriental Rugs, Roosevelt Hotel, 45th

title: Fox Quitting Video Games
description: The 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation said it would phase out its video game division, effective immediately.

title: Two Schools Are Shut In Restless West Bank
description: The military government in the Israeli-occupied West Bank today ordered two Arab schools closed for a month and imposed curfews in some areas after rocks had been thrown at Israeli vehicles.

title: TULANE CONTROVERSY CAUSES DEFECTIONS
description: Joe Gagliardi Jr., a quarterback from North Babylon, L.I., entered Tulane in the fall of 1982 after selecting the school over Rutgers, Navy and Virginia. Now he is sitting out a transfer year at Rutgers.

title: C.D. Rates Decline
description: Interest rates on certificates of deposit dropped sharply in New York and around the country last week, an indication that competition for the newly deregulated instruments was continuing to lessen, the Bank Rate Monitor said yesterday.

title: HELEN FILENE LADD
description: Helen Filene Ladd, a major benefactor of Skidmore College and a descendant of the founder of the Filene department store chain, died last Friday as a result of an automobile accident in Wayne, Me. She was 84 years old and lived in Wayne.

title: 'Terror Has an Address'
description: What's become of Ariel Sharon? That's the question often asked by United States diplomats who have come to wish for a return of his hawkishness to Israel.

title: SPEEDY NETS THWART BULLETS
description: The New Jersey Nets continued to demonstrate the high-speed and high- scoring style of a Stan Albeck team tonight as they routed the Washington Bullets, 127-110, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena. In doing so, they achieved their highest point total since the final game of the 1981-82 season.

title: Coast Arraignment Delayed
description: The scheduled arraignment of a technician accused of selling secret missile data to a Polish spy has been put off until Dec. 12. Federal District Judge Stanley A. Weigel today granted a joint motion by the defense and prosecution to delay the arraignment of James Durward Harper Jr.

title: PORTRAITS WITH A LIVED-IN LOOK
description: CRAIG YERKES specializes in an unusual type of portrait: wire bird cages modeled after his clients' houses. Mr. Yerkes, a 27- year-old designer trained in architecture whose cages may include such details as Palladian windows, pedimental gables and balustraded roofs, is one of a growing number of artists and craftsmen who do unconventional house portraits.

description: b-After a charge of $6.7 million from early redemption of notes. c-Net income

description: Wayne Stemmer, chief real estate investment officer for Citibank, has been named president of the Unicorp American Corporation, a former real estate investment trust.

description: The share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in the form of a stock dividend to shareholders of record Sept. 13.

title: REGIONAL ROLL-CALL ON MILK PRICE BILL
description: Following are the positions of representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut when the House today rejected an immediate 11 percent cut in milk price supports. A ''yes'' represents a vote in favor of the proposed 11 percent cut and a ''no'' represents a vote against it; ''xxx'' means not voting.

title: Kaiser Drops Suit
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation said it had withdrawn a suit filed a year ago against Mitsui & Company USA Inc. and its Japanese parent, Mitsui & Company Ltd., charging that sales of low-cost steel by Mitsui injured Kaiser and other United States steelmakers in violation of antitrust and anti-dumping laws. Kaiser said it dropped the suit after a comprehensive review of Mitsui documents showed that ''whatever technical violations there may have been, there was no injury to our company's interests.'' It declined to elaborate.

title: GRENADIAN 'CARETAKER' HAS WEALTH OF TALENTS
description: The United Nations official who was named yesterday as head of Grenada's interim government is a British-educated economist with experience in a variety of posts in teaching and international affairs.

title: KENTUCKY VICTOR SAYS SHE'LL START FRESH
description: Martha Layne Collins, the victor in Kentucky's gubernatorial contest Tuesday, said today that she had ''hit the ground running'' with plans for her new administration.

title: Raymond Buyout
description: Stockholders of Raymond International Inc. have approved a leveraged buyout of the Houston-based construction and engineering company that gives control to management and employees. The agreement, approved by 93 percent of the eligible votes cast and valued at about $219 million, calls for stockholders to receive $27.50 for each common share and $132.53 for each preferred share.

title: TELETEK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NBC TO END LATE-NIGHT NEWS SHOW
description: ''NBC News Overnight,'' one of the late-night news programs that were introduced last year in hopes of creating a new news audience in the early morning hours, will be taken off the air next month, Reuven Frank, the president of NBC News, announced yesterday.

title: 3 PEOPLE SERIOUSLY INJURED IN A FIRE ON EAST 22D STREET
description: A five-alarm fire tore through an apartment building on East 22d Street yesterday, forcing a dawn evacuation of the six-story structure and seriously injuring two residents and a firefighter.

title: REAGAN, IN JAPAN, PLEDGES CLOSER TIES
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone of Japan today pledged renewed efforts to solve mutual problems of economic trade and to press further for world peace and arms control.

title: EATON FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Grenada's Medical Students Resume Study in New Jersey
description: The New Jersey State Board of Medical Examiners gave provisional approval today to let the Grenada medical school rent space in New Jersey until next Jan. 31.

title: State Dept. Is Wary Of 'Forced Labor' Rule
description: The State Department, warning against economic warfare with the Soviet Union, urged a cautious approach today in efforts to bar the import of goods made by forced labor.

title: CHINA AFFIRMS ITS HONG KONG DEADLINE
description: China affirmed today that it would announce its plans for Hong Kong no later than next September if it fails to reach an agreement with Britain on the future of the colony.

title: Betty Nuthall, 72; British Tennis Star Captured U.S. Title
description: Betty Nuthall, who in 1930 became the first Briton to win the United States women's tennis championship, died Tuesday at New York Hospital of coronary arrest. She was 72 years old.

title: Politicians Deny Extortion Charges
description: City Councilman Luis A. Olmedo and two other Brooklyn politicians pleaded not guilty yesterday to Federal charges they had conspired to extort $12,000 from a food-processing company seeking to move to a vacant city-owned site in the Bushwick area.

title: COUNCIL OF CHURCHES AVOIDS VOTE ON HOMOSEXUAL GROUP
description: The National Council of Churches today refused to admit into membership a denomination formed primarily for homosexuals.

description: A $230 million issue of Northern California Power Agency revenue bonds was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 10.18 percent for 10 1/8 percent bonds due in 2009, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: A DEAL WITH SYRIA?
description: Cui bono? Who profits? The Romans would ask whenever the perpetrators of an act refused to step forward. Of the recent attacks on American, French and Israeli servicemen, we may ask: Who would benefit if Western forces were pushed out of Lebanon, indeed out of the Middle East altogether? They are Syria, and, looming behind it, the Soviet Union. Syria has repeatedly demanded the ouster of ''United States and NATO'' forces. Besides local proxies, Syria has at its disposal fanatical Iranians imported for suicidal missions. Even without access

description: The share earnings have been adjusted for a 5-for-3 stock split paid Sept. 23.

title: USING BLEACH ON FURNITURE SURFACES
description: Distinctive-looking bleached blond wood furniture was probably born in the Art Nouveau movement of the late 19th century and was also popular as Art Deco furniture in the 1930's. Originally the lightening of wood through bleaching may have helped to neutralize the yellowing that most varnish finishes acquired in the days before modern lacquers came into being.

title: UNDERCOVER GAME STORE NETS SIX IN BROOKLYN INVESTIGATION
description: Six men, including a reputed organized-crime figure, were arrested yesterday on loan-sharking, gambling and other charges stemming from a Brooklyn undercover investigation into the video-game business.

title: Cardinal Mozzoni, 79, Long a Vatican Envoy
description: Umberto Cardinal Mozzoni, president of the sanctuaries of Pompeii and Loreto, collapsed while celebrating mass and died Monday in a Rome clinic, the Vatican said Tuesday. He was 79 years old.

title: 2 Held in Slaying Of Pratt Student
description: Two teen-agers were charged last night with the drowning murder of Ann Pfreundschuh, a 21-year-old Pratt Institute student who was found slain Tuesday, bound hand and foot and submerged in the bathtub of her Brooklyn apartment.

title: SURGERY SIDELINES UMPHREY OF GIANTS
description: Rich Umphrey, the starting center, became the latest to join the Giants' long list of casualties today. Umphrey underwent an appendectomy this afternoon at Pascack Valley Hospital in Westwood, N.J., and will miss the remaining six games this season.

title: EX-AGENT RECEIVES 25 YEARS FOR MURDER PLOT CONVICTION
description: Edwin P. Wilson, a former agent of the Central Intelligence Agency, was sentenced yesterday to 25 years in prison for attempting to murder two prosecutors and six witnesses against him.

description: G. D. Searle & Company said it had acquired Laboratori Made, a subsidiary of Italseber Farmaceutici S.p.A., a major Italian drug company, for undisclosed terms.

But while they denied the specific amount of the payment, the Hitachi officials indicated that the Japanese electronics company is paying I.B.M. for use of certain software as part of the settlement.

description: Interest rates were stable to slightly lower yesterday for Treasury notes and bonds, and Government securities dealers said there was more demand for new issues than was evident early this week.

description: New York has fed five years of Manhattan traffic jams into a computer and come up with something akin to a Farmer's Almanac for motorists.

description: Researchers have found they can make babies fall asleep more quickly by increasing the amount of sugar and one of the constituents of protein in the evening bottle.

description: Spokesmen for chain discount stores and small retailers complained to Congress today that the Reagan Administration was lax in pressing antitrust cases and was thus costing consumers billions of dollars a year.

title: AWrite-Ino
description: Six Democratic officeholders in the town of Haverstraw who were ruled off the ballot Oct. 28 by the State Court of Appeals celebrated re-election today following a successful last-minute write- in campaign.

title: Qantas-Boeing Pact
description: Qantas, Australia's national airline, said it received Government approval to spend $640 million on nine new Boeing airliners. It will buy six 200-seater B767 extended-range aircraft and three 300-seater 747's.

title: RECORD PRICE FOR ROTHKO
description: Mark Rothko's ''Black, Maroons and White,'' a huge 1958 abstract work measuring about 9 feet by 13 feet, was sold last night for a record $1,815,000. It was the highest auction price ever paid for a post-World War II painting, for an Abstract Expressionist painting and for a work by the artist.

title: Oilers 7, Capitals 4
description: Jari Kurri scored twice in the third period as Edmonton (14-2-1) gained its seventh victory in a row. Wayne Gretzky assisted on both of Kurri's goals and on goals by Willy Lindstrom and Glenn Anderson. He also scored a short-handed goal in the first period, his 21st goal this season.

title: 3 NOVELISTS CRITICIZE HOLLYWOOD
description: Exactly 45 years ago today, the author Hamlin Garland brought down the house at the annual meeting of the American Academy of Arts and Letters when he excoriated motion pictures as the major culprit in cheapening the writing of fiction and drama.

title: SHARING THE PET AFTER A BREAKUP
description: Joint custody is not new in this country, but there seem to be few precedents for what occurred in September in California. After a year of bitter divorce proceedings, a Santa Ana judge awarded Rex and Judi Wheatland joint custody of their 2-year-old, known as Runaway. Runaway happens to be a dog.

description: David Kimche, director general of the Israeli Foreign Ministry, met here today with Butros Ghali, Minister of State for Foreign Affairs, to discuss the faltering relations between the two countries, the Israeli Embassy said.

title: WHY 'CHAPLIN' IS NOT OPENING ON BROADWAY
description: Tonight, a musical entitled ''Chaplin'' was supposed to have opened on Broadway. But the Mark Hellinger Theater will be dark this evening, because ''Chaplin'' closed three weeks ago, having lost $4 million on the road.

title: Key Rates
