title: INCUMBENT FACING MAYORAL RUNOFF IN MIAMI
description: Mayor Maurice A. Ferre will have to beat Xavier Suarez in a runoff Tuesday if he is to succeed in winning a sixth two-year term.

title: MCLEAN INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NATHAN'S FAMOUS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 25
description: b-After tax credits of $285,300 for the quarter and $462,700 for the 6 months. c-After tax credits of $258,000 for the quarter and $409,000 for the 6 months.

title: ERRANT SHIPPING OF SECRETS PROMPTS CONCERN
description: The State Department began assessing today whether any intelligence or diplomatic secrets were compromised when inmates at a nearby prison obtained documents from a safe that was sent there in error.

title: BRAZIL'S CONGRESS RATIFIES BILL TO CURB WAGES
description: The Brazilian Congress today ratified a decree to limit wages that the Government had called an essential step toward obtaining foreign loans to meet payments on Brazil's $90 billion foreign debt.

title: STAGE: CARROLL O'CONNOR IS STAR IN 'BROTHERS'
description: IT doesn't take genius to see why

title: TODD WILL START, ENDING SPECULATION
description: Richard Todd, who has started every game at quarterback for the Jets since the second one of the 1979 season, is disappointed that he did not receive a vote of confidence from Coach Joe Walton after the 17-14 loss to the Baltimore Colts last Sunday.

title: MUSIC: A RENAISSANCE BAND
description: AS performers' interest in centuries-old music continues to grow, we are hearing more and more concerts played on instruments of curious name and shape and being given increased instruction in theories about performance practices of ages past.

title: STEWART SANDWICHES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
'84 Toll Rates Won't Rise On the Panama Canal
description: The Panama Canal will be maintained and improved without increased toll rates in 1984, the agency that operates the waterway announced today.

title: A SHOW FOR FANS OF CUSTOM KNIVES
description: New York's sixth annual custom- knife show opens today, and its promoters note with delight that among the blades exhibited will be those closely resembling the survival knife used by Sylvester Stallone in his starring role in the motion picture ''First Blood.''

title: VICTOR IN TURKISH ELECTION TO TRY TO EXPAND ECONOMY
description: The economist who is expected to head the first civilian Government of Turkey in more than three years said today that he would seek to give new momentum to the nation's stagnant economy, with emphasis on aiding middle-income groups.

title: CONCERT: NATHAN MILSTEIN
description: WHEN Nathan Milstein played his own set of variations for violin, ''Paganiniana'' in Carnegie Hall on Wednesday night, the silence in the audience was one of heightened tension. For it was clear that the virtuosity that was being displayed was not just expert showmanship.

title: ACCELERATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including extraordinary credits of $5,000 for the quarter and $68,000 for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary credits of $39,000 for the quarter and $216,000 for the 9 months.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. San Diego Clippers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. This is Bill Walton's only scheduled appearance at the Garden this season.

title: DINER'S JOURNAL
description: -grade foie gras, the inflated livers of farm-fattened geese or ducks, find its buttery, preternaturally subtle flavor is worth anything short of armed robbery to obtain. Until recently, most foie gras served in New York's restaurants was imported from France in a semipreserved state. Now, however, fresh foie de canard (duck liver) is being produced by a farm in upstate New York, and it is fast becoming the cynosure of menus in some of the city's better restaurants.

title: 2 Bid to Regain Jobs in Yonkers
description: A lawyer for two Yonkers school district employees transferred for their responsibility in the death of a football player with heart trouble said today that he had begun an appeal with the State Education Department to regain their jobs.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Mutual Funds' Stake Abroad
description: -term capital appreciation by investing abroad are gaining popularity as a possible avenue of asset diversification. Two major brokerage firms - Dean Witter Reynolds Inc. and Paine, Webber, Jackson & Curtis Inc. - have recently offered clients new funds with an investment scope ranging from Japan to Europe and North America.

title: REMEMBERING CITY'S WAR VETERANS
description: Sixty-five years ago today - Nov. 11, 1918 - the Great War ended in the trenches of Europe. And as has happened on this date ever since, French citizens, along with some visitors from the United States, will bring flowers to the six American cemeteries within France. The largest is the Meuse-Argonne, near Verdun, where 14,246 American men are buried. In New York, the anniversary will be observed with a parade, a harbor tour and a poetry reading.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 11, 1983
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: COURT OVERTURNS A WAR CONVICTION
description: A Federal judge today overturned the 1942 conviction of a man whose arrest for refusing to obey wartime evacuation orders led to a Supreme Court ruling upholding the legality of the internment of more than 100,000 Japanese- Americans.

title: AMWAY ADMITS FRAUD
description: The Amway Corporation, which uses an army of part-time workers to sell household items door-to-door, pleaded guilty today to a criminal charge of defrauding the Canadian Government of more than $28 million (Canadian) through customs violations.

title: RETAILERS' SALES UP IN OCTOBER
description: Strong sales of cars and furniture pushed retail sales up 1.1 percent in October, with the monthly total surpassing $100 billion for the first time, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: Economic Scene; On Rational Expectations
description: THE theory of rational expectations, whose leading developer is Prof. Robert E. Lucas Jr. of the University of Chicago, has provoked intense controversy among economists.

title: DRUG ABUSE IN BOXING NEEDS A NATIONAL CURE
description: To the Editor:

title: THIRD WORLD MOVES INTO LA MAMA
description: The Pygmies couldn't make it. For one thing, it's too cold now in New York for anybody who has spent a lifetime au naturel in Africa's steamy equatorial forests. But the show will go on anyway. Adventurous souls who journey this weekend to the La Mama Annex, east of the Bowery on Fourth Street, can see and hear exotic talent from almost all over the third world.

title: DAHLBERG ELECTRONICS INC tr to Sept 30 reports earnings for 1983
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $27,000 for the quarter and $176,491 for the 9 months and a gain of $1,815,162 for the 9 months on the sale of Digital Systems division.

title: PIPER JAFFRAY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings were adjusted for 3-for-1 stock split paid last month.

title: ORROX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DECA ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CHILDREN OF MIXED ANCESTRY: ORPHANS OF ARARTHEID
description: Eileen Gyani is a 10-year-old girl with bushy hair and a chocolate skin. The characteristics have been her downfall.

title: SCREEN: ADAPTED 'CHEESE'
description: ''IAM THE CHEESE'' has the homespun simplicity that its title betrays, and the clumsiness, too. It concerns a 15- year-old boy named Adam Farmer, who has on many occasions had ''The Farmer in the Dell'' sung to him; from this the film (and Robert Cormier's novel, on which it is based) takes its title. Adam is the cheese, the one who stands alone. Fortunately, this imagery is invoked only a couple of times.

title: Pickens's Plan For Gulf Oil
description: T. Boone Pickens Jr., chairman of the Mesa Petroleum Company, told Wall Street security analysts yesterday that an investor group he heads would not sell its shares in the Gulf Oil Corporation back to Gulf. He also said he did not advocate the breakup of Gulf Oil.

title: SAN FRANCISCO REJECTS SKYSCRAPPER CURB BUT APPROVES SMOKING LAW
description: By narrow margins, San Francisco voters have rejected restraints that would have slowed the building of skyscrapers downtown, but they have approved restraints on where people can smoke on the job.

title: DRUG TAPE SOURCE NAMED IN HEARING
description: A clerk in a law firm that initially represented John Z. DeLorean was the source of the videotapes broadcast by CBS News and its Los Angeles affiliate last month, a Government prosecutor told the court today.

title: CONSUMER CREDIT UP $2.38 BILLION
description: Outstanding consumer installment credit in the United States increased by $2.38 billion in September, seasonally adjusted, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: LTV and Republic
description: The Justice Department said it has asked for more information on the proposed $623 million merger between the LTV Corporation and the Republic Steel Corporation. An LTV spokesman said the request ''was fully expected'' as part of the procedure for reviewing mergers. The department is not expected to object to the merger.

title: ADVERTISING
description: LPG/Pon's Cable Account Proving once again that no

title: JAPAN AND U.S. IN PACT TO BOLSTER YEN'S VALUE
description: The United States and Japan announced today that they had agreed to take steps to strengthen the yen's value against the dollar in an effort to reduce the huge American trade deficit with Japan.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Memories

title: M.T.A. WEIGHS PLAN TO LIMIT FARE RISE
description: In an effort to limit increases in subway, bus and commuter railroad fares early next year, the Metropolitan Transportation Authority is considering raising tolls on the Triborough Bridge and five other crossings to $1.50 from $1.25.

title: COMDISCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
DRUMMOND MCCALL METALS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 CITY RIVERS MADE DIVERS SICK
description: Health researchers reported ''strong evidence'' today that diving in polluted water, including the Hudson River, could cause gastrointestinal illness.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1983

title: Dr. George P. Robb, 85; New York Cardiologist
description: Dr. George P. Robb, a cardiologist and the co-developer of angiocardiography, a technique used in the diagnosis of heart disease, died Sunday at his retirement home in Englewood, Fla. He was 85 years old and was a native of Syracuse.

title: HYMAN W. ZUSSMAN
description: Hyman W. Zussman, a former executive of the Ciba-Geigy Corporation, died Monday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital.

title: No Headline
description: Baby Jane's 'Defender' When Dr. C. Everett Koop was named Surgeon General in 1981 he was, under the law, seven months too old for the job and had virtually no experience in public health. These barriers, however, soon collapsed because it was not Dr. Koop's qualifications that made him so attractive to the Reagan Administration. It was his opinions.

title: ART: THE FORGED-IRON SCULPTURE OF ALAIN KIRILI
description: THE sculpture of Alain Kirili has evolved toward a greater and greater inclusiveness. While the artist continues to depend on a vocabularly of simple forms that can be responsive to almost any architectural setting, he has greatly expanded the sculptural possibilities of those forms by accommodating within them a broad range of human and religious concerns. It took considerable conviction for someone with his French avant-garde and Minimal art orientation to make art that by the late 1970's had an unmistakable ethical dimension.

title: DAMASCUS SAYS ITS GUNS FIRED AT U.S. PLANES
description: Syrian antiaircraft batteries opened fire on four American F-14 fighter jets today as they flew a reconnaissance mission over Syrian military positions in Lebanon, a military spokesman in Damascus said.

title: WILLIAMS SCORES 25
description: Coach Hubie Brown came out of the dressing room laughing tonight after the Knicks defeated the Indiana Pacers, 99-91, at the Market Square Arena to halt a four-game losing streak.

title: SCOUTING
description: A Friend Recalls Power Memorial

title: EIP MICROWAVE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Bad Day at the Bank

title: IMASCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30, 1983
description: The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: TEACHERS SAY GAMBLERS OUTBID THEM
description: The New Jersey Education Association opened its annual three-day convention here today, and the hottest topic was not on the agenda.

title: BARBADOS SEEKING TO OUST REPORTER
description: The Prime Minister of Barbados has moved to expel a Guyanese-born journalist, and the journalist says the reason may be his criticism of the invasion of Grenada.

title: ROCKWELL INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings were adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split in June 1983.

title: DECORATOR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net losses after losses from discontinued operations of $67,532 for the quarter and $286,449 for the 9 months.

title: HAGLER OUTPOINTS DURAN TO KEEP MIDDLEWEIGHT TITLE
description: Marvelous Marvin Hagler, with a disdain for the romantic, modified the comeback story of Roberto Duran tonight with a 15-round decision to retain the undisputed middleweight championship.

title: THEATER: 'AMEN CORNER,' MUSICAL SET IN HARLEM
description: BOOK musicals are a dying breed, so at least let it be said that ''Amen Corner,'' the new show at the Nederlander, is mounting a noble campaign to rectify this trend. Have you been craving a musical in which the characters would rather talk incessantly than sing or dance? ''Amen Corner'' is the answer to your prayers.

title: PROVINCETOWN-BOSTON AIRINE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Baldwin Loses Its Treasurer
description: James E. Schwab, the man who held the reins of Cincinnati's Baldwin-United Corporation for a few weeks last summer, has left his position as treasurer of the troubled financial holding company to become chief financial officer of Corporex Companies, a real estate developer in Kentucky.

title: SENSIBILITIES IN LEBANON DULLED BY ALL THE DYING
description: ''After nine years of dying,'' a Government official said, ''we've been immunized against death.''

title: STATE STARTS CRACKDOWN ON 'BOTTLE BILL' VIOLATORS
description: Two dozen undercover state conservation officers fanned out through New York City yesterday and issued citations to violators of the ''bottle bill'' in an effort to improve compliance with the two-month-old container-return law.

title: PENTA SYSTEMS INTERNATIONAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results reflect pooling of interests merger executed in September.

title: BRIEFING
description: Watt Is Hot

title: GOSPEL CHOIR GOES GREEK FOR NEXT WAVE FESTIVAL
description: IT might not have occurred to

title: NEW RULES PASSED FOR ATOM PLANTS
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today approved new regulations requiring utilities to spend millions of dollars to assure that atomic power plants can be shut off in a major accident.

title: CLASSIFIED FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a realized loss of $2,000 for the quarter and a realized gain of $58,000 for the 9 months on the sale of investments. c-Including realized gains on the sale of investments of $138,000 for the quarter and $80,000 for the 9 months and a gain of $75,000 for the 9 months from the cumulative effect on prior years of a change in accounting.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: BUSINESS PEOPLE

title: ALEXANDER & ALEXANDER SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including changes in accounting for the pension plan and realization of tax credits of $1,202,000 for the quarter and $3,489,000 for the 9 months. c-Net losses after a charge of $40 million for the quarter and 9 months for the reduction in the acquired tangible net assets of Alexander Howden Group PLC. Year-ago revenues are restated.

title: 3 PLEAD GUILTY IN BACHE CASE
description: Three men pleaded guilty in Manhattan yesterday to fraud charges involving the embezzlement of more than $18 million from Prudential- Bache Securities Inc.

title: SCOUTING
description: A Package Deal?

title: RAIN SLOWS RUSH-HOUR TRAFFIC
description: Rush-hour traffic came to a virtual standstill on New York City streets and suburban highways last night as rain propelled by strong winds pelted the metropolitan area.

title: 'Brothers' Closes
description: ''Brothers,'' the play by George Sibbald, directed by and starring Carroll O'Connor, closed Wednesday evening after one performance and seven previews at the Music Box Theater. The cast included Frank Converse, Dennis Christopher, Pat McNamara and Gary Klar.

title: Indians' Sale Reported
description: Officials of the Cleveland Indians declined comment on a report that Donald Trump has purchased the team.

title: BARRIER TO PHONE FEE IS VOTED
description: The House of Representatives tonight approved by a voice vote legislation that would block the telephone industry from charging a monthly fee for household and business phones to be linked to long-distance networks.

title: PAGEANTRY AND PRAYER: EAST GERMANS HAIL LUTHER
description: Bearing lanterns through this city's cobbled streets, thousands of East Germans gathered in the medieval market square tonight in a scene dominated by a huge placard that read, ''God Over All Things.''

title: 6 Enter Not Guilty Pleas In Abuse of Retarded
description: Six current or former state hospital aides pleaded not guilty today to abusing mentally retarded residents in what the Justice Department called the first case to use Federal civil rights laws to protect the mentally handicapped.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Steel Industry Calls For Global Quotas

title: A NEW, ANGRIER MOOD ON DEATH PENALTY APPEALS
description: The Supreme Court's impatience with death penalty appeals, evident for several years, has evolved into a new, angrier mood in the weeks since the Court opened its new term. A majority is now determined to shorten the path from death sentence to execution and is reaching out for cases with which to convey that message.

title: Celestial Cancels Initial Stock Offer
description: Celestial Seasonings Inc., which grew from a small company into an aggressive factor in the tea market, said it has withdrawn its initial public offering of 910,000 shares of common stock.

title: IRAN MOVES TO SEVER TRADE TIES TO FRANCE OVER PLANES FOR IRAQ
description: Iran has acted to sever all trade, banking and cultural ties with France, apparently in retaliation for the French sale of warplanes to Iraq, Government officials said today.

title: SOUTHWEST GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-No share earnings because of provision for preferred dividends.

title: CUSTOM ENERGY SERVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a net loss from discontinued operations of $919,297. Year-ago results have been restated.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When I came home from Vietnam, I was treated like dirt.

title: Tandem Computers Up
description: Tandem Computers, a diversifed computer designer and manufacturer based in Cupertino, Calif., reported yesterday that net income in the fourth fiscal quarter of 1983 ended Sept. 30 rose 6 percent, to $8.8 million, or 21 cents a share, from $8.3 million, or 21 cents a share on fewer shares outstanding, a year earlier. Revenues rose 35.2 percent, to $117.9 million, from $87.2 million.

title: DISNEY NET FALLS 12.8% IN QUARTER
description: Walt Disney Productions reported yesterday that earnings in the fourth fiscal quarter fell 12.8 percent, depressed by a $14.8 million loss at the Disney Channel and higher net interest expense.

title: 'Our American Cousin'
description: A new adaptation of ''Our American Cousin,'' the 19th-century drama by Tom Taylor that was presented at Ford's Theater in Washington the night Abraham Lincoln was shot, will be staged for the next two weekends by the Washington Square Players of New York University at the University Theater, 35 West Fourth Street.

title: 'Shelf' Rule Is Adopted, But S.E.C. Sets Limits
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today made permanent its ''shelf'' registration procedure for bringing new securities to market with little delay, but limited its use to the largest and most creditworthy concerns.

title: Maurice Woods, 45, Is Dead; Television and Stage Actor
description: Maurice Woods, a stage and television actor, died of cancer in Lenox Hill Hospital on Nov. 1. Mr. Woods was 45 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: EXPAND THE ARMS TALKS
description: The next few weeks constitute a real moment of choice for the future of Europe and the effort to prevent an even more dangerous arms race. As the Geneva negotiations on intermediate range nuclear forces approach an excruciating and dangerous end, all the parties concerned - the Europeans as well as the superpowers - need to find a way to avoid the confrontation that would follow if the new NATO missiles be deployed next month.

title: Only in Oakland
description: Joe Morgan , the second baseman who was released by the Philadelphia Phillies, has apparently narrowed his prospective teams down to one - the Oakland A's. Morgan, who lives in Oakland, told The Oakland Tribune he was interested in playing for the A's ''and no one else.''

title: FOR THE JAPANESE, A PEEK BEHIND THE PALACE WALLS
description: For Japanese, one of the special bonuses of a visit by an American President is that they get a rare glimpse behind the weathered walls of the Imperial Palace.

title: 'Delicacy' and Women Lawyers
description: One legal truism is that hard cases make bad law. Another should be that when lawyers resist applying certain laws to themselves, they make bad cases. A case recently argued before the Supreme Court, Hishon v. King & Spalding, illustrates the point.

title: GEORGE RUSSELL: HIS BIG BAND AND HIS BIG THEORY
description: GEORGE RUSSELL is a jazz composer and a jazz musician. But, primarily, he is a jazz theorist - possibly the first of his kind. For almost 40 years, he has been developing, justifying and clarifying his Lydian chromatic concept of tonal organization, which has over the last two decades vitally affected both jazz and popular music. The pianist and composer John Lewis has called it ''the first profound theoretical contribution to come from jazz.''

title: Clark Kinnaird, Writer, 82; Had Column About History
description: Clark Kinnaird, a King Features columnist who wrote ''Your America Day- by-Day'' for more than 20 years, died Nov. 4 in Flemington, N.J. He was 82 years old.

title: A POLITICAL-CONTENT BILL
description: The House of Representatives, in a splendid display of empty political showboating, has again passed the so- called ''domestic content'' bill, this time by 219 to 199, in the full confidence that either the Senate will defeat it or President Reagan will veto it as pledged.

title: CBI INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 8
description: Revenue figures represent contract revenues.

title: Guitarists at Carnegie
description: David Bromberg and Taj Mahal, two wide-ranging folk guitarists, will share a double bill tomorrow at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall, Seventh Avenue at 57th Street. Both will perform solo. Tickets are $10.50 to $13.50, and are available through Teletron (947- 5850), Ticketron (977-9020) or the Carnegie Hall box office (247-7459).

title: DISNEY, WALT, PRODUCTIONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SILENCE ON HEINEKEN KIDNAPPING
description: The police declined to issue any information today on their search for for Alfred H. Heineken, the chairman of the Heineken brewery, who was kidnapped at gunpoint Wednesday night on the street outside his offices.

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Young Lords Photos
description: A photographic history of the Young Lords Party, the East Harlem political and social-activist group of the late 1960's and early 70's, will be on view through next month at the Caribbean Cultural Center, 408 West 58th Street.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Drama of Persuasion

title: Marine Sergeant Gets Discharge Over Grenada
description: A socialist-leaning marine veteran who opposed the United States invasion of Grenada has been given an honorable discharge, a Marine spokesman said today.

title: NEW APPEALS COURT OPPOSED BY STEVENS AT A HOUSE HEARING
description: Associate Justice John Paul Stevens of the Supreme Court has told the House Judiciary Committee that he opposes a bill to create a new Federal appellate court to help the High Court with its workload.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Met Roster Moves
description: In a roster shakeup yesterday aimed at protecting six promising young players, the Mets assigned Mark Bradley , Clint Hurdle , Rusty Tillman and Ronn Reynolds to Tidewater in the International League and exposed them to the risk of being drafted by rival clubs. The six young players then were added to the roster, bringing it to the maximum of 40.

title: Turkey Approaches Democracy
description: With this week's election, Turkey moved from outright military rule to quasi-democracy. It stretches truth to describe the vote as free, since all of Turkey's older parties and more than 2,000 politicians were barred from taking part. But the poll was no mere charade. The winner, with a majority, was a party led by Turgut Ozal, the brash freeenterpriser least favored by the generals who seized power three years ago.

title: ADVERTISING
description: AC&R Travel Account

title: HOUSE VOTES AID FOR ISRAELI PLANE
description: The House of Representatives approved legislation today that would allow Israel to use $550 million in military credits to finance the construction of a new fighter plane.

title: REAGAN URGES JAPAN TO JOIN U.S. IN A GLOBAL 'PARTNERSHIP FOR GOOD'
description: President Reagan, addressing the ''good and dear friends of Japan,'' called on this nation and its Parliament today to join the United States in ''a powerful partnership for good.''

title: Move for Impeachment Is Begun by 7 in House
description: Seven Democratic Representatives today asked the House to impeach President Reagan for ordering the invasion of Grenada two weeks ago.

title: AFTER SIX INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $67,100 for the latest first quarter and $23,900 for the year-ago first quarter.

title: PRODUCER PRICES INCREASE 0.3%
description: Falling energy prices helped to offset a big jump in food costs as the Producer Price Index for finished goods rose a seasonally adjusted three- tenths of 1 percent in October, the Labor Department reported today.

title: FOR OLD TIMERS, A DEPRESSING SIGHT
description: Tourists stood in the pouring rain today, patiently waiting to pass through metal detectors hastily erected at Capitol doorways after a bomb exploded near the Senate floor Monday night.

title: ACCORD REPORTED ON APPOINTMENT OF RIGHTS PANEL
description: The Senate approved a bill early today that would reconstitute the United States Commission on Civil Rights as a hybrid eight-member agency appointed jointly by the President and Congress. The vote was 79 to 5.

title: IMMUNOGENETICS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $95,000 for the quarter and $612,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: CORRECTION
description: A reference in the ''Inside'' directory on page A1 in some late editions yesterday misidentified the auction house that sold Mark Rothko's 1958 painting ''Black, Maroons and White'' for a record $1,815,000. It was Sotheby Parke Bernet.

title: F.B.I. CHIEF SAYS CAPITOL BOMBING RESEMBLES OTHER BLASTS
description: William H. Webster, Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, said today that ''a number of individuals and organizations'' were under investigation in the bombing of the Capitol but added, ''We don't know who did it.''

title: 'From $8.00 to $1.59 a Body'
description: Veterans Day began in 1919 to honor the World War I armistice and was later carried forward to honor all veterans, of battles as recent as Lebanon and Grenada. The idea of this day also reaches backward, notably to an earlier November and one of the most memorable veterans' days ever: the day Lincoln spoke at Gettysburg.

title: GUARANTY TRUST CO OF CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AROUND TOWN WITH NEW YORKERS IN THE ARTS
description: NEIL SIMON likes to wander through Bloomingdale's on weekends and to lunch nearby at Serendipity. Judy Collins goes on movie binges - three a day, and it would be four if her boyfriend didn't draw the line. Cynthia Gregory plays pool and goes to the race track. Beverly Sills likes to duck into the American Museum of Natural History to visit the dinosaurs - or whatever else might catch her eye.

title: JAZZ: ON ALTO, EARL HOWARD
description: EARL HOWARD presented two smooth, dreamlike pieces Tuesday at the Kitchen. ''Spangle'' was an alto saxophone solo in two movements, and ''Lava'' was a longer, rhapsodic piece for alto saxophone, piano, percussion and trombone.

title: U.S. BONDS AND NOTES CLIMB SHARPLY IN PRICE
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds rose sharply yesterday as the Government completed this week's three- part $16 billion note and bond financing at yields significantly lower than expected when the week began.

title: Hasidic Festival
description: The annual Israeli Hasidic Festival will be given tomorrow and Sunday at Hunter College, 695 Park Avenue, at 69th street.

title: L.I. Man Charged With Killing Wife
description: A Long Island man kissed his wife yesterday morning and then shot her to death because she insisted on moving to a condominium that he said he could not afford, according to the Nassau County police.

title: EGYPT AGREES TO SEND AN AIDE TO ISRAEL FOR CONTINUED TALKS CAIRO, Nov. 10 (AP) - An Egyptian envoy will visit Israel to resume talks on issues that have strained relations since the Israeli invasion of Lebanon last year, it was announced here today.
description: The announcement came after David Kimche, director general of the Israeli Foreign Ministry, met with Foreign Minister, Kamal Hassan Ali.

title: EARLY START FOR THOMSON CELEBRATIONS
description: Virgil Thomson doesn't actually turn 87 until Nov. 25, but the celebration has already begun. Tomorrow at 1:30 P.M. at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Mr. Thomson will participate in a performance of his score for the 1936 Pare Lorentz film ''The Plow That Broke the Plains,'' reading a text taken from the film's narration. The program will also feature the New York premieres of two of the composer's recent works, ''Fanfare for Peace'' and ''Cantantes Eamus,'' both scored for chorus, brass and percussion.

title: UNI-AGE INSURANCE?
description: To the Editor:

title: Devil's Bag Out of the Remsen
description: Woody Stephens picked up the left front foot of the brown colt in Stall 8 yesterday morning, pointed to a shiny swelling and sighed.

title: BRANDYWINE SPORTS INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
CONCERT: GIDON KREMER WITH ENGLISH CHAMBER
description: THE English Chamber Orchestra played a program at Carnegie Hall last night that at one moment brought old music a little closer to the present and at another showed how comfortably this same present can live with its past.

title: CRUCIAL HEALTH LESSONS ARE GOING UNTAUGHT
description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: AID TO ARTS BY BUSINESS RISES
description: A signficant increase in business support for the arts was reported today, a finding that buttresses the Reagan Administration's position that Federal aid for the arts could be reduced, but runs contrary to observations by arts administrators.

title: REUNION OF UNHAPPY RUNNING BACKS
description: The only other time their teams played each other was in 1977, when Texas beat Oklahoma in Dallas. Earl Campbell, then a senior at Texas, ran for 124 yards and scored the only touchdown in a 13-6 Longhorn victory. Billy Sims was a sophomore at Oklahoma that season but had an injury and did not play in the game.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ANEW YORKER can go straight to the Embassy 72d Street and see ''Experience Preferred . . . but Not Essential,'' whereas a Londoner has to be satisfied with having viewed it on television. Even though it's an English movie, it has for some reason never been sold to English movie houses.

title: Della Gould Emmons Is Dead; Writer About Era of Pioneers
description: Della Gould Emmons, a writer noted for her chronicles of pioneer days in the Pacific Northwest, died Sunday. She was 93 years old.

title: Zimbabwe Says Bishop Has Ended His Fast
description: A Government spokesman said today that Bishop Abel Muzorewa, under detention, had ended a weeklong hunger strike. But officials of Bishop Muzorewa's opposition party were unable to confirm the statement.

CORRECTION
description: An article in The Home Section yesterday on divorce and family pets misidentified a Manhattan psychotherapist. She is Dr. Fern Kazlow.

title: ARTHUR M. SHERWOOD
description: Arthur M. Sherwood, a retired lawyer and former secretary of the Socony-Mobil oil company, died Tuesday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 69 years old.

title: LEBANESE MOSLEM LEADER SAID TO ASK ARAFAT TO LEAVE
description: Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, was reportedly asked by a leading Lebanese Moslem politician today to leave Tripoli, where he has taken refuge from rebel Palestinians attacking his nearby stronghold.

title: FRIENDS BECOMING INVESTORS TO SAVE CHELSEA RESTAURANT
description: In September, when Alyson Arnold stopped GianCarlo Santini on the street, she had been living for months on an allowance that provided her with two packs of cigarettes a day, food for her cat and the subway fare home and back.

title: SOVIET RADIATION IS DETECTED ANEW
description: Ambassador Arthur A. Hartman said today that microwaves were beamed at the United States Embassy again for three months this year, five years after the last such radiation was noted.

title: BROADWAY
description: Marsha Norman has 2 new works ready for staging.

title: ART: HAUNTING MOODS OF EDWIN DICKINSON
description: ''IT never occurred to me to join a group which advocated a particular philosophy of art,'' the painter Edwin Dickinson (1891-1978) said in the late 1950's. ''It would have been unnatural to me.'' Which partly explains why, though his career of more than 60 years ran parallel to a number of American movements, he can't be pegged as belonging to any of them.

description: United State District Judge Charles Stewart yesterday refused to hear the question of whether the Manville Corporation's 14-month-old Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing should be dismissed.

description: Two Haitian boat captains were convicted Wednesday of trying to smuggle 165 of their countrymen into the United States on a voyage marked by starvation, beatings and murder that left up to 50 people dead.

Georgian Joins the House
description: George Darden was sworn in today to complete the term of Representative Larry P. McDonald, the conservative Georgia Democrat killed in the Soviet downing of a Korean Air Lines flight. Mr. Darden, also a Democrat, was told by Speaker of the House Thomas P. O'Neill Jr. that his first House session was likely to be short because the House hoped to adjourn for the year by next Friday. Mr. Darden defeated Mr. McDonald's widow, Kathryn, in a runoff.

title: CARME INC reports earnings for Year to July 31
'THE FRONT LINE WITHERS'
description: These lines are being written at the far end of the northern European plain, one potential invasion route for Soviet tanks during the first stages of World War III. The French Army barrack up the road is the only sign of military preparations for the ''inevitable'' conflict now being fought in the minds of armchair strategists. Mostly, people here in Douai are concerned about the economic crisis - and for good reason. The main industries of the region - automobiles, textiles, coal mining - are in the doldrums. Soviet tanks seem far, far away.

title: BLACK MAYORAL HOPEFUL IN BOSTON IN UPHILL RACE
description: Raymond L. Flynn arrived at his first campaign stop this morning, as usual, driving his own battered 1974 station wagon, the one with a hole in the floor, 99,000 miles on the speedometer and a broken taillight.

title: PUBLISHING: INDUSTRY'S PROBLEMS AND PROSPECTS
description: -buying season, but this Christmas will be more important than most to the book industry. The reason? ''The Christmas selling season will probably answer just how far we've come out of the recession,'' said Roger Straus, president of Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

Brink's Trial Set
description: An Orange County judge today denied a defense motion to grant separate trials to Kathy Boudin and Samuel Brown in the $1.6 million Brink's armored car holdup.

title: AFTER DECADE OF ABANDONMENT, CUSTOM HOUSE INVITES TENANTS
description: Shadows tumble down matching curved stairwells. Deserted rooms - their gloomy chill broken only by a few startling shafts of daylight - give on to empty hallways that yawn in silence. The rumble of lower Manhattan scarcely breaches the marble and oak walls.

description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said today that he could not give a ''target date'' or even set clear criteria for the withdrawal of American forces from Grenada.

title: Colon at the Cathedral
description: Johnny Colon and his 11-piece Latin dance band will perform free tonight at 8 in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 110th Street. Funds from sales of beverages and food will be donated to the House the Homeless fund of the Coalition for the Homeless. The number for more information is 226-7802.

title: Pro-West Angola Rebels Say They Downed Plane
description: Pro-Western insurgents in Angola said today that they shot down an Angolan jetliner that crashed after takeoff, killing all 126 people aboard.

title: ELLIS, LAUREN: THE TRIUMPH OF SPORTSWEAR
description: Perry Ellis, Ralph Lauren, Gloria Sachs and the other designers of casual clothes clinched the case for the pre-eminence of sportswear as the spring fashion shows drew to a close yesterday. There were some romantic overtones, as Mr. Ellis chose to place his fashions in a mythical Australia and Mr. Lauren selected an equally mythical Africa. Both conceded that the locales were strictly imaginary. ''I know they don't wear clothes like this on safari,'' Mr. Lauren said. ''My wife just came back from Africa and told me that when she saw the collection.''

title: CONCERT: KLAUS TENNSTEDT LEADS BRUCKNER WORK
description: ANTON BRUCKNER'S expansive symphonies could be called filibusters set to music were it not that, unlike the senatorial ramblings that are one of the 19th century's gifts to our representative system, the Austrian composer's works are marvels of formal excellence and logic.

title: RANGERS BACK FROM GRENADA REVELING IN PRAISE AS HEROES
description: ''America loves a winner,'' said First Sgt. William Acebes, one of the United States Army Rangers who returned here recently from Grenada,

By Robert Manning;

McIlhenny is on view this weekend at New York's two largest art auction houses. Next week, the art brought together in this way will be dispersed to points all over this country and abroad after it goes up for bidding at Christie's, Park Avenue at 59th Street, and Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street.

title: Brazil Loan Progress
description: William R. Rhodes, senior vice president at Citibank and chairman of Brazil's 14-bank advisory group, said that as of late yesterday more than $4 billion of the new $6.5 billion loan to Brazil had been committed by the nation's commercial creditors. According to banking sources, about 170 banks had responded positively to the request for additional loan funds. More than 800 banks have loans outstanding to Brazil.

title: BISHOP'S CRY IN LAST HOUR: ' 'OH, MY GOD'
description: According to a witness, the last words of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop on Oct. 19, before he was seized at Fort Rupert and later executed, were: ''Oh, my God. They have turned the guns against the people.''

title: SCREEN: 'PURPLE HAZE,' 'CATCHER IN RYE' UPDATE
description: The story goes something like this: There's this guy named Caulfield who gets shipped out of a preppie Eastern school for misbehaving. He didn't really do anything terrible. I mean he didn't run off with the dean's daughter, for God's sake. He just didn't shape up according to a lot of really boring regulations.

title: Mario Trillo Acts in Family Interest
description: The word among general managers is that Manny Trillo's agent is tough. ''Am I a tough negotiator?'' Manny Trillo's agent said, repeating the question. ''I guess so. Why should you play for less? If you think you're one of the best at that position, why should you play for less? We love Philadelphia and we got traded. I guess you're right. I'm tough.''

title: DYNASTY WITHOUT TRADITION
description: Experts may view it as a naive Chinese muscatel, but Dynasty medium-dry white wine heralds China's emergence into the competitive world of budget-priced wines.

title: Tennis Accord Reached
description: A legal battle that began when World Championship Tennis filed an antitrust suit early this year against the Men's International Professional Tennis Council ended yesterday with a settlement whose terms will take effect in 1985 and continue for five years. Under the accord, the W.C.T., which had accused the council of monopolizing the men's tennis circuit, will be able to place three major tournaments on the Grand Prix, the world's largest pro tennis circuit, which the council administers. These three tournaments are the W.C.T. Finals at Dallas, the W.C.T. Tournament of Champions at Forest Hills and the W.C.T. World Doubles Championship in London.

Henderson, 30, who once admitted having a cocaine habit that cost him $10,000 a week, was ''in very bad shape,'' said Arnold Barry Gold .

title: POP: BALLADS SUNG BY JOHNNY MATHIS
description: WHILE Johnny Mathis's singing has changed very little in the 27 years he has been making records, today one's perception of him is very different from that of two decades ago. A style that once seemed affected in its throaty ethereality has been so influential on singers like Al Jarreau and George Benson that Mr. Mathis looms as the genuine pioneer of a romantic ballad style whose hallmark is the bending and constricting of notes for tonal effects that are unrelated to interpretation.

title: SEARCH CONTINUES AT PRISON FOR SECRET PAPERS
description: Four maximum security blocks at the Lorton, Va., prison near Washington were searched today for secret Government documents, as the State Department conceded that security agents had compounded a ''horrendous mistake'' by ignoring a warning that secret papers were in the hands of prisoners.

title: Bridge:One Change Over the Years May Console a Heavy Loser
description: At the beginning of the century, before bridge metamorphosed into auction and contract, redoubles were permitted ad infinitum. This made it possible to lose the family farm on a single deal, and the later elimination of multiple redoubles served to limit the sufferings of those blessed with ebullient and wealthy partners.

title: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1983 International
description: Vagueness on the pullout schedule of United States forces in Grenada was indicated by Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. He said he could not give a ''target date'' or even set clear criteria for the withdrawal. Mr. Weinberger cited new incidents of sniper fire in the Grenadian hills and suggested there might be an extended role on the island for United States military engineers and other units. (Page A1, Column 6.) Receptions accorded U.S. troops returning from Grenada contrast sharply with those given the troops who returned from Vietnam. ''When I came home from Vietnam I was treated like dirt,'' said an Army Ranger. ''But now, I walk down the street and people slap me on the back and say, 'Thanks.' '' (A1:5-6.)

title: DANCE: AFFILIATE ARTISTS SERIES OPENS

description: THE Joffrey Ballet presented this season's first performances of two contemporary choreographic rituals on Wednesday night at the City Center Theater.

title: ART: COMPELLING SHOW OF EARLY STUART DAVIS
description: 1964) is best known for his jazzy, linear, epigrammatic later paintings. Faced with the multifarious impressions that come to us in a great American city, he knew how to pick and choose among them, and how to make them dance and sing. Looking at them, we remember how he prized what he called ''the numerical precision of the black piano players in Newark saloons.''

title: Soviet Pays Brezhnev Tribute On Anniversary of His Death
description: The Communist Party daily Pravda paid tribute today to Leonid I. Brezhnev on the first anniversary of his death, praising his devotion to the party and the country.

title: Brokerage Accord
description: Quick & Reilly Inc., a large discount stock brokerage, and Lind-Waldock Inc., the leading discount commodities brokerage, said they had entered into a reciprocal trading agreement that will put each into the other's field. Quick & Reilly, based in New York, said it would clear commodities transactions through Chicago-based Lind-Waldock, while Lind-Waldock will clear stock transactions through Quick & Reilly.

title: U S WEST: BUILDING AN IMAGE
description: U S West was the first of the new regional telephone companies to choose a name, the first to embark on a splashy promotional advertising campaign, which cost $2.5 million, and the first to announce new subsidiaries and a board of directors.

title: OCTANE RATING HELPS GASOHOL SALES IN U.S.
description: In the United States, interest in alcohol as a motor fuel reached its peak in 1979, as the nation's retail gasoline supplies dropped and lines at the pumps grew. Gasohol, a 90-10 mixture of refined gasoline and ethanol derived from corn, was seen as a means of reducing dependence on foreign oil by using America's grain surplus.

title: 2,000 Indonesians Slain, Rights Group Reports
description: Death squads have killed more than 2,000 people suspected of being criminals this year, and the campaign has intensified since August, when the Government banned news coverage of the killings, people at the country's leading human rights organization said today.

title: DANCE: THE CAROLYN CARLSON TROUPE
description: Carolyn Carlson was one of Alwin Nikolais's leading dancers when she left in 1971 to choreograph. Shortly afterward, she moved to Paris. From 1975 to 1980 she directed and choreographed for a specially created modern dance ensemble at the Paris Opera Ballet. Since 1980, she has headed a similarly created new troupe at Venice's La Fenice Theater in Italy.

title: U.S. REJECTS A PLAN ON SEYCHELLES
description: Ambassador David Fischer says the United States supports the present leftist authorities here and is avoiding contact with exiles who want the Americans to invade and change the Government.

title: EXETER OIL CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RESIDENTS GIVE A BRONX CHEER TO DECAL PLAN
description: Sarah Torres says that ''they're an outrage''; Allie Regner thinks they're ''kind of fun''; Steve Saltiel calls them ''really stupid,'' and Wilmer Cintron says they're merely ''dumb.''

title: WYLY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $100,000 from discontinued operations and a tax credit of $660,000. c-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $420,000 and an extraordinary credit of $2,310,000 from tax loss carryforward. The 1982 figures were restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: ORMAND INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FLUKE, JOHN, MANUFACTURING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago restated for a 5 percent stock dividend in February.

title: Lampoon Has Narrower Loss
description: National Lampoon Inc., a magazine publisher based in New York, reported yesterday that it had a loss of $156,100 in the third quarter, compared with a deficit of $171,400 a year earlier. Revenues slipped 14 percent, to $2.51 billion, from $2.92 billion.

title: Salem 1 Is Closed Because of Leak
description: A leak of radioactive water forced a shutdown of the Salem 1 nuclear power plant, utility officials said today.

title: POLITICAL CLASH CLOUDS FUTURE OF SCIENCE HALL
description: A $3.5 million renovation of the Hall of Science at the site of the 1964 World's Fair in Queens is to be completed this month, but the museum's future has become entangled in a political dispute.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Commodore Corp., Syracuse, Ind., said it had completed the acquisition of Majestic Industries Inc. in Texarkana, Tex,, for an undisclosed price. The companies produce manufactured housing.

title: CORRECTION
description: The calendar of coming events in The Home Section on Thursday gave incorrect details about the Christmas Fair of the Park Avenue Methodist Church. It will be held next Saturday from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. at 106 East 86th Street.

title: El Paso Unit Sale
description: The El Paso Company said it had agreed in principle to sell the chemical manufacturing business of its El Paso Productions unit to a management group. El Paso did not announce terms of the sale, but said the book value of the properties was about $240 million.

title: KMS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $65,000 for the quarter and $202,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $55,000 for the quarter and $188,000 for the 9 months.

title: HOUSE AND SENATE AGREE ON SPENDING
description: House and Senate negotiators agreed today on a catch-all spending bill that is needed to keep parts of the Federal Government operating through Sept. 30.

title: AMFESCO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CELTICS WIN 7TH STRAIGHT
description: Larry Bird scored 39 points, including 16 in a 45-point first period, and the Boston Celtics rolled to their seventh consecutive victory tonight, beating the Detroit Pistons, 126-118.

title: Company Declines Toxic-Waste Job
description: A company that was asked to accept dioxin- contaminated soil from the former Diamond Akali Company herbicide plant for burial has declined to take it, a spokesman said today.

title: REBEL IN EL SALVADOR PREDICTS U.S. INTERVENTION THERE IN '84
description: A Salvadoran guerrilla leader said today that he expects that rebel forces will have to confront American troops in combat in 1984 and that he had prepared a new military strategy for that contingency.

title: Sun Chemical Profit
description: The Sun Chemical Corporation reported yesterday that it had earnings in its third quarter of $4.3 million, or 55 cents a share, contrasted with a loss of $7.9 million a year ago.

title: COLLEGE OFFERS FINANCIAL AID TO MIDDLE CLASS AND WEALTHY
description: In a significant shift, private universities that once focused their student aid on scholarships for the poor are now including aid programs for middle-income, upper-middle-income and even wealthy students.

title: DENOUNCES NORTH
description: Excerpts from speech, page 6.

title: LAUREL ENTERTAINMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Thompson Case Settled
description: The Seattle SuperSonics have been given permission to sign David Thompson, their star free-agent guard, despite the National Basketball Association's earlier threat to void such a contract because it would put the team above its $4.6 million salary cap for this season. Under the collective bargaining agreement with the National Basketball Players Association, the N.B.A. is not supposed to apply the cap to a team's signing one of its own veteran free agents.

title: EX-HUSBAND OF FEMINIST SAYS SHE TOLD HIM TO KILL MAN IN '65
description: A former husband of the feminist Ginny Foat broke into tears today as he testified that he and Mrs. Foat robbed and killed an Argentine businessman 18 years ago because they were running out of money.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Memories in the Mist

title: Montclair Falls
description: Chris Delia, in his first start as a quarterback, scored on runs of 23 and 4 yards to lead Glassboro State to a 14-7 victory over Montclair State, the two-time defending champion, in a New Jersey State Conference game last night at Page Stadium in Glassboro, N.J. Glassboro State moved into a first-place tie with Montclair State, which had won 19 stright league games. Both teams have 5-1 records. Mark Casale, Montclair State's senior quarterback, completed 12 of 25 passes for 145 yards to bring his career total to 6,096 yards.

title: $3 Million Finding Against Hospital
description: A State Supreme Court jury in Brooklyn returned a $3.25 million judgment against Methodist Hospital Thursday for failing to detect water on the brain of a teen-ager that eventually led to the loss of much of his vision, a lawyer for the boy said yesterday.

title: THE NEW DISCOUNT FURRIERS
description: ''In 1962, you could buy a new Cadillac for $6,000 and a beautiful mink for $5,000. Today, a new Cadillac will cost you $20,000 but a Blackglama mink costs $3,000.''

title: BAKER DELAYS ACTION ON PHONE FEE
description: Senate Majority Leader Howard H. Baker Jr. today turned aside pleas from the House of Representatives for quick action on a bill that would block the telephone industry from charging customers a monthly fee for a hookup to long-distance networks.

description: b-After a tax benefit from a capital loss carryforward of $840,000. c-Includes after-tax gains of $17,907,000 and $4,623,000 from the sale of Canadian operations and on nonoil and gas assets, respectively.

description: b-Net loss.

description: b-Including a net charge of $58,763 for the quarter and 9 months for bad debt.

title: MACANDREWS & FORBES GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest third quarter earnings include a charge of $267,000 from a change to LIFO accounting for the company's chocolate products inventories. The latest 9 months results include a nonrecurring charge of $982,000 from an employment contract with the former chairman of Technicolor Inc., and a charge of $743,000 from the change to LIFO accounting. The year-ago 9 months results include a gain of $401,000 from acquisition-related activities. The latest quarter and 9 months results also include Technicolor Inc. which was acquired by MacAndrews & Forbes in December 1982.

title: TRIPOLI IS DIVIDED ON ARAFAT'S STAY IN HIS STRONGHOLD
description: The leaders of this predominantly Sunni Moslem city were divided today over whether Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, should leave Tripoli and eliminate the threat of heavy fighting here.

description: ''I'm sorry to call at this hour - .''

title: JETS ACTIVATE A WARY MCNEIL
description: Although he said he doubted that he could play Sunday against the Buffalo Bills, Freeman McNeil was activated today by the Jets after missing six games with a dislocated shoulder.

title: RUMSFELD MAKING HIS FIRST MIDEAST TRIP AS ENVOY
description: Donald H. Rumsfeld, President Reagan's new special envoy to the Middle East, is flying to the region to confer with key leaders on how to foster a political settlement in Lebanon, Administration officials said today.

title: Democrats to Sponsor Debate ; Democrats to Sponsor Public Debate Jan. 15 WASHINGTON, Nov. 11 (AP) - The House Democratic Caucus, brushing aside objections from Walter F. Mondale, who is considered the front-runner among Democraatic Presidential candidates, have announced plans for a roundtable candidates' discussion as part of a nationally televised debate among the party's contenders next Jan. 15.
description: Five of the eight candidates immediately said they would take part. Former Vice President Mondale did not rule it out, but an aide said he would have preferred a different format.

description: This town, which may arguably house the greatest collection of scientific minds and machinery in the world, still votes by paper ballot and counts the results by hand.

Quotation of the Day
description: ''Let me make one thing plain: You are not alone, people of Korea. America is your friend and we are with you.'' - President Reagan. (1:6.)

title: Terex Cutting Employee Hours
description: Beginning Monday, 450 salaried employees at two Ohio plants of the Terex Corporation will be placed on four-day work weeks for two months and their weekly pay will be cut 20 percent as the company reorganizes under Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings, a spokesman said.

title: AMERICAN FINANCIAL ENTERRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Cruguet Out 8 Weeks
description: Jean Cruguet, the 44-year-old jockey who underwent surgery for removal of his spleen Thursday evening after he had been injured in a spill at Aqueduct, will be able to resume riding in about two months, his doctor, Michael Last, said yesterday. Dr. Last, a surgeon at Long Island Jewish Hospital in New Hyde Park, L.I., where the operation was performed, said Cruguet would be hospitalized for 10 to 14 days, then ordered to rest for 6 weeks.

title: Leslie Irvin, Murderer In a Landmark Ruling
description: Leslie Irvin, whose conviction for a 1954 murder prompted a landmark United States Supreme Court ruling on the issue of pretrial publicity, died Wednesday while still in custody. He was 59 years old.

title: CITY IN ARGENTINA LIVES UP TO ITS REBELLIOUS IMAGE
description: Argentines call it el Cordobazo, the big Cordoba blow, accenting how this interior city is known as the nation's center of revolt.

title: EXCERPTS FROM PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS IN SEOUL
description: Following are excerpts from the address that President Reagan is delivering to the South Korean Parliament today, as made available by his office:

title: Celeron Pipeline
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company's Celeron Corporation said it has received clearance from state and Federal officials to build a 1,200- mile crude oil pipeline from California to West Texas. The project, estimated to cost more than $600 million, would connect with existing pipelines to Gulf Coast refineries and is expected to be completed by 1986, the company said.

description: THE SELECTED POEMS OF SHUNTARO TANIKAWA. Translated from

description: First impressions, thank goodness, are not invariably lasting. If that were so this column would not be about the glories of white truffles.

TOUGH DEFENSE WINS FOR KNICKS
description: Minutes after the Knicks beat the Indiana Pacers Thursday night, Richie Adubato and Rick Pitino, Coach Hubie Brown's assistants, were charting the course for the next night's game against San Diego at Madison Square Garden.

title: U.S. ENERGY CRISIS :THE TURNING POINT
description: To the Editor:

title: City Ballet Will Open With a Gala Tuesday
description: The New York City Ballet will open its 79th New York season Tuesday in the New York State Theater with a gala benefit featuring three signature ballets by George Balanchine, ''Symphony in Three Movements,'' ''Symphony in C'' and ''Apollo.''

title: NATIONAL LAMPOON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

TWO PLANS OFFERED FOR KAISER ASSETS
description: The Kaiser Steel Corporation's assets may be divided between an Oklahoma-based investor group and a Colorado coal-mining company. a Kaiser spokesman said today.

title: COURT BACKS A WORKER WHO WOULD NOT LOBBY
description: A Federal appeals court has ruled that a company may not dismiss an employee solely because he would not lobby for the legislation his employer supported.

title: AMERICAN SCIENCE & ENGINEERING reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 28
Dr. William Bradford; Vaccination Developer
description: Dr. William Leslie Bradford, who helped develop the triple vaccination given children against diphtheria, tetanus and pertussis, or whooping cough, died Friday at Strong Memorial Hospital in Rochester. He was 85 years old and had been in active practice in Rochester.

title: FINDING TREASURE AT THRIFT SHOPS
description: It's not only smart to be thrifty these days, but it's also considered clever to join the sharp-eyed bargain hunters checking out possible treasures in thrift shops. For those who have the time and the patience, the rewards can be satisfying, especially if one beats out the professional dealers who regularly scout the stores.

title: SATURDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Indiana Pacers, at Indianapolis. Indiana has not beaten the Nets in two years, a streak covering seven games. (Radio - WNBC, 660; 8:30 P.M.) Football Georgia vs. Auburn, at Athens, Ga. Auburn, ranked first in the computer ranking compiled by The New York Times, takes on an undefeated opponent in a game that could prove decisive for the Southeastern Conference race. (Television - Channel 7, 3:30 P.M.)

title: Harvester Plant
description: An Oak Brook, Ill., marketing company said it expects to sign an agreement within two weeks to buy the 36-acre, closed International Harvester Company plow plant in Canton. Randy Bolduc, chairman of Temco Inc., told a news conference that a price of $1.2 million had been agreed on tentatively.

title: A FUNERAL PRECESSION IN MANILA TURNS INTO ANS ANTI-MARCOS PROTEST
description: Thousands of anti-Government demonstrators took to the streets today as the body of the man accused by the police of killing the opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. was carried to a cemetery for burial.

title: Guild Re-Elects Asner
description: -election victory as president of the Screen Actors Guild. Mr. Asner, an outspoken critic of President Reagan's Central America policy whose comments prompted frequent objections from Charlton Heston, former guild president, received 9,997 votes Wednesday to 2,787 for his opponent, J. D. Hall. The guild claims a total of 55,000 members.

title: Elegant Compromise on Civil Rights
description: For a time, the protracted struggle between the White House, Congress and civil rights groups seemed likely to destroy the U.S. Commission on Civil Rights. Now it looks like the fight was worth it: An eleventh-hour compromise will renew the agency as a hybrid, appointed jointly by the President and Congress, and preserving it as an independent, bipartisan watchdog.

title: Jetliner With 156 Aboard Skids off Miami Runway
description: An Eastern Airlines jetliner carrying 156 people skidded off the runway during an emergency landing at Miami International Airport tonight after a tire blew out on takeoff, disabling the landing gear, aviation officials said.

title: FRENCH BISHOPS EXPLAIN A-ARMS VOTE
description: French Roman Catholic bishops, who agreed this week that nuclear deterrence is a legitimate defense, based their conclusion on what they described as the ''aggressive and dominating character of Marxist- Leninist ideology.''

title: WESTINGHOUSE UNIT RETREATS
description: A decision by Westinghouse S.A., a subsidiary of the Westinghouse Electric Corporation, to suspend outlays while it reorganizes under the Spanish equivalent of bankruptcy law illustrates the difficulties that American businesses can have operating in a depressed economy under foreign restrictions.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 28.

title: HEALTH CARE & RETIREMENT CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
VISTA RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
POLES RALLY TO MARK OLD NATIONAL DAY
description: Thousands of Poles, many shouting Solidarity slogans, staged impromptu rallies tonight in celebration of the nation's unofficial independence day. The rallies were quickly broken up by policemen.

title: HADSON PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Weekend yesterday incorrectly identified the source of a $5 million gift to the Metropolitan Museum. The money came from Iris and B. Gerald Cantor, who also donated 80 Rodin sculptures.

title: Stanford Losing Coach
description: Stanford's football team, which has lost eight of its nine games, is losing something else: the coach, Paul Wiggin , who said yesterday that he would step down when the season ends. Stanford has two games left, and the coach has one year left on his five- year contract.

title: FRANK PRICE NAMED TO HEAD MCA'S UNIVERSAL FILM STUDIO
description: Frank Price, who resigned as chairman of Columbia Pictures one month ago in the aftermath of a power struggle, became chairman of the MCA Motion Picture Group late this afternoon. Central to the newly created position is control of the production and distribution of Universal Pictures.

title: Survivor of Shipwreck Found in Air Pocket
description: Divers searching a oil rig crew boat that capsized Thursday in the Gulf of Mexico found its cook alive today, huddled in an air pocket, the boat's owners said.

title: Your MoneyLeonard Sloane Bond Swaps Reduce Taxes
description: BOND swapping has long been a favorite preoccupation of some holders of municipal bonds around this time of year. It serves as a means of establishing a loss on securities owned and thereby cutting taxes, while at the same time often keeping a portfolio intact.

title: REAGAN VISITING BORDER ZONE AT TIME OF GROWING TENSION
description: The tour President Reagan plans to take of the demilitarized zone in Korea will come at a time of renewed tension between the northern and southern portions of that divided nation.

title: BusWestchester
description: Liberty Lines, Westchester County's largest bus operator, reached tentative agreement last night on a three-year contract with its drivers and mechanics, averting a strike that had been threatened for 12:01 A.M. Saturday.

title: CADETS IN HIGH SCHOOL WEIGH DUTY AND RISK
description: Marine Cadet First Lieut. Joann Stroh, 17 years old, faced her unit of 100 fellow Junior Reserve Officer Training Corps students and called them to attention in the high school cafeteria. In camouflage uniforms and combat boots, in green tunics, trousers and spit-shined shoes, they stood in silence, remembering the marines who died in Beirut.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: UP SOUTH At the Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street (860-1888), they are coming down the home stretch with memories of a vestigial Jewish past, one that came and has almost gone in the 20th century. It is a story of the South Bronx, ''The Miracle of Intervale Avenue,'' a photographic show that will be taken down next Tuesday.

title: PLAYERSMalcolm Moran; Two McAdams Got Halloween Treats
description: TOTOWA, N.J.

title: Hofstra Goalie Badly Hurt in Fall
description: Andrew Radcliffe, a standout goalkeeper for Hofstra University's soccer team, was badly injured early this morning when he fell from a fifth- story dormitory window. The 20-year- old Radcliffe, of Smithtown, L.I., was unconscious and in critical condition at Nassau County Medical Center in East Meadow.

title: WILL A WOMAN BE A VICE-PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's entrance as a contender for the Democratic Presidential nomination and the results of last Tuesday's state and local elections could hasten a historic change in American politics: the selection of a woman as the Vice-Presidential candidate of a major party.

title: SHOE-TOWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $911,000 for the quarter and $2,908,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss The year-ago figures are pro forma reflection of Shoe-Town acquisition of the Felsway Corp., July 30, 1982. They include Felsway earnings until July 30 and combined earnings through Oct. 2, 1982.

title: 2 Reporters in Florida Facing Jail Over Sources
description: Two reporters facing six months in jail for refusing to divulge confidential sources say they have no regrets, and no thoughts of changing their minds.

title: FIFTH AVENUE CARDS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: SECRET SERVICE PROTECTING JACKSON MONTH BEFORE OTHER CANDIDATES
description: The Secret Service began providing protection to the Rev. Jesse Jackson on Thursday, more than two and a half months before the seven other candidates for the Democratic Presidential nomination are scheduled to receive protection.

title: U.S. AIDES DETAIL HELP FOR GRENADA
description: United States officials said here today that more than a third of a newly approved aid program for Grenada would be devoted to medical services and education. They said the aim was to act as swiftly as possible to replace Cuban medical personnel and teachers who had been expelled from the island.

title: A SWITCH TO ALCOHOL AS AUTOMOBILE FUEL IS GAINING IN BRAZIL
description: A Brazilian who sets off for the weekend in the wrong kind of car is turned away from service stations all day Saturday. And when he is allowed at the pump, fuel costs $2.37 a gallon, nearly $1 more than for the driver of the right kind of car. To buy the wrong car, an auto loan carries stiffer terms, and to keep it, the owner pays a higher road tax.

description: The Chrysler Corporation, whose earnings set a company record this year, will not pay a fourth-quarter dividend on common stock, a company spokesman said.

title: TV 'WAR GAME' TO STAR EX-GOVERNMENT FIGURES
description: ABC News is planning to broadcast a televised ''war game'' in which former leading Government figures will appear as actors, portraying a President and his advisers as they contend with a hypothetical international crisis.

description: To the Editor:

description: The Treasury market was closed yesterday for Veterans Day, and securities firms operated with reduced staffs in their corporate and tax-exempt bond departments.

title: STRIFE IN P.L.O. MUST END, SYRIA IS TOLD BY SOVIET
description: Syria's Foreign Minister left Moscow today carrying an unambiguous message that the Soviet Union wants the internal struggle in the Palestine Liberation Organization stopped.

title: THERE'LL BE A NEW ARTIE SHAW BAND
description: Artie Shaw, whose recordings of ''Begin the Beguine,'' ''Back Bay Shuffle'' and ''Lady Be Good'' pushed him past Benny Goodman as the most popular swing-band leader of the late 1930's - and who left the music business in the mid-50's vowing never to return - is coming back. And so is one of the most celebrated homes of the swing bands, the Glen Island Casino.

title: CHURCH PANEL STANDS BY 'NONSEXIST' READINGS
description: The National Council of Churches today stood by its recently issued volume of Bible readings that eliminated references to God as solely male.

title: Slayer of Father Is Freed on Bail
description: An 18-year-old woman was freed on bail today, only hours after she began serving a prison term of two and a third to seven years for killing her father, a wealthy Saratoga County real-estate developer.

title: ANDERSON JACOBSON INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 12, 1983 International
description: South Korea was urged by President Reagan to pursue democratic change as the ''foundation of true security'' on his arrival in Seoul on a two-day visit. In a speech to Parliament, he also denounced North Korea. The South Korean Government called out many more troops in taking more precautions to protect Mr. Reagan after some combative-toned denunciations from North Korea. (Page 1, Column 6.) Whether Yasir Arafat should leave Tripoli to eliminate the threat of heavy fighting in that northern Lebanese city between Syrian-backed Palestinian rebels and Arafat loyalists was debated by the city's leaders. Mayor Ashir Daye and other local officials want him to go, but Mr. Arafat has the support of Sheik Saed Shaaban, a Moslem clergyman who controls most of Tripoli with a militia of 600 men. (1:4.)

title: Max Roach at Kitchen
description: The drummer Max Roach will perform tonight with Fab 5 Freddy, a rap vocalist, and D. J. Spy, a disk jockey, and several crews of break dancers at the Kitchen (925-3615), 59 Wooster Street. Shows begin at 8:30, and tickets are $5.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report yesterday about a restaurant owner in Manhattan's Chelsea section incorrectly described a restaurant she once managed. The restaurant, Ruelles, on Columbus Avenue, is open.

title: WAL-MART STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings reflect 100 percent stock dividend paid on July 8, 1983.

title: Ballet Theater Season to Open Dec. 6
description: American Ballet Theater will present three world premieres, a company premiere, a new production and three revivals in addition to 26 repertory ballets during its 1983-84 performance schedule. The company's season will open Dec. 6 at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, where it will be for nearly a month.

title: BOW VALLEY INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WHITE HOUSE WON'T AID MOVE TO SPUR WESTWAY
description: Reagan Administration officials say the White House is withholding support from an amendment to a spending bill in Congress intended to overcome legal and environmental obstacles to the Westway project.

title: County Changing Phone Numbers
description: The telephone numbers are being changed at Westchester County government offices as part of a telecommunications system that officials hope will save the county up to $30 million over the next 10 years.

title: Creusot Rescue Plan
description: Creusot-Loire has reached agreement with the Government and banks on a financial rescue plan, the industrial group said today. Sources close to the talks said the agreement averts a bankruptcy filing by the heavily indebted group. It also appears to end a month of talks between Creusot-Loire and its major shareholder, Schneider S.A., on the one hand and banks and the Government on the other.

title: SOCCER AT RUTGERS : A SUCCESS STORY
description: Rather than being a typical tale of grit and determination, rags to riches, the recent soccer success at Rutgers University reads like an uncomplicated primer on winning in easy lessons. No dramatic uphill climb, no struggling against almost insurmountable odds to reach respectability.

title: Subway Repairs Causing Rerouting
description: The New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that it was rerouting some service on the No. 5 and N subway lines to allow for track maintenance and repair work.

title: BUSINESS EXCHANGE INC reports earnings for Year to July 31

title: SECURITY TIGHTENED IN SEOUL IN ADVANCE OF REAGAN VISIT
description: The South Korean Government put political opponents under house arrest today as security in the capital was sharply tightened on the eve of President Reagan's scheduled two-day visit.

title: DISPUTE BOILING BETWEEN KOCH AND WEINBERGER
description: The Koch-Weinberger dispute is boiling on, with denunciations from several sides.

title: Convention Center: A Risky Rescue
description: The $375 million fund created to build the New York City Convention Center is now clearly insufficient. Unexpected problems, especially the cast steel nodes of the space frame, have raised the estimated cost by about $100 million.

title: PLIGHT OF WEAKER NEWSPAPERS
description: All across the country - in San Francisco, Miami, Cincinnati and 48 other cities with more than one newspaper - fierce competition and rising costs are squeezing the smaller newspapers especially hard. Their predicament is testing the effectiveness of a Federal law passed expressly to help insure the survival of newspaper voices that would otherwise fall silent.

title: Texas, Oklahoma Bank Audit
description: Ten major banks in Texas and Oklahoma with sizable loans to the ailing energy industry are undergoing a special review by Federal bank examiners, the office of the Comptroller of the Currency said in Washington yesterday.

FOREST OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ASSOCIATED SAID TO PLAN SALE OF 12 STIX STORES
description: The Stix Baer & Fuller department stores in St. Louis will be sold next week by the Associated Dry Goods Corporation to the Dillard Department Stores of Little Rock, Ark., according to industry sources.

title: STAGE: 'COLONUS' MIXES SONGS WITH SOPHOCLES
description: Playing a preacher in a black Baptist church, Morgan Freeman steps in front of his congregation and announces, ''I take as my text this evening the Book of Oedipus,'' and, in context, his statement is as natural as if he had said, ''the Book of Job.'' In ''The Gospel at Colonus,'' Lee Breuer as adapter-director and Bob Telson as composer show us how Oedipus was transfigured by his suffering and became the saintliest of sinners.

'YOUNG WARRIORS' FROM MALIBU
description: For the first half hour or so, ''Young Warriors'' appears to have been mistitled, because it revolves around four spoiled Malibu-bred fraternity boys. Sharing a dormitory room with a Pia Zadora poster on the wall, these lunkheads favor practical jokes, casual sex and beer-guzzling. The only potential warfare in their future is apt to be the battle of the bulge.

title: Holiday Closings
description: Because of Veterans Day yesterday, most Federal, state and municipal government offices were closed and there was limited trading of Government securities. Most banks were also closed, and foreign exchange trading in the United States was limited. The weekly money supply report, usually released Friday, was postponed until 4:15 P.M. Monday.

title: PATIENT NETS BEAT MILWAUKEE
description: When it comes to age and experience, no team comes close to the Milwaukee Bucks. Nate (Tiny) Archibald and Bob Lanier together have completed more National Basketball Association seasons - 25 - than the Nets' starting five.

title: Diagram Bridge: Old Queens and Foolish Duke
description: One of the world's oldest decks of playing cards visited New York this week. It is certainly the oldest known complete deck of hand-painted cards, and perhaps the oldest of any kind originating in France or Flanders. It is believed to have been made in the Lille area between 1470 and 1485, and is in beautiful condition.
