title: Comings and Goings
description: The Rangers have recalled the left wing Rob McClanahan, the 1980 United States Olympic veteran who was sent to Tulsa before the start of the season. At the same time, the Devils recalled the defenseman Bob Hoffmeyer, a former Philadelphia Flyer, from their Maine farm club and sent another defenseman, Murray Brumwell, to Maine. . . . Vlado Bogicevic surprised the Cosmos by announcing he would play for them in their N.A.S.L. indoor season-opener tonight.

title: Francis W. Carpenter, Ex-Aide For U.S. Mission to the U.N.
description: Francis W. Carpenter, director of news services for the United States Mission to the United Nations from 1957 to 1967, died of a heart attack Thursday at Bridgeport (Conn.) Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Bridgeport.

title: CIVIL RIGHTS ADVOCATES APPLAUD SENATE ACTION
description: Civil rights advocates praised the Senate today for taking action to insure the survival and independence of the United States Commission on Civil Rights.

title: Christine Craft Lawyers Requesting a New Trial
description: Lawyers for Christine Craft, the former television anchor, asked for a new trial Thursday on her claim that she was demoted from the anchor desk of KMBC-TV because of sex discrimination.

title: CITY U. THEME: 'ACCESS AND QUALITY'
description: During his first year as chancellor of the City University of New York, a position he assumed 14 months ago, Dr. Joseph S. Murphy gave 111 speeches, and one theme was dominant: the notion of the university as a place of both ''access and quality.''

title:
PATENTS;
A Meter to Measure Comfort in Vehicles
description: A ride quality meter to measure comfort offered by trains, buses and planes was patented this week for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration.

title: Activision Sets Layoffs for 90
description: Confronted by lackluster orders for new video games as retailers sell off low-priced products from last season, Activision Inc. said today it would lay off more than 90 employees, one-quarter of its work force.

title: Vagabond to Add Financial Corp.
description: The Financial Corporation of Santa Barbara said it has signed a definitive agreement to be acquired by Vagabond Hotels Inc., despite a higher bid for control by a unit of the Westwood Savings and Loan Association. The agreement calls for Vagabond to pay $9.50 a share in cash for 3.7 million shares of the Financial Corporation, a deal valued at $34 million.

title: Percy to Seek Fourth Term
description: Senator Charles H. Percy, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, will seek a fourth term, his aides said Thursday. Mr. Percy, an Illinois Republican, will declare his intention to run again in a series of stops throughout the state next Monday, the aides said. Representative Tom Corcoran of Illinois, who faces Mr. Percy in Republican primary next March, challenged the Senator to a series of debates.

description: In 64 years in the National Football League, the Chicago Bears had one big boss: George Halas , also one of the founders of the league. For 15 years, his son, George Jr. served as president, but the son died in 1979, and Halas remained the Papa Bear until his own death on Oct. 31.

description: Rabbi Mordecai M. Kaplan, the Jewish teacher who died Tuesday at the age of 102, was praised at his funeral yesterday as a man of personal warmth and innovative ideas who brought profound changes to Judaism.

title: DON'T FURTHER WEAKEN CITIZENS' LAWSUITS
description: Having diminished Federal enforcement of public- interest laws, the Reagan Administration has shifted its attack to citizen enforcement of those same laws. Following a United States Supreme Court decision that cuts back on awards of attorneys' fees to citizens who bring public-interest lawsuits, the Administration now is drafting legislation that would further discourage such citizen suits.

title: THEATER: 'FAITH HEALER' BY BRIAN FRIEL IS REVIVED
description: In Scott Fitzgerald's ''Last Tycoon,'' the novelist wrote that ''there are no second acts in American lives,'' a line that comes to mind because once in a while there are second chances in the New York theater. If a play dies on Broadway, sometimes it gets resuscitated (rather than merely revived) Off Broadway, or more likely Off Off Broadway. That has now happened with Brian Friel's ''Faith Healer,'' at the small nonprofit Vineyard Theater, on East 26th Street, where the play is being offered by a new set of professional dreamers.

description: b-Including a tax credit of $125,000 and a gain of $57,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Ransom for Heineken Is Said to Be $8 Million
description: Dutch newspapers said today that the kidnappers of Alfred H. Heineken had demanded a ransom of at least $8 million for him and his chauffeur.

title: Martial Law in Turkey Is Extended 4 Months
description: The military Government has extended martial law for four months, Turkish newspapers reported today.

title: INFANT IN TEXAS DIES AS A WIDE APPEAL FOR NEW LIVER FAILS
description: Fourteen-month-old Ashley Bailey died today, ending a fight for a liver transplant that was aided by President Reagan, Gov. Mark White of Texas and friends who raised more than $100,000.

title: INMATES ARE FREED WITHOUT ANY BAIL
description: New York City, which has been releasing prisoners from its overcrowded jails by allowing them to pay 10 percent of their bail, began freeing them last night on their own recognizance without paying any bail.

title: Wilson Apologizes
description: Willie Wilson , the 1982 batting champion of the American League, apologized to the people of Kansas City yesterday for his involvement with cocaine. He appeared at a news conference with Ewing Kauffman , the owner of the team, and said: ''I'm sorry for my family, the Royals, my teammates and fans, and especially the young fans.

This resulted in an after-tax charge of $1,612,000, or 23 cents a share. c-The combined result of the cheese plant sale and the provision for plant closings is reflected as a net charge of $25,000.

title: Odd Men Out
description: A mathematician who believes our future lies not in our stars, nor in ourselves, but in numbers argues that the Democrats can win the Presidency next year by nominating a man named Buck, Norman or Pete.

title: LEBANESE ADJOURN PARLEY IN GENEVA
description: Representatives of Lebanon's warring factions adjourned today after a week of meetings that produced proposals for legal, political and electoral changes.

title: DIVIDENDS CONTINUED BY KODAK
description: The Eastman Kodak Company, which announced earlier this week that third-quarter earnings plunged 44.4 percent, yesterday declared an extra dividend of 55 cents a share - the same as last year - and a wage dividend estimated at $255 million for 92,000 company employees in the United States. The company has paid wage dividends every year since 1912, with the exception of 1933.

title: Columbia Wins And Sets Mark
description: Columbia, ranked third in the nation, raised its soccer record to 14-0-0 today by defeating Cornell, 1-0, on a goal by Solomon Gelb 51 minutes into the game. Cornell has a 7-3-4 record.

title: K-TEL INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Protesters Disrupt Columbia Lecture
description: About 30 protesters last night attempted to disrupt a lecture at Columbia University by Eden Pastora Gomez, a former official of the Sandinista government in Nicaragua who has broken with the movement.

title: BANISTER CONTINENTAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: TECHNOSEXISM
description: Millions of mechanical objects are now speaking English through the new technology of speech synthesis - computers, clocks, elevators, automobiles, vending machines and even bathroom scales. Although the engineers and managers who build these devices mean to satisfy consumer needs, and to realize a profit, they are unwittingly helping to perpetuate cultural stereotypes. These talking machines are associating females with low- level service jobs, while associating males with tasks that are broader in range and higher in status.

title: 2 JUDGES BAR FUELING OF COAST NUCLEAR PLANT
description: Two Federal appellate judges today granted a stay of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission's decision this week to allow the Pacific Gas and Electric Company to load fuel at its Diablo Canyon nuclear reactor in California.

title: 2 Time Bombs in Jordan
description: Jordanian security authorities in Amman have defused another time bomb, the second in 24 hours. The Interior Ministry said today that a suitcase packed with 25 pounds of explosives was spotted in a vacant lot near the Chinese Embassy. On Wednesday authorities defused a 12.5-pound bomb near the Saudi Arabian Airlines office in Amman.

title: 'Witcher' Helps to Find Bodies of Kansas Couple
description: A ''witcher'' using divining rods helped to find the bodies of two people who were slain four years ago, and two computer programmers were arrested in the slayings.

title: MONEY TALKS: IT SAYS GOODBYE
description: Not long ago, a friend of mine remarked that it was bad enough when dentists decided they were entitled to live as well as doctors, but now veterinarians expect to live as well as dentists. He went on to say that because his dog wasn't on Blue Cross, he and his wife faced the choice of repairing the animal's stomach or permitting their oldest son to finish Colgate.

title: ISLANDERS WIN 7TH IN ROW
description: The result - a seventh straight victory - but nothing else pleased Coach Al Arbour tonight as the Islanders scored a 6-5 decision over the Penguins at the Civic Arena.

description: Everyone with an interest in contemporary music owes a debt of gratitude to Lukas Foss. As the music director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic Symphony Orchestra, Mr. Foss has devoted considerable time and energy to the propagation of the new. Their ''Meet the Moderns'' series is one of the most continually interesting showcases in town.

The bridegroom is the son of Pauline J. Faux of Atlanta and Lewis E. Faux Jr. of Anderson, S.C. The Rev. Lamar Kincaid performed the ceremony at the First Congregational Church.

title: A TV 'FIRST' REMEMBERED
description: ON Friday, an important Long Island anniversary will pass with very little fanfare. In fact, probably no one will celebrate it. Yet on that date 10 years ago, something happened in Central Islip that marked the beginning of a new era for the Long Island media. At 8:30 that Sunday morning, a master control operator pushed a button and brought on a film showing the flag and playing ''The Star-Spangled Banner,'' putting the Island's first and only commercial television station on the air.

title: NOT QUITE PAKISTAN
description: SHAME

title: THE PAUSE BETWEEN SEASONS
description: NOW is the the time of year when the seasons hang in the balance, the weather almost motionless between summer's calm and the first tingle in the air heralding winter. The time has come to go down to the shore and, for the brief time it lasts, experience the shifting scene first hand.

title: Smokers Urged to Abstain
description: Margaret M. Heckler, the Secretary of Health and Human Services, is urging Americans who smoke to quit their habit, saying it would ''add immeasurably to the nation's health.'' Mrs. Heckler made the plea in her role as honorary chairman of the ''great American smokeout of 1983,'' which will begin at midnight Wednesday and lasts until midnight Thursday. The goal of the campaign is to get at least one of every five of the nation's 55 million smokers to abstain for 24 hours.

description: It was Oct. 15, the day of Byram Hills's most important game. Although the school was ranked first in Westchester County, it was facing second-ranked Westlake, which was on a 14-game winning streak and had beaten the Bobcats soundly the season before.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: After the grand marshal of New York's St. Patrick's Day parade said the event would demonstrate support for the Irish Republican Army, former Gov. Hugh L. Carey was among several public figures who declined to join the paraders last March. Mr. Carey said he would try instead to organize a movement of Americans to seek a peaceful solution to the strife in Northern Ireland. ''This won't be a dead story the day after the parade,'' he said of the dissent surrounding the march.

title: MONEY AND ACHIEVEMENT: A MIXED BAG
description: IN La Due, Mo., a high income suburb of St. Louis with a population of nearly 9,400, the school treasury budgets $4,600 for each student in its district and pays the average teacher $30,000 a year. In Harvey, Ill., just south of Chicago in a low-income area with a population of nearly 36,000, the West Harvey-Dixmore School District spends roughly $2,300 per student and pays its teachers an average of $19,000 a year. In La Due, student scores on national standardized tests are well above the national norms. In Harvey, students are categorized as low achievers.

title: JAZZ: MURRAY AND BAND
description: The 12-man David Murray Big Band, which is appearing for the next five Mondays at Sweet Basil, is designed to work like the early territory bands. Every member is a potential soloist, and at a cue from Butch Morris, the conductor, the trumpets or low brasses or reeds will shout out a riff until the whole room is rocking.

title: UNDER THE WIRE
description: Although the city put a halt to the construction of so-called ''sliver'' projects earlier this year, the tall, narrow apartment buildings towering over others on their blocks will continue to rise throughout midtown as developers who had started work before the ban was adopted finish their projects.

title: A CHIEF ADEPT AT CREAM SAUCES

With the opening of the Toll Gate Hill Inn last July, all that has changed. The barn-red clapboard house, dating back to 1745, has both agreeable dining capabilities and six guest rooms upstairs.

title: FISH VENTURE BUOYS GREENPORT
description: AN international fishing venture is approaching the docks of Greenport, and village officials think it offers the best promise yet of taking the little North Fork village back to its glory days, when commercial fishing was the basis of a prosperous economy.

title: Dr. Lucy W. Loomis Wed in Hartford

title: Intricate Defensive Strategies Paying Off for Young Steelers

But that's ''stupid,'' according to Jack Lambert, the 10-year linebacker, who offered his opinion after a practice last week. ''It's like comparing Muhammad Ali and Joe Louis, or O. J. Simpson and Jim Brown. They're all great athletes.''

title: BRITISH PLANNING ITS OWN 'RAPID STRIKE' FORCE
description: Military officials say Britain is planning to organize an intervention force prepared for deployment anywhere in the world.

title: SUPERMARKET MYSTERIES
description: FOR just one day, I would like to be the woman behind the woman in the supermarket aisle who puts the head of lettuce on the shelf with the detergents and leaves the package of frozen fish next to a box of saltines. I wonder what must be going through her head when she exchanges packaged dried soup for a pound of margarine. Or leaves frozen fried chicken between canned pineapple chunks and mandarin oranges.

He continues to make single and multiple images of personalities and subjects that the public, for the most part, takes for granted.

The orientation of these small-scale paintings of Maine, Nantucket and New York State is visual, the technique realistic.

For example, would you recognize the voice piped in to the ladies' room as Winston Churchill's? (Kate Smith belts ''God Bless America'' in the men's.)

title: A REDISCOVERY OF ISLANDS

You crossed the cove from the landing on the opposite side to reach this hotel, in a small boat with an open cabin. From the boat the angle of the cable car track looked almost vertical and the highest bungalow inaccessible without the cable car.

LaGuardia High School of Music and the Arts, Amsterdam Avenue and 65th Street. The school, which can ac- commodate 2,600 students in grades 9 through 12, was created with the merger of the High School of Music and Art and the High School of the Performing Arts.

title: Palsy Victim's Husband Loses Bid on Mental Test
description: The estranged husband of a cerebral palsy victim who wants to starve to death because her disability makes her almost completely dependent on others for nearly all her bodily functions has lost a bid to have her examined by a psychiatrist who lectures for the Right to Life League.

title: Miss Moeckel Is Bride Of Ray William Urwin

And with the increase in the state sales and income taxes, it has finally begun to put up the money to improve the quality of public education, and with it the state's position against wealthier states' education statistics.

title: AMERICANS ON GRENADA: MILITARY BUT NOT MARTIAL
description: From the sky it looks like a score of other Caribbean islands: a slender lily pad in the azure sea, surrounded by a ribbon of beach, with orange rooftops, a church, a soccer field and the all but inevitable landing strip carved out of the lush green hills.

title: ATLANTA'S NEW MUSEUM HAS SPACES TO FILL
description: As everyone who cares about such things must know by now, the new High Museum building in Atlanta is the hottest thing of its kind in the museum world since the Guggenheim Museum opened on Fifth Avenue close on 25 years ago. Richard Meier's building has star quality. Not only does it look good, and feel good, but it delivers.

description: THE GLORIOUS FLIGHT Across the Channel with Louis Bleriot, July 25, 1909. Written and illustrated by Alice and Martin Provensen. 39pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: WARD RECALLS 'SPECIAL TESTS' OF HIS EARLY CAREER
description: Benjamin Ward, who was named Police Commissioner last week by Mayor Koch, recalled in an interview the ''special tests'' to which he was put as the first black officer in a Brooklyn precinct more than three decades ago.

title: MAKING MORE BY TAKING LESS PAY
description: When it comes to collecting your paycheck, taking less today can mean more tomorrow. Increasing numbers of workers are joining salary reduction plans, voluntarily taking pay cuts so they can stash the money in tax-sheltered retirement accounts sponsored by their companies. Salary reduction plans - also known as CODA's (for cash-or- deferred arrangements) or 401K plans (for the section of the Tax Code under which they qualify) - are a variation on traditional company thrift plans in which worker contributions are deposited in a company-sponsored investment account. But with conventional plans, workers invest after-tax dollars, while with salary reduction plans they invest pretax money. Under salary reduction plans, workers agree to reduce part of their pay, which their company then invests in, say, a stock or bond fund. There is no current income tax due on the deferred pay, and contributions to the investment account accumulate tax-free until the money is withdrawn when the workers quit or retire. Then they collect their deferred pay, plus accumulated interest, and pay income tax figured at favorable rates. ''They're really pretty wonderful, and are a financially efficient way for employees to invest,'' said Harold Dankner, a partner in the Washington office of the accounting firm Coopers & Lybrand. In theory, a salary reduction plan is simple. Say a 35-year-old executive earning $50,000 a year decides to defer $2,500 - 5 percent of his salary - and have it contributed to the tax-sheltered savings plan. The pay shown on his W2 form would drop to $47,500 and the executive would save $885 in Federal income tax, according to the accounting firm Peat, Marwick Mitchell & Co.

title: TEAM TITLE GOES TO KENNEDY
description: Andy McConnell of Bronx Science overtook two competitors in the final 600 yards and won the Public Schools Athletic League cross-country title yesterday in Van Cortlandt Park.

title: John Snodgrass, Ellen Lee Carlson Wed in Bermuda
description: Ellen Lee Carlson, daughter of Eric Carlson of New York and Judith Flynn of Plandome, L.I., was married in Warwick, Bermuda, yesterday to John D'Arcy Snodgrass, son of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Snodgrass of Plandome Heights, L.I. The Rev. Frederick J. Marshall of the Presbyterian Church of Scotland performed the ceremony at Christ Church.

description: Until last year, Whittier House, the 19th century mansion and adjoining town house at 172 and 174 Grand Street in Jersey City, was the home of the Jersey City Boys Club until last year. Then a fire forced the club out.

Copley of Roxbury, Conn., New York and Key West, Fla., and Doris Starrels of Venice, Calif. The Rev. Charles Bevan performed the ceremony at St. John's Episcopal Church in Salisbury, Conn.

title: DECISION TIME AT GREYHOUND
description: Greyhound Lines has had nobody to leave the driving to since Nov. 2, but company officials said last week that would change soon whether or not striking workers returned. Representatives of the 12,000 strikers, 7,500 of them drivers, vowed not to accept the company's latest offer, even though Greyhound announced plans to begin hiring replacements from among the 45,000 people who have applied for their jobs.

title: ITALY GETS TOUGH WITH THE MAFIA
description: Paul Hofmann, a former New York Times correspondent, is the author of ''O Vatican!,'' to be published next month by Congdon & Weed. By Paul Hofmann MERTA - A WORD PROMInent in the idiom of Sicily - is usually translated as ''conspiracy of silence.'' It is omert a that has always decreed that whenever a Mafia killing occurs, even in a crowded marketplace, anyone who happens to have witnessed it, including the dead man's widow and children, will stonily say: ''I didn't see anything. I heard shots and ducked into a doorway.''

title: CALIFORNIA: MAKING ADDED TAXES COUNT
description: LOS ANGELES A WIDE-RANGING program of educational reform is being put into effect in California this fall that school officials say could become a model for other states that want to reverse a decline in student achievement. Among other things, the program, to be financed from recently augmented tax revenues, tightens requirements for high school graduation, raises teacher salaries, establishes a merit-pay bonus for teachers, and makes it easier for schools both to discipline problem students and discharge incompetent teachers.

title: RIGHTS AMENDMENT STRESSED AS MAJOR 1984 ELECTION ISSUE
description: Feminist leaders have promised to wage political war on those in Congress who oppose passage of the proposed Federal equal rights amendment and to make the measure a major issue for the 1984 elections.

title: PRESERVING THAT SINGLE-FAMILY TOUCH

title: A BAD IDEA THAT COULD SPREAD
description: IT is hard to blame T. Boone Pickens Jr. for trying to get the maximum value from his investment in Gulf Oil. The company's rich oil and gas reserves, which on their own could be highly profitable, are buried in a corporate body along with many low-value, even worthless, parts. But if the Pickens effort to split up Gulf succeeds, it will be hard for other major oil companies to escape the same fate. What we will be left with is an array smaller oil companies, each with much less capital to spend on such vital activities as exploration for new oil and gas. In short, our dependence on foreign oil could increase.

title: MORE GOOD NEWS ABOUT INFLATION
description: ''There just isn't a lot of inflation out there,'' said the economist Donald Ratajczak of Georgia State, reacting to the latest producer price numbers. The index, which measures price increases on finished manufactured goods, rose only three-tenths of one percent in October, or a 3.6 percent annual rate. Inflation's continued moderate pace undoubtedly surprised many economists - especially those who expected it to heat up in the aftermath of this summer's drought. Meanwhile, the economy showed little sign of slowing, as consumers kept buying and borrowing. Retail sales rose 1.1 percent in October and consumer installment credit expanded at an annual rate of 7.9 percent. That, plus a welcome drop in interest rates, sent the stock market soaring late in the week. The Dow Jones industrial average gained almost 32 points to close the week at 1,250.20. And the Government's 30-year bond closed with a yield of 11.66 percent. Because of the Veterans' Day holiday, the Federal Reserve will not release the latest money supply figures until Monday.

That happened Friday night in Jackson, Ky., where Schlichter's team, Ohio University-Chillicothe, defeated Sue Bennett Community College, 103- 99, in the opening round of the Lee's Junior College tipoff tournament.

He had practiced the moves many times while preparing to take the test for a black belt in tae kwon do , a Korean art of self-defense. But the third time, he slipped. A tiny misstep, it was nonetheless significant. It showed that his balance and coordination were deteriorating.

But since World War II, the centers of composition have moved elsewhere and Vienna has become instead an active center of the ''authenticity'' movement, restoring the glories and subtleties of ages past.

title: WHAT DO WE REMEMBER?

And on First Avenue, the United Nations building was drenched in rain and shrouded in fog. What do we remember: the dread of war or hope of peace?

title: ALONG BRUSSELS' RESTAURANT ROW
description: Rue des Bouchers is more than a street of small restaurants in the center of old Brussels. It is the gateway to a neighborhood of food that takes in four narrow, cobbled streets in the center of the Belgian city, two short blocks north of the Grand'Place. Along Rue des Bouchers and the three tiny streets that branch off it - Petite Rue des Bouchers, Rue de la Fourche Petite and Rue Gretry - there are more than 70 restaurants, one next to the other, on the street levels of the old step-roofed stone, brick and timber buildings in what is one of the oldest sections of historical central Brussels.

It was not a word which was foreign or unfamiliar to her, and as she got older and her understanding grew, so did our explanations and stories grow.''

When he's home, Marvelous Marvin Hagler trains in the two-story brick building on Centre Street in the Massachusetts shoe- manufacturing town that Rocky Marciano put on the map. And if Rocky Marciano had not been killed in a plane crash in 1969, the heavyweight champion, who would be 60 years old now, might be involved with the undisputed world middleweight champion who is co- managed by two of Marciano's boyhood friends.

title: BROOK EXPLORES OPERA AS THEATER

Mr. Brook will present his interpretation of Georges Bizet's ''Carmen,'' entitled ''La Tragedie de Carmen,'' at the Vivian Beaumont with a carefully trained company of singer-actors that includes no fewer than five alternating principal casts.

title: LONDON SWEARS IN A WOMAN AS CITY'S 656TH LORD MAYOR
description: -Dame Mary Donaldson today became the first woman to serve as Lord Mayor of London since the post was created in 1192.

title: Expensive Louisiana Race
description: The recent Governor's race was the most expensive in Louisiana history and left Gov.-elect Edwin Edwards's campaign committee owing $4.4 million, according to campaign reports. Mr. Edwards spent $12.6 million in the campaign in which he defeated Gov. Dave Treen, who spent $6.4 million. Governor Treen was the previous high campaign spender with $5.8 million in his bid for the post in 1979.

title: Suffern Takes Rockland Title
description: On a cold and windy afternoon, Suffern dethroned North Rockland as champions of the Rockland County Conference A by defeating the host Red Raiders, 8-6, yesterday. North Rockland, the county champions the last two years, had been ranked second in the state and had won 25 consecutive games before last week's loss to Ramapo.

title: ANTI-SANDINISTA HOSPITAL: MORALE SEEMS HIGH
description: On a small farm in the Honduran countryside, 90 Nicaraguan men and boys are being treated for wounds suffered in the guerrilla war against the Sandinista Government.

title: WHAT MAKES AUDIENCES FOND OF 'RITA'?
description: For a people who pride themselves on a populist kind of anti-intellectualism and who mistrust any apparent signs of education, Americans are awfully eager to pay good money to see commonplace movies that appear to exalt teachers and any institutionalized learning process. It's as if they were saying that they admire educations, even though they wouldn't want their sisters to go out with one.

title: CRAMMING BY COMPUTER: NEW APPROACH TO SAT'S
description: THE Scholastic Aptitude Tests will be given next on Dec. 3 across the nation, and Luis Altmont of New York City, like thousands of other high school seniors, is getting ready. Each afternoon he gathers up his study materials and sits down for an hour of practice.

title: NEW VESSELS, NEW VOYAGES
description: The competition among cruise lines trying to fill the more than 7,400 berths being added this season alone (3,600 in 1983, 3,872 in 1984) is bound to make this winter an exciting one. In addition to the attraction of sailing aboard new ships, the debut of which inevitably sets off an initial flurry of bookings, many lines are offering inducements such as fare discounts, free air fare and free land packages. (See Practical Traveler, page 3, for details.)

title: Clippers Are Showing Signs of Revival
description: In October 1981, the face of Donald T. Sterling smiled down from huge billboards that lined the streets of San Diego and from advertisments on the backs of buses. The ads read: ''My Promise: I will make you proud of the Clippers.''

title: CORN DOLLIES

title: 10 HOSPITALS IN NEW YORK TO TRY TO SHORTEN SURGERY-PATIENT STAY
description: Ten New York hospitals are preparing an experimental program to shorten the hospital stays of some surgical patients and to shift more surgery from hospital operating rooms to clinics and outpatient surgery centers. The program, which is expected to begin next year, is intended to reduce costs. It is also intended to cut the long waits for elective surgery at many of the city's teaching hospitals. Health officials said the program would save public health funds because about 90 percent of all surgery was financed by the public Medicaid program for the poor, by the Medicare program for the elderly and by employee health benefit programs and private insurers, such as Blue Cross and Blue Shield of Greater New York. According to Steven Sieverts, head of the program and a Blue Cross Blue Shield vice president, surgeons in participating hospitals will ask ''carefully selected patients'' to volunteer to be discharged earlier than usual or have their surgery done without hospitalization. He estimated that ''thousands'' of patients would agree to take part by the end of the first year. The procedures will include such cases as hernia repairs, removal of gall bladders and the setting of broken bones. Dr. Walter Wichern, head of surgery at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, which is participating in the program, said shorter hospitalization and outpatient surgery were more feasible now because of improved surgical techniques, more use of localized anesthesia and a new surgical attitude that emphasizes swift ambulatory recovery.

Martinelli of Yonkers last week, as he reflected on his successful bid for a fifth term in office. ''I have great faith in the people. of Yonkers. Go level with them and even if what you're saying is unpopular, they'll respect you.''

title: ...AND AT PREPARATORY SCHOOL
description: TO 15-year-old Jamie, being enrolled in a college- preparatory school in Connecticut ''is my one big chance to do something with my life.'' Margaret, who is 16, said she ''jumped at the chance'' to attend a private girl's school in Massachusetts. Jamie and Margaret are foster children whose expenses for tuition, room and board are being shared by the schools they attend and the states they are from.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a transmission error, the name of Edward Tew was misspelled in an article last week about horse farms in Brookhaven Town.

title: WMCA IS A RADIO STATION ATTUNED TO MAKING A DIFFERENCE
description: Tomorrow morning, people who listen to WMCA will hear this voice, recorded in the upstate New York women's prison known as the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility: ''There are a lot of strangers in here. That's one thing I had to learn when I came in. I was sure everyone knew one another except me. I was the one outsider. And, of course, we're all strangers in here.''

title: ACCORDION: PAULINE OLIVEROS
description: The composer Pauline Oliveros offered some distinctive dinner music late Tuesday night at the Ear Inn, a restaurant and performance space in lower Manhattan. Miss Oliveros greeted the audience warmly, then announced that she was going to shut her eyes and ''engage in a process called emptiness, first listening to what I am going to play and then proceeding to play it.''

description: The once-pristine clarity of Lake Tahoe has deteriorated to its worst level since studies began on the water's transparency in 1959, a researcher says.

description: The State Department of Agriculture and Markets announced this week that 350 upstate farmers and three milk cooperatives had been paid a total of $4.1 million, almost all the money they were owed as a result of a default earlier this year by the Glen and Mohawk Milk Association of Fultonville.

description: Ten Russian college students scheduled to take classes at the State University at Albany this fall have not left Moscow, and there is now doubt whether the student exchange will be completed, university officials say.

Belli, son of Mr. and Mrs. John P. Belli of Lawrenceville, N.J. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Joseph J. Faraone, assisted by the bridegroom's cousin, the Rev. John Meehan.

description: Argentina's President-elect Raul Alfonsin last week provided an advance look at his style of governance, appointing eight close colleagues from his not-so Radical Party to Cabinet positions. They will replace the military Government on Dec. 10.

title: DIPLOMATICALLY, ASIA IS A LUXURY TRIP
description: President Reagan put aside day-to-day crises last week to focus on some of the strengths of American foreign policy. His trip to Japan and South Korea drew attention to the close ties not only with those two allies but with most of the countries in the Far East.

title: THE CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: Unusual Opportunities In Benefit Sales Preholiday gift and craft shows, with part of the proceeds going to an educational or religious institution or financing more supplies for cottage- industry workers, offer possibilities for unusual selections, handmade wares or discounted designer merchandise.

title: QUAKER SCHOOLS: STRONG MORAL MINORITY
description: THERE was complete silence in the room, except for the slight rustle of denim when one of the 22 first- graders would shift position. Silence sat upon the entire school like a mist for a full five minutes, then teachers broke into the quietness with gentle, friendly words. The day had begun at Moses Brown School.

title: GREYHOUND IS PLANNING BUS SERVICE THIS WEEK
description: Greyhound Lines Inc. and its striking employees face a possible confrontation this week as the company tries to get its drivers and other workers back on the job and attempts to resume bus operations that were stopped by the walkout 11 days ago.

title: AUTHENTIC MARYLAND SHORE FARE
description: The Home Entertaining section was interesting, but contained certain jarring notes as pertain to authentic Eastern Shore fare (''Sailor's Treasure,'' by Elizabeth Hawes, Oct. 23). Whisky sours with a bourbon base may be acceptable among the recently arrived gentry in Talbot County, but never among native Marylanders.

title: FITNESS TIPS OFFERED
description: SOMERVILLE A GYNECOLOGIST here believes there is more to a woman's annual physical than a Papp smear and a breast examination.

title: GROUPS NOW TEACHING STUDENTS HOW TO LEAD
description: WHEN Wendy Allyn was a high school senior, she was the only student sitting on the California State Board of Education. Before she graduated, she helped write a bill, which was signed into law by Gov. George Deukmejian in early October, that granted full voting privileges to future school board members who are students. Now a freshman at Harvard, Miss Allyn credits much of her ability to help write that bill to her training at the National Leadership Institute.

title: CO-OPS GET GOOD NEWS AND ADVICE
description: PARTICIPANTS in a conference on the operation of cooperative apartments were told last weekend that the opening of a national secondary market for co-op loans should make it easier in the months ahead to buy co-op apartments.

title: Return to the Ring
description: Eddie Mustafa Muhammad , a former light-heavyweight champion, boxed a five-round exhibition against William Josera of Bloomington, Ill, Friday night in Milwaukee. ''I felt at home,'' Muhammad said.

title: ST. JOHN'S DEFEATS BROOKLYN BY 49-6
description: Dennis Bligen scored three touchdowns as St. John's routed Brooklyn College, 49-6, yesterday at Redmen Stadium to remain in contention for a bid to the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division III playoffs.

description: AT the very root at the question in hand lies the problem of defining justice. This can be a very vexing point if we have as our field of investigation things present or things to come. But when it is a matter of things past, say for instance 100 years of armed combat, the problem disappears; does not the aphoristic poet sum it up for us in his couplet:

description: Annette Insdorf, an associate professor at Columbia and Yale, is the author of ''Indelible Shadows: Film and the Holocaust.''

description: -pianist Richard Nanes could write a manual on how to succeed in business by really trying to get out of it.

description: As she nears the middle of her four- year term as Brooklyn's District Attorney, Elizabeth Holtzman says that changes she has made in her office have improved the ''quality of prosecution'' in the city's most populous borough.

description: John Sweeney was sentenced Thursday to the maximum term of six and a half years in prison for strangling the actress Dominique Dunne.

title: MCENROE TO MEET CONNORS IN FINAL
description: John McEnroe and Jimmy Connors won in straight sets today and gained the final of the $315,000 Benson and Hedges Grand Prix tennis tournament. They met in the final last year, and Connors won.

title: In his letter, Mr. Markiewicz asserted that the Holocaust was not solely a Jewish catastrophe. He based this on the number of non-Jews who were Holocaust victims, and on the plans that called for the eradication of all ''racially undesirable aliens,'' which he assumed to include non- Jews.
description: First, of all ethnic groups that suffered during the Holocaust, none felt the Nazis' prolonged persecution and deliberate harassment as the Jews did. No other group experienced a parallel to the Gestapo-sponsored Kristalnacht, when only Jewish shops were vandalized, only Jewish houses of worship were torched and only Jews were rounded up and beaten.

title: AUBURN DEFEATS GEORGIA
description: Auburn, which only three years ago was on probation and not winning often, played its way into the Sugar Bowl by beating previously undefeated Georgia, 13-7, before a crowd of 82,122 today in Sanford Stadium.

description: Lesley Valdes writes frequently about music.

Roundtree, president and an owner of All-Stainless Inc., a steel products distributor in Hingham, Mass., were married yesterday. Justice of the Peace Rona Hollingshead of Hull, Mass., performed the ceremony at Lanatana's in Randolph, Mass.

A coalition of New York City and suburban residents offset upstate resistance and passed his billion-dollar bond issue to rebuild highways and bridges by a surprisingly cushy margin of 6 percent.

All such ideas deserve exploration in the interest of improving the quality of teaching in our public schools.

description: Dr. Kenneth O. Dike, the president of Anambra State University in Enugu, Nigeria, died in a hospital there on Oct. 26, it became known Friday. He was 65 years old.

description: George Balanchine died on April 30, just four days after the New York City Ballet began its season at the New York State Theater last spring. The company he co-founded and guided - and for which he choreographed a treasure house of Neo-Classic ballets - now faces its first opening at Lincoln Center, on Tuesday, without him.

title: Miss Castle Plans January Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Harmon Castle of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Forest Castle, to James Kennedy Mason, son of the late Harold Mason and the late Jean Kennedy Mason, both of New York. A January wedding is planned in Darien.

title: OPERA LESSON
description: SOME 3,000 schoolchildren in Fairfield County will go to the opera this week to see Mozart's ''Impresario'' presented by Opera New England.

title: MEHATA HAS A MANDATE NOW TO CHANGE THE PHILHARMONIC
description: The New York Philharmonic's recent decision to extend Zubin Mehta's contract as music director was not surprising, given the alternatives. If you sit down and draw up a list of potentially available candidates, you will see that this is not an era of super conductors. For all his shortcomings, fully enumerated in these pages over the last few seasons, Mr. Mehta actually is in the upper crust of a rather small loaf. Where are the titans who would have replaced him?

title: ACCUSER REFUSES TO LOOK AT FEMINIST AND TESTIFY
description: Ginny Foat's former husband refused today to look her in the eye and repeat his charge that she helped kill a man 18 years ago.

title: States Rated on Environment
description: Minnesota is making the best effort to protect the environment for its citizens, and Alabama the worst, a national conservation group says.

title: POSTERITY WEIGHS KURT WEILL'S STATURE
description: Kurt Weill once said that he didn't ''give a damn about posterity.'' Whether he meant that or not, posterity cares about him. Yet while its judgments may seem absolute, they are not. They shift with fashion - as in the down-and-up reputation of Mozart, for instance, from the 19th century to now. And they can be influenced by active champions of a given artist's work: disciples and enthusiasts who acquaint the public with an artist's work and ultimately - if the public's opinion sustains that of the enthusiasts - tip posterity toward a favorable judgment.

title: WASHINGTON RALLY DRAWS THOUSANDS
description: Thousands of people gathered here today near the White House and the State Department to protest President Reagan's policies in Central America and the Caribbean.

title: PAPA'S FLYING MACHINES
description: THE GLORIOUS FLIGHT Across the Channel with Louis Bleriot, July 25, 1909. Written and illustrated by Alice and Martin Provensen. 39pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: 24 (AT LEAST) LITTLE PIGS
description: THEY may be bacon to the butcher, pork bellies to the trader, villains to George Orwell, but season after season pigs, to lots of writers, illustrators and publishers of children's books, are you and me, mom and pop and the kids next door. We have at hand 11 picture books featuring pigs, and although they're all for the very young, some are quite sophisticated and delightful, others plain and engaging, some plumped up with false imagination, some pointless, and one an odd item with nothing but point.

title: KILLER IN THE CLASSROOM
description: Every day some three million children are exposed in their schools to possibly dangerous amounts of asbestos. The deadly fibers flake from the ceiling, or crumble from insulation and piping. They cause no disease as they lodge in children's lungs. But in 20 to 30 years, the fibers will produce asbestosis, lung cancer and mesiothelioma.

title: BREACH OF SECURITY
description: Sometimes Government secrets aren't leaked, but simply overflow. State Department officials last week found themselves trying to explain how a gaggle of classified documents had been left in an unlocked file cabinet that was erroneously sent to a maximum security prison in Lorton, Va., for refurbishing.

description: Penn State overcame an outstanding performance by Allen Pinkett, Notre Dame's sophomore tailback, and scored a touchdown with 19 seconds left today to win, 34-30, in Beaver Stadium.

title: Madison and Lane Gain B-Division Title Game
description: Madison and Franklin K. Lane won semifinal games yesterday and will meet next Saturday for the B-division championship of the Public Schools Athletic League. Madison defeated Flushing, 22-6, and Lane scored a 14-6 victory over Sheepshead Bay.

title: CROSS-COUNTRY RULE ANGERS COACHES
description: During a meeting of the athletic policy committee this month, the executive director of the division of pupil personnel for the city's public schools said he was considering dropping a rule that prohibits athletes from competing on outside teams in their sports during their seasons.

title: CHANCELLOR'S POST IS FILLED AT N.Y.U.
description: Dr. John Brademas, president of New York University, has announced the appointment of Dr. L. Jay Oliva as chancellor and executive vice president of the university.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: MARTIN GUERRE AND THE PRINCETON SCHOLAR

description: Holocaust: Four Films Mastervision 105 minutes. $64.95

title: MIAMI WINS WITH KICK, 17-16
description: Jeff Davis's 19-yard field goal as time ran out gave Miami a 17- 16 victory tonight over Florida State.

title: INFANT HANDICAPS TEST THE MEANING OF MERCY
description: ''WE'RE

title: RESORTS INTERNATIONAL UPS THE ANTE
description: ON a cloudy and cold October day, as the wind snapped with a bitter ocean chill, a group of local dignitaries gathered on a barren lot to break ground for Resorts International's second big gamble here - a new 1,000-room casino hotel and mammoth exhibit hall. The scene was vintage Atlantic City - the crumbling remains of the Seaside Bar and Lounge loomed next door, a beauty queen with a Miss America crown waved at one and all and a Dixieland band belted out such tunes as ''I Want to Be Happy.'' It was a portrait of anxious optimism, a fitting backdrop for the company that won big on its first roll in Atlantic City and is now betting it all again.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Football
description: Jets vs. Buffalo Bills, at Shea Stadium, 1 P.M. The Jets won the previous game this season, 34-10, holding the Bills to 65 yards rushing and Joe Cribbs to 28 on 13 carries. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M. Radio - WCBS 880, 1 P.M.) Giants vs. Washington Redskins, at Giants Stadium, 4 P.M. The Redskins, defending Super Bowl champions, have lost only twice by a total of 2 points. (Television - Channel 2, 4 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 4 P.M.)

title: PRECISELY, WATSON
description: Time was, that if you wanted to call for the best time in the country - that supplied by the cesium beam atomic clock system at the Naval Observatory in Washington - you probably got a busy signal. Now, however, the observatory can handle 8,000 calls at once rather than a mere 10.

title: FOOD
description: GOOD NUTS TO CRACK

title: The Jews Of France
description: Paul Lewis's article ''The Jews of France'' (Oct. 9) was a valuable introduction to a key minority in French contemporary life. The writer's perspective, however, revealed a bias toward the Andre Wurmser position which questions how ''Jewish'' one should really be in France.

title: DEATH ROW ON TRIAL
description: Robert Sherrill, Southern correspondent for the Texas Observer, is the author of ''The Oil Follies of 1970-1980: How the Petroleum Industry Stole the Show (and Much More Besides),'' published this month.

title: Mark S. Ordan Is Wed To Kathryn Ann Sklar
description: Kathryn Ann Sklar, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Sklar of Hollis Hills, Queens, was married yesterday to Mark Samson Ordan, son of Doris K. Ordan of Brooklyn and the late Dr. Harry Ordan. The ceremony was performed by Rabbis Peter Weintraub and Judah Nadich at the Park Avenue Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: NICARAGUA HAS GRENADIAN JITTERS BUT TALKS GO ON
description: Ripples from the Caribbean washed Nicaragua's shores last week. In Managua, Victor Tirado Lopez, one of the nine members of the Sandinista junta, warned that ''foreign'' troops might come to the aid of United States-backed Nicaraguan rebels who, he said, had failed to seize a portion of the country's territory.

title: MONTANA DEBATES LAW ON HIRING VETERANS
description: Although state officials here say they believe in giving hiring preference to military veterans, the extent of that preference has prompted one of Montana's most acrimonious debates in recent years.

title: HOW A NUCLEAR HOLOCAUST WAS STAGED FOR TV
description: LOS ANGELES People are incinerated before our eyes, whole city blocks are reduced to rubble, vast farmlands are scorched, and a deadly shower of radiation falls from the sky. And that is only the beginning. The worst is yet to come in ''The Day After,'' ABC- TV's stark depiction of the aftermath of nuclear war, scheduled to be shown next Sunday evening at 8.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The Cincinnati Reds have acquired Bob Owchinko , a left-handed pitcher, on waivers from the Pittsburgh Pirates. Owchinko, who had a 10-6 record as a starter for Hawaii of the Pacific Coast League last season, has been with San Diego, Cleveland and Oakland during his six major league seasons. . . . The Philadelphia 76ers acquired Sam Williams , a forward, from Golden State for a second-round draft choice in 1984 and cash.

title:
ART;
WHAT THE ISLAND'S CERAMISTS ARE CREATING THESE DAYS
description: CONSIDERING the large number of major ceramics exhibitions in area galleries this year, Long Islanders could be forgiven for thinking that 1983 was the year of the pot. Actually, pottery per se has played a minor role in most of these shows, from the Heckscher Museum's Daniel Jacobs collection in the spring to ''The Raw Edge,'' a selection of contemporary ceramic art currently on view at the Hillwood Gallery of the C. W. Post Center.

title: Dave McKenna Concert
description: Dave McKenna will play a solo stride-piano concert tonight at 5 P.M. in the Church of the Heavenly Rest, Fifth Avenue and 90th Street. Tickets are $7; $5 for students and the elderly. The information number is 369-8040.

title: WOMEN'S HEALTH DISCUSSED AS A WORLDWIDE PROBLEM
description: Women from the United States and third- world countries gathered in New York this past week to plead for improvements in women's health around the globe.

title:
GARDENING;
WEATHER CAN BE A ROSE'S WORST ENEMY
description: WHILE fall is not the time of year when gardeners think about roses, a number of observations made while judging the All-America Rose Selections trial last season may be helpful to those who will soon be planning for the year ahead.

title: CHRISTIAN EDUCATORS RETURNING TO CHINA
description: MORE than 30 years ago the door to China closed to the West, and the network of Christian colleges and universities that had sprouted there since the 19th century were lost to their founders. But after China and the United States normalized diplomatic relations in January 1979 that door reopened, and although the role of Christian educators in China had changed dramatically, Christian churches in North America once again began contributing to Chinese education.

title: A WINTER VACATION FOR PARENTS: COLLEGE
description: FOUR years ago our second of three sons entered the freshman class of Williams College, in Williamstown, Mass. At that time my husband and I never dreamed we would also become students there.

title: 41 OR 21, OR INFINITE SIGHT
description: -ONE - what a seemingly uncomplex and limitless age. Does it only seem that way to me 20 years later, or is this a feeling I can recapture now at 41?

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: The Army was reported developing an electronic identification tag - a microchip with more information than the present metal dog tags contain. The chips would contain each soldier's medical, financial and personnel history.

title: IN SEARCH OF THE PERFECT MOTEL
description: There are, scattered throughout the land, ideal motels, motels that fulfill in every respect the function for which motels were invented: Carefree overnight stays involving a minimum of contact with humans other than your immediate party and imposing absolutely no obligation. The criteria for the ideal motel may vary slightly with your particular neurosis, but some are universal.

title: OVERBEY OF MONTCLAIR SETS PACE OF 42-0 ROUT
description: James Overbey ran for 109 yards and two touchdowns and led Montclair in a 42-0 drubbing of Bloomfield yesterday in Bloomfield.

title: Ruth Swenson Is Engaged

Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter T. Milano of Millington, N.J. The bride- to-be graduated from Wheaton College in Norton, Mass. Mr. Milano is an alumnus of Dartmouth College.

title: Rockets Win by 2
description: Ralph Sampson, who scored 23 points, hit two free throws with 1 second left tonight to give the Houston Rockets a 100-98 victory over the Dallas Mavericks.

title: FOOD FOR GATEWAY
description: Until recently, the nearest emergency source for such food items as milk, bread and orange juice for the 5,000 residents of Battery Park City's Gateway Plaza was not a neighborhood deli but the local dry cleaner: Gino Choi, proprietor of Gino's Battery Park Cleaners, stocked a few convenience food items to spare the residents the 10- block hike from the 92-acre Hudson River landfill development to the nearest food store in Tribeca.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
A GOOD IDEA, BUT LET MANAGEMENT DO IT
description: THERE is a subtle irony about the

title: JAZZ: JACK WILSON, PIANIST
description: Jack Wilson has spent the last 20 years in California playing piano in a wide range of jazz situations - in studios, in clubs, on television, in groups of various sizes, as a soloist and as an accompanist to singers. Last spring he moved to New York and started establishing himself in its jazz community.
