description: THREE years ago, when Dale

title: City Reproved
description: To the Editor:

title: Holland by Bike
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed the article on the windmills at Kinderdijk in ''Dutch Classics'' (Travel, Aug. 28) but would like to point out an impor

title: SALVADOR SUSPECT IS DEFENDED
description: The State Department said today that a Salvadoran student arrested for the murder of an American military adviser ''was not involved in the crime and his confession was obtained under duress.''

title: GRENADIANS' TOLL PUTS BY U.S. AT 21
description: American officials here said today that a total of 21 Grenadians had been killed in the United States-led invasion of this Caribbean island. But they left open the possibility that the toll might be higher because some of 42 unidentified bodies now presumed to be those of Cubans might actually be Grenadians.

title: JUDGE SUES TO BLOCK PANEL'S INVESTIGATION OF HIM
description: A series of courtroom disputes between Judge Elliott Wilk of Civil Court in Manhattan and a lawyer who often represented landlords has led to an investigation by a state agency into charges that the judge was biased and ''swayed by partisan interests'' in rulings against the landlords.

title: AFTER GRENADA, COULD THERE BE A NEXT TIME AND PLACE?
description: QUESTION. After Grenada will it be easier for a President to use force?

title: FIGHTING THE ODDS IN LONDON
description: At 10:05 P.M. on a Monday, 20 minutes after checking in at our hotel to begin a week's stay in London, my wife and I presented ourselves at the closest casino. Our haste was prompted by the requirement that 48 hours must elapse between one's signing up and one's ''gaming.'' Had we waited until the following morning to register, we could not have begun throwing away our pounds until Thursday. So by 10:08 P.M., for a fee of $22.50, I was a conditional member of the Chelsea Village Casino Club and entitled as well to admission into two affiliated clubs 48 hours after appearing on their premises. I could bring four guests.

title: VIOLENCE WEAKENS GUATEMALA REGIME
description: Politicians, church officials and foreign diplomats here say that a sharp rise in political violence, combined with a campaign against the Roman Catholic church, has begun to undermine the three-month-old Government of Brig. Gen. Oscar Mejia Victores.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: METUCHEN
description: -year-old

title: INTERVIEWS PLANNED IN SEARCH FOR HOME FOR BABY WITH AIDS
description: Social workers will soon start identifying prospective foster parents among hundreds of callers who offered to take in a homeless 14-month-old girl who has acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, state officials have reported.

title: J. W. Charleston Weds Miss Betts
description: Anne Louise Betts, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert B. Betts of New York, was married yesterday to James W. Charleston, son of Donald Charleston and Vivian Sanderson, both of Minnetonka, Minn. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony at the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church.

title: STATES WIDEN ROLE IN SCHOOL FINANCING
description: DESPITE a widespread taxpayer revolt that started in the late 1970's, the nation's states are playing an ever-increasing role in the financing of public elementary and secondary schools. And in the opinion of most experts in the field, the role of the states, which now provide about half of all school appropriations, will continue to increase through the rest of the century.

title: Claire Dennison, Luther T. Griffith To Marry Feb. 18
description: Claire Dennison, daughter of Elizabeth Dennison of Pecos, Tex., and the late John Paul Dennison, and Luther Theodore Griffith, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Francis Willard Griffith, plan to be married Feb. 18.

title: 4 PASTORAL CENTERS OFFER COUNSELING
description: ''THERE are times when people have to re-group and re-sort, times people want to pause and examine who they are, where they are going, how they've blocked themselves, what the strings are that tied them down,'' James Walkup said. ''That becomes a rich, reflective time and they reach out for something.''

title: DEVELOPER LEARNS PLOIGHT OF JOBLESS
description: -century school buildings has become an education in blue-collar unemployment for a New London developer.

title: NEW SESSION COULD BE TRICKY FOR GOV. KEAN
description: TRENTON UNLIKE a sports contest, where the final score clearly indicates the winner, an election lets both major parties claim a victory of sorts.

title: 'ZOOMAN': FORCEFUL, BUT FLAWED
description: NEW BRUNSWICK SOME playwrights continue to revise their works long after opening night. It could be illuminating if Charles Fuller, who won the 1982 Pulitzer Prize for ''A Soldier's Play,'' which begins performances next week at the Whole Theater in Montclair, took a new look at ''Zooman and the Sign,'' a provcative but structurally unsound 1980 play at the Crossroads Theater here.

title: Ex-Hobokenite's Letter Is Called Unfactual
description: Dear Ex-Hobokenite:

title:
WHAT'S HAPPENING IN THE FARM BELT;
A WITHERING DROUGHT TAKES ITS TOLL
description: DES MOINES, IOWA THE grain elevators dotting the

title: REAGAN, POWER AND THE WORLD
description: Leslie H. Gelb is The Times's national security correspondent, based in Washington. By Leslie H. Gelb WARE OF THE IMPACT OF MILITARY power yet lacking in diplomatic follow- through, excessive in rhetoric but usually cautious in action, skilled in domestic politics but inexperienced with the world, bold and erratic and often mired in personal and bureaucratic struggles - these have come to be the trademarks of the Reagan foreign policy. In two and one-half years, President Reagan has earned grudging respect for the United States in some quarters, fear and bewilderment in others. He has been long on developing and deploying American military power and on sidestepping catastrophic failures, but short on concrete diplomatic results.

title: FAKING IT AT 3 MILE ISLAND?
description: The crippled Three Mile Island nuclear plant continues to look like one of the world's best renewable sources of courtroom energy. A Federal grand jury last week indicted its former operator on charges of falsifying safety tests before the 1979 reactor accident.

title: AIRPORTS SERVING ATLANTIC CITY PLAN A $3.7 MILLION EXPANSION
description: Two airports serving this gambling resort plan $3.7 million worth of improvements next year that authorities say are needed to handle the substantial increase in air traffic created by the casino industry.

title: OUT OF POCKET
description: When high-ranking bureaucrats go to bat for the lower echelons, they risk getting beaned. So it was with Robert L. Gingles , who put himself in line for fiscal injury when, as paymaster for 15,000 State Department employees, he authorized what he considered to be overdue raises for 25 French nationals working in the Paris Embassy. Mr. Gingles said he did so only after his bosses had dragged their feet for 22 months and he thought ''we had exploited these people long enough.''

title: COMPUTER LITERACY IS NOT LITERACY
description: I WAS THE LAST person on my block to own a digital watch. In a typical liberal-arts way, I suppose, I resisted and resented everything about computers. Yet now I own a computer, have taught myself BASIC, am learning assembly-language programming, subscribe to computer magazines and find myself discussing baud rates more often than epistemology. I have, in short, become computer literate.

title: EARLY OBJECTS SHOW AN ESOTERIC TASTE
description: Thomas F. Flannery Jr., a Chicago neon-sign producer, was a born collector. He began by acquiring guns and clocks - mechanical things - in his teens. Then, at the age of 21, he made his first purchase in the field of medieval and Renaissance art, a collecting interest that absorbed him until his death at the age of 52 in 1980.

title: RECENT CASSETTES RANGE FROM 'HIGH NOON' TO HIGH C'S
description: Jazz in America ''Dizzy Gillespie's Dream Band''; ''Max Roach''; ''Gerry Mulligan''; ''Dizzy Gillespie.'' All produced by Gary Keys; di rected by Stanley Dorfman. Sony Beta 16-19 minutes each. $15.95 each.

title: Detainees Fingerprinted
description: The authorities in southern Florida, worried about the crime rate among Cuban refugees, have fingerprinted and photographed nearly 800 Cuban detainees at the Atlanta Federal Penitentiary. The Atlanta police have ordered copies of the prints and photographs of the inmates, many of whom can be released when sponsors are found.

title: ANDROPOV AFTER A YEAR: UNCERTAINTY AT THE HELM
description: In the last years of Leonid I. Brezhnev's life, portraits of Stalin began to appear in the windows of trucks, evidence of a dimly defined blue-collar longing for a tough boss who could check the corruption, sloth and indirection spreading through Soviet life.

title: KATHARINE GIBBS: MORE THAN TYPING
description: ''EVERYBODY looked sheepish,'' Patricia Dolson, a 1976 Boston College graduate, recalled of her first day of class at the Katharine Gibbs School in Norwalk in 1980.

title: RUSSIA: A PEOPLE WITHOUT HEROES --
description: David Shipler's article begins in an evocative manner, with the image of the sad, gray appearance of autumn in Moscow. For me, this image is the prelude to a larger theme: the poignant plight of older, developed nations caught in a spiritual autumn and uncertain whether it is merely a recurring season or the harbinger of inevitable decline.

title: IN REFORM IDEAS, A CERTAIN DEJA VU
description: THE CHASE after excellence alternates forever with the rush to the lifeboats to escape rising tides of disaster. The end is often near, but it happily never comes. Satellites light up the sky and, simultaneously, first- grade science classes. The schools put the nation at risk and the schools are better than ever.

title: REGIONAL ROLL-CALL ON SPENDING BILL
description: Here is how New York area legislators voted Saturday when the House of Representatives approved, 173 to 136, compromise emergency spending legislation for Cabinet departments and related agencies whose regular appropriations have not been enacted. A ''yes'' represents a vote to continue financing, and a ''no'' represents a vote against it; ''xxx'' means not voting.

title: POLITICAL CHANGE ON THE AIR AND IN THE WIND
description: In ruling that radio and television broadcasters may stage political debates between some candidates without giving equal time to all, deregulators on the Federal Communications Commission won one last week. So may have some contenders.

title: WHY N.A.S.L. IS IN TROUBLE
description: JUST four years ago, the North American Soccer League was hailed as a phenomenal success story, a sure thing for investors and fans who wanted to get plugged into the sport of the future.

title: HEROIC LIVES
description: THE GREAT ALEXANDER THE GREAT

title: International
description: A tour in the demilitarized zone between North Korea and South Korea and a visit to the American troops based there was on the schedule of President Reagan. ''You are on the the front lines of freedom, Mr. Reagan told the Americans in remarks prepared for the visit. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: TWO AFRIKANERS ON TRIAL FOR TREASON
description: Two young Afrikaners, members of South Africa's dominant white group, went on trial here this week accused of supporting the most prominent of the outlawed, black nationalist movement opposed to the system of racial separation that has become synonymous with Afrikanerdom in general. They are charged with high treason, an offense that carries a possible death sentence.

title: Susan L. Short and Dr. Benjamin N. Shain Marry
description: Susan Lillian Short, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maynard Joseph Short of Wauseon, Ohio, and Dr. Benjamin Ned Shain, son of Bernard Shain of Edison, N.J., and Helen Frances Reiss of Brooklyn, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents by Judge James Marlott of the Probate Court of Fulton County.

title: LOTTERY TICKET SALES BY NEW YORK STATE SET A WEEKLY RECORD
description: New York sold $20.5 million in lottery tickets from Oct. 30 through Nov. 5, the biggest weekly sales in its 16 years of operations, according to the lottery director, John D. Quinn.

title: AIRPORT EXPANSION UNDER NEW ATTACK
description: RESIDENTS of Westchester and Connecticut who have recently joined forces to fight expansion of the Westchester County Airport have begun to mount a united campaign to prevent the county's adoption of the airport's controversial master plan.

title: THE JEWS OF FRANCE --
description: Reading Paul Lewis's article, I was reminded of my student days at the Universite de Poitiers. My ''home'' was in the central-west part of France, the city of Tours.

title: SOME INSPECTION LICENSES REVOKED IN JERSEY
description: Nearly 200 owners of private garages are having their licenses to inspect cars revoked before they get a chance to examine one vehicle.

title: SPENDING MEASURE PASSED IN CAPITOL
description: Both houses of Congress today quickly adopted legislation needed to finance some Federal Government operations when they open for business Monday morning. Congressional leaders said President Reagan would sign the bill, assuring no disruption of Government services.

title: PHYSICISTS MAKE NUCLEAR APPEAL
description: Some 12,000 physicists from 43 countries have appealed for an immediate halt in the deployment of any additional nuclear weapons until there can be an accord stopping all testing, production and deployment.

title: Opposition Is Favored In Peru Elections
description: Opposition candidates are favored in opinion polls to defeat candidates of Peru's governing party Sunday in nationwide municipal elections, which leftist guerrillas have threatened to disrupt.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE;
description: B.B. KING IN RED BANK

title:
DINING OUT;
CLIFTON: NO LACK OF CHINESE CHEFS
description: IN A comfortable, modern setting on Clifton's

title: Elizabeth S. Lebow Engaged to Kenneth A. Flatto
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Stanley E. Lebow of North Woodmere, L.I., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Susan Lebow, to Kenneth Alan Flatto, son of Mrs. Frederic K. Raiff and Frederick A. Flatto, both of New York. An April wedding is planned.

title: Longtime Reagan Aide Gets Job With Pacific Telephone
description: Dennis LeBlanc, a longtime aide to Ronald Reagan who took a Government post under the President, has left for a job representing the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company before Federal agencies.

title: DEMOCRATS SEE STRENGTH IN LOCAL NUMBERS
description: Washington--Although the Republicans came out of last week's elections with their Senate majority intact, the Democrats could claim to see brighter signs for the future in other returns from a mixed bag of local, state and Congressional contests. The results suggested, Democrats said, that their ''three-legged strategy'' for 1984 is a sound one. According to Ann F. Lewis, political director of the Democratic National Committee, the three legs of the tripod supporting the party's hopes are: 1) increased voter turnout; 2) a revitalized coalition of big voter groups such as minorities and women; and 3) a massive effort by Democratic volunteers to offset the Republican advantage in money.

title: Sahara's Past
description: After interpreting radar studies of the Sahara made by the space shuttle Columbia in November 1981, scientists concluded that the remains of Stone Age settlements appeared to lie below the sands in southwestern Egypt and northwestern Sudan. Preliminary, shallow digging by scientists from the United States Geological Survey, the University of Arizona and the Egyptian Geological Survey turned up clues: layers of waterborne soil and artifacts.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ACAPULCO
description: Mexico's oldest and best-known resort is in the process once again of finding itself and its crowd. The glitz- and-glamour group no longer populates Acapulco as it once did, although you're still likely to see a familiar face or two. Remarkably low prices, caused by sharp devaluations of the Mexican peso, this year brought many people who always wanted to see Acapulco but could never afford it before; some Acapulquenos and regular visitors reacted as if this was an affront to their exclusivity. The spirit of the place became a bit confused.

title: INITIATOR OF 'BABY DOE' CASE UNSHAKEN
description: Lawrence Washburn Jr., the lawyer who began the court fight to force surgery on a severely deformed Long Island infant, says that despite legal setbacks he still believes that the parents of the baby girl do not have the right to block the operations.

title: CROSSING KENYA ON THE 'IRON SNAKE'
description: The train leaves at dusk, rolling slowly east out of the Nairobi station into the African dark. After 20 minutes it slides under an overpass carrying the Mombasa road and picks up speed as it heads onto the plains. The passengers can see nothing of the ground, riding through blackness midway between Mount Kenya to the north and Kilimanjaro to the south, each 100 miles away.

title: A WINNER'S OTHER GOALS
description: IF an athlete was ranked second in the

title: ILLINOIS PREVAILS BY 49-21
description: Illinois, led by Dwight Beverly's three touchdown runs and two by Thomas Rooks, clinched its first Rose Bowl berth in 20 seasons and at least a tie for the Big Ten Conference title by beating Indiana, 49-21, today.

title: BUDGET PIE: SHIFT IN THE SLICES
description: SALARIES of classroom teachers dipped markedly as a proportion of overall expenditure in a survey of spending patterns in the nation's public schools during the 20-year period from 1960 to 1980, but the rising share of expenditures for retirement programs and non-taxable health and dental benefits for teachers helped offset this change to some degree.

title: NO ANDROPOV ERA
description: A year has passed since Yuri V. Andropov succeeded Leonid I. Brezhnev. The ''Andropov era,'' so widely heralded in the Western press, has not unfolded.

title:
ANTIQUES;
THE TREASURES OF JAPAN IN NEWARK
description: NEWARK ''LACQUERWARE decorated in gold is not something to be seen in a brilliant light, to be taken in at a single glance; it should be left in the dark, a part here and a part there picked up by a faint light.''

title: Pro Basketball Notebook; Riley, Under Fire, Defends Nixon Trade
description: The Los Angeles Lakers have been ''under the microscope'' since they traded the popular point guard Norm Nixon to the San Diego Clippers, their Pacific Division rivals, says Coach Pat Riley. ''And unjustly so,'' he adds.

title: PROSPECTS
description: A Glimpse Into 1985

title: A BIASED WARNING ON BIRTH DEFECTS
description: To the Editor:

title: L.I. DIRECTOR SHAPES KENNEDY TV FILM
description: IT has been 20 years since John

title: Shots in Anaheim Force Evacuation of 3 Motels
description: A gunman firing wildly from a hotel room across the street from Disneyland injured one woman and forced the evacuation of 100 people from three motels before he surrendered today after a all-night standoff with the police.

title: BOB DYLAN MINGLES EXHILARATION AND MISANTHROPY
description: Bob Dylan's ''Infidels'' (Columbia QC 38819) is a disturbing artistic semirecovery by a rock legend who seemed in recent years to have lost his ability to engage the Zeitgeist.

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: NEW JERSEY'S newly chosen ''Teacher of the Year'' says that she doesn't mind the public appearances and speechmaking that go with the title.

title: THE ALASKA RAILROAD MAY NOT PAY THE FREIGHT
description: Washington and the state of Alaska are having another of their tiffs about money.

title: CONSUMER RATES

GARDENING;
WEATHER CAN BE A ROSE'S WORST ENEMY
description: WHILE fall is not the time of year when gardeners think about roses, a number of observations made while judging the All-America Rose Selections trial last season may be helpful to those who will soon be planning for the year ahead.

title: Coin Flip To Decide Champion
description: A coin flip today between Sachem and Brentwood will determine the outcome this season for the first place team in Division I-League I.

title: LONG RUN BRINGS TEXAS BACK, 20-14
description: Ronnie Robinson, playing a week after his shoulder was separated, ran 40 yards for a third-quarter touchdown to help Texas to a 20-14 Southwest Conference victory over Texas Christian today.

title:
WHAT'S HAPPENING IN THE FARM BELT;
AT RATH: WORKERS AGAINST THEMSELVES
description: RATH Packing Company's key to survival may be the re-negotiation of its three-year labor contract. Local 46 of the United Food & Commercial Workers International Union, A.F.L.-C.I.O., represents almost 1,500 of the 1,800 workers at the Waterloo, Iowa, company, which has filed for reorganization under Chapter 11 of the Federal bankruptcy laws.

title: AMTRAK
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
WEATHER CAN BE A ROSE'S WORST ENEMY
description: WHILE fall is not the time of year when gardeners think about roses, a number of observations made while judging the All-America Rose Selections trial last season may be helpful to those who will soon be planning for the year ahead.

title: PAYING THE BILL FOR SCHOOL REFORM
description: AMERICAN public schools need help. That was the message of the bipartisan National Commission on Excellence in Education, which in May released a report lamenting the ''rising tide of mediocrity'' in American schools. ''If an unfriendly foreign power had attempted to impose on America the mediocre educational performance that exists today,'' it declared, ''we might well have viewed it as an act of war. As it stands, we have allowed this to happen to ourselves.''

title: Breland Wins Boxing Title
description: Mark Breland, the world champion from Brooklyn, unleashed a flurry of punches to the head in the second round and stopped James Mitchell of Louisville, Ky., today to win the 147-pound title at the United States Amateur Boxing Championships. Two other world champions also won in this competition, which served as a qualifying meet for the United States Olympic trials next June. The super-heavyweight Tyrell Biggs of Philadelphia beat Warren Thompson of Baltimore, and Steve McCrory of Detroit stopped Jesse Flores of San Antonio after 57 seconds in the 112-pound division.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: GARDENS OF STONE

title: COMPANIES SEEK CURBS ON COPIES OF PRODUCTS
description: WASHINGTON ANEW BRITAIN toolmaking company has added its name to a growing list of American manufacturers finding that success in the marketplace brings not only profits but imitators.

title: BREZHNEV GIVEN A MINOR NICHE IN SOVIET PANTHEON
description: A low-key but respectful article in Pravda this week on the first anniversary of Leonid I. Brezhnev's death confirmed that, in contrast to his two predecessors, he has been granted a humble but solid niche in the Soviet pantheon.

title: TOWNS WIN MONEY
description: WHILE it hardly sounds like a problem, the State Attorney General's Office found itself this summer with more money than it could give away - nearly $50,000, in fact - after an out-of-court settlement of an antitrust suit.

title: STUDENT-ALDERMAN SEEKS CITY TIES
description: NEW HAVEN

title: Keel Wings Under Discussion
description: The future of the 12-Meter Class, the type of yacht used in the America's Cup competition, will be at stake this week when the keel boat committee of the International Yacht Racing Union, the sport's international governing body, meets in London.

title:
CAMERA;
SOME POINTERS ON FILMING THOSE THANKSGIVING FESTIVITIES
description: Fred W. Rosen and George Schaub are photographers who frequently write about their work.

title: THREE FIRST BOOKS OF POETRY
description: Alan Williamson teaches English at the University of California, Davis. His latest book of poems is ''Presence.'' THE HANDS IN EXILE

title: SETTLEING DOWN IN GRENADA
description: Nearly three weeks after the invasion, American forces on Grenada were settling in for an indefinite stay despite President Reagan's initial assurances they would be out in a matter of days. Congressional sources said last week they had received private estimates ranging from two or three more weeks, from members of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, to six months, from Sir Paul Scoon, Grenada's Governor General.

title: DEVOTED AND MISERABLE
description: THE LETTERS OF JOHN MIDDLETON MURRY TO KATHERINE MANSFIELD

title: BOXER TURNS TO AIDING YOUTHS
description: TRENTON IT IS said that professional boxing is only an illusion for young

title: ONE FISHERMAN'S SAFARI
description: It may be a voyage only for the intrepid, the foolish or

title:
GARDENING;
WEATHER CAN BE A ROSE'S WORST ENEMY
description: WHILE fall is not the time of year when gardeners think about roses, a number of observations made while judging the All-America Rose Selections trial last season may be helpful to those who will soon be planning for the year ahead.

title: LIGHTS CAN TRANSFORM DIM CORNERS INTO GARDEN SPACES
description: Eric Rosenthal is an amateur gardener and freelance writer.

title: VIRGIN GORDA'S REMOTE RESORTS
description: From the top of Virgin Gorda peak, a quarter-mile above the sun-diamonded sea, the island's two crablike arms seem to stretch toward the horizon. From this height, Virgin Gorda looks immense. It comes as a surprise to learn that the island, third largest (or second smallest) of the four major British Virgin Islands, extends at most 10 miles from clawtip to clawtip and at its widest is no more than two miles across.

title: HOW L.I.'S ORIGINAL INHABITANTS LIVED
description: AT least 3,000 years before the first Europeans touched on its shores some four centuries ago, Long Island was home to a self-sufficient people who, living in close harmony with the land and its waters, built a flourishing society. Although much of this civilization has disappeared over the last 400 years, some remnants remain: in isolated outposts where their descendents have survived, but mostly in local museum display cases, where artifacts gleaned from archeological digs or salvaged from construction bulldozers hint at what once was.

title: MORGAN STAR AGAIN AT BERGEN CATHOLIC
description: Mike Morgan, a senior tailback, ran for a touchdown and kicked what proved to be the decisive extra point as Bergen Catholic edged Paterson Kennedy, 7-6, yesterday in Oradell.

title: Great Lakes and East Are Thrashed by Gales By The Associated Press
description: Icy gales gusting up to 50 miles an hour thrashed the Northeast and the southern Great Lakes yesterday as the Coast Guard suspended a search for people who had radioed they were abandoning a boat in 10-foot waves off Chicago.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: It's a splendid week for musical marathons in New York.

title: ATTACK ON THE CAPITAL
description: The fact that some people are violently opposed to American foreign policy was brought uncomfortably close to home late one night last week when a bomb exploded outside the Senate Democratic leader's Capitol office.

title: CONGRESS FEELS LITTLE HEAT TO SETTLE GAS PRICING POLICY
description: For all its complexity, the debate over natural gas prices that raged in Congress last week could be described simply as an argument between those who say the removal of Federal controls would lead to higher prices for consumers and those who say prices would fall.

title: JAMES T. FARRELL
description: To the Editor:

title: SCHINDLER WARNS REFORM JEWS AGAINST LAXITY
description: Rabbi Alexander M. Schindler, president of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, has told the of 57th biennial convention of the organization that spiritual practices have been neglected by Reform Judaism and its leaders should set a better example of religious commmitment.

title: NEW HAVEN SEEKDS CURE FOR A HOUSING-PROJECT SLUM
description: YOUNG men lounge by the entrance to a dilapidated high- rise building in New Haven, one of them drinking from a bottle inside a paper bag. Some of the windows in the front hallway are shattered; others are boarded up. The smell of urine pervades the corridor. Graffiti and bullet holes cover the metal door to the stairs, which are dark even in the daytime and littered with broken glass.

title: CONCERT: ATLANTIC QUARTET AND CONTEMPORARY WORKS
description: Rather than one or two main courses, the concert sponsored by the League of Composers-International Society for Contemporary Music at Carnegie Recital Hall Thursday night offered a smorgasbord of musical morsels.

title: CHAMPIONS OF THE CLARINET DISPLAY ITS LITERATURE AND ITS VIRTUES
description: Allan Kozinn is a frequent contributor to Arts and Leisure.

title: THERE'S A LESSON TO BE LEARNED FROM CASSANDRA
description: ADIP into history can be refreshing, and somewhat illuminating, particularly if some of the characters of the past have current relevance.

title: Hofstra Wins to End at 10-0
description: ''This is the greatest football team in the history of Hofstra,'' Coach Mickey Kwiatkowski told his happy players today.

title: PLAN TO SELL MONTAUK BASE STIRS PROTEST
description: MONTAUK POINT AT the start of World War II, this isolated and sparsely populated area at the tip of Long Island was thought to be the most likely place for enemy forces to attempt an invasion. To defend it, the Federal Government established the military base known as Camp Hero, where four massive 16-inch guns were set into bunkers built with thick concrete walls, their ceilings topped by soil several feet thick.

title: YOUTHFUL PACERS BEAT NETS, 111-101
description: After playing six of their first seven games at home in Byrne Meadowlands Arena, the Nets learned a little about life on the road tonight. And if what they discovered here against the youthful Indiana Pacers becomes a pattern, the 7-city, 16-day tour that began tonight will not be a pleasant one.

title: The Holocaust: Other Views
description: I missed David L. Blumenfeld's statements on the Holocaust (''One Man's Mission for Six Million,'' Long Islanders, Sept. 4) but must take issue with the comments on its theme by Stanislaus J. Markiewicz (Letters to the Editor, Oct. 9).

title: HOW CAN PRIVACY BE SAFEGUARDED?
description: Many cable subscribers are aware that in the not- too-distant future cable television may be a two- way affair. But relatively few subscribers have considered what that will mean for their privacy.

title: BrooklynAccused Of Bilking Job-Seekers
description: A 35-year-old Brooklyn man has been arrested on charges of placing a bogus help wanted advertisement that offered 100,000 jobs for artists, writers, actors, dancers, models, educators and others, with pay of $800 to $4,000 a month and agency fees of only $10.

title: STILL CLASSIC
description: KENNETH GRAHAME'S angaging pastoral, THE WIND IN THE WILLOWS, is celebrating its 75th anniversary this year, and two publishers are marking the occasion - Scribners with a reissue of the much-loved edition illustrated by Ernest H. Shepard ($17.95) and Viking with a new volume illustrated by the British artist John Burningham ($15.75).

title: Harvard Trounces Penn, 28-0
description: Harvard trounced Pennsylvania, 28- 0, today at Soldier Field, and an Ivy League championship for the Crimson became something more than a September possibility.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: DANCE

title: FACTORS IN MAKING A CHOICE
description: WHEN fuel prices were substantially lower than they are today, homeowners rarely fretted over their heating bills. But sharp fluctuations in the price of home heating oil, natural gas and even wood have created a need to keep constantly alert to see how heating costs can best be kept in hand.

title: ;  Many Facets
description: To the Business Editor:

title: SCHOLAR AND PAMPHLETEER
description: C. WRIGHT MILLS

title: A FESTIVAL OF PHOTOGRAPHY IN MADISON AND SPARKILL
description: MADISON THIS town is alive with photography these days. At the Fairleigh Dickinson University library through Nov. 30 is a retrospective by the German-born Hans Schiff; meanwhile, in the Photography Gallery at Drew University is a recapitulation of the roughly two dozen exhibitions held there since 1979.

title: Kimberlee Ann Hyatt Plans a June Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Hyatt of Bloomfield, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Kimberlee Ann Hyatt, to Thomas Raymond Watkins, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald R. Watkins of Darien, Conn.

title: LOOKING FOR A LEBANON EXIT
description: Whatever the threat to those students in Grenada, the real American hostages this autumn are the marines in Lebanon.

title: ONE PRICE OF HIGH BAIL: OVERCROWDED CITY PRISONS
description: In August, when Charles Thomas was arraigned on a narcotics charge, a city judge set bail at $350. Mr. Thomas had no money and was sent to a grim cell at the Brooklyn House of Detention. He waited there until this month, when a bargain-bail program was ordered by a Federal judge to ease overcrowding. It cost Mr. Thomas only $35 to leave.

title: A LONG REIGN COMES TO A CLOSE
description: RUNNING a town is like being on a treadmill, said John J. Sullivan, the First Selectman of Fairfield. It has to be experienced. ''Professors can't teach it,'' he said.

title: Jennifer Knapp, an Architect, Marries Thomas Chandler Crawford in Boston
description: Jennifer Knapp, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Charles Knapp of Chestnut Hill, Mass., was married at the Colonnade Hotel in Boston yesterday to Thomas Chandler Crawford, son of Mr. and Mrs. Chandler H. Crawford of Lafayette Hill, Pa. Rabbi Lawrence Milder and the Rev. Paul E. Chreiman, a Methodist minister, officiated.

title: PREPAYING TUITION? WELL, IT DEPENDS
description: AT first glance it seems like a very attractive offer. In letters to the families of entering freshmen, a rising chorus of college financial officers are offering a guarantee against increases in tuition and room and board charges for the full four years of undergraduate education - if the family will pay for all four years at once, at the freshman-year rate. For those who can't put the money up front, many of the schools offer to help set up a loan.

title: WHITE-WATER PSYCHOLOGY
description: David Black's fifth book, ''Murder at the Met,'' will be published next August. By David Black THE FIRST WAVE HIT broadside. It curled over my head and slammed down beside me, tilting the raft 45 degrees. The four men on the other side of the raft reared so high that to see them I had to glance almost straight up. Leaning forward, their faces contorted into grimaces, they seemed to be flying single file down the river. Their paddles scooped air.

title: PUTTING A HAPPY FACE ON THE BRONX
description: New York City officials are hoping that life imitates art in the South Bronx. In the coming months, the city Housing Commissioner said last week, many abandoned apartment buildings in that beleaguered community will be spruced up with colorful vinyl sheets - depicting curtains, venetian blinds, shutters, flowerpots and other signs of life - placed over boarded-up windows.

title: U.S. Warns Babies in Danger From Accordion-Style Gates
description: The Consumer Product Safety Commission has cited seven recent infant deaths in warning of entrapment and strangulation hazards with accordion- style baby gates.

title: SEASIDE RECIPES OF OLD
description: -year-old bottle of Chateau Margaux or Chateau Yquem for $4 at the Ocean Hotel in Long Branch.

title: WRITING BY COMPUTER: IS IT MIGHTIER THAN THE PEN?
description: LESLIE MEYERS, who is 11 years old, says he likes to type out his writing assignments on a computer because it's easier than writing with a pencil or pen. When he's finished typing, he can press a button and ''print it up as a story,'' and the finished product looks neater than if done by hand.

title: THE AMERICAN FAMILY TAKES SOME MORE HARD KNOCKS
description: For some years now the air has been thick with the sound of the nuclear family being exploded by our novelists and playwrights. Parent against parent, sibling against sibling, father failing to understand son, and son defiantly refusing to be understood by father: The emphases vary, but the story is the same, and it is one of disintegration, fragmentation. The danger, which is a sort of thematic overkill, has not, however, always been avoided. Yesterday's subversive subject has very often, too often, become today's whining platitude. So it's obvious what one should ask of George Sibbald's ''Brothers'' and Christopher Durang's ''Baby With the Bathwater,'' both of which could be providing future anthropologists with footnotes to their treatises on the psychopathology of American family life: Is either of them really necessary?

title: Death Row Rights
description: The American Civil Liberties Union branch in Chicago sued the Illinois Department of Corrections in April 1981, contending that the constitutional rights of Death Row prisoners at the Menard Correctional Center were being violated.The Federal District Court suit charged, among other things, that the cells were too small and poorly ventilated, inmate medical and dental needs were being neglected and educational and recreational opportunities were restricted.

title: BUYING FOR LESS
description: To the Business Editor:

title: Real Rates
description: To the Business Editor:

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: THE PURPLE DECADES: A Reader. By Tom Wolfe. (Berkley, $7.95.) In 20 classic pieces, including ''memorable hunks'' of ''The Right Stuff,'' Tom Wolfe ''conveys excitement or shock in the face of anomaly . . . by deploying various devices of verbal intensity and oddness,'' Paul Fussell observed in his review. Mr. Wolfe ''doesn't spatter out these wonderful words for their own sake,'' the review pointed out. ''He exhibits them because they're the right medium for his satiric and moral vision,'' and he exhilarates his readers by making them ''share the enthusiasm with which he perceives the actual.''

title: THE ART OF MIME IS CHANGING
description: ALTHOUGH most people think of mime as wordless story- telling by performers in white face, few realize that contemporary artists in New Jersey are changing the classic art form.

title: ARIZONA STOPS U.C.L.A., 27-24
description: Arizona toppled U.C.L.A. from first place in the Pacific 10 Conference with a 27-24 victory today in a game that began at 10:30 A.M. local time for national television coverage.

title: WAGING PEACE IN THE UNITED NATIONS
description: THE United Nations has tripled its membership since it moved into its New York

title: U.N. JUVENILE CRIME PANEL MEETS IN NEWARK
description: A United Nations panel of legal experts from 16 countries met here this week to discuss juvenile crime and to recommend rules that would balance the rights of the young with the interests of society in general.

title: INEXHAUSTIBLE ALBANY
description: There is a sentiment abroad that if you drop a good reporter, or novelist, into a place where nothing is happening, something will happen. The writer's very presence in an ordinary locale brings out the extraordinary. The instincts of an original writer serve as the stimulus for inventive reporting or storytelling; magically, an original sees things anew, bringing freshness to the familiar.

title: Jerilyn M. Boylan To Become Bride
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph I. Boylan of Westfield, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jerilyn Mary Boylan, to Jeffrey Scott Campbell, son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Campbell of McLean, Va.

title: BRAZIL KEEPS THE BANKS HAPPY
description: While foreign creditors looked on with satisfaction, Brazil tightened the financial screws last week. On fourth try, a Government measure holding down wage increases passed the Chamber of Deputies - and none too soon, in view of a crucial meeting of the International Monetary Fund scheduled for this week in Washington.

title: RYE TENNIS PLAYER TRIES FOR COMEBACK
description: AMONG the serious tennis players in the county 10 years ago was a spunky girl from Rye, whose request to play on the boys' team at Rye Neck High School drew wide attention. Donna Rubin, who was easily triumphing over her female opponents, explained at the time that she felt she needed stronger competition and could hold her own against the boys.

title: MERGER OF SAVINGS BANKS IN THE COUNTY BRING CHANGES FOR CUSTOMERS
description: THE local savings bank gets a new name. It gets a facelift - maybe automatic teller machines and expanded hours. Perhaps the bank becomes more competitive on rates. But you can no longer sit down with the president to chat about a loan.

title: PICTURE A GHOST, A MOOSE OR A TIN SOLDIER
description: The prerequisites for a picture-book editor read a little like the vital statistics of a mythical being. Start with the eye of a hawk and a musician's ear, necessities for matching the right manuscript to the right artist. Add Jack Benny's timing, Winston Churchill's gift for decision and the humility of a Carmelite nun to nurture, guide and shove that collaboration of talent and temperament to its goal, a complete wedding of written word and illustrator's art.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
STRONGER U.S. SHOWING AT MEDALLIC CONGRESS
description: For years the United States has lagged behind much of the world in nurturing the field of medallic art. Now U.S. medalists have served impressive notice that this nation's stature in that field may be undergoing a metamorphosis, akin to that of the caterpillar changing into a butterfly.

title: Lisa Gayle Schoen to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles J. Schoen of New Hyde Park, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lisa Gayle Schoen, to Steven C. Leibrock, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Leibrock of Rosedale, Queens. A September wedding is planned. Miss Schoen is a registered sales assistant at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York, where her fiance is a telecommunications analyst for the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company.

title: STATE COLLEGES ON L.I. PURSUE DONATIONS
description: LONG ISLAND's public universities, their enrollment figures swelling, are beginning to assume a more aggressive fund-raising posture. Emulating the area's private instituitions, they are seeking money from private sources to solidify their financial base and to fill the gap between what they receive from the state budget and what is needed to run rapidly expanding programs.

title: U.S. 'CONCERNED BY FATAL INCIDENT IN GUATEMALA
description: The Guatemalan authorities said today that two linguists who worked for a United States agency had been found dead, apparently the victims of a fiery car crash. A colleague, however, said he believed they were murdered, and added that they did not even know how to drive.

title: Angela de la Paz Guerrero to Wed Clifford Zinnes
description: Angela de la Paz Guerrero, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Luis Beltran Guerrero of Caracas, Venezuela, and Clifford Fich Zinnes, son of Harriet Zinnes of New York and the late Irving I. Zinnes, plan to be married in June.

title: Q AND A
description: Question:

title: DOWN, DOWN ON AMERICA
description: RACK! Something snapped in me, and I faced up to a conviction I had been trying to stifle for years: the reluctant and terrible conviction that the greatest threat to the peace of humanity is the United States.

title: WAITING FOR THE BIG BANKS TO REVIVE
description: For investors in the big international bank stocks, the possibility of a major loan default by a foreign country is like nuclear war. Both are too horrible to contemplate. Over the summer, with economic crises abounding in South America, the specter of default and the decimating effects on bank capital became all too real. Investors fled and the stocks of the so-called money-center banks in New York, Boston, Chicago and San Francisco took a monumental nose dive. But lately, some big investors have decided that the default fears have gone too far. One of these is Delaware Investment Advisers. In recent weeks, the Philadelphia-based pension fund manager has put $150 million of its $5.5 billion equity portfolio into Citicorp, Chemical Bank, Wells Fargo and a number of other money-center banks. And, as of last week, it was still buying. The rush is on, explained George Deming, vice president, because the big banks are near their historical lows relative to the rest of the market. And, within a matter of weeks, he believes, the Brazilian debt crisis, which sent the group into a tailspin in the first place, is likely to ease. Many of Wall Street's leading analysts also say the big banks are a bargain. ''They are incredibly oversold,'' said Thomas Hanley, a bank analyst at Salomon Brothers. ''The time to worry about defaults was a year ago. Now the International Monetary Fund, the debtor countries and the banks are all pulling on the same oar.''

title: CLARINETIST AND VIOLINIST AMONG FIVE PERFORMERS IN RECITAL PROGRAMS
description: Organized by instruments, last week's five debut recitalists divided into two clarinetists, two pianists and an odd man out, a violist.

description: IN a referendum last week,

description: Following are excerpts from Pope John Paul II's discourse to the Pontifical Academy of Sciences today, as translated to English by the Vatican from the original French:

title: GIVING METRO-NORTH A CHANCE
description: HEY, commuters, would you believe there may be light at the end of the tunnel - and that light is the face of Peter Stangl, new president of the Metro-North Commuter Railroad Company.

title: Cosmos Beaten Indoors
description: The Cosmos returned to indoor soccer tonight and lost, 7-5, to the Golden Bay Earthquakes before a crowd of 7,657 at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Yale Wins First
description: Jeff Bassette scored three touchdowns on short runs, including a 1-yard burst with 6 minutes 5 seconds to play for the winning score, as Yale defeated Princeton 28-21 today for its first victory of the season.

title: LOAN SHARK IN LOVE
description: WALTZ IN MARATHON

title: DEMOCRATIC FRESHMEN HOPE TO MAKE THE DEFICIT ISSUE PAY OFF
description: Representative Jim Wright of Texas was telling the story about the football player from Rice and the Cotton Bowl game against Alabama. The Rice halfback broke free and was racing for a touchdown, and one lad from the Alabama squad, who was sitting on the bench at the time, got so upset that he ran on to the field and tackled the runner. Last Tuesday night, Mr. Wright said, he felt like that Rice halfback. ''Except the guy who tackled me was from my own team,'' said the majority leader.

title: THE TRANSCONTINENTAL LOOMS LARGER
description: ROBERT B. CLAYTOR is 61 years old; hardly a young man. But he does ponder Horace Greeley's time-honored advice about going West. Or, to be more precise, taking his East Coast railway West. Not long ago, after a spell at the throttle of an old steam engine chugging its way through the West Virginia coal country served by his railway, this earthy chief executive of the Norfolk Southern Corporation doffed his blue coveralls and acknowledged that: ''I see a certain romance in being the first transcontinental.''

title: A REFORMERS ROUNDTABLE ON FINANCES
description: Q. WE have been hearing a lot of suggestions on how to improve public schools in this country, but we haven't heard much about how to pay for these improvements. Where will the money come from?

title: Political Contributions: Another Viewpoint
description: In ''Corporations Plan Bigger Politics Role'' (Oct. 30), the manager of public affairs for Ciba-Geigy, Tom Chizmadia, is quoted as saying that he does not believe that the average corporate political action committee contribution of $657 can buy any political votes. Yet the same article points out that Ciba-Geigy's own collection for what is ironically called a ''good-government fund'' soared from $3,700 in 1979 to a whopping $33,000 last year. Seemingly not to be outdone, Pepsico has a sum of $225,000 this year from which to grease the palms of our elected officials.

title: Holding Court Alfresco
description: When Judge Marc Cianca found there were no rooms available in the Martin County Courthouse Wednesday, he moved his court out to the sunny lawn, complete with American flag, bench, attorneys' tables and chairs for spectators. He heard 18 cases in two hours, leaving Chief Circuit Judge C. Pfeiffer Trowbridge feeling envious. ''I've been wanting to hold court on that lawn for 10 years and now Cianca has beaten me to it,'' Judge Trowbridge said.

title: TACTICS IN PRESIDENTIAL RACES FOUND TO HAMPER RECRUITING
description: Presidents who campaigned against cumbersome Federal bureaucracy have often alienated prospective appointees to their administrations as a result, according to a recent report on Presidential hirings.

title: THE DIFFICULT FRENCHDEFENSE HAS ITS PROPONENTS
description: Strangers to the French Defense and claustrophobics cannot imagine why anyone would be attracted to it. But there are volunteers for submarine duty, too.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: WHEN a customer announced that a $2 million lottery ticket had been sold at the Hasting's Stationery Store, Richard J. Gabie , the head clerk at Hasting's Electric, looked up from his work and said, ''You're kidding.''

title: HOW A.T.&T. LOST THE FIGHT OVER LONG-DISTANCE ACCESS FEES
description: WASHINGTONThe American Telephone & Telegraph Company has long been considered the country's most powerful corporate lobby.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: AMERICAN BUSINESS ASSOCIATES, a company formed in Manhattan last February to help other concerns get an edge on competitors, so far has done most of its organizing in New Jersey. It has started four area councils in the Garden State, compared to only one in Manhattan and one on Long Island.

title: DEFICIT MYTHS
description: Congress is in a tizzy over the prospect of triple digit Federal deficits over the next few years. This concern has produced a flurry of activity aimed at narrowing the deficits by raising taxes. What goes around, comes around.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
SEAFOOD BAHAMAS STYLE
description: Late in the Bahamian winter afternoon the sun is still warm on the face and shoulders, but the ocean breeze picks up enough to remind one that dinner should soon be on the agenda. Appetites may sleep in the heat of high noon, but the islands' salty air and turquoise blue of the shallow ocean are reminders of the delicacies of Bahamian cuisine: fresh seafood.

title: NEW JERSEY JOURNAL
description: HAVING lost Round 1, chain stores in Bergen and Hudson Counties are preparing for Round 2 in their fight to overturn the state's Sunday sales ban on a variety of retail goods.

title: POLES TRY A NEW TWIST ON PRICES
description: Poland unveiled two proposals for increases in food prices today and, in an effort to prevent protests, said the public could choose which proposal would be used.

title: RUSSIA: A PEOPLE WITHOUT HEROES --
description: David Shipler writes: ''It is an article of conviction among Soviet intellectuals that the Bolsheviks who made the Revolution were men of ideas . . . . Lenin, Trotsky, Plekhanov, Bukharin were more than skillful activists . . . .'' This wording could give the (mistaken) impression that G. V. Plekhanov was a Bolshevik. Though Plekhanov wrote for the Bolshevik press at some points in the pre-Revolutionary era, he was neither a Bolshevik nor a Menshevik. Plekhanov once explained his position by noting: ''My tactical views were completely worked out when neither the Bolsheviks nor the Mensheviks had yet seen the light . . . . If I have sometimes supported the Bolsheviks and sometimes the Mensheviks, that occured for the simple reason that sometimes the one and sometimes the other were right

description: For the past two weeks, David J. Friedland, a former State Senator from Hudson County, has been testifying about what the Government contends is official corruption in his home county.

title: PLAINVIEW ELIMINATED
description: Ron Judson scored twice yesterday to help Garden City defeat Plainview, 29-0, and insure the Trojans of their third straight Conference B, Division B title. Garden City will play Sewanhaka for the conference championship on Nov. 25.

description: Derrick Harmon rushed for a career-high 222 yards and scored 2 touchdowns today to lead Cornell to a 31-6 victory over Columbia on snow-covered Schoellkopf Field.

title: AN AFRICAN JOURNEY, FROM THE CAPE TO CAIRO
description: Africa from the Cape to Cairo: This colossal progression has long been the dream of adventurers, lured by the continent's secrets, by its people, its wildlife and its majestic geography - shimmering savannas, sudden mountains, powerful rivers and immense valleys. The dream reached its most audacious dimensions in Cecil Rhodes's ill-fated plans for a Cape-to-Cairo railway. But the urge to span the continent from bottom to top did not die with Rhodes's dream, and air travel can now accomplish what rails failed to do.

description: AROAD improvement project on Main Street in Smithtown is being planned by the State Department of Transportation around preservation of a historic half-mile stand of locust trees. description: Affiliate Artists offered its second dance concert Thursday night in the Theater of the Riverside Church. The five choreographers who presented works have all participated in dancers-in-residence programs around the country under the auspices of Affiliate Artists Inc.

What's more, being young - they range in age from 10 to 17 - they tend to feel that with time, talent and the proverbial big break, the goal is not an unrealistic one.

title: WIDE-OPEN ANDOVER DEFEATS EXETER, 28-6
description: When Dave Graham took over as head coach at Andover this season, he promised his team would gear its offense around a passing game. As the son of Otto Graham, the former star college and professional quarterback, his promise surprised no one.

description: The audience laughed throughout and cheered as ''Artificial Horizon,'' a new piece by Jane Comfort, came to a close on Friday at Dance Theater Workshop's Bessie Sch"onberg Theater. But for one member of that audience the evening was a mix of ingredients whose point was never very clear.

title: Resort Rail Plan: Opposition Explained
description: In his Oct. 9 Opinion Page letter about Atlantic City rail service, Douglas John Bowen said that RAGE (Residents Against Gamblers Express) was uninformed. This indicates his own lack of understanding of both the issue and RAGE's position.

title: NATIONAL THEATER WAITS IN THE WINGS
description: Contrary to popular belief, there is a national theater devoted to American works. This national company recently presented both a revival of ''Guys and Dolls'' and the world premiere of ''Glengarry Glen Ross,'' the latest drama by Chicagoan David Mamet. It is now preparing to mount ''Jean Seberg,'' a musical biography of the actress. The only problem is that this national theater is England's.

description: ''Made in Heaven!'', the new play that is the season opener for the American Jewish Theater at the 92d Street Y, is a perfectly funny bit of business set in an imperfectly fashioned comedy that has something to say about our times.

title: Sports of The Times; Days of Kennedy, Days of O'Brien
description: WHEN Larry O'Brien accepted the position of commissioner of the National Basketball Association eight and a half years ago, after having served as special counsel to President Kennedy and President Johnson, Postmaster General of the United States and National Chairman of the Democratic Party, there were many who asked him why, after all he'd been through, would he go into sports?

title: THEY WISH US A MERRY CHRISTMAS
description: THERE is no harm in retelling the story of the birth of Jesus, reprinting familiar carols or even recycling Hans Christian Andersen's rather sadistic tale of the little fir tree that gets hung with ornaments at Christmas only to be thrown out and burned up as trash. These are all parts of a seasonal industry. But it's depressing to go through a pile of the 1983 products and find so little evidence of fresh response. Here are a few exceptions in a mediocre lot.

title: JUDGE IN ALASKA BARS WOLF HUNTING FROM AIR
description: A State Superior Court judge in Alaska has temporarily halted the hunting of wolves from the air by the State Department of Fish and Game in a program to reduce preying on declining moose populations in Alaska's interior.

title: CATHEDRAL EXPANDS CONCERTS
description: NEWARK THE Cathedral of the Sacred Heart here has added a new dimension to its expanded concert series this season: performances by its own professional orchestra and chorus with noted guest artists.

title:
DINING OUT;
TAKING THE GAME SERIOUSLY
description: ALLIGATOR tail, elk, bear, deer, suckling pig, buffalo, reindeer, moose, wild boar and rattlesnake find their way into the cook pots of the Horse and Hound Inn at one time or another. Pheasant and quail, the gamebirds offered, sound jejune by comparison. For the last 14 years, Claus Hattasch, the chef and owner of Horse and Hound, has maintained this inn that dates back to 1721 as faithfully as modern conveniences allow. Secreted in South Salem, stashed away on a byway to Connecticut, the stage set established - beamed low ceilings, wide and cozy hearth, rough woods, pewter plates - radiates Colonial charm.

title: MIDDLE EAST ENTERS A NEW, PERHAPS MORE PERILOUS, PHASE
description: BEIRUT, Lebanon IN August 1982, American marines landed in Beirut on

title: THE FACTORY-BUILT HOUSE GETS A FOOTHOLD IN CITY
description: THE year 1983 is establishing itself as the period in

title: JETS AND GIANTS SEEKING ANSWERS AMID THE LOSSES
description: When this pro football season began, Brad Van Pelt had great hopes.

title: RAISING DYSLEXICS TO THE COLLEGE LEVEL
description: WHEN Mary Knepfel entered the Project Success program at the University of Wisconsin here in the summer of 1981, she was, like most freshmen, 18 years old. But unlike most freshmen, she was still reading at the fourth-grade level. Moreover, her spelling and word order were so mixed up that it took hours to read her letters. She lacked self-confidence, was afraid to talk to anyone and had few friends. She was dyslexic.

title: ELEO POMARE DEALS WITH MAN'S INHUMANITY TO MAN
description: Eleo Pomare once perched on a barre in a loft studio theater. Small, wiry and black, he held a chunk of watermelon in his hands, biting into it deliberately and, just as deliberately, staring calmly at the audience as he spat out the seeds, one by one. It was an unforgettably powerful moment - in a dance lost in the years of struggling loft performances - but one curiously without malice, demagoguery or false theatrics.

title: FLATTERY FROM A SPEAKER
description: Ask anyone at a jazz concert where they'd like to sit and odds are they'll say, ''Right up front.'' Ditto with rock and pop fans. Jazz and pop listeners like immediacy, impact, and detail - and that's what they get by crowding around the stage, the closer the better.

title: Hofstra Goalie Critical
description: Andrew Radcliffe , the outstanding Hofstra soccer goalkeeper, remained in critical condition yesterday at Nassau Medical Center in East Meadow, L.I. He suffered multiple head and internal injuries Friday morning in a five-story fall from a window of a dormitory. ''He has numerous broken bones and is in very, very bad shape,'' said Ed Smith , a hospital spokesman.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: MOTHER LOVE

title: YALE FANS PREPARE FOR GAME
description: ''ICAN'T think of a bigger or more exciting event to take place in New Haven,'' said Jane Snaider, director of the city's Visitors and Convention Bureau. She was referring to next Saturday's 100th meeting of the Yale Elis and the Harvard Crimson at 1 P.M.

title: Facility Begun to Turn Waste into Glass Logs
description: The Federal Government has begun construction here of a $1.3 billion facility to convert radioactive waste from nuclear weapons production into glass logs for permanent storage underground.

title: ALL ALONG SWEEPS TURF TRIPLE
description: Walter Swinburn had a wonderfully close-up view of the stretch run of the Washington D.C. International today. The jockey spent most of the final two furlongs looking over his shoulder rather than looking toward the finish line. That's how easily he rode All Along to a historic victory in the 32d International at Laurel Race Course.

title: JUDGE SPEEDS UP AGENT ORANGE SUIT
description: In the month since he was selected to preside over the multibillion-dollar lawsuit by Vietnam veterans against makers of the defoliant Agent Orange, Chief Judge Jack B. Weinstein of Federal Court for the Eastern District of New York has reshaped and accelerated the case.

title: 450-YEAR OLD REGAL BIRTHDAY SOUNDS AT SARAH LAWRENCE
description: AROYAL gala marking the 450th anniversary of the birth of Queen Elizabeth I begins at 3 P.M. today on the campus of Sarah Lawrence College in Yonkers.

title: RECENT CASSETTERS RANGE FROM 'HIGH NOON' TO HIGH C'S
description: Joan Sutherland in the Making of ''Lakme'' Mastervision 60 minutes. $59.95

description: NAPOLEON

description: ONE CHRISTMAS
