description: WILLIAM FAULKNER

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Robert Drew is generally credited with developing the cinema verite style of documentary cinematography in which a hand-held camera is used to record scenes under natural conditions. And he used this method to photograph President John F. Kennedy.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: A COUNTRY SUCH AS THIS

title: Vermont
description: To the Editor: We were shocked and dismayed after reading the article ''Autumn in Vermont'' by Nora John

title: P.L.O. LEADER LISTS DEMANDS TO QUIT TRIPOLI
description: Yasir Arafat, who withdrew his forces into this northern Lebanese city last week while fighting off attacks by rival Palestinians, said today that he wanted certain security guarantees before he would leave the area.

title: FOR BETTER CARE AND FEEDING OF THE GIFTED
description: IT WOULD be a very peculiar state of affairs if our society took the position that children who are found to possess remarkable musical aptitude were, nevertheless, not to be given any special consideration or instruction. And it would be literally unthinkable if we argued that young people blessed with superior athletic ability should not be encouraged to develop their gifts.

title: CAREERS DEDICATED TO U.S. FREEDOMS' DEFENSE
description: To the Editor:

title: GREENWICH CAPTURES TITLE
description: Greenwich captured the Western Division championship of the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference with a 13-0 victory yesterday over Stamford Catholic.

title: Dr. Emily Bland Sonnenblick to Wed Dr. Kenneth Offit, a Medical Resident
description: Dr. and Mrs. Edmund H. Sonnenblick of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Emily Bland Sonnenblick, to Dr. Kenneth Offit, son of Sidney and Dr. Avodah K. Offit of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: DEATH-ROW ISSUES CREATE BITTER SPLIT
description: The logic behind recent Supreme Court rulings on death sentence appeals has confounded even some of the Justices. Only the majority's general intent is clear: Shorten the path from sentencing to execution.

title: WHAT SACRIFICES MUST AN ATHLETE MAKE?
description: AT 4:30 in the morning the train came to a stop. Before the American athletes and coaches could roll out of their bunks the Russian border guards were in the doorways of the four-man sleeping compartments. The tone of their voices and their gestures made it clear this was serious business.

title: NO REST FOR VIGILANCE
description: To the Editor:

title: China
description: To the Editor: I have just returned from a visit to the People's Republic of China and write this not to suggest to future tourists what to take with them but what to leave at home - gifts for the children of China.

title: DOBBS FERRY FINISHES AT 8-0
description: Dobbs Ferry and Byram Hills took conference championships and completed undefeated seasons by shutting out their opponents yesterday.

title: SCIENCE CENTER TO EXPAND
description: -square-foot nature museum on the 415-acre arboretum of Connecticut College here, has begun an expansion program that will double its size.

title:
SPEAKING PERSONALLY;
LOOK! DOWN THERE! IT'S CORPORATEMAN!
description: I,TOO, was once slim, young and

title: WEINBERGER TIED TO CURB ON PRESS
description: A Pentagon spokesman said this week that Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger approved in advance the restrictions imposed on reporters in the first days of the invasion of Grenada.

title: 'BIG-CITY' RENT INCREASES PUSHING SUBURBS TO CONTROLS
description: It's just mid-autumn, but in Westchester a freeze has set in. The county board that regulates apartment rents in 18 communities imposed a halt in all increases three weeks ago, the first such freeze in New York State in 10 years. Last week, a Westchester landlords group was in court challenging the action.

title: U.S. IS HOPING TO STEER CLEAR OF CONDEMNATION BY O.A.S.
description: The Reagan Administration faces criticism in the week ahead from the Organization of American States over the invasion of Grenada, but it has apparently headed off a resolution that would formally condemn the action, Latin American diplomats said today.

title: CAUTION SIGNALS FLASH AT THE FEDERAL LEVEL
description: INUNDATED with expert advice, Congress is eager to do what it can to improve the quality of American education - provided, however, that the legislation does not cost too much or significantly increase the Federal deficit.

title: FROM THE BOTTOM OUT-OF-SIGHTS ON UP
description: CLASS

title: RECORD CROP SEEN FOR WHEAT IN 1984
description: Wheat farmers in overwhelming numbers appear to have rejected the Reagan Administration's newest plan to reduce planting for next year's crop, according to Federal officials, farmers and agricultural experts.

title: PEACE DRAFT DUE FROM LATIN BLOC
description: Nicaraguan analysts and diplomats here say the four-nation group that has been seeking a regional peace settlement in Central America will present a series of draft accords to Central American foreign ministers in Washington in the coming week.

title: ARE ASSAULATS ON LEGAL AID FLOUTING THE LAW?
description: Overshadowed by the noisy battle between the Reagan Administration and Congress about the Civil Rights Commission, a kind of guerrilla warfare continues over what seems to be President Reagan's least favorite program - Federally funded legal services for poor people.

title: JUSTICE DEPARTMENT BATTLES AGAINST CONFLICTS BETWEEN POLICE AND MINORITIES
description: On a recent Saturday in a white working-class suburb bordering one of Chicago's black neighborhoods, Justice Department officials spoke to a group of white police officers, most of whom looked as if they would rather be somewhere else.

title: 28 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 28 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: LAW AND ORDER AND GOOD TIMING
description: Mayor Koch named the first black police commissioner in New York City history last week, and in the process seemed to improve his standing with more than a few minority-group leaders. Mr. Koch said he chose Benjamin Ward, the city's Correction Commissioner, to run the nation's largest police force because of his law enforcement experience, not his race (although, the Mayor acknowledged, ''he is black, no question about that''). City Councilman Frederick E. Samuel of Harlem seemed to speak for many black politicians when he called it Mr. Koch's ''best appointment to date.''

title: PHILADELPHIA RAISES SECURITY AT SCHOOL IN ATTACK ON ASIANS
description: School officials say they have increased security at a West Philadelphia high school as a precaution after the second beating of an Asian student this fall.

title: ON EDUCATING GIFTED CHILDREN
description: SINCE the release of ''A Nation at Risk'' and the report of the Task Force on Education for Economic Growth - both decrying the sad state of American education and calling for a renewed pursuit of ''excellence'' - the public has been in a frenzy over the deplorable job that our schools are doing in turning out literate and productive citizens. And, of course, the press has contributed to this by highlighting the worst scenarios.

title: VIOLIST 'OBSESSION' PART OF HER PLAYING
description: WHEN Rosemary Glyde was attending the Juilliard School of Music, working for her master's degree in the violin, her father, a professor of music at Auburn University in Alabama, gave her a special present. It was his precious viola, made in 1786.

title: WE HAVE BEEN HERE BEFORE
description: ITRAVELED to Washington for

title: CONCERT: GOTHAM ENSEMBLE
description: During the intermission of the Gotham Chamber Players concert in the Goodman House Wednesday night, this listener thought seriously of giving up and going home. Edgard Feder, the conductor, seemed so ineffectual that there appeared to be little point in staying.

title: Mary J. Vaux to Marry Peter Wesley Acheson
description: Mary James Vaux, daughter of George Vaux of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and the late Mrs. Vaux, and Peter Wesley Acheson, son of Mr. and Mrs. David C. Acheson of Washington, plan to be married Dec. 28.

title: THE PLEASURES OF GIVING
description: Among the many joys of this time of year, the sort that can intensify the holiday seasons general glow is matching the right gift with the right person: perhaps a touch of fantasy here, a bit of extravagance there, even a modicum of practicality for good measure. The search, seemingly endless though it may be, is everything. But time does run out, and without help the conscientious gift giver's best- intended plans can come to nought. On the following pages are suggestions that may aid in that search for well-made, individually appropriate gifts to bring delight to the eyes of their receivers. 1.*Handwoven, silk paisley shawl, circa 1850, $750. At Vito Giallo Antiques, 966 Madison Avenue. 2.*Leopard-print bra and tap pants made of panne, $700. At Jackie Rogers, 787 Madison Avenue. 3.*Full lead-crystal candleholder is nine and seven-eighths inches high, $455. At Baccarat, 55 East 57th Street. 4.*Circa 1860, this brass magnifying glass, $185, is one of several available at Marco Polo, 1135 Madison Avenue. 5.*Paloma Picasso's bracelet in 18- karat gold with pave diamonds around an unusually large moonstone, $35,000. At Tiffany & Company. 6.*Stylized camel is made of pewter and brass, $300. From Andrea by Sadek. At Galleria 73, 1025 Lexington Avenue. Ruth Vitow, 160 East 56th Street. 7.*Many configurations are possible with these battery-operated, manipulatable lamps, $24.95 each. At the Museum Shop, 37 West 53d Street. 8.*Sterling-silver pitcher with a 40- ounce capacity has a pineapple motif, $3,225.

title: SOUTH BRONX YOUTH GROUP IMPARTS A FAMILY FEELING
description: Carlos Reyes and Marcos Saladini danced as they waited for a gypsy cab in front of Our Lady of Victory Roman Catholic Church on Webster Avenue in the South Bronx.

title: 4 REPORTED DEAD AS TRAIN JUMPS TRACKS IN TEXAS
description: Four people were reported killed and at least 91 were injured this morning when an 11-car Amtrak passenger train derailed nine miles north of this East Texas city.

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from about 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States. And Bear in Mind

title: ;  Re-Regulating the Skyways
description: To the Business Editor:

title: O'ROURKE: 'NO INTENTION OF DOING A HOUSECLEANING'
description: WHITE PLAINS THE voice that answered the campaign telephone a day after last week's election said, ''Reid for County Executive, except we're not.''

title: GRENADA INVASION CREATES RIFTS IN THE CARIBBEAN
description: Caribbean officials say the invasion of Grenada has caused new rifts among the countries of the Caribbean and appears to have set back efforts for political and economic cooperation in the area.

title: TRANSPLANTS RAISE MEDICAID QUESTION
description: AS a result of Yale-New Haven Hospital's new liver-transplant program, Connecticut has become involved in a national debate over whether liver transplants for the poor should be paid for by the state and Federal Governments.

title: F.C.C. RULING CALLED BARRIER TO SPREAD OF CABLE TV
description: Residents of rural and low-income areas will have difficulty getting cable television service because of a ruling last week by the Federal Communications Commission, according to state officials who have a role in overseeing the industry in New York and New Jersey.

title: A MOTHER'S REFORM PLAN: DOWN WITH CUPCAKES AND BIRDS
description: IT IS amazing. All those panels and commissions have managed to study the problem of educational mediocrity without being distracted by a single, original thought. There is nothing new about merit pay or special recognition for highly capable teachers. Longer school days and years have been tried before. In my day, they called it detention and summer school. I'm all for recycling, but such ideas deserve a proper burial.

title: Laurie Shaffer to Wed Randall Scott Whiting
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Fiske Shaffer of Suffield, Conn., formerly of Brooklyn Heights, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Laurie Robbins Shaffer, to Randall Scott Whiting, son of Mr. and Mrs. David R. Whiting of Clinton, N.Y.

title: PUBLIC TV MAY COME TO DEPEND ON ADVERTISING
description: The Temporary Commission on Alternative Financing for Public Telecommunications, or TCAF, as it came to be known, has reported to Congress on whether public television should be allowed to carry advertisements. TCAF said it should not. On the other hand, it did not say this particularly vehemently, and even as it made the case for why public television should not carry advertisements, it seemed to be making an equally compelling case for why it should. One had the impression, reading the report, that TCAF wished the question had not come up in the first place.

title: Miss Merrell Has Nuptials
description: Leslie Drayton Merrell, daughter of Alida Van Laer Kilburn of New York and Cyrus Walbridge Merrell Jr. of Santa Fe, N.M., was married yesterday to Mark Robert Zimmerman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Zimmerman of Chapel Hill, N.C. The Rev. Paul C. Hewett, rector of the Anglican Church of the Advent in Rye Brook, N.Y., performed the ceremony at the Brick Presbyterian Church in Manhattan.

title: Andrea Pedone Marries Francis T. O'Halloran 3d
description: Andrea Dawn Pedone, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Edward Pedone of Yonkers and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Francis Thomas O'Halloran 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. O'Halloran 2d of Rumford, R.I. The ceremony at Christ the King Roman Catholic Church in Yonkers was performed by the Rev. James P. Griffin, the bride's cousin, and the Rev. William J. O'Halloran, the bridegroom's uncle.

title: MONEY FOR OPERA AND MUSIC THEATER
description: The Opera-Musical Theater Program of the National Endowment for the Arts has announced a total of $5 million in grants to assist professional opera and music theater companies and to support regional touring and other neccessary services. In addition, 37 grants totalling $580,205 will be awarded to encourage the production of new musical theater in the United States.

title: DETECTIVE FROM A FOUNDING FAMILY
description: UNCIVIL SEASONS

title: SHUFFLING PATIENTS
description: When Montefiore Hospital and Medical Center embarked on an extensive expansion program a few years ago with only a limited amount of available land in its Bronx neighborhood, it adopted a plan that combined demolition and renovation as well as new construction.

title: NAKASONE PLANS TO CALL ELECTION NEXT MONTH
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone decided today to dissolve the lower house of Parliament before the end of the month and call general elections for Dec. 18 to seek a new mandate for his year-old conservative Government, officials close to Mr. Nakasone said.

title: FICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE TENTH VIRGIN

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
SILVER FIT FOR A MEDICI
description: Silversmiths have flourished in Florence since the time of the Medicis. Today they are still practicing their art on the left bank of the Arno. This, the traditional artisan quarter of Florence is a warren of little streets between the Pitti Palace and the Church of San Frediano. Most of these workshops are hidden behind nameless facades where black- overalled craftsmen stoop over wooden tables, chiseling and polishing the silver pieces that are sold in stores all over the world, from the jumble of shops on the Ponte Vecchio to Tiffany's in New York.

title: STUDENT EVACUEES RESUME CLASSES
description: CLASSES have resumed at the St. George's University School of Medicine - not at its evacuated campus in Grenada, but at three separate host campuses in New York and New Jersey.

title:
ANTIQUES;
SPECULATORS CAUSED HIGH RUG PRICES
description: HIGHLIGHTED in Sotheby Parke Bernet's sale of 19th-century and some 18th-century Oriental rugs and carpets were 35 lots from the collection of the late Karl Milde of Litchfield. Much of the collection, gathered in the 1930's, has been on exhibit at various times at the Asia House in New York City and the textile museum in Washington D.C.

title: THE JEWS OF FRANCE --
description: My family was fortunate to be in Paris this past spring, and to be present at the Passover seder described by Paul Lewis.

title: READING DEVICES ACQUIRED
description: VISUALLY impaired people in the New Haven area may soon find reading easier because of the Xerox Corporation's gift of two Kurzweil Reading Machines to Yale University and Southern Connecticut State University.

title: ACRE BY ACRE, STATE IS LOSING ITS TREES
description: FROM the hardwood swamps and pine forests of Cumberland County to the scarlet and gold woodlands of northern Bergen County, more than just autumn leaves are falling.

title: A TEST OF WILL
description: BY A. ALVAREZ A. Alvarez is the author most recently of ''The Biggest Game in Town'' (Houghton Mifflin). HARVEY DINNERSTEIN

title: HELPING THE FOSTER CHILD AT COLLEGE...
description: CHARLES CHAMBERS, a foster child raised in New York City, thought his only options when he graduated from high school last year were to join the armed forces or get a job. He knew that foster-care funds provided to the family he lived with would stop at age 18, unless he went to college. If he did, room, board, books and travel would be paid up to age 21, but not tuition.

title: NATO AFTER GRENADA
description: In the U.S., our successful action blocking Cuba's takeover of Grenada has met with the approval of all but our most die-hard doves; in Europe, however, President Reagan's decision to prevent further Communist penetration of this hemisphere has met with disapproval from what we thought were our most reliable allies.

title:
THE REGION;
TRAVEL ADVISORY: BRING MONEY
description: The cost of moving around the region is about to go up, transit officials said last week, taking a toll on most everyone except walkers and bicyclists. On East River bridges and tunnels, tolls may rise by 25 cents - in effect a subsidy so fare increases for subway, bus and commuter rail riders won't have to be quite so high as some had predicted.

title: PLEASING FARE IN 'DINING ROOM'
description: THEATER THREE in Port Jefferson is offering a sterling production of A. R. Gurney Jr.'s ''Dining Room.'' This comedy-drama is a series of vignettes, memories and ghosts of meals and deals that have taken place over generations in a formal dining room.

title: CITY'S ANIMAAL AFFAIRS AGENCY ASSUMES NEW TASKS
description: On his first day as director of the city's Bureau of Animal Affairs, Martin B. Kurtz got a call from a man who said his wife had awakened with a snake on her head.

title: ISRAELI POLICEMEN KILL 2 PALESTINIAN YOUTHS AFTER ROCK-THROWING
description: Israeli border policemen shot and killed two Palestinian youths today after a rock- throwing incident in the Israeli-occupied West Bank.

title: Turkey
description: To the Editor:

title: OFF BY A FEW FEET
description: It was some put down for Frank Lorenzo , chairman of Continental Airlines. Mr. Lorenzo, who has been battling striking pilots over work- rule changes aimed at saving money, was aboard a Continental flight that landed on a taxiway instead of a runway at Denver's Stapleton Airport last week. No one was hurt and there was no damage (the taxiway is as long as the runway but only half as wide).

title: ON LANGUAGE
description: A Czar Is Not a Tsar KEITH BENDIS

title: A FINALE AT RIVERDALE
description: Carried on the shoulders of his players and with television cameras from three New York channels recording the event, Frank Bertino's last game as coach of the Riverdale School ended on a high note yesterday as the undefeated Indians downed Fordham Prep, 28-6. The overflow crowd of more than 2,000 at the winner's field, most on hand to honor Bertino for his highly-successful 40 years as coach of the Bronx preparatory school, gave the popular Albright College alumnus a standing ovation and later attended a reception for him at the school.

title: ADAM S. C. HULTON
description: Adam S. C. Hulton, a retired executive with the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, died of a liver ailment Thursday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Christine Berry Is a Bride
description: Christine Marie Berry, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Lloyd Berry 4th of Wynnewood, Pa., New York and Tucker's Town, Bermuda, was married yesterday to Charles Wesley Welsh 3d, son of Gayle S. Stewart of Wayne, Pa., and Mr. Welsh 2d of the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia. The Rev. Nils Blatz performed the ceremony in the chapel of St. David's Episcopal Church in Wayne.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE ;
 CRAFTS FESTIVAL
description: It's billed as a Crafts Festival - and more than 100 craftsmen will display, demonstrate and sell their wares - but the Arts Council at Freeport's annual event today is actually multimedia. There will be performances by the Camerata Youth Orchestra of Mozart, Bach and the world premiere of Andante for String Orchestra by Glenn Rubin, which was commissioned to mark the orchestra's fifth anniversary; concerts by the Long Island Musical Ensemble and the poet-guitarist Enoch Terris; workshops for children; an antiques critique and even the crowning of the Freeport Flower Festival Queen. All this takes place between 11 A.M. and 5 P.M. at the village's recreation center, 130 East Merrick Road, and is free. SHALL WE DANCE?

title: WESTERN JOURNALISM ISN'T NEWS TO THE THIRD WORLD
description: Evelyn Waugh's novel ''Scoop,'' written in the 1930's after a tour in Ethiopia as a war correspondent, has become the classic description of the often clownish relationship between a third world government and those trying to report on it. The novel is still valid but perhaps not so comical in the light of the debate raging over the third world's efforts to establish ''a new world information and communications order.''

title: FOR VIETNAM VETERANS, ADVICE AND PRIDE
description: AT first it seemed an improbable tenant on the ground floor of the White Plains Mall, nestled among a bank, a golf goods shop and a discount variety store.

title: THE BOY WHO BECAME A MOUSE
description: THE WITCHES, By Roald Dahl. Illustrated by Quentin Blake. 202 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $10.95. (Ages 9 and Up)

title: Corn Dollies
description: To the Editor: After reading Michael Sterne's article ''Corn Dollies: An Ancient Craft'' (Travel, Oct. 2), I feel compelled to inform your readers that they can save the air fare to Eng

title: NEW HAND AT PRESERVING THE PAST IS HOPEFUL ON FUTURE
description: GENE A. NORMAN, an architect and former executive vice president of the Harlem Urban Development Corporation, took office Aug. 15 as chairman of the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission. He is facing the designations of an Upper West Side Historic District, Rockefeller Center and as many as 42 theaters, and legislation to exempt religious institutions from landmark designation. Recently he discussed his first months on the job.

title: PENGUINS END ISLANDER STREAK
description: The warning signs began Tuesday night against Philadelphia, when the Islanders allowed 41 shots. Friday night in Pittsburgh, the Penguins nearly doubled the Islander offense, with a 43-22 margin in shots. Still, the Islanders kept winning.

title: GUITAR: MITCHELL KORN IN SOLO
description: Mitchell Korn is a man in love with his instrument. At his solo concert Wednesday in the Museum of Natural History, he spoke fondly of the ''great big sound of the 12-string guitar.''

title: WILLIAM BROCK: OUR MAN FOR TRADE
description: Clyde H. Farnsworth is a reporter in the Washington bureau of The Times. By Clyde H. Farnsworth N ELONGATED BOX, wrapped in white paper and a rose-red ribbon, was in the possession of a party of Americans when they went to the Kasumigaseki quarter of Tokyo. Getting out of the flag-bedecked, black Cadillac, four men, including Ambassador Mike Mansfield, trooped into the lobby of an 11-story, brick-and-glass building across an intersection from the Foreign Office and were greeted by a group of dark-suited Japanese trade officials.

title: BRITISH HOLIDAYS
description: To the Editor:

title: Taken for Prowler, Girl Shot
description: Laura Hardin, 8 years old, shot by her stepfather, was in critical condition today in a hospital. Quinton Palmer told the police he saw a prowler outside early Friday and went to his stepdaughter's room with his pistol after he heard a noise. The police ruled the shooting an accident.

title: FROM ST. NICHOLAS TO LITTLE WILLIE

title: TEACHERS LEARN ABOUT ABUSE
description: NEWTON THE Family Life Program of the state's Department of Education requires public- school teachers this year to introduce in their classrooms topics such as ''child abuse,'' ''sexual assault'' and ''incest.''

title: McCall's 246 Yards Help Pitt Top Army
description: Joe McCall rushed for 246 yards and two touchdowns today as Pitt (8-2) won its sixth consecutive game, 38-7 over Army.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: -cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.
