title: Stallworth Hurt Again, Will Miss Colts Game
description: The veteran wide receiver John Stallworth, who missed six games because of hamstring problems before returning to the Pittsburgh Steeler lineup last week, will be watching from the sidelines again Sunday.

title: RECONCILING FREE TRADE WITH HELP FOR AMERICAN INDUSTRIES
description: WASHINGTON APPARENTLY, William H.

title: Article 033568 -- No Title
description: Russia: A People Without Heroes

title: Robin Yuder To Be Bride
description: Mr. and Mrs. Paul Yuder of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Lynn Yuder, to Steven George Minskoff, son of Lillian Minskoff and Jerome Minskoff, both of New York. A spring wedding is planned.

title: Miss Schellbach To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lewis C. Schellbach of Manhasset, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kathryn Anne Schellbach, to Henry Pendleton Rogers, son of Howland P. Rogers of Tuxedo Park, N.Y., and Harriet Clay of East Hampton, L.I.

title: Q&A Rights in a Sublet Question:
description: I want to sublet my apartment, but the management insists on writing the sublease with the sublessee. Will this affect my right to buy the apartment if the condominium conversion is completed? . . . K.V.B., Manhattan

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: ERMA BOMBECK has written seven books of humor, the last several of which have sold spectacularly well. Consider: ''The Grass Is Always Greener Over the Septic Tank'' (1976) was on the New York Times best-seller list for 26 weeks. ''If Life Is a Bowl of Cherries, What Am I Doing in the Pits?'' (1978) was there for 49 weeks. ''Aunt Erma's Cope Book'' (1979) was on for 39 weeks. Each of the three titles sold between 500,000 and 700,000 copies in hardcover.

title: FOR VETERANS OF WORLD WAR II, TOURS OF THEIR BATTLEFIELDS
description: Bob Reynolds knows only too well why World War II veterans want to return to the scenes of bloody battles where they fought for their country and to stay alive.

title: IN THE NEW YORK REGION: PLANS ON HOLD
description: THOSE who ultimately make the decisions about public policy - the politicians who control the pursestrings - say they agree with the educational reformers that it is time to improve the schools. But in the three-state New York metropolitan area, that newly heightened political interest in education has yet to be translated into the kinds of sweeping changes already made in other states.

title: BEGIN OUT OF POWER: A PORTRAIT OF GRIM SECLUSION
description: The big stone house at 3 Balfour Street is quiet now.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS ;
SOME BRIGHT NEWS ABOUT ELECTRICITY
description: Commercial solar power is coming of age in sunny California, slowly and without much national notice. The world's largest photovoltaic plant will start generating electricity this month near San Luis Obispo, according to its owner, Arco Solar Power Production Inc.

title: HOUSTON IS AT FIVE PLAGUES AND COUNTING
description: In the beginning was the plague of recession in oil, gas and real estate. Then came a tornado and afterwards a hurricane. The floods followed. Houstonians began saying that the world was coming to an end. This week a swarm of locusts arrived to prove them right, at least those who go by the Bible on such matters.

title: CRANBERRIES: BEYOND HOLIDAY SEASONS
description: AS much as the cranberry producers on Cape Cod, in New Jersey, the Middle West and Northwest would like people to consider their product for use year round, cranberries still suffer as much from the tyranny of the seasons as pumpkins and minced meat. Bags of the glossy red berries appear in markets in the fall, and by mid-winter they start to become scarce. Because they freeze beautifully right in the original package and keep for many months from one season to the next there is no excuse for not having them on hand.

title: NEW YORK'S IMPACT II SPREADS A WIDE NET
description: AT the sound of the chime, a half- dozen students at Public School 155 in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn broadcast the morning news, along with selected features, over the school's public-address system. The subjects range from the weather to consumerism (such as local comparison-shopping for jeans), to a student-written biography of Harriet Beecher Stowe.

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: Senate

title: AUTHOR FROM 3 COUNTRIES
description: Salman Rushdie was interviewed in Toronto by Michael T. Kaufman, The Times's Ottawa bureau chief, who was based in India from 1979 to 1982.

title: JERSEY REPORTS DELAY ON DIOXIN HEALTH TESTS
description: State health officials say they still do not have some results of medical tests given nearly five months ago to 88 people who worked at or near a dioxincontaminated former herbicide manufacturing plant in Newark.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: The Wild West Opens a Branch In Sunny Spain

title: JAZZ: JAMES WILLIAMS ON PIANO AT ZINNO
description: During his four years with Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers and, currently, with the trumpeter Jon Faddis's new group, James Williams has been playing piano in settings that call for strong, percussive statements and a broad, relatively flamboyant style.

title: No Headline
description: Elizabeth Nugent Wed

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Business Day Wednesday incorrectly characterized the debt position of Southwestern Bell. It will have the second-heaviest debt burden of the seven Bell operating companies, after the Pacific Telesis Group.

title: THE KENNEDY REALITY
description: For millions of Americans, and more millions around the world, there has been an aching void in political leadership since Nov. 22, 1963. No American President since John Kennedy has had anything like his ability to touch the hearts of people across the divides of culture, and none is in sight.

title: OILERS FINALLY WIN
description: Oliver Luck, making his first pro start, completed two touchdown passes as the Houston Oilers snapped a 17-game losing streak with a 27-17 victory today over the Detroit Lions.

title: Islanders Lack Enthusiasm
description: Lou Nanne was laughing. The Minnesota North Stars' general manager had enjoyed what he had just seen in Pittsburgh Friday night where the Islanders played the Penguins.

title: JESSE JACKSON'S OPPORTUNITY
description: To the Editor:

title: A PROGRAM TO TURN YOUNGSTERS INTO THEATERGOERS
description: Alfonso Ribeiro, who is 12 years old, is in the seventh grade at Intermediate School 141 in the Bronx.

title: CUBA SETS FIVE DAYS OF MOURNING FOR ITS DEAD
description: Cuba declared five days of mourning today as it prepared for the return to Havana of Cubans killed resisting the American-led invasion of Grenada.

title: DECALS TO THE RESCUE
description: To the Editor:

title: Mozambique Halts Flights
description: Mozambique's national airline said today that it had suspended all flights within the country indefinitely. No reason was given, but oil company sources said there was a shortage of fuel for the airline's three Boeing 737's.

title: British Retail Prices Up
description: British retail prices rose four-tenths of 1 percent in October after an equivalent September increase, according to the Employment Department. The annual rate of increase slowed to 5 percent last month, from 5.1 percent in September, it said.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Alter Egos

title: DRUG CONTROL BRINGS CONTROVERSY
description: LAST month, a small group of prominent American track and field athletes volunteered to submit to drug-control tests by a physician attached to the United States Olympic Committee's Task Force on Drug Control.

title: BILLS RALLY TO DEFEAT JETS, 24-17
description: The Buffalo Bills played so foolishly yesterday that their coach apologized for his poor performance. And still, like most teams this season, they found a way to beat the Jets.

title: KNICKS' WALKER IS IMPRESSIVE
description: Darrell Walker has drawn attention from assistant coaches and pro scouts as they travel the country preparing their early-season scouting reports.

title: CHALLENGING THE GIFTED PUPIL
description: America cannot afford to risk wasting the talents of the nation's gifted students by ignoring their needs, Senator Christopher J. Dodd says.

title: PRESIDENT SEEKING NEW TURF FOR BLAIR
description: Donald S. Erenberg's task when he was hired as president and chief operating officer of D. H. Blair & Company was to make it bigger, expand its corporate finance operations and push into other brokerage areas - retail and institutional sales, research and tax shelters.

title: Sachs & Rosen Spots For Van Heusen JeansWhen the Van Heusen Company, part of the Phillips-Van Heusen Corporation, takes to the TV airwaves in this area Wednesday on behalf of its new Cacharel jeans for men, it will mark quite a departure for jeans advertising. But, then, as explained by Ellery Gordon, president of the Cacharel division, the target audience he is pursuing is quite a departure too.
description: Cacharel is after the over-35, no- longer-firm-fleshed males of the regular guy variety who like jeans but not necessarily rock music or the rock scene.

title: THE GRENADA PAYOFF
description: The results of last week's scattered elections may really have been ''good news'' to the Democratic national chairman, Chuck Manatt, but he sounds as if he's whistling past the graveyard. The fact is that if the Presidential election were to be held tomorrow, Ronald Reagan probably would win going away.

title: 76ERS SET BACK CLIPPERS
description: Julius Erving's two free throws four minutes into overtime put the Philadelphia 76ers ahead to stay, and they downed the San Diego Clippers, 124-116, tonight in the National Basketball Association.

title: TRUDEAU SAYS ALLIES SUPPORT PLAN TO END IMPASSE OVER ARMS
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau said today that Western European leaders had expressed broad support for his proposals to end the impasse between Moscow and Washington over arms control.

title: A REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: REAGAN'S VISIT IS A TOUR DE FORCE FOR THE IMAGE MAKERS
description: If all the world's a stage, then President Reagan has just played the palace and the troops in the trenches in the same week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It wasn't Camelot, but we shared our questions and our struggles.'' - Suzanne Elsesser on meeting between Roman Catholic women and bishops. (B7:4.)

title: Skid Row Killings Trial To Open After 4 Years
description: Trial was scheduled to begin Monday in the long-delayed case of Bobby Joe Maxwell, charged in the murders of 10 male transients in 1978-79.

title: NEW FILM ON EFFECTS OF NUCLEAR WAR IS PLANNED
description: Movie rights to ''War Day,'' an unpublished novel about the ways in which people manage to survive after a nuclear war, have been purchased by Keith Barish, a real estate entrepreneur turned Hollywood producer. The movie will be directed by the controversial film maker Constantin Costa- Gavras, who was nominated for an Academy Award in 1969 for ''Z.''

title: Miller Will Leave Top Olympic Post
description: F. Don Miller, 63-year-old executive director of the United States Olympic Committee, will resign after the 1984 Games in Los Angeles, a committee spokesman said today.

title: CommoditiesH. J. Maidenberg A Rebound Is Seen For Gold
description: THE price of gold bullion finally

title: REAGAN GIVES VOW OF SOLID SUPPORT TO SOUTH KOREANS
description: President Reagan, ending a two- day visit to this country, pledged ''steadfast support'' today for South Korea and said he would strengthen the United States forces stationed here.

title: Client Conflict Ends Nadler-Calet TalksNadler & Larimer and Calet, Hirsch & Spector each announced Friday that they had called off their merger discussions, saying they were unable to resolve the client conflict arising because each represents a liquor importing company.
description: According to Larry Spector, the negotiators had tried to find a way to continue to service Monsieur Henri Wines, a subsidiary of Pepsico, which is at C.H. & S., and Austin Nichols & Company, a subsidiary of Pernod Richard of France, which is at N. & L.

title: Treasury List Is Small; Tax-Exempts Heavy
description: Investors and traders in the Treasury market will enjoy a brief hiatus in note and bond financings this week, after absorbing $16 billion of new three-, 10- and 30-year issues last week.

title: AT THE BARBER SHOP, TALK ABOUT GRENADA
description: Two parliamentary institutions disagreed about the United States incursion into Grenada. The General Assembly of the United Nations was clearly disapproving, but President Reagan's action was supported by the parliamentarians at the Courthouse Barber Shop.

title: ; APPIAN WAY: BUILT TO RESIST POTHOLES
description: To the Editor:

title: Arrows Lose, 8-2, To Extend Slump
description: Vic Davidson scored three goals, all in the second half, to lead the Cleveland Force to a 8-2 victory over the New York Arrows in a Major Indoor Soccer League game tonight before 6,100 fans at Nassau Coliseum.

title: PANEL SELECTS 3 FOR FIRST SHIELD OF JERUSALEM PRIZES
description: Henry M. Jackson, the late Senator from Washington; Yosef Begun, an imprisoned Soviet dissident, and Simone Veil, a former French Cabinet minister, were named yesterday as winners of the first Shield of Jerusalem prizes for their ''defense of the rights of the Jewish people.''

title: A Rose-Colored Recovery
description: There's been a rush of good news about the economy, most conspicuously the unexpected October plunge in the rate of unemployment. Were the gloomsayers just dead wrong? Yes. Is the economy out of the woods? Far from it.

title: ONCE-HOSTILE VATICAN FORGES CLOSE LINKS WITH SCIENTISTS
description: Catholic women's representatives and bishops met to discuss women's role in the church. Page B7.

title: Medicines for Arthritis Go Beyond Symptoms
description: New medicines to control inflammation in arthritis patients may also correct underlying immune deficiencies associated with the disease, according to doctors in New Mexico.

title: ROCK: GERMAN GROUP TRIO
description: ONE ordinarily thinks of German rock in terms of portentous, technologically sophisticated synthesizer music by groups like Kraftwerk and Tangerine Dream. But the German group called Trio that appeared at the Ritz on Friday has created a splash with a minimalist style it jokingly calls ''the New Happiness.''

title: CITY'S COACH HAILS RENEWED RIVALRY
description: When the basketball rivalry between New York University and City College resumes on Nov. 26, Floyd Layne says it will be one of the warmest moments of his career.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Labor of Love?

title: NEW SUIT QUESTIONS MANVILLE TACTICS
description: A recent court filing in the Manville Corporation's bankruptcy proceeding charges that the company has tried for years to avoid its liability for the asbestos injuries that its workers developed. In the process, the filing says, Manville used tactics of questionable legality and morality.

title: U.S. WARNS SYRIA IT WILL RESPOND TO SHOTS AT JETS
description: President Reagan's national security adviser, Robert C. McFarlane, warned today that neither Syria nor any other nation could attack United States forces with impunity.

title: CORRECTIONS
description: Because of a production error, the stock prices listed yesterday for the New York Stock Exchange in Section 3, Business, reflected daily trading activity Friday rather than figures for the full week. The correct figures appear today beginning on pages D4 and D13.

title: DANCE: TULSA BALLET THEATER IN NEW YORK DEBUT
description: THE Tulsa Ballet Theater is directed by Roman Jasinski and Moscelyne Larkin, who were leading dancers in the De Basil Ballets Russes de Monte Carlo and the rival Ballet Russe de Monte Carlo, headed by Serge Denham.

title: GRENADA INVASION: A SERIES OF SURPRISES
description: Sgt. Tom Wilburn was hanging in his parachute, 400 feet above the island of Grenada, when he concluded that the United States invasion of that small, lush dot in the Caribbean was not going to be the pushover that he had expected.

title: Mayor in Italy Is Arrested
description: Magistrates investigating links between the Mafia and a number of Italian casinos have arrested the Mayor of Campione d'Italia, a millionaires' gambling resort on Lake Lugano. The arrest of Mayor Sergio Costioli and his deputy Saturday night brings to 25 the number of casino executives and public figures detained since the operation began Friday.

title: MAKING A BAD DAY BETTER
description: IT'S 7 A.M. The toast is burning, the

title: Bridge:Point Range in No-Trump Can Make a Big Difference
description: Every beginner learns, usually in his first lesson, that a one no-trump opening bid promises 16-18 high-card points. In tournament play that was 99 percent true back in the 1950's, but then diversification set in.

title: Police Said to Open Fire On a Pakistani Rally
description: Policemen fired on a rally and protesters set off a bomb as opponents of Pakistan's military Government tried to revive a 13-week drive for free elections, opposition sources said today.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Computer Products Inc. said its computer overseas finance subsidiary would offer $20 million of convertible subordinated bonds in the Eurodollar market, through Robinson Humphrey/American Express, Shearson/American Express International, Morgan Grenfell & Co. and Banque Paribas.

title: MCDOWELL CHIEF QUITS; CHARTER SOUGHT OUSTER
description: Floyd W. Kephart Jr. has resigned as chairman and chief executive officer of McDowell Enterprises, a Nashville construction company.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: A Sure Shot

title: TENSIONS THAT SERVE THE 'NATIONAL INTEREST' OF NORTH KOREA
description: To the Editor:

title: Fleming Captures Shore Marathon
description: Tom Fleming of Bloomfield, N.J., won the Jersey Shore Marathon for the third time as he led a field of more than 2,000 runners across the finish line today in 2 hours 17 minutes 55 seconds.

title: COMPUTER HACKERS DESERVING OF MEDALS
description: To the Editor:

title: RATHER CITES WHITE HOUSE CRITICISM
description: Dan Rather, anchorman of the ''CBS Evening News,'' said his network's news division has been subject to ''unrelenting'' criticism from the Reagan Administration. ''There is certainly criticism, and certainly pressure'' said Mr. Rather. ''I guess we get more than either one of the other two networks.''

title: NEW ASSERTION IN BARBIE CASE
description: A lawyer defending the Nazi war criminal Klaus Barbie said in an interview Saturday night that a French Resistance hero committed suicide after being betrayed by his comrades.

title: 6 EX-GIANTS AID THE REDSKINS
description: On Washington's drive for its first score against the Giants today, Nick Giaquinto caught a pass for a 17- yard gain to the 2. When John Riggins bolted into the end zone on the next play, Otis Wonsley blocked Mark Haynes out of the way.

title: Pilots' Group Firm on Strike
description: The Air Line Pilots Association would like to settle its strike against Continental Airlines but is ready to continue the walkout indefinitely, according to the association's president, Henry Duffy.

title: A Correction
description: The correct telephone number for the U.S. Naval Observatory Master Clock mentioned in a Topics item yesterday is 900-410-TIME.

title: U.S. CONDUCTS GRENADA CAMP FOR QUESTIONING
description: In the nearly three weeks since the invasion of this Caribbean island, American troops have detained more than 1,100 Grenadians and Cubans for interrogation. The prisoners were held in a camp equipped with wooden interview booths and boxlike isolation chambers with small holes for ventilation. American military officials said that 74 prisoners were released from the camp today, leaving only 100 of the total still in custody there. Thirty-one others, said by officials to include a number of high-ranking officials of the former Government of Prime Minister Maurice Bishop, were transferred to the island's Richmond Hill prison.

title: Required Reading How Big the Deficit?
description: Representative Charles E. Grassley, Republican of Iowa, in a press release describing the size of the Federal deficit for the fiscal year 1983, Oct. 27, 1983:

title: SENATOR BAKER AND THE 'WET NOODLE'
description: Senator Howard H. Baker Jr. was not happy the other day when he took the Senate floor to complain about the slow pace of legislative activity. As majority leader, the Tennessee Republican was particularly perturbed by the failure of his colleagues to pass a bill raising the national debt ceiling.

title: PAT BRADLEY WINS BY 7 SHOTS IN JAPAN
description: Pat Bradley shot a final-round 64 today and won the Mazda Japan Golf Classic by seven strokes with 206.

title: STUDY CITES VENGEANCE AS KEY FACTOR IN ARSON
description: Half the arson fires in New York City residences are set out of ''personal vengeance or other emotional ventings,'' city officials have concluded. They said this meant that New York ''will always face a significant level of arson'' that cannot be prevented.

title: Sachem Gains Playoffs
description: Sachem High School was declared the Suffolk County Division I-League I champion by virtue of a drawing of lots held yesterday. Sachem and Brentwood finished the season Saturday with 6-0-1 records, but because of a 1981 ruling by the county's football committee, only one of them can make the playoffs.

title: MCENROE DEFEATS CONNORS IN FINAL
description: John McEnroe scored a straight-set victory over Jimmy Connors, who seemed to lose spirit after having been fined for swearing, in the final of the $315,000 Wembley Grand Prix tennis tournament today.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: -hunt season in England? Again? Well, here's a chance to catch up on the institution, all in glowing colors, with redcoats (hunters) on magnificent horses being guided by lithe hounds after the quarry. Forget the countryside and go downtown to the Dog Museum of America, 51 Madison Avenue, at 27th Street (696-8350), where fox-hunting is very much in evidence.

title: BUCKLING PIPES
description: The financial underpinnings of the nation's municipal water and sewage systems are rotting away. If a major renovation does not begin soon, efforts at environmental protection and urban renewal will - like old sewer lines - crack, buckle and eventually collapse. The Potomac and Ohio Rivers are among several major rivers that may revert to the poisonous states from which they just emerged.

title: Advertising; CBS Unit's Publishers Lead Shifts
description: PETER G. DIAMANDIS, president since Sept. 27 of CBS Consumer Publications, announced several key executive appointments over the weekend, including the naming of four publishers. He said the changes were in line with his desire to streamline the company and make it into a fast-paced consumer-oriented organization.

title: JEWELRY INSPIRED BY TREASURE OF TROY
description: At the end of World War II, the celebrated treasures of Troy, excavated in the 19th century by the German archeologist Heinrich Schliemann and stored in a Berlin Museum, vanished, perhaps never to be recovered. The treasures remain the most massive documentation of the wealth and culture of Anatolian civilization in the third millenium.

title: 130,000 Diseased Chickens Slaughtered in Pennsylvania
description: In an effort to contain a deadly and highly contagious disease, the slaughter of chickens in southeastern Pennsylvania has begun, Federal and state officials said today.

title: RANGERS SPOIL RED WINGS' REUNION, 6-3
description: For Ed Mio, Ron Duguay and Ed Johnstone, it was a miserable homecoming at Madison Square Garden last night. In their first game against the Rangers since New York traded them to Detroit last June, none of the three played particularly well, and the Rangers won handily, 6-3.

title: WilliamR.FisherJr.,47,Dies; Wall St. Securities Executive
description: William R. Fisher Jr., executive vice president and chairman of the finance committee of the securities firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, died of cancer Saturday at St. Barnabas Hospital in Livingston, N.J. He was 47 years old and lived in Summit, N.J.

title: CABARET: PEGGY HEWETT
description: FOR the last six years, Peggy Hewett has been developing a comic style that stems largely from her ability to pay serious attention to songs that were never meant to be taken quite as seriously as she takes them. However, in her act at the Ballroom, ''Peggy Hewett's New Tropical Revue,'' a theme that is carried out by the presence of such songs as ''Carioca,'' ''Hot Voodoo,'' ''Dear Old Southland'' and ''I Never Has Seen Snow,'' she is giving greater display to her ''straight'' singing so as to bring more balance to her program than it has had before.

title: Barbara Pollack and Joel Berger, Lawyers, Marry
description: Barbara Ruth Pollack, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Pollack of Cedarhurst, L.I., was married yesterday to Joel Berger, son of Lillian Berger Goldberg of Jamaica Estates, Queens, and the late Judge M. Marvin Berger. Rabbi Joan Friedman performed the ceremony at the Water Club in Manhattan.

title: Col. John Roosma Dead at 83; Basketball Star at West Point
description: Col. John S. Roosma, a retired Army commander on Governors Island and a member of the National Basketball Hall of Fame, died yesterday at his home in Verona, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: A BAD TIME FOR QUEENIE
description: IT'S hunting season around Rochester, New

title: ARAFAT SAYS HIS FORCES HELD 6 ISRAELIS IN AREA UNDER ARTILLERY FIRE
description: As negotiations continued here to end the violent Palestinian confrontation, Yasir Arafat said today that his forces had been holding six previously captured Israeli soldiers in an area that has been under artillery fire for the last 10 days.

title: OPEC Price Outlook
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is likely to keep its benchmark price of $29 a barrel unchanged for most of 1984, assuming there is no serious worsening of political tensions in the Middle East, according to the HWWA Economic Institute. But the price could rise toward the end of the year if the recovery in Western economies continued, the institute said.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the meaning of a sentence in Ira Berkow's Sports of The Times column in yesterday's sports section was changed. The sentence, referring to Larry O'Brien, should have read ''And he said then that, well, he wasn't denigrating the job of commissioner of basketball, which is challenging, but he'll be honest - it's not politics.''

title: Globe-Democrat Worker Suggests Buying Paper
description: A copy editor at The St. Louis Globe-Democrat said Saturday he would attempt to organize a group of employees and investors to purchase the newspaper and keep it from closing.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Who's Who on Court

title: DERAILMENT LINKED TO SPLIT IN RAIL REPAIRED SAME DAY
description: The derailment of an Amtrak passenger train that killed four people Saturday morning occurred when a section of rail that had been repaired earlier in the day apparently split apart, officials said here today.

title: MUSIC: VIRGIL THOMSON'S 87TH BIRTHDAY CONCERT
description: ONE of the first questions that Virgil Thomson asked the film maker Pare Lorentz back in 1936 after being approached to write a film score was, ''How much money have you got?'' Mr. Lorentz was delighted. ''All those highflyers,'' he said to Mr. Thomson, referring to other composers he had consulted, ''all those high-flyers talk nothing but esthetics. You talk about money; you're a professional.''

title: S.M.U. MAY BE IGNORED BY MAJOR BOWLS
description: Southern Methodist, with an 8-1 record this season and only two losses in 32 games during the last three seasons, may not be invited to a major bowl game Jan. 2, and this has the Mustangs fit to be tied.

title: New Deal for Permian ;  By Reuters
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation will announce today a new agreement to sell its Permian Corporation subsidiary, Occidental's chairman, Armand Hammer, said yesterday. He said the new deal is better than the failed, $375 million agreement to sell Permian to the First City Financial Corporation of Canada.

title: ORDER TO REIMPRISON WOMAN IS FOUGHT WITH PETITION DRIVE
description: In the last year, Bernice Lane has had three raises in her job as a rental agent's assistant. She has a neat two- bedroom apartment, takes care of her invalid mother, attends college three nights a week and, in her spare time, delivers meals to homebound elderly people. She is also on the board of directors of a center for the aged.

title: OPPOSITION PARTIES ARE WINNING IN PERU
description: Left- wing and center-left parties scored major victories in Peru's municipal elections today and the ruling party of President Fernando Belaunde Terry conceded defeat.

title: HOMELESS BRAVING WINTER IN ALASKA
description: They are known as the ''cold people,'' and in the winters here some of them die.

title: ROCKEFELLERS RESTYLE FUND FOR THE 1980'S
description: The Rockefeller Brothers Fund, one of the country's wealthiest foundations, has adopted a ''strategy for the 80's'' to accommodate the interests and style of a fourth generation of Rockefellers.

title: New Drugs, New Problems
description: The head of the United States Olympic Committee's Athletes Advisory Council says the fight against drug use by athletes would be a continuing battle because of the constant discovery of new chemical derivatives.

title: U.S. STEEL'S OIL-PIPE GAMBLE
description: The rust- brown blast furnaces and gray sheet mill stand eerily quiet along the interstate highway nine miles west of Birmingham. But 18 months after being closed by the United States Steel Corporation, this two-square-mile complex, known as the Fairfield Works, is being reborn.

title: Radio Stations Push 35-to-64 Market Study
description: The 18-to-49 age group has been held up for so long by marketers as the most desirable of target audiences for most products and services that it is hard to get them to think otherwise, even if the population makeup is changing. This makes it tough on the media that attract a somewhat older crowd.

title: BRAZIL AID IS RUSHED BY BANKS
description: Scarcely six weeks after it was announced, a $6.5 billion commercial bank loan for Brazil, the biggest such package in the history of international finance, appears to be rapidly falling into place.

title: SWEDES SPLIT ON PLAN FOR UNION INVESTMENTS
description: After 12 years of lobbying, Sweden's powerful labor unions are about to see a dream come true - union-controlled investment funds created by a new payroll tax and a tax on corporate profits.

title: IN TROOP 2020, MANY GIRL SCOUTS ARE 60 AND OLDER
description: Mary Kovaltsik never had a chance to join a Girl Scout troop - her father died when she was young and she had to work to help support her family.

title: DOCTORS SAY EARLY SURGERY COULD AVERT RUPTURE OF MAJOR ARTERY, SAVING MANY
description: Earlier diagnosis and surgical treatment of a ballooning of the body's main trunk artery could save at least 2,000 Americans and $50 million in patient-care costs each year, according to a report to a meeting of the American Heart Association here.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Winners Cash In

title: OUTDOORS: REPAIRING CANOES IS ALMOST A LOST ART
description: WOODBURY, Conn.

title: REDSKINS DOMINATE GIANTS
description: The Giants had played so badly in recent weeks that it seemed impossible they could do worse. Today, they did the impossible.

title: Junior Samples, 56, Is Dead; Regular on 'Hee Haw' Show
description: Junior Samples, a rotund, slow-talking comedian who became a regular on the television show ''Hee Haw'' in 1969, died today of a heart attack. He was 56 years old.

title: Defecting Chinese Pilot Flies MIG-19 to Taiwan
description: A Chinese Air Force pilot flew a MIG-19 jet fighter to Taiwan today and asked for political asylum, the Defense Ministry reported.

title: Choking Food Stamps
description: One easy way to shrink the size of a social program is to girdle it in red tape. That, it seems, is the thinking of Carl B. Williams, a welfare policy consultant who wrote most of the proposed new Federal rules for food stamps. The targets of the changes are those old Reagan bugaboos: ''fraud, waste and abuse.'' The certain result of the proposed rules would be chronic confusion for food stamp officials and cruel hardship for some recipients.

title: Washington WatchClyde H. Farnsworth Trade Issues Heat Up for '84
description: WASHINGTON THE calls for protection coming from two basic industries - autos and steel - promise high visibility for trade issues in election year 1984.

title: Comfrey Herbal Tea Recalled After Tests
description: Celestial Seasonings has issued a nationwide recall of its comfrey herbal tea because tests found minute traces of the potentially toxic chemical atropine, commonly known as deadly nightshade.

title: CHARGERS TOP COWBOYS, 24-23
description: Derrie Nelson returned a blocked punt 21 yards for a touchdown and Ed Luther passed for 340 yards as the San Diego Chargers scored a 24-23 upset victory over the Dallas Cowboys today.

title: BOSTON HOPING TO SAVE DISPUTED RENEWAL UNIT
description: ''Sure, I've been there,'' said Esther Santos, looking across a field littered with glass toward the glistening white facade of the John F. Kennedy Library. ''I've heard the comments from the people who look out and see the view. They say, 'Oh, my God, that's terrible! Look at that disgusting housing project over there. Why don't they do something about it?' Those people don't know I live there.''

title: Fake Blinds Can't Hide Blight
description: New York's Department of Housing Preservation and Development seems bent on proving that one can have too much of a pretty and good thing.

title: Marcos Issues Threat to Businessmen
description: President Ferdinand E. Marcos said today that he had a dossier on businessmen involved in tax evasion, black-marketing of dollars and smuggling, and vowed to take them to court for economic sabotage.

title: Colombia Bars Extradition
description: The Colombian Government has rejected a United States request for the extradition of a Colombian citizen charged with drug trafficking. A decree signed by President Belisario Betancur and published Saturday night said Jesus Mejia Romero, sought by the United States along with 22 other Colombians for his supposed involvement in drug trafficking to Florida, would be tried by local courts instead. The crime in which he was supposedly taking part had taken place in Colombia also, the decree said.

title: Driver Collides With 16 Cars
description: A speeding off-duty cabdriver struck 16 cars Saturday, injuring 10 people, one of them critically, the police reported. Wallace Seegers, 34 years old, was arrested while at Washington Adventist Hospital and charged with reckless driving, driving while under the influence of drugs, and battery, the police said. Leaving Washington, the police went on, Mr. Seegers began speeding and struck 16 cars in half a mile before coming to a stop in a service station.

title: 50 YEARS OF KEEPING COUPLES TOGETHER
description: -SALEM, N.C., Nov. 13 - American couples are no longer marrying primarily for procreation, or for economic security, or because society stigmatizes the unmarried. They are marrying for love and companionship - for intimacy, in a word. But the problem with intimacy is that it leads to differences. Differences become disagreements. Disagreements become conflicts. And conflicts have a way of becoming fights, which drive couples apart until intimacy draws them together once more.

title: Iran Repeats Its Vow To Close Off the Strait
description: Iran has repeated its threat to close the Strait of Hormuz at the entrance to the Persian Gulf if Iraq disrupts Iranian oil exports.

title: NO SHIFT IN FED POLICY IS SEEN
description: The consensus of credit market participants is that Federal Reserve officials who set monetary policy will decide to make no changes at tomorrow's meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee. But there continues to be a variety of interest rate forecasts, with some analysts expecting significantly lower rates by mid- 1984 and others expecting higher rates.

title: A TORAH MARKS REBIRTH OF TEMPLE HIT BY ARSON
description: The congregation of the Emanuel Synagogue rose as an Israeli mayor, holding the Torah to his chest as he would a child, walked down the aisle to the ark. There the synagogue's rabbi set down the 100-year-old scroll - a gift of the people of Afula, Israel, to the people of the Hartford area.

title: 3 ARE RUNNING FOR HORSE OF YEAR
description: The horse of the year title, depending on whom you listen to, is either racing's supreme honor or a meaningless popularity contest. This year's competition looks like a close and contentious one among three worthy champions, but more than ever it also seems an absurd exercise in choosing among horses who cannot be compared.

title: Soviet Calls DMZ Visit By Reagan Provocative
description: The Soviet Union accused President Reagan today of making a provocative trip to the Korean demilitarized zone and said the visit was meant to help ''intensify military preparations'' in Asia.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sartorial Resurrection

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 14, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the planned release dates for major economic indicators to be reported this week. Monday Business Sales, Inventories Sept.Tuesday Industrial Production Oct.

title: INCENTIVE FOR HOSPITALS TO KEEP COSTS DOWN
description: To the Editor:

title: WAR ON FLORIDA BOILER ROOMS
description: Louis Dibileo, a 43-year-old insurance salesman in Taylor, Pa., figured it was his once- in-a-lifetime chance to pay for his four children's college education. For a $9,000 investment, said the man on the phone at the Stratford Company of Miami Beach, Fla., Mr. Dibileo would own the oil and gas drilling rights on Government property - rights that would be worth much more than $9,000.

title: Sunny's Halo Is Retired
description: Sunny's Halo, the erratic colt who won the Kentucky Derby this year, has been retired from racing, according to David Cross, his trainer.

title: Volcker Warns On Inflation
description: Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said Saturday that there were again signs in the economy that could result in expectations of higher inflation. Even though manufacturing and construction industries where recession was most severe have relatively flat wage and cost trends, he said, wage rises in less-affected sectors such as finance, utilities and services have remained between 6 and 8 percent.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: Falcons vs. Los Angeles Rams , at Atlanta. Vince Ferragamo, the Rams' quarterback, made his first start in a Monday night game against the Falcons on Nov. 19, 1979, a 20-14 victory for the Rams.

title: N.Y.U. IS MAKING WARY RETURN TO COURT
description: AS a reincarnated tradition, nearly everything about New York University's basketball team is new - the players, the home court, the philosophy.

title: DEFENSE OFFICIAL FAULTS CONGRESS ON SALVADOR
description: A top Administration official said today that El Salvador's armed forces need more mobility to counter recent guerrilla attacks, but Congress has not appropriated enough money to provide this.

title: ON THE PCJR'S DEBUT
description: To the Editor:

title: BILL HELPS CANADA'S RAILROADS
description: Canada's Parliament on Monday is scheduled to replace an 87-year-old law that has generated billions of dollars in operating losses for the nation's railroads by restricting what they can charge to haul grain.

title: TRAIL IN WOUNDING OF 2 POLICEMEN AT BLACK WAKE OPENS TODAY
description: In February, in an incident that sharply increased racial tensions in this city, a white police officer was shot and another knifed in a bizarre clash with black mourners at a wake.

title: SMALL AIRPORTS CLOSING AS PROFITS FALL
description: Lester Davis remembers when dozens of planes lined the tarmac at his Davis- Coram Airpark here. Now there are barely a handful.

title: OPERA: 'PETER GRIMES' AT MET
description: ''PETER GRIMES'' is a portentous opera, which announces from the very start the dark and fateful nature of its subject. At the Metropolitan Opera on Saturday night, in which there were cast changes in four major roles, Benjamin Britten's opera often fell prey to that portentousness - the beating drum, the sweeping violins, the trumpet blasts, the straining dissonances.

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: President Reagan and his wife, Nancy, are due back today from a six-day visit to Japan and South Korea. The President's schedule for the week is expected to be light.

title: Joanne M. Magro, a Nurse, Wed to Dr. Jay Seebacher
description: Joanne Marie Magro, daughter of Louise Magro of Garden City, L.I., and the late Salvatore Magro, was married yesterday to Dr. Jay Robert Seebacher, son of Sophie Seebacher of Ossining, N.Y., and the late J. Ira Seebacher. Rabbi Arthur Schwartz performed the ceremony in the Interfaith Chapel at the C. W. Post Center of Long Island University in Greenvale, L.I.

title: ORPHANS GIVE MRS. REAGAN SURPRISE GIFT
description: Nancy Reagan received an unexpected gift from 2,000 Korean orphans today: a chorus of ''God Bless America'' at the end of a busy day.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A player in a National Hockey League game has a breakaway, and as he skates near the opposing bench, a player on the opposing team hops through the first door as a teammate leaps onto the ice through the second door and cleanly stops the Team A player with the puck. Is this legal?

title: Communist Party Holds Rally in Cleveland
description: About 500 members of the Communist Party USA rallied downtown today on the last day of their four-day national convention, with Gus Hall, party chief and perennial Presidential candidate, presiding.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: FAMILY POLITICS. Love and Power on an Intimate Frontier. By Letty Cottin Pogrebin. 278 pages. McGraw-Hill. $14.95. GIRLS & BOYS. The Limits of Nonsexist Childrearing. By Sara Bonnett Stein. 208 pages. Scribner's. $13.95.

title: City Ballet Will Open With a Gala Tomorrow
description: The New York City Ballet will open its 79th New York season tomorrow in the New York State Theater with a gala benefit featuring three signature ballets by George Balanchine, ''Symphony in Three Movements,'' ''Symphony in C'' and ''Apollo.''

title: JAZZ: 2 BANDS AT BOTTOM LINE
description: TWO musicians who have played in Ornette Coleman's electric jazz band, Prime Time, led their own groups Friday at the Bottom Line.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bank of California has named William R. Caldwell executive vice president and head of the banking group.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Flurry of Activity Before 2 Big Art Auctions

title: Just a 'Backer On Cribbs
description: MINUTES after the Buffalo Bills stunned the Jets, 24-17, yesterday on a 33-yard touchdown pass from Joe Ferguson to Joe Cribbs with 22 seconds remaining, some of the Bill assistant coaches hurried in their blue parkas from their press-box perch into the Shea Stadium elevator that would take them down to the locker-room level. Shaking his head, Al Sandahl, the tight-end coach, turned to Jim Niblack, the offensive line coach.

title: MANY WOMEN HELD IN ZIMBABWE DRIVE
description: Soldiers and policemen have seized hundreds of women, including several foreign teachers and schoolgirls, in what they say is a crackdown on prostitution.

title: POLISH SHOPPING: CHASING THE SCARCE AND SHODDY
description: The days are growing shorter here, but the lines are growing longer.

title: ADDITIONAL CASEY STOCK DEALINGS MADE PUBLIC IN C.I.A. DOCUMENTS
description: William J. Casey has acquired stock in companies that do business with the Central Intelligence Agency since he took over as Director, according to documents recently made public.

title: BASS FISHERMEN FEAR NEW LAW MEANS RUIN
description: Three days before a new law on striped bass fishing went into effect, Ralph Pastore took his 25-foot boat out into New York Harbor and caught 150 bass near the Statue of Liberty. He sold the bass, most of which were between 18 and 22 inches long, at the Fulton Fish Market for $1,400.

title: Brazil Strike Continuing
description: Metalworkers voted today to continue a week-long strike that has paralyzed much of Brazil's auto industry. They are seeking pay increases above a Government limit that was designed to curb inflation. The stoppage started last Monday at the Ford plant at Sao Bernardo, on the city's outskirts, and spread to Volkswagen and other factories.

title: Books: Famed Publicist By Dan Carlinsky;
description: ''ALWAYS LIVE BETTER THAN YOUR

title: Reagan Called Tax Obstacle
description: Two top tax experts in Congress said today that President Reagan's refusal to agree to any tax increase could doom the Federal Government to budget deficits approaching $300 billion by the end of the decade.

title: Guild Re-Elects Asner
description: Ed Asner won an easy re-election victory as president of the Screen Actors Guild. Mr. Asner, an outspoken critic of President Reagan's Central America policy whose comments prompted frequent objections from Charlton Heston, former guild president, received 9,997 votes Wednesday to 2,787 for his opponent, J. D. Hall. The guild claims a total of 55,000 members.

title: DALTREY TACKLES OPERA AND THEATER
description: Roger Daltrey, late of the Who, is breaking out of the rock-idol mold and singing 18th-century Baroque music in ''The Beggar's Opera.'' He's also playing twins in Shakespeare's ''Comedy of Errors,'' and planning to direct a movie about two of London's most infamous gang bosses.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1983 International
description: ''Steadfast support'' for South Korea was pledged by President Reagan as he ended a two-day visit to the country. He also said that he would strengthen United States forces stationed there and that the United States would meet its ''responsibilities as a Pacific power.'' (Page A1, Column 6.) Syria was warned by a senior Reagan Administraion official that the United States will respond if Syrian gunners continue shooting at American aircraft over Lebanon. The official, Robert C. McFarlane, President Reagan's national security adviser, cited in a television interview the invasion of Grenada as an example of United States resolve to protect American lives. He said that while he considers a war with Syria unlikely, Damascus should take a ''sober view'' of the United States commitment in Lebanon. (A1:4.)

title: Unit of IBH Given Credit
description: Hanomag, the Hanover-based subsidiary of the IBH construction group that sought court protection from its creditors on Nov. 4, has received a bridging credit the equivalent of between $760,000 and $1.1 million to keep production going at least through part of next week, according to a company spokesman.

title: CHINA SAID TO FORCE 2 NEWSPAPER EDITORS TO QUIT THEIR POSTS
description: Several editors of the Communist Party newspaper People's Daily have been forced out of their jobs in an intensification of an antiliberal campaign, diplomats said today.

title: Bonita Weisman Is Married to Michael Fromson
description: The marriage of Bonita Weisman, daughter of Dr. Abner I. Weisman of Manhattan and the late Martha Behrman Weisman, to Michael Erik Fromson took place in Weston, Conn., yesterday. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard Fromson of Weston and Hartford.

title: ON MIDEAST, SHARED VIEW
description: News Analysis

title: Israeli President Pays Tribute To the Memory of Ben-Gurion
description: Israeli leaders gathered near a desert kibbutz today to pay homage to David Ben-Gurion, founding father of the country, on the 10th anniversary of his death.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Innocence on a String
description: The accused, in the American legal system, enjoys the presumption of innocence, meaning it's the prosecution's job to prove guilt. That presumption should protect a defendant until the moment of judgment, including the time a judge is deciding whether to allow release on bail. The Constitution forbids ''excessive bail,'' which usually means higher than necessary to assure appearance at trial. In theory, therefore, judges should never deny bail or set it prohibitively high just to keep ''dangerous'' defendants behind bars.

title: SON REPLACING FOUNDER AS TOP OFFICER AT FLUKE
description: John M. Fluke Jr. will take over tomorrow as chief executive officer of the John Fluke Manufacturing Company, which was founded by his father in 1948 in the family's basement. It is now the nation's third- largest electronic instruments company, after the Hewlett-Packard Company and Tektronix Inc.

title: BRAZIL'S HYDROELECTRIC PROJECT
description: The Brazilians know that they have built something impressive across the lusty Parana River into Paraguay. The question is whether they will be able to use it effectively.

title: 111 Militant Women Seized at Australia Base
description: The police arrested more than 100 militant women today when they forced their way into a top-secret, joint United States-Australian military base.

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.75

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 14, 1983

title: STEELERS' DEFENSE STOPS COLTS, 24-13
description: The Pittsburgh Steelers have played better games this season. Their defense has been stronger; their offense has scored more.

title: Kansas Town Frowns On Mere Sauntering
description: Sauntering is against the law here, even though Duane West, a city commissioner, said Harry S. Truman sauntered when he took his daily walks.

title: Man Killed in Struggle With
description: A man the police had taken to a Queens hospital for a psychiatric examination was shot to death last night in the hospital in a struggle after he grabbed a policeman's revolver, the police said.

title: CATHOLIC BISHOPS MEET TO DISCUSS ROLE OF WOMEN
description: Roman Catholic bishops and representatives of Catholic women's groups today ended a two-day conference that focused on issues of growing tension on the role of women in the modern church.

title: Woman, 29, Charged In Death of Infant Son
description: A 29-year-old Brooklyn woman was charged yesterday with second-degree murder in the death of her newborn son, the police said.

title: AT THE ROOT OF URBAN SCHOOL PROBLEMS
description: To the Editor:

title: LONELY SINGLES TRY TO FIND ROMANCE AT DEPARTMENT STORE
description: ''We're going in,'' said Martin Gallatin to the 15 apprehensive men and women under his command, one of whom confessed that he would just as soon be parachuting into combat.

title: 2 MEN ARRESTED IN FATAL KNIFING OF STUDENT, 19
description: Two Queens men were arrested last night and charged with the murder of a 19-year-old St. John's University student who was stabbed in the heart as she lay on the ground outside a student rooming house in Jamaica Estates last Thursday.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Calendar Aids Stock Action
description: STOCK prices shook off some of their worries last week and moved briskly ahead, thanks partly to a confluence of several dates on the calendar.

title: Bangladesh Chief Orders Elections for Next May
description: The military ruler of Bangladesh said today that presidential elections would be held next May, and he immediately sanctioned free political activity.

title: RELIANCE GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After gains from the early extinguishment of debt of $275,000 for the quarter and $3,225,000 for the 9 months.

title: ANACOMP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Bruce Bochte , the former Seattle Mariner first baseman, ended his one-year retirement from major league baseball yesterday by signing a one-year contract with the Oakland A's. . . . Don Robinson , the Pittsburgh Pirates' right-handed pitcher, will undergo exploratory arthroscopic surgery Thursday to determine the condition of his sore right shoulder.

title: Evans to U.S.F.L.
description: Vince Evans , the Chicago Bear backup quarterback, will become the Chicago Blitz starting quarterback. Evans, whose contract with the Bears expires Feb. 1, confirmed his move last night by saying, ''I haven't formally signed yet, but my lawyer and my wife and I completed negotiations tonight.''

title: 18 Turkish Activists Get 8-Year Jail Terms
description: A martial-law court in Istanbul sentenced 18 leaders of the Turkish Peace Association to eight years in prison today for establishing an organization to overthrow the Government.

title: Capitalism for the Pentagon
description: The military appropriations bills now taking final shape in Congress do nothing to resolve the paradox: Despite the largest real-dollar peacetime military program in history, the nation's forces have been stretched thin by a few peacekeeping operations and the invasion of Grenada.

title: Guards and Building Workers Reach a Pact With Columbia
description: Negotiators for Columbia University and the union representing 123 security guards and more than 500 maintenance and housekeeping employees reached a tentative agreement on a new contract last night, minutes before a strike deadline of 12:01 A.M. today.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Class in Jazz

title: OUTBOARD MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The year-ago quarter and year net reflects a $9.9 million pre-tax charge that arose from provisions for plant relocations in connection with the company's plant efficiency program and a $2.1 million net gain on the exchange of common stock for a portion of the company's 7 3/4 percent sinking fund debentures.

title: HORNBECK OFFSHORE SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday in SportsMonday misstated the result of a Catholic High Schools Football League semifinal game. St. Anthony's defeated Cardinal Spellman, 29-23.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $12,000 for the quarter and $141,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago share earnings have been restated to reflect a 10 percent stock dividend paid Aug. 1.

title: American Air Pact
description: American Airlines Inc. said representatives of its 6,000 flight attendants have accepted proposals for a new-three-year contract.

title: USING SCIENCE IN THE SERVICE OF SPORT
description: In two previous Pan American Games, Peter Westbrook had seen his hopes for a gold medal in fencing ended by the same rival, Manuel Ortiz of Cuba.

SHAPELL INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: PITTSBURGH CELEBRATES REOPENED STREETS
description: This city's downtown section, which has often resembled a Western frontier town in 22 months of subway and office-building construction, regained some semblance of normalcy today when two main arteries were reopened, amid considerable fanfare.

title: Business and the LawTamar Lewin Fall in Income At Big Firms
description: ALTHOUGH the partners at New York City's largest law firms are still making plenty of money, the signs are increasing that the era of real riches may be coming to an end for all but a few special partners at a few special firms.

title: Forestry Parley for Mexico
description: A representative of the Mexican Government signed an agreement with the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization today for Mexico City to hold the ninth World Forestry Congress in July 1985. The two-week conferences are held every nine years. Some 2,500 foresters from 100 countries attended the last in Jakarta, Indonesia, in 1978.

title: TV: 'FOUR CORNERS' ENERGY AND THE LAND
description: ''THE FOUR CORNERS: A NATIONAL SACRIFICE AREA?'' is not just another documentary, thank goodness, about the march of technology and its savage effect on the environment. The documentary, even though it comes down heavily on the side of the environmentalists, is more thoughtful than that. It will be seen on Channel 13 at 10 o'clock tonight.

title: NOW, A PRESS FOR GRENADA
description: The argument about America's reasons for invading Grenada goes on. So does the occupation. History's judgment will depend on results in the longer term, and those results will depend on what happens next.

title: Chickens, Unruffled, Get Heftier
description: A gentle word, a quiet song and a stroke of the feathers makes chickens happier, healthier and heftier, researchers at Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University say.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Conrac Corp., Stamford, Conn., has named John J. Daly president of its Code-A-Phone Corporation subsidiary.

title: SAN FRANCISCANS GET THREE NEW BUILDINGS
description: SAN FRANCISCO THIS is a conservative city architecturally, for all it may be otherwise politically. When it does try to innovate, its attempts seem curiously awkward, as if architects were unsure just how to express the elusive spirit of this city. Although the best architecture in San Francisco's past has traditionally had an easy, effortless grace about it, that seems like the hardest thing of all for architects to achieve here today. A lot of architecture these days in San Francisco seems to try too hard, rather than not hard enough.

title: Steelworkers Board To Discuss Top Post
description: The executive board of the United Steelworkers of America will meet Thursday at Pittsburgh to discuss naming a successor to the union's president, Lloyd McBride, who died Nov. 6.

title: ADAC LABORATORIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding have been restated to reflect acquisition accounted for as a pooling of interests.

title: KN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF ; New York City Opera In Bizet's 'Carmen'
description: The New York City Opera's Saturday afternoon performance of Bizet's ''Carmen'' got progressively better as it went along. After a lackluster first act, which was held together only by the propulsive conducting of Christopher Keene, the principal singers seemed to find themselves, participating more and more actively in the drama, and singing better as well.

title: Occidental Will Sell Permian to Wesray
description: The Occidental Petroleum Corporation said yesterday that it had signed a definitive agreement to sell its Permian Corporation unit to Wesray Operations Inc., less than two weeks after a previous deal to sell Permian collapsed.

title: Ex-Governor Felled by Fumes
description: John Davis, a former Governor of North Dakota, and his wife were hospitalized in fair condition after being overcome by carbon monoxide in their home this morning. The authorities said the gas might have come from the furnace. ''We suspect for some reason there was a reversing draft in the chimney,'' said Vince Feist, a deputy chief. Mr. Davis, 69 years old, was Governor from 1957 to 1960, and served as President Nixon's civil defense director.

title: Drug Tests Set
description: OTTAWA, Nov. 14 (UPI) All Canadian athletes participating in next year's Summer and Winter Olympic Games will undergo mandatory tests for illegal body-building drugs before they leave Canada, Sports Minister Celine Hervieux-Payette said today. She also said the anabolic steroid tests might be imposed for Canadian athletes attending other international events. In recent months, Canadian athletes have been involved in use or possession of banned drugs in two separate international competitions.

title: Murchisons Ponder Sale of Cowboys
description: Clint W. Murchison Jr., a principal owner of the Dallas Cowboys since the franchise was founded in 1960, is considering selling the team, Tex Schramm, the club president, said yesterday.

description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Danish Industry Orders
description: Industrial orders in Denmark, excluding those at shipyards, rose 11 percent in September from the period a year ago, after a 15 percent gain in August, the National Statistics Office said today.

title: MONDALE WOOS HIS PARTY'S CONSERVATIVE WING
description: In January, 1980, when he was gearing up his re-election campaign, President Carter called in 20 so-called neoconservative Democrats for a half-hour talk about politics and issues. They urged him to increase military spending and adopt sterner policies toward the Soviet Union.

description: Outraged former French Resistance leaders demanded today that the lawyer for Klaus Barbie, the Nazi war criminal, prove assertions that an underground hero killed himself after comrades betrayed him to the Germans.

Swiss Trade Deficit
description: Switzerland's trade deficit widened to the equivalent of $10.8 million in October from $8.8 million in September, the Federal Customs Office said today.

title: GREENHAM COMMON: IRON AGE TO THE NUCLEAR AGE
description: Greenham Common is a Royal Air Force Base used by the United States, situated about 50 miles west of London in Berkshire. A total of 96 United States- made Tomahawk ground-launched cruise missiles, manned and protected by United States technicians and military security forces, are scheduled to be housed there in hardened concrete silos. The first of these nuclear-tipped missiles are expected to be operational by the end of the year.

title: CHIEF TRADE ADVISER TO NIXON
description: Carl Joyce Gilbert, an industrialist who served as chief foreign trade adviser to President Nixon, died at University Hospital in Boston Sunday after a brief illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Dover, Mass.

description: A Staten Island group founded to prevent child abuse is a sham whose gun- carrying members have not pursued an abuse case in six years, State Attorney General Robert Abrams charged yesterday.

title: SOVIET COMMENT ON LEFTIST INROADS IN AMERICAS FOUND IN GRENADA
description: Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, the Soviet Chief of Staff, reportedly told the Grenadian Chief of Staff in Moscow last March that, while two decades ago ''there was only Cuba in Latin America, today there are Nicaragua, Grenada, and a serious battle is going on in El Salvador.''

title: Biegenwald Drops Insanity Defense
description: Lawyers for Richard F. Biegenwald today withdrew his plea of not guilty by reason of insanity in the killings of five people.

title: GINNY FOAT, ON STAND, DENIES SHE HAD ROLE IN DEATH OF ARGENTINE
description: Ginny Foat took the witness stand today in her murder trial and denied ever having met the victim in the case, an Argentine businessman, or killing him.

description: b-After a tax charge of $153,000 for the quarter and a tax credit of $176,000 for the 9 months. c-Including tax credits of $342,000 for the quarter and $809,000 for the 9 months.

title: Suspect Is Convicted Of 10th Coast Killing
description: Jurors today convicted Angelo Buono Jr. of the one remaining murder count against him.

title: FOR SPRING, THE VIEWS OF INDIVIDUALISTS
description: Not every fashion collection among the recent spring openings in New York was a blockbuster. Not every designer tried to offer all kinds of clothes for all women. Some focused on a particular style of dress or a special fashion need. Some have already developed faithful followings; others aspire to do so.

title: U.S. Court Restricts Farm Foreclosures
description: The Farmers Home Administration may not foreclose on borrowers in 44 states without informing them of their right to seek a loan deferral and offering them a hearing, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: Columbia Given Berth in Playoffs
description: The Columbia soccer team received a berth yeterday in the Eastern Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I soccer tournament.

title: Advertising; BBDO Will Buy Waring
description: BBDO INTERNATONIONAL, the world's eighth-largest ad agency, has agreed to acquire Waring & LaRosa, a 15-year-old consumer agency billing about $80 million.

title: FOREIGN CHILDREN GIVEN GIFT OF LIFE
description: After a Ugandan child was mauled by a hyena 10 years ago, civic groups in Uganda issued a plea for help in finding a plastic surgeon to reconstruct the child's face.

title: Charlotte Curtis Excluding the Media
description: JOHN CHANCELLOR scrapped his announced speech at New York University the other night and, in view of the situation in Grenada, discussed and deplored the exclusion of the news media from covering the invasion and the fighting. What troubled him, he said, was not just the ban but that many Americans cheered it.

title: FIRST BILLION-DOLLAR BUDGET IN NASSAU SOUGHT BY PURCELL
description: Nassau County's first billion-dollar operating budget was proposed today, with expenditures designed to add 50 new police officers and replace 130 who are expected to retire.

title: British Stock Holdings
description: The percentage of shares in British companies held by financial institutions rose to 58 percent in 1981 from 48 percent in 1975 and 30 percent in 1963, a survey by the London Stock Exchange showed today. The proportion held by individuals shrank to 28 percent in 1981 from 37.5 percent in 1975 and 54 percent in 1963.

title: 'MATTER OF LAW' IS CITED IN WOMAN'S DRUG CASE
description: The special narcotics prosecutor who pressed the case that returned a woman to prison after 21 months of freedom said yesterday that he had pursued the case as a ''matter of law.''

title: Gottlieb Heads Abrams
description: Paul Gottlieb, president, publisher and editor in chief of Harry N. Abrams, the art- and illustrated-book publishing company, has been elected chief executive officer of Abrams, which is a Times Mirror Company subsidiary. Mr. Gottlieb succeeds Seymour Turk, who was chief executive and chairman for the last four years. Mr. Turk is joining the Book- of-the-Month Club as senior vice president and general manager.

title: A TIP BY PUBLIC LEADS TO ARREST OF 2 IN MURDER
description: Authorities yesterday credited information from the public with aiding in Sunday's arrest of two Queens men in the murder of a 19-year-old St. John's University student who was stabbed in the heart as she lay pinned to the ground.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1983

title: MOR-FLO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
MOTOR CLUB OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: AS BOSTON'S VOTERS CHOOSE A NEW MAYOR, THEY EMBODY A CHANGING CITY
description: When Boston's voters go to the polls Tuesday, they will not only be electing a new mayor for the first time in 16 years, they will also embody the dramatic changes that are altering the character of this 350-year- old city.

title: EXCERPTS FROM DOCUMENT ON SOVIET VIEW OF GRENADA
description: Following are excerpts from a memorandum dated March 10, 1983, from the Grenadian Embassy in Moscow, reporting on a meeting between Marshal Nikolai V. Ogarkov, the Soviet Chief of Staff, and Maj. Einstein Louison, the Grenadian Chief of Staff, as made public by the State Department:

title: Burmese Politician Sentenced to 5 Life Terms
description: Brig. Tin Oo, once one of the most powerful political figures in Burma, was sentenced to five life terms in prison today for misuse of state funds and property.

title: 2. LAW 'IS NOT A SUICIDE PACT'
description: The Administration has not offered a persuasive legal case for the invasion of Grenada. The decisions of states to use force under Article 51 of the United Nations Charter is almost always a conditioned reflex under circumstances of stress. Their legality is not determined by how well they are explained, however, but by how well they correspond to the pattern of state practice deemed right by the society of nations. By that standard, the American and allied campaign in Grenada is legitimized by classic precedents in international law, notably the Cuban missile crisis of 1962.

title: 1. GRENADA WAS ILLEGALLY INVADED
description: In the aftermath of the Grenada invasion, there seems to be a widespread feeling that international lawyers should sit down and shut up, while the national bosom swells with pride at the exploits of our fighting men. But, among international law experts, a group not noted for unanimity, there is remarkably broad agreement that the United States' invasion was a flagrant violation of international law.

title: BACKER SEES NO GAS DECONTROL IN '83
description: A chief supporter of legislation to remove price controls on natural gas said yesterday that he no longer had any hope of passing a bill this year, a failure he said was partly due to inept and penurious lobbying by the major oil companies.

title: NATIONAL THEATER PLAN
description: Actors' Equity announced on Monday the outlines of its plan for a $1 billion national theater. Representatives of the union, speaking at a conference in New York, likened the proposed project to the Federal Theater of the 1930's.

SOLIDLY BEHIND ARAFAT
description: What does Syria hope to accomplish by backing the mutiny within the Palestine Liberation Organization? Nothing less than the final rout of Yasir Arafat - at a cost of many innocent lives. President Hafez al- Assad wishes to replace King Hussein of Jordan as the negotiator for Palestine, and thereby to extend his influence well beyond Lebanon. Yet Palestinian rights cannot be recovered by Syrian guns or maneuvers.

description: A hockey player who has just been recalled from the minor leagues and scores a goal in his first game back usually reacts with some giddy expression of delight.

Juan Carlos Lectoure , representing Roldan, the No. 1 contender, said the fight might take place in New York or South Africa.

The authority's newly named chairman, Robert R. Kiley, has urged that work on the project continue.

The Pub has dusted off the smaller Bird Cage Room, unused for several years, and is filling it with Mort Sahl, who played the same enclosure in 1977.

4-Game Suspension
description: Behn Wilson of the Chicago Black Hawks was suspended for four games by the National Hockey League yesterday for ''irresponsible and potentially very dangerous'' use of his stick against Steve Yzerman of the Detroit Red Wings. Detroit filed a protest after Yzerman, a rookie, was injured while being checked by Wilson, a defenseman, in a game Nov. 3. Brian O'Neill , the league's executive vice president, who announced the suspension, said it would take effect Nov. 21 unless the Black Hawks waived their appeal period.

title: Brazil Plane Order
description: The Provincetown- Boston Airline said it plans to acquire 10 Embraer EMB-120 Brasilia aircraft from Brazilian state-owned Embraer Brasileira de Aeronautica S.A. The airline said that, with spares, the order is valued at $50 million. It said the 30-seater twin turboprop aircraft are powered by Pratt and Whitney engines. The airline said it plans to use the planes on its Florida routes.

description: Debut recitals can impress or disappoint, but rarely do they give sheer pleasure. Sara Sant'Ambrogio's afternoon of cello music at Carnegie Recital Hall Saturday - despite its periodic excesses and technical stumblings - did just that.

description: To this day, Victor H. Palmieri enthusiastically describes the challenges he faces in untangling the morass at the Baldwin-United Corporation and why the job is a natural step in a career built on handling business and government crises.

title: New Sense in Realty Taxes
description: Real estate taxes on New York City's commercial buildings have long been recognized as both too low and too random. But simply raising them whenever the sale of a building exposed its true value only increased the injustice and ran the risk of discouraging desirable development. Now the Koch administration thinks it has found a remedy, and at first glance this new course seems right.

The year-earlier quarter and 9 months results include $4.2 million of after-tax gains on sales of securities and in the quarter include $4.7 million of earnings resulting from the recovery of an unrealized market loss recognized in the second quarter of 1982 on an investment in marketable securities included in current assets.

title: CHARGES FILED ON 33 FILIPINOS
description: The Government filed criminal charges of smuggling and other offenses today against 33 executives and employees of eight leading textile and garment companies.

The company, which makes medical monitoring systems, said it expects to file within a few days. Biochem also said that its sales have slowed recently due to uncertainty among its customers caused by the Government's new Medicare reimbursement formulas.

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF ; Schickele's 'Bestiary' With Calliope Band
description: The members of Calliope, a self-described Renaissance band, believe that the unique qualities of antiquated musical instruments such as the viol, the hurdy-gurdy, the shawm and the sackbut lend themselves not only to performances of early music, but also to some music being written today. They proved their point Saturday night with an engaging concert at the Abraham Goodman House.

title: Big Soviet Grain Harvest
description: The Agriculture Department said today that it predicted a Soviet grain harvest of 200 million metric tons for 1983, the largest since the record crop of 237 million tons in 1978. The Russians now keep their official grain crop figures secret.

title: U.S. STARTS NEW INQUIRY ON BRAKES OF GENERAL MOTORS' 1980 X-CARS
description: The Government announced a new investigation today into the safety of power brakes on one million General Motors X-model cars.

title: VESCO IS LINKED TO CUBA SMUGGLING PLOT
description: Robert L. Vesco, the fugitive financier, is living in Cuba and was the instigator of a plot to smuggle United States goods into Cuba, according to a Federal prosecutor.

title: CITY SEEKS TO ADD JAILS IN BROOKLYN
description: New York City is near an agreement to house as many as 600 prisoners in one of two buildings in Brooklyn, a move designed to prevent a further release of inmates from overcrowded jails, city officials said yesterday.

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF ; Russell Big Band In Two Showpieces
description: The George Russell Big Band played a polished, hard-charging concert Saturday at the Entermedia Theater. Mr. Russell has drilled his 14 young musicians until every chord is perfectly balanced - the brasses punch, the saxophones croon, the electric keyboards glimmer ominously. Every section of an extended work can wax or wane at its own rate.

title: ADVERTISING ; Sylvia Porter Magazine Off to Ambitious Start

title: ELEPHANTS REVEAL THEIR SOCIAL LIVES TO LONE RESEARCHER
description: SLIT EAR was feeding with her nine daughters and grandchildren when Tania came into view. The two matriarchs, members of a four-family group of 23 African elephants, had been apart for some time and were clearly excited about their reunion. Slit Ear stopped eating and ran toward Tania. The two elephants raised their heads and ears, clicked their tusks, turned, backed into each other, entwined trunks, all the while rumbling, trumpeting and loudly flapping their ears.

description: THE young and charming Tulsa Ballet Theater offered two new productions at its performance on Sunday afternoon at Brooklyn College. One of them turned out to be a familiar work in an unfamiliar guise.

title: MUSIC: SAX AND QUARTET
description: HENRY THREADGILL brought an ambitious piece to Carnegie Recital Hall last Saturday - a three- movement quintet for strings and his own alto saxophone or flute.

title: CALVIN KLEIN IS OFFERING $60 MILLION FOR PURITAN
description: Calvin Klein, the fashion designer, said yesterday that he and his business partner, Barry Schwartz, had offered to acquire the Puritan Fashions Corporation for about $60 million.

title: ADVERTI
description: People

title: Milton Bradley Expects Deficit
description: The Milton Bradley Company said it expects to report losses for the fourth quarter and year. It cited lower sales and lost opportunities in the personal electronics market resulting from Texas Instrument Inc.'s recent departure from the personal computer market.

title: Gift to Fordham
description: A $1 million gift from the family of the Rev. Dr. Nicholas J. Langenfeld has established a professorship in his name in social research at Fordham University's Graduate School of Social Service, the university president, the Rev. James C. Finlay, announced yesterday at a ceremony at Fordham's Lincoln Center campus.

title: A Boost for Tomorrow's Workers
description: Although the rate of unemployment has dropped below 9 percent for the work force as a whole, it remains more than twice as high for teen- agers. In the flush of economic recovery, the alienation of so many of the nation's future workers ought to be less tolerable than ever.

title: CENTENNIAL GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Agent Orange Placebo

title: COOK INTERNATIONAL LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
