title: Louise Hamilton Dies at 71; Professor at Hunter College
description: Louise Hamilton, a founder of the Hunter College School of Social Work and professor emeritus of social work there, died of pneumonia Wednesday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 71 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BELLSOUTH EAGER FOR KICKOFF
description: For the people who will be running BellSouth, the holding company that will own the Southern Bell Telephone and Telegraph Company and the South Central Bell Telephone Company starting Jan. 1, the view from their 45th-floor executive suite couldn't be better.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: On Same Side of Fence

title: MUSIC/NOTED IN BRIEF ; Rhythm in the Kitchen: Be-bop Meets Hip Hop
description: For years, ''hip hop, be-bop'' has been one of rap-funk's many catch phrases. Last Friday, the Kitchen brought together be-bop, in the person of the longtime jazz drummer Max Roach, with hip hop - the rap vocalist Fab 5 Freddy, the disk jockeys D. J. Spy and Dr. Nick Nice, and a five-man ''crew'' of dancers, the New York City Breakers.

title: MCO HOLDINGS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Canada Acts On Rail Fees
description: The House of Commons today voted to more than quintuple the amount that Canadian railroads may charge for hauling grain, ending a fee structure that has been in place since 1898.

title: CONCERT: AMERICAN SYMPHONY
description: Vato Jordania, a recent defector from the Soviet Union, made his conducting debut in this country with the American Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall Sunday afternoon. Mr. Jordania was a last-minute replacement for Giuseppe Patane, a principal conductor of the orchestra. While Mr. Jordania's all-Tchaikovsky program never quite coped with the fine points of ensemble playing, it solved broader musical problems handsomely.

title: HERSHEY OIL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STANDARD COMMERCIAL TOACCO CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Rate Cut in Australia
description: The Australian Bank Ltd. said today that it would lower its prime lending rate to 12 percent from 12.5 percent, effective Wednesday. A spokesman said the reduction was the result of declines in short-term market rates, notably for bank bills.

title: POP: 2D VOICE AT COOKERY
description: Now that 88-year-old Alberta Hunter is back at the Cookery singing on a modified schedule - Wednesdays through Saturdays at 9:30 P.M. only - the restaurant's entertainment program is being filled out by a much younger singer, Laura Theodore, who performs Sundays through Tuesdays at 9 and 11:15 P.M. and on Fridays and Saturdays at 11:15 P.M.

title: HALMI, ROBERT, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: 'WONDER WOMEN' CITED FOR GIFTS TO AMERICAN LIFE
description: At the age of 16, Marie Balter was confined to a state mental hospital in Massachusetts. She spent most of the next 20 years in such institutions. She recovered, went on to receive a master's degree from Harvard University and now works full time helping mental patients.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Bruce L. Burnham, a former chief executive at Bonwit Teller, announced yesterday that he would retire as chairman and chief executive of Dayton's department stores at the end of the fiscal year, Jan. 28.

title: SURGICARE TO MERGE WITH MEDICAL 21
description: The Medical 21 Corporation and the Surgicare Corporation, two Texas- based operators and developers of outpatient surgical centers, said yesterday that they had agreed in principle to merge in a pooling-of-interests transaction.

description: Residents of Florida's largest city are expected to vote in large numbers tomorrow in a mayoral runoff election that has brought heated ethnic appeals.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Indiana Pacers , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks will seek to climb above .500 in their second meeting of the season with the Pacers. In the first game, last Thursday at Indianapolis, Ray Williams scored a game-high 25 points to pace a 99-91 victory. (Television - MSG Cable, 7 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.)

title: S.E.C. Cites Touche Ross
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured Touche Ross & Company, a major accounting concern, for its audits of a defense contractor that was involved in a dispute with the Navy over millions of dollars in cost overruns on shipbuilding contracts.

title: BAKER INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: MAJOR U.S. BISHOP SAYS POPE OFFERS 'SUPPORT, NOT REBUKE'
description: Archbishop John R. Roach, president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, said today that there were strains between the Pope and American bishops, but that they could be ''best understood as the growing pains in a maturing relationship.'' He also underscored the need for the bishops to respond to the concerns of Roman Catholic women.

title: BEHIND THE SCENES, PERHAPS A COUP
description: Representative Fernand J. St Germain of Rhode Island looks like the shrewd, inside politician he is. The son of a millworker from Woonsocket, R.I. is not slick and telegenic but short and stocky, with a ruddy face and a walk that is almost pugnacious.

title: AMEDCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago results have been restated to reflect acquisitions completed during 1983 which are accounted for as poolings of interest.

title: REPORT TO CONGRESS PROVIDES FIGURES FOR NUCLEAR ARSENAL
description: In a confidential report to Congress, the Defense Department has said the United States nuclear arsenal for medium-range, short-range, and naval weapons includes 10,800 warheads and emphasizes bombs and missiles over artillery.

title: A PECULIAR SHIP CRUISES THE ATLANTIC IN SEARCH OF KNOWLEDGE
description: ''It used to be fashionable to say we know more about the moon than we do about the ocean,'' said Prof. Joseph L. Reid. ''I don't believe that's true anymore.''

title: Rebels Attack in Salvador
description: About 300 rebels armed with automatic weapons attacked a town in the center of a Government reconstruction area, but pulled back today after 12 hours of combat. A Defense Ministry spokesman said one soldier was wounded in the attack on San Lorenzo, 37 miles east of the capital. San Lorenzo is at the center of a United States-financed reconstruction project designed to attract refugees back to their homes.

JURY TO HEAR EVIDENCE OF CHEATING BY CASINO DEALERS AND SUPERVISORS
description: A state grand jury will soon begin hearing evidence of cheating by ''numerous'' dealers and supervisors at Atlantic City gambling casinos, Attorney General Irwin I. Kimmelman announced today.

CASTRO SAYS THE COUP IN GRENADA 'OPENED DOORS' TO U.S. INVASION
description: President Fidel Castro, denouncing the United States invasion of Grenada, said today that it came only after the men who had overthrown and killed Prime Minister Maurice Bishop ''sank the revolution and opened the doors to imperialist aggression.''

title: Quotations of the Day

title: PARCELLS CRITICAL OF GIANT ERRORS
description: At the end of a pro football season, general managers, coaches and personnel people sit down and evaluate what they have and what they need. Today Coach Bill Parcells conceded that, despite the five games remaining this season, evaluation time might have arrived for his disappointing Giants.

title: Yonkers City Manager Quits, Effective Jan. 1
description: Sal Prezioso, the Yonkers City Manager, announced today that he was resigning, effective Jan. 1.

title: PENNEY'S HOLIDAY LINE OMITS ADAM COMPUTER
description: The J. C. Penney Company said yesterday that it would not carry the Adam home computer during the Christmas shopping season because of ''problems of availability.''

title: GROUP PROTESTS CUTS IN LEGAL AID
description: Sharp cutbacks in funds for Federal legal aid since President Reagan took office ''are severely affecting the delivery of legal services for the poor,'' according to a group of Washington lawyers.

description: John K. McKinley, chairman and chief executive of Texaco Inc., received a longer lease on the top management post yesterday.

title: SOME SAD PEOPLE, IT SEEMS, ARE UNHAPPY AS MATTER OF HABIT
description: Two men looked out through prison

title: KN Energy Plans Oil-Gas Spinoff
description: KN Energy Inc., as it said it would do last month after rejecting an acquisition proposal from the Mesa Petroleum Company, said it plans to spin off its oil and gas exploration and production operations to two new companies. KN said its board had authorized the formation of a new corporation, the Midlands Energy Company, which will own KN's exploration and production units, the Midlands Gas Corporation and the Excelsior Oil corporation.

title: Broken Hill And G.E.  Alter Pact
description: The General Electric Company and the Broken Hill Proprietary Company of Australia yesterday announced that G.E. had agreed to retain a 20 percent to 25 percent share in several Australian coal mines in order to complete G.E.'s sale of its Utah International Inc. subsidiary to Broken Hill.

title: BLOCKER ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
INVENTORIES ROSE 0.7% IN SEPTEMBER
description: Inventories held by American businesses rose seven- tenths of 1 percent in September, and sales jumped 1.5 percent, the Commerce Department reported today.

description: b-Net income.

title: Israel Plans 5 Settlements
description: Israel decided today to set up five new Jewish settlements in the occupied West Bank, raising the number of such outposts to more than 120. A source told the Israeli radio that the Government's committee on settlements decided three of the settlements would be built near Jericho in order to hinder any future United States or Jordanian proposal to return the area to Jordan, A fourth settlement will be in the northern part of the West Bank, and a fifth will be near Nablus, the largest Arab city in the West bank.

title: OLD POLICE HEADQUARTERS DRAWS 5 RENOVATION BIDS
description: Hoping that a 10-year-old streak of bad luck is over, city officials yesterday got their first glimpse of five private proposals to rebuild the old Police Headquarters in lower Manhattan.

title: Electronic Associates Stake
description: Electronic Associates Inc., a West Long Branch, N.J., manufacturer of computer-based simulation systems, said that a group led by investor Howard Benedek had acquired 5.1 percent of the company's stock and that the group had requested a meeting with management. Electronic Associates said it has no further knowledge of the group's plans.

title: Williams to Move To Reopen Case
description: Former Senator Harrison A. Williams Jr., facing a three-year prison sentence on a bribery conviction, said yesterday that he was moving to reopen his case on the basis of ''newly discovered evidence.''

title: Mechanical Failures Blamed In 2 Jet Crashes Off Lebanon
description: Two F-14 Tomcat fighters crashed into the Mediterranean in separate incidents last week because of mechanical failures, the Navy said today.

title: No Headline
description: AN AMATEUR'S GUIDE TO THE NIGHT. By Mary Robison. 129 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $11.95.

title: Pennsylvania Justice Sues 2 Papers in State
description: A justice of Pennsylvania's Supreme Court filed a libel suit today against two of the state's largest newspapers, asking more than $280,000 in damages for a series of articles dealing with his political activity.

title: AIDS Cases Reported Declining in New York
description: Cases of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, or AIDS, in New York State have been reported in lower numbers during the past three months, the State Health Commissioner said yesterday.

title: E.P.A. IS ASSAILED ON ACID RAIN PLAN
description: A coalition of environmental and public health groups accused the Environmental Protection Agency today of seeking a rule change that would weaken efforts to control acid rain.

DELOITTE BUYS JAPAN SPECIALIST
description: Deloitte Haskins & Sells, one of the Big Eight accounting firms, has acquired Sho Iino Accountants, an accounting firm that serves Japanese companies, Deloitte announced yesterday. Company officials would not disclose the purchase price or the financial terms of the agreement.

title: K Mart Income And Sales Rise
description: The K Mart Corporation said yesterday that improved profit margins and expense controls helped earnings to nearly triple in its latest quarter, while sales increased 11.6 percent.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Architecture of Old Charms the Young

title: STRONGER POLICIES ON ALIENS FAVORED
description: Public support for restrictions on hiring illegal aliens is stronger than it has been at any time since 1977, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: SCOUTING
description: Matlack Viewing The Bright Side

title: PLAYSWilliam N. Wallace; Vikings Caught for Lingering
description: Rule 12 in the National Football League covering ''unsportsmanlike conduct'' is a large umbrella, and for the Minnesota Vikings Sunday it even included the act of lingering.

title: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 15, 1983 International
description: American cruise missiles arrived at an air base in England, the British Government announced. They are the first of NATO's new generation of medium-range missiles to be deployed in Western Europe. The announcement was made by Defense Secretary Michael Heseltine, who had to shout to be heard over howls of protest from opposition members of Parlament. (Page A1, Column 6.) A revised arms control proposal was made by the United States at the Geneva talks. The American delegation offered a refinement of its previous plan for limiting medium-range missiles. In Moscow, the Government press agency Tass called the offer ''patently unacceptable.'' (A1:6.)

title: ARAFAT IS WILLING TO GO TO DAMASCUS
description: Yasir Arafat is sending a top aide to Moscow and has offered to go to Damascus himself for talks aimed at ending the fighting between his supporters and Palestinian rebels, according to a spokesman for the P.L.O. leader.

title: U.S. Official a Theft Victim
description: Inspector General Joseph Sickon of the General Services Administration did not have to look hard for a crime at the agency when he arrived at work today. He found his office had been burglarized. Four electric typewriters and a clock radio were stolen, according to a spokesman, who said it could not be determined whether any records or documents, such as open investigative files, were also taken.

title: Thrift Units Cautioned
description: The housing industry appears headed for another confrontation with high interest rates and rapid inflation, perhaps as soon as 1985, Albert L. Wojnilower, chief economist of the First Boston Corporation, said today at a thrift institution convention.

title: BERKLEY, W R, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: CONGRESS SEEKS FAST COMPROMISE ON FISCAL BILLS
description: Congressional leaders searched urgently today for compromise formulas on several major fiscal measures as the lawmakers entered what they hope will be the final week of work before their scheduled adjournment Friday.

title: COMMODITIES Heating Oil Futures In Downward Trend
description: Despite the onset of the heating season and the forecast of firmer crude oil prices in the coming months, prices of heating oil futures showed a downward trend yesterday. Prices of the January and February heating oil contracts eased, while the spot December delivery closed slightly higher.

title: NEW SCENE IN THE CITY: A 'VILLAGE' RECORD SHOP
description: In a city where daily life often takes on theatrical overtones, where department stores, bookstores and delicatessens are transformed into events, one of the latest stage settings is a three-story, neon-lighted, pulsating, raspberry-and-black-walled record store in Greenwich Village.

title: INDEPENDENCE HOLDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $600,000 for the quarter and $1,460,000 for the 9 months.

title: TAXES ALIENS PAY TO TEXAS FOUND TO TOP BENEFITS
description: Illegal immigrants are widely viewed by Americans as a drain on the public treasury, but a new study in Texas has found that they contribute far more to the state's coffers in taxes than they take out in health, welfare and other publicly financed services.

title: Tokyo to Protest to Seoul
description: Japan said it would send a protest to South Korea over an incident today in which a small Japanese fishing boat was fired on and briefly seized. An Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries Ministry official said the fishing boat, the Kinfuku Maru, was fired on by a South Korean patrol boat in the Sea of Japan between the southernmost Japanese island of Kyushu and South Korea.

title: CLARK CONFIRMATION STALLED BY THE CRITICS OF REAGAN'S POLICIES
description: The confirmation of William P. Clark as Secretary of the Interior was stalled today by an effort of 40 Senators, mostly Democrats, to bring a resolution critical of the Reagan Administration's environmental policies to the floor of the Senate.

title: GAF Blocked In Sale of Unit
description: The GAF Corporation was blocked from selling its building materials business when the United States Court of Appeals in Manhattan upheld a previous order at the request of Samuel Heyman, head of a dissident shareholder group.

title: TROTTIER AND BOSSY EXCEL
description: Greg Millen is in his sixth National Hockey League season, so he knows what Mike Bossy and Bryan Trottier can do on the ice.

title: PSA Plans to Cut Flight Attendants
description: Pacific Southwest Airlines plans to reduce the number of flight attendants on most of its flights, eliminating seats in some cases to comply with Federal rules.

title: MAY DEPARTMENT STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
REAGAN PRESSING CONGRESS ON DEBT
description: President Reagan bade Congress today to approve legislation raising the national debt ceiling to $1,600 billion, warning that failure to do so would cause the Federal Government to run out of cash Dec. 1.

description: The Giants are among the National Football League teams that Warren Moon, the highly acclaimed Canadian Football League quarterback, is interested in joining next season after he becomes a free agent, his lawyer said yesterday.

title: City Stores Seeks Seligman & Latz
description: The City Stores Company, operator of the W. J. Sloane furniture store chain, said it had agreed to acquire Seligman & Latz Inc., a specialty retailing concern, for $43.3 million.

title: WEST MIDTOWN SEES GAINS FROM CONVENTION CENTER
description: New York's $375 million convention center is expected to help the city's tourism industry while also pumping new blood into the West Midtown commercial district, an area that has not yet capitalized on its pre-eminent mass transit accessibility and its lower average office rents.

title: HOUSE EMPLOYEE QUITS IN SEX CASE
description: The House ethics committee recommended today that a House employee be dismissed for having had sexual relations in 1980 with a 17-year-old girl who was a page under his supervision at the time.

title: WAVETEK CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1

title: 3dSuspectIsArrested In Slaying in Queens
description: A third suspect was arrested last night on murder charges in the fatal stabbing of Kathleen Habeeb, a 19- year-old student at St. John's University, the police said.

title: MANVILLE'S EX-PRESIDENT FOUGHT CHAPTER 11 STEP
description: Five days before the Manville Corporation filed for bankruptcy, the company's former president and chief operating officer - who had taken early retirement two days earlier - sent a handwritten letter to Manville's chairman arguing that the company should not enter Chapter 11.

title: TURKISH CYPRIOT LEADER: RAUL RAIF DENKTASH
description: Rauf Denktash has been the virtually uncontested leader of the Turkish Cypriots on Cyprus for 20 years. Thus it probably was no surprise to radio listeners on the eastern Mediterranean island to hear his voice proclaim the establishment yesterday of an independent Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus. In a recent interview with a Turkish newspaper, Mr. Denktash had said that ''the Greek Cypriot is the legitimate party in the eyes of the world and Turkish Cypriots are not to be their equals.''

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. 76ers , at Philadelphia. Coach Hubie Brown can gauge the Knicks' progress by this first meeting of the season between the Atlantic Division foes.

description: Prudential-Bache Securities has signed a $100 million lease for 12 floors of a 35-story building being put up by Jack Resnick & Sons Inc. at 1 Seaport Plaza in the South Street Seaport developmment, according to an announcement yesterday by the two companies.

description: A campaign to designate chili as America's official food got under way at the Capitol Monday when advocates of a ''gastropolitical'' resolution held two chili tastings.

description: New Yorkers are getting their first glimpse of a future that looks more like the past - a plan for a four-block parcel that is meant to evoke Gramercy Park's intimacy and Central Park West's majesty on what is now an empty landfill.

title: VOTE ON EQUAL RIGHTS MEAUSRE
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the House of Representatives today rejected a revival of the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution. The vote in favor of the measure was 278 to 147, six votes short of the two-thirds majority required for approval. A ''yes'' vote was a vote in favor of the equal rights amendment. Voting ''yes'' were 225 Democrats and 53 Republicans. Voting ''no'' were 38 Democrats and 109 Republicans. An ''xxx'' denotes members not voting. There are no vacancies in the 435-member House. ALABAMA Democrats - Bevill, yes; Erdreich, yes; Flippo, yes; Nichols, no; Shelby, no.

title: PROTEIN OF CANCER CELLS USED TO HALT CORONARIES
description: A human protein derived from cancer cells has stopped heart attacks in progress in a small number of patients, American and Belgian researchers said here today.

title: Medich Charged
description: Dr. George Medich , the physician who was known as Doc during his 11 seasons as a major-league pitcher, has been charged by Pennsylvania authorities with writing seven improper prescriptions. If convicted he could be sentenced to as much as seven years in prison and fined $35,000.

title: 6 CITY WORKERS HAILED FOR HAVING MADE A DIFFERENCE
description: It is a miracle, E. B. White once remarked, that New York works. ''By rights New York should have destroyed itself years ago,'' he wrote, ''from panic or fire or rioting or failure of some vital supply line in its circulatory system.''

title: UNITRODE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
STAGE: 'BLUE PLATE SPECIAL,' RURAL TOUCH
description: THE motivation behind ''Blue Plate Special,'' the new musical at the Manhattan Theater Club, seems to be: If ''Pump Boys and Dinettes'' can be a hit, then any country-western-flavored musical set in a diner can be a hit. Given the surprising success of ''Pump Boys,'' whose lengthy run was wildly out of proportion to its modest virtues, this theory may not be as crazy as it sounds. But ''Blue Plate Special'' may quickly put it to rest.

title: Resin Venture in Japan
description: Toray Industries today announced an agreement with the Phillips Petroleum Company to set up a joint venture in Japan to produce polyphenylene sulphide resin, used in making car parts and electronic components.

title: Suspects Indicted In Student's Death

title: A MANET AND A CEZANNE SELL FOR NEARLY $8 MILLION
description: Edouard Manet's ''Promenade,'' an 1890 full-length portrait of a woman, became the star offering in an auction of 40 works from Paul Mellon's art collection when it sold last night at Christie's for $3.96 million. It was a record, more than twice what had ever been paid at auction for a Manet.

title: White House Urges M-1 Rise
description: The White House would like the M-1 money supply to grow somewhat faster and return to the target range set by the Federal Reserve, Larry Speakes, the chief White House spokesman, said today. ''We would like to see M-1 money growth get back within its target range in order to reflect a slow steady growth in the money supply,'' he told reporters.

description: WRITTEN, directed and produced by Paul Cowan for the National Film Board of Canada, ''The Kid Who Couldn't Miss'' is about Billy Bishop, the World War I flying ace whose reputation was on a par with that of Manfred von Richthofen, Germany's famed ''Red Baron.'' The film, which can be seen tonight at 9 on Channel 13, uses Bishop to illustrate, quite effectively, its real point: ''Heroism, like war itself, is neither as simple nor as glorious as we would like.''

title: COMMODITIES Precious Metals Rise; Recovery Sign Awaited
description: Prices of precious metals futures closed with slight gains yesterday as traders awaited some clear signs that the recent sharp declines had ended. One of the signs of a recovery would be price rises accompanied by increased trading volume. During the price breaks that began in late September, both prices and volume had declined, brokers noted.

And it has been two years since judges in Milan announced that they had cleared an Italian driver and the Monza race course director who had been blamed for the crash and instead placed the blame on the British driver, James Hunt.

title: Refinance Plan For Argentina
description: Bernardo Grinspun, who will become Economic Minister when the newly elected civilian government is installed Dec. 10, said today that Argentina will have to refinance about $17 billion of foreign debt next year. Mr. Grinspun said the country faced foreign capital and interest payments coming due next year of $18 billion, in addition to $2 billion in accumulated interest. He said the country could expect a trade surplus.

OPERA: NEW 'TURANDOT' IS PERFORMED IN BOSTON
description: BOSTON BEFORE Sarah Caldwell put together her new production of Puccini's ''Turandot,'' which had its premiere by the Opera Company of Boston Sunday afternoon, she and the scenery designer, Ming Cho Lee, traveled to China. There they met with members of the artistic design department of the Central Opera Theater of Peking, a group that has itself produced Western operas in China. They requested help in creating new costumes for the opera, with its tale of a Chinese princess posing riddles to her suitors.

description: Allan J. MacEachen, the Canadian Minister of External Affairs, said at a news conference on Monday that he had ''absolutely no evidence'' to show that the United States or its Caribbean allies in the invasion of Grenada had blocked Canadian rescue plans so that these would not interfere with the military landings then being prepared.

title: Advertising; ABC Seeks Additional Magazines

In the first 13 months after becoming president of the ABC Publishing Division in October 1981, Robert Gene Burton changed the presidents of seven of the 10 operating companies in his part of the American Broadcasting Companies.

title: JUSTICE STEWART, RETIRED, FINDS HE IS IN DEMAND
description: In his 23 years on the United States Supreme Court, Justice Potter Stewart set few records, either for time on the bench, influence or visibility. His effectiveness stemmed, instead, from hard work, steadiness and common sense.

description: Victor G. Bloede, the only creative man to run Benton & Bowles in its 54- year history, will retire at the end of the year, just before his 64th birthday in January.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1983
description: The Economy Factory output rose 0.8 percent in October, the 11th consecutive monthly gain, the Federal Reserve reported. The increase was the smallest since the recession ended last November, reflecting a normal slowing of growth. Economists hailed new evidence of rising outlays for expansion and modernization. (Page D1.) President Reagan urged Congress to raise the national debt limit to $1,600 billion. Otherwise, he warned, the Government will run out of cash Dec. 1. (A26.)

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ANYONE interested in minimalism, the blues or pure hypnotic music should find time this weekend for an extraordinary triple bill of African musicians. Saturday night in Carnegie Recital Hall and Sunday afternoon in the Alternative Museum, three virtuoso soloists will perform - Ephat Mujuru from Zimbabwe, Seleshe Damessae from Ethiopia and Djimo Kouyate from Senegal.

title: FREED PRISONERS SHOWN TO HAVE LONG RECORDS
description: Many of the prisoners freed from city jails under a court-ordered release program have long, serious criminal records, according to figures provided yesterday by District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan.

title: Golden West Sale
description: Golden West Homes said its chairman emeritus, Jerry Golden, had sold his entire stake in the company to the William Lyon Company, and that as a result, Lyon's chairman and chief executive officer, William Lyon, had been elected chairman of Golden West. Mr. Golden's shares represented 19.2 percent of the company's approximately 3.4 milllion shares outstanding. In another transaction, Golden West's previous chairman, Dave Totten, also agreed to sell his stake in the company - totaling about 3.7 percent - to William Lyon, a residential home builder in California. Mr. Totten will remain on Golden West's board.

title: Jersey to Begin Driver Photos
description: Some New Jersey motorists will have to get their pictures taken to renew their drivers' licenses starting Jan. 2, the head of the Department of Motor Vehicles, Clifford W. Snedeker, reminded drivers today.

title: GROUP OF SCIENTISTS CLOSE TO GOVERNMENT FIGHTING SPACE WEAPONS PLAN
description: Almost any time now, most arms- control experts say, the arms race may well expand from the land and sea and air into near-earth space, the frontier of the rest of the universe.

description: Billie Sol Estes, convicted of swindling, emerged from prison today and proclaimed: ''I've done the crime, I've done the time and I did it alone.''

title: Blitz Signs Evans
description: Vince Evans , the one-time starting quarterback for the Chicago Bears who has been unhappy playing behind the Bears' new starter, Jim McMahon , made it official yesterday. He turned down an offer from the Bears that would have made him one of the highest paid backup quarterbacks in the National Football League and signed a contract with the Chicago Blitz that will make him one of the highest paid starting quarterbacks in the United States Football League.

title: ENEMIES OF ARAFAT MOUNT AN ASSAULT ON HIS STRONGHOLD
description: Rebel Palestinians launched a heavy attack on Yasir Arafat's last stronghold this morning, and riflemen and tanks advanced to within 200 yards of the camp's barbed wire barriers. More than 100 civilians were reported killed or wounded in the assault, which came after two days of relative calm and was the most intense since the start of the fighting 12 days ago.

title: ROUSE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
WELL-THUMBED BOOKS THAT INSPIRED FIVE PASSIONATE COOKS
description: ON my kitchen bookshelf, tucked in between M. F. K. Fisher's ''A Cordiall Water'' and Elizabeth David's ''Summer Cooking,'' is a little book called ''Come an' Get It.'' Written by Ramon F. Adams and long out of print, it celebrates the grizzled chefs who cooked for hungry cowmen back in the days when, like Napoleon's army, they traveled on their stomachs. I don't read it for recipes - indeed, some would curl the hair of the most hardened range rider.

title: Louise Treadwell Tracy, 87; Actor's Widow Started Clinic
description: Louise Treadwell Tracy, widow of the actor Spencer Tracy and founder of the John Tracy Clinic for the hearing-impaired, died Sunday after a long illness. She was 87 years old.

title: TECH HIFI TRIES DISCOUNTING
description: Tech Hifi, the Northeastern and Middle Atlantic stereo retailer, found that a knowledgeable sales staff handing out free expert advice was not the way to make money selling electronic equipment. Its new turnaround marketing strategy may sound familiar: discount pricing.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH

A few months before filing for bankruptcy, the company said that six million Americans had used the very-low-calorie formula known as the Cambridge Diet.

title: GENERAL GIVES HIS STARS TO A WOUNDED MARINE WASHINGTON, Nov. 15 (AP) - The Marine Commandant presented his four stars today to the corporal who scrawled ''Semper Fi'' in a note to the general as the young marine lay seriously wounded from a bomb attack in Beirut.
description: ''Your gesture will remain in my heart forever,'' said Gen. Paul X. Kelley as he awarded a plaque with his stars to Lance Cpl. Jeffrey Nashton of Rome, N.Y. The plaque, too, read ''Semper Fi,'' - short for Semper Fidelis, the Marine motto, meaning always faithful.

A SADLY IMPERFECT VOICE

Feminists who have listened to a selection of computer voices want to know why the more masterful and authoritative voices giving really serious instruction always sound like males. Naturally they don't like it. They say it perpetuates the patriarchal bias of society, ''patriarchal'' having replaced ''sexist'' as this year's feminist word for deploring the present state of man- woman relationships.

title: END THE ALLIES' ANXIETY
description: For three years, America's allies have watched the battle between the pragmatists and ideologues in the Reagan Administration with growing concern. Canada's Prime Minister, Pierre Elliot Trudeau, put their central anxiety in a nutshell when he talked of a ''superpower relationship which is dangerously confrontational'' and of a ''widening gap between military strategy and political purpose.'' This climate of apprehension explains why the allies reacted so much more strongly to the invasion of Grenada than to Lyndon B. Johnson's invasion of the Dominican Republic.

title: WALL RACK FOR UTENSILS
description: THE importance of organizing kitchen utensils well, so that you have everything you need close at hand, cannot be overemphasized. There is nothing more frustrating than thrashing around the kitchen looking for a whisk or a spatula while something curdles or burns. In my kitchen all essential utensils - pots, pans, spatulas, ladles and so on - hang from racks on the ceiling or the walls. This not only makes the tools more accessible, but also keeps them in better condition.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Prices Rise on Fed Purchases
description: Prices of Treasury securities rose slightly yesterday, with all of the gains coming in the second half of the day after the Federal Reserve bought an undisclosed amount of notes and bonds for its own account.

HEARNS DROPS DATE, LAWYER DROPS HIM
description: Thomas Hearns has pulled out of a scheduled Jan. 14 defense of his World Boxing Council junior middleweight title against Wilfred Benitez, the man he took the title from a year ago. Mike Trainer, Sugar Ray Leonard's lawyer, had taken over Hearns and his manager, Emanuel Steward, as clients, but when they dropped out of the Benitez fight, which Trainer had arranged with Home Box Office, the lawyer left the camp. Hearns would prefer challenging Marvelous Marvin Hagler for the middleweight title, although it is more likely he could get a 154-pound unification match with Roberto Duran. Trainer, however, could not understand Hearns - or Steward - passing up Benitez.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: REVIVAL No"el Coward, the indefatigably clever artist for most seasons, had been absent from the American theater for 20 years when he opened in his own new comedy ''Nude With Violin'' on Broadway in November 1957. Mr. Coward starred as a valet who had held inviolate the secret that his late master, a celebrated artist, was a fraud whose work was actually done by other hands.

title: West German G.N.P.
description: The real growth in West Germany's gross national product will be well over 1 percent in 1983 and at least 2.5 percent in 1984, the Finance Minister, Gerhard Stoltenberg, said in a statement today. The economy shrank by 1.1 percent in 1982.

description: The 201-room Tahara'a, one of Tahiti's largest hotels, said Monday that it was shutting down and looking for a buyer because it could no longer absorb losses from a three-week-old strike by hotel workers.

title: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 16, 1983 International
description: Turkish Cypriots declared their part of Cyprus an independent nation. The action was deplored by the Greek Cypriot President, who heads the island's internationally recognized government. There were no reports of violence, but Turkish troops and Turkish Cypriot border guards were reported on alert along the so-called green line that has divided Cyprus since 1974. (Page A1, Columns 5-6.) Greece condemned the Turkish Cypriots' announcement that the northern part of Cyprus had been proclaimed independent. Athens denied reports that it had called a general mobilization. (A18:1.)

title: BOSTON ELECTS RAYMOND L. FLYNN, A POPULIST COUNCILMAN, AS MAYOR
description: A political era ended in Boston today as Raymond L. Flynn, a City Councilman of conservative Irish roots and populist views, rode a wave of newly awakened neighborhood political strength to victory in the mayoral race.

title: COMMITTEE CELEBRATES 50 YEARS OF AIDING REFUGEES

description: Grim prospects for natural gas are about to become grim realities. Consumers, already burdened by sky-high heating bills, will end up paying much more. Producers, already suffering from sluggish sales, will see thousands of industrial users switch to imported oil. Is there a way to avoid such serious disruptions in the $50 billion market for natural gas? Yes, but only if the Senate acts bravely - and speedily.

title: THEATER: YOUNG MELVILLE

In 1850 he had moved from New York City to Pittsfield, Mass., a place with ancestral echoes, and settled with his family in a house named Arrowhead.

title: ITALIANS APPROVE PLAN ON MISSILES
description: The Italian Chamber of Deputies today voted 351 to 219, with one abstention, affirming a 1979 decision to install 112 cruise missiles in Sicily if arms limitation talks in Geneva failed to produce results.

title: Off-Duty City Officer Is Shot by Policeman
description: An off-duty New York City police officer was shot in the face and shoulder last night by an on-duty officer on a Brooklyn street, the police said.

title: AMERICAN MONITOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ENERGY EXCHANGE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Comparable year-ago results are not available because the company went public in November 1982.

title: U.N. LEADER DENIES LOSS OF POST
description: The president of the United Nations General Assembly, Jorge Enrique Illueca of Panama, said today that there was no truth to reports that he had been dismissed as Vice President of his country.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: 30-Year Bonds By Fannie Mae

title: NEW INTEREST IN COLLECTING ART POTTERY
description: IN 1968 at an upstate New York auction, Marcia and William Goodman paid $22 for their first piece of American art pottery, a green and cream-colored jardiniere pedestal decorated with molded red apples. On the bottom it bore the mark ''Weller,'' but so little was known about the pottery that it took almost a year for the Goodmans to identify it as a pattern called Baldin, made about 1915 by the Weller Pottery in Zanesville, Ohio.

title: Advertising; Goodyear Flies High At J.W.T.
description: THE other morning, when Robert E. Mercer, chairman and chief executive of the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, arrived for breakfast at J. Walter Thompson, the beneficiary of his company's recent ad agency consolidation move, a relaxed top management team accorded him only the honor it might give any visiting king or pope.

title: SCOUTING
description: The Hard Way

title: MUSIC: BILSON AND FRIENDS
description: -music scene has not by any means reached the level of excellence and diversity of, say, London's: We still lack the large- sized ensembles and choruses that so distinguish the English capital. But on a more intimate level, it would be difficult to imagine a much better concert of this sort than that offered Monday night at the Abraham Goodman House.

title: AMERICA'S BURDEN IN FOREIGN DEBT CRISES
description: To the Editor:

title: BETHLEHEM MAY BRING IMPORT SUIT
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation is preparing a far-reaching trade suit that would place a ceiling on imports of basic steel below current levels.

title: CHARTER MEDICAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Year-ago share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split paid in September 1983.

title: STRATEGY FOR PEACE IN MIDEAST
description: In the Middle East, the United States has a purpose - but it can't seem to develop a policy and a strategy to achieve it. The purpose is obvious: to bring about peace between Israel and its Arab neighbors and to help countries of the region meet the problems of modernization.

title: Jersey Expanding Credit-Card Bail
description: A program permitting defendants in Municipal Courts to pay fines and post bail with credit cards may be made available next year throughout New Jersey, officials said today.

title: Acting in Concert
description: The owners of the Braves and the Falcons think it is time for football and baseball to go their separate ways in Atlanta, and they want the city to build one and possibly two new stadiums to accommodate the teams, which share the 19-year-old Atlanta- Fulton County Stadium. In a meeting with the chairman of the city's Stadium Authority, Ted Turner , the Braves' owner, and Rankin Smith , the Falcons' owner, complained that the stadium was outdated. According to the authority chairman, Marvin Arrington , the teams' owners asked the authority to build two new stadiums or to build one new facility while renovating the present one.

title: DR PEPPER HALTS TRADING IN STOCK
description: The Dr Pepper Company, one of the nation's leading soft-drink producers, asked the New York Stock Exchange to halt trading in its stock yesterday pending ''a significant announcement,'' after a meeting today of its 11- member board of directors.

title: Soviet Population Increases
description: The population of the Soviet Union rose by 2.4 million in the past year to 272.5 million, the highest increase in 20 years, the official Soviet press agency Tass reported today. Tass said the population increase was caused by economic development, a rise in living standards and several Government measures to increase subsidies to families.

title: Another White Officer Set Free in Zimbabwe
description: Zimbabwe today released from detention without trial a fourth white air force officer who had been accused of subversive activities.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Allied Corp. has appointed M. Jack Ripley chairman and chief executive of Allied Canada Inc., Toronto.

title: BRIEFING
description: It Was Simply Beastly

title: Two Groups Join To Save Salmon
description: Those interested in aiding the

title: TORONTO SUN PUBLISHING reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
STUDY SAYS HEDGES MAY STOP BURGLARS
description: A neatly trimmed hedge could be as effective as a locked door in stopping a burglar, research by a University of Utah graduate student shows.

title: PENTAGON AIDE WARNS SALVADOR TERROR MUST END
description: A high Defense Department official charged tonight that ''the death squads of the violent right'' in El Salvador are actually benefiting the leftist guerrillas and ''more must be done'' to restrain them.

title: EMETT & CHANDLER INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $118,000.

title: DOUBLE DUTY FOR 3 GIANTS
description: A major problem for the Giants has been the erratic performances of the special teams. They have often been anything but special.

title: CYPRIOTS SOUGHT TO DRAMATIZE LOT
description: A spokesman for the newly declared Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus said today that Turkish Cypriots proclaimed their part of the island a sovereign state on Tuesday to focus world attention on their cause and to improve their ability to obtain a federation with Greek Cypriots on equal terms.

title: Harris Bancorp Gets New Chief
description: The Harris Bankcorp of Chicago yesterday announced the promotion of B. Kenneth West, 50 years old, to the positions of chairman and chief executive officer.

title: CORADIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $337,000 for the quarter and 9 months from the repurchase of 13 percent convertible debentures.

title: RECITAL: GREGORY FULKERSON, VIOLINIST
description: THE most striking piece on Gregory Fulkerson's recital Tuesday night at Alice Tully Hall was the first performance of Jon Deak's ''Greetings from 1984.'' In a sense, this is a score for violin and piano, just what one might expect at a violin recital. But Mr. Deak, who is associate principal bass of the New York Philharmonic, is a composer who likes to frustrate common expectations. He also likes to illustrate extramusical ideas with what amount to sound effects, and both those tendencies were fully audible in this new piece.

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: CALENDAR: GIFTS FOR THE HOLIDAY SEASON
description: Museum Holiday Gift Shops

title: OPTICAL RADIATION CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
STRATEGIC ALLIANCE: PROBLEMS
description: Oscar Wilde once wrote that there are only two tragedies: One is not getting what one wants and the other is getting it. Israel's Government seems at last to have what it has longed for since 1977 - a strategic alliance with the United States. Yet neither Israel nor the United States have begun to imagine the problems this could create.

title: I.M.F. Action Awaited
description: Monetary officials in Washington said today that no decision had been taken by the I.M.F. on a loan to the Philippines.

title: WATERMAN MARINE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $3,949,000 from the writeoff of deferred tax benefits for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Woman Seized in Fracas On Arizona Picket Line
description: The Arizona police today arrested the wife of a discharged Phelps Dodge Corporation striker on charges of disturbing the peace as sporadic demonstrations continued at the copper company.

title: MANY BOYCOTT HERZOG SPEECH
description: Some 70 countries were absent when President Chaim Herzog of Israel addressed the General Assembly this morning. The absentees included virtually all the Communist countries; the Arab countries, except Egypt, and many countries espousing nonalignment.

title: JACOBS ENGINEERING GROUP INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
ROLFITE CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes tax credits of $512,527 for the quarter and $828,527 for the 9 months.

title: FOR CLAUDETTE COLBERT, AN AWARD AND A PARTY FIT FOR A STAR
description: CLAUDETTE COLBERT was just as rapt as everyone else. There she was, larger than life, asking Ray Milland to kiss her, falling into Clark Gable's arms, a svelte Cleopatra, a flirtatious, beruffled dancing girl, a gamin in pajamas.

title: COPLAND HONORED ON 83D BIRTHDAY
description: As an 83d birthday tribute to a Brooklyn boy who grew up and became widely known as the ''dean of American composers,'' Mayor Koch last night invited some special guests to Gracie Mansion and presented Aaron Copland with the New York City Seal of Recognition.

title: Former World Leaders Seek to Solve Problems
description: Former government leaders, some of them now heads of their countries' political opposition, started a new international pressure group today to try to defuse major world problems.

title: NAUGLES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 20
COMSERV CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: SCITEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AMERICAN CONTROLLED INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income from discontinued operations of $368,857 for the quarter and 9 months.

title: PONDEROSA INC reports earnings for 12 wks to Nov 3
INTEREST RATES RISE SLIGHTLY
description: Interest rates rose slightly yesterday in all maturities of the Treasury market, reversing the modest declines that occurred in the morning.

title: ISRAELI JETS BOMB BASE OF SUSPECTS IN MARINE ATTACK
description: Israeli fighter planes today bombed an eastern Lebanese training base reportedly belonging to pro-Iranian Shiite militiamen suspected of involvement in recent suicide attacks on American, French and Israeli military barracks in Lebanon.

title: Steel Talks Put Off
description: Talks scheduled to be held today between the United States and the European Economic Community on a dispute over American import controls on special steel have been put off until the end of November, trade sources said. The Common Market wants compensation for the American restrictions.

title: Virginia Tire Blaze Costly
description: Virginia has been spending $26,000 a day to contain the oily runoff from a pile of seven million used tires that has been burning at a dump since Oct. 31.

title: ECONOMIC PROBLEMS TIED TO APARTHEID
description: South Africa's racial policy of apartheid, or racial separation, is creating ''inflationary pressures'' and ''adding to unemployment'' in that country, according to a confidential report by the International Monetary Fund.

title: PSA TO GET 20 BRITISH JETLINERS
description: -based airline company, announced yesterday that it had ordered 20 newly developed, short-haul jets for $300 million from British Aerospace to compete more effectively in the West Coast market.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 17, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: BASIC AMERICAN MEDICAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNESCO'S BUDGET HITS $374 MILLION
description: Despite American objections, the United Nations Educational, Cultural and Scientific Organization adopted a $374.4 million budget for 1984-85 today, an increase of $13 million over the current budget.

title: STATE SENATE CONFIRMS KILEY AS HEAD OF M.T.A.
description: Robert R. Kiley, saying he had no ''magic potion or panacea'' to offer, was confirmed today by the State Senate as the fifth chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: 6 Miners Die in South Africa
description: Six miners died Tuesday night after they were overcome by carbon monoxide fumes two miles below the earth's surface at an Anglo American Corporation gold mine southwest of here.

title: DATATAB INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results for the latest periods include a pretax gain of $200 for the quarter and a pretax loss of $23,150 for the 9 months on the sale of equipment.

title: THE SURVIVING PERIL OF A SUNKEN SUB
description: To the Editor:

title: KEAN SEEKS TO AVERT POLICE LAYOFFS IN 6 CITIES
description: Governor Kean announced today that he would ask the Legislature for $5 million to help the state's six biggest cities meet salary increases being won by police officers and firefighters under binding arbitration.

title: WEST BANK TEACHERS ALMOST CIRCUMVENT ISRAEL'S PLEDGE RULE
description: A group of foreign teachers in the West Bank have raised a new challenge to the Israeli Government's policy of requiring them to pledge that they will not support the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Buttes Gas & Oil Co. announced that its offshore contract drilling subsidiary had concluded a $113 million financing agreement with a group of banks led by Security Pacific National Bank.

title: GLENN STEPS UP HIS ATTACKS ON MONDALE POLICIES
description: Senator John Glenn of Ohio stepped up his political attack on Walter F. Mondale in a speech here tonight, saying that the former Vice President's campaign proposals would add to the Federal deficit by requiring at least $89 billion a year in new Federal spending.

title: Article 048909 -- No Title
description: Money bags containing $9 million in cash fell out the back door of a Brink's truck onto the Southeast Expressway, the police said today. All but $2,000 was reported recovered by guards as traffic was rerouted.

title: CLASSES ON NUCLEAR WAR MOVE INTO CURRICULUMS
description: William Everdell was sketching the outlines of West Germany on a chalkboard in a classroom at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn Heights, talking to his students about the Pershing 2 missiles to be deployed in that country starting next month.

title: SCHOOLS GIVEN GUIDANCE ON ATOM-WAR TV FILM
description: Top New York City school officials, concerned about the way children might react to an upcoming television movie about nuclear war, sent a memorandum to public school superintendents and principals last week, advising them on how to deal with the subject.

title: TV: JULIA CHILD SERIES ON DINNERS
description: LET it be clear at the outset that I adore Julia Child. In a class with Lucille Ball, the Muppets and Walter Cronkite, she has one of those personalities that seem tailor-made for television. She doesn't just appear on the screen; she comes floating into your home as a welcome presence. She is not just a food authority; she is a natural entertainer.

title: MILLER-WOHL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock distribution paid Aug. 10.

title: CARDILLO TRAVEL SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: SCOUTING
description: Hurt Feelings

title: NORTH AMERICAN NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including securities gains of $96,119 for the quarter and $133,860 for the 6 months. c-After a securities loss of $440 for the quarter and a securities gain of $16,863 for the 6 months.

title: SENATE PANEL ACCUSES CAREY ON '82 CAMPAIGN ADS
description: A committee of the Republican-controlled State Senate charged today that former Gov. Hugh L. Carey had ''subverted'' a statefinanced promotional campaign by using its television advertising to influence last year's race for Governor.

title: ATCOR INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Liners Cancel Grenada Calls
description: Winter cruise visits to Grenada by the luxury liners Queen Elizabeth 2 and Cunard Countess have been canceled because of problems in connection with the United States-led invasion of the island, the Cunard Line said today.

title: INDIA, WITH BITTERSWEET MEMORIES, AWAITS QUEEN
description: Roughly 250 miles southeast of here, in the city of Lucknow, stand the ruined shells of a cluster of late 18th-century buildings. From them, the British once ruled a vast expanse of northern India.

title: SECRET PAPERS REPORTED IN CAMPAIGN INQUIRY
description: Representative Donald J. Albosta said tonight that several highly classified Government documents had been found by Congressional aides investigating the unauthorized transfer of documents from the Carter White House to Ronald Reagan's Presidential campaign in 1980.

title: Bell System's Final Dividend
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company announced yesterday that the final dividend to be paid out by the consolidated Bell System would be $1.35 a share, to be paid on Feb. 1, 1984, to shareholders of record on Dec. 30.

title: CITY BALLET: 3 BALANCHINE WORKS OPEN THE SEASON
description: THE New York City Ballet opened its season at the State Theater Tuesday night with three ballets by George Balanchine, and this all-Balanchine program served as a simple declaration of belief in the company's esthetic.

title: Medich in Drug Program
description: George (Doc) Medich, the former major league pitcher, is undergoing treatment for a dependence on drugs he is charged with improperly prescribing, hospital officials said today. Medich, a resident in orthopedic surgery at Children's Hospital here, was charged Monday with seven counts of writing prescriptions to nonexistent patients and to people who never received the drugs.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Mavericks, at Dallas. Kelvin Ransey of the Nets returns to Dallas, where he played last season. Ransey, a guard, has been averaging 6.9 assists a game as a reserve this season. The much-improved Mavericks are in first place and the only Midwest Division team over .500. (Television - Channel 9, 8:30 P.M. Radio - WNBC 660, 8:30 P.M.).

title: THE N.H.L. - LYSIAK STYLE
description: Quietly, the National Hockey League and Tom Lysiak agreed yesterday on a conditional out-of-court settlement designed to permit the Chicago Black Hawks' center to appeal a 20- game suspension for having ''deliberately'' and ''forceably'' felled a linesman in a game three weeks ago. Originally, no appeal was possible.

title: MAXCO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including income of $6,192 for the quarter and a loss of $15,466 for the 6 months from discontinued operations and a gain of $324,000 for the quarter and 6 months on the sale of discontinued operations. c-Including income from discontinued operations of $10,102.

title: ARAFAT FOES PUSH INTO STRONGHOLD
description: Syrian-backed Palestinian rebels fought their way today into the muddy streets of the Beddawi refugee camp just northeast of here and said they had taken Yasir Arafat's last stronghold in Lebanon.

title: Tram to Be Closed
description: The Roosevelt Island tramway will be closed for 10 days, beginning at midnight tomorrow, to replace the cable that hauls the tram cars and for other routine maintenance.

title: SAME SPACE, SAME BUDGET: 2 DIFFERENT SOLUTIONS
description: SHARING ideas was not something new for the New York architects Megan Walker and Michael Lipkin, as they had been classmates at Yale University's Graduate School of Architecture. But last year when Miss Walker and Mr. Lipkin bought raw space across the hall from each other on the same top floor of a building on the Lower East Side, they found themselves working together again - this time practicing design theories for themselves.

title: EARNINGS
description: R. H. Macy & Company reported yesterday that earnings in the first fiscal quarter of 1984 rose 24.6 percent on a 16.8 percent increase in sales.

title: U.S. PLANS GRENADA PULLOUT BY DEC. 23
description: The Reagan Administration said today that American combat troops would be withdrawn from Grenada by Dec. 23 and that there was no need for Congress to authorize their presence beyond that date.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Sundered Bell's Street Value
description: how to play the whole and the parts upon the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company - got off to a rousing start yesterday.

title: Edmund O. Stillman, Political Trend Analyst
description: Edmund O. Stillman, director of Hudson Research Europe, an independent policy research group based in Paris, died of cancer there last Thursday. He was 59 years old and lived in Paris and Redding, Conn.

title: TO FACE LIFT OR NOT?
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:Do you want to know what I did with the article by Mary-Lou Weisman? I cut it out, hung it over my mirror - and reread it every day while I tug at my face.

title: NEW KEEL BACKED
description: An International Yacht Racing Union committee upheld today the legality of winged keels, a move that likely means 12-Meter yachts will be redesigned to look like the America's Cup winner, Australia II.

title: BAYOU RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Comparable year-ago results are not available because the company began operations as a public company on Jan. 10, 1983.

title: Pentagon Honors Women
description: Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger today dedicated a special Pentagon corridor devoted to honoring the 200,000 women in uniform and other women who have served the armed forces since the Revolutionary War.

title: Coppola Studio for Sale as Deal Fails
description: Francis Ford Coppola's embattled Zoetrope Studios is up for sale again after the latest deal to buy the studio fell through, a Zoetrope spokesman said.

title: SLUSHER RAISES PAY AND HACKLES
description: In the offices of some National Football League franchises, owners and general managers spit out Howard Slusher's name from between clenched teeth and say that, given the choice between two relatively equal players, they will draft the one who has another agent.

title: WRATHER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SOVEREIGN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After realized investment losses of $261,951 for the quarter and $212,705 for the 9 months and a tax credit of $97,945 for the quarter and 9 months. c-After realized investment gains of $7,846 for the quarter and $185,246 for the 9 months. Both 1982 periods were adjusted to give effect to an approximate 7 percent dividend in December 1982. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: MIZEL PETRO RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
SIGMA MINES (QUEBEC) LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The latest 9 months earnings reflect higher gold prices and a gain of $1,799,000 after tax on the sale of investments.

title: TO FACE LIFT OR NOT?
description: TO THE HOME SECTION:If you ask me, a person of either gender who has a face lift for cosmetic purposes is ipso facto ''vapid.'' I don't think integrity is so cold a consolation - and, I have a hunch, neither do you. JAMES P. JORDAN Alexandria, Va.

title: Article 049211 -- No Title
description: Egon Schiele's ''Portrait of the Painter Zakovsek,'' a rare 1910 oil by the Viennese Expressionist, sold last night for $2.4 million, a record auction price for a work by this artist or any other German Expressionist.

title: $500 Million Issue By Salomon Unit
description: A $500 million issue of bonds collateralized by Government National Mortgage Association pass-through securities is offered through Salomon Brothers. The securities are issued by Salomon Brothers Mortgage Securities.

title: ALMY STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
description: b-Net loss.

title: PANEL ASKS LOAN CURB OVERSEAS
description: House and Senate negotiators have agreed on a series of measures to tighten supervision over international lending of American banks as part of a bill that would increase the American contribution to the International Monetary Fund by $8.4 billion.

title: L.I. Man Accused Of Gas Tax Fraud
description: A former gasoline distributor on Long Island was charged yesterday with defrauding New York State and New Jersey out of more than $2 million in gasoline excise and sales taxes from 1978 to 1981.

title: U.S. AIDES, PLEASED BY RAID, DENY JOINT PLANNING
description: Reagan Administration officials expressed satisfaction today with the Israeli bombing attack on a pro-Iranian group in Lebanon. The group is believed to have been involved in the terrorist attacks on American, French and Israeli forces in Lebanon.

title: Director of Census Chosen
description: President Reagan said today that he would nominate John G. Keane, an Illinois businessman, to be Director of the Census. Mr. Keane, a former vice president of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency in Chicago, lives in Barrington, Ill.

title: PurcellAsksState ForPilgrimPrison
description: The Nassau County Executive, Francis T. Purcell, called on the Cuomo administration today to give the Long Island Correctional Facility in Brentwood to Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Francis L. Dale , the publisher of The Los Angeles Herald Examiner and a former president of the Cincinnati Reds, last night confirmed that he is a candidate to replace Baseball Commissioner Bowie Kuhn , whose resignation takes effect Dec. 31. But Dale, 61, said he ''would have doubts about doing it even if it was made available.'' . . . Lynn Dickey , the quarterback for the Green Bay Packers, has signed two one-year contracts through the 1985 season.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If I had been a white middle-class man with an ex-wife who had come up and said, 'This man is a murderer,' and if this woman was a deranged alcoholic, I would not have been prosecuted.'' - Ginny Foat after her acquittal in murder trial. (B9:1.)

title: CENTURY OIL & GAS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Breaking a Barrier
description: After 89 years as an all-male bastion, The Jockey Club has admitted women - three who have long played prominent roles in horse racing. They are Helen Chenery , who raced Secretariat and Riva Ridge and is in her second term as president of the Thoroughbred Owners and Breeders Association; Allaire du Pont , who owned Kelso and is on the executive committee of the breeders association, and Martha Gerry , who raced Forego and is a trustee of the association. Ogden Mills Phipps , the chairman of the 91-member Jockey Club, said the new members ''bring a perspective on the sport of thoroughbred breeding and racing which will be most beneficial to a service organization such as The Jockey Club,'' which registers thoroughbred race horses and keeps the American Stud Book.

title: RJ FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FIVE U.S. SCIENTISTS WIN 1983 LASKER AWARD
description: Five American scientists whose research has had a powerful influence on the areas of vaccines, heart disease and the human brain were named yesterday as winners of the Albert Lasker medical research awards for 1983.

title: CONFEREES DEBATE EFFORT FOR ANTISATELLITE ARMS
description: As House and Senate conferees debated whether to provide start-up money for production of antisatellite weapons, an expert on military technology said today that the Soviet Union launched a ''target satellite'' into orbit Oct. 1.

title: HERS
description: ARE little girls forever exalted, forever doomed, to adore their fathers? My father died this fall at the age of 78 from Parkinson's disease. It was the right time for him to die. His death was anticipated, even yearned for; his body had become as stiff and bent and useless as a discarded wire hanger. His keen mind occupied a ringside seat at his own body's undignified betrayal. It was the right time for him, but not for me, not for the part of me called ''Daddy's girl.''

title: A DEMOCRATIC DISPUTE TURNS NASTY
description: Democrats, it has seemed over the years, love to maul one another as much they do Republicans. They are at it again, this time over party rules, and some Democrats fear it is getting out of hand.

description: To the Editor:

title: Fearful Nicaraguans Dig Air-Raid Trenches
description: Thousands of Nicaraguans began digging air-raid trenches today after Government warnings of an imminent invasion involving United States troops.

description: A strong earthquake jolted the island of Hawaii today, damaging homes, breaking gas and water lines and disrupting telephone service. At least four people suffered minor injuries.

title: RUN, JEANE, RUN
description: Everybody knows that President Reagan is going to run again. Paul Laxalt makes no bones about it: it's all over but the formal announcement, which is being held back only to build suspense. Republican National Committee cameramen take positions at the ''front'' in South Korea to film the khaki-clad candidate glaring aross the DMZ for a film to be shown at the convention. It's all over but the declaring.

title: CONGRESSIONAL AGREEMENT CALLS FOR 100,000 NEWLY SUBSIDIZED HOUSING UNITS
description: Breaking a legislative stalemate over the Government's role in housing, Congress today moved toward passage of legislation that would authorize Federal subsidies for 100,000 additional housing units around the country.

title: Atrocities by Insurgents Reported in Peru
description: Maoist guerrillas who had vowed to disrupt local elections killed at least 26 people in one village and cut fingers off voters in four other villages on the day after the balloting, the police said today.

title: I.B.M. on Campus
description: Columbia University's graduate school of business and the International Business Machines Corporation plan a three-year, $3.5 million program to introduce computers into the school's curriculum. The program, known as the Information Technology Project, is designed to help Columbia simulate real-life situations facing business managers on a day-to-day basis.

SONOMA VINEYARDS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
TV SYNDICATION RULES TO REMAIN UNTIL SPRING
description: The chairman of the Federal Communications Commission promised today that the agency would delay until next spring a final vote on a proposal to allow the major television networks to enter the program syndication business.

title: Blues Player Hurt
description: Mark Reeds , a right wing for the St. Louis Blues, was struck by a stick and suffered severe cuts around his right eye during a game Tuesday night against the Montreal Canadiens.

title: NAPOLEONIC SILKS - AND HIS TENT
description: JEAN COURAL, a slightly built man, didn't seem to mind at all that he was somewhat dwarfed by Napoleon Bonaparte's large, rectangular, blue and white striped battlefield campaign tent. Rather, he appeared to revel in the fact that the tent, discovered a few months ago in an obscure warehouse outside of Paris, was on public exhibition for the first time outside France and has become the core of a Fashion Institute of Technology exhibition of 19th-century Napoleonic silks from Lyons. He gazed at the tent, which Napoleon had used in the course of the Spanish campaign, turned back, threw out his left arm and said with a good deal of quiver in his voice, ''After Napoleon, nothing!''

title: DEBT CEILING IS A RECURRING PROBLEM
description: Congress once again is being told by a President that it must do something it tries to avoid: approve an increase in the ceiling on the national debt.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: AN ADMIRABLE WOMAN. By Arthur A.

title: Q&A
description: Q. Our house was built in 1937 and has a brick foundation with a fully finished room in the basement. Due to a broken gutter downspout, water accumulated on the outside of one wall and seeped through the brick and the plaster, leaving a serious case of mildew on the inside. Also, the plaster is crumbling and coming off in several places where the wall is below the ground level. We plan to patch the plaster in the worst places, then wash the walls with a bleach solution to kill the mildew. After that we thought of applying two coats of a waterproof paint sealer that the manufacturer advertises as being ''warranted for 10 years to waterproof basement and concrete interiors.'' We then plan to paint over this with a stain killer that will cover the mildew stains, then apply a regular interior wall paint. Do you think this will solve our problem?

title: HUNDREDS OF RIKERS I. CELLS VACANT UNDER COURT ORDER
description: While the city was releasing 610 inmates from its jails earlier this month, hundreds of jail cells and dormitory beds - more than enough for all the freed prisoners - remained empty on Rikers Island.

title: Student Loan Bonds Backed
description: An innovative issue of student loan revenue bonds of the Louisiana Public Facilities Authority was offered yesterday through underwriters led by Howard, Weil, Labouisse, Friedrichs Inc., a New Orleans-based firm. The $69.8 million of 7 percent bonds due in 1986 were offered at a price of 100.

title: APPLAUSE FILLS THEATER IN A TRIBUTE TO THE LUNTS
description: The last time Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne came to Broadway was in 1970, to see the play ''Home.'' As they entered the theater, the audience rose and applauded. ''Lunt said, 'There must be someone important here - everyone's standing,' '' recalled Donald Seawell, a friend of the couple. ''It never occurred to him it was for them.''

title: Too Rough in Tulsa
description: His Tulsa Roughnecks won the North American Soccer League's championship and he was named the league's coach of the year, but the club's threatened financial collapse and its dramatic rescue by fan donations proved too much for Terry Hennessey . Yesterday, he announced his resignation and said that he was moving to Australia. Steve Earle , the assistant coach, was named his replacement.

title: FILM OFFICIAL DISMISSED
description: Thom Mount, president of worldwide motion picture production at Universal Pictures, was abruptly dismissed today.

title: STUDY CALLS CITY INDIFFERENT TO GROWING CRISIS OF HUNGER
description: A new study says that the problem of hunger in New York City has reached crisis proportions, growing beyond the capacity of voluntary efforts, and that the Mayor and other city officials are ''indifferent'' to the situation.

title: U.S. SUPPORTS WESTWAY BUT IS HOLDING UP FUNDS
description: The Reagan Administration told Governor Cuomo today that it still supported the Westway project, but that, for now, it was prevented by legal and fiscal considerations from spending any more money on it.

title: Chicago Board Response
description: The Chicago Board of Trade plans to strengthen surveillance and discipline of members in response to a warning from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission's division of trading and markets, the chairman of the exchange said Tuesday. The warning came in the form of a recommendation that the commission refuse to approve the Board of Trade's applications for new contracts unless it improves surveillance and disciplinary procedures.

title: MAYFAIR SUPER MARKETS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 3
NEW TYPE OF MAYOR-ELECT IN BOSTON: RAYMOND LEO FLYNN
description: There have been mornings when Catherine Flynn has come downstairs in the shingled house on Flint Place in South Boston, and found a homeless man, a derelict, slumbering on the couch. Her husband, the Mayor-elect of Boston, had seen him slumped in some doorway as he returned from a meeting the night before, and had brought him home for a sandwich and a bed.

title: Japan Vehicle Exports
description: Vehicle exports by Japanese companies in October rose 2.9 percent from a year earlier, to 462,678 units, but were down 1.7 percent from the 482,203 vehicles sent abroad in September, industry sources said today.

title: PEACE PACT URGED FOR LATIN REGION
description: The four- nation group that is seeking to mediate an end to the conflict in Central America proposed today that the five Governments in the region sign peace treaties immediately, Latin American diplomats said.

title: STATE TO TEST A NEW SYSTEM FOR PAYING NURSING HOMES
description: New York State is planning to test a new Medicaid system of financing nursing homes that would pay them more for the care of poor elderly patients with difficult medical and psychiatric problems.

title: AN ANTIQUE FINISH FOR OLD FURNITURE
description: AN old, battered piece of furniture may be basically sound and useful, but not worth stripping down to the raw wood and refinishing with a traditional natural finish that lets the grain and color show through.

title: President Quits At Carnation
description: The Carnation Company of Los Angeles said yesterday that Dwight Stuart, 59 years old, had resigned as president ''to devote full time to personal interests.'' Timm F. Crull, 52, executive vice president, was named to succeed him. Mr. Stuart is the son of the late Elbridge Hadley Stuart, former chairman of Carnation, and the grandson of Elbridge Amos Stuart, the company's founder. Mr. Crull joined Carnation in 1955. He left in 1977 to become president of Norton Simon Inc. and returned to Carnation in 1980.

title: WITNESS IS SLAIN AFTER DISCLOSURE OF HIS IDENTITY
description: A key witness in a Manhattan murder trial was found shot to death Monday, several hours after his name had been made public in court. Yesterday, the judge declared a mistrial after jurors said they had read about and discussed the witness's slaying.

title: TV: STREISAND WORLD
description: -hour interview with Barbra Streisand on ''20/20'' tonight is that we all share the same insights, the same knowledge and the same sympathetic understanding of Miss Streisand. The contradiction is that she is not interviewed very often, either on television or in print, and so we know her only as an entertainer, or in what we pick up now and then in the gossip columns. No matter. On ''20/20'' tonight, at 10 o'clock on ABC-TV, Geraldo, Barbra, you and I - we are en famille.

Celtics' Streak Snapped at 9
description: Mark Eaton scored 10 of his 17 points in the final quarter and blocked two shots in the final 3 minutes to lift the Utah Jazz to a 122-109 victory tonight over the Celtics, snapping Boston's winning streak at nine games.

description: The International Monetary Fund has approved a standby credit of $652 million for the Philippines, President Ferdinand E. Marcos announced today.

title: THE AMERICAN WAY
description: Robert Coard is the model of the modern American immigrant. He came to the United States in 1945 from his birthplace, Grenada. He got an education and made his way up. He became director of Action for Boston Community Development, the city's respected anti-poverty agency. He was voted one of Boston's outstanding citizens. He was asked to the White House.

title: Cosmos Routed

Leading 1-0 after the first period, the Sockers put five shots past the Cosmos' David Brcic to take control. The Cosmos got two goals from Hubert Birkenmeier, their regular goalkeeper outdoors.

title: THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1983 International
description: Israeli jets bombed a training base in eastern Lebanon reportedly belonging to pro-Iranian Shiite militiamen suspected of involvement in recent suicide attacks on American, French and Israeli military barracks. The base is three miles from the Syrian border. The Christian Phalangist radio said 30 people were killed and about 50 wounded. (Page A1, Col. 6.) Yasir Arafat's last redoubt was in jeopardy as Syrian-backed Palestinian rebels fought their way into the Beddawi refugee camp outside Tripoli. Tripoli's leaders met in efforts to prevent the fighting from spreading into the city of 600,000. (A1:5.)

description: Maurice A. Ferre's election to a sixth term as Mayor of Miami in a runoff vote Tuesday night apparently resulted from bloc voting by blacks and unexpected support from non-Latin whites.

description: Dai Rees, a Welsh professional golfer who was the captain of the last British team to win the Ryder Cup, died in Tuesday night after a long illness.

description: BALLET NUEVO MUNDO DE CARACAS took a daredevil approach to dancing when it opened a week's season on Tuesday night at the City Center Theater. It was an evening of flash and glitter.

description: Evaluation is a subject usually confined to a few early pages of an elementary textbook. It has a dreary aspect, and the author and the reader proceed thankfully to more exciting topics.

description: It has been almost seven months since the side of a rain-soaked mountain suddenly tore loose, tumbled in an avalanche of mud toward the Pacific Ocean, and buried a long stretch of California's Route 1. And like many of the 1,500 or so residents of Big Sur, Sue Rideout sometimes wonders if the road will ever be open again.

title: A.T.& T. Contract
