It said Standard Telephones and Cables Ltd. of Britain and Submarcom of France were chosen to provide the other part of the system. The system, expected to cost a total of $335 million, will be owned by 28 international telecommunications corporations.

title: Alaskan Volcano Erupts
description: Pavlof Volcano erupted Tuesday for the sixth time in the last 10 years, spewing ash to an altitude of 25,000 feet and forcing planes to take detours, officials said. While some ash from the volcano on the Alaska Peninsula may fall on the communities of Cold Bay, King Cove and Sand Point, the eruption posed no threat to the sparsely populated area, Tom Miller, a spokesman for the United States Geological Survey, said.

title: Was This E.R.A. Defeat Necessary?
description: Tuesday's vote against the Equal Rights Amendment in the House had less to do with the substance of the amendment than with exploiting the ''gender gap'' and targeting E.R.A. opponents for defeat in next year's elections. The skirmish may have done the E.R.A. - already deeply wounded - more harm than good.

title: Flynt Delivers Fine In Overstuffed Suitcases
description: Larry Flynt, the publisher who has been ordered to pay a fine of $10,000 a day until he discloses the source of a tape recording in the John Z. DeLorean drug case, delivered his second installment in court today in two suitcases packed with small notes.

description: A Canadian company has started a cable-television service for children that offers a 24-hour-a-day channel of stories and computer graphics, but no sound.

title: After Arafat
description: Already crippled by Israel, Yasir Arafat has been finished off by Syria. What General Sharon could not complete in the face of America's protest, President Assad has now completed, apparently over Soviet protest. The final blow to the only independent organization of Palestine Arabs has been delivered by other Arabs. Mr. Arafat, having lived by Soviet arms, has been crushed by Soviet arms. Long sustained by oil money from the gulf, he has succumbed to superior force bought by oil money from the gulf.

SENATE APPROVES INCREASE IN LIMIT OF FEDERAL DEBT
description: The Senate this morning paved the way for Congress to adjourn by the end of this week by adopting legislation to raise the national debt ceiling and allow the Government to continue borrowing money. Earlier, the Senate took another major step toward clearing its agenda by rejecting, 59 to 38, a bill to provide tax credits against the tuition parents pay to send their children to private schools. President Reagan had placed the tuition tax credits at the top of his legislative priority list, but Senator Bob Dole, the Kansas Republican who offered the proposal, said it was probably dead now unless supporters could convince Congress it would not harm the public schools.

To Face Lift or Not?
description: -Lou Weisman's welcome exploration of the moral dilemma middle-aged feminists experience when contemplating facial cosmetic surgery (Hers, Nov. 3) ought to be required reading for all women seeking social equality, and particularly for older women. In recent years, far too little has been said by feminists, or even by older women who are social activists, about this basic injustice.

title: Output in Belgium
description: Belgium's industrial production dropped 27.4 percent in July from June, mainly as a result of the summer holiday season, but it rose 5.4 percent from July 1982, the Statistics Office said today.

title: DEBT LIMIT DRAMA: A CONSERVATIVE MAKES A DEAL
description: After he said grace over breakfast this morning in the Senate dining room, Senator William L. Armstrong did not have another peaceful moment.

title: RUSSIANS' 1983 CROP
description: A Soviet official indicated today that his nation's grain harvest this year would be 200 million metric tons or more. This confirms American estimates of the 1983 Soviet crop.

title: Dow Climbs 3.35, to 1,251.32
description: Stock prices rose modestly yesterday, with several of the technology issues scoring impressive gains.

title: MICROS SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: GINNY FOAT, THE EX-NOW LEADER, ACQUITTED OF MURDER IN LOUISIANA
description: A jury of six men and six women found Ginny Foat not guilty of murder today, and tears, laughter, hugs and general chaos took over the courtroom.

title: Julia Child Series on Dinners
description: LET it be clear at the outset that I adore Julia Child. In a class with Lucille Ball, the Muppets and Walter Cronkite, she has one of those personalities that seem tailor-made for television. She doesn't just appear on the screen; she comes floating into your home as a welcome presence. She is not just a food authority; she is a natural entertainer.

title: ORIOLES' RIPKIN VOTED M.V.P.
description: In the perfect ending to a perfect baseball season, Cal Ripken Jr. of the Baltimore Orioles yesterday won the American League's award as the most valuable player. He thus became the first player to win the award the season after capturing rookie-of-the-year honors.

title: MONDALE RETURNS FIRE ON ARMS ISSUE
description: In one of his sharpest verbal assaults yet on his rival for the Democratic Presidential nomination, Walter F. Mondale today accused Senator John Glenn of seeking a ''blank check'' for military spending.

title: Youth, 15, Held In Student's Death
description: A man arrested Tuesday night as the third suspect in the murder of Kathleen Habeeb, a St. John's University student, was released yesterday, and a 15-year-old youth was then arrested and charged with the crime.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE ;  CPC International Sets Division Realignment
description: CPC International is not a very descriptive name. Nor is it a household word, but many of its products are - Skippy peanut butter, Hellman's mayonnaise and Thomas' English muffins.

title: CONCERT: WARSAW ORCHESTRA
description: THE programs that foreign orchestras bring to New York on tour tend to fall into a few definite, predictable patterns. One common plan offers a generally short and undemanding piece by a composer of the country in question, a big work from the standard orchestral repertory and an internationally known soloist in a concerto of his or her choice. The concert given by the Warsaw Philharmonic at Carnegie Hall last night followed that scheme, deviating from the norm only in that for its the big orchestral piece the orchestra opted for one of Shostakovich's less popular but more interesting symphonies, the often harrowing No. 10 in E minor.

title: India Dusts Off Past For the Queen's Visit
description: On their state visit to India, Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip will live in British Raj splendor complete with period furniture and bedsheets. But there will be no heavily spiced feasts.

title: Topics Changes of Pace
description: The Day of Two Noons

title: American Solar
description: The American Solar King Corporation said its fiscal 1983 results will be lower than an earlier forecast of 49 cents a share and revenues of $19 million. The company also said it will delay filing its annual report with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The company, which makes solar thermal collectors, did not disclose its latest estimate, but said it was the second reduction since its fiscal year ended on July 31.

title: U.S. ORDERS HALT IN FARM LOAN FORECLOSURES
description: Orders have been sent to state offices of the Farmers Home Administration to comply with a court order that effectively halts the agency's farm foreclosures the rest of the year, the Agriculture Department said today.

title: RANGERS DEFEAT CAPITALS
description: One quarter of their 1983-84 season is over, and after those 20 games, the Rangers stand in first place in the Patrick Division.

title: BLESSINGS CORP reports earnings for 12 wks to Oct 8
Weights and Women
description: American women who think that lifting weights might make them look like muscle-bound men have another think coming, according to a fitness expert. In a report to a White House symposium on physical fitness and sports medicine, Dr. Richard O. Keelor said that American women are so undermuscled that they can achieve highly beneficial gains through weight-training without developing bulky muscles.

title: NEW WARNER HIT: ITS STUDIOS
description: Warner Communications Inc. lost enough money in its Atari computer and video game business in the third quarter - $180.3 million - to bankroll a year's worth of motion pictures at its Warner Brothers studios.

title: Baseball; M.V.P. Voting
description: AMERICAN LEAGUE

title: ADVERTISING ; Carnation's Dog Food Alters Disputed Claim
description: When you make taste preference claims on behalf of consumers who cannot articulate their own, you are skating on thin ice. And last month, the Carnation Company, maker of New Breed Dog Food, found that out.

title: SENATE'S ROLL-CALL ON TUITION CREDIT
description: Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate today killed a bill to provide tuition tax credits to parents who send their children to private schools. A vote 'for' is to kill the measure; a vote 'against' to save it.

title: LOS ANGELES COUNCIL PASSES TAX ON NEWS ORGANIZATIONS
description: Despite protests from local newspapers and broadcasting companies, the Los Angeles City Council today voted, 11 to 3, in favor of a business license tax on news organizations.

title: BARUCH-FOSTER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FLOWERS EVERYWHERE
description: Loup Daraux - president and designer, respectively, of Un Jardin . . . en Plus - live in Cannes on the French Riviera and are, one might say, obsessed with flowers. Forty shops around the world sell their flower-bedecked wares, and they have just opened their first American store - a multicolor bazaar that will appeal to those who like to surround themselves with flowers.

title: U.N. CALLS FOR FALKLAND TALKS
description: The General Assembly adopted a resolution today calling on Argentina and Britain to resume negotiations and ''find as soon as possible a peaceful solution to the sovereignty dispute'' over the Falkland Islands.

title: DESIGNATRONICS INC reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
COMMODITIES Metals and Grains Fall Over Dollar Worries
description: A sharp rise in the dollar's value and forecasts of higher interest rates sent precious metals futures tumbling yesterday. The forecasts of a rise in United States interest rates next year, which could further strengthen the dollar, were particularly disturbing to European traders and investors, brokers said.

title: Citicorp Optimism
description: Citicorp's chairman, Walter B. Wriston, said he expects record profits for 1983, but he offered no specific dollar figure. He made his comments to reporters after a speech to an insurance industry group. Citicorp's net income for 1982 was $723 million, or $5.78 a share. Mr. Wriston said that while Citicorp's writeoffs on bad loans for 1983 would be higher than in 1982, the writeoffs were ''right on target for what the bank holding company had budgeted at the beginning of the year.''

title: MACY, R H, & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: Sales figures represent net retail sales.

title: FILM ON A NUCLEAR WAR ALREADY CAUSING WIDE FALLOUT OF PARTISAN ACTIVITY
description: ''The Day After,'' the ABC-TV film about a nuclear war and its aftermath, has emerged as a significant political rallying point for partisans in the nuclear arms debate.

title: ERNST, E C, INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including an extraordinary tax credit of $53,000. Revenue figures represent contract income.

title: SmithKline
description: The SmithKline Beckman Corporation said it could have flat earnings in the fourth quarter, but it does not expect them to fall below those of the year earlier.

title: GOLDFIELD CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income including a tax credit of $449,750. c-Including a tax credit of $624,560.

title: DELTA DRILLING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

PLANT USE UP BY HALF POINT
description: The nation's factories, mines and utilities operated at 78.6 percent of capacity in October, up half a percentage point from September, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Perma, Frates In Kaiser Pact
description: The Perma Resources Corporation and an investment group led by J. A. Frates 3d of Tulsa have worked out a final agreement on joint ownership of the Kaiser Steel Corporation, they said today. The agreement would become effective only if the acquisition of Kaiser by the Frates group is approved by Kaiser shareholders at a Dec. 14 meeting.

title: AMERFORD INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
The Law, the Poor and the Torpedoes
description: President Reagan is so hostile to the Federal program of legal services for the poor that only the crudeness of his tactics has saved it.

title: CONTINENTAL STEEL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $7,183,000 and a gain of $2,452,000 from the favorable settlement of certain liabilities incurred during the company's reorganization proceedings.

title: FAY'S DRUG CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split distributed Sept. 2, 1983.

title: Bicknell Staying
description: Boston College's football team has come a long way since 1978, when the Eagles had an 0-11 record, and much of the credit has gone to Jack Bicknell , who took over as coach in 1981. After a 5-6 record his first year, the team made it to the Tangerine Bowl with an 8-2-1 record last year and, with a 7-2 mark this season, is expected to receive an invitation to the Liberty Bowl.

title: PEOPLES DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 24
description: Share earnings reflect a 5-for-4 stock split in October 1982 and a 3-for- 2 split in July 1983.

title: GINNY FOAT SAYS THE JURORS HAD TO KNOW HER PAST TO JUDGE HER
description: Her murder trial over, Ginny Foat began early today ''to pick up the pieces of my life,'' as she said last night she planned to do now that she has been acquitted.

title: Star Suspended
description: Othell Wilson , the senior guard who averaged 13.6 points a game and totaled 152 assists for the University of Virginia last season, has been suspended for the team's first four games by Coach Terry Holland . ''We had guidelines about certain on-court behavior and until he is able to respond favorably,'' said Holland, ''he will not be seeing action in games for our basketball team.''

title: Quake Jolts Wilmington
description: A minor earthquake shook Wilmington and parts of Pennsylvania this afternoon, but apparently causing no damage or injuries, officials said. Newspapers and radio stations in the area were flooded with telephone calls soon after what sounded like a loud explosion at 2:55 P.M. Kenneth D. Woodruff, associate director of the Delaware Geological Survey at the University of Delaware in Newark, said the earthquake had registered about 2.5 on the Richter scale.

title: Southern Union To Sell Utility
description: The Southern Union Company said it plans to sell its New Mexico utility operations for their book value, estimated at $225 million, at the end of last year to the Robert O. Anderson School of Management Foundation at the University of New Mexico.

title: Holiday Fairs This Weekend
description: St. Joseph's Church in Greenwich Village, 371 Avenue of the Americas, at Washington Place. Sunday, 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. Handmade goods, clothing, books, records, games, raffle. Admission, 50 cents (25 cents for children). St. Luke's School, Grove and Hudson Streets. Today, 5 to 10 P.M. and tomorrow, noon to 6 P.M. Boutique, thrift shop, auction, raffle, entertainment. Admission, $1 (children and the elderly, free).

title: HINDU RALLY RIVALS TURNOUT FOR QUEEN ON ARRIVAL IN INDIA
description: Queen Elizabeth II arrived here today for a 10-day state visit and was welcomed by small groups along the road from the airport and people standing two and three deep along New Delhi streets. Much larger crowds, meanwhile, joined in a vast Hindu revival rally near the Presidential residence where she is to stay.

title: MANAGEMENT ASSISTANCE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including tax credits of $254,000 for the quarter and $1,004,000 for the year. c-Net income. d-Including income from discontinued operations of $381,000 for the quarter and year and a tax credit of $877,000 for the quarter and year.

title: JAMAICA WATER PROPERTIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BACHE AGAIN CENSURED FOR BROKER MISDEEDS
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today censured Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. for violating the agency's margin rules and failing to properly supervise a stockbroker who, the agency charged, was involved in multimillion-dollar stock frauds.

title: 2 NIGHTS WITH JOAN BAEZ AND A FLOOD OF MEMORIES
description: WHILE Joan Baez hasn't been a total stranger to New York City in recent years, the folk singer's appearances tonight and tomorrow at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street, represent what Miss Baez cheerfully referred to the other day as ''your basic comeback.''

title: FIVE CENTRAL AMERICAN COUNTRIES SET NEGOTIATIONS FOR NEXT MONTH
description: The Foreign Ministers of five Central American countries and four mediating nations agreed today on a schedule and procedures for beginning negotiations aimed at limiting military buildups and clandestine arms traffic in the region.

title: MISSILES AND PACIFISTS
description: France's President, Francois Mitterrand, told his people last night that ''the East has developed missiles and the West has developed pacifists.''

title: GRENADA SNIPERS WOUND 2 G.I.'S
description: Snipers wounded two United States paratroopers today, military spokesmen said. Their wounds were said to be slight.

title: Britain May Raise Taxes
description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Nigel Lawson, in presenting the Government's expectations for the economy to the House of Commons, said today that production would grow 3 percent next year, with inflation falling to 4.5 percent by the fourth quarter.

title: GENERAL EMPLOYMENT ENTERPRISES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Coleco Denies Soaring Debt
description: Coleco Industries Inc., responding to published reports that its short- term debt had soared as the company gears up to produce its Adam computer system in volume, said it has stayed ''well within'' its credit lines. The company, based in West Hartford, Conn., also denied reports that retailers can return unsold machines for credit, even if they are not defective, and said that early indications show that customers are satisfied with the Adam system.

title: EXCERPTS FROM OPINIONS ON COPYRIGHT PROTECTION
description: Following are excerpts from the opinions by the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit yesterday in the case of Harper & Row and Reader's Digest v. The Nation magazine. Judge Irving R. Kaufman wrote the majority opinion, which was joined by Judge Lawrence W. Pierce. Judge Thomas J. Meskill issued a dissent. By Judge Kaufman

description: A large rise in the nation's crude oil stocks and continued sluggish demand for oil products caused heavy selling of energy futures contracts in unusually active trading yesterday.

description: Following are excerpts from an opinion issued here today by Judge Leonard D. Wexler in Federal District Court that denied a request by the Federal Government to examine the medical records of a severely handicapped infant, identified only as Baby Jane Doe:

description: Heart disease caused by cigarette smoking will kill 170,000 Americans this year, the Government said today in a report on smoking and health.

description: IN its short existence (1889-1903),

title: GREEK CYPRIOTS ARE WORRIED BUT EXPECT NO DRASTIC STEPS
description: Daily life has changed little for Greek Cypriots on this Mediterranean island since Tuesday's declaration of independence by the Turkish Cypriot minority.

title: NETS BEATEN 115-113
description: The mismatch was obvious: Albert King of the Nets, who is 6 feet 6 inches and 190 pounds, was struggling to guard the forward Jay Vincent, 6-7 and 235. Yet for much of the game tonight, the struggle was a standoff.

title: CONCERT: PHILHARMONIC
description: ON occasion, when the wind is from the right quarter, the New York Philharmonic can play as beautifully as any orchestra in the world. That is an unarguable fact. Last night happened to be one of those occasions. Klaus Tennstedt led an all-Strauss program that wound up with a masterly performance of ''Thus Spake Zarathustra,'' one of the most dazzling demonstrations of orchestral writing that the repertory has to offer. This was upper-crust Strauss all the way, conducted with a keen sense of where the big climaxes in the meandering work lay and played not only with sheer brilliance of technique but with the cohesiveness that this piece must have if it is not to disintegrate into hollow noise.

title: SYNCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
WAR AND PEACE MARKED IN A CEREMONY IN JERSEY
description: The past as prologue was vividly portrayed here today on the 200th anniversary of the signing of the Treaty of Paris that ended the Revolutionary War.

description: Vilas Hearing Set

description: Computers are transforming the telephone industry workplace into what some experts call the office of the future.

description: Medieval goatherd called Bodo is hero of a new musical.

title: RESIGNATION OF METHODIST BISHOP LINKED TO STRESS AND LONG HOURS
description: Stress from travel, controversy and 18- hour work days pushed Bishop James Armstrong to resign as head of the United Methodist Church in Indiana and as president of the National Council of Churches, a Methodist official said today.

title: CONNECTICUT SCHOOL PLAN ASKS TOUGHER GRADUATION STANDARDS
description: Connecticut's Education Commissioner today proposed a broad plan for improving education in the state's public schools, including a longer school year, tougher high school graduation requirements and a full-day kindergarten program.

title: Terex Announces Employee Layoffs
description: The Terex Corporation, the nation's fifth-largest construction equipment maker, announced indefinite and temporary layoffs that affect more than half its employees.

title: AUTHENTIC COUSCOUS
description: COUSCOUS, the savory Moroccan stewlike dish usually combining lamb, chicken, carrots, squash, chickpeas or other vegetables, all piled over a dune of steaming semolina, is a wonderfully soothing late autumn meal. Several city restaurants turn out the genuine thing.

title: GEORGE WASHINGTON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Operating earnings. c-Net income.

title: GLENN VS. MONDALE: IDEOLOGICAL SHOWDOWN NEARS
description: Just when the Democratic Presidential campaign seemed to be slipping into a relaxed holiday rhythm, strategists for Senator John Glenn decided that his campaign had too little momentum for him to take a vacation from the chore of trying to overtake former Vice President Walter F. Mondale.

title: Philips Net Rises 28%
description: N.V. Philips' Gloeilampenfabrieken said today that its third-quarter profits rose 28.8 percent, to 103 million guilders, or $34.2 million, from 80 million a year earlier.

title: Utility Issue
description: A $125 million issue of Pennsylvania Power and Light Company 13 1/8 percent bonds due in 2013 are offered at a price of 99.076 to yield 13.25 percent through underwriters led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. The yield of the A-2/BBBx bonds was 148 basis points greater than for 30-year Treasury bonds. They are refundable after five years.

title: BUNDY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
MORE THAN 100 STRIKERS ARE ARRESTED
description: Greyhound buses began rolling again yesterday, but they carried few passengers through cordons of strikers around the country.

title: MOLSON COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $206,000 for the quarter and a loss of $338,000 for the 6 months from discontinued operations. Year-ago results have been restated. Share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid in July. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Extendable Notes At BankAmerica
description: A $200 million issue of BankAmerica Corporation's three-year extendable notes with a final maturity in 1995 was offered at a price of 99.9 with an 11 1/2 percent coupon to yield 11.537 percent to 1986 through underwriters led by Salomon Brothers Inc.

title: Chico Freeman Quartet
description: The tenor saxophonist Chico Freeman will lead a quartet Sunday at the Manhattan Healing Arts Center (431- 1372), 386 Broadway, off Canal Street. Also in the group are Cecil McBee on bass, Harry Pickens on piano and Freddie Waits on drums. Sets begin at 7:30 and 9 P.M., and tickets for the evening are $7; $5 for students.

title: Kelcher Retiring
description: Louie Kelcher, the 30-year-old San Diego nose tackle, has told the Chargers he is filing for immediate retirement because he ''had a business opportunity come up back home'' in Texas. Kelcher was among the final cuts before the season. He was re-signed and played second string for the first time in his nine-year career.

title: THEATER: PETER BROOK'S 'TRAGEDIE DE CARMEN'
description: FOR his ''Tragedie de Carmen,'' Peter Brook has transformed the Vivian Beaumont's stage into a bullring carpeted with gravel and earth. It's an arena buffeted on every side by fate, and its round shape is echoed in every step of this production's relentless thrust.

title: Battery Park City ToGetNewChiefs
description: Governor Cuomo will soon replace both the president and chairman of the Battery Park City Authority, officials of his administration said yesterday.

title: Sun in Agreement To Add Exeter Oil
description: The Sun Company, an integrated oil company based in Radnor, Pa., said it had entered into a definitive agreement to acquire the Exeter Oil Company of Los Angeles, a small independent oil company, for about $75.6 milion. Under the agreement, Sun would pay $36 for each of Exeter's 2.1 million outstanding shares.

title: A Special Charge For Union Pacific
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said it will take a special charge of about $125 million in the fourth quarter because of the diminished value of an ethylene and propylene complex in Texas of which it is part owner.

title: Congress Bars U.S. Aid For the Guatemalans
description: Congress has barred Guatemala from receiving any American military or economic aid except for aid channeled through private voluntary organizations.

title: AUCTIONS
description: Postwar art at top prices.

title: Citicorp Unit
description: The Federal Reserve Board has approved Citicorp's request to establish a new unit in Oklahoma to handle industrial banking activities and other operations.

title: GROUP OF 10 PLANS MONETARY TALKS
description: Senior treasury officials from the world's major Western nations and Japan agreed today to open a new round of negotiations aimed at changing the international monetary system.

title: Jury Acquits Man In I.R.A. Gun Plot
description: A Federal jury yesterday found a Queens man not guilty of gun-running charges in a conspiracy to buy firearms and explosives for the Provisional Irish Republican Army.

title: QUEENS RIVALS TO PLAY FOR CITY SCHOOLS TITLE
description: Moments after John Adams defeated DeWitt Clinton last week to earn a second consecutive appearance in the Public Schools Athletic League championship game, Chris Ritter, the split end who played a key role in Adams's 6-0 victory, said that he did not have a preference for an opponent in the title game.

title: Restaurant Reopens After Botulism Inquiry
description: The tables were filled at lunchtime today at the Skewer Inn, which has reopened a month after it was called the source of an outbreak of botulism,

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * CBS/Records Group has appointed Richard C. Wolter president of the Columbia House division.

title: 2 Czechs Flee to the West
description: Two Czechoslovak woodsmen fled safely through the fortified Czechoslovak border defenses into West Germany today and appealed for asylum, the Bavarian police said. A spokesman here said the two men hiked miles through thick forest during the night. They were quoted as saying they were unhappy with political conditions in Czechoslovakia.

title: THE NATION RULING: NEWS AND THE PUBLIC DOMAIN
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit, in its ruling yesterday in case of The Nation, took apart a 2,250-word article bit by bit.

title: WALKER, HIRAM, RESOURCES reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss after a writedown of U.S. oil and gas properties of $176,985,000.

title: SEAPORT REVISITED: WHAT'S NEW FOR WINTER
description: T is nearly four months since the South Street Seaport celebrated its renaissance with an opening as lavish as the debut of a world's fair. Many thousands have visited the Seaport every sunny day since, But will the throngs love the flavor that evokes the busy mercantile quarter of more than a century ago in November and December as they did in July and August? There are 5,000 or 6,000 who come to the Seaport each week to cast an affirmative vote. As the days grow shorter and colder, the Seaport has completed almost everything that it had planned in those early hectic days. The escalator to the second floor of the Fulton Market building is now running. And the second floor, which was then not ready, is now humming with dozens of food vendors. The lovely restaurant on the third floor is open. Stores that opened with empty shelves are now fully stocked. The multi-everything movie that was still being assembled is now overwhelming audiences with a high- decibel panoramic production.

title: QUAREX INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: 'NATE AND HAYES,' PIRATES IN SOUTH PACIFIC
description: ''NATE AND HAYES,'' which opens today at Loews State and other theaters, tries unsuccessfully to be that buoyant, rollicking pirate movie we all remember having seen in our youth and which they don't make anymore.

title: 3 FROM ROYALS GET 3-MONTH TERMS IN DRUG CASE
description: A Federal magistrate, noting a professional athlete's ''special place in our society,'' today sentenced the star center fielder Willie Wilson and two other members of last season's Kansas City Royals to three months in prison for trying to buy cocaine.

title: Admiring Support
description: In an effort to focus attention on the problem of drug and alcohol abuse among high school students, school authorities in Stafford County, Va., arranged for a special showing a couple of weeks ago of a drug-education television program featuring Nancy Reagan . At a panel discussion after the taped telecast for 250 parents and students, Dale Porter , the coach of Stafford High School's junior varsity basketball team, estimated that 70 percent of his players were regular drinkers at weekend parties.

description: Excerpts from opinions, page B4.

But other House-Senate conferees working on an intelligence authorization bill were unable to overcome an impasse on restrictions on covert operations in Nicaragua.

title: ATV SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
IN PAKISTAN SKIDES INTO CIVIL WAR
description: In the United States, little notice is being paid to the remarkable 13- week-long civil disobedience movement in Pakistan - for 31 years an American ally - by millions who demand democracy.

title: LEWIS JORDAN, RETIRED NEWS EDITOR OF THE NEW YORK TIMES, IS DEAD
description: Lewis Jordan, retired news editor of The New York Times and author of the writing and editing manual used by its staff, died of emphysema yesterday in Sharon (Conn.) Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Kent.

title: SCREEN: 'IN FOR TREATMENT' OF CANCER
description: FILMS about the terminally ill are not casually recommended. The problem is not only that one knows how they must turn out. There's also the awareness that before it reaches its inevitable conclusion, it has to make certain obligatory points about faith, courage and what might be called enlightened resignation. The possibilities for surprise are limited.

title: MEADOWLANDS CUP TO SLEWPY
description: The scene is familiar, and it keeps reappearing: Slewpy, with Angel Cordero Jr. saving ground on the rail, sneaks up on the inside and wins a rich race at The Meadowlands. It worked a year ago in the Young America, three weeks ago in the Paterson Handicap, and again tonight in the $400,000 Meadowlands Cup.

British Silver Show
description: More than 75 silver objects from the 13th to the 19th centuries, all part of a British collection, are on view through January at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum, Fifth Avenue and 91st Street.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: CLASS. A Guide Through the American Status System. By Paul Fussell. With Illustrations by Martim de Avillez. 202 pages. Summit. $13.95.

title: GENERAL AUTOMATION INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Including an extraordinary credit of $130,000. c-Net loss including an extraordinary credit of $150,000.

title: Hunters Tell of Survival In Slain Horses' Bodies
description: Two deer hunters stranded on a windy mountain survived by killing their horses and crawling into the carcasses to keep warm.

title: House Panel Defeats Natural Gas Rollback
description: Republicans on the House Energy and Commerce Committee joined today with Democrats from states that produce natural gas to defeat a bill that would have rolled back natural gas prices by 5 percent to 10 percent. The vote ended the prospects for any such legislation this year.

title: TU INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago figures because the company went public early in 1983.

title: Crew Search in Gulf Ends
description: The Coast Guard has suspended its search for survivors from an oil company workboat, the Laverne Hebert, that sank in the Gulf of Mexico in a storm Nov. 9. Five crewmen from the boat, owned by Gulf International of Houma, La., are missing.

title: INTERSTATE UNIFORM SERVICE CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 27
SENATE VOTES I.M.F. INCREASE
description: After months of parliamentary impasse, the Senate approved today a compromise bill that would authorize the United States to commit an additional $8.4 billion to the International Monetary Fund. The Senate, on a 67-to-30 vote, sent the legislation back to the House, which had approved, with great reluctance, a different I.M.F. bill earlier this year.

title: Advertising; Magazine On Sports For Hotels
description: IT takes a certain kind of person to come to this country as a relatively inexperienced stranger with plans to start a magazine to be run from overseas, and start right off with over 1 million circulation, thanks to the cooperation of major hotel chains and airlines.

title: THE SOUND OF A GUN
description: Prime Minister John Compton likes to quote, these days, a Caribbean song that includes the lines: ''I hope the day will never come / when we awake to the sound of a gun.''

title: FRENCH JETS RAID BASES OF MILITIA LINKED TO ATTACKS
description: P.L.O. rebels tightened their grip on a camp near Tripoli that was Yasir Arafat's stronghold. Page A7.

description: Year-ago share earnings adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend Sept. 6 and a 2-for-1 stock split in the form of a 100 percent stock dividend in January 1983.

GREEK AND CYPRIOTS EXCHANGE BARBS AT U.N. COUNCIL
description: Representatives of the two ethnic populations on Cyprus exchanged claims and charges here today as debate on the proclamation of an independent Turkish Cypriot republic got under way at the Security Council.

title: U.S. IS NOW FACING LEBANON DECISION
description: Now that Israel and France have attacked the pro-Iranian group that is believed responsible for the terrorist attacks on their troops and the American marines in Lebanon, the time has come for the Reagan Administration to decide whether it will do the same, high-ranking officials said today.

title: China-Japan Oil Pact
description: China and Japan have agreed that China will ship between 8 million and 8.6 million tons of crude oil to Japan in 1984, unchanged from planned sales this year, the Japan-China Association on Economy and Trade said today.

description: b-After a charge of $998,000 from an accounting change.

title: Sale by Unocal
description: The Korea Explosives Business Group has agreed in principle to take over the equity currently held by the Unocal Corporation in the Energy Company, their 50-50 joint venture oil refinery, officials of the companies said. They said Korea Explosives agreed to pay $52.2 million to Unocal by year-end. Unocal, a holding company for the Union Oil Company of California, initially invested about $10.3 million in the refinery, which began operations in 1969.

title: ANDROPOV SENDS MESSAGE TO EDITOR OF IOWA PAPER
description: Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, sent a message to the editor of The Des Moines Register today saying that the Soviet Union was seeking ''mutually beneficial cooperation'' with the United States, especially in agriculture.

description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz will appear on ABC-TV to present the Reagan Administration's side of the nuclear arms debate immediately after the showing of a television movie on the network depicting nuclear war.

description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined in the week ended Wednesday, the first drop in seven weeks, the Investment Company Institute reported yesterday.

description: b-Net income.

title: STEELWORKERS' SECRETARY IN CHARGE UNTIL UNION ELECTION ON MARCH 29 Lynn R. Williams was named temporary president of the United Steelworkers of America yesterday, replacing Lloyd McBride, who died last week.
description: The union's executive board, meeting in Pittsburgh, selected Mr. Williams, a Canadian who is the union's secretary, as temporary president by a vote of 16 to 12. It set March 29 for a rank-and-file election to choose a permanent president.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: School Songs

title: The Worm & the Apple Bad Manners and Good Judgment

title: ART: 'FLOWERS OF THREE CENTURIES' AT THE MORGAN
description: THE naturalist and gentleman had his heyday as a species in the 18th and 19th centuries, but he has by no means died out. On the contrary, he and his female counterpart continue to flourish - perhaps more aristocratically than before - producing such stars as John Dupont, the ornithologist, and Miriam Rothschild, the parasitologist. Being at the top of the human pile may spark a special interest in the class systems of other organisms.

title: WITH TRAFFIC WOES IN 42d St.'s FUTURE PLANNERS LOOK BACK TO THE TROLLEY ERA
description: A desire named Streetcar is stirring on 42d Street these days, as city officials and the 42d Street Development Corporation look into the feasibility of restoring trolley service to the renascent street.

title: The W.B.C. System
description: Jose Sulaiman, the World Boxing Council's president, said yesterday that while the W.B.C.'s heavyweight title would be declared vacant if Marvis Frazier upsets Larry Holmes next Friday, Frazier would be invited to fight directly for the championship or to participate in a tournament to decide a successor. According to W.B.C. rules, when any champion fighting within the weight limit loses a nontitle fight, the title is declared vacant. The sanctioning body will not recognize the Holmes-Frazier bout, to be held in Las Vegas, Nev., because Frazier is not among its top 10 contenders.

title: Sudan Says It Has Freed 2 Kidnapped by Rebels
description: Sudanese Army troops stormed a rebel hideout near the southern town of Bentiu today, freeing two of 11 kidnapped foreign workers and inflicting heavy casualties on the rebels, an army statement said.

title: Lakers 127 Cavaliers 114
description: Earvin (Magic) Johnson collected a career-high 22 assists and scored 23 points to lead Los Angeles to its sixth straight victory.

title: Economic Scene; The Debate On Deficits
description: CONGRESS, rushing to wrap up its business in time for adjournment by the end of this week, is ready to raise the ceiling on the national debt.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Celtics, at Boston. The Knicks' tough loss at Philadelphia on Wednesday night is followed by a game against another Atlantic Division power.

description: b-Net loss.

title: CONTINENTAL: A LAST DANCE?
description: The workout in the gymnasium at the New York Institute of Technology was more than two hours old when Herb Brown called for a fullcourt drill that required each group of four players to make four layups.

description: To the Editor:

title: ART: JON BOROFSKY SHOW
description: THE work of Jon Borofsky has always kept clear of the traditional postures of exhibited art. To hang flat on the wall in a frame does not suit it. When it comes in three dimensions, it rejects the very notion of a plinth. Nor does it chime with the ancient idea that works of art need space and solitude to be seen at their best.

title: TURKISH CYPRIOTS SAY MOVE HAS GIVEN THEM NEW HOPE
description: The newly declared Turkish Republic of Northern Cyprus does not have a flag, a national anthem or even its own currency. But officials and residents of the new nation said today that their declaration of independence had given them hope.

title: SCOUTING

title: BRIEFING
description: 'Government by Poll'

title: GREYHOUND USES HALF FARES TO LURE RIDERS PAST PICKETS
description: Y. H. Chen, a tourist from Taiwan, was heading for the Greyhound ticket counter in the Port Authority Bus Terminal at Eighth Avenue and 41st Street when he found himself surrounded by striking employees of the bus company.

title: Jazz; Bill at St. James
description: The pianist Billy Taylor with the singer Joe Lee Wilson, and the singer Ebony Jo-Ann with the saxophonist Bilal Sunni-Ali will share a double bill Sunday at St. James Presbyterian Church (283-4541), 409 West 141st Street at St. Nicholas Avenue. The concert begins at 3 P.M. and tickets are $10.

title: NATIONAL-STANDARD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

description: Senator Gary Hart of Colorado entered the political debate over national military policy today, asserting that former Vice President Walter F. Mondale and Senator John Glenn of Ohio were engaging in an ''irrevelant'' argument over the past. All three are contenders for the Democratic Presidential nomination.

title: GREAT OUTDOOR AMERICAN ADVENTURE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
FILM: 'YENTL,' A DRAMA WITH DRAMA STREISAND
description: THE facts that Barbra Streisand has produced, directed and is co-author of ''Yentl,'' and that she stars in it wearing a pillbox-contoured designer yarmulke, do not adequately convey the sincerity of the effort. The best thing about ''Yentl,'' which opens today at the Ziegfeld and other theaters, is its earnestness. It may resemble a vanity production from afar (or at close range, too, for that matter), but even at its kitschiest it seems to be heartfelt. That goes a long way, though not far enough, toward saving the film from its own built-in difficulties.

title: COSTA RICA PROCLAIMS NEUTRALITY
description: President Luis Alberto Monge proclaimed a policy of ''permanent'' and ''unarmed'' neutrality today, but said Costa Rica would continue its traditional role in regional politics and promotion of democracy.

description: IC Industries Inc. said yesterday that it plans to increase its holdings in the Trane Company to just under 50 percent of its stock. IC also said it is attempting to persuade Trane, an air- conditioner manufacturer, to agree to a merger.

description: Rita Lavelle used the $1.6 billion toxic waste cleanup program ''to help Republican candidates be elected,'' a prosecution lawyer charged today on the opening day of the trial of the discharged official of the Environmental Protection Agency.

description: FOLLOWING the death last summer of Carl Rosen, the chairman of the Puritan Fashions Corporation, Puritan's stock on the New York Stock Exchange rose to a high of 26 7/8 on rumors of a takeover. Last Friday it reached a low of 12 1/4, after the company reported a 60 percent drop in third-quarter earnings.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: ''YENTL,'' the Barbra Streisand movie opening today at the Ziegfeld, is based on a short story by the 79-year- old Nobel Prize winner Isaac Bashevis Singer. Miss Streisand directed the picture, produced the picture, wrote the picture (along with Jack Rosenthal), starred in the picture and sang all the songs in the picture. Which left Mr. Singer a trifle nonplused. Some weeks ago, in an interview in Women's Wear Daily, he explained that he had met Miss Streisand. ''And I told her the human being doesn't have all the qualifications. She cannot be the actress, the producer . . . but she chose this way. So if she succeeds, I will consider it a miracle.''

title: IN SURPRISE, JETS DROP CRUTCHFIELD
description: Dwayne Crutchfield, the Jets' leading rusher this season, was released yesterday just minutes after practicing in his usual spot as No. 1 fullback.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article yesterday about the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company misstated the 1982 salary of its chairman, Charles L. Brown. It was $661,667.

description: Congressional conferees today rejected the Reagan Administration's plan to resume production of nerve gas and other chemical weapons but cleared the way to begin testing an antisatellite weapon.

description: Dr. Albert H. Aldridge, chief surgeon of gynecology and obstetrics at the Woman's Division of St. Luke's Hospital from 1938 to 1958, died Sunday at Moore Memorial Hospital in Pinehurst, N.C. He was 90 years old and had lived in Pinehurst since retiring in 1975.

title: FUTURE OF GENEVA ARMS TALKS IN DOUBT
description: American and Soviet negotiators met today at the 104th session of their talks on intermediate-range nuclear weapons. They agreed to hold another round of discussions next Wednesday.

description: The government of the District of Columbia may not legally exist, and all city laws may be null and void.

description: There are increasing signs that political victory resulting from the Grenada invasion is encouraging the Reagan Administration to take military action in Central America. This would be a grave mistake.

description: President and Nancy Reagan will travel to their ranch near Santa Barbara, Calif., for the Thanksgiving holiday, the White House announced today. The Reagans are expected to leave on Wednesday and return Sunday.

description: THE theme was variations at the New York City Ballet's performance on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater. The program's two most elaborate offerings were sets of variations of one kind or another.

Datapoint, a data-processing systems company based in San Antonio, said revenues rose 5.8 percent, to $139.7 million, from $132 million.

description: A special commission recommended today that a surcharge be placed on electric power rates in the Northwest as part of a comprehensive solution to the Washington Public Power Supply System's financial problems.

Stern, the agency's chairman and president, said yesterday.

title: ROBERT ASHLEY'S VIDEO OPERA IN DEBUT AT KITCHEN

The work is ''Perfect Lives,'' a three-hour opera for television; the artist is Robert Ashley, and the place where it will be screened is the Kitchen, the SoHo performance and video space at 59 Wooster Street (tickets are $5 and the number is 925-3615).

title: SITTING IN JUDGMENT
description: Two weeks ago, before the first Federal District Court hearing in the Baby Jane Doe case got underway, Judge Leonard D. Wexler said he wanted the lawyers to know that President Reagan recently appointed him to the bench. He asked if that made a difference, and the lawyers said it did not. The 59-year-old judge's decision to mention the President, particularly since the case was brought by the Administration, surprised none of his friends.

description: A Superior Court jury has awarded nearly $16 million in damages to 97 Jackson Township families who said chemicals from the municipal landfill had tainted their well water.

FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1983 International
description: French planes attacked installations in central Lebanon belonging to pro- Iranian Shiite militiamen suspected of involvement in recent truck-bomb attacks against French, American and Israeli forces in Lebanon. Lebanese officials said there had been extensive damage. Casualties appeared to be heavy. (Page A1, Column 6.) Washington should now decide whether American jets should also attack the pro-Iranian group believed to be responsible for the terrorist attacks on American, French and Israeli forces, according to high-ranking Reagan Administration officials. A senior State Department official said that if all the suitable targets in the area where the pro-Iranian Shiites are based had been destroyed, there might not be any point in ordering an air attack now. (A1:5.)

title: Rolm Switchboard

Rolm, one of the leaders in the PBX business, had been challenged recently by some startup companies that claimed their systems were better at handling data communications. The company, based in Santa Clara, Calif., said users of the existing PBX can upgrade to the new model, which is to be available in a year.

description: Devil's Bag, the undefeated 2-year- old, towered over all of his contemporaries - until last Saturday. In the Remsen Stakes at Aqueduct, a race Devil's Bag was forced to miss because of a bruised heel, Dr. Carter ran so impressively that Devil's Bag at least would have had to run hard for the first time in his career.

title: THE JAZZTET COMES IN , BUT LEAVES NOSTALGIA OUT
description: WHEN a jazz group that was once a great success gets together again after a long separation, the expectation is that there will be a good deal of nostalgia involved, a revival of tunes and arrangements associated with the group. But when the Jazztet - a sextet organized in 1959 by Art Farmer, then a trumpeter and now a flugelhornist, and Benny Golson, the saxophonist - came together in 1982 after a lapse of two decades, the musicians made a point of not getting out their old arrangements.

SCREEN: RUSSIA'S 'VASSA'
description: ''VASSA'' is Gleb Panfilov's glum adaptation of a play by Maxim Gorky, ''Vassa Zheleznova,'' detailing the tragedy of a powerful heiress in the precarious Russia of 1913. The title character, a woman of great wealth who has a ruthlessness to match, engineers the downfall of her husband once his philandering threatens the family's reputation. Not even her husband's suicide appears to shake the resolve of Vassa, who is so oppressive a presence in her own household that her absence provokes a virtual orgy of celebration on the part of other members of her family.

title: Harvester to Shut Louisville Plant CHICAGO, Nov. 18 (AP) - Citing an industry-wide surplus of iron castings, the International Harvester Company said it would phase out operations at its Louisville, Ky., foundry within a year, affecting 710 employees. The company said the decision did not affect its forge operations or its 130 employees at an adjacent plant in Louisville.
description: John Horne, vice president and general manager of the company's engine and foundry operations, said the decision was irrevocable.

title: JERSEY ARBITRATION LAW: WHY UNIONS TEND TO WIN
description: New Jersey's arbitration law is being blamed by some municipal leaders for unaffordable increases in wages for police officers and firefighters. And this week, Governor Kean said that he would ask the Legislature for $5 million to assist the state's six largest cities in meeting budget problems.Labor experts say the law, known as the ''last best offer'' law, usually does what it was intended to do - encourage unions and management to submit realistic figures and shorten bargaining time. It does this by prohibiting compromise. If union and municipality cannot reach agreement, the arbitrator must pick the offer he deems best.

Ford. But many book industry officials oppose the court ruling and hope that Harper's will appeal.

title: TV: 'KENNEDY, 'FIRST OF A 3-PART SERIES ON NBC
description: ''Kennedy'' is an imitation of history. It is not really a re-rendering, and there is not much monkeying around with what we know really happened. When the three-part, seven-hour re- enactment takes a point of view, it's personal, not political, and this doesn't so much deepen our insights as it does reawaken our memories. We supply the interpretation ourselves because ''Kennedy'' is something like a montage of old newspaper headlines: great events stand out, but the details are buried somewhere beneath. The first episode, three hours long, will be shown on NBC-TV tomorrow night at 8 o'clock, with two- hour programs at 9 Monday and Tuesday nights.

title: Florida Property Seized By U.S. as Drug Related
description: Two houses and seven acres of beachfront property in this resort town have been seized in one of the largest drug- related takeovers of real estate by the Government, the United States Attorney's office in Miami said today.

title: WHEN TOYS ARE COLLECTORS' ITEMS
description: The original Bartholomew Fair was chartered by Henry I in 1133 as a church-related festival. It ran in London until the mid-19th century, though by then it was a raucous gathering place complete with fortune tellers, jugglers and Punch- and-Judy shows. Now Bartholomew Fair is the name of a genteel shop on 57th Street that sells antique toys, games, puppets and books for children.

Malone of Youngstown, Ohio, the newly elected president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops, finished introducing a visiting priest this week by alerting the bishops that their guest's speech ''is perfumed by the heather of Scotland.'' title: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1983 International
description: Moscow indicated that it would cut by half the number of its SS-20 missiles if the NATO alliance agreed to drop plans to deploy the 572 new American missiles in Europe. According to an announcement by the State Department, Yuli A. Kvitsinsky, the chief Soviet arms negotiator in Geneva, told Paul H. Nitze, his American counterpart, that Moscow would accept a proposal if offered by Washington. The Reagan Administration turned down the offer. (Page 1, Column 6.) The Soviet Defense Minister accused the United States of having deliberately doomed disarmament negotiations. The Minister, Dmitri F. Ustinov, also reaffirmed standing Soviet demands on the issues, lessening hope for a last-minute shift in Moscow's position. In his criticisms, which were published by Pravda, Marshal Ustinov stressedSoviet pledges to match any American buildup. (6:4.)
