description: Western and some third-world diplomats here predict that Iraq will eventually use its new French-built warplanes in the war against Iran, but will probably not use them against the huge Iranian oil terminal at Kharg Island.

title: DONOVAN TESTIFIES HE KNEW NOTHING OF 'NO SHOW' JOBS
description: Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan, testifying at a Brooklyn perjury trial, reasserted yesterday that he had known nothing about ''no show'' jobs on a Queens subway project while he was a top executive of a construction company involved in it.

title: New Stadium Planned
description: The owner of the Miami Dolphins, Joe Robbie, confirmed that he planned to build a 70,000-seat football stadium and sports complex in the Dade County area, and that the project would be formally announced in two weeks. Robbie has had a running dispute with the city of Miami over the Dolphins' Orange Bowl lease, which expires after the 1986 season.

title: OF DECALS AND PRIORITIES FOR THE SOUTH BRONX
description: T o the Editor:

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 43.

title: STERLING SOFTWARE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The results for 1983 and 1982 were restated for the pooling accounting of acquisition of Pacesetter Systems last September.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Oldest Transit Car Runs Again on 3d Ave.

title: LATCHKEY CHILDREN NEED FEDERAL FRIENDS
description: To the Editor:

title: APARTHEID: NEW FOCUS
description: About 120 American corporations with operations in South Africa have agreed to change the focus of their anti-apartheid activities to emphasize projects such as education, health and housing.

title: 30 Groups Ask Marcos To Resolve Succession
description: Thirty business, professional and labor organizations appealed today to President Ferdinand E. Marcos to help head off national financial disaster by resolving questions of succession should he die or become incapacitated.

title: Carew Likely to Stay
description: Rod Carew, contrary to earlier beliefs, apparently will remain with the California Angels. ''We're well on our way to an agreement, and I think we will have an agreement,'' Jerry Simon, Carew's lawyer, said yesterday.

title: HELPING SPECIAL CHILDREN
description: OFTEN the parents of handicapped, disabled or gifted children are bewildered when they seek out those programs intended to aid or treat their children. In an effort to put together as much of this information as possible and to make it easily available, the Children's Services Department of the Brooklyn Public Library has created a Special Needs Reference Kit and has placed copies in the library's 58 branches as well as in its central library on Grand Army Plaza.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: CONGRESS ACTS WITH AN EYE ON THE DOOR
description: The voting board in the House of Representatives lit up like a prop for the big number in a Busby Berkeley musical, and the nearly empty chamber began to fill with the actors entering from stage left, right and center to vote.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 19.

title: Ex-Goalie Loses Suit
description: Dunc Wilson, the former hockey goalie, has lost his $400,000 lawsuit against the Vancouver Canucks. Justice George Murray of British Columbia Supreme Court ruled that Wilson's nine-year National Hockey League career would have ended in 1979 even if he had not developed skin cancer. Wilson, who earlier had played two seasons for the Rangers, contended that the club was negligent because team doctors had failed to diagnose the skin cancer early enough.

title: U.S. SAYS MOSCOW OFFERS TO REDUCE MISSILES BY HALF
description: The United States said today that the Soviet Union had made a new, informal offer to cut by half the number of SS-20 missiles aimed at Western Europe if NATO dropped its plans to deploy 572 new American missiles in Europe.

title: Dissident Steelworkers To Consider Candidate
description: Dissident members of the United Steelworkers of America, unhappy with the current union administration, plan to meet this weekend to consider running a candidate in next year's special election for the union's presidency.

title: BRIEFING
description: Deft Move by a Pro

title: PIPER HYDRO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Letter: On Tax-Exempt Bonds No Strings on State Financing
description: To the Editor:

title: LEVI'S CHIEF TO STEP DOWN
description: Robert T. Grohman, the 59-year- old president and chief executive officer of Levi Strauss & Company, said yesterday that he would step down next April. Analysts said Mr. Grohman, the first head of the company not related to the founder, had long said that he planned to take early retirement.

title: NUCLEAR METALS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Menudo at City Hall: Insurance Against Damages

title: Oil Rig Is Blown Up
description: The 10,000-ton oil rig Alexander L. Kielland, which capsized on March 27, 1980, with the loss of 123 lives, was blown up and sunk today. The accommodation rig, which overturned when one of its five legs snapped in a storm halfway between here and Scotland, was sunk by explosives in a 2,300-foot deep fjord near here. The opposition Labor Party tried to prevent the sinking for environmental reasons, but Parliament voted 68 to 60 Thursday night to go ahead with the plan.

title: BLANCHE STERN PRINCE
description: Blanche Stern Prince, mother of Harold Prince, the Broadway director and producer, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Manhattan.

title: POLAND WARNS CATHOLIC LEADERSHIP TO SILENCE 69 DISSIDENT PRIESTS
description: The authorities have ordered the Roman Catholic Primate, Jozef Cardinal Glemp, to silence some 69 ''antisocialist'' priests, warning that otherwise they may face arrest, church officials said today.

title: INVENTION DESIGN ENGINEERNG reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
REALTY INCOME TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CENTER IS BACKED FOR TRANSPLANTS
description: The House Commerce Committee has approved a bill that would create a national center for organ transplants and a computer system to match organ donors to patients.

title: NANKIN EXPRESS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 9
SWEDISH OUTPUT UP
description: Sweden's seasonally adjusted industrial production rose 2.4 percent in September from August and was up 5.8 percent from September 1982.

title: Bridge:How to Solve the Problems Of a Weak Trump Holding
description: In earlier days textbooks set rigid standards for ''biddable suits.'' A holding of four small cards was not considered biddable, but this often meant that the most effective trump suit was not uncovered. Four small opposite four small may be the right selection, although that is an extreme case.

title: MARINES HOLD EXCERCISE IN HONDURAS
description: An estimated 1,200 United States Marines and about 500 Honduran Army troops landed today on the northern Honduran coast in an amphibious training exercise.

title: FIRST ATLANTA TO BUY STAKE IN SOUTHEAST
description: The Southeast Banking Corporation of Miami said today that the First Atlanta Corporation would invest $40 million in Southeast. Officials said the move could foreshadow a merger of the two banks.

title: 'NIGHT IN HEAVEN'
description: ''A Night in Heaven,'' which opened yesterday at the Criterion and other theaters, has the style if not the explicit content of a pornographic film, the sort of movie in which the story is simply an excuse to examine at great length a very limited number of particular activities. Here, however, the particular activities are somewhat less instructive.

title: MCFARLAND ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
OPERA: VERDI'S 'ERNANI' IN NEW PRODUCTION BY METROPOLITAN
description: ''Ernani'' is an important opera because it is by Giuseppi Verdi. Other than that, its attractions are modest. It is, in fact, third-rate Verdi, which makes it second-rate anyone else, or better. It is a mass of musical and dramatic cliches, but operagoers with an ear tuned to history find it fascinating for what it led up to. It is an early, extremely rough steppingstone on the way to such greater matters as ''La Forza del Destino'' and ''Don Carlos.'' And, of course, Verdi enthusiasts know it has attracted a long list of famous singers, which gives the work a certain patina of importance.

title: RADICE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
EMANUEL SCHEAR
description: Emanuel Schear, a former vice president of the Wall Street brokerage firm of Laidlaw-Coggeshall, died of a heart attack Thursday.

title: KNICKS DEFEAT CELTICS
description: The Knicks took away the fast-break style Boston thrives on and beat the Celtics, 110-103, tonight at Boston Garden.

title: SCOUTING
description: Albeck Returns To San Antonio

title: THE GAME HOLDS ITS APPEAL AT 100
description: Jack Blake, who has been Yale's ticket manager for 30 years, said late today that 68,000 tickets had been sold for Saturday's 100th game with Harvard. That figure, only 2,896 below capacity in the 69-year-old Yale Bowl, underlined the appeal of The Game, an appeal that overlooked the following:

title: U.S. JOINT CHIEF OF STAFF ENDORSE SINGLE MILITARY SPACE COMMAND
description: The Joint Chiefs of Staff have recommended that the military form a unified command for its activities in space, Pentagon officials said today.

title: ORDER BY CUOMO PROTECTS RIGHTS OF HOMOSEXUALS
description: Governor Cuomo issued an executive order yesterday that is intended to protect homosexuals in New York State from discrimination in state employment and in the provision of state services.

title: FOR OSSINING, A SING SING PRISON BY ANY OTHER NAME DIDN'T SMELL AS SWEET
description: ''When you tell people you're from Ossining, they usually ask, 'Where's that?' '' said George Watson, who has lived here for more than 40 years.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Governor Still Making Way for His Team

title: BUDD CANADA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a writeoff of $3,128,000 for the quarter and year.

title: WESTERN ENERGY DEVELOPMENT reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: DAIRY BILL PUTS REAGAN IN TIGHT SPOT POLITICALLY
description: Congress is leaving President Reagan with a politically painful choice on a bill that would, for the first time, pay farmers to reduce milk production.

title: No Headline
description: Who Owns History? When Harper & Row charged The Nation with theft from its then still-unpublished book of former President Ford's memoirs, it raised questions that dwarf the financial stakes of the case. A 2-to-1 majority of the United States Court of Appeals in New York has now decided the narrow though intriguing ones. The magazine need not pay for its limited paraphrase of the book; its account of the pardoning of Richard Nixon qualifies as historical information that cannot per se be monopolized by copyright.

title: HOUSE DRUG QUERY IS ASSAILED
description: Former Representative Barry Goldwater Jr. of California said today that it was ''irresponsible'' of the House ethics committee to say there was ''substantial evidence'' that he had used drugs.

title: UNION MEMBERSHIP TO VOTE ON GREYHOUND'S NEW OFFER
description: Leaders of the striking Greyhound employees agreed yesterday to submit a new contract proposal by the company to its members for votes by Nov. 29, but the bus line reiterated its intention to continue limited operations with newly hired replacements and nonstriking workers.

title: State New Music Tour Arrives at Guggenheim
description: The New York State New Music Network tour, sponsored by the State Council on the Arts to promote the playing of new music - arrives at the Guggenheim Museum today, with performances at 3 P.M. by the Group for Contemporary Music and at 7 by the Harmonic Choir and Steve Reich and Musicians.

title: Joseph H. Weston, Publisher Of an Arkansas Newspaper
description: Joseph H. Weston, whose mimeographed newspaper, The Sharp Citizen, led to a change in Arkansas criminal libel law, died Tuesday in a Veterans Administration hospital at Poplar Bluff, Mo.

title: C.I.A. REPORT SAYS SOVIET ARMS SPENDING SLOWED
description: The Central Intelligence Agency said today that Soviet military spending, especially for procurement of new weapons systems, had grown more slowly in the last seven years than previously thought.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''When you tell people you're from Ossining, they usually ask, 'Where's that?' But the minute you say it's where Sing Sing is located, their eyes light up and their heads start shaking with acknowledgment.'' - George Watson of Ossining, N.Y. (27:1.)

title: ATLANTIC FINANCIAL FEDERAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-There are no comparable year- ago figures because the company went public Sept. 23, 1983.

title: SENECA OIL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company has changed its fiscal year-end to Dec. 31 from Sept. 30.

title: ENTER THE IRELAND ISSUE
description: As President of the United States, would you appoint a special envoy to Northern Ireland for the purpose of more directly involving the United States Government in the search for peace? That's the question some of us have been asking the Presidential candidates.

title: House Backs Israel at U.N.
description: The House of Representatives today approved the annual State Department authorization bill, which for the first time formally codifies existing Administration policy to cut off the United States financial contribution to the United Nations if Israel is expelled from the organization. The bill was approved in the House by a vote of 254 to 146. The Senate was expected to vote soon.

title: SCOUTING
description: Corporate Racers

title: AFTER 20 YEARS KENNEDY BAND TENDS LEGACY
description: The fervid band of people who served John Fitzgerald Kennedy is scattered and diverse now.

title: Co-op Developers Banned for a Year
description: One of the biggest developers of cooperative apartments in New York City and his partner have been barred for a year from submitting plans for co-op conversions, Attorney General Robert Abrams said yesterday, after what Mr. Abrams said were violations of state law in the conversion of a building in the Riverdale section of the Bronx.

title: CAMACHO WINNER ON KNOCKOUT IN 5TH
description: Hector (Macho) Camacho retained his World Boxing Council superfeatherweight title by knocking out Rafael Solis of Puerto Rico in the fifth round of a scheduled 12-rounder tonight.

title: MAYOR KOCH'S HELPERS IN PINPOINTING POTHOLES
description: To the Editor:

title: Mother Saves Sons But Dies in Fire
description: A mother guided her two sons to safety early today before she died in a fire that swept through their home in this Suffolk County community.

title: DONOVAN COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $191,000 for the quarter and $785,000 for the 9 months and a gain of $756,000 for the 9 months from an accounting change. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued coal operations.

title: NEW ROLE FOR CAPTIAN KANGAROO
description: The Corporation for Public Broadcasting said today that programs starring Bob Keeshan as Captain Kangaroo would be broadcast on public television. The programs are designed to introduce children to the symphony orchestra and to other performing arts and fine arts.

title: Martial-Law Judge in Turkey Sentences 4 Leftists to Death
description: A military judge today condemned 4 leftist militants to death and sentenced 111 others to varying jail terms, an official announcement said.

title: OF DECALS AND PRIORITIES FOR THE SOUTH BRONX
description: To the Editor: This winter, there will be few city blocks in the South Bronx without a building where there is no heat and hot water for a long period. We will see their inhabitants again all winter: children with bronchitis, old people slipping into pneumonia.

title: SALVADOR SAYS REPORTED MASSACARE VICTIMS WERE SUBVERSIVES
description: Salvadoran Army officials, reacting to reports that soldiers had massacred large numbers of civilians, said today that 20 ''subversives'' had been killed in a recent army sweep northeast of here.

title: 2 OF 3 SUBWAY TRAINS IN CITY ARE NOW REPORTED ON TIME
description: Two of three subway trains arrived at their stations on time in the last week, Transit Authority officials said yesterday. While performance was far from adequate, officials said, the statistics represented considerable progress from a week in July, when one of three trains were on time.

title: STANDARD HAVENS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
AROUND THE NATION
description: Black Mayors HonorStrom Thurmond COLUMBIA, S.C., Nov. 18 (UPI) - Senator Strom Thurmond, a one-time segregationist candidate for President, was honored tonight by South Carolina's black mayors as ''a legendary leader and statesman.'' James Risher, Mayor of Gifford who is chairman of the 14-member Conference of Black Mayors, said the South Carolina Republican was guest of honor at the group's third annual appreciation dinner for his efforts on behalf of small towns. Mayor Risher said Senator Thurmond's record on civil rights in the years since his 1948 States Rights Presidential campaign proved the Senator had changed his attitudes.

title: A WARY TRUCE AT CITY HALL FOR THE BEST OF ENEMIES
description: Mario M. Cuomo finally made it to City Hall yesterday. He was a half-hour late by the public schedule and six years late by his private political schedule. It was his first visit there since being elected Governor.

title: CONSUMERS DISTRIBUTING reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
ADMINISTRATION MOUNTS DRIVE TO COUNTER ATOM WAR FILM
description: The Reagan Administration, responding in advance to a television dramatization of a nuclear war and its aftermath, is stepping up its efforts to persuade the public that its policies are the best way to prevent such a war.

title: MUSIC: JEAN-CLAUDE ELOY
description: Jean-Claude Eloy's ''Gaku-No- Michi,'' or ''Paths of Music,'' is a four-hour electronic-music score that was presented Wednesday night at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation as part of the Forum 83 ''international festival of today's music.''

title: Houston Likely To Sign Crutchfield
description: Joe Walton, the coach of the Jets, shed little light today on why the Jets released their starting fullback, Dwayne Crutchfield, after practice Thursday.

title: The Police Blotter
description: Thirty families in Jamaica, Queens, had to be relocated yesterdayy after a three-alarm fire caused heavy damage to their apartment building at 87-70 173d Street, at the corner of Hillside Avenue. The fire, of undetermined origin, was spotted at 1:45 P.M. and brought under control at 3:15 P.M. Five people, including three firefighters, were injured, none seriously. . . . A 51-year-old Jamaica man, Felix Rivera, was shot in the chest at 11:05 A.M. at 87th Avenue and Queens Boulevard by a police officer who saw him carrying what turned out to be a toy gun. Mr. Rivera, whom the police described as retarded, was reported in stable condition at Jamaica Hospital. . . . Robert Davis, 39, of Manhattan, was arrested and charged with several recent bank robberies when he picked up his last paycheck at the Windows on the World restaurant in the World Trade Center, where he had been dismissed for failing to show up for work as a kitchen manager. Mr. Davis was traced through two holdup notes written on the back of paycheck stubs.

title: HARRIS & PAULSON INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Year-ago results are not available because the company went public in December 1982.

title: FED IN OCTOBER, SET A STABLE POLICY
description: Federal Reserve officials in charge of monetary policy decided early last month to hold policy stable, according to a summary of the minutes from the Oct. 4 meeting of the Federal Open Market committee that were released late yesterday.

title: HALIFAX ENGINEERING INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 19, 1983

title: ISLANDERS OUTSHOT BY 45-14 IN LOSS
description: The Islanders gave up the most shots they have all season, 45, and took their fewest, 14, tonight and lost, 7-1, to the Washington Capitals.

title: Schlichter Ineligible
description: The Ohio Regional Campus Conference has ruled that Art Schlichter, the suspended Baltimore Colt quarterback, cannot play college basketball in its league.

title: U.S. MAY BAN SALVADOR EXILES IN HIRED DEATHS
description: The Reagan Administration is considering sanctions against Salvadoran exiles in the United States who are strongly suspected of paying for and at least partly directing death-squad activities in El Salvador, according to a senior Administration official.

title: MAYNARD ENERGY reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Results for the latest periods include those of Zephyr Resources Ltd. for one month from Sept. 1.

title: Davila Triumphs In Return to Ring
description: Alberto Davila, in his first bout since the knockout that led to the death of Francisco (Kiko) Bejines, won a unanimous 10-round decision Thursday night from Julio Rodrigues.

title: Execution Stay Is Denied
description: Antonio James lost his appeal today for a delay of his execution for robbing and fatally shooting Henry Silver, 71 years old, in 1979. Judge James F. McKay said in State District Court that he saw no reason to block the execution.

title: Youth Killed in Chile After Huge Protest Rally
description: An 18-year-old youth died tonight as riot police fired tear-gas grenades and used water cannon to disperse demonstrators at the end of Chile's biggest anti-Government rally in a decade of military rule.

title: VERDI DREW FROM HUGO
description: ''Ernani,'' Verdi's fifth opera, was a tremendous success at its premiere and carrried his reputation beyond Italy for the first time. Based on Victor Hugo's ''Hernani,'' it had its first performance in Venice in 1844.

title: Comerica Unit
description: The Federal Reserve Board has approved an earlier request by Comerica Inc. to open a credit banking subsidiary in Toledo, Ohio, a bank spokesman said. Comerica had sought the subsidiary to escape Michigan's usury ceiling on credit card loans. The interest ceiling that banks may charge on credit card loans.

title: Article 053686 -- No Title
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association's basketball championship tournament doubled in value yesterday when CBS Sports agreed to pay an estimated $96 million for three years' television rights beginning in 1985. CBS is paying $48 million under the terms of a three-year contract that expires with this season's tournament.

title: HOW TO SEE SOCIAL CUTS AS PENNY ANTE SAVING
description: One of our most enduring fables portrays the United States as throwing away untold billions of dollars each year on bloated and useless social programs. If we only trimmed the fat, so the notion goes, we could increase defense spending and maybe even balance the budget in the bargain.

title: No Headline
description: THE BUTCHER OF LYON. The Story of Infamous Nazi Klaus Barbie. By Brendan Murphy. Illustrated. 336 pages. Empire Books. $13.95. THE story of Klaus Barbie, a young Gestapo officer assigned during the German occupation of France to Lyons, goes beyond the atrocities he himself is accused of having committed. According to Brendan Murphy in ''The Butcher of Lyon,'' Barbie contaminated many of the people with whom he came into contact. We read that informers and collaborators flocked to him in Lyons, that the United States Army Counter Intelligence Corps employed and protected him in Germany after the war was over, and that finally, with American assistance, he was smuggled to Bolivia, where he ingratiated himself with several regimes.

title: NOT THE ONLY GAME IN TOWN
description: When Harvard and Yale play football for the 100th time in the Yale Bowl today, tradition will ooze as thick as the brandy from the spectators' hip flasks. But one bit of history will probably be ignored. The first Harvard-Yale game, played in 1875, was waged on the infield of Hamilton Park, a private race track on the outskirts of New Haven.

title: DANCE: MOLISSA FENLEY IN BROOKLYN
description: Molissa Fenley and Dancers, along with Anthony Davis's music ensemble, Episteme, blew into town Thursday night with a potent, exciting new entry in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's ''Next Wave'' series.

title: SYNCOM CORP reports earnings for Qtr to July 31
MOVE BY CYPRIOTS REJECTED AT U.N.
description: The Security Council voted overwhelmingly today to reject the declaration of an independent republic by Turkish Cypriots, terming it ''legally invalid.''

title: CONCERT: THE DELLER CONSORT
description: Early-music ensembles are not all alike. Some seem to specialize in quaintness, some try for charm, others emphasize the musicological seriousness of it all.

title: RONCO TELEPRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
HOLIDAY TURKEY: THE FEAST THAT WON'T GO AWAY
description: The definition of eternity, according to one wag, is a ham and two people. At this time of year, the Thanksgiving turkey might do as well.

title: VALVANO SEES A LEAN SEASON
description: The story has become his trademark and the people at the luncheons, basketball clinics and motivational seminars that he attends ask Jim Valvano to repeat it the way they would want Frank Sinatra to sing, ''My Way'' whenever he appeared in concert. Valvano, who was looking dapper in a navy blue pinstripe suit, white shirt and maroon tie, was only too happy to oblige today, adding a few embellishments that now make the story sound as dramatic as the game that inspired it.

title: Substitute Official Is Hit
description: The violence and near-violence marring National Basketball Association play so far this season have now directly involved one of the substitute game officials replacing the locked-out regular referees. The incident occurred Thursday night in San Diego when Coach Don Nelson of the Milwaukee Bucks, who were losing by 10 points midway through the final quarter en route to a 19-point defeat by the Clippers, rushed onto the court and, after screaming at Referee Eddie Pimpton, hit the official in the side with his elbow.

title: Your S.P.C.A.S.  Needs You
description: I herewith create the Society for the Preservation of Civilized American Speech. I do so at the urging of a gentleman in Kingsville, Tex., who writes that the country needs a revival of the kind of language that once made human discourse possible without savage vulgarity.

title: PENTRON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $20,600 from discontinued operations.

title: Kupchak Returning
description: Mitch Kupchak, the Los Angeles Laker forward who has been sidelined since 1981 with a broken bone and torn ligament in his left knee, has been returned to the active roster. Kupchak, 28 years old, signed a multiyear contract with the Lakers before the 1981-82 season but played only 26 games before being hurt.

title: REPORTER'S NOTEBOOK: THE BRAZILIANS
description: Like any country, Brazil has its own ways of doing business. When appointments are made, each party expects the other to be half an hour late. Telephone messages are often not returned. ''They're just a reminder that you called before you call again,'' said a secretary in Rio.

title: F.B.I. HUNTING SUSPECT IN BUFFALO IN $7 MILLION CONNECTICUT HOLDUP
description: The F.B.I. said yesterday that it had received its first clues as to the whereabouts of a Wells Fargo security guard accused of stealing $7 million in Connecticut two months ago - three notes the suspect sent to his fiancee, his mother and a lawyer last week.

title: MCDONNELL, TYMSHARE IN MERGER DISCUSSIONS
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation said yesterday that it was holding preliminary talks that could lead to the acquisition of Tymshare Inc., which operates one of the nation's largest networks for transmission of computer data.

title: SPORTS PEOPLE ;  Cowboys Sign Punter
description: Jim Miller was signed yesterday by the Dallas Cowboys to replace the injured John Warren and relieve the starting quarterback, Danny White, of punting chores. Miller, who punted for San Francisco the last three years but was released during the exhibition season, has a pro average of 40.6 yards a punt.

title: TOM BROWN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $9,630,677 for the quarter and $12,438,971 for the 6 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,462,500. d-After income from discontinued operations of $81,917.

description: b-Net income

title: TOE TO TOE OVER THE TRADE TURF
description: Turf warfare is nothing new on Capitol Hill, where scores of Congressional committees and subcommittees have proliferated over the last two centuries and fought one another for jurisdiction over the choicest political terrain.

title: CORATOMIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Quebecers May Modify Laws on Use of French
description: The separatist leaders of Quebec have moved to modify certain provisions of a law that upholds the primacy of French and limits the use of English in education, on advertising signs and in public proceedings.

title: CITY BALLET: 'JEWELS'
description: Thursday night in the New York State Theater, the New York City Ballet danced George Balanchine's ''Jewels'' for the first time since 1980. The revival restores an unusual work to the repertory, for ''Jewels'' is that rarity, a full-evening plotless ballet. Its three sections, evoking the luster of emeralds, rubies and diamonds, are set to music by three different composers and are not directly connected by any narrative device. Yet they complement one another beautifully when performed together.

title: PLAYERSIra Berkow
description: For Bill Laimbeer, the Detroit

title: SATURDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Detroit Pistons , at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. This is the teams' first meeting of the season. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M., live, and 1:30 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.)

title: LIFE AND DEATH AS DOCTORS STRUGGLE TO SUBDUE CANCER
description: Dr. Jeffrey Buckner had just begun evening rounds. It was 7 P.M. He had 22 patients to see, including a handyman, a young mother and a high school dropout and fan of the Grateful Dead. They ranged in age from 17 to 70 and came from as far away as Brazil. Every one of them had cancer.

title: WINDSOR INDUSTRIES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income

title: Biting the Jailhouse Bullet
description: Mid-November brings the first real cold, the first big holiday and, not coincidentally, a decline in the number of people sent to jail. That permits a halt in New York's court-ordered release of detainees to relieve overcrowding - and a chance to avert such orders in the future.

title: Official, Reversed By Koch, Resigns
description: A deputy administrator of the city's Human Resources Administration whose demotion of a lower-level employee in the agency was reversed on orders of Mayor Koch's office has resigned.

title: Minolta Camera
description: The Minolta Camera Company said it has halved its disk camera production, to 50,000 units a month, because of sluggish sales in Japan and abroad. Minolta, the only disk camera maker in Japan, started producing the cameras in April at a rate of 100,000 a month. It exported nearly 80 percent of its total output.

title: ARGENTINA CLAIMS NUCLEAR CAPACITY
description: Argentina announced today that it had developed the technology to make enriched uranium, giving it the capacity to make the fuel for nuclear explosives.

title: SANDERS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
description: The share earnings reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Oct. 11.

title: SANDINISTAS ARE DRILLING TO FIGHT THE 'YANKEES'
description: Preparations for war are visible in every part of this capital city.

title: 6 OF AMERICA'S 8 WOMEN ASTRONAUTS TOP FLY IN '84
description: Crew rosters for four space shuttle missions call for six of the eight women who are United States astronauts to go on flights in 1984, with one to become the first woman to walk in space.

title: WISCONSIN REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a gain from equity in extraordinary income of a company accounted for on the equity method of $115,000 and a tax charge of $313,000. c-After a gain of $115,000 from equity in extraordinary income of a company accounted for on the equity method and a tax credit of $113,000. d-After a gain of $1,848,000 from equity in extraordinary income of a company accounted for on the equity method.

title: SENATE FINANCE PANEL PUTS OFF TAX BILL UNTIL 1984
description: The Senate Finance Committee today put off until February any action on Senator Bob Dole's proposal for a four-year, $150 billion package to reduce budget deficits through tax increases and spending reductions.

description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch announced agreement yesterday on a project that would involve more than $1 billion in commercial, industrial and residential development in sections of the New York and New Jersey waterfronts.

title: MONEY SUPPLY UP $2.2 BILLION
description: The basic measure of the nation's money supply rose $2.2 billion in the week ended Nov. 9, the Federal Reserve System reported yesterday.

description: The Trane Company said it had asked a United States District Court in Wisconsin to restrain IC Industries from acquiring any more Trane shares and to require the company to divest itself of the Trane shares it owns.

title: REPORT CRITICIZES LONDON POLICE
description: London's police force is rife with racial prejudice, dishonesty and drunkenness, according to a report commissioned by Scotland Yard and made public today.

title: IF THIS IS NOVEMBER, IT MUST BE JULY 4
description: Christmas is here. I know because of the catalogues. It's true the leaves have just turned and Con Edison is still fussing over my summer air- conditioning bills. But Christmas is here. My mailman says so every day. Winter boots from L.L. Bean, long underwear from Eddie Bauer and an opus from Saks with the heft and gloss of a National Geographic can mean only one thing. Some companies know enough to be embarrassed and use the words ''holiday,'' and ''season,'' but the bows are there and the tinsel is there, and everyone knows what's going on.

title: AN I.M.F. CONCESSION TO BRAZIL
description: In a new letter of intent with the International Monetary Fund, Brazil has won a major concession on its inflation target for 1984, Ant^onio Delfim Netto, the country's top economic official, disclosed yesterday.

title: Michigan Unit Asks Rate Rise
description: The Consumers Power Company said it asked the Michigan Public Service Commission for permission to increase electricity rates by about $776.7 million, beginning next year.

title: Eastern Foresees 84 Cash Shortfall
description: Eastern Air Lines Inc. could be held in default of its debts next month, but most lenders would relax loan terms if the carrier and its unions agreed on a cost- cutting plan, the company said in a quarterly report filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: AMERICA'S STRONGEST MILITARY OFFICER
description: If you are tired of this country's tested arrangements for civilian control of the military, relief is on the way. In legislation that few have noticed and fewer understand, Congress is considering a shift in the civilian-military balance in the Pentagon, and, in the process, giving the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff more power than any military officer in our history.

description: WASHINGTON CHEMICAL reagents invented by two scientists at the University of Colorado in Boulder are described as accelerating the production and increasing the purity of DNA, the basic raw material of genetic engineering.

description: Transportation Secretary Elizabeth Hanford Dole today called for deregulation of the nation's newest transportation industry, the commercial launching of space satellites.

title: 3 Killed in Florida Collisions
description: Three people were killed and five others were injured early today in four chain-reaction collisions on a portion of Interstate 10 that was blanketed by smoke from a forest fire, officials said. A Florida Highway Patrol spokesman said a pickup truck, two cars and six tractor-trailers were involved in the crashes shortly after midnight about 80 miles west of Tallahassee.

title: CPU COMPUTER reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: NewYorkMayGet A National Forest
description: New York State is virtually assured of getting its first national forest after approval today by the Senate of a measure preventing the sale of 13,232 acres of Federal land near Ithaca, according to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, Democrat of New York.

title: Philbin Acquitted In Fatal Accident
description: The former Jet defensive end Gerry Philbin and his business partner were acquitted by a Suffolk County Court jury today in the death of a workman who was buried in a sandslide last April.

title: ARAFAT SAYS HIS FORCES REGAINED PART OF CAMP BUT REBELS DISAGREE
description: After hours of heavy shelling and ground fighting, Yasir Arafat said tonight that his forces had regained a ''large area'' of the Beddawi refugee camp on the edge of the city.

title: MIDAS LEADS GROWTH IN REPAIR OF MUFFLERS
description: The Midas International Corporation, propelled by rising auto costs, motorists who are keeping their cars longer, and the public's disenchantment with the old-style repair industry, has become the McDonald's of muffler retailers.

title: U.S. MOVES TO SEND MAN TO ISRAEL ON WAR CHARGES
description: A 63- year-old retired automobile worker who is accused of being a Nazi death camp guard in World War II was arrested today on an extradition request from Israel, the authorities said.

title: SCOUTING
description: Down the Stretch

title: U.S. ACCUSES INSURANCE FUND OF DEFRAUDING THE TEAMSTERS
description: The Central States Health and Welfare Fund of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters was defrauded of more than $12 million by an insurance company that was owned by Allen M. Dorfman, a slain teamsters' associate, the Labor Department said today.

title: Export Act Extended
description: Congress late today sent to the White House a bill extending the President's authority to restrict exports for national security or foreign policy reasons. The bill, passed by voice in the House and Senate, extends the provisions of the Export Administration Act until Feb. 29, 1984. The enforcement provisions of the act expired in September.

title: Arrows Win, 5-2
description: Fred Grgurev's power-play goal in the second period and Mike Lashchev's short-handed goal in the third quarter carried the New York Arrows to their first victory of the Major Indoor Soccer League season tonight, a 5-2 decision over the Baltimore Blast before 6,093 fans at Nassau Coliseum. Grgurev's goal, this third of the season, tied the score, 2-2. Val Tuksa put the Arrows, who lost their four previous contests, ahead, 3-2, at 1 minute 25 seconds of the third period.

title: PATENTS
description: -Ray Body Scanner

title: UNWANTED BOOKS: WHERE TO DONATE THEM
description: You have too many books on your shelves. They are not valuable - just former best sellers or books that you will never read again. You don't want to throw them away. What should you do?

title: FOR SAUDIS: CLEANLINESS, GODLINESS, WEALTHINESS
description: This city is invaded each day by an army of 3,000 Sri Lankans. Armed with brooms and mechanized street sweepers, they advance quietly and efficiently through the city's markets and grand boulevards. Their mission is to keep Riyadh clean. The results are staggering, Saudis and foreigners agree. Ten years ago Riyadh was one of the dirtiest, dustiest cities in the Middle East. Today the city is relatively spotless. Nevertheless, Rodney R. Proto, managing director of Browning-Ferris Saudi Arabia Ltd., a joint Saudi- American venture that has a five- year, $233 million contract to clean the city, is not satisfied.

title: LONGS DRUG STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
Ransom Is Called Ready In Heineken Case
description: Dutch newspapers have reported that the Heineken brewery raised $10 million for the ransom of its chairman, Alfred H. Heineken, and his chauffeur, who were kidnapped Nov. 9.

title: South Korea G,N.P. Up
description: South Korea's gross national product grew by a provisional 10.4 percent in the third quarter, compared with a 7.1 percent rise in the corresponding 1982 period, the Bank of Korea said today. In the first nine months, the G.N.P. was a provisional 9.9 percent higher than in the 1982 period, which saw growth of 5.7 percent.

description: Our environmental concerns center about lung-related atmospheric pollution to the virtual exclusion of other matters pertaining to good health. We're so worried about what we breathe that we tend to overlook comparable hazards.

description: The president of a tugboat-manufacturing company is cracking one- liners with a group of marine engineers: ''Comparing a conventional screw-type tug with our tug,'' he says dryly, ''is like comparing Popeye before and after a can of spinach.''

title: ELIE WIESEL: BEARING WITNESS
ST. FRANCIS PREP TAKES TITLE, 15-0
description: Undefeated St. Francis Prep of Queens showed strong defense and enough offense today to defeat St. Anthony's of Smithtown, L.I., 15-0, in the Catholic High Schools' Football League championship game. It was the Terriers' 10th championship - the most for any school in the league.

title: HUMANITY AND BABY JANE DOE
description: There is evidently no one at all in the Department of Justice with both authority and humanity. If there were, it could not have made the merciless decision it did in the case of Baby Jane Doe. How many days and weeks of torment must the poor parents suffer before the Reagan Administration abandons its callous tenacity?

title: VOLCKER: ON CENTER STAGE
description: WHEN Paul A. Volcker testified July 20 before a Congressional panel that the Federal Reserve Board in effect would not tighten monetary policy, the Dow Jones industrial average soared 30.74 points, its biggest one-day gain in eight months. A week later, when Mr. Volcker testified that a credit squeeze was shaping up, the market fell 14.12 points.

title: U.S.CONDEMNS 'VIOLENT RIGHT' IN EL SALVADOR
description: Departing from longstanding Administration policy of muffling criticism of selected right-wing governments, Fred C. Ikle, a senior Pentagon official, said last week that ''the death squads of the violent right'' must be defeated along with leftist guerrillas in El Salvador.

title: FOR THE DYING, QUALITY OF LIFE IS IMPORTANT
description: THERE is a quiet revolution under way in the medical community, a grassroots movement that is both at odds and in keeping with medical tradition.

title: PUTTING ALL YOUR ASSETS IN ONE BASKET
description: ''GOD is in the details,'' Friedrich Nietzsche once said. In financial services, innovations are often found in the details. Take the case of the growing number of central asset management accounts now being introduced by an array of financial institutions.

title: EVER-FLEXIBLE OPTIONS
description: OPTIONS are sometimes compared to fire insurance: They can provide investors with coverage if a stock they own goes down, and they can allow investors to share in the increases on stocks they would like to purchase.

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: Officer Robert Berger's troubles with the Baltimore police began in February 1982 when the department ordered him to stop imitating Al Jolson in blackface during off-duty hours.

title: MARGIN BUYING'S LEVERAGE
description: By last September, 200,000 new margin customers had come into the market, and it is estimated that 75,000 more will have joined them by year's end. The amount of money borrowed by margin buyers has soared nearly $9 billion to $19.8 billion.

title: 25th in a Row For Cam Fella
description: Cam Fella, the 4-year-old pacer, won his 25th straight race of the year at Roosevelt Raceway tonight, establishing a record for consecutive victories in a single season in harness racing.

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: BEING the largest student credit union in the country has not deterred the University of Connecticut's credit union from seeking more clients. In fact, it has gone so far this semester as to offer its members money for good grades.

title: CRIME
description: Clive Egleton's name is usually associated with British espionage or suspense thrillers, and even though his new book is a police procedural, it will not cause any basic revision in the estimate of his work. A CONFLICT OF INTERESTS (Atheneum, $13.95) introduces Detective Inspector Coghill, who has the murder of a blackmailing call girl on his hands. But lurking in the background are the K.G.B., the C.I.A. and British intelligence. At least, they lurk in the early part of the book. Then they come out of hiding. So if this is a procedural, it nevertheless has enough espionage and suspense for Mr. Egleton to hold on to his license.

description: MALAMUD READING

title: CRIME AND CAPITAL PUNISHMENT IN CHINA
description: The method is always the same: a bullet fired into the back of the head while the criminal kneels in submission to fate. Only the nature of the victims has changed to include, besides murderers and rapists, lesser criminals such as thieves, embezzlers and hooligans.

title: JUDGE AND ADVOCATE
description: Jerold S. Auerbach is the author of ''Unequal Justice'' and ''Justice Without Law?'' and the chairman of the department of history at Wellesley College. BRANDEIS

title: CHOOSING A STOCKBROKER: FULL SERVICE VS. DISCOUNT
description: FOR many people, choosing a stockbroker can be as bewildering as picking stocks. For small and large investors alike, the choice of a broker can make a significant difference in commissions paid and services received.

title: AMERICAN PAINTERS ARE NOW PRINTMAKERS, TOO
description: Once upon a time, print people were not like the rest of us. In all but name, they formed a secret society. They had their clubs, their magazines and their coded language. Their talk was of states and stones, rockers and roulettes, foul biting and burr. What they were arguing about was usually a small sheet of paper. And the image - like a celebrated automobile of some 50 years ago - came in any color you wanted, provided that it was black. In those distant days the color print, though technically possible, was regarded as unsporting. Hadn't black and white been good enough for D"urer, good enough for Rembrandt, and good enough for Goya? Such was the status of the black-and-white print that at one moment in our century a mezzotint engraving after an English 18th-century portrait in oils was said to cost as much as the original painting.

title: SCIENCE, CONSCIENCE AND BOMBS
description: Pope John Paul II has an admirable interest in correcting misjudgments, even those of the distant past. Recently he found a good word to say for Martin Luther, the whistle-blower who forced Reformation and schism on Western Christendom. This week the Pope firmly dissociated himself from predecessors who persecuted Galileo, assuring scientists that as seekers of the truth ''you will find in the Church and in this Apostolic See your most convinced allies.''

title: 'THE TAPE TELLS ALL'
description: When Stan Weinstein picks a company's stock, he does not look at earnings, cash flow or consider what kind of job the company president is doing. He shuns the fundamentals and takes the technical approach, studying supply and demand for shares and the trend of the overall stock market.

title: TRIPOLI ENGULFED IN FIERCE BATTLE OF P.L.O. FACTIONS
description: Artillery explosions thundered throughout this city of 600,000 today and rockets shrieked overhead as rival Palestinian factions battled for the Beddawi refugee camp to the north.

title: SEARS BROKER SELLS WALL ST. TO MAIN ST.
description: Vincent Romano is a stockbroker. His office is between the restaurant and the candy counter in a Sears store. When Sears bought the Dean Witter brokerage house, Mr. Romano, who usually works in a branch office in Schaumburg, Ill., with 30 other Dean Witter account executives, was assigned to a store in northwest Chicago that attracts mainly blue-collar customers.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
LUBECK'S DELECTABLE MARZIPAN
description: To people with a sweet tooth, L"ubeck's fame derives from one footnote to the city's long history. It is the world capital of marzipan. Made from a confectioner's paste of ground almonds, powdered sugar and a few drops of rose water, marzipan is used to fill pralines and to mold or sculpture anything and everything, including, once, a life- sized effigy of Prussia's King Frederick William IV. It is the sweetest - and probably calorie-richest - of all sweetmeats, and L"ubeck produces more of it each year than the rest of the world combined.

title: CONGRESS, GONE BUT NOT DONE
description: Congress has wound up a bad year. The session now adjourned faced one overriding issue: the oppressive budget deficits in future years. Lacking a President's leadership, the legislators toyed with a few remedies and then chose default.

title: EIGHT HISTORIC CAPITAL CITIES
description: WILLIAM K. STEVENS is chief of the New Delhi bureau of The New York Times.

title: LONDON LEADERS PLAY DOWN RISE IN MISSILE FEARS
description: LONDON FALLING back upon the national penchant for understatement, British officials are dismissing the outbreak of anti-Americanism here during the last few weeks as just a momentary rift in an otherwise sober and rock-steady relationship. The antagonism aroused by the combination of the Grenada invasion and the arrival of the first American cruise nuclear missiles hardly compares, they say, with the chill after the Suez invasion in 1956, when Foreign Office diplomats refused to talk to their opposite numbers in the State Department. And the ''ban the bomb'' movement of the same era attracted marchers in far greater numbers than the turnouts last week, when the first cruise shipment arrived at the Greenham Common air base. ''What we have seen is a blip in the relationship between London and Washington, not a sea change,'' a senior British official said.

The firms, most of them tiny one- or two-person operations, offer advice about everything from what color clothing to wear to complement one's complexion - and career goals - to how to survive a hostile media interview.

Roy Cole performed the ceremony at St. Alban's Episcopal Church in Washington.

description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said today that the outcome of the struggle within the Palestine Liberation Organization was certain to have ''major implications'' for the future of the American- sponsored peace efforts in the Middle East.

description: EVEN before the first shovel of dirt is turned, the Garden City Apartments, a 346-unit luxury condominium project that will be adjacent to the new Garden City Hotel, may have broken new ground financially.

title: Third World Ministers to Visit Mideast for Talks on P.L.O.

title: UNION'S PEACE SCORES 5 TOUCHDOWNS
description: Keith Peace ran for 271 yards and scored 5 touchdowns and 2 conversions to lead Union to a 58-27 victory over Nutley yesterday in the first round of the North Jersey, Section 2, Group 4 playoffs in Union.

title: CHILDREN WATCH?
description: ''Dad, what's the biggest kind of bomb?,'' my 9-year-old son asked me. And I wondered: At what age should parents expose children to the realities of nuclear war? Tonight, with the broadcast of ''The Day After,'' parents will have to decide whether their children should be encouraged, allowed or forbidden to watch the suffering and destruction that the film depicts.

title:
DINING OUT;
SEAFARE WITH GRACE IN ARDSLEY
description: THE Ship's Galley Inn has been operating quietly in Ardsley for almost two years. The place is worth knowing about when you are in the neighborhood and in the mood for fish. Superficially, The Galley would seem to have a lot in common with other seafood restaurants in the county - not a curious coincidence as the owners, Pat and Peter Longo (who is the chef, as well), have put in long engagements at the Fishmarket Inn. Waterfront murals, weathered boards, fish nets and corks help create a familiar nautical motif. The dinner sequence, which usually includes a basket of white and dark breads, an overflowing salad bowl to be served family style, a heavy mug of creamy herb dressing, a bowl of steaming vegetables, awful rice and a basket of fruit for dessert, completes the dej a vu. But similarities stop there.

title: A TOUCH OF NYNEX
description: It was inevitable that Ma Bell would someday pass away, but I wasn't aware of her decline until a few years ago when she began saying, ''Have a nice day.''

title: PAPERBACKS:NEW AND NOTE WORTHY
description: THE PATH TO POWER: The Years of Lyndon Johnson. By Robert A. Caro. (Vintage, $9.95.) The winner of the National Book Critics Circle Award as 1982's best nonfiction work, this is the first installment of Robert Caro's life of President Lyndon Johnson. Based on seven years of research, it assesses Johnson's career as it was played out against the vast panorama of 20th-century American history. Our critic, David Herbert Donald, summed the book up as ''fascinating, immensely long and highly readable,'' admired its verbal snapshots of Johnson and found it ''stunningly successful'' in recounting what Johnson did.

description: Karen Stabiner is a West Coast freelance writer.

title: KING PRESSES CASE ON IRISH ISSUE
description: LOCAL politicians usually steer clear of foreign affairs. It's not their province. Comptrollers tend to be even more cautious. Most court the image of the impartial, nonpolitical watchdog of other politicians.

title: THE WRONG STUFF
description: The image-makers are moving in on John Glenn, and if he allows them and encourages them, you can bet on Mondale and Reagan in 1984.

title: NEW EFFORT FOCUSES ON ARTS EDUCATION
description: IN 1978, the results of a questionnaire sent to school administrators and principals by the Council for the Arts in Westchester indicated that while county educators believed that the arts were an important element in school programs, they did not constitute an integral part of the education of children in county schools.

title: THE MILITARY TAKE ITS LUMPS
description: Argentina's military last week suffered the delayed effects of past mistakes. The ruling junta, with only a month left before it hands power over to civilians, decided to court- martial former President Leopoldo Galtieri and two colleagues for the disastrous invasion of the Falkland Islands in April of last year. The Supreme Council of the Armed Forces will try General Galtieri, Adm. Jorge Anaya, the former navy commander, and Brig. Gen. Basilio Lami Dozo, who headed the air force, for ''possible responsibilities of a nature punishable under military law.''

title: ELIE WIESEL: BEARING WITNESS
PROBING SOVIET SOCIETY
description: RUSSIA

title: THREE INVESTING SCENARIOS: HOW AGE INFLUENCES TACTICS
description: EVERYONE has a different notion about how to make the nest egg grow. Life situations often determine who is a swashbuckler and who prefers a piggy bank. Financial experts say age is a primary determinant of investment strategy, with different goals for young singles, middle-age couples with children, and couples preparing for retirement.

title: Margaret Barrett Becomes a Bride
description: Margaret Lynn Barrett, daughter of Mrs. Abe Gold of New York and the late Ralph Hirshberg, was married yesterday to James F. Noonan, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John T. Noonan of Brooklyn. Rabbi Ronald Sobel performed the ceremony at the National Arts Club in New York.

title: BISHOPS STUDYING WOMEN'S PLACE IN THE CHURCH
description: It may turn out that the principal issue for the Roman Catholic Church in America is not nuclear disarmament, secular politics or ecumenism, but women. Pope John Paul II believes Catholic women should stick to their traditional place within the church, low in the hierarchy and far from the priesthood. Increasing numbers of Catholic women are rejecting that status and, many times, the church itself. The issue divides not only Pope and feminists, but also conservatives and liberals, the Vatican and the American church.
