title: DEBATE RISES ABOUT CURBS ON GRENADA
description: The debate about restriction of news coverage of combat in Grenada has brought into the open military suspicions about the press and its patriotism.

title: OPERA: NEW PRODUCTION FOR VERDI'S 'ERNANI'
description: ''Ernani'' is an important opera because it is by Giuseppi Verdi. Other than that, its attractions are modest. It is, in fact, third-rate Verdi, which makes it second-rate anyone else, or better. It is a mass of musical and dramatic cliches, but operagoers with an ear tuned to history find it fascinating for what it led up to. It is an early, extremely rough steppingstone on the way to such greater matters as ''La Forza del Destino'' and ''Don Carlos.'' And, of course, Verdi enthusiasts know it has attracted a long list of famous singers, which gives the work a certain patina of importance.

title:
DINING OUT;
DINING WITH AN OPERATIC THEME
description: NEW RESTAURANTS open and close at an alarming rate, so it's all the more rewarding to hear of one that has been pleasing customers for almost 25 years.

title: NORTH CAROLINA ST. TOPS HOUSTON, 76-64
description: The experts had predicted that the result would not be close. Unlike the final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament last spring, when North Carolina State defeated Houston by 2 points, this game more or less figured to be a showcase for Akeem Olajuwon, Houston's 7-foot center and the basketball fraternity known as Phi Slama Jama.

title: DONOVAN ON THE STAND
description: The subject was no-show jobs, and Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan showed up in Federal District Court in Brooklyn last week to tell all he didn't know about them. Mr. Donovan was called by defense attorneys for two former union officials charged with lying about padding the payroll on a subway tunnel project undertaken by Schiavone Construction Company in the late 1970's, when Mr. Donovan was executive vice president of the company. The labor bosses supposedly lied to a grand jury that investigated related matters last year and found ''insufficient credible evidence'' to indict Mr. Donovan. In court last week, Mr. Donovan said, ''I don't know that Schiavone paid salaries to people who did not work, of my own knowledge.''

title: No Headline
description: Nina Lentini Is Engaged

title: France
description: To the Editor: I enjoyed the article entitled ''1300 Years of Living Histo

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
BIG BROTHER AND BLOCK MODELING
description: As 1984 approaches, a quiet revolution in computers and information gathering may be bringing us closer than we realize to George Orwell's controlled state of Oceania. The public seems preoccupied with teen-age computer ''hackers'' accessing sensitive computer systems. But our more enduring fears should focus on a technology that corporations, nonprofit organizations and governments are using with increasing frequency to harness seemingly innocuous data from personnel or communications departments and adapt it in new and unexpected ways such as targeting individuals for promotion or dismissal.

title: Union Crushes Hofstra, 51-19
description: Hofstra, with a defensive line that averaged 220 pounds, was unable to cope with the skills of a 170-pound quarterback, Dan Stewart, and a 145-pound split end, Winston Britton today.

title: DANCE: SIX NEW WORKS
description: Dance Theater Workshop's Choreographers Showcase has come up with a good selection of new work, seen on the first of four Tuesday performances being presented this month.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Shelburne, Vt. Decks the Halls For Christmas

title: HOCKEY TEAMS TAKE TO THE HIGHWAYS
description: The rink is cold and its surface is covered with hundreds of thousands of ounces of liquid, ready to be chilled and enjoyed. But it is not water waiting to be transformed into ice for skating: It is beer and soda, cases upon cases, stacked on the floor of what used to be the Riverdale Ice Skating Center.

title: Henderson Plea
description: Thomas (Hollywood) Henderson, the former star linebacker of the Dallas Cowboys, has pleaded not guilty to five felony sex and drug counts related to charges of an assault on two teen-agers. Henderson, who is free on $16,000 bail, was ordered to appear in Municipal Court in Long Beach, Calif., for a preliminary hearing Jan. 3.

title: RITES OF PASSAGE
Faith Wilcox Plans Bridal For January
description: Dr. and Mrs. David Sanborn Wilcox of West Hartford, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Faith Fuller Wilcox, to Clive Jeppe Russ, son of Norman Durham Russ of Johannesburg and Princess Michel Cantacuz ene of Westerly, R.I., and Paris. The wedding is to be in January in Boston.

title: SOBER WARNING TO THE PREGNANT
description: The Surgeon General advises women who are pregnant or considering pregnancy not to drink alcohol. Last week, the New York City Council moved to make sure they get the message.

title: THE PROFESSIONALS PREDICT STAR PERFORMERS FOR 1984
description: IN the first 14 1/2 months of the bull market that came charging out of the chute in August 1982, all but one of 89 industry groups monitored by Standard & Poor's showed gains. Manufacturers of communications equipment snared first prize, advancing 164.2 percent. Entertainment issues were the poorest performer, slipping 1.7 percent. Plunging interest rates provided the common spur then for the stock market's best sustained rally in half a century.

title: Bodensee
description: To the Editor: In the article ''What's Doing in Arlberg'' (Travel, Oct. 30) by James N. Markham, the enlarged map listed the capital of Vorarlberg Bregenz instead of Bregenz.

title: A $4 BILLION STATE BUDGET IS FORESEEN
description: HARTFORD THE curtain went up last week on the first tryout of Connecticut's budget drama for 1984-85. Like the rewriting of a script before the show officially opens on Broadway, the state budget is likely to undergo a lot of revisions before Governor O'Neill sends it to the General Assembly in February.

title: NEW LAW CURTAILS LOBSTER TRAWLING
description: BOTH tradition and conservation practices were recently rewarded when new state regulations for lobster fishing on Long Island Sound went into effect. The regulations ban trawling as the main way to catch lobsters and any night harvesting.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Football
description: Giants vs. Eagles at Philadelphia. (Television - Channel 2, 1 P.M. Radio - WNEW 1130, 1 P.M.). Buffalo Bills vs. Los Angeles Raiders at Orchard Park, N.Y. The last time these teams met, in 1980, the Bills won, 24-7, to tie the series at 11 victories each. (Television - Channel 4, 1 P.M.).

title: Rome
description: To the Editor: In the description of the small Roman hotel on the Piazza Trinit^a dei Monti now called the Scalinata di Spagna in Paul Hof

title: BRIGHT TO ALTER FAIR-CATCH POLICY
description: Leon Bright would like to get a good night's sleep. Lately, it has been difficult.

title: THE APPEAL OF BONDS
description: INDIVIDUALS in recent years have begun to imitate sophisticated institutional investors, dividing their investments between bonds and stocks. The bonds offer stable cash flow and current yields well in excess of recent inflation. The stocks offer potential capital gains.

title: ; INVISIBLE HAND
description: To the Business Editor:

title:
NUMISMATICS;
BRAND SALE GIVES THE COIN MARKET A BOOST
description: The coin market may be down a bit right now, but it's far from out. That was the message delivered on Nov. 7 and 8 when several hundred bidders gathered in New York for the first of two auctions in the American segment of the Brand Sale.

title: THE USES AND ABUSES OF TAX SHELTERS
description: NOW is the season, just before year-end, when taxpayers are most eager to shield a portion of their income from taxes. And with many investors flush with profits from the stock market, curiosity has intensified about tax shelters.

title: FELLOWSHIPS HONOR FOUNDATION HEAD
description: NEW HAVEN, like other cities in the late 60's, was beset by economic crisis and torn by violence the year William L. Bradley took over the presidency of the Edward W. Hazen Foundation. Until then, the small philanthropy's good works had been conducted chiefly in Asian or African countries.

title: FROM COVER TO COVER
description: IM one of those people with a

title: 'LESSER GOD' AT GEORGE STREET
description: -anniversary season, the George Street Playhouse here has come up with a credible, but not altogether well-conceived and somewhat constricted, production of ''Children of a Lesser God.''

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: -agers who have babies often choose to keep their children, childless couples who want to adopt an infant are ''going to have trouble,'' says Toni McHugh of the Morris County community of New Vernon, chairman of the National Committee for Adoption.

title: PCB LEVELS IN STRIPED BASS IN THE HUDSON DECLINE
description: The average level of polychlorinated biphenyls (PCB's) in striped bass in the Hudson River has fallen below the danger point set by the Federal Government, but New York has decided not to lift its ban on commercial fishing in the river, according to the State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Carol M. Gilbert Weds Dr. Bruce H. Patterson
description: Carol Marie Gilbert, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert James Gilbert of Edison, N.J., was married yesterday to Dr. Bruce Hull Patterson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Roswell S. Patterson of Waverly, Pa. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: ART FRON JAPAN
description: Collecting Japanese art is a century-old tradition in this country, as strong today as when it began in earnest after Japan opened its doors to the West in 1848. Yet, not surprisingly, collecting habits have changed dramatically over the decades. At the turn of the century, for example, most collectors acquired a sampling of all Japanese arts - scrolls, prints, ceramics, embroidered textiles, carved ivories, swords and lacquer boxes. Today's enthusiasts follow a different course, preferring to collect in depth only one or two categories of Japanese art.

title: East Meadow Gains
description: East Meadow and Farmingdale both won yesterday and will play for the Conference A title on Saturday.

title: Seafood Haven
description: To the Editor: In reference to the ar

title:
ABOUT MEN;
FORMER LIES
description: HERE IS NO WAY TO duck it - and I don't try. The plain fact is that although I have in every way a rewarding present occupation, I am still mostly a ''formerly.'' It is a description used by other people, usually out of earshot, identifying someone in the past tense, invoking some former title. ''You know him. He was for years the head of . . .''

title: Andrea Terry Marschalk, a Sculptor, Married to Peter Christian Scheyhing
description: At St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn., yesterday Andrea Terry Marschalk, a sculptor, was married to Peter Christian Scheyhing, chief of operations for Medicine & Computer magazine in White Plains. The Rev. William A. Eddy performed the ceremony.

title: Q&A
description: A Questionable Fee Question:

title: Initiative-Referendum Called Boon to Public
description: Several Assembly and Senate concurrent resolutions propose an amendment to the State Constitution that would permit the people to recommend laws and amendments through the initiative process and to approve or reject all or any part of an enacted law through the referendum process.

title: Family Slain in Oregon
description: The owner of a remodeling company killed his wife and four children and then turned a gun on himself early today, the police said. The dead were identified as Robert M. Galloway, 52 years old; his wife, Mary Lou, 44; and their children, James Robert, 20; Lori, 16; Ronald, 14; and Larry, 13. The bodies of the parents, one son and the daughter, who was telephoning for help, were found at their home, police said, while the other sons were found at the J & J Remodeling Company.

title: TRIALS OF A PUBLIC DEFENDER
description: ''HOW CAN YOU DEFEND THOSE PEOPLE?''

title: Elizabeth Ann Reamer to Marry Blake Hornick
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Norman Reamer of Kingston, N.Y., of the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Reamer, to Blake Hornick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton J. Hornick of New York and New City, N.Y.

title: IN THE VCR RACE, BETA STILL LEADS WITH HIGH-FIDELITY SOUND
description: No sooner had Sony launched the first video cassette recorder (VCR) in 1976 than several other manufacturers banded together in an attempt to corner the market with a different and wholly incompatible product. Ever since, the Beta system developed by Sony and the VHS system espoused by Panasonic and its licensees have been bitter rivals for the favor of their worldwide public.

title: 'Burned-Out' Rocket Returns
description: Robert Reid, the Houston Rocket guard, says he was ''burned out'' after the 1981-82 season, which, more than the ''religious reasons'' he originally cited, caused him to give up a lucrative basketball career for a year.

title: COLLEGE STUDENTS SET RECORD PACE
description: Overall college enrollment this fall is 1.1 percent higher than last year's record of 12.6 million, primarily because of an increase in the number of part-time students, college research groups have reported.

title: SALVADOR OFFICER CONCEDES KILLING OF CIVILIANS
description: United States officials said today that the commander of a Salvadoran Army battalion had admitted that his troops killed civilians in an antiguerrilla offensive, but that he had denied the action was deliberate.

title: Planning To Retire
description: THE climate for retirement planning has rarely been better: The economic recovery and the many new investment vehicles provide two incentives for contemplating the future now. ''There are a lot of options out there,'' said Donald Kerr, a vice president of the Irving Trust Company of New York. ''Choosing the right one, or several, depends mostly on what you can afford with what you have.''

title: A FOR-PROFIT HMO WATCHED
description: THE president of United States Health Care Systems Inc. - the parent corporation of the state's newest and only for- profit HMO - dismisses as ''hogwash'' the notion that the D.R.G. system is hurting health-maintenance organizations.

title: FAILED CAMPAIGNS PUT DREAMS ON HOLD
description: AWEEK after losing his comeback attempt, former Democratic Mayor John C. Mandanici of Bridgeport was preparing for another fight. He is planning a court challenge to a state law that prevents him from being a Democrat for two years because he ran on the Taxpayers Party ticket this time.

title: MICHIGAN DEFEATS OHIO ST., 24-21
description: Steve Smith, Michigan's senior quarterback, made up for a lot of past mistakes today when he threw for two touchdowns and ran for another to lead the Wolverines to a 24-21 victory over Ohio State and into the Sugar Bowl game Jan. 2.

title: TALES OUT OF JAIL
description: On his release from prison last week, Billie Sol Estes said that but for his sealed lips, Lyndon B. Johnson would have gone to the jailhouse instead of the White House. In 1965, Mr. Estes, then a Johnson crony and financial backer, was convicted of fraud and concealing income from his highly lucrative practice of mortgaging nonexistent fertilizer tanks.

title: Slain Politician Honored
description: President Reagan signed a bill Friday authorizing a Congressional gold medal in honor of Representative Leo J. Ryan, Democrat of California, killed five years ago to the day near Jonestown, Guyana. Mr. Ryan was shot and killed while investigating reports of brutality in the cult headed by Jim Jones. More than 900 members of the cult died after Mr. Jones ordered them to drink a mixture of a powdered soft drink and cyanide.

title: MORE RICHES MINED FROM THE 78 ERA
description: Whenever a new recording technology comes along, it swallows up, or at least echoes, the technologies that have preceded it. Thus for some 35 years, now, we have had tape-recordings of 78 r.p.m. originals, which are then duplicated onto LP's for commercial distribution.

title: Members End Boycott Of Parliament in Japan
description: Opposition politicians ended a 37-day boycott of Parliament on Friday after a compromise was reached in a dispute over the bribery conviction of former Prime Minister Kakuei Tanaka.

title: Newsletters For Investors Are Booming
description: ON Jan. 7, 1981, stock market oracle Joseph Granville issued his now famous cry, ''Sell everything!'' Thousands of investors who paid $250 a year for his market advisory newsletter heeded the call, and in one day the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 23 points, chopping nearly $40 billion from the total value of stocks traded on the United States stock exchanges and over-the-counter markets. The self-prophesying decline was short-lived, and Mr. Granville's followers are now finding themselves on the sidelines of one of the longest sustained bull market rallies in half a century. Any investor following his continuing bearish recommendations would have lost money in 1982 and so far in 1983.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME SPRINGTIME IN THE DEAD OF WINTER
description: ONE advantage of living in the North is that of experiencing the panorama of colors, textures and forms that are provided by the changing seasons. That this changing scene has no counterpart in the South has been a disappointment to many who move to the land of eternal summer.

title: GUILFORD HOCKEY TEAM LEARNS TO PAY ITS OWN WAY
description: IN May of 1982, the Board of

title: DECIDING HOW MUCH TO RISK
description: TO make money, the truism goes, one has to spend money. But there are no such truisms about the amount of money that an individual should spend, or invest, in pursuit of more. The risk that any individual takes should be determined by a number of factors.

title: GETTING TO KNOW THE POMEROL
description: FRENCH WINE MAKERS ARE notorious for their lack of interest in anyone's wines but their own. Recently, an old grape grower insisted that, au contraire and unlike most of his colleagues on the C^ote d'Or, he was interested in all the wines of France, not just those from his corner of Burgundy.

title: A WEEKEND DEVOTED TO WINE
description: A series of events designed to tell consumers about wine, and featuring several well-known experts in the field, drew 65 residents from the New York City area to Tarrytown last weekend.

title: ORCHESTRAS UNDER WAY
description: ONLY time can tell whether county residents will support two full-sized, fully professional orchestras, but the New Orchestra of Westchester gave its inaugural concert last weekend amid great optimism, while the White Plains Symphony continues its 21st season after what the orchestra's manager, Ruth Moss, called ''an absolute smash'' opener last month, ''with attendance much better than we had dared hope.''

title: A 3d U.S.-Employed Linguist Seized at Guatemalan Home
description: Kidnappers seized a Guatemalan linguist working for the Agency for International Development last week, the third A.I.D. teacher abducted in about a month, officials said today.

title: FRANCE UNVEILS PLAN TO LIMIT OWNERSHIP OF NEWSPAPERS
description: A plan by the French Government to limit the number of newspapers and periodicals anyone may publish threatens to provoke one of the most bitter political discussions since the Socialists came to power more than two years ago.

title: THE REGION ; A PLAN TO EASE THE FISCAL PERIL OF PUBLIC SAFETY
description: One law that police officers in New Jersey have found personally profitable is the statute imposing binding arbitration in wage disputes. Since the system was imposed in 1978, police officers and firefighters have pushed their salaries up and the budgets of many municipalities to the breaking point. Last week, Governor Kean said he would ask the Legislature for $5 million to help half a dozen strapped cities - Newark, Jersey City, Paterson, Camden, Elizabeth and Trenton - avoid layoffs that might make them less safe.

title: Doctor as 'Captain': Other Views
description: I read with interest the article about Dr. Joseph E. De Junco of St. Francis Hospital on Oct. 23 (''For a Young Cardiologist, an Essential Rx Is Compassion''). The article delineated the human side of health care, but was incomplete and inaccurate in part.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: If anyone has lived the total jazz life, it is Lionel Hampton. As an early teen-ager, he was playing drums in a band sponsored by a black newspaper, The Chicago Defender. When he moved to California at the age of 15, he began playing drums professionally. He was in the Les Hite band at Sebastian's Cotton Club in 1930 when Louis Armstrong was the star of the show and the theoretical leader of the band. Mr. Hampton, who had found a set of vibraphones in a recording studio and had learned to use the instrument, played his first recorded vibes solo with Mr. Armstrong on ''Memories of You'' in 1930. Six years later, when he was leading his own band in Los Angles, Benny Goodman heard him and persuaded him to go on the road with the Goodman band as a member of the Benny Goodman Quartet. He also filled in on drums with the big band.

title: COPYRIGHT LAW COMES IN SECOND
description: When the Constitution's free- speech guarantees and copyright protections make competing claims on justice, judges should favor free speech, a Federal appeals court ruled last week. ''We do not believe it is the purpose of the Copyright Act to impede that harvest of knowledge so necessary to a democratic state,'' Judge Irving R. Kaufman wrote for the 2-to-1 majority.

title: THE RETURN TO NORMAL IS A SLOW JOURNEY FOR GRENADA
description: Its tourist planners like to portray Grenada as an exotic spice island, full of romance, sparkling beaches and tropical drinks with rum and a twist of lime. But even more exotic than its nutmegs, cacao and bananas are its politics.

title: RIVAL NICARAGUAN EXILES SEEK SUPPORT IN U.S.
description: Differences between the rival Nicaraguan guerrilla exile forces have made it difficult to create an effective exile political opposition to the Nicaraguan Government, United States officials said after a visit to Washington this week by a leading Nicaraguan guerrilla leader.

title: A CLASSIC RECOVERY, AFTER ALL
description: CHICAGO ALITTLE more than a year ago,

title: Theatergoers Moved By 'Getting Out'
description: Bravo to ''Getting Out!'' Bravo to Studio Theater of Lindenhurst! (''Powerful Prison Drama,'' Theater Review, Oct. 16).

title: A PROMISING START, AND THEN...
description: IMAGINE a restaurant where the captain asks

title: FOOD ; WITH CELERY ROOT, OR CELERIAC, UGLINESS IS ONLY SKIN DEEP
description: CELERY root, also called celeriac, has never made it to the vegetable Top 10. It is ugly and gnarled, so coarse- looking that those who have never cooked it are put off doing so by its appearance. But under the skin, this vegetable has a pale ivory flesh much like a potato - with a delicate hint of celery. It is at its best in late autumn and early winter, and goes particularly well with game and roasts, especially chicken, pork or turkey. It most often appears on the menus of French restaurants as an hors d'oeuvres - celeri remoulade - shredded raw and tossed in a mustard-flavored mayonnaise.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME SPRINGTIME IN THE DEAD OF WINTER
description: ONE advantage of living in the North is that of experiencing the panorama of colors, textures and forms that are provided by the changing seasons. That this changing scene has no counterpart in the South has been a disappointment to many who move to the land of eternal summer.

title: BATTLE FATIGUE
description: Jerome Charyn, who teaches at Princeton University, is the author of ''Pinocchio's Nose.'' TIGER THE LURP DOG By Kenn Miller. 214 pp. Boston: Atlantic/Little, Brown & Co. $14.95. BLACK COCONUTS, BROWN MAGIC By Joseph Theroux. 227 pp. New York: The Dial Press/Doubleday & Co. $13.95.

title: THE JACK BENNY SHOW
description: MCA 60 minutes. $29.95

title: WASHINGTON STATE STUNS WASHINGTON
description: For the second consecutive season, Washington was upset in its final game of the season today by Washington State, 17-6, and was denied an opportunity to go to the Rose Bowl.

title: Marla Johnson Is Married
description: At St. Ignatius Loyola Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan yesterday Marla Johnson, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Warren Johnson of New York and Elberon, N.J., was married to Joseph J. Truini Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Truini of Wallingford, Conn. The Rev. Victor Yanitelli performed the ceremony.

title: MESSAGE FROM A PLAYWRIGHT HELD CAPTIVE IN HIS OWN LAND
description: Helen Dudar is a frequent contributor to Arts and Leisure.

title: BROWN TOPS COLUMBIA, 42-36
description: Penn scored 21 points in less than 6 minutes of the first half today and defeated Dartmouth, 38-14, to earn a share of the Ivy League championship with Harvard.

title: SEE THE EFFECTS OF NUCLEAR WAR. BE EMOTIONAL
description: -TV of ''The Day After,'' a movie depicting a nuclear attack on the Kansas City, Mo., area, will give many Americans a gut-level appreciation of the effects of nuclear war. Some people think this is unfortunate. John Fisher, president of the American Security Council, which advocates peace through a strong defense, stated: ''By showing nuclear war and how terrible it is, you repeat the only argument the nuclear freezers have. People get very emotional about that, and whoever is best organized will capitalize on that emotion.''

title: RULING ON HOSPITALS FACING CHALLENGE
description: THE Connecticut Hospital Association will file suit this week in Superior Court in Hartford challenging a State Department of Mental Health ruling that the department is not obligated to accept all mentally ill patients referred by the state's 36 general hospitals.

title: Off-Duty Officer Is Wounded In Struggle in a Queens Alley
description: An off-duty police officer was shot last night during a struggle with two men in a Queens alley, the police said.

title: RATES CALL THE TUNE FOR MARKET
description: the price of money - so dominate the investment psyche these days that stocks and even some commodities seem almost helpless to move on their own. Look to money and bond rates, says the new orthodoxy, for that's the way to financial success. And what determines interest rates? Why, the Federal Reserve Board, of course, the subject of microscopic scrutiny by more high-paid analysts than ever studied the Kremlin elite at a May Day parade.

title: THE WRIGHT STUFF
description: DIANE ACKERMAN is a writer and licensed pilot. Her third poetry collection, just published, is ''Lady Faustus'' (Morrow).

title: FROM UNKRAIN TO UNIONDALE
description: OF all the games Mike Lashchev will play in his life, none of them will have the drama of that day in Lvov, Soviet Union, when he and his wife had to convince the court they no longer wanted to be married.

title: SINKING FIELD AT ISSUE
description: WHEN the new Norwalk High School was opened in 1971, it was cited by the American Institute of Architects as an outstanding example of institutional architecture.

title: Oilers Rout the Devils by 13-4
description: Jari Kurri scored five goals and Wayne Gretzky had three goals and five assists tonight to lead the Edmonton Oilers to a 13-4 victory over the New Jersey Devils.

title:
GARDENING;
SOME SPRINGTIME IN THE DEAD OF WINTER
description: ONE advantage of living in the North is that of experiencing the panorama of colors, textures and forms that are provided by the changing seasons. That this changing scene has no counterpart in the South has been a disappointment to many who move to the land of eternal summer.

title: A SELECT LIST OF LONDON'S SMALLER HOTELS
description: DONALD GODDARD, who lives in London, is working on his sixth book, the true story of one man's race against the Germans for perhaps the single richest prize of World War II (to be published by Times Books).

title: TONGUE-TIED LINGUIST
description: RATES OF EXCHANGE

title: Rosie Ruiz Arrested
description: Times have not been rosy for Rosie Ruiz , the bogus distance runner who created a flap after the Boston Marathon in 1980. Miss Ruiz finished first in the race but was stripped of her title after race officials proved she had cheated by jumping into the race about a mile before the finish.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: KATHLEEN KENNEDY

title: IS U.S. HIGH TECH MOVING FAST ENOUGH?
description: IN 1935, the British realized that

title: SALES-TAX INCOME UP IN CONNECTICUT
description: Revenues from the state sales tax were 24 percent higher in September than for the same month last year, and a top state budget official said he expected revenues from the tax to continue rising through the end of the year.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN ALBUQUERQUE
description: With the closing of the New Mexico State Fair in September, Albuquerque's brief, annual recollection of its Old West attachment (more or less forgotten since the city became part of the ''Sun Belt'') has ended; the Stetsons and the Tony Lama boots have been stuffed in the closet for another year, and the calf ropers, barrel racers and bronc riders have ''gone on down the road.'' October's International Balloon Fiesta (there were 430 entrants this year in the biggest- ever display of the rising, drifting beauties) is a thing of the past, too. Albuquerque is ready to settle into that special semisomnolence in which it becomes more quietly Indian and Spanish than any other Southwestern metropolis - at least so Albuquerqueans confidently believe. Even the mild hustle and bustle of the holiday season has a particularly Latino and Native American atmosphere in the 375-year-old Duke City and environs.

title: THE CO-OP AND HOW IT WORKS
description: THE crafts cooperative, a proven marketing concept, has found a profitable direction in temporary holiday shops set up in high-traffic commercial areas.

title: ISLANDERS DEFEAT CAPITALS
description: Butch Goring is a specialist these days, playing in a position that can't be found in the National Hockey League guidebook. He is 34 years old in a sport dominated by players a decade younger, and only a little bit of work comes his way now.

title: EXPRESSWAY AGENCY IN JERSEY TO SHARE PORTION OF REVENUES
description: The Atlantic City Expressway Authority, breaking its tradition of keeping toll revenues for itself, has agreed to contribute at least $2.5 million a year for other transportation programs in southern New Jersey.

title: QUICK AND EASY DOES IT
description: HERE IS SOMEthing warmly professional about sharing and borrowing techniques and ideas from chefs whom we have had the good fortune to invite into our kitchen. One of the most recent and enjoyable of these occasions came about when Georges Blanc, one of France's finest chefs and the owner-chef of the celebrated La Mere Blanc of Vonnas, stopped by to prepare and share a meal. The fish course of that meal consisted of thin fillets of sole, quickly moistened with water and baked in a very hot oven for scarcely more than a minute. The fillets emerged from the heat tender, succulent and ready for the table, topped with a savory seafood sauce.

title: Data Bank; November 20, 1983
LANDLORDS ARE LAX ON SMOKE DETECTORS
description: THE smoky, dank smell of a doused fire

title: GERMANS ON BOTH SIDES ARE WARY OF ALLIES' ARMS
description: EAST BERLIN TOMORROW, when the Bonn Parliament debates the deployment of American medium-range missiles in West Germany, the 70 percent of East Germany's population that watches West German television will be in a position to draw some uncomfortable parallels. The Soviet Union has promised to match the NATO action by placing its own new nuclear missiles in East Germany and Czechoslovakia. As with the deployment in the West, Moscow's announcements have spread anxiety and alarm.

title: CYPRIOTS DEBATE U.S. USE OF BASE FOR BEIRUT FORCE
description: The United States is using Cyprus's largest civilian airport to supply American troops in Lebanon, prompting opposition within the Cypriot Government.

title: Letting Go
description: To the Editor:

title: MUSIC: WAVERLY CONSORT
description: Jean-Philippe Rameau is that rarest of birds - a truly underrated great composer. Rameau's daring harmonies often prefigure Debussy, his dramatic sense is irrepressibly vivid, and he left behind a sizable quantity of material, including at least 25 substantial theater works.

title: 2 MISSING IN IOWA EXPLOSION
description: Tons of dynamite stored in a concrete bunker exploded today, leaving a giant crater and causing shock waves felt 10 miles away.

title: ALBECK'S REUNION SPOILED AS NETS LOSE
description: Stan Albeck returned to the place of his former triumphs, the HemisFair Arena, where he led the San Antonio Spurs to three consecutive Midwest Division titles. And although the fans treated him relatively well, his former players didn't.

title: ELIE WIESEL: BEARING WITNESS
A HEART TOO MANY
description: One of the oddest set of circumstances ever to bedevil a deal in an international championship occurred earlier this year. And it happened almost at the end of a close final match, with the impending swing on the deal due to decide the title.

title: Abdul-Jabbar Hits 30,000
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar sank a pair of free throws in the third quarter of the Los Angeles Lakers' 117-110 victory over the Portland Trail Blazerstonight to become the second player in National Basketball Association history to score 30,000 points.

title: DRIVING CANADA'S FASTEST-MOVING BANK
description: TORONTO WILLIAM D. Mulholland often talks wistfully about his boyhood dream of becoming a fireman - and when he does, he affects a folksy, personal manner. ''I guess I'm really a marshmallow,'' he says with a smile.

title: ; ELIE WIESEL: BEARING WITNESS
description: Why do Elie Wiesel's critics fear to speak out publicly, when they would probably think nothing of openly voicing an opinion on most other subjects? (''Bearing Witness: The Life and Work of Elie Wiesel,'' by Samuel G. Freedman, Oct. 23.) Is his cult of personality so strong that it silences those well qualified to speak on the subject? Not everyone experienced the Holocaust, but those who did not should not be made to feel that they cannot speak to the issue.

title: Article 054601 -- No Title
description: The constantly rising Great Salt Lake could cause $480 million damage if the water level climbs three feet more by spring, according to a Utah state study.

title: 2 SHOPS FOR HANDMADE GOODS
description: ''We help others to help themselves'' is the motto of the Scarsdale Woman's Exchange, a shop established in 1931 as a marketplace for homemade food items to enable local families to earn income during the depression.

title: EAST END PRIZE: RADIO LICENSE
description: WHEN Philip J. Kenter petitioned the Federal Communications Commission several years ago to assign East Hampton its first FM radio channel, it was the starting signal for a snail-paced race that is still in progress and promises to go on for several more years. The prize is a license to operate the new station allocated to East Hampton by the F.C.C. in 1981, and its pursuit has pitted Mr. Kenter against three competitors, all apparently as eager as he is to operate the station at 96.7 on the FM band.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS
description: -cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.

title: Future Events
description: Tickets to the following may be obtained from the beneficiaries unless otherwise indicated. .

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWSChanging Hearts
description: He was 19 years old and a high school athlete - basketball, baseball, football - until his junior year. Doctors told him he had a degenerative heart disease that in time would make the organ useless.

title: PORTRAIT PHOTOGRAPHER EXAMINED
description: APORTRAIT photographer's success depends very much on the fame of the subjects depicted. So a reputation as

title: Jane I. Walker Is to Marry Dean Craig Sperry in June
description: Announcement has been made by Dr. and Mrs. Granville Walker of New Canaan, Conn., of the engagement of their daughter, Jane Inman Walker, to Dean Craig Sperry, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Sperry of Cornwall, Vt.

title: TURKISH CYPRIOTS MAKE THE BREAK
description: Nine years ago, backed by Turkish troops who had just seized the northern third of Cyprus, Rauf Denktash threatened to set up an independent Turkish Cypriot state if the Greek majority on the island did not accept a more equitable political arrangement. Last week, with the situation essentially unchanged from 1974, the Turkish Cypriot leader made good his threat.

title: HUNTERDON CENTRAL ADVANCES, 10-7
description: Tom Bill completed a 4-yard touchdown pass to John Bredeson early in the fourth quarter to propel Hunterdon Central of Flemington past Woodbridge, 10-7, in the first round of the Central Jersey, Group 4 playoffs yesterday in Woodbridge.

title: ELIE WIESEL: BEARING WITNESS
POP MUSIC SURGES ALONG NEW AND UNEXPECTED PATHS
description: As the rock generation approaches middle age, it has become the pop cultural establishment. The old intergenerational battles that pitted rock hipness against pop squareness - the Beatles and the Rolling Stones against Frank Sinatra - have receded into the past.

title: PLEA SAYS DEATH ROW INMATE DIDN'T KILL CHILDREN
description: Newly discovered evidence strongly suggests that a man scheduled to be executed Dec. 7 in Arizona for murdering his two baby daughters may not be guilty, according to a petition filed by the man's attorneys and an article to be published in a legal magazine next week.

title: CENSUS BUREAU FIGHTING PLAN TO SHARE ITS PERSONAL DATA
description: The Reagan Administration has drafted a plan requiring the Census Bureau to share the personal information it collects about the American people with a number of Government agencies.

title: ROCK: GENESIS AT THE GARDEN
description: Under the leadership of Phil Collins, the 1970's art-rock group Genesis has reached new heights of popularity. At the same time, Genesis, which is now a trio augmented for touring purposes by a guitarist and a drummer, has turned away from turgid pop allegories toward a simpler, more skeletal rock style.

title: U.S. BILL CALLED SPUR TO HOUSING IN NEW YORK AREA
description: The $15.6 billion housing bill passed by Congress Friday could finance the construction and rehabilitation of thousands of apartments for low- and middleincome people in the New York metropolitan area, according to lawmakers and local officials.

title: MARCOS ATTACKS BUSINESSMEN
description: There's nothing like a list of political demands to fray the nerves of supreme authority. ''I have reached the end of my patience,'' Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos declared last week after a business group called for elections and related measures to calm the crisis set off by the Aug. 21 murder of opposition leader Benigno S. Aquino Jr. Mr. Marcos, contending that ''economic saboteurs'' were costing the Government tens of millions of dollars of revenue, brought criminal charges against 33 leading members of the organization, the Filipino Business Conference.

title: '73 POLICE REPORT SAYS WARD DIDN'T RELEASE 16 AT MOSQUE
description: An internal Police Department report, prepared in 1973 and just made public, says the decision to release up to 16 witnesses and possible suspects in the slaying of a police officer 11 years ago was made by the chief of detectives at the time, and not by Benjamin Ward, who was a deputy commissioner in charge of community affairs.

title: Peter Fraiman and Alison Davies Wed
description: Alison Patricia Davies, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward J. Davies of San Francisco and Wrexham, Wales, was married yesterday to Peter Guy Fraiman, son of Justice Arnold Guy Fraiman of New York State Supreme Court and Mrs. Fraiman of New York and Norfolk, Conn. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony in the chapel at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan.

title: Stamford Catholic Wins
description: Last week's loss to Greenwich for the Eastern Division championship of the Fairfield County Interscholastic Athletic Conference was a blow to Stamford Catholic, previously 7-0. But yesterday there was some consolation as the Crusaders beat Stamford, 41-6, and took its third straight city championship. Catholic, who beat Stamford in last year's city title game, was scoreless in the first quarter, but scored 20 points by halftime.

title: THANKSGIVING LESSON
description: MY 7-year-old daughter has just explained to me the story of the first Thanksgiving. I listened intently as she expounded upon the sailing of the Mayflower, the exchanges between Pilgrims and Indians, the struggles to build a life in America, the first harvest and, ultimately, the joyous celebration to give thanks for all that the Pilgrims had found and built for themselves in their new home. With great insight and understanding, my daughter recaptured an important chapter in American history.

title: WHITE HOUSE PLANS TO HONOR SOME LEADING HIGH SCHOOLS
description: The Reagan Administration is spending $820,000 to honor some of the nation's top public and private high schools, but the schools themselves will not get a penny.

title: FAVORITE DRINKS OF THE COLONISTS
description: TODAY, perhaps in an unconscious tribute to the comforts of central heating, drinks cooled by ice cubes are served year round.

title: ETHICS REPORTS
description: The House ethics committee closed out its pursuit of impropriety, delivering itself of the opinion that on the whole Congress acquits itself well.

title: DOCTOR AS 'CAPTAIN': OTHER VIEWS
description: Phyllis Bernstein, author of the article ''For a Young Cardiologist, an Essential Rx is Compassion,'' is to be commended for emphasizing the importance of the humanistic aspect of medical care. However, Dr. De Junco's reported statement that he feels almost like the ''captain of the ship'' generates concern from both a legal and philosophical viewpoint.

title: No Headline
description: Amy Nachtigall to Wed

title: TWO VISIONS OF THE SOUTH FORK
description: ANATIVE son whose ancestors were among its early settlers, Everett T. Rattray, the late editor and publisher of The East Hampton Star, created his South Fork with words. City-born and bred, Robert Giard, the photographer who has lived in eastern Long Island since 1974, uses images.

title: EX-WORKERS SUE COMPANY
description: THE debate in Connecticut over plant closings took a new twist last week, when 13 former employees of the Armstrong Rubber Company filed a $200 million Federal lawsuit seeking retirement benefits they say the company owes them.

title: Surgeon Engaged To Miss Thomas
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lowell S. Thomas Jr. of Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and Little Deer Isle, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Megan Evans Thomas, to Dr. Robert Martin Olson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl M. Olson of Meadowbrook, Pa. The wedding is planned for Dec. 30.

title: ILLINI FIRST 9-0 BIG TEN TEAM
description: Jack Trudeau passed for four touchdowns, twice to Tim Brewster, and Thomas Rooks scored two touchdowns to lead Rose Bowl-bound Illinois to a 56-24 victory today over Northwestern. The victory gave Illinois (10-1) its first Big Ten Conference title in 20 years.

title: RUSSIA'S CUBO-FUTURISTS CREATED A STARTLING 'OPERA'
description: Harlow Robinson teaches in the Department of Slavic Languages at SUNY-Albany.

title: THE SCENE BEFORE THE GAME
description: NEW HAVEN FOR most, The Game did not

title: STRATEGIES FOR THE SOPHISTICATED
description: STOCK market technicians were once considered the eggheads of Wall Street. But no more. Those individuals who fill their offices with arcane graphs and trend lines, surround themselves with computer printouts and talk of advance-decline ratios, uptick-downtick volume and high-low differentials have come into their own. They've gotten respect, primarily because their record in recent years for predicting turns in the market - especially the August 1982 bull market - has been superb. Currently, there is hardly a brokerage house without at least a modest staff of these number-crunching wizards.

title: MAGIC, MYTH AND MORALS
description: AFRICAN FOLKTALES

title: INSTITUTE AIDS RETIRED PEOPLE
description: THE Institute for Retired Professionals, a new cooperative venture between Fairfield University and the Town of Fairfield's Department on Aging, has provided a group of retirees with an opportunity to learn from each other as well as from the faculty at the university.

title: NO MORE HUSH-UP DISASTERS
description: Any company can deal with success. The challenge lies in dealing with disaster. And when disaster strikes, public relations executives are counseling their clients to be as forthright as possible.

title: PINPOINTING NASSAU'S BUDGET FIGURES
description: SIX of the Big Eight wanted the job. The one that was chosen is to be paid approximately $85,000 a year. The Nassau County Comptroller says it is a job that has ''no real purpose.''

title: ANXIETIES OVER THE DEFICIT YIELD TO ELECTION WORRIES
description: Last January, President Reagan's budget proposal for the 1984 fiscal year, with its modest defense spending cuts and its proposal for standby tax increases, was described by aides as a ''ticket to the dance.'' Further concessions by Congressional Republicans and Democrats, they said, could lead to a felicitous bipartisan solution to the $200 billion Federal deficits that stretched into the indefinite future.

title: SYRACUSE UPSETS WEST VA.
description: Harold Gayden ran for two touchdowns to lead Syracuse to a 27-16 upset victory over West Virgina today.

title: The Stock Market Outlook: Quick Jumps, Quick Drops
description: THE easy money has been made in the stock market, most agree. The investor today, unlike at the bullmarket's burth in August 1982, cannot blindly buy shares and blithely watch them rise in value. Rather, selectivity is demanded.

title: DIVERSITY OF MUTUAL FUNDS REQUIRES BUYER SELECTIVITY
description: SINCE the market boom began in August 1982, it has taken diligent work to find a stock mutual fund that performed poorly. Mutual funds investing in stocks had an average total return of more than 56 percent from the start of the rally through early November. The best have risen more than 110 percent. In the same period, the Dow Jones average rose 58 percent.

title: No Headline
description: Dorothy Arasi Is Wed

title: COMPANIES IN SEARCH OF BIONIC MAN
description: AWOMAN whose job was final inspection grabbed something resembling a bracket for wall
