title: ISRAEL SEES NO QUICK CURE FOR LEBANON-- OR ANY OTHER ILLS
description: Israel paused last week to remember its first Prime Minister, David Ben Gurion, and more heroic days. ''Now

title: REGULATION AND THE ECONOMIST
description: THE Environmental Protection Agency recently proposed a regulation for arsenic emissions in the city of Tacoma, Wash., that would risk as many as two deaths for each 100 people exposed to the pollutant, according to the agency's estimates. William D. Ruckelshaus, the agency's administrator, acknowledged that arsenic emissions from the plant, a copper smelter outside Tacoma, could be further reduced, but warned that the cost of such controls could be so high that the smelter might be forced to close, depriving Tacoma of jobs and income.

title: S.M.U. BEATS ARKANSAS, 17-0
description: Reggie Dupard's two touchdowns led Southern Methodist to a 17-0 Southwest Conference victory over Arkansas today. The shutout was the first against Arkansas since the 1973 opening game, when Southern California won by 17-0 - a streak of 125 games.

title: CITY IN KANSAS TALKS OF DEPICTION OF ITS DEATH
description: The day before ''The Day After,'' the television movie depicting a nuclear attack and its aftermath here, residents and visitors confronted one another and the movie.

title: WHAT'S NEW IN CORPORATE IMAGE-MAKING
description: Beyond the hiring of a public relations firm, many companies appear uncomfortable talking about what they do to make themselves or their executives look better.

title: Susan B. Miller and Michael Reuben, Lawyers, Are Engaged to Marry Jan. 7
description: Susan Barbara Miller, an associate with the New York law firm of Patterson, Belknap, Webb & Tyler, plans to be married in New York Jan. 7 to Michael Barrett Reuben, an associate with Kramer, Levin, Nessen, Kamin & Frankel, also New York lawyers.

title: TROUPE OFFERS YOUTH NEW LIVES VIA ART
description: PATERSON AFTER a decade of good times and bad, the Inner City Ensemble Theater and Dance Company here, a performing-arts training program for talented urban youths, has emerged as one of the nonprofit art world's most solid success stories.

title: AN ANTI-DETERRENT FILM
description: The emotional shock to the public of a look at life after a nuclear exchange could have lasting political consequences. It is conceivable that tonight's movie - as well as other doomsday messages - could spur a great popular movement aimed at eliminating all nuclear weapons. But by undermining the credibility of our nuclear deterrent, such a movement could increase the likelihood of a nuclear exchange.

title: AND BEAR IN MIND
description: The listings above are based on computer-processed sales figures from about 2,000 bookstores in every region of the United States. And Bear in Mind

title: BREAKUP OF BLACK FAMILY IMPERILS GAINS OF DECADES
description: At the height of the civil rights movement in 1965, when a quarter of black families with children were headed by women, Daniel Patrick Moynihan wrote in a report to President Johnson that this growing matriarchy was an important cause of poverty among black Americans. Mr. Moynihan, then a White House aide, created a furor, accused by many of blaming the victims for their distress.

title: STATE NEEDS A DISTRIBUTION CENTER FOR FOOD
description: WHEN the metropolitan consumer slices a New Jersey tomato, he or she probably does not realize the ordeal that the vine-ripened fruit has just been through.

title: LIVE, DIE: MOOT POINT
description: After watching ''The Day After,'' many Americans will wonder whether it would be better to perish in a nuclear blast than to survive. But some scientists, in both America and the Soviet Union, now believe this question is moot: They say that nobody will long survive an all-out exchange.

title: GLENN DECIDES TO ESCALATE
description: John Glenn believes in carrying a big stick, but apparently not in speaking softly. Addressing the Coalition for a Democratic Majority, a group of defense-minded party conservatives, the Ohio Senator last week noted that in the Senate Walter F. Mondale had voted against the B-1 bomber, several nuclear-powered aircraft carriers and the development of the Trident submarine and cruise missile (both of which the former Vice President now supports).

title: 4 KILLED AS TRAINS COLLIDEIN TEXAS
description: Four railroad crewmen were killed and another was severely injured today when the tanker train they were in rammed into the back of a parked freight train shortly before dawn near a residential neighborhood here.

title: Afghanistan
description: To the Editor: William Finnegan's ''Tongue-Tied in the Bazaar'' (Travel, Oct 23) is all too true, includ

title: OUTDOORSNelson Bryant ONE might postulate that the ever- growing desire of many Americans to own a hand-crafted knife is nothing more than a romantic yearning for the past or a Walter Mitty-type syndrome, if a fighting blade is purchased, in which one imagines oneself another Jim Bowie.
description: There may be a little of the above involved, but the basic motivation comes from a hunger to own something of quality, something built by a skilled artisan, that also functions superbly.

title:
CAMERA;
FOR THE BEST RESULTS WHEN PHOTOGRAPHING CHILDREN
description: Don Langer is a freelance writer and instructor in photography.

title: FOR ELDERLY, A NEW WAY TO SHARE
description: They like the same songs, ''I Can't Get Started'' and ''Star Dust.'' They sit glued to the television set watching the treachery on ''Dynasty'' and ''Dallas'' and howling at Benny Hill's antics. While she plays solitaire at the dining-room table, he reads.

title: MEN SAID TO KEEP HEALTH LONGER
description: Women may live longer but men's health is better for a larger percentage of their life, doctors report in a new study focusing on quality of life rather than longevity.

title: Mayer Beats Lendl
description: Gene Mayer survived 18 aces and beat Ivan Lendl, 7-5, 4-6, 6-3, in the semifinals of the $750,000 European Champions tennis tournament today.

title: Dissidents Pick Candidate
description: Dissident members of the United Steelworkers of America, unhappy with recent contract concessions, chose Ron Weisen today as their presidential candidate. Mr. Weisen, a 48-year-old Pennsylvania welder, pledged to rebuild the union from the ground up. His opponents on March 29 are expected to be Lynn Williams, 59, the interim president, and Joseph Odorcich, 67, a vice president.

title: DUMPING IN SOUND STIRS NEW CONCERN
description: IN announcing plans to dump

title: FOLLOW-UP ON THE NEWS
description: An eye-catching punishment for drunken driving was started two months ago by a judge in Texas. He ordered an offender to carry a bumper sticker on his car, saying:

title: NAUTICAL THEMES IN THE CUBIST VEIN
description: ONE of the most dedicated, forceful and inventive American exponents of synthetic Cubism was Stuart Davis, who returned home from Paris in the 1920's with the basis of a Cubist pictorial language that he contined to refine for some 40 years. From the raw material provided by a study of Braque and Leger, he developed an intensely personal creative vision based on observation of the real world but shaped by subjective and theoretical concepts that transformed what was seen, heard and felt into abstract line, shape, color and rhythm.

title: SPARE PARTS FOR ARMS CAN COST AN ARM AND A LEG
description: A recent Pentagon investigation of spare-parts horror stories showed that the Air Force paid more than $1.4 million early this year for an order of jet engine spares for which the manufacturer had charged only about $530,000. Two commercial firms higher in the Government contracting chain had added almost a million dollars in markups. ''All they did,'' said a middle- level Pentagon official who asked to remain anonymous, ''was place an order for the Air Force; they performed no real function.'' Moreover, there is little likelihood that even the original manufacturer's price was realistic, according to this manager. Not all officials insist on anonymity. A. Ernest Fitzgerald, a high- ranking civil servant and famous whistleblower in the Air Force, said that recent scandals about grossly inflated spare-part prices had been valuable because they involved simple items about which common-sensical members of the public, or Congress, could not be fooled. A $269 wrench, three inches long, or a $900 plastic cup to place under the leg of a flight navigator's stool are obviously absurd, he said. ''The horrible truth, however, is that everything is priced about the same way,'' he said. ''The rip-off of taxpayers on the big items - weapons, engines, aircraft - is as bad as on spares.'' In interviews, five experienced Defense Department auditors expressed the belief that it would be possible to save as much as half of the $84.4 billion set aside in the next Defense budget for procurement, plus more money on other parts of the total $247 billion military spending bill.

title: PSST, HOW ABOUT A GOOD LITTLE MOVIE
description: Do you you feel not up to being overwhelmed? Would you like to save the ''don't-miss'' movie of the year until someone else insists that you see it? Are you looking for a film that won't knock your socks off, leave you devastated or explode in your face? Do you sometimes suspect that you simply aren't good enough for most of the movies that are available?

title: IF SURROGATE PARENTHOOD IS THE CHOICE
description: ''IWOULD like to help an infertile couple to have a child,'' said Cheryl Evans, a 22- year-old Long Island homemaker with two children, age 1 and 4. ''I feel it would be a really nice thing to do. I could use the money, but it's not the main reason why I want to do it.''

title: Don't Overlook Yale
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: COLLECTOR'S LEGACY: A LIVING PAST
description: THANKSGIVING came early for members of the Indian and Colonial Research Center in Old Mystic. Yesterday, 90 of them gathered at the Old Mystic Methodist Church to sip cider and feast on a traditional turkey dinner finished off with Indian pudding.

title: STEEL HAS WON A PLACE IN SCULPTURE
description: Steel, the underpinning of our industrial age, is a 20th-century newcomer to the repertory of artists' materials. Stone, bronze and wood were the time-honored sculptural basics - that is, until the Spaniard Julio Gonzalez began welding iron in the 1920's, making ''direct metal'' sculpture without the cumbersome casting process of bronze, and later helping Picasso to do the same. Gonzalez wanted a new identity for iron, which he felt had been regarded as ''a murderer or the mere instrument of overmechanized science.'' The way was clear, he said, for it ''to be forged and hammered by the peaceful hands of an artist.'' In this country, David Smith, who - inspired by Picasso - began to weld and bolt steel in the 1930's, became its chief promoter. ''It is structure, movement, progress, suspension, cantilever and at times destruction and brutality,'' he wrote. And today, this macho material is a sculptor's staple, the first industrial substance to be established as a medium for three-dimensional art.

title: RECIPE FOR AN AMERICAN NATIONAL THEATER
description: Imagine it. On the main stage Jason Robards Jr. is giving

title: MURDER CHARGE AGAINST TUFTS PROFESSOR ROCKS MEDICAL SCHOOL
description: In downtown Boston, history, lust, learning and entertainment all have their place. A few blocks south of where the Colonial fathers lie under crooked tombstones, the Tufts University School of Medicine and the city's theater district meet another zone, one usually marked in red on tourist maps as the Combat Zone.

title: BESTSELLERS
description: 113 PET SEMATARY, by Stephen King. (Doubleday, $15.95.) The new family in town discovers the horrors that lie in a neighboring cemetery. 2212 POLAND, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $17.95.) Seven centuries of history in fictional form. 3422 THE NAME OF THE ROSE, by Umberto Eco. (Helen & Kurt Wolff/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $15.95.) Unraveling the mystery of a murder in a 14th-century Italian monastery. 4311

title: HOUSES ALONG CANAL NETWORK
description: Like other Hudson River towns working hard to rebuild, Jersey City has looked to its waterfront as prime territory for new development.

title: Dorset
description: To the Editor: Reading the article by A. L. Rowse, ''A Historian's Tribute to Pastoral Dorset'' (Travel, Oct. 23), made me want to pack my bags and set out for England. For me there are few places as strongly evocative of particular literary passages as the area around Dorchester.

title: TESTING THE LIMITS OF EXPLICTNESS
description: Sex, along with violence, has always been a key staple of popular entertainment. Generally, though, there have been limits on its explicitness. But in the past decade or so of expanding permissiveness those limits have been broadened considerably and in some instances obliterated. One of the more fascinating current pastimes is watching how far television, especially cable TV, can go in increasing sexual explicitness.

title: SOLAR OFFICES
description: No longer considered a pioneering design concept for housing, elements of passive solar orientation are now being used in the planning of some office buildings. Among them are those in East Ridge Executive Center, an office park at Exit 8 on Interstate 84 in Danbury, Conn.

title: TEST TRANSMITTER SIGNALS U.S. CRAFT
description: The Navy is using an experimental high-powered, low-frequency radio transmitter to keep in touch with its submarine fleet while the craft are deeply submerged, even under the thick North Pole ice cap.

title: ECONOMY IS ONESURE THEME, BUT WHO WILL IT WORK FOR?
description: Members of the House and Senate tore through the business of legislating last week to get home and get down to the business that will preoccupy most of them until Nov. 6, 1984 - campaigning for their own re-election and the election of others in their own party. Representatives Tony Coelho of California and Guy Vander Jagt of Michigan are chairmen, respectively, of the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee and the National Republican Congressional Committee, which provide advice and money to candidates for the House. They talked about 1984 with Caroline Rand Herron, an editor of The Week in Review, and Steven V. Roberts, a reporter in the Washington Bureau of The New York Times. Excerpts follow.

title: CONSUMER RATES
THE HEAT THAT DRIES THE LAUNDRY CAN HELP CUT ENERGY COSTS
description: WASHING machines, clothes dryers and similar appliances all add to the annual cost of the energy needed to run a house, so it makes good sense to do whatever you can to cut down on the expense of operating these appliances.

title: CANTONLIKE
description: ''I reckon it is an attempt to really partition Lebanon,'' said an adviser to Druse chieftain Walid Jumblat, ''on a cantonlike basis.''

title: CONCERT: NEW MUSIC ON THE ROAD
description: The New York State Council on the Arts has had the nice idea to send new music out on the road; and since early this month, a caravan of performers and composers has been touring the cities of Buffalo, Rochester, Ithaca, Syracuse and Albany.

title: AT SPANISH PAPER, ACCENT IS ON VIEWS
description: UNION CITY WHEN Eden Pastora Gomez, leader of the 1979 Nicaraguan revolution, held his first news conference in the United States earlier this month, only one reporter was granted an exclusive interview.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: UPPER WEST SIDE
description: WHEN urban renewal began on Manhattan's Upper West Side, Austin Haldenstein, the real-estate broker, recalled the other day, 11 brownstone houses were put up for sale. ''We couldn't move them for $25,000 or $35,000,'' he said.

title: BEN CROSS REFUSES TO BE TYPED AFTER 'CHARIOTS OF FIRE'
description: Ben Cross was leaving the Palm Court of the Plaza Hotel the other day when a man at a nearby table stopped him. ''Say, aren't you that guy from 'Chariots of Fire?''' he asked. ''Aren't you Ben Cross?'' The actor grimaced, shifted uneasily from foot to foot, and finally said yes. Then he pulled a cigarette from his pocket and deliberately lit it in front of the man.

title: DETERMINING HOW MUCH FORCE IS TOO MUCH
description: -year-old Brooklyn man was arrested for scrawling graffiti on the wall of a subway station. At 3:22 A.M., he was admitted to Bellevue Hospital Center in a coma. What happened to Michael Jerome Stewart in the intervening 32 minutes is a mystery that remains unresolved.

title: FREE AND CLEAR
description: A man scorned can muster formidable fury, according to the lawyers who defended Ginny Foat in an 18-year-old Louisiana murder case.

title: 'LOOKS GOOD ON A RESUME'-BUT IS THAT THE POINT?
description: THERE'S been much written in the last few years about my generation's preoccupation with postgraduate job prospects, getting into the ''right'' graduate schools - in short, with earning a lot of money. Unlike the 60's, when college students scared ''the Establishment'' with their long hair and different styles of dress, we now scare one another with increased competitiveness, both for grades and jobs.

title: JERSEY TO REWARD THE GOOD DRIVERS
description: Insurance Commissioner Joseph F. Murphy has approved a new auto insurance rate system under which thousands of good drivers who are now being charged the highest premiums in the state will pay up to $1,193 a year less.

title: NEW APPROACHES TRANSFIGURE OLD MUSIC
description: Concert life today begins with the music. We decide what we want to hear and how, and then we create an occasion that will fit. The Baroque did things the other way around. Then it was the occasion that ruled, and music was shaped, adapted, often bent, even disfigured, in order to serve the needs of the moment.

title: CONGRESS LEAVES A REPRESENTATEIVE WEEK BEHIND
description: Though the record of the 98th Congress's first session was gratifying, President Reagan said yesterday, everything ''was not all roses.'' Gratifying was also a word House and Senate leaders used, as Congress went home for a two-month vacation last week. But they weren't throwing any bouquets either.

title: BALLERINA: LYNN SEYMOUR
description: Mastervision 60 minutes. $59.95

title: REVENUES SOARING AT JERSEY CASINOS
description: Casino profits in the third quarter here more than doubled over the same period in 1982, bringing the industry's net for the first nine months of 1983 to nearly triple that for the comparable period last year.

title: IOWA DEMONSTRATES VOTE TO HOLD CAUCUSES EARLY
description: Iowa Democrats voted today to defy the party's national leaders and hold the state's precinct caucuses on Feb. 20.

title: EVENT TO MARK 20TH YEAR OF BEATLEMANIA
description: ''IF you say John, Paul, George or Ringo, everyone in the world knows who you mean,'' Charles Rosenay said. ''Nothing ever matched the media coverage they got. If their name was on a fork, the fork would sell. It's never been like that since.''

title: STATE DEPT. ALTERS THE RULES FOR RUSSIANS' TRAVEL IN U.S.
description: Where Russians may go, page 16.

title: F.D.A. Renews Its Warning Against Eating Brie Cheese
description: The Food and Drug Administration renewed its warning today against eating Marcillat brand brie and other soft cheeses, saying nine new cases of severe diarrhea and cramps had been reported by people who ate the cheese in Wisconsin.

title: BREWSTER BUS FARE EXPECTED TO RISE
description: MUCH confusion has surrounded the overnight changeover in service under which Mount Kisco Bus Lines assumed operation of a commuter bus line formerly run by the Walters Transit Company, but one issue is becoming clear: fares are expected to rise soon.

title: Michele Seltzer Betrothed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abe Seltzer of Purchase, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michele Seltzer, to David Seth Breslin, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Breslin of East Windsor, N.J.

title: LIBRARIES LENDING CASSETTES
description: THE next time you stop in the local library to borrow a favorite novel, you may walk out with the book under one arm and the movie based on that book under the other.

title: ARAFAT STRUGGLES TO HANG ON IN TRIPOLI
description: Reconciliation may be the avowed goal of its leaders, but it was mayhem that prevailed throughout Lebanon last week.

title: TELEVISIONDOS AND DON'TS
description: Don't wear a checkered suit. You'll look fat, and the lines in the cloth will appear to undulate on the television screen.

title: IF ROBERT FORST HAD AND APPLE...
description: WHENEVER I SHOW off my word processor to writers who don't own one, they're pretty impressed with it, particularly the fiction function that can adjust a full-length work from indicative to subjunctive in one second, or shift the point of view, or substitute one set of symbols for another, all with the flick of a finger. It's a CPR-66, and in the imaginative-prose field, it's state of the art.

title: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 20, 1983;  International
description: Rival P.L.O. factions battled for the Beddawi refugee camp in Tripoli. In a counter-attack that began Friday, guerrillas loyal to Yasir Arafat, the Palestine Liberation Organization leader, have been firing barrages of rockets and mortars from several places in the city. The rebels have been responding with the their heaviest bombardments since fighting in Tripoli began 17 days ago. (Page 1, Column 6.)

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THERE'S A HAND IN THE SKY

title: ENVIRONEWS
description: THE state's Bureau of Forest Management, part of the Department of Environmental Protection, has begun preparing for its part in the statewide survey of woodlands that the United States Forestry Service will conduct next summer.

title: BOOOAARD! FOR MODEL RAILROAD
description: UNION EVERY Wednesday at precisely 7 P.M., the headlights on a number of locomotives are switched on and the trains - both passenger and freight - slowly pull out of the station here on their way westward.

title: Miss Matthews Weds Dimitri Sevastopoulo
description: Cynthia Berkeley Matthews, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Blaine E. Matthews of Portsmouth, Ohio, was married yesterday to Dimitri Sevastopoulo, son of Mrs. Marc Sevastopoulo of New York and the late Mr. Sevastopoulo. The Very Rev. William Sutfin Schneirla of St. Mary's Eastern Orthodox Church in Brooklyn performed the ceremony at the home of the bridegroom's mother.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER
description: The confrontation at the Madrid Airport was unpleasant. An American, carrying a tote bag full of film he had used on a month's vacation, was asked by a security officer to put it through an X-ray machine. The traveler, fearing possible damage to the film in the form of fogging, asked that the bag be inspected by hand. The officer balked, the American insisted and angry words were exchanged. Finally the officer seemed to submit: He personally opened each of the traveler's two-dozen cannisters, removed the 35-millimeter film cartridges and examined them - and then hastily thrust everything back in the bag and put it through the machine anyway.

title: Penn State Ties Pitt In Confusing Finish
description: Penn State kicked a 32-yard field goal as time ran out today and tied Pittsburgh, 24-24, after Pitt had seemingly won the game with 75 seconds left and after many spectators had swept onto the field thinking it had ended.

title: EDUCATION IS TASK FOR WASTE PANEL
description: MANAGING Connecticut's hazardous wastes, says the head of a new state commission, begins with teaching people the difference between dioxin and Drano.

title: Barbara Gottlieb, Architect, to Marry a Physician
description: Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Gottlieb of Manhattan have announced the engagement of their daughter, Barbara Gottlieb, to Dr. David Mark Kaufman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert M. Kaufman of Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: Something different in the Brooklyn Academy of Music's experimental ''Next Wave'' series is promised by the fact that Wednesday's opening is by a soloist-choreographer rather than a company.

title: 13,000 Demonstrate Against Marcos at 2 Sites
description: About 13,000 people took part in two demonstrations against President Ferdinand E. Marcos today, neither of them in Manila, and the state television said the army had created a special brigade named Prompt to help preserve order in the capital.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: DR. JOHN H. MARBURGER 3D, president of the State University of New York at Stony Brook, has indicated that the Jewish community still has unresolved concerns about the university's response to the controversy over Prof. Ernest Dube's course material linking racism and Zionism. As a result, Dr. Marburger will appear tomorrow night at Temple Beth Torah in Dix Hills.

title: EASING THE IMBALANCES IN OFFICE-BUILDING ASSESSMENTS
description: THE Koch administration's altered

title: Burial Set to Recall Meeting at the Elbe
description: A World War II veteran who spent much of his life crusading for peace will be granted his dying wish: to be buried near the Elbe River in East Germany where he and other American soldiers first met advancing Soviet troops in 1945.

title: ATLANTIC CITY KEPT ON TEACHER AGENDA
description: ATLANTIC CITY SPOKESMEN for both ''camps'' believe that the New Jersey Education Association, which was squeezed for rooms during its annual convention here last weekend, will return next year.

title: OPTIMISM ON WALL STREET, BUT AMBIVALENCE AS WELL
description: AFTER a year of euphoria as the stock market soared, the mood throughout the financial markets has become one of sobriety and caution. Even as the Dow Jones industrial average rang up three consecutive new highs in early October, Wall Street remained subdued in its reaction. The feeling generally is that there are profits still to be made, but expectations are more measured, decisions less frenetic.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: In the Business of Discounting It All

title: May Bridal Is Set By Miss Tolmach And Daniel Katz
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ned Stephen Tolmach of Great Falls, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elisabeth Joy Tolmach, to Daniel Franklin Katz, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jay Katz of Woodbridge, Conn. A May wedding is planned.

title: STREET COMEDY MOVES INDOORS
description: MARC WEINER is a comedian who attributes his growing popularity at clubs around the country to the fact that he involves his audience in a grab-bag world of comedy.

title: CHURCH IN CHILE DOESN'T JUST PRAY FOR REFORM
description: As Msgr. Juan Francisco Fresno, Archbishop of Santiago, arrived to offer mass at a modest church in the Conchali neighborhood recently, the crowd broke into loud applause.

title: NEW APPROACHES LEAD TO UNUSUAL EFFECTS IN PRINT
description: ''RENAISSANCE'' is a tempting word to apply to recent trends in printmaking. Efforts to move away from convention have become particularly apparent, with less emphasis placed on the craft's discipline and more on the achievement of unusual effects.

title: Beth Ann Harlan Wed to a Lawyer
description: Beth Ann Harlan, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Benjamin M. Harlan of Dayton, Ohio, and Boca Raton, Fla., was married yesterday to Scott Warner, son of Mable Milne Hurlbutt of Salisbury, Conn., and Harry R. Warner Jr. of Amityville, L.I. Justice of the Peace Stuyvesant K. Bearns performed the ceremony at the couple's home in Salisbury.

title: ARMY TRYING OUT VIDEO WAR GAMES
description: The Army is playing video war games, not to entertain the troops but to measure how stress affects performance.

title: FROM A COMMON BED OF FEELING
description: THE MODERN POETIC SEQUENCE

title: REAGAN LAUDS CONGRESS'S RECORD DESPITE FAILURE TO REDUCE DEFICIT
description: President Reagan congratulated the departing Congress today for approving ''key reforms'' and ''bravely resisting attempts by some'' to increase spending, but he said it failed to approve ''a responsible budget to help bring down deficits.''

title: The Role of Investment Counselors
description: After investing on his own for many year, Vernon Carns, a retired marketing manager from Waco, Tex., picked Roger Engeman & Associates as his investment adviser in early 1976. The results have more than justified that decision: His initial investment of $100,000 soared to $555,000 by mid -1983.

title: AN 'OTHELLO' SET IN ANGOLA
description: ''OTHELLO, the Black of Angola,'' currently at the Arena Players Repertory Theater in East Farmingdale, is Frederic De Feis's adaptation of the Shakespeare tragedy. It is an attempt, he says, ''to interpret the relationship between Othello and Iago in psychological terms readily understood by a contemporary audience.'' Actually, Shakespeare's play, unassisted by Mr. De Feis, is quite clear.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Webster , the Pittsburgh Steeler center, was hospitalized yesterday because of a cervical inflammation, and if he misses today's game against Minnesota, it would be a first for him in his 10-year career covering 156 games. . . . The Boston Red Sox have retired the No. 4 worn by Joe Cronin, the Hall of Fame shortstop and former president of the American League. Ted Williams is the only other Red Sox player whose number has been retired. . . . The Cosmos have signed for the indoor season Gerry Grey , a midfielder who was with the now-defunct Montreal Manic and is a member of the National Team of Canada. . . Roberto Duran, who lost in his bid for an unprecedented fourth world title last week, has agreed to defend the World Boxing Association's junior-middleweight crown against No. 1-ranked Mike McCallum , but Duran's manager, Luis Spada, has asked the W.B.A. for a postponement in the 90- day period for facing McCallum because Duran needs additional time for a hand injury to heal. . . .

title: DECORATIVE ARTS OF THE 20'S
description: EXHIBITIONS of the decorative arts often seem remote. They focus on daily life, but the era or place covered is often too far off for us to identify with. But this is not the case with ''At Home in Manhattan'' at the Yale Art Gallery, which surveys modern decorative arts from 1925 to the Depression.

title: IN PRAISE O F LEVIANTHAN
description: ''They say the sea is cold, but the sea contains the hottest blood of all,'' said D. H. Lawrence in his poem ''Whales Weep Not!'' Concerned that these warmblooded leviathans are within sight of a watery Armageddon, the Canadian poet Greg Gatenby has unearthed and commissioned hundreds of pieces of lore, poetry, paintings, sculpture and music for ''WHALES: A Celebration'' (Little, Brown, $39.95 through Dec. 31; $50 thereafter), rallying them into a lavish artistic tribute to all cetacea. Variously perceived as white goddesses, black roses, emperors, all species of whale and dolphin are here honored by poets, including John Masefield, C. H. Sisson and Maxine Kumin; by writers and scientists from Plutarch to Carl Sagan; by artists like Robert Rauschenberg and Raoul Dufy (woodcut, top right), and by composers such as Leonard Bernstein, Ned Rorem and John Cage. There is a cautionary tale from Margaret Atwood, ''The Afterlife of Ishmael,'' in which Melville's sailor is visited by the god of whales and condemned to everlasting life in his small cottage overlooking a sea bereft of whales. Stanley Kunitz's contribution is ''The Wellfleet Whale,'' a haunting poem about the fate of a beached whale - ''Somebody had carved his initials in your flank. . . . The gulls had been pecking at you. The sound you made was a hoarse and fitful bleating.'' Samples from the classics reecho myths about life in the belly of the beast (from Jonah to Pinocchio), but there are true stories, too. There are also two songs composed in the shape of a whale (one by Rodion Shchedrin, bottom left) which, even if they sound no more comprehensible than the call of the right back whale when played, will be homage enough.

title: BOARD TO WEIGH O'ROURKE BUDGET PLAN
description: WHITE PLAINS HE had just presented the Board of Legislators with his first County Budget, one that proposed a 9.4 percent property-tax increase, and County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke was telling reporters how the legislators had received it.

title: ANTISUB WARFARE: SOVIET TRYING TO CATCH UP
description: MilitaryAnalysis

title: EXPRESSIONISM AT ITS ROOTS
description: It would be hard to think of an artistic term currently more overused

title: An Independent Newspaper Publishes Again in Grenada
description: For the first time in more than two years, an independent newspaper was published in Grenada today.

title: REPORTERS, ALLOWED INTO CUBA, FOUND FAMILIAR CURBS
description: The Government of Fidel Castro, conscious that the battle over Grenada was one of image as well as military might, was unusually open in allowing foreign reporters into Cuba after the invasion.

title: THE 'HOTEL KIDS' ARE FAILING SCHOOL--AND VICE VERSA
description: SLEEPING two to a bed, playing in hotel hallways, eating meals prepared on a hot plate - the bleak conditions that prevail for children in New York City's homeless families have been well documented in recent months. School officials last week added another to the list of deprivations: Many of the school-age ''hotel kids'', as they are now known to city officials, do not attend school regularly; of those who do, many are performing poorly.

title: NOT HANNAH ARENDT
description: AN ADMIRABLE WOMAN

title: SACHEM, EAST ISLIP IN FINAL
description: Sachem, a team that entered the Division I playoffs by virtue of a draw of lots, took advantage of its good fortune and defeated Half Hollow Hills East yesterday, 28-0.

title: RESIDENTIAL HOTEL RETAINS ITS STATUS
description: In recent years, as the demand for traditional rental apartments has increased, the city has seen a decline in the number of residential hotels offering long-term occupants such conveniences as maid and switchboard services. Among the holdouts was the 77-year-old Spencer Arms Hotel, at Broadway and West 69th Street.

title: ; THE DAMAGE A MUSCULAR DOLLAR INFLICTS--HERE AND ABROAD
description: To the Editor:

title:
GARDENING;
SOME SPRINGTIME IN THE DEAD OF WINTER
description: ONE advantage of living in the North is that of experiencing the panorama of colors, textures and forms that are provided by the changing seasons. That this changing scene has no counterpart in the South has been a disappointment to many who move to the land of eternal summer.

title: 'THE BIG SCORE,' CRIME AND RETRIBUTION
description: Does it sound familiar: the dedicated narcotics cop, the pushers who manage to evade punishment thanks to their repulsive lawyers, the big drug raid that ends in a wild shootout during which a million dollars disappears?

title: Votes in Congress; Last Week's Tally in Key Eastern States
description: %Senate

title: FORSYTHE TRANSPOSES LITERARY THEORIES TO THE STAGE
description: William Forsythe is on his way to France now to create a work to Gene Autry songs for the Paris Opera Ballet. In the meantime, he has left the Joffrey Ballet with a technologically and intellectually complex piece. ''Square Deal'' gave the Joffrey's New York audience something to boo about and made the heretofore expatriate American choreographer as controversial as he deserved.

title: BRISK OFFICE LEASING SURPRISES THE EXPERTS
description: ALL over commercial Manhattan, the

title: PLAN FOR MALL IN NORTH HAVEN IS FACED WITH NEW OBSTACLE
description: LAST month Mall Properties Inc., a developer from New York City, was about to claim victory in its 10-year battle to build a shopping mall, larger than any now in the state, in the small town of North Haven. This month, the company's fortunes are not so bright, and opponents of the mall are jubilant.

title: ON FLORIDA'S MERRITT ISLAND
description: ALBERTA EISEMAN is a writer who lives in Westport, Conn.

title: Co-op Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: Maurice English Dead at 74; Headed University Presses
description: Maurice English, a poet, reporter and author who recently retired as director of the University of Pennsylvania Press, died Friday at Graduate Hospital in Philadelphia after a heart attack.

title: HUNGARY CRACKS DOWN ON DISSIDENT GROUPS
description: A growing sense of nationalism appears to have bolstered Hungary's small group of dissidents, but also to have led to a Government crackdown.

title: POP: JONATHAN SCHWARTZ
description: A devoted student of the best in American pop-song literature, Jonathan Schwartz combines an unerring taste in quality songs with an encyclopedic knowledge of pre-rock music. And in his ninth engagement at Michael's Pub, where he is appearing with a quartet through Dec. 3, the singer illuminates his songs with fascinating tidbits of pop lore.

title: THE ABC'S OF 'GETTING BETER'
description: Maybe at the age of 40, getting older looms as a frightening prospect. One is just far enough this side of doddering to fear it without understanding all the implications.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: WHEN John F. Ahearne served on the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, he was sometimes viewed as a ''swing vote'' on the five-member panel, between two hard-line industry supporters and two Commissioners with a more skeptical outlook. But Dr. Ahearne's term expired at the end of June, and now, with a four-year proceeding on Indian Point drawing toward a close, attention has turned to his replacement, Frederick M. Bernthal .

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: When You Print That, Smile!

title: RAISING THE ROOF
description: Ten years ago, citing the neighborhood's pervasive blight and a decline in business, the operators of the city's West Side Airlines Terminal Building on West 42d Street closed the facility, which had served as a midtown departure point for travelers using Newark's airport.

title: THE ORACLE OF SHELTERS
description: ROBERT A. STANGER has made a killing in tax shelters - by selling information about them. Mr. Stanger was head of the tax incentive department at Merrill Lynch when he saw a need for reports on tax shelter programs and decided to go into business on his own.

title: Wagner Trounces St. John's in Playoff
description: Ed Christensen, who started the season as the fourth-string tailback, scored on runs of 73, 14 and 10 yards in leading Wagner to a 48-7 rout of St. John's yesterday in the Eastern College Athletic Conference Division III Metro New York-New Jersey playoff game.

title: KATONAH DEBATING TRUCK BYPASS SITE
description: KATONAH FOR nearly 10 years, residents in this quiet little hamlet had tried unsuccessfully to prompt state officials to do something about the heavy truck traffic on Route 117, which runs through the heart of town.

description: Mort Sahl was back in town for a brief celebration of his 30th year as an observer of the American political scene in the Bird Cage Room at Michael's Pub where his monologue was billed as ''Mort Sahl in an Extended Run or Until the News Runs Out.''

title: HOME-SALE PACTS UPSET BAR GROUPS
description: BAR associations are up in arms over a proposed broker-originated sales contract that could eliminate lawyers from most residential real- estate transactions in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and Queens. The Long Island Board of Realtors hopes to distribute the contract to its members.

title: HAS JAPAN'S AUTO INDUSTRY STALLED?
description: THE TOKYO OFFICES of the Toyota Motor Company, a senior marketing executive explains Japan's astounding industrial achievements. ''I honestly believe that everything one has to know about strategy in business is contained in this book,'' he says, holding up his own dogeared copy of Alfred P. Sloan's ''My Years With General Motors.'' The book, he adds, has provided ''all of the wherewithal'' for the success of his company, Japan's largest auto maker.

title: SCHOOLS RESPOND TO 'DAY AFTER' CAVEATS
description: -FOR-TELEVISION film has prompted teachers throughout New Jersey to review the best pedagogical approach to the sensitive subject of nuclear war in the hope of minimizing the movie's potentially devastating effect.

title: VASECTOMY STUDY REASSURES
description: Because of biological complexities and cultural proclivities, birth control for men is still rather primitive. Surgical sterilization, or vasectomy, has been the choice of about 10 million Americans.

description: An arms debate developed in a Kansas town featured in a film on atomic war. Page 26. A review of the film is in Arts and Leisure, Section 2.

title: DOLL, BLUEPRINTS AND MORE
description: ''IHAVE come to realize that I do not have the capacity to stay with something too long,'' said Robert J. Seidenberg of Hewlett Harbor. ''It starts to become old hat and it bores me.''

title: BALLET: CARACAS TROUPE
description: Venezuela's Ballet Nuevo Mundo de Caracas, directed by Zhandra Rodriguez and Dale Talley, is the successor to the Ballet Internacional de Caracas, which was seen in New York in 1979.

title: WALLS THAT ARE RICH IN DETAIL
description: IN THEIR 1897 CLASSIC MANUAL, ''THE DECOration of Houses,'' Edith Wharton and Ogden Codman Jr. wrote that ''in decorating the walls of a room, the first point to be considered is whether they are to form a background for its contents, or to be in themselves its chief decoration.'' To be sure, but sometimes both objectives can be realized together. And sometimes even the most subtle wall decoration can be a form of art in itself.

title: Tass Says Astronauts Are Preparing Return
description: Two Soviet astronauts who have been in orbit aboard the Salyut 7 space station for nearly five months will return to earth in a few days, Tass, the official Soviet press agency, said Friday.

title: Elizabeth Maury Engaged To Marry David B. Perry
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Maury of Rowayton, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Fontaine Maury, to David B. Perry, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hoyt O. Perry Jr. of Southport, Conn.

title: 'DIVA'S' DIVA IN STATE DEBUT
description: PHILADELPHIA THE movie ''Diva,'' the official French entry in the 1981 Academy Awards, has become something of a cult hit around the world. In New York City, it ran consecutively for almost two years, closing just last month.

title: 'AMITYVILLE 3-D'
description: The third in a 3-D series, as in ''Jaws 3-D'' or now ''Amityville 3-D,'' simply isn't a good idea. Once the first two films in a series have exhausted most opportunities for action, the third is liable to average half a dozen exposition scenes for every eventful episode. And 3-D exposition is the stuff of which headaches are made; the footage tends to be so dark that you can barely tell whether it's night or day. There's no reason why something like a domestic quarrel need be photographed with gloomy 3-D lighting, even if there are dishes being thrown.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The season is fast approaching for choral singing, whether it involves listening to any of the dozen or so performances of Handel's ''Messiah'' next month or joining in the singing of carols outside the concert hall. This Sunday at 3 P.M. (Nov. 20) an unusual taste of a different variety of choral music is being offered at the 92d Street Y.

title: AROUND THE GARDEN;
description: JOAN LEE FAUST This Week:

title: IMAGES OF DELHI; OLD AND NEW
description: On the elaborately inlaid marble walls of the Hall of Private Audience in the Red Fort, the walled palace compound of Old Delhi, is inscribed the famous Persian quotation: ''If there be a paradise on earth, it is here, oh! it is here, oh! it is here.'' More than 300 years ago the Peacock Throne stood in this room, under a gilded silver ceiling. It was described by a contemporary French traveler as a solid gold, jewel-encrusted platform, six by four feet, ''supported by six massy feet . . . sprinkled over with rubies, emeralds and diamonds.'' Its back was formed by two peacocks with their tails fanned out, all set with pearls and precious stones to simulate the colors and iridescence of their feathers. Twelve gold pillars held up the pearl-fringed golden canopy, ''all richly emblazoned with costly gems.'' Here the Mogul Emperor reviewed his cavalry and his fighting and ceremonial elephants and received his ministers, his nobles and foreign dignitaries in dazzling grandeur.

title: MELVIN LAIRD, WELL RECEIVED, TALKS ON DEFENSE AT PURCHASE
description: DURING the late 1960's and early 1970's, when he was President Nixon's Secretary of Defense, Melvin R. Laird was not the most welcome guest on college campuses, rampant with protests over United States military involvement in Southeast Asia.

title: Cuba Takes Out Ad in Times To Publicize Castro Speech
description: The Cuban Government, in a paid advertisement in The New York Times today, is publishing the complete text of a speech given by Fidel Castro last Monday denouncing the United States invasion of Grenada.

title: Diane Depkovich To Become Bride
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Depkovich of Convent Station, N.J., of the engagement of their daughter, Diane Elizabeth Depkovich, to Tim Hanak, son of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer W. Hanak of Washington Court House, Ohio.

title:
LEISURE;
FLOWERING PLANTS ADAPT TO ENERGY CONSERVATION
description: Michael B. Trimble is a professional horticulturist and writer. With the winter months approaching, the thought of heating sunny rooms, small greenhouses or sun porches to warm temperatures may take the bloom off an indoor gardener's enthusiasm. One way around this is to fill these places with rugged plants capable of withstanding a lower, money-saving setting on the thermostat.

title: ALTERNATIVE MINIMUM TAX BITES
description: UNLIKE 1981 and 1982, when the Reagan Administration and Congress approved major tax bills, this has not been a year for widespread tax changes. Even so, a lot of wealthy taxpayers may be unhappy when they finish their returns.

title: BALLET FOLKLORICO EXPLORES MEXICO'S COLORFUL TRADITION
description: Impressions of villages of early

title: POLICE REVIEW ARREST TACTICS
description: -enforcement officers in a crowded restaurant here to seize four men suspected of dealing in cocaine have led to controversy over arrest procedures.

title: SEAFOOD OF GENEROUS PORTIONS
description: AS its name suggests, Quarter Deck specializes in seafood. The restaurant is in the basement of a small building in Stamford that houses a popular ground-floor bar. The restaurant itself seems more of an afterthought to the lively business upstairs.

title: 'LA BALANCE,' FRENCH THRILLER
description: The slam-bang police thriller is familiar enough as an American genre, but with ''La Balance'' Bob Swaim has effectively transposed it to Paris. Mr. Swaim's film is shrewd, gritty and exciting in the tradition of ''The French Connection'' or ''Dirty Harry,'' even if its band of plainclothes policemen have distinctly Gallic mannerisms. As members of the Territorial Brigade, an elite force in Paris, they keep American movie posters on their office walls, and they love to eat. When they ransack a suspect's apartment, as they do in one sequence, they do not neglect to taste the meal - rabbit with pistachios - that is cooking on the stove.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

title: GOOD WORKS ARE MEASURED IN INCHES
description: AUTUMN is a dangerous season. School has started and the children's schedules are established. The days slip into their rythmic regularity. Restlessness engulfs me. I once more, to solve problems with the benefit of insight, to hear the wisdom of my own counsel. And so, before the last leaf falls from the last tree to mark the change of seasons, the telephone will ring and I will once again volunteer.

title: Early Birds In Market Get Gains
description: ANALYSTS weren't expecting much excitement when the Lotus Development Corporation brought its initial public offering to market Oct. 6. High- technology stocks had just taken a beating, and the tiny Cambridge, Mass., company had just one product, a multifunction personal computer program.

title: Leslie Higgins Is Married
description: The marriage of Leslie H. Higgins, daughter of the late Thomas Higgins of Newport Beach, Calif., and the late Julia Donahue Higgins of New York, to Peter M. Toczek took place yesterday at the Carlyle Hotel. Civil Court Judge Robert Nahman performed the ceremony. The bridegroom, son of the late Dr. and Mrs. Henry Toczek of East Orange, N,J,. is a member of the New York Stock Exchange and president of the New York and Foreign Securities Corporation.

title: 'THE DAY AFTER': TV AS A RALLYING CRY
description: ''The Day After,'' ABC's much-discussed vision of nuclear Armageddon, is no longer only a television film, of course; it has become an event, a rally and a controversy, much of it orchestrated. Part of the controversy has to do with whether ''The Day After'' makes a political statement, which it does, although the statement is muddy, and part of the controversy has to do with how we confront the nuclear abyss. Champions of the film say it forces us to think intelligently about the arms race; detractors say it preaches appeasement. In fact, both sides have something going for them in their arguments, even if the champions of the film, for the moment, are being heard more clearly than the detractors. ''The Day After'' will be seen on ABC at 8 o'clock tonight.

title: MUSIC: KAVAFIAN SISTERS
description: It was an affecting sight - two sisters alone on the stage of Carnegie Hall Thursday night playing string duets. For Ani and Ida Kavafian, this was truly a sisterly affair, in which one player seemed at times almost the mirror image of the other.

title: BRINGING UP BABY: A MOTHER OF THE 50'S LOOKS BACK
description: FOR young married women in the 1950's, babies and copper- bottomed stainless-steel cooking pots were of supreme importance. They came in reverse order of arrival and impact - pots first, then babies shortly afterward. It was never even considered that young, upper-middle-class, college-educated married women would not have babies.

title: LOW-KEY DENG CULT SEEN EMERGING IN CHINA
description: A poster displayed last month in the Shanghai newspaper Liberation Daily looked familiar. It showed a phalanx of soldiers, sailors, fliers and technicians marching forward to the slogan, ''Build powerful, modernized and standardized revolutionary armed forces.''

title: BEHIND THE BOSON
description: THE LEFT HAND OF CREATION

title: DESPITE ITS DECOR, SHOP PREPARES BEEF
description: AS shoppers enter the Stamford Town Center's third level from the southeast, a small, strikingly handsome shop catches their eye. Its polished green Italian marble floor, curved blond wooden counters and mirrored walls resemble an elegant European bank or beauty salon. Only its name, Brae Beef, and a blackboard announcing the day's special of beef stew at $1.80 a pound suggests that the neatly attired men in long white coats behind the counter are butchers.

title: The Customers; The Best and Worst Investment Advice I Ever Got:
description: ''I bought an option on 2,000 shares of Kodak at 3 3/4 and I lost my shirt. That was on a broker's advice - E.F. Hutton as a matter of fact, if you want to go right to the firm. The best advice I ever had was an inside one on Nike Shoes when it was going public. It was about $13 when it came out. It ran to $30 and split. It's back down now to about $16.'' - Marty Pattwell, finance department, the Burroughs Corporation, Atlantic Highlands, N.J.

title: COYOTES INCREASING IN STATE
description: AS a day of hunting goes, Thomas Yankowski was not expecting anything too unusual, perhaps a deer or a fox, when he recently went to the Paugussett Forest in Newtown.

title: JULIAN BREAM STREACHES WITH CONTEMPORARY MUSIC
description: Allan Kozinn is co-author of a history of the guitar to be published by William Morrow early in 1984.

title: ALUMINUM COMPANY OFFICIAL
description: J. Louis Reynolds, a son of the founder of the Reynolds Metals Company and an executive of the company for half a century, died Friday in the Medical College of Virginia Hospital in Richmond. He was 73 years old and lived in Richmond.

title: HEALTH PLAN SEEKS HOSPITAL DISCOUNTS
description: ACCORDING to the State Health Plan for 1982-87, the development of Health Maintenance Organizations, or HMO's, ''has high priority in New Jersey.'' The plan, which defines public-policy goals, says that HMO's are the most effective approach to cutting medical costs without sacrificing quality of care.

title: Ellen Lori First Weds S. I. Gordon, a Lawyer
description: At Temple Beth-El in Cedarhurst, L.I., yesterday Ellen Lori First, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mervin H. First of Amityville, L.I., was married to Stuart Irwin Gordon, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan L. Gordon of North Bellmore, L.I. Rabbi Harvey Goldscheider performed the ceremony.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''At first we thought some areas were more dangerous than others.

title: WARSAW IS HOPING TO CALM FOOD PRICE FUROR
description: A meeting of Polish leaders on economic issues ended today with hopes that public resentment over scheduled food price increases can be defused.

title: A TRIO OF EXPERTS OFFER THEIR INVESTING STRATEGIES
description: Q UESTION: Let's try to get an economic context for the next year, the kind of environment that we're going to be making investment choices in. One view is the double nickel look - 5 percent growth and 5 percent inflation. Also next year is a Presidential election year, and some people think that has an impact on the market. Bob, do you want to go first?

title: SYRIA THREATENS SUICIDE RAIDS
description: Syria's Defense Minister was quoted today as saying that his armed forces were prepared to launch suicide attacks against United States warships and had missiles that could hit anywhere in Israel.

title: SHOPPER'S WORLD
description: In the Cretan village of Daratso, past an arbor heavy with clusters of purple grapes, lies the courtyard of Veta Chatziagelaki, filled with flowers and bright sunshine and summer silence. A stranger can choose between intruding upon the silence with a shout and turning tail for the short drive back to Canea, the island's cultural capital. If you are serious about your mission, you shout.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 'EVENTING' AT UCONN

title: Golf Rules Changed for Some Situations
description: In the 1978 Masters Tournament, Gary Player hit an approach shot onto the bank of Rae's Creek, the water hazard guarding the green of the par-5 13th hole. A protruding drainage pipe near his ball made a full swing impossible. The pipe was an immovable obstruction, and under the rules, Player was entitled to relief. He dropped a ball on the ledge of the hazard, where the ground was firm enough to putt on. Player took two putts and made birdie.

title: ANGRY CHURCHES CONFRONT MELLON OVER THE DECLINE OF 'STEEL VALLEY'
description: HOMESTEAD, PA. MOST of the industrial suburbs strung along the Monongahela River southeast of Pittsburgh look something like this one. A steel mill stretches up the brownish river as far as the eye can see, and in the neighborhoods behind it, scores of church spires point to the sky. Work and religion hold ''Steel Valley'' together.

title: NOTRE DAME A 9-0 WINNER
description: Tom Quinn kicked a 35-yard field goal, and Jim Locklear caught a 47- yard touchdown pass from Mark Coffey to give Notre Dame a 9-0 victory over Msgr. Donovan of Toms River in the first round of the South Jersey, Parochial A playoffs yesterday in Lawrencevile.

title: VERDI DREW FROM HUGO
description: ''Ernani,'' Verdi's fifth opera, was a tremendous success at its premiere and carrried his reputation beyond Italy for the first time. Based on Victor Hugo's ''Hernani,'' it had its first performance in Venice in 1844.

title: DISPUTE CONTINUES ON DUMPING IN SOUND
description: IN announcing plans to dump

title: Sudan Rescues Aliens From Guerrilla Group
description: The Sudanese Army has freed seven French and two Pakistani workers who were captured this week by anti-Government guerrillas, the army general command said today.

title: WHAT THE NEW BELL CRACKS UP TO BE
description: The Bell System finally revealed how things will be after the Jan. 1 breakup. For the widows and orphans who wondered how much of an increase A.T.& T. and the seven new operating companies would give shareholders, the payout will rise only 1.1 percent, to $5.46 a share in 1984, from $5.40 currently. The 20,000 pages of documents that the company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission had other insights. Profits of the seven operating companies and the new A.T.& T. will will rise to $8.7 billion, from $7.3 billion in 1982; revenues will balloon, primarily from double accounting methods, to $116 billion from a 1982 total of $65 billion, and the highest-paid chief executive of the operating companies will be William L. Weiss of Ameritech at $465,000. Trading in the new Bell shares will start tomorrow, even though stock certificates will not be issued until February. While no windfall is promised for the 3.2 million Bell shareholders, the breakup has already been a gold mine for certain printing companies and promises to be one for the brokerage industry and the Postal Service.

title: A TAPE SERIES FAVORS THE MODERN
description: The cassette revolution seems finally to have come of age, with the most esoteric kind of repertory being made available in a cassette-only format by Composers Recordings, Inc. The modestly priced, double-length tapes contain a wide variety of contemporary music, which, of course, is CRI's reason for being.

title: ; RITES OF PASSAGE
College Player Dies
description: Paul Cunningham, a starting guard for Howard Payne University's football team, collapsed on the sidelines and died today during the team's 35-6 loss to Abilene Christian. The freshman from Dallas left the field near the end of the third quarter and appeared to have fainted, said Mede Nix, a Howard Payne official.

title: TRACKING GIFTS FOR SPECIAL CLIENTS
description: AHUMAN skull with a hinged jaw, the tail section of an airplane, a life-size stuffed tiger, and a 1939 World Championship baseball signed by Lou Gehrig and Joe DiMaggio were recently on the shopping list of Sara McGinnis.

title: JAPAN IN NEWARK: PARTS ARE BETTER THAN THE WHOLE
description: NEWARK IT WILL be a while before the

title: NEW THEORY GIVEN FOR CAUSE OF AIDS
description: There may be no single cause of acquired immune deficiency syndrome, one expert on AIDS has suggested, even though many scientists are urgently searching for proof that some single virus or other infectious agent is responsible.

title: THEATER FOR THE DEAF TO GO TO OLYMPICS
description: ACONNECTICUT theater troupe is going to the Olympic Games. The National Theater of the Deaf, based in Chester, has been selected by the Los Angeles Olympics Organizing Committee to be one of six American theater companies to perform at the International Olympic Arts Festival next summer on the campus of U.C.L.A.

title: 20TH ANNIVERSARY OF BEATLEMANIA
description: ''IF you say John, Paul, George or Ringo, everyone in the world knows who you mean,'' Charles Rosenay said. ''Nothing ever matched the media coverage they got. If their name was on a fork, the fork would sell. It's never been like that since.''

title: BLUEBERRY BUSHES GETTING NEW HOME
description: ONE of the region's largest blueberry plantations is being moved this month, from a farm in Kent recently purchased by former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger to a meadow at the Kent School, a private institution some 10 miles away.

title: Mutual Benefits
description: Gained in Project On Schiff Estate

title: HARVARD CAN SAVOR CENTENNIAL AT LAST
description: Greg Gizzi spent the last week trying to forget that the Harvard-Yale game today was the 100th in the series. He succeeded so well that even an hour after he led Harvard to a 16- 7 victory, the centennial spirit had still not hit him.

title: ONE-WOMAN SHOW STARS A TEACHER
description: THIS afternoon, Laurie Cohen will portray Emily Dickinson in an Off Off Broadway showcase production of the one- woman show ''The Belle of Amherst.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
description: HOLIDAY EXHIBITS

title: ALLURE OF LEASING GROWS
description: ONE of the most common alternatives to investments in stocks and bonds is leasing, which involves the purchase of equipment by investors for lease to other parties. Lawrence J. Lucas, president of the Leastec Corporation of Walnut Creek, Calif., which puts together leasing deals, said leasing suits two kinds of investors - those who want tax shelters and those who want income. Mr. Lucas recommended leasing partnerships for people with incomes of $100,000 or more and for retirees looking for tax benefits and cash flow.

title: WITH BIRTHDAYS ON THANKSGIVING, MORE TO GIVE THANKS FOR
description: WHILE it may be true that you can't go home again, don't try telling that to my mother. Every Thanksgiving, when most American adults are as close to that archetypal place as they're ever going to get, my mother re-creates the real thing by giving her two daughters a birthday party. Unfailingly, and without the least diminishment of love and attention as the years pass, she lavishes upon my sister and me a magnificent cake, candles ablaze, and insists on the whole assembled gang singing the birthday song. ''Happy Birthday, Bonnie and Susie,'' they dutifully warble, using our childhood names and making us both feel about 10 years old again.

title: Passports
description: To the Editor:

title: SHAPIRO AND J.F.K.: A COMPARISON
description: LAST Sunday, Peter Shapiro, Essex County's first elected County Executive, completed five years in office. The date was unremarked, even in his hometown of South Orange, since five-year intervals have no significance in American politics.

title: ASSEMBLY SETS DISTRICTING VOTE
description: TRENTON THE State Assembly is scheduled to vote tomorrow on a new Congressional redistricting plan to replace the one voided by the United States Supreme Court earlier this year.

title: NOV. 24, 1963: AND THE GAME WENT ON
description: IT was another football Sunday in New

title: WASHINGTON-MOSCOW CHILL IS CAUSING NEW GLOBAL JITTERS
description: WASHINGTON LOOKING back 50 years to when President Franklin D. Roosevelt opened diplomatic relations with Stalin's Russia, George F. Kennan recalled last week that the two nations ''rubbed each other painfully in many ways.'' Their ideological competition then was ''far more intense than today,'' he said, and political tensions were ''no smaller.'' But he added the sweeping verdict that the problems half a century ago were modest beside today's nuclear anxieties. ''What we did not anticipate was anything resembling military conflict between our two countries,'' the renowned scholar and diplomat said. ''It is weapons we now talk about, weapons we read about, weapons we negotiate about. Behind this endless debate about weaponry the real political issues between the two countries fade into obscurity.'' Trapped in the nuclear competition, he said, the superpowers ''are simply writhing helplessly at immense danger to themselves and to the world around them.''

title: Nina Starr Engaged to Robert Smith
description: Announcement has been made by Beryl H. Arrants of Chappaqua, N.Y., of the engagement of her daughter, Nina A. Starr, to Robert L. Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Smith of Trenton, Mich., and Lauderdale-by- the-Sea, Fla. A January wedding is planned.

title: RITES OF PASSAGE
description: Michael Norman's article ''Rites of Passage'' (About Men, Oct. 23) deeply affected me, and, while I wept as I read it, I felt so

title: U.S.F.L. TEAMS PROVIDE AN OPTION FOR N.F.L.'S TALENT
description: When the United States Football League begins its second season Feb. 28, the rosters of several teams will include players now employed by National Football League teams.

title: COMEDY BUOYS 'TERMS OF ENDEARMENT'
description: Stephen Farber is a freelance

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: The Newark Museum began with Japanese art; that is, its founding in 1909 took place with the purchase of 3,000 Japanese objects - for $10,000 - from the George T. Rockwell Collection. And it has continued to collect in the field since then, receiving major gifts from other collectors - 1,200 netsuke, or small carved ivory figures, for example, from a New York acquisitor in the late 1930's - and making its own purchases of prints, paintings, pottery and sculpture.

title: GRAND GRAFFITI
description: CREATIVITY IS THE whim of fancy, the study of fact. Sometimes it is what the eye sees, stores and then, later, resurrects. Sometimes it is a straightforward solution to a business problem. And sometimes it is both, as seems to be the case with Paloma Picasso's newest jewelry designs for Tiffany & Company. Using scribbles and doodles reminiscent of the graffiti that bedecks - more aptly, defaces - New York City subways, she has created a collection of attractive brooches, pendants and earrings. Some of the pieces are made of 18-karat gold, but most are shaped in palladium, a precious metal that was popular during the World War II years as a replacement for then-scarce platinum. Once platinum was again available, palladium faded from view and its price fell to below gold's.

title: KNICKS STOP PISTONS IN OVERTIME, 104-101
description: Bernard King scored 6 of the Knicks' 10 points in overtime last night to pave the way for a 104-101 victory over the Detroit Pistons at Madison Square Garden.

title: Agents Search Home Of Tennessee Financier
description: Agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation searched the lakeside mansion of Jake Butcher, a bankrupt financier, Friday night and carried away hundreds of documents that investigators hoped would shed light on nine Tennessee bank failures.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: YOU may not have noticed this as you picked your way through your television dinner or swiped a carrot stick out of the icebox last night, but we are in the midst of the dinner season.

title: Stanford Recalls '82 Play
description: Some members of the Stanford band wore football helmets, and one alumnus, Gary Tyrrell, was in a wheelchair as a joke for the 86th game with California today. This time California won, 27-18, in routine fashion.

title: Radiation Said to Kill Small Breast Tumors
description: Studies carried out over the last five years show that about 92 percent of women treated with radiation to eradicate small breast cancers were cured, according to the chairman of the Radiological Society of North America.

title: City Center Plans Gala
description: A gala performance on Dec. 11, with noted singers, dancers and other theatrical celebrities, will mark the 40th anniversary of the season's opening of City Center, 131 West 55th Street. Tickets range from $20 to $2,500; proceeds benefit the 55th Street Dance Theater Foundation Inc. Information: 246-8989 or 586-2820.

title: U.S. WILL APPEAL RULING BARRING ACCESS TO RECORDS ON 'BABY DOE'
description: The United States Department of Justice announced yesterday that it would appeal a ruling by a Federal District Court that denied a Government request to review the medical records of a severely handicapped infant hospitalized on Long Island.

title: GOAL AND ACHIEVEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: RIGHTS COMPROMISE
description: As expected, the United States Civil Rights Commission got a lease on reconstructed life. As predicted, the Legal Services Corporation, even less favored by the Administration because it administers federally funded programs, not just advice, hung on in limbo.

title: ALTERNATIVE TO NUCLEAR DETERRENCE(GROUNDWORK IN PLACE)
description: * To the Editor: As a participant in the Conference on the World After Nuclear War, held in Washington last week, I was shocked by your editorial. Most offensive (and wrong) is your assertion that the ''scientists . . . were describing a study that should not be confused with science'' because it had ''not yet been published.'' The results of the Turco, Toon, Ackerman, Pollack and Sagan (TTAPS) study presented at the conference may be the most thoroughly reviewed material in history. They were carefully reviewed seven months ago by a distinguished group of about 100 atmospheric scientists (many of them have since embarked on similar independent studies, whose results overwhelmingly confirm those of TTAPS in all important respects). They have also been subjected to the usual referee process for publication in Science.

title: WHY FOOTBALL INJURIES REMAIN A PART OF THE GAME
description: THE right stuff! That phrase is so wonderfully

title: Pigeons Fed Despite Ban
description: The pigeons at a French Quarter square are eating as well as ever despite an ordinance authorizing a $25 fine for feeding them.

title: ;  Birthing Rooms: Another Aspect
description: I am writing in response to the ''About Long Island'' article (Oct. 30). Sure, birthing rooms are a wonderful new step in hospital health care.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: CHILDHOOD

title: FROM 1,500 MILES, PROFESSOR TEACHES HIS CLASS BY COMPUTER
description: Twice a week Norman N. Holland climbs the steps to the study in his home in Gainesville, Fla., flips on a computer and enters a detailed discussion about the week's classwork with fellow students enrolled in a course offered at the New Jersey Institute of Technology, 1,500 miles away.

title: A 'GRAND AND TRAGIC' RUSSIA WITH UNDIMINISHED TERRITORIAL APPETITE
description: To the Editor:
