description: IT IS almost impossible to pick up a newspaper these days without noticing that

title: 'BABY JANE' FILE IS KEPT CLOSED
description: A Federal judge told the Government last week to mind its own business in the case of Baby Jane Doe. Judge Leonard D. Wexler of District Court denied the Justice Department's request for complete medical records of the infant, born Oct. 11 on Long Island with severe birth defects.

title: TAX INCREASE HAS 2 IN MICHIGAN FIGHTING FOR SEATS
description: Two Democratic State Senators representing suburban districts here who voted for a 38 percent increase in the state income tax are facing elections seeking to oust them from office.

title: ADAMS AND MADISON REPEAT AS P.S.A.L. CHAMPIONS
description: The sun was bouncing off the eletronic scoreboard yesterday at Midwood Field, making it difficult to read the numbers. But even the glare couldn't keep the Madison players from seeing that they were moments away from winning their second straight B Division title and finishing their season undefeated at 10-0.

title: REPORT TO USTINOV
description: Memo to: Dmitri Ustinov, Defense Minister of the U.S.S.R., Moscow.

title: F.D.A. ACTS TO SUPPRESS SALE OF 'RECREATIONAL' STIMULANTS
description: The Food and Drug Administration has taken action to suppress the sale of nonprescription stimulants that are often used by young people for ''recreation.''

title: FRIENDS FONDLY RECALL 'A VERY HUMAN' PRESIDENT
description: TWENTY years after the death of John F. Kennedy, historians argue the significance of his Presidency, revelations about his private life cloud his public image and debate over his assassination continues.

title: SCIENTISTS PURSUE ENERGY OF THE STARS
description: PRINCETON IN AN effort to create an alternative energy source, scientists at

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: BEHIND THE ATTIC WALL

title: Real Estate Deals For the Little Guy
description: REAL estate investing has become an easier proposition in recent years, and there are signs that it will become easier still.

title: TELEVISION DOS AND DON'TS
description: Don't wear a checkered suit. You'll look fat, and the lines in the cloth will appear to undulate on the television screen.

title: Tokyo
description: To the Editor: As one who has spent time exploring the food sections of Tokyo's major department stores with the same zeal as most tourists devote to the city's shrines and tem

title:
STAMPS;
NEW CEPT ISSUE HONORS GENIUS
description: In all the years that the ''Europa''

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
TELL IT TO THE BUSINESS BUREAU
description: One of the largest consumer injury cases in Federal Trade Commission history was handed over last week to volunteers with three hours' training at the Council of Better Business Bureaus. It looked like a good deal to General Motors, but a headache to owners of GM cars suspected of having defective parts.

title: ;  Invisible Hand
description: To the Business Editor:

title: FUNDS VOTES TO RELOCATE FIRE-STRICKEN TOWN
description: Congress passed an appropriation bill Friday night that included $42 million to relocate parts of Centralia, Pa., which has been menaced by an underground mine fire for 21 years.

title: AIRPORTLESS BEDFORD WEIGHS FLIGHT BAN
description: BEDFORD THERE are no airfields in this community of 18,500 and no planes have ever made emergency landings. The Town Council, however, has before it an ordinance that would prohibit aircraft from landing in the area.

title: Child, 2, Is Seriously Injured By Berserk Man in Brooklyn By United Press International
description: A man went berserk in Brooklyn yesterday, snatching a 2-year-old boy from his parents at Cooper Street and Evergreen Avenue and pounding the child's head against the pavement, fracturing his skull, the police said.

title: BETTER TIMES FOR MANHATTAN DON'T TRAVEL WELL TO BOROUGHS
description: There have been better days for the outer boroughs, as residents of Manhattan are fond of calling the rest of the city. Since Mayor Koch settled into City Hall, a modest increase in employment in Staten Island and, to a lesser extent, in Queens have been more than offset by a marked decline in Brooklyn and the Bronx, where factories, shops, banks and restaurants - the economic underpinnings of those boroughs - have closed at a fearsome rate.

title: Star War
description: The skirmishing between San Diego and astronomers at the renowned telescope at Mount Palomar, 60 miles to the north, began in 1978 when the city decided to replace 26,000 mercury vapor street lights with more efficient lamps. The choice was between high-pressure sodium and low-pressure sodium.

title: TELEVISION WEEK
description: Among the numerous programs occasioned by the 20th anniversary of John F. Kennedy's assassination is a fictional mini-series, ''Kennedy,'' to be broadcast on NBC on Sunday from 8 to 11 P.M., and Monday and Tuesday from 9 to 11 P.M. The seven-hour dramatization views the election of the nation's youngest President, crises in his Administration's 1,037 days, and his murder. Martin Sheen, who portrayed U. S. Attorney General Robert F. Kennedy in the 1975 mini- series ''The Missiles of October,'' now stars as the President. The cast also includes Blair Brown, Charles Brown, Geraldine Fitzgerald, Vincent Gardenia, E. G. Marshall and John Shea.

title: BONN DISCLOSES SOVIET MOVES ON NEW MISSILE OFFER
description: West German officials provided some details today of what they called an attempt by the Soviet Union to present a new arms reduction proposal as though it had originated with the United States.

title: RUSSIA'S ECONOMIC DILEMMA
description: Regarding Leonard Silk's article ''Andropov's Economic Dilemma'' (Oct. 9), the problems of the Soviet Union's economy should not surprise anyone, given the incompatibility between the philosophy of central planning and the needs of individual freedom which make our own marketplace function. I was, however, somewhat surprised and pleased to note that the Russian economists recognize this.

title: SUSTAINING THE RECOVERY-AND SPURRING IT ABROAD
description: THE outlook for the United States economy and investment is for continued but moderate improvement in 1984. However, the year made famous more than three decades ago by George Orwell will still be a time of tensions and troubles.

title: PREGNANT STUDENTS GET HELP
description: NEWTON EDUCATORS and health professionals here have established a new special-education program - the Team Learning Center - for Sussex County's unmarried pregnant teen-agers. Its aim is to encourage the adolescents to continue their studies while preparing for motherhood.

title: THINGS CHANGE, EVEN INBOSTON
description: City Councilman Raymond L. Flynn, a populist once better known as an outspoken opponent of court- ordered busing, was elected Mayor of Boston last week, defeating Melvin H. King, a black activist and former state legislator.

title: McNeil Is Ready but Cautious
description: Freeman McNeil answered the twofold question yesterday without hesitation. He said that he was ready to play, and that statistics proved the Jets were a better team when he played. He added just as quickly, however, that he was not a savior.

title: LEGISLATORS DOUBTFUL OF DEALING WITH BUDGET BEFORE '84 ELECTION
description: As members of Congress scattered for home today for a two-month vacation, they left behind a $200 billion budget deficit and expressed little confidence that they would deal with the problem before the 1984 election.

title: DANCE: SATORU SHIMAZAKI, SOLOIST
description: Earlier in this century, such choreographic pioneers as Isadora Duncan, Mary Wigman and Michio Ito often presented solo concerts notable for their emotional candor. On Friday night at the Theater of the Riverside Church, Satoru Shimazaki, a Japanese-born modern dancer, offered a solo concert in their tradition. He even performed some of their works.

title: Mary A. Reiser To Wed in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Reiser of New Canaan, Conn., and Sag Harbor, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Anne Reiser, to Walter Joseph O'Donnell, son of Dr. and Mrs. Walter E. O'Donnell of Gloucester, Mass. A July wedding is planned.

title: ON JAMES MICHENER'S 'POLAND'
description: On the threshold of 1984, Communist rewriters of history have scored a significant victory in their longtime effort to erase inconvenient individuals and events from the chronicle of modern times. The object of the latest attempt to relegate people to the status of nonpersons is Polish Jewry. For the three million Jews of Poland who perished in the Holocaust, it constitutes a second death.

title: 21 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 21 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: SPANNING THE AGES IN VERSE AND LYRICS
description: AS a professor, Aaron Kramer prefers the past. As a poet, he heeds the call of contemporary issues. As translator, performer, lyricist, contributor to scholarly journals and poet, he spans the the ages, from Beowulf to a Broadway-style musical.

title: BAR SAYS DIRT AND DISREPAIR ARE HINDERING FAMILY COURT
description: The courthouses of New York City's Family Court are dirty and in disrepair, and the court's employees are underpaid and demoralized, according to a report to be released today by the City Bar Association.

title: A PASSION FOR PERU
description: Mario Vargas Llosa is a Peruvian novelist. His latest book, ''The War of the End of the World,'' will be published by Farrar, Straus and Giroux next summer. This article was translated by Edith Grossman.

title: SEEKING THE BEST RATES: BANKING'S LATEST RULES
description: WITH deregulation of interest rates now almost complete, people can run their personal finances almost as if they were the treasurers of large corporations: Even with relatively small amounts of money, say $500, they can shift their funds from one type of highly secure investment to another in a quest for the greatest return.

title: EGYPT'S ANGRY ISLAMICMILTANTS
description: Sana Hasan is a graduate student of political science at Harvard and the author of ''Enemy in the Promised Land: Recollections of the First Egyptian Tourist in Israel,'' forthcoming from Pantheon.

title: COMMODITIES FOR NOVICES: A DIM FUTURE
description: THE experts say that individual investors in commodity futures lose money on as many as 85 percent of their buy and sell decisions. And the experts say they do not do much better themselves. Nonetheless, a correct decision in the futures market offers the prospect of enormous profits in a short time without putting up a great deal of cash.

title: THE LAST DAYS OF CHILDHOOD

title: WINNING AND LOSING: THE LESSONS OF YOUTH SPORTS

To judge from the number of other youngsters participating in publicly and privately organized leagues for the 7-to-17-year-old set, we are not alone in this experience. And this does not begin to count those families with athletes in the upper range of the age bracket who are involved in interscholastic sports.

The Regents have proposed that high school students take more academic courses and more tests and spend more time with computers. Last week Anthony J. Alvarado, the New York City Schools Chancellor, joined the chorus of educators who are worried the plan will result in fewer students earning Regents diplomas.

title:
PHOTOGRAPHY VIEW;
POST-MODERNISTS IN THE MAINSTREAM
description: Much of contemporary art, especially that which we know as Post-Modernist, is meant to undercut and displace the esthetic standards and aspirations of its antecedents. This rejection of the immediate past has, of course, long been a strategy for artists; rebellious sons have savaged their painterly forefathers with Oedipal regularity throughout art history. (Never mind that such a rejection frequently proves illusory, a convenient fiction that gives art and artists room to breathe.) It is characteristic of Modernist art, just as it is of Post-Modernist art. What makes Post-Modernist art different, if we are to believe its most articulate advocates, is that it stands in opposition not only to the Modernist art that is its immediate forebear but also to the entire tradition of high culture and its institutions.

title: Utility Denies Falsifying Data
description: The Metropolitan Edison Company, which operated Three Mile Island during the worst accident in commercial nuclear power history, pleaded not guilty Friday to charges that it falsified important records and covered up to prevent Federal officials from discovering what was going on.

title: A CURIOUS RETICENCE
description: When Emma Bovary gives birth, Flaubert is laconic. No descriptions of pains wracking her body, no mention of blood, of hysteria, of gasps or of struggles - none of the physical details later so clearly described when she pursues satisfaction of her erotic desires. Charles, her physician husband, is in attendance. ''She gave birth on a Sunday at about six o'clock, as the sun was rising,'' the translation reads. '' 'It is a girl!' said Charles. She turned her head away and fainted.'' The natural and religious worlds - the conjunction of the dawn and the Sabbath - are irrelevant to the birth. Emma faints because she feels her universe is bounded by the constraints of the bourgeois world; the birth of a child she takes as just another sign of constriction.

title: GAME CHANGES, BUT APPEAL REMAINS SAME

No, it won't be long now before the players representing a university on probation will hear the jingle-jangle of sets of car keys as opposing fans heckle them about recruiting violations. And more than one referee will quietly stew after he makes an unpopular call that prompts the student section to lead a chant that is more suited for table talk at a fraternity house.

title: Savannah

My husband attended a convention in Savannah in 1982, and I accompanied him, fully expecting not to like the city. I was very wrong. As V. S. Pritchett pointed out, Savannah is an enchanting city - it feels like another century in comparison with New York. Physically, it is beautiful, with clean, wide streets, lushly green squares and beautiful old houses fronted by lacy ironwork balconies. It is a walker's city - and a photogra

As the last trace of the thundering report reverberated beyond the vast expanse of land at the Suffolk County Trap and Skeet Club in Yaphank, Mr. Piffath split open his smoking gun and walked toward the attendant to determine the results of his practice round.

Unemployment has dropped to 11.1 percent, the lowest level in 16 months; inflation is projected to hold at around 5 or 6 percent for the next two years, and the Government says that mink sales are likely to be up 15 percent this year.

The bank, a Federal agency that finances exports, provided $150 million of credit when Laker Airways bought the planes from McDonnell Douglas. When the airline collapsed last year, the Ex-Im Bank, as holder of the first mortgage, seized the planes.

title: Klein Bid Expiring
description: The offer by the fashion designer Calvin Klein and his business partner to purchase the Puritan Fashions Corporation for $60 million expires today at 6 P.M., Eastern standard time. It is unclear what Puritan's board will decide. Mr. Klein and Barry Schwartz, his partner, last Monday offered $16.50 a share to gain control of Puritan, a major manufacturer and distributor of clothing bearing the Calvin Klein label. Puritan shares, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, closed Friday at $16, up $3.75 for the week.

title: Citibank Bid

As a functional member, the Citicorp unit would be able to handle its own check-clearing operations rather than having to use one of the British clearing banks.

description: An Assembly panel that has been highly critical of the state's prison system says the Eastern New York Correctional Facility in Napanoch is a clean, ''model'' prison where the inmates have few complaints.

description: Volunteer organizations that aid homeless and hungry people in New York City are to receive up to $8 million from the Federal Government for this winter, Representative Joseph P. Addabbo said yesterday.

title: Lisa Fried, Photographer, Marries Asher Kornbluth
description: Lisa Ann Fried, daughter of Drs. Seymour and Sylvia Fried of Tenafly, N.J., was married yesterday to Asher Kornbluth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Kornbluth of Far Rockaway, Queens.

title: Bridge:New Goren Teaching Device Allows User to Test Bidding
description: The first major attempt to provide bridge instruction via the home computer has been prepared by the Charles Goren organization. In some respects, it is reminiscent of Autobridge, a favorite for half a century, but it goes considerably beyond it.

description: A book to be published on Monday asserts that Prime Minister Harold Holt of Australia was a spy for China for 36 years and that he faked his drowning in 1967 to flee to China.

description: About 15,000 Filipinos, some carrying signs saying ''Thank you, President Reagan'' and led by the mother of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., marched today in a show of support for the United States.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: A receiver in a college football game leaps to catch a pass and lands simultaneously with one foot inbounds and one out-of-bounds. Is the reception legal? If the receiver straddles the line, one foot inbounds and one out-of-bounds, is that also legal?

title: Janice Lynn Miller Married to Peter Michael Katz
description: Janice Lynn Miller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray H. Miller of Sands Point, L.I., and Sarasota, Fla., was married yesterday to Peter Michael Katz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome L. Katz of New York and Remsenburg, L.I. Rabbi Martin Rozenberg performed the ceremony at the Tower Suite in Manhattan.

title: 2 IN BULGARI FAMILY SEIZED BY GUNMEN AT AN ESTATE IN ITALY
description: Two members of Italy's millionaire Bulgari jewelry family were seized by gunmen posing as paramilitary officers, and hundreds of policemen searched today for the kidnappers, the authorities said.

title: The Height of Vanity
description: Sometime next year, human growth hormone made from genetically tailored bacteria will reach the market in copious supply. That's good news for especially small children, some of whom can be brought up to more ordinary height with the hormone. A more dubious benefit is the possible use of the drug for cosmetic purposes, to make ordinary children taller.

description: ''All of us are very angry. It is unfair to do this in Tripoli.

title: Amway Sales Fall
description: The Amway Corporation said slowing sales caused revenues in its latest fiscal year, ended Aug. 31, to decline $70 million, to $1.13 billion, from a year earlier and prompted layoffs of 230 employees. The closely held direct- sales company cited ''lingering effects of the recession'' for the layoffs, which involve about 3 percent of its workforce. A spokesman said the layoffs were not related to a fine of $20 million levied against Amway earlier this month after the company pleaded guilty to customs fraud charges.

title: SEASONAL RULES IN EFFECT TO EASE MIDTOWN TRAFFIC

description: When Buck Williams became a professional basketball player in 1981, his talents were still raw. He was obviously a fine rebounder, but in other areas he was lacking.

description: The art patrons of this old river city christened their new $33.5 million Kentucky Center for the Arts this weekend. Its $750-a-ticket opening was a watershed in a most extraordinary renaissance.

title: ISRAELI JETS BOMB PALESTINIAN BASES IN LEBANON HILLS
description: Israeli jets bombed pro-Syrian Palestinian guerrilla bases in the mountains east of here today, and one attacking plane was shot down, apparently by a shoulder-fired surface-to-air missile.

description: A senior Israeli official announced plans today to move 250,000 Palestinian refugees out of 28 United Nations-run camps in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip and settle them in new homes over the next six years.

title: THE CHELSEA HOTEL, 'KOOKY BUY NICE,' TURNS 100
description: On one of his first visits to the Chelsea Hotel, Ulick O'Connor saw a distinguished-looking man standing at the reception desk. Curious, Mr. O'Connor, a poet and biographer fromDublin, inquired about his fellow guest's identity.

title: McEnroe Winner, Earning $200,000
description: John McEnroe won the $750,000 European Champions tennis tournament today, defeating Gene Mayer in the final, 6-4, 6-3, 6-4. The first prize in Europe's richest indoor event was $200,000.

title: SHULTZ REAFFIRMS ATOMIC ARMS VIEW
description: Secretary of State George P. Shultz said tonight that a television portrayal of nuclear war "dramatizes the unacceptability" of such a conflict. He said it showed the need for the Reagan Administration's policies but that it did not represent "the future at all.

description: A Federal district judge has ruled that the controversial diet pills called starch blockers are drugs, not food, and the Food and Drug Administration has ordered them off the market until it can test them for safety and effectiveness.

title: Greyhound Union Locals Begin Voting on Pact
description: Striking union locals around the country began voting today on the latest Greyhound contract offer, which would cut wages $40 a week.

title: Confusion on A.T.&T. Stock; Analysts Split On Way to Go
description: For months now, the 3.2 million stockholders of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company have been deluged with mail, sales pitches and advice - all relating to the forthcoming breakup of Ma Bell into eight new companies. For the stockholders, the result has been mass confusion, which promises to reach a crescendo this morning when trading starts in the new shares.

title: STAGE: HAVEL'S 'PRIVATE VIEW' OPENS
description: THE dehumanizing effects of totalitarianism are demonstrated with wounding honesty and irony in Vaclav Havel's ''Private View.'' This triptych of interrelated short plays, opening last night at the Public Theater, is an event of artistic and political urgency.

title: CHICAGO CARDINAL'S NEW AIDES SEEN AS OPENING TO MINORITY GROUP
description: Joseph Cardinal Bernardin's recent announcement of four new auxiliary bishops, one of them black and one Hispanic, is seen as part of a group of major changes in the Chicago Archdiocese of the Roman Catholic Church. The administration is being streamlined and democratized and the Archdiocese is reaching out to minority group neighborhoods.

title: SURVEY SAYS COMPANIES GAVE RECORD AMOUNT TO CHARITIES
description: Despite a third consecutive year of slack profits, American companies gave a record amount to charities last year, a national survey has found. Increasingly, the donations took the form of merchandise and property.

title: Soccer Fans Clash in India
description: One person was killed and several were injured today when angry soccer fans went on a rampage, the Press Trust of India news agency said. The agency said a man was killed when a bus outside a soccer stadium was attacked by spectators angered by a referee's decision during the Delhi Cloth Mills Soccer final between two teams from Calcutta.

title: Hyde Sees Rights Measure's Defeat as an '84 Issue
description: Representative Henry J. Hyde of Illinois, one of 109 House Republicans who helped defeat the proposed Federal tuition last week, charged today that Democrats sacrificed the measure to gain a campaign issue for 1984.

title: HOLOCAUST STUDY CENTER PLANS A LARGE EXPANSION
description: The Simon Wiesenthal Center, this country's largest institution devoted to the study of the Holocaust, plans an addition that will nearly quadruple the size of its facility here.

title: CONVENTION CENTER RESCUE WITH MINIMAL RISK
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. SAYS IT MAPS NEW TOP PRIORITY
description: The Environmental Protection Agency is shifting its chief attention and much of its resources to dealing with problems of toxic substances in the air, land and water.

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: The first session of the 98th Congress has ended with the earliest adjournment since 1965. Except for an occasional committee hearing, it is anticipated that all will be quiet on Capitol Hill until Congress returns on Jan. 23.

title: RAIDER FIELD GOAL DOWNS BILLS, 27-24
description: Buster Barnett, a special-teams player for the Buffalo Bills, gave Kenny Hill of the Los Angeles Raiders an extraneous jab on a punt in the fourth period today at Rich Stadium. Pointing, Hill shouted back at Barnett: ''Hey, you don't have to do that. Just look at the scoreboard.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Adoption Fair Shows The Difficult Cases

title: BIG EAST: PROSPEROUS, NEW PLAYERS AND PAT EWING
description: THE Big East, now among the most prosperous of college basketball leagues, is shifting - a bit uneasily to accommodate an influx of new players in important roles, but comfortably to a new television package, the most lucrative in collegiate sports.

title: Dorothy Wolkenberg Wed
description: Arthur S. Hirsch, a State Supreme Court Justice, and Dorothy R. Wolkenberg were married yesterday.

title: Gail A. Mueller Becomes Bride of Joseph Tirinato
description: Gail Anne Mueller, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Mueller of St. Louis, was married yesterday to Joseph C. Tirinato, son of Martin Tirinato of Syracuse and the late Mrs. Tirinato.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1983 International
description: Israel lost a plane in its bombing of pro-Syrian Palestinian guerrilla bases in the mountains east of Beirut. Western and Lebanese military sources said two American-manufactured Israeli F-16's and five Israeli- made Kfirs bombed offices of the Syrian-backed As Saiqa Palestinian guerrilla group and the Syrian Baath Party in Falugha and Sofar. They were also said to have attacked a position of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, General Command in nearby Baal Shemaa. The targets were in predominantly Druse villages. (Page A1, Column 6.) The residents of Tripoli expressed bitterness at becoming victims of a Palestinian feud as heavy barrages of artillery shells sprayed the city. The shelling in the city and the nearby Beddawi refugee camp has lately been the most intense of the 18-day battle between loyalists of Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, and rebels who accuse him of being too moderate toward Israel. (A1:5.)

title: RANGERS EDGE NORDIQUES, 6-5
description: Kent-Erik Andersson could have won a game for the Rangers in Boston Saturday night when, in sudden-death overtime, he got the puck alone five feet in front of an unguarded net. But his shot was too wide, and the game finished in a 6-6 tie.

title: OIL BOOM ENDS SOONER THAN OKLAHOMA PLANS
description: For the last five years Oklahoma was doing fine, really O.K. The dust yielded its black gold and the state spent like a wildcatter with a gusher. It seemed that the great oil and gas boom would never quit.

title: 'Inept' Felon Creates $20 Bill With $20 Bill
description: A man described by a Federal district judge as "the most inept counterfeiter I ever heard of" was sentenced to five years' probation for cutting the corners off a $20 bill and pasting them on a $1 bill.

title: Dance: City Ballet Does 'Barocco'
description: PERHAPS the litmus test of the New York City Ballet's standards will always be the way in which it dances George Balanchine's greatest ballet, "Concerto Barocco."

title: Miss Shriver Wins
description: Pam Shriver defeated Wendy Turnbull, 6-4, 7-5, in a rain-swept match today and won the $150,000 National Panasonic Classic for the second time in three years. The victory was worth $27,500.

title: DANCE: CARACAS TROUPE PRESENTS 2 PREMIERES
description: THEMES from mythology have offered choreographers a peg on which to hang many a ballet. But myth serves as more than a pretext for dance in Renato Magalhaes's '' 'Apollo' and 'Daphne,' '' which was given its New York premiere by the Ballet Nuevo Mundo de Caracas on Thursday at City Center. Moods and characterization counted for as much as any dance steps in this charming and poignant little pas de deux.

title: LIFE IN KOREAN DMZ: THE BOREDOM HAS AN EDGE
description: Somehow, winter's first dusting of snow this week softened the landscape and made it less bleak. Not much less, though.

title: STAGE: 'MARILYN,' MUSICAL ABOUT MONROE'S MAGIC
description: IF you read all the fine print in

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Two-Faced Sign

title: AFTER CYPRUS, GREEKS WARM UP TO U.S.
description: The United States, which has been much criticized here in recent years, has received unusual praise from Greek officials for its strong condemnation of the recent Turkish Cypriot proclamation of sovereignty.

title: MOSCOW-BOUND COMPUTER IS SEIZED
description: The United States Customs Service said today that components of a highly advanced American computer had been seized in Sweden before they could be shipped to the Soviet Union.

title: WORLD CHESS SEMIFINALS BEGIN TODAY IN LONDON
description: The semifinal round of matches for world chess championship candidates starts today in London, and the matches will pit age and experience against youth. Fifty-two-year-old Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland will face 20-year-old Gari Kasparov of the Soviet Union, and 62-year-old Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union will face 32-year-old Zoltan Ribli of Hungary.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the planned release dates for major economic indicators to be reported this week. Monday

title: No Headline
description: In her comfortable four-bedroom home in a redwood grove overlooking Mill Valley in Marin County, Iris Ergas sat down with her foster son soon after he arrived to live with her family four months ago. He had begun to call her and her husband Mommy and Daddy, Mrs. Ergas said.

title: Injured Student Is Still Critical
description: Margaret Cimino, an 18-year-old Harvard freshman who was struck by the crossbar of a goal post being torn down by fans after the football game with Yale on Saturday, remained in critical condition yesterday at the Hospital of St. Raphael in New Haven, Conn.

title: Murder of Well-Liked Senior Leaves Pratt Campus Shaken
description: The mourning for Anne Pfreundschuh, the period of public grief, lasted three long days.

title: A Risky Mideast Course
description: Memorandum to President Reagan:

title: Art: Postwar Museum Opens in Los Angeles
description: The opening of the "Temporary Contemporary" Museum in the section of this city called Little Tokyo is on more than one count a most remarkable achievement.

title: ANDROPOV SENDS A LETTER TO BONN
description: The Government announced today that the Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, had sent a letter to Chancellor Helmut Kohl on the eve of the start of Monday's parliamentary debate on whether to proceed with the deployment of new medium-range missiles.

title: RATE OUTLOOK TIED TO 'FLOW OF FUNDS'
description: A favorite tool of economists is the ''flow of funds'' analysis, which tries to identify how the money supplied by investors and other lenders will match the money demanded by various kinds of borrowers.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Nov. 21, 1983: MONDAY Bank Amer Rlty InvGenuine PartsBaxter Travenol LabsGopodrich (B F) CoCentury Tel EnterpInterlake IncCigna CorpJohnson ControlsDisney (Walt) PrdtnsNafco Finl GroupDu Pont (E I) CoRepublic CorpFirst Interstate BncrpSan Diego G & E

title: A Tale of Two Risks
description: Here is a bit of sad and cautionary history that President Reagan might ponder before he finally commits the nation, as he seems bent on doing, to a new arms race in outer space:

title: JIM BROWN'S BAD DREAM
description: TEN years ago, Jim Brown was in New York making a forgettable movie named ''Three the Hard Way'' when the unforgettable running back arrived at a promotional cocktail party. With a medieval majesty, he strode into the room with a long black cape flowing over a black silk shirt, a black and red sweater, black slacks and black shoes.

title: Casey Responds on His Stock In Concerns With C.I.A. Jobs
description: William H. Casey, Director of Central Intelligence, says he had stock in 13 companies with Central Intelligence Agency contracts that ranged in value from $12 to $3,995,774.

title: Magazines and Dailies Report Revenue Gains
description: Two segments of the print media have released some very upbeat advertising status reports.

title: The Editorial Notebook; Capitalistic Poverty Law
description: Contrary to the image projected by the Reagan Administration, not all legal services lawyers are political agitators. Some are true capitalists who help their clients in the finest spirit of free enterprise. But they're being treated like dirt.

title: British Indexes Fall and Rise
description: The British economy's long- term leading indicators continued to decline in October, while the shorter leading indicators rose again, according to the Government's central statistical office. The longer leading index, which indicates turning points in economic activity about one year in advance, fell to 108.9 in October, from 110.2 in September.

title: FOLK: JOAN BAEZ STRESSES MODERN BALLADS AT BEACON
description: week American ''comeback'' tour at the Beacon Theater on Saturday with a concert that found the beauty and resonance of her fervent folk-pop soprano undiminished after more than two decades in the limelight.

title: SMITHSONIAN FLIGHT ARCHIVES TO BE SOLD ON 10 VIDEODISKS
description: ''People now fly in to see the photo collection here,'' the head of the Air and Space Museum said. ''Soon the entire collection will be available for the price of an airplane ticket to fly here.''

title: Effect on Stock Averages
description: Today's trading of the stock the new American Telephone and Telegraph Company and its seven regional offspring will not immediately affect the major stock market averages.

title: INTERNATIONAL REPORT Small Rises Lift Hopes
description: Argentina's automobile industry, mired in a three-year-old sales trough, is showing some signs of recovery. And its executives are hoping that the upturn can be maintained.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 21, 1983

title: Mrs. Lloyd Bows
description: Martina Navratilova continued her domination of Chris Evert Lloyd today with a 6-2, 6-2 victory in the final of the $200,000 Lion Ladies Cup four-player tournament.

title: End Game for Euromissiles
description: Now that the first American cruise missiles have reached Europe, the allies are waiting nervously for the second shoe to drop - Moscow's. Since a last-minute deal in Geneva is unlikely, the Russians are bound to make good their threat to quit negotiations for a time. They have also threatened to deploy more missiles in Eastern Europe.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Parents Pitch In For School's Security

title: HISTORIANS' POLL RANKS KENNEDY HIGH, BUT AUTHORS CONTINUE TO ARGUE CASE
description: A poll of 1,000 historians ranks John F. Kennedy 13th among the 39 men who have been American Presidents, between James K. Polk and James Madison. Despite that academic exercise, 20 years after his death, Kennedy's place in history remains unsettled and controversial.

title: Swede Victor
description: Thomas Hogstedt of Sweden took an $88,500 Grand Prix tournament today as he beat Butch Walts in the final, 6-4, 6-4. Hogstedt banged across 19 aces.

title: Oil Trading in London
description: Trading in crude oil futures contracts will begin Monday in London, the first such market outside the United States. Organizers of the contract, to be carried on London's International Petroleum Exchange, say it will giving the marketplace a greater say in oil-pricing decisions.

title: HALT STEELER STREAK
description: Steve Dils threw two touchdown passes and Benny Ricardo kicked a 39-yard field goal today as the Minnesota Vikings built a 17-7 lead and held on for a 17-14 upset of Pittsburgh to end the Steelers' seven-game winning streak.

title: 3 U.S. EMPLOYEES OUSTED BY ARAMCO
description: Three American employees of the Saudi-controlled Arabian American Oil company were dismissed from their jobs last month after friends and relatives in jail in Saudi Arabia complained about mistreatment by Saudi oficials.

title: Veitch Gets Post
description: John Veitch will begin training Viola Sommer's stable on Jan. 1, replacing Frank Martin, who is taking over the training of Louis Wolfson's Harbor View Farm. Martin has been the leading trainer in races won in New York for 12 of the last 13 years, winning mostly with a large stable of claiming horses owned by Mrs. Sommer and, previously, her late husband Sigmund Sommer.

title: SCIENTISTS SAY TV FILM UNDERSTATES POSSIBLE DEVASTATION OF NUCLEAR ATTACK
description: The real thing could be worse, much worse. If anything, the nuclear holocaust depicted in the television drama ''The Day After'' is an understatement, according to recent scientific studies.

title: OCEAN EXPEDITION ENDS, OFFERING MAJOR NEW FINDINGS
description: The world-roving drill ship Glomar Challenger, which in 15 years has probably added more to knowledge of geological history than any other expeditionary vessel, has come home with significant new findings.

title: CORRECTION
description: A chart in Business Day last Wednesday accompanying an article about the breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company misstated Bernstein & Company's estimate of 1983 earnings per share for four telephone holding companies.

title: No Sex Bias Is Found In Milwaukee TV Suit
description: A Federal jury has ruled that Milwaukee television station WCGV-TV was not guilty of sexual discrimination against a former talk show host who was paid less than her co-anchor, who is a man.

title: INSURERS DEBATING TRANSPLANT COSTS
description: With the survival rate in organ transplants rising, the Federal Government and insurance companies are grappling with the question of who will pay the staggering costs.

title: Craig Virgin Wins 12,000-Meter Race
description: Craig Virgin, two-time winner of the world cross-country championship, won an international invitation race at the Meadowlands today, clocking 34 minutes 46 seconds over the 12,000-meter course.

title: Millions of Americans Gather To View Nuclear War on TV
description: After weeks of intense debate, millions of television viewers gathered in churches, in college lecture halls and in living rooms last night to watch "The Day After," the television movie about the nuclear razing of Kansas City and its aftermath in Lawrence, Kan.

title: COPING WITH EARLY SUCCESS
description: ADVICE from a successful entrepreneur: ''Never forget the

title: ANOTHER FRAZIER ENTERS BOXING'S CENTER RING
description: ALL the great warriors have a touch of nobility. Joe Frazier always figured he got his from his blood. ''You got to go back to my father and grandfather,'' he would say. ''They were the men.''

title: Dairy Quotas For Europe
description: The European Parliament has endorsed the imposition of production quotas to control the mounting surplus of dairy products in Europe.

title: TASK IN GRENADA OVERSIMPLIFIED
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Parade's Pathfinders

title: SINGLE-FATHER SURVEY FINDS ADJUSTMENT A PROBLEM
description: Contrary to popular expectation, housekeeping and child-care responsibilities are not the greatest problem areas for single fathers, a new national survey of custodial fathers suggests. The survey, one of the most ambitious ever undertaken on single fathers, finds that they say their greatest difficulties are balancing the demands of work and parenthood and adjusting to the problems of being single again.

title: NICARAGUA LOOSENS THE REINS ON OPPOSITION PAPER
description: Newspaper censorship has been substantially eased in Nicaragua over the last few weeks, and the opposition daily La Prensa has taken full advantage of the unexpected thaw.

title: Pop Music: Bob Moses and His Band
description: BOB MOSES sang along with his drum solos and recited neo-Beat poetry as part of his early set Friday at Seventh Avenue South. Equally eccentric was the way he deployed his 10-piece band, which included a trumpet, 4 saxophones, 2 additional percussionists, keyboards and electric bass.

title: ; DIALOGUES ARE THE LEAST OF CHAPLIN
description: To the Editor:

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.70

title: Columbia Beats Hartwick in Soccer, 2-1
description: Columbia proved stronger on defense and more cohesive in midfield and defeated Hartwick College, 2-1, in the New York Region final of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer tournament yesterday at Baker Field.

title: Elliott Is Winner
description: Bill Elliott of Dawsonville, Ga., who has not won since his 1976 debut on the Nascar tour, became the 12th driver to win on the tour this year by capturing the Western Nascar 500 today.

title: Dorothy Roberts Is Married
description: Dorothy Hyman Roberts, widow of Paul M. Roberts, was married yesterday to Paul Martin Cohen, a partner of Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb. Rabbi George B. Lieberman performed the ceremony at the couple's New York apartment. The bride is president of Echo Scarfs, founded 60 years ago by her father, the late Edgar C. Hyman. Mr. Cohen's first wife, Dorothy Rodbell Cohen, died.

title: Migration Losses Are Found In Areas of South and West
description: Despite the boom in the South and West's population, several states in those regions are losing residents to migration, a population study has found.

title: Police Station in Guadeloupe Damaged by Bomb Explosion
description: -A-PITRE, Guadeloupe, Nov. 20 (AP) - A bomb exploded early today outside the police station at Grand-Bourg on the island of Marie- Galante. No injuries were reported.

title: Buyout Deals Add Up For Forstmann Little
description: Last week was a busy one at Forstmann Little & Company, a relatively new Wall Street firm that has been successful in the game of leveraged buyouts.

title: PRESSURES ON FARES
description: News Analysis

title: BRIEFING
description: Whistler and Friends

title: College Bowl Schedule
description: INDEPENDENCE BOWL

title: DARK HORSES LIKE IOWA CAUCUS RULES
description: News Analysis

title: A FAMILY: STORIES OF 7 BLACK WOMEN
description: When Angela Jones was born in the 1950's, the vast majority of black children were raised, as she was, in two-parent families. She is 31 years old now and divorced, the mother of a 3-year-old girl she is rearing in the Bronx under two difficult conditions: without a father and in poverty.

title: Growing Steel Protectionism Battle
description: Domestic steelmakers have been beating the protectionist drum loudly in recent weeks, and this has already had repercussions overseas. For instance, West German steel companies, angered by protectionist pressures from this side of the Atlantic, last week urged the Common Market to scrap an agreement restricting the amount of European steel imported to the United States.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: A PAUSE FOR BREATH. By Edith Reveley. 209 pages. The Overlook Press.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: One-Man Campaign

title: RITUALS AND REUNIONS AT 'THE GAME'
description: It was a weekend of rituals comforting in their familiarity, of friends reunited in pursuit of their past.

title: New Trial for Texas Prisoner Asked by Carolina Prosecutor
description: Travis Medlock, the South Carolina Attorney General, has asked Attorney General Jim Mattox of Texas to seek a new trial for Lenell Geter, a black engineer from South Carolina who was convicted in October 1982 of holding up a fast-food restaurant near Dallas.

title: Mrs. Kirkpatrick Hints At Arms to Argentina
description: The United States sees no reason to maintain its ban on arms sales to Argentina despite British opposition, Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the American delegate the United Nations, said today.

title: REDSKINS TROUNCE RAMS
description: The last time the Washington Redskins played in the Los Angeles area, they won the National Football League championship in Super Bowl XVII last January in Pasadena.

title: TV: HBO FILM TO STAR STEWART AND BETTE DAVIS
description: ''RIGHT OF WAY,'' a film making its debut on pay- cable's Home Box Office today at 10 A.M. and 8 P.M., has the distinction of teaming for the first time the veteran screen stars Bette Davis and James Stewart. Unfortunately, its strong points end just about there.

title: Special U.S. Envoy Confers With Syrian Foreign Minister
description: President Reagan's special Middle East envoy met with Foreign Minister Abdel Halim Khaddam of Syria today.

title: Coke Bottler to Be Sold
description: Castlemaine Tooheys Ltd., an Australian brewing company, has agreed in principle to buy the Sydney bottler of Coca-Cola from the Coca-Cola Export Corporation on undisclosed terms, the companies said Friday.

title: Congressman in Group FacingHuntingCharge
description: An Alabama Congressman, a law-enforcement officer and a Virginia game commissioner are among two dozen people charged with violating game laws by hunting doves over a baited field.

title: Sanchez Is Winner In Squash Tourney
description: ranked player in the World Professional Squash Association, last night won the $34,000 1983 Chivas Regal Open at the Uptown Racquet Club on East 86th Street.

title: RULES OF COURTSHIP: ADAPTING TO CHANGE
description: A group of 250 men and women between the ages of 35 and 60 - all members of the 4,000-member Westport Unitarian Singles Group - met here one evening recently to find out more about the acceptable rituals that have developed around dating.

title: IMPACT OF SOVIET RESOURCES
description: Buried deep under the permafrost of Siberia lies one of the earth's great storehouses of natural resources, with the potential for transforming the world economy.

title: PRESENTED PARODIES OF BALLETS
description: Iva Kitchell, an internationally famous dance comedian, died on Saturday at the Ormond Beach Memorial Hospital in Florida after a stroke. She was 75 years old.

title: Miss Bernstein Weds Fellow Lawyer on L.I.
description: Elizabeth Shana Bernstein and John A. MacKinnon, both lawyers on the staff of the Attorney General of the Navajo nation in Window Rock, Ariz., were married yesterday. Rabbi Richard Schachet performed the ceremony at the Fox Hollow Inn in Woodbury, L.I.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Like Casals, but Taller

title: 2 More Jets to U.S.F.L.
description: Two more Jets players will be wearing different uniforms next season. Johnny Lynn, a reserve corner-back whose use in the nickel-back position had made him virtually a regular, and Ron Crosby, a reserve linebacker, have decided to switch to the United States Football League.

title: Irish Still Unsure On Bowl
description: Notre Dame postponed a decision last night on whether to accept or reject an invitation to the Liberty Bowl until sometime today, according to the Rev. Edmund P. Joyce, executive vice president of the university.

title: CommoditiesH.J. Maidenberg Profiting By Spreads On Options
description: SPREADING options may be the most conservative way of participating in commodities markets or in the financial and stock-index markets because it is basically a hedged position. The spreader does not care whether prices rise or fall, as long as either side moves sharply and quickly.

title: FEW BOND OFFERINGS IN SHORT WEEK
description: Relatively few tax-exempt and corporate bond issues are scheduled for sale this week, which will amount to only three business days for the many market particpants who do not intend to work on the Friday after Thanksgiving.

title: OPERA: REDOING ROSSINI
description: WHEN Count Almaviva sang of his love for Rosina in the production of Rossini's ''Barber of Seville'' at the Church of St. Ann in Brooklyn on Saturday night, he was holding a red heart in his hand and balancing on a tightrope leading to her balcony. When Rosina dreamt of him in turn, her arms and legs floated in the air around the stage, detached from her torso, which dipped and turned with each phrase. And when Don Basilio proposed a slanderous scheme to Don Bartolo, a white tongue extended out of his mouth, grew longer and longer, until it wrapped itself around Basilio and every object on stage, tangling them in a literal as well as verbal web.

title: Preserving Peace Through Deterrence
description: Since taking office, I have traveled to 48 states, 3 United States territories and 47 foreign countries, Everywhere I have gone, leaders and ordinary citizens alike have voiced one concern above all others: the need to avoid nuclear war. Our Government has set policies in place that, if adhered to, will keep such a war from ever taking place.

title: Japan to Curb VTR Exports
description: Japan has agreed to limit exports of videotape recorders to the European Economic Community to 5.05 million units in 1984, an 11 percent increase from this year. But all of the increase, 500,000 units, will be partly constructed VTR's that will be completed in Europe.

title: MIDEAST RUMORS FLY: HOW ILL IS SYRIAN PRESIDENT?
description: The Middle East has always been fertile ground for rumors, but a bumper crop of unconfirmed reports and speculation has sprung up here in recent days.

title: MONDAY SPORTS
description: Football

title: DEATH SQUADS IN SALVADOR: CENTRISTS BECOME TARGETS
description: NewsAnalysis

title: MUSIC: BIRDSONGS OF BOSTON
description: -man band from Boston that played Saturday at Danceteria, has found a common ground amid garage-band rock, classical minimalism, British progressive rock and its own favorite noises.

title: The Question After
description: I watched "The Day After," ABC's film about the effects of nuclear war, with a doctor friend knowledgeable in these matters. As I sat stunned by the horror - the people vaporized, the slow deaths from radiation, the panic and savagery, he remarked quietly that it was understated.

title: WOOLFOLK LEADS GIANTS OVER EAGLES
description: The Giants, whose performances had become worse and worse each week, reversed their fortunes today with a vengeance.

title: ADVERTISING
description: People

title: Shoreham Panel Says Evacuation Depends on Suffolk's Cooperation
description: A panel appointed by Governor Cuomo has concluded that without the cooperation of Suffolk County there can be no successful evacuation of the region around the Shoreham nuclear power plant in the event of a major accident.

title: LOU L. BRITO
description: Lou L. Brito, the San Diego fishing boat captain credited with inventing the purse seiner and revolutionizing the tuna industry, died Thursday.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 21, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: TRIPOLI IS BITTER OVER PALESTINIANS
description: As heavy barrages of artillery shells disintegrated apartment walls, blew out windows and sprayed deserted streets with shrapnel today, the terrified people of this city expressed bitterness at becoming victims of a Palestinian feud.

title: New Weekday Paper From Investment Firm
description: One thing that William O'Neil & Company, the brokerage firm, particularly prides itself on is its computer- based marketing analysis.

title: ACCOUNTING QUESTIONED
description: Roland Spicka, the management board chairman of Wibau A.G., a construction machinery company that is 37 percent owned by IBH Holdings A.G., has resigned after bankers negotiating loans to save the insolvent company questioned its accounting methods.

title: L.C.&F. Gets New Job For Bristol-Myers Unit
description: Laurence, Charles & Free, one of the Mickelberry agencies, has been given an additional assignment by Westwood Pharmaceuticals of Buffalo for the Fostex line of acne and oily-skin treatment products.

title: Figures Hold Met Solution For Johnson
description: To find the new manager of the Mets, turn left at the cow pasture north of town, drive into Bear Gulley Road to the house on the lake and start looking for the man at the I.B.M. computer.

title: Buyout Deals Add Up For Forstmann Little
description: Last week was a busy one at Forstmann Little & Company, a relatively new Wall Street firm that has been successful in the game of leveraged buyouts.

title: RUTGERS DEFEATED IN PLAYOFF BY F.D.U.
description: The most successful soccer season in Rutgers history came to a disappointing end today, as the fifth-ranked and undefeated Scarlet Knights lost to ninth-ranked Fairleigh Dickinson, 2-1, in the second round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association playoffs.

title: PLAN TO HOLD BACK SOME CITY PUPILS RETAINED
description: New York City's Schools Chancellor, Anthony J. Alvarado, has decided to continue, with modifications he made several months ago, his predecessor's policy of holding back fourth- and seventh-grade students who fail standardized reading tests.

title: OUTDOORS: ON ADJUSTING HUNTING RIFLE
description: THERE are, judging from the fusillades I have heard echoing across the bleak November hills, many deer hunters who neither sight in their rifles nor take the time to study the ballistics of the cartridges they are using.

title: 2 Teen-Agers Missing A Day After Iowa Blast
description: Two teen-agers last seen hunting near the site of an explosion of 12.5 tons of dynamite remained missing today, and the authorities thought they were probably dead.

title: The Game Stopped
description: WE were playing touch football when the President was shot. The fiancee of one of the players came running through the park, calling: ''The President's been shot in Dallas. They've closed the Stock Exchange.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Wine Starts the Day

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Del Monte Corp., San Francisco, has named R. Edward Glover vice president and regional director in charge of European and African operations for Del Monte International Inc.

title: 30 Patrons Wounded By Bomb in Paris Cafe
description: One of two men on a motorcycle hurled a bomb early today into a packed restaurant on the edge of Paris, slightly wounding 30 diners, including several children, the police said.

title: CAROLYN LEIGH, LYRICIST FOR 'PETER PAN,' DIES
description: Carolyn Leigh, the songwriter whose lyrics in such hits as ''Hey Look Me Over'' and ''The Best is Yet to Come'' spoke of a persistent optimism, died suddenly in Lenox Hill Hospital on Saturday following a heart attack. She was 57 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Edward Carr Jr. Dies; Ex-Legal Aid Official
description: Edward Q. Carr Jr., a former attorney in chief of the New York City Legal Aid Society, died of cancer Saturday at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. He was 65 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: CONTROLLED DRINKING GAINS AS A TREATMENT IN EUROPE
description: MANY problem drinkers and even some victims of severe alcoholism can learn to control their drinking without having to abandon it entirely, according to several leading experts in Europe.

title: INTERACTION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vote Against Boycott
description: Athletes from the United States and the Soviet Union have joined with those of other nations in asking that governments put politics aside and refrain from boycotting the 1984 Olympic Games. Their action came in the approval of a resolution proposed by the star American hurdler Edwin Moses that the Olympics be staged ''without political influence.''

title: SOVIET TV DEPLORES KILLING OF CIVILIANS IN TRIPOLI

title: STAGE: 'DOONESBURY'
description: THE qualities that have made Garry Trudeau's comic strip ''Doonesbury'' a national treasure are all present in the musical-comedy version at the Biltmore Theater. You'll hear the offhand dialogue that snares the self- contradictions of college kids of the 1960's. You'll find some sly political jokes aimed at targets as ideologically diverse as William P. Clark and Jane Fonda. Best of all, you'll notice that the tone of Mr. Trudeau's work is intact: on stage, as in the strip, Mr. Trudeau speaks in a sweet voice that lifts him well above the madding crowd of diurnal satirists.

title: HEART ATTACK OFTEN BONDS SWEETHEARTS
description: ADVERSITY has often been said to bring out the best in people, but a New York psychologist was still surprised to find that marriages generally improve after the husband suffers a heart attack. John L. Michela of Columbia University Teachers College studied 40 couples within a year of the husbands' heart attack, finding that increased marital satisfaction was a ''consistent and predominant'' trend.

description: Dwayne Crutchfield, the Jets' leading rusher, who had a history of rule violations, said yesterday that he believed he was released by the team last week because Coach Joe Walton was unhappy with his performance on the field.

title: South African Prices

title: LAMSTON STILL SMALL AND LOCAL
description: While the fadeout of the neighborhood variety store has been predicted for years, M. H. Lamston evidently hasn't been listening. In 1984, the 32- store chain will celebrate 50 years in the metropolitan New York area, a period in which it has witnessed the rise and fall of many larger and smaller retailers.

title: Bridge: For the Pair Title Qualifiers, Frr
description: The American Contract Bridge League has always frowned on cash prizes, but some players nevertheless receive valuable awards. All those who qualify for the final of the Grand National Pair Championship, for example, have their expenses paid to it. This is played as a curtain-raiser to the Spring Nationals, and three partnerships from the metropolitan area earned free trips to San Antonio in March.

title: Berry Drops His Lawsuit
description: St. John's and Walter Berry have withdrawn a Federal lawsuit against the National Collegiate Athletic Association that stemmed from the N.C.A.A.'s refusal to allow him to play basketball for the university this season. ''We dropped the suit,'' said Peter Aron, Berry's lawyer, ''because Walter determined that it was in his best interest to conclude the school year at San Jacinto.

description: b-Net income. Gerber Systems Technology Inc. is an 80 percent owned subsidiary of Gerber Scientific Inc.

title: FORMER NURSE INDICTED IN TEXAS CHILD INJURY CASE

title: Pan Am Drug Confusion Cited
description: Confusion ''compounded by rumor'' was largely responsible for the withdrawal of 11 United States track and field athletes from the Pan American Games last August in Caracas, Venezuela, according to a report issued today by a panel of The Athletics Congress.

description: A man who said he had a bomb commandeered a Republic Airlines DC-9 today and demanded to speak to the Rev. Jesse Jackson, the police said. The man was subdued by passengers and no bomb was found.

title: PLAYSMichael Janofsky

title: MUSICA: SACRA AT FISHER HALL
description: THE choral repertory is an enormously deep sea, but the musical public is generally not able to glimpse more of it than a few big waves, which go under names such as ''Messiah'' and Mass in B minor. There is a rich body of works under the surface that most choral groups either never think to explore or are not able to bring before the public because of financial reasons. Audiences always will turn out in profitable numbers for yet another seance with Handel, it seems, but must be educated to realize what riches they are missing by concentrating on a few beloved masterworks.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Lighting Up, Literally

title: WOMEN, NONFLIERS, BRING PLANE DOWN
description: With her husband, the pilot, slumped unconscious in the cockpit of a light plane, Jane Turner and an elderly passenger gripped the controls and managed a ''magnficent'' landing, though neither had flown a plane.

description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split distributed Sept. 9.

title: Wang and VLSI

This is the same price that VLSI, which is based in San Jose, Calif., received from its initial public offering last February. VLSI was bid at $12.50 today in over-the- counter trading, up 75 cents.

title: POLAND'S MILITARY GIVEN NEW POWERS
description: Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski strengthened his control over Poland today by setting up a powerful military government in reserve, ready to take over political and economic affairs at his command.

title: Talking Businesswith Holiday of Armco Better Times Seen for Steel
description: It has been a harrowing year for Armco Inc., the nation's sixth-largest steelmaker. The company, which lost $345 million last year, reported a stunning $422 million loss in the third quarter, much of it attributable to a $236 million write-off for the closing of its huge Houston Works.

title: PARLIAMENT IN BONN DEBATES MISSILES
description: Parliament opened debate today on the deployment of American missiles in West Germany, with Chancellor Helmut Kohl pledging to go ahead with the plan. Outside, demonstrators scuffled with policemen in the streets.

title: RIDDLE OF MUMMY WITH TWO SKULLS
description: Lady Tashat, the daughter of the treasurer of the Temple of Amon in Egyptian Thebes, lived sometime between 1085 and 710 B.C. At the time of her death, she was married, about 15 years old, a member of a harem and one of the few educated women of her day. The inscription on her coffin reveals little else.

GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: TELEVISION There's probably a lot of television you've missed, television from other parts of the world that have not even run on Channel 13 but have been found absorbing by millions of viewers in other climes. The fifth annual New York World Television Festival, which has seen it all, is winding up today in the theater of the Museum of Modern Art, 18 West 54th Street.

title: Strawberry Is Rookie of Year
description: Darryl Strawberry, an exception in the Mets' routinely dismal season, ran away yesterday with the National League award for rookie of the year.

description: The most interesting thing about the advertisers on ''The Day After'' on the ABC Television Network Sunday night was that few of them were the big guys you would expect to see represented on a network blockbuster.

description: In a joint announcement yesterday, the Puritan Fashions Corporation and Calvin Klein, the designer, said that Puritan had deferred its decision on Mr. Klein's $60.2 million takeover offer and that Mr. Klein had extended the offer until next Monday.

title: BALLET: NEW FACES IN BALANCHINE'S 'JEWELS'
description: New dancers often renew ballets. And young Carlo Merlo, one of several dancers making debuts in roles in George Balanchine's ''Jewels'' over the weekend, made the ballet's ''Emeralds'' section look as fresh and poignant on Sunday afternoon as it did on first acquaintance.

description: Contradictory statements by the Government and some news reports have called into question the announced success of the reprisal raid by French aircraft last week on pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militiamen in Lebanon.

title: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1983 International
description: Yasir Arafat was cornered along with several thousand guerrilla loyalists by Syrian-supported Palestinian rebels at the edge of downtown Tripoli, Lebanon. A spokesman for the P.L.O. leader said the rebel offensive had severed the last road links between Mr. Arafat and pockets of his backers holding out in the Beddawi refugee camp. (Page A1, Column 6.) The people of Tripoli are resigning themselves to a long, painful siege and continuing nerve-shattering artillery shelling. (A1:5-6.)

title: BRIEFS

title: BELL STOCK'S MOMENT OF TRUTH
description: After months of speculation, yesterday's start-up in trading in the shares of the nation's new phone companies was a moment of truth. The news was mostly good, with trading active, though not overwhelming, and prices not far from what analysts had projected.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Mike Heath , the Oakland catcher, yesterday signed a three-year contract with the A's. . . . The Dallas Cowboys said yesterday that the wide receiver Drew Pearson would not play in the Thanksgiving game against St. Louis because of a sprained foot and ankle.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There's no room for gender bias in our system. There's no room for the funny joke and the not-so-funny joke, there's no room for conscious, inadvertent, sophisticated, clumsy, or any other kind of gender bias, and certainly no room for gender bias that affects substantive rights.''

title: Americans Are Refused Visit With Zimbabwean
description: Two American lawyers said here today that the Zimbabwean authorities had refused to allow them to visit Bishop Abel Muzorewa, the former Prime Minister, who has been jailed and accused of subversion.

description: Notre Dame ended two days of uncertainty today by accepting a bid to play Boston College in the Liberty Bowl on Dec. 29 in Memphis.

description: A fourth-grade teacher who refused to sign an oath of loyalty to the state and Federal constitutions was dismissed tonight by the Grove Board of Education.

title: Market PlaceRobert J. Cole Arbitragers' Exciting Day
description: WALL STREET professionals devised a simple formula yesterday for the start of trading in the new A.T.& T. and its seven regional spinoffs: Buy the old and sell the new. Their basic assumption, which turned out to be correct, was that the Bell System's parts would be worth more than the whole.

title: HANS SPIALEK, ORCHESTRATOR OF 147 SHOWS ON BROADWAY
description: Hans Spialek, who orchestrated ''On Your Toes'' as well as 146 other Broadway shows in the 1930's and 1940's, died of cancer Sunday in New York. He was 89 years old.

description: Development of an artificial hip that does not have to be anchored in place by bone cement could prevent at least 10,000 repeat operations on hip surgery patients each year, its designers say.

description: William P. Clark, whose appointment was confirmed last Friday in a Senate vote, took over today as Secretary of the Interior.

title: Castro vs. (Some) Censorship
description: A revolutionary named James Madison once offered this classic defense of press freedom: ''A people who mean to be their own governors must arm themselves with the power knowledge gives. A popular government without popular information or the means of acquiring it, is but a prologue to a farce or a tragedy, or perhaps both.''

title: AT LONG LAST, RAPID TRANSIT MAKES ARRIVAL IN BALTIMORE
description: It was long before daylight, but to Baltimoreans a new age was dawning. At 5:03 A.M., the silver cars of the Metro glided out of Reisterstown Plaza Station. The age of rapid transit had begun for Baltimore.

title: PLAN TO BURN PCB'S IN THE GULF PROTESTED AT HEARING IN TEXAS
description: About 2,000 people packed into a public hearing today, most of them to denounce the Reagan Administration's tentative approval of a plan to burn PCB's, DDT and other chemical wastes in the Gulf of Mexico.

description: Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland combined precise opening play with his lethal ending technique to win the first game of his semifinal match for the world chess championship with Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union here tonight.

title: U.S. BARS SOVIET NICKEL
description: The Reagan Administration today announced a ban on imports of nickel from the Soviet Union in a move that denies Moscow dollar earnings while reinforcing a 1963 trade embargo against Cuba.

title: NEW IMAGES SUGGEST VOLCANISM ON VENUS
description: SOVIET and American spacecraft have produced increasingly strong evidence that the planet Venus has been rocked by widespread volcanic activity in the recent past and may still be experiencing violent eruptions. If so, it would mean that Venus is the third body in the solar system, other than Earth and Jupiter's satellite Io, known to be alive with volcanism.

title: STUDENTS VOICE FEAR AND HOPELESSNESS IN TALKS THE DAY AFTER 'THE DAY AFTER'
description: ''I think I'd rather die than survive a nuclear war,'' said 15-year-old Renee Blackwell. ''Nuclear war was always in the back of my mind, but that show really woke me up.''

title: TIME INC. DROPS TELETEXT EXPERIMENT

title: 89 Arrested in Turkey For a Communist Plot

title: License Actions Pending In Collapse of Sky Walks
description: A licensing board has asked the Missouri attorney general's office to begin legal action to suspend or revoke the licenses of several architects and engineers involved in design or construction of the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Kansas City.

title: YARBOROUGH ARRESTED
description: Cale Yarborough, three-time NASCAR Grand National champion, was arrested yesterday 20 miles east of Columbia, S.C., and charged with driving under the influence of alcohol, the Highway Patrol said. Yarborough was taken to the Richland County Sheriff's Department, where he was given a blood-alcohol test, the highway patrol reported. He was released on a personal recognizance.

title: JETS TOP SAINTS ON PUNTRETURN
description: The Jets, who have not had much success or fun this season, spoiled someone else's fun tonight in the Superdome. After trailing for most of the game, the Jets beat the New Orleans Saints, 31-28, on Kirk Springs's 76-yard punt return.

title: AEROJET AIDE TELLS OF WARNING MISS LAVELLE ABOUT PERJURY
description: A top official of the Aerojet-General Corporation testified today that he had warned Rita M. Lavelle last February that she was giving out false information about her knowledge of a California toxic dump.

title: FOR REGIONAL SHARES, IT WAS A SLOW START
description: Forty-five minutes before the start of trading yesterday, Robin J. Stonehill did not have a single buy or sell order for shares of Southwestern Bell.

description: THE data base management program dBase II, which I began

description: Five men were charged in Manhattan yesterday with conducting ''a massive tax-shelter fraud'' involving $130 million in false income-tax deductions.

title: ATOMIC WAR FILM SPURS NATIONWIDE DISCUSSION
description: In letters and telephone calls, in quiet discussions and contentious gatherings, millions of Americans talked yesterday of fear, hope and the horrors of nuclear war that they had seen dramatized on television Sunday night.

title: All Noise on the Western Front
description: If graphic renderings of the horror of war were a way of promoting peace, there might have been no major wars in this century. Except in wartime, most war stories tend to be anti-war. Yet ''The Red Badge of Courage'' did not reduce America's enthusiasm for World War I; ''All Quiet on the Western Front'' did not protect the West against World War II. Indeed, one could argue that humanism in the contemplation of war can breed pacifism, which may only render democracies vulnerable and thus invite war.

title: FRIENDSHIP CHARACTERIZES STOPPARD REHEARSALS
description: Henry and Annie - formerly adulterous lovers now wed to each other - are having the kind of fight that can mark a fatal turning point in a relationship. He is clever and biting; she is no match for the verbal pyrotechnics he can generate so effortlessly. The fireworks end when he makes a spiteful remark and she, disgusted, walks out of the room.

title: Speed Reported Legal In Train Crash in Texas
description: A Southern Pacific train that rammed a line of idle freight cars, killing four men and injuring a fifth, should have been able to stop, officials say.

title: TV: 'THE CRISIS GAME' SIMULATES WAR DEBATE
description: ''THE DAY AFTER'' has come, gone and become a part of television history. Whether the ABC film will inspire a reasoned debate about the arms race is uncertain. Credit ABC, however, for attempting to start one. ABC followed the film on Sunday night with a discussion on ''Viewpoint.'' Tonight, at 11:30 on ''Nightline,'' it begins a four-part war-game simulation called ''The Crisis Game.'' The ''Viewpoint'' discussion raised more questions than it answered; the war game, one suspects, will, too. There is value in this; the questions are necessary to the debate.

title: Palestinians Condemn Israeli Relocation Plan
description: A group of Palestinian refugees from a camp near the occupied West Bank town of Bethlehem today rejected Israel's plan to relocate them.

title: MUSIC: SAXOPHONE QUARTET
description: The New Music Network, which has been sending avant-garde musicians around New York State, brought the World Saxophone Quartet to the Guggenheim Museum auditorium on Sunday. It was a perfect acoustical setting, and the group performed unamplified.

title: CENSUS BUREAU FINDS TURNOUT IN FEDERAL ELECTIONS IS RISING
description: The Census Bureau said today that the rate of participation in Federal elections appeared to be ''turning upward,'' and it predicted a ''continuing rise in turnout over the next several elections.''

title: CORRECTION
description: A review of Italian restaurants in The Living Section on Aug. 17 incorrectly described the ownership of Harry's Bar in Venice. It is owned by Arrigo Cipriani and his immediate family.

title: GREEK CYPRIOT MEETS REAGAN AND PRAISES U.S. STAND ON TURKS
description: President Spyros Kyprianou of Cyprus met with President Reagan today and said later he was encouraged in his efforts to obtain a reversal of the declaration of sovereignty last week by Turkish Cypriots in the northern third of the Mediterranean island.

title: COMSAT FILLS 3 POSTS, INCLUDING A NEW ONE
description: The Communications Satellite Corporation yesterday announced the election of three new officers ''to improve its ability to organize and articulate strategic business activities'' and to make Comsat a more market- driven company.

title: Four Killed at Texas Sawmill As a Work Cable Whips Free
description: Four workmen who appeared to be trying to free a stuck machine with a cable were decapitated today when the cable whipped free and struck them, the authorities said.

title: PERSONAL INCOME RISES 1.2%, BUT SPENDING LAGS
description: Americans increased their personal income by 1.2 percent last month, the biggest rise in more than two years, but raised their spending by only about half that much, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: HUGE CONDORS SEEM DESTINED TO SURVIVE, AFTER ALL
description: THE California condor, the

title: BRITISH LAND OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30

title: OSHA RULES WORKERS MUST BE TOLD OF HAZARDOUS CHEMICALS
description: The Reagan Administration will announce a rule this week aimed at telling factory workers what hazardous chemicals they are handling, while safeguarding industry trade secrets.

title: HEALTH INFORMATION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
2 Saved as Navy Jet Crashes
description: The two crew members of a United States Navy F-4 Phantom jet were rescued when the plane crashed into the South China Sea last night, a Navy spokesman said today. He said the two, whose names were not released, were flying from the aircraft carrier Midway to the Cubi Point Naval Air Station, part of the Subic Bay base north of Manila.

title: WEATHERFORD, R V, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: Charlotte Curtis The Affluent Society, 1983 JOHN KENNETH GALBRAITH'S ''The Affluent Society'' is 25 years old this year and, as the best-selling economist sees it, ''Americans still have an extraordinary capacity to ignore poverty.'' Nor have the acquisitive changed very much. They go right on demanding an excess of consumer goods, he said, when what the nation needs is education, libraries and a whole range of urban services.
description: ''I am still struck by our superb capacity to manufacture consumer gadgetry including electronic games versus our capacity to produce schools,'' he continued. ''But better education doesn't add to the G. N. P. and the purchase of a school toilet seat does.''

title: PUBLICKER INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including nonrecurring gains of $215,000 for the quarter and $753,000 for the 9 months. c-Including nonrecurring gains of $827,000 for the quarter and $4,040,000 for the 9 months.

title: Joseph Bonanno Wins a Cut In His Conspiracy Sentence
description: Joseph Bonanno's five-year prison sentence for conspiracy to obstruct justice today was reduced to a year and a day after his attorney said the reputed leader of an organized crime family had already suffered the ''ravages of time'' in the 56-month case.

title: 8 Batsheva Dance Bills
description: The Batsheva Dance Company of Israel, a modern-dance troupe, will give the first of eight performances Dec. 6 at 7:30 P.M. in the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street.

title: Japan Output at Peak
description: Japanese industrial production in the July- September period reached a record high, helped by brisk exports, hot weather and other factors, the Ministry of International Trade and Industry said today. The adjusted industrial production index, with a base of 100 in 1980, rose 3.3 percent in the quarter, to 106.3, from the previous three months. The former high of 103.2 had been reached in the January-March quarter of 1982.

title: PANEL IN JERSEY FINDS BIAS AGAINST WOMEN IN THE STATE COURTS
description: -TROY HILLS, N.J., Nov. 21 - A task force on sex discrimination in New Jersey state courts said today that women were treated unequally both as lawyers and in judges' decisions.

title: Realty Trust's Floating Notes
description: Wells Fargo Mortgage and Equity Trust, a real estate investment trust, is selling $50 million of floating-rate extendable notes due in 1995, which are offered at a price of 99 1/2 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES;
description: The golden dome at Notre Dame

title: PRESTON JACKSON
description: Preston Jackson, a trombonist for the Preservation Hall Jazz Band who in the 1930's had been a member of Louis Armstrong's band, died Sunday while traveling to a concert in St. Louis.

title: Advertising; Paperback Aided Start Of Agency
description: BACK in April, Stehling & Baratoff & Partners opened its doors at 200 West 57th Street. And Wendy Stehling and Michael Baratoff, who once worked on different Procter & Gamble products at Benton & Bowles but never met there, began the search for clients.

title: WOOLFOLK HEALTHY AFTER RECORD GAME
description: Butch Woolfolk walked into the locker room in Giants Stadium today and was immediately besieged with questions about his health.

description: b-Net loss.

title: SYSTEM FAILS AND A PLAYER DIES ON FIELD
description: The medical examiner said that 17-year-old Fernando (Fred) Guedes, a junior varsity football player at Yonkers High School, died of heart failure, but it was not that simple.

title: Article 059343 -- No Title
description: Cicely Tyson has legally demanded arbitration against Elizabeth Taylor and the Broadway producer Zef Bufman for $625,000 that she contends they owe her, her manager said yesterday.

description: Changing Gears

description: Soviet ships appear to have ended their search for wreckage from the South Korean airliner shot down over the Sea of Japan in September, Japanese Coast Guard officers said today.

title: 3 Plays in Spanish
description: Three plays will be presented in repertory by the Repertorio Espanol through Dec. 18 in the Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street. Friday at 8 P.M., the work will be ''El Dia Que Me Quieras'' (''The Day You Will Love Me'').
