title: SEARCH PRESSED FOR GUNMEN WHO RAIDED CHURCH IN ULSTER
description: Security forces in both Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic hunted gunmen today who raided a Protestant church on the Ulster side of the border on Sunday evening and killed three people and wounded seven.

title: PLANT INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $470,000 for the quarter and $1,520,000 for the 9 months and losses on the disposal of discontinued operations of $313,000 for the quarter and $2,385,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $321,000 for the quarter and $404,000 for the 9 months.

title: SHOWING OFF AMERICA TO VISITORS FROM AFAR
description: George Lambert recalls the time he took a Belgian radio commentator on a long weekend of canoeing in Minnesota's Boundary Waters Canoe Area.

title: RICHARD LOO, ACTOR 5 DECADES
description: Richard Loo, a Chinese-American actor best known for his many portrayals of Japanese villains in World War II movies, died in Los Angeles on Sunday night at the age of 80.

title: South Africa Planning to Try Reporter for Foreign Papers
description: Allister Sparks, a South African journalist who writes for The Washington Post and The Observer of London, is to go on trial on charges under the Internal Security and Police Acts.

title: Electromedics Accused by S.E.C.
description: A Colorado medical supplier was accused by the Securities and Exchange Commission of illegally inflating its inventories in 1981 and 1982, causing its income to be falsely increased by about $2 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 22, 1983
description: International Washington imposed a ban on imports of Soviet nickel, a move that will deny Moscow dollar earnings while reinforcing a trade embargo against Cuba. The Soviet Union imports Cuban nickel, some of which, Reagan officials believe, finds its way into the nickel the Russians export to the U.S. The officials said Moscow could avert the ban by guaranteeing that its shipments contain no Cuban nickel. They doubted that it would wish to do so, however. (Page D1.)

title: Ashland Oil Investigation
description: The Federal Government has begun an investigation into whether kickbacks and bribes were paid in an Ashland Oil Company petroleum deal arranged by an Atlanta dentist.

title: Burma to Begin Trial Today
description: The Burmese Government announced today that two North Korean army officers would go on trial Tuesday for the bombing last month that killed 21 people, including four South Korean Cabinet ministers. The Government says there is firm evidence that the two took part in the Oct. 9 bombing just before a wreath-laying ceremony at the Martyrs' Mausoleum north of Rangoon. Official sources have said the North Koreans would be tried for murder and illegal possession of weapons.

title: PANEL SUGGESTS COMBINED AGENCY FOR U.S. ECONOMIC AND ARMS AID
description: A high- level commission created by the Reagan Administration to review United States foreign aid programs recommended a major reorganization today. Under the proposal, all economic and military assistance would be administered through a new agency, tentatively called the Mutual Development and Security Administration.

title: MOSCOW SAID TO LOSE SWAY AMONG AFRICANS
description: On a continent where the talk used to be of increasing Soviet influence, a young Zimbabwean has dropped the nickname Comrade Nikita and now is called Cowboy.

title: REGAN SEES FARE OF 85/ IN 1984, BUT $1.60 IN '87
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan said yesterday that an increase in New York City's 75-cent subway and bus fare could probably be held to 10 cents in 1984. Beyond then, however, he projected rapidly growing M.T.A. deficits that would require a fare of $1.25 in 1985, $1.50 in 1986 and $1.60 in 1987.

title: BIG BOARD SHORT INTEREST UP BY 6.2%, TO A RECORD
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest rose 6.2 percent, or 11.3 million shares, in the month ended Nov. 15, to a record 194.2 million shares. The previous high of 182.9 million shares was set on Oct. 14. The short interest for the period a year earlier totaled 139.7 million shares.

title: BROOKLYN MAN TELLS OF ORDEAL IN GRENADA PRISON
description: On Aug. 15, 1979, Antonio Langdon was making repairs at his mother's home, three miles from St. George's, Grenada. His 5-year-old daughter, Shauna, was playing at his feet.

title: Police Said to Leave Town To Avoid Breaking the Law
description: Most of the city's 55 police officers are hiding out in Arizona, 225 miles away, to avoid a court order directing them to end their strike and return to work, according to a official here.

title: MALAISE IN PORTUGAL
description: Little attention has been paid to Portugal since its joyous ''red carnation'' revolution on April 25, 1974, and the turbulent aftermath. An attempted Communist coup failed in 1975, and since then the country has muddled along while the spotlight moved to new dramas.

title: Decision File Safer Windshields From Plastic
description: The Department of Transportation says auto makers may now use plastic-coated windshields, which are expected to prevent many of the 625,000 facial injuries annually caused by glass shards after a crash.

title: AIDES THINK CUOMO IS UNLIKELY TO ACT TO OPEN SHOREHAM
description: A draft report by Governor Cuomo's panel on Shoreham gives support to views long held by plant critics. News analysis, page B2.

title: GEOTEL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Prudential Eurobonds Linked to Phone Stocks
description: The Prudential Funding Corporation, a subsidiary of the Prudential Insurance Company of America, is selling $150 million of 10 1/8 percent Eurobonds, with warrants attached to buy the stock of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company and the seven new regional telephone companies to be spun off Jan. 1.

title: QUEST MEDICAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHERNE INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
COMPLEX KENNEDY
description: Public memorials to John F. Kennedy belong on the anniversary of his birthday, not his death day. His life, though brief, was full of meaning. His death, though dramatic, had none.

title: FOR CHILDREN AT HANUKKAH
description: They are in their mid-70's, they live in Alaska, they listen to Beethoven and New Wave music, they have an egalitarian marriage - and traditional names: Bubbe and Zeyde.

title: Columbia Is Host
description: Columbia and Fairleigh Dickinson will meet in the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association soccer championship Saturday at 1 P.M. at Columbia's Baker Field.

title: MARCOSES SOOTHE ANXIETIES OVER SUCCESSION
description: The ruling party of President Ferdinand E. Marcos decided today to restore the office of vice president, which was abolished by Mr. Marcos a decade ago.

title: Kennedy, Young and Old
description: Robert Kennedy was being more than elegiac when he said of his dead brother, ''I think, really, he made Americans feel young again.'' The New Frontiersmen really were young. The torch really had been passed to a new generation.

title: CONCERT: BEETHOVEN WORKS
description: THE concert presented by the Beethoven Society in Alice Tully Hall on Saturday afternoon consisted entirely of Beethoven wind music performed by the New York Philomusica Chamber Ensemble.

title: No Headline
description: * Acorn Computers Corp., Woburn, Mass., a subsidiary of Acorn Computers Ltd. in Britain, has promoted Harvey Lawner to president.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Boston Celtics , at Madison Square Garden, 8:05 P.M. While the Knicks have been on a surge, winning five of their last six games, the Celtics have slumped.

title: Article 059037 -- No Title
description: A Federal jury awarded $6 million today to a man who said that his mother died because she took the arthritis drug Oraflex.

title: A CARNEGIE CONCERT FOR THE SPITBALL SET
description: As a Mozart serenade filled Carnegie Hall, Tory Dillahunt was hit with a spitball lobbed from the balcony. During a Verdi march, Rachel Gunderson rummaged under her seat for a lost barrette. A Tchaikovsky scherzo prompted Alka Vohra to sigh loudly: ''I'm hungry. Will it be over soon?''

title: Owens Dedication
description: After a controversy that had taken on racial overtones, a park built by the townspeople with donations from all over the country was dedicated in Oakville, Ala., on Sunday to the memory of Jesse Owens , the native son who won four gold medals at the 1936 Olympic Games in Berlin. A crowd of 400, four times the population of Oakville, was present for a ceremony that almost didn't happen.

description: When Adlai E. Stevenson 2d, the United States representative at the United Nations, came here to make a speech in October 1963, a local matron hit him on the head with a placard and a college student spat on him.

description: COLUMBIA, which is scheduled to return to orbit next week, will bring with it the most ambitious schedule for scientific projects ever done in space - as well as a burst of whimsy.

Kennedy as little more than a callow youth, deficient in judgment, bereft of real vision or courage, his triumphs guttering like a candle. One half-expected that the eternal flame at Arlington would be shut off to conserve energy.

title: World Steel Output Rises
description: The production of crude steel in 29 major industrial countries rose 18.6 percent in October from depressed levels of a year ago, the International Iron and Steel Institute said today.

title: Volcker's View Of Prime Rate
description: The prime lending rate at banks, which has exceeded 10 percent for several years, will eventually drop below that level if inflation remains moderate, Paul A. Volcker, the chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, said today. He said, ''you could argue on the basis of the current inflation rate that the prime rate certainly ought to be below double-digit levels.''

title: U.S. PREMIERE OF ITALIAN FILMS PLANNED
description: Eleven contemporary Italian films never shown before in the United States will be screened Nov. 28 through Dec. 5 at Cinema 2, Third Avenue at 60th Street.

title: Film Festival Focuses On Eastern Values
description: A monthlong retrospective of works by the film-making team of Ismail Merchant, James Ivory and Ruth Prawer Jhabvala will begin on Dec. 8 at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street.

title: N.B.A. Penalizes 2 in Referee Incidents
description: The National Basketball Association yesterday suspended Coach Don Nelson of the Milwaukee Bucks for two games and fined him and Coach Doug Moe of the Denver Nuggets $3,000 each for acts of misconduct toward substitute referees.

title: ARGENTINE MILITARY UNDER ATTACK ON JUDICIAL FRONT
description: Adm. Emilio E. Massera, a retired commander in chief of the navy with Cary Grant looks, was a man with his own political party and, it was said, underground army.

title: EX-CHAIRMAN OFFERING HIS SUPERIOR OIL STOCK
description: Amid renewed conjecture that the Superior Oil Company would be taken over, Howard B. Keck, retired chairman, disclosed his intention to sell the 18.7 percent stake he controls.

title: ABC SEES LITTLE PROFIT, IF ANY
description: ABC officials said yesterday that ''The Day After'' would at best achieve marginal financial success, despite its huge audience. Nevertheless, the officials said the film would probably enhance the network's prestige.

description: Year-ago share earnings reflect a 5 percent stock dividend paid in June.

description: A 33-year-old man charged with 16 robberies convinced at least three psychiatrists, the prosecution and a Brooklyn judge that he was a victim of mental illness stemming from combat experiences in the Vietnam War.

title: U.S. WILL NOT PROSECUTE IN 1978 KILLINGS ON COAST
description: The Federal Government will not prosecute Dan White, a former San Francisco Supervisor, for civil rights violations in an attempt to extend his punishment for the murder of Mayor George Moscone and Supervisor Harvey Milk, it was announced here today.

title: Trolley Folly
description: The New York planners pushing ''surface light rail'' transit for 42d Street must have grown up with Judy Garland joyfully singing the ''Trolley Song.'' It leaves the impression that trolleys, as in some happier, simpler age, are self-cleaning and self-effacing vehicles.

title: A's Obtain Caudill
description: Bill Caudill , one of the American League's top relief pitchers the past two seasons, was acquired by the Oakland A's yesterday in a trade with the Seattle Mariners.

title: Jury Fines Northwest Industries CHICAGO, Nov. 21 (AP) - A Federal jury today found Northwest Industries guilty of violating Federal securities law and awarded $18.1 million to current and former stockholders of the company.
description: The jury determined that Northwest had violated securities law by withholding word that it planned to sell its beverage division while it was buying back stock from shareholders.

title: Two Die as U.S. Planes Collide Over the Desert
description: Two Air Force jets collided and exploded in a ball of flame near this high desert base today, killing the two airmen in one plane and injuring the two in the other, the authorities said.

title: 13,000 Join Protest Of Bolivian Austerity
description: About 13,000 workers marched through La Paz today to protest the Bolivian Government's tough austerity measures.

description: Giorgio Armani dominated the Milan spring ready-to-wear showings with his pared-down, comfortable, mannish tailored clothes. He carried this theme throughout his collections for Erreuno and Mario Valentino as well as his own.

title: 6 Fire Companies Closed in Newark
description: Six of Newark's 32 fire companies were shut down today in preparation for the threatened layoffs of 76 firefighters.

description: Syrian-supported Palestinian rebels battled their way to the edge of downtown Tripoli today, cornering Yasir Arafat and leaving him few military or political options.

title: Mrs. Reagan to Visit Mother
description: Nancy Reagan is visiting her ailing mother, Edith Davis, in Phoenix. Sheila Tate, the First Lady's press secretary, said Sunday that later Mrs. Reagan would stop in Los Angeles before going to the Reagans' Santa Barbara, Calif., ranch Wednesday.

title: BULLETIN
description: It all comes back with an etcher's clarity. Warmed by the bright Hawaiian sun on that morning of Nov. 22, 1963, we mounted the steps into the cabin of a VC 137, one of the Air force's Presidential fleet, tail number 86972. Along its white and blue flanks were the words United States of America. This was appropriate, for among the passengers were most of President John F. Kennedy's Cabinet plus enough other Administration members to feed the illusion that if this plane went down, the process of Government would falter for at least an instant. But we had no such somber thoughts as we took off for a three-day meeting in Tokyo with our opposite numbers in the Japanese Government.

title: Trader Wins Potato Case
description: As a result of the potato-futures default in 1976, a Federal District Court jury in New York has awarded Joseph Strobl $460,000, which under antitrust law is tripled, to $1.38 million.

title: SPEAKERS IN THE U.N. ASSEMBLY CRITICIZE SOVIET FOR AFGHAN ROLE
description: The General Assembly heard condemnations today from Pakistan, China and other countries of the continued Soviet occupation of Afghanistan.

title: No Appeal Seen On Silence Ruling
description: The New Jersey Assembly will not appeal a Federal judge's ruling that struck down a law requiring a daily minute of silence in New Jersey public schools, but the Senate has not made a decision yet, legislative sources said today.

description: A report in Sports Pages yesterday about the Columbia-Fairleigh Dickinson soccer game incorrectly reported the scheduled date. It is 1 P.M. Sunday, at Baker Field.

title: SCREEN: DOCUMENTARIES ON BECKETT AND CHAIKIN
description: Students of the theater and, for that matter, anybody interested in the contemporary theater, will want to see the new program opening today at the Film Forum. On the bill are the 57-minute ''Rockaby,'' a record of the preparations and rehearsals for the world premiere performance of Samuel Beckett's play ''Rockaby,'' and ''Joe Chaikin Going On,'' a 58-minute documentary on the life and work of Joe Chaikin, the Brooklyn-born actor, director and avant-garde theater force.

title: German Growth in '84
description: West Germany's gross national product will rise 2.5 to 3 percent next year, adjusted for inflation, according to the latest forecast of the Council of Experts, Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff told Parliament today. The council, consisting of five West German economists, will issue the forecast Thursday.

title: MENUDO SIGNS LONG TERM RCA PACT
description: Menudo, the Puerto Rican teen pop group that has been called ''the Hispanic Beatles,'' has signed a long- term recording contract with RCA Records. RCA declined to specify the size of the deal, but executives there said that the contract, which calls for 12 albums in six years, excluding potential movie soundtracks, was comparable to the company's multimillion-dollar agreements with Kenny Rogers and Diana Ross.

title: Bulova Leaves D.D.B. For Della Femina Unit
description: Doyle Dane Bernbach had an announcement of its own to make yesterday, that it and the Bulova Watch Company, a client since 1964, are splitting.

description: b-After a nonrecurring charge of $4.2 million relating to the acquisition costs of Foxcraft Associates.

title: I.M.F. APPROVES PLAN TO UNLOCK BRAZIL LOANS
description: The International Monetary Fund today gave its seal of approval to a new austerity program for Brazil in a decision expected to unlock more than $12 billion of fresh credits for the world's biggest debtor country and help it stave off default.

title: FREDERICK W. SHAW
description: Frederick W. Shaw, a former news editor for U.S. News and World Report, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Washington. He was 67 years old.

title: Afghan Rebels Kill 12 In Downing a Copter
description: Moslem insurgents in Afghanistan shot down a military helicopter, killing an Afghan Army general and 11 other people, including several Russians, Western diplomats said today.

title: T.I. Introduces Portable Model
description: In a move analysts said indicated that Texas Instruments plans to remain in the higher-priced end of the personal computer market, the company introduced a portable version of its Professional Computer. Like the current Professional Computer, the new portable is compatible with the International Business Machines Corporation's Personal Computer, which is emerging as an industry standard. T.I.'s portable, which comes with a black-and-white display screen and 64,000 characters of internal memory, is the first new computer entry by the Dallas-based company since it announced last month that it was discontinuing production of its 99/4A computer and withdrawing from the low end of the market.

description: A 25-day-old child was beaten to death last night at the Carter Hotel, and her father was arrested and charged with the slaying, according to the police.

title: IN GRENADA, 2 DIPLOMATS AND 2 VIEWS ON INVASION
description: The drive from the Cuban Embassy, a small ranch house overlooking the sea, to the American Mission, in a clifftop inn with a view of St. George's harbor, takes about half an hour.

title: THE SUCCESSFUL DINNER PARTY: A GAME PLAN
description: SOMEONE invites you to a dinner party. You accept, and then you realize that you cannot remember the last time you entertained. For three years you have been telling friends that you will have them over as soon as the chairs are recovered, but you are still waiting for the fabric. Now there is another excuse: You cannot think about giving a dinner party with Thanksgiving at hand.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Suns, at Phoenix. New Jersey, continuing a seven-game road trip, goes up against the powerful front line of Alvan Adams, Maurice Lucas and Larry Nance.

title: TRICO PRODUCTS CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: ON COWS, PEDIGREES AND PROFIT
description: Fifty-five large Holstein cows stood quietly chewing their cud in Madison Square Garden yesterday, the latest fashion in investments being promoted in New York.

title: REAGAN REPORTED TO ORDER INQUIRY ON NEW REPORTS
description: President Reagan has directed the Justice Department to investigate the unauthorized disclosure of details about National Security Council meetings in September on the situation in Lebanon, an Administration source said tonight.

title: Mesa Resumes Buying Gulf Stock
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said it and other members of a group it heads had resumed purchases of common stock of the Gulf Oil Corporation following termination by the Federal Trade Commission of the waiting periods regarding their investments in Gulf.

title: Angels Keep Carew
description: He had sought a better deal with another club, but the offers didn't come through, so Rod Carew , the California Angels' free-agent infielder, has signed a new contract that will keep him with the Angels for two more years. No financial terms were disclosed, but the 38-year-old Carew, a seven-time American League batting champion who had an average of .339 last season, made about $1.1 million for the 1983 season. When he joined the free agent re-entry draft, no other club selected him, but the Angels retained the right to negotiate with him.

title: CDI CORPORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
THACKERAY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including an extraordinary gain of $370,000 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net loss. Results for the latest periods include operations of Brennand-PAIGE Industries, acquired in August.

title: 20 YEARS AFTER, CAPITAL PAYS KENNEDY HOMAGE
description: On the 20th anniversary of his assassination, John Fitzgerald Kennedy was remembered by his family and political clan today as the enduring leader of a multitude ''still in the arena at the center of the struggle.''

title: Arnold Brackman, 60, Dead; Reporter and Author on Asia
description: Arnold C. Brackman, an award-winning author who wrote extensively on Southeast Asia, died Monday in Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived in Brookfield Center, Conn.

title: BRIEFS
description: Bobbie Brooks Inc. said it expects a loss for its fiscal third quarter, ending Jan. 31; it lost nearly $3.7 million in last year's third quarter.

title: HACH CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
ECKERD, JACK, CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: Results reflect LIFO charges equal to 3 cents a share for the latest first quarter and 4 cents a share for the year-ago first quarter.

title: SOUTH BOSTON SAVINGS BANK reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Letter: On Realty Taxes Value Land and Building Together
description: To the Editor:

title: Technology Sales to China
description: The United States has removed restrictions on the export to China of many high-technology goods, Commerce Department officials said today.

title: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1983 International
description: A plan to deploy American missiles in West Germany was approved by a vote of 286 to 226 in Bonn's Parliament after an acrimonious two-day debate. A Government spokesman said deployment would begin today. (Page A1, Column 6.) It was Iranians who exploded the truck bomb in the American Marine compound in Beirut on Oct. 23 with the ''sponsorship and authority of the Syrian Government,'' Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger said. His statement marked the strongest public accusation by the Reagan Administration to date on who was responsible for the attack that killed 239 American servicemen. (A1:5.)

title: HANDLEMAN CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
BIG BOOST FOR MEALS-ON-WHEELS
description: LAST Thursday Christina Hagan, a lawyer, had lunch with a group of friends and acquaintances at the Water Club in Manhattan. They dined on hors d'oeuvres including melon and prosciutto, crudites and breaded zucchini spears with mustard and marinara sauces; a cold antipasto salad a la Esposito, and pasta a la Esposito. It cost each of them $100, and they didn't even flinch. It was for a good cause, Miss Hagan said - to help feed elderly shut-ins.

title: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: SCOUTING
description: Brighter Torch

title: OMEN IN IRAQ: THE CASE OF THE VANISHING BROTHERS
description: President Saddam Hussein of Iraq appears to have built around himself a personality cult that approaches the one surrounding his mortal enemy, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian leader.

title: ROOKIE GETS FIRST-ROW SEAT
description: There are those who say Bruce Kuczenski has the best seat in the house.

title: CITY WILL SUBSIDIZE 15 PRIVATE MENTAL CLINICS
description: Contending that care for the mentally ill is the ''shame of the State of New York,'' Mayor Koch said yesterday that the city would provide $2.6 million to 15 private hospitals to prevent their overcrowded psychiatric clinics from closing.

title: LEGAL GROUP ASSERTS ATTICA IS IN 'EMERGENCY SITUATION'
description: Citing what they said was a pervasive atmosphere of racism, brutality and institutional indifference, a group of lawyers charged yesterday that conditions at the state prison at Attica had deteriorated to ''an emergency situation.''

title: DOW UP BY 7.01, TO 1,275.81
description: Trading in telephone company stocks dominated the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, accounting for almost 8 percent of all shares that changed hands and helping to push up stock prices in general.

title: Macy's Sales Rise; Profit Gains Seen
description: R. H. Macy & Company said that November sales for its stores open more than a year are running 16 to 17 percent ahead of last November, and that new stores are contributing another 3 to 4 percent to the total corporate sales gain. Edward S. Finkelstein, chairman and chief executive, said before the company's annual meeting that if the sales trend continued, profits in the second quarter, ending Jan. 28, would improve ''significantly'' from the year before.

title: Y. & R. Officer Named Y&R/Dentsu Chairman
description: -year-old chairman of Y&R/Dentsu, has resigned and been replaced at the joint venture by Jerry G. Roberts, 41, executive vice president in the international division of Young & Rubicam.

title: SICK CHILDREN REFLECT BRAZIL'S DASHED HOPES
description: In the little Catholic hospital for children here, a 2-year-old girl in a printed blue dress sits in the center of her crib, motionless. Her brother, about 4, stands beside the crib. He has a large distended belly.

title: Presidential Voting In Salvador Planned For Next March 25
description: The Salvadoran Constituent Assembly, after months of bitter debate, announced tonight that presidential elections would be held March 25.

title: Reagan Meets Israeli
description: President Reagan met today with President Chaim Herzog of Israel and pledged America's ''unswerving commitment'' to Israel's security. ''We have always had, and will continue to have, close relations with Israel,'' Mr. Reagan said in an appearance with Mr. Herzog in the White House Rose Garden.

title: The Fate of a Witness
description: Bobby Edmonds, an eyewitness to a Manhattan murder, was himself murdered last week soon after a judge disclosed his name and address to the defense. That his murder was an outrage is clear. But does it also reflect a breakdown of the legal system? Does it justify the reluctance of other witnesses in similar circumstances to testify? So far, the answer to both questions is no.

title: U.S. URGED TO SHIFT A-ATTACK POLICY
description: McGeorge Bundy, the former White House national security adviser, urged today that the United States respond to any nuclear attack on it with a ''substantially'' smaller one and then seek to bring the nuclear exchange to a speedy end at the lowest possible level of destruction.

title: KNICKS BEAT CELTICS IN DOUBLE OVERTIME
description: The Knicks put together an outstanding team effort last night in defeating the Boston Celtics, 117-113, in double overtime at Madison Square Garden.

title: ADVERTISING
description: People

title: Probation Order For Wisconsin
description: The University of Wisconsin football program was placed on probation for one year today, and Ken Stills, a safetyman, was declared ineligible because of a recruiting violation charge, the National Collegiate Athletic Association announced.

title: Columbia No. 1
description: Columbia's undefeated and untied soccer team has taken first place alone in the weekly national rankings of the Intercollegiate Soccer Association of America. The Lions, who have 16 victories, were tied for the top spot last week with Indiana. At 1 P.M. Sunday, they play fourth-ranked Fairleigh Dickinson at Baker Field in the quarterfinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.

title: SOVIET STRIKES TONE OF REGRET OVER KENNEDY ASSASSINATION
description: The 20th anniversary of President Kennedy's assassination has been marked here with a series of articles that strike a regretful tone about the killing and suggest that Kennedy, had he lived, might have sponsored a ''long-term turning of U.S. policy towards detente,'' as the Kremlin's leading American expert expressed it.

title: Harper Hurt, May Miss Rest of Season
description: After having won their first game in four weeks Monday night, the Jets learned today that they might have lost Bruce Harper, their most versatile player, for the last four weeks of the regular season.

title: CRACKER BARREL OLD COUNRY STORE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BIONEX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: The Tree, the Music . . .

title: Burma Charges Two In October Bombing
description: A military court charged two maimed North Korean Army commandos today with murdering 19 people in a bomb attack on a group of high-ranking South Korean officials.

title: PUNT-RETURN PLAY WINNER FOR JETS
description: The figures flickered on a screen in front of Larry Pasquale at the Jets' camp yesterday: ''Beautiful. Good job,'' Pasquale said, talking to the screen, as once again Kirk Springs returned a punt 76 yards for a touchdown.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All of us in this church may not gather all together again.

title: Wavetek Realigning Top Executive Ranks
description: The Wavetek Corporation, a San Diego-based maker of electronic test equipment, has promoted John M. Thornton to chairman and chief executive officer and Louis W. Abbott to president and chief operating officer.

title: BLACK THEATER STARS GIVEN AWARDS
description: ''Hospice,'' Pearl Cleage's show about a mother-daughter relationship, was named best drama, and ''Champeen,'' Melvin Van Peebles's musical look at the careers of Bessie Smith and Joe Louis, was picked as best musical at the 11th annual Audelco Recognition Awards for members of the black theater.

title: GBC CAPITAL LTD reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
ENVOYS MEET BRIEFLY ON LONG RANGE MISSILES
description: American and Soviet negotiators met today to discuss long-range nuclear weapons, but Western officials said Moscow might break off parallel talks on European missiles after the vote in the West German Parliament to accept the deployment of new United States nuclear forces.

title: STIFEL FINANCIAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BUSINESS DIGEST
description: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 23, 1983

title: SCREEN HIPPIE NOSTALGIA
description: ''Hilary's Blues'' was made in 1973 and is only now being released, presumably on the theory that audiences are ready for hippie nostalgia. Even if they are, they probably aren't ready for this.

title: ARAFAT STRONGHOLD IS QUIET BUT NEW BATTLE IS EXPECTED
description: After days of heavy shelling between Palestinian factions, Tripoli was mostly calm today, but commanders on both sides indicated that heavy fighting was likely to resume soon and that they had stopped all but occasional firing only to resupply and give their soldiers a rest.

title: FINAL WAKE HELD BY 2,000 IN DALLAS
description: Dallas's last official wake for John Fitzgerald Kennedy was held today in the city where he was slain 20 years ago, with future memorials to celebrate his life rather than mark the day of his death.

title: TAX-FRAUD CASE BEGAN WITH TIP I.R.S. GOT IN '81
description: Federal agents received confidential information two years ago leading to a major investigation that culminated Monday in the indictment of five men accused of arranging fraudulent tax deductions amounting to $130 million.

title: TEXT OF MEMORIAL TRIBUTE TO JOHN KENNEDY IN THE CAPITAL BY HIS BROTHER
description: Following is the text of a tribute delivered today by Senator Edward M. Kennedy at a memorial mass at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church here on the 20th anniversary of the assassination of his brother, President Kennedy:

title: I.B.M. and Intel
description: The International Business Machines Corporation raised its stake in the Intel Corporation to 16.3 percent, or 18,195,000 shares, with the acquisition of 2,145,000 shares from Sept. 19 through Nov. 14, according to documents filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission. The price of the new shares ranged from $35.30 to $43.77, for a total of $86.9 million. Intel rose 75 cents, to $42.50 bid, today in over-the-counter trading. I.B.M. fell $2.25, to $123, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: RAX RESTAURANTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Chase Is Offering $300 Million Issue
description: A $300 million issue of the Chase Manhattan Corporation's floating- rate, extendable notes due in 1992 are being offered at a price of 99.85 through underwriters led by Lehman Brothers Kuhn Loeb Inc.

title: SOMETIMES A NAME IS ALSO A PLUS
description: The invitation read: ''Carolyn Deaver, Fred J. Hayman and Marvin S. Traub invite you . . .''

title: Donnelley Phone Book
description: Illinois Bell has canceled its contract with the Reuben H. Donnelley Corporation for the printing of the state's Yellow Pages and has sued Donnelley to make it adhere to the remainder of its contract, which expires Nov. 22, 1984, Donnelley said yesterday. The company, a unit of Dun & Bradstreet that has printed the Chicago Yellow Pages for almost a century, said the phone company acted after Donnelley sought better terms when the contract was renewed. Donnelley said it intended to print its own directories.

title: GAYLORDS NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Net loss.

title: Careers; Agriculture Job Market Still Slow
description: AGRICULTURE ranks as one of the nation's largest employers. It is a multibillion-dollar business that feeds a large part of the world, and it has many ramifications, ranging from agricultural economics to zoology.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Bank of Tokyo - Curacao - Ltd.'s $100 million issue of 11 7/8 percent bonds due in 1990 was priced at par, through Credit Suisse First Boston Ltd.

title: A FILM ABOUT TV BASE IS GROWING IN LONG ISLAND CITY
description: In 1976, when the lights were turned on again at the old Astoria Film Studios in Long Island City, Queens, after years of darkness, they also lit up the potential of the surrounding industrial neighborhood as a base for film and television production and related service enterprises.

title: THE VERSATILE COPPER PAN FROM FRANCE
description: ALTHOUGH most of us are still scrambling around trying to get tomorrow's Thanksgiving feast in order, in just a few days, after the last turkey sandwich has been consumed, thoughts will inevitably turn to Christmas and the annual challenge of gift-buying.

title: SUPERIOR CARE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations and disposal of Jackson & Coker Inc. of $43,797 for the quarter and $138,256 for the 6 months. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations and disposal of Jackson & Coker of $70,367 for the quarter and $261,561 for the 6 months. During the latest quarter the company sold a subsidiary, Jackson & Coker Inc., for $1.7 million. The results are restated to reflect the sale.

title: SCOUTING
description: Three of a Kind

title: NEW PLAN FOR CONVENTION CENTER
description: A plan to cover cost overruns at New York City's Convention Center by using funds from the Municipal Assistance Corporation was discussed yesterday at a meeting between Governor Cuomo and Democratic legislative leaders.

title: COLLEGES WITH FRIENDS AT THE U.S. TROUGH
description: To the Editor:

title: BANK OF BOSTON IN PACT FOR RIHT
description: In a further expansion of its growing New England network, the Bank of Boston Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the RIHT Financial Corporation, the third-largest bank holding company in Rhode Island.

title: A DOUBLE STANDARD OF JUSTICE?
description: When athletes receive preferential treatment from society as a whole, there is reason to question the scale of values that favors people who play games for a living over other citizens.

title: COMMONWEALTH MEETING OPENS TODAY
description: Heads of government of Commonwealth nations will convene here Wednesday for a weeklong conference that is expected to include discussion of concerns about two member countries, Grenada and Cyprus.

title: Steel Price Rise
description: National Intergroup Inc. said it will increase its list prices for steel sheet on Jan. 1 by an average of 6 percent. The seventh-largest steel company, formerly known as the National Steel Corporation, announced the increase three months after having been the only major steelmaker to not join other steelmakers when they raised their list prices by 7 percent.

title: HARPER & ROW PUBLISHERS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
HITACHI'S I.B.M. WOES MAY CONTINUE
description: Problems with contested software technology are continuing for Hitachi Ltd., despite its settlement last month of a suit by the International Business Machines Corporation on charges of technology theft. The situation appears to be shaking investor confidence, and Hitachi's stock has fallen sharply in Tokyo.

title: PRICES RISE FOR A THIRD DAY
description: Prices of debt securities rose for the third consecutive day as traders were encouraged by a drop in overnight interest rates and by active investor demand at the Treasury auction of two-year notes.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: ''What do the astronauts of Project Mercury serve on Thanksgiving?'' asks Louis Phillips.

title: BONN PARLIAMENT VOTES TO DEPLOY NEW U.S. MISSILES
description: The West German Parliament approved a plan tonight to deploy American Pershing 2 and cruise missiles. A Government spokesman said deployment would begin Wednesday.

title: ROOKIE AWARD TO KITTLE
description: Ron Kittle, the left-fielder who helped lead the Chicago White Sox to a division championship, today was named the American League Rookie of the Year.

title: Cuomo to Discuss Fate of Shoreham
description: Governor Cuomo said yesterday that he would go to Suffolk County next month to discuss the fate of the Shoreham nuclear power plant before making a decision on what to do about it.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of a typographical error, an article in Metropolitan Report Thursday about Rockefeller University's plan to dispose of radioactive wastes misstated the proposed method. The school would burn them.

title: MYSTERIOUS ODOR FORCES SCHOOL IN JERSEY TO CLOSE
description: The odor, said the principal, Raymond L. Nazzaro, adding an emphasis to the word as he spoke, is a ''solvent type.''

title: Pact Limits Curtiss On Western Union
description: The Western Union Corporation and the Curtiss-Wright Corporation said they had reached an agreement under which Curtiss-Wright will not increase its holdings in Western Union beyond 25 percent without that company's consent.

title: Navy Contracts
description: The Navy said it had awarded a $2.8 billion contract to the McDonnell Douglas Corporation for F-18 fighter jets. The contract was one of a package totaling $5.9 billion that the Navy said it had awarded or reached agreement on.

title: DURO-TEST CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
U.S. GIVES ITS VERSION OF ARMS DISPUTE
description: The United States has protested to the Soviet Union over what it says was a Soviet effort to misrepresent to West Europeans the contents of talks in Geneva on medium-range missiles, Administration officials said today.

title: MEDTRONIC INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The year-ago results are restated.

title: DYSAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Including a gain from the sale of securities of $4,489,000 for the quarter and a gain of $41,222,000 for the year.

title: WEINBERGER LINKS SYRIA TO BOMBING
description: Secretary of Defense Caspar W. Weinberger said today that it was Iranians who exploded the truck bomb in the Marine compound at the Beirut airport a month ago, with the ''sponsorship and knowledge and authority of the Syrian Government.''

title: President Leaves ASEA's U.S. Unit
description: ASEA Inc., the American subsidiary of a Swedish industrial group that has been expanding in the United States, said yesterday that Paul A. Brunner, its president since last year, had resigned to pursue other business interests.

title: A Settlement In Sex-Bias Suit
description: Ramapo College agreed today to pay $230,000 to a former professor who charged that sex discrimination and sexual harassment had prevented her from getting tenure. The settlement was reached on the sixth day of a trial in Federal court.

title: TACOMA BOATBUILDING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a change in accounting methods.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Rick MacArthur, 27-year-old president of the Harper's Foundation since last April, is assuming the position of publisher of Harper's, replacing Louisa Kearney, who resigned to have a baby.

title: REPORT FROM WATT SEES '83 SUCCESS
description: James G. Watt sent a report to President Reagan calling the Interior Department's year ''marvelously successful'' before he resigned under pressure as Interior Secretary. The report was released today.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: A PRESIDENTIAL proclamation designating November 1983 National Alzheimer's Disease Month is calling attention to a mysterious, mind-destroying disease that currently afflicts two million Americans directly and devastates the lives of perhaps 10 million of their relatives.

title: Raise Called Unneeded
description: Governor-elect Edwin Edwards did not realize how much Louisiana State's football coach earns until his offer to set up a $1 million trust fund to supplement the salary was turned down. Mr. Edwards said his plan to add about $100,000 a year to the salary was rejected by Chancellor James Wharton and Athletic Director Bob Brodhead. ''They said it was unnecessary,'' he said.

title: SMUCKER, J M, CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Exhibition Bout for Leonard
description: Sugar Ray Leonard, who retired as the world welterweight boxing champion last year because of a retina injury that nearly cost him the sight in his left eye, said today that he would return to the ring for an exhibition match next month.

title: ABC PLANS ENTERTAINMENT COST CUT
description: In an attempt to cut costs and increase profit margins, ABC Television today announced ''an intensified cost-containment policy'' for all entertainment programs on the network in 1984.

title: '83 GONCOURT WINNER PICKED
description: Frederick Tristan, the 52-year-old author of a book about the dangers of literary fame, has received the Goncourt Prize, France's coveted literary award.

title: First Boston Sells Commercial Paper
description: First Boston Inc., the holding company for the First Boston Corporation, an investment banking firm, said it has begun selling commercial paper. Proceeds will be used as a source of short-term financing.

title: 40 in a 'Charity' Held in Drug Raid
description: Federal officials said a mob-linked narcotics ring was smashed today with the arrests of more than 40 suspects who were accused of using a charity for the handicapped as a front for the sale of cocaine, methaqualone and methamphetamines.

title: RELIANCE FINANCIAL SERVICES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including realized investment gains of $4,840,000 for the quarter and $35,218,000 for the 9 months. c-Including realized investment gains of $4,695,000 for the quarter and $2,541,000 for the 9 months and a gain of $2,558,000 for the 9 months from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: MARCEL DALIO, 83, FILM ACTOR, DEAD
description: Marcel Dalio, one of the few actors to find film success in both France and Hollywood, where he played with Humphrey Bogart in ''To Have and Have Not'' and as the croupier in ''Casablanca,'' died here Sunday, friends reported today. He was 83 years old.

title: MOOG INC reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-After loss on discontinued operations of $3,029,000 and loss on disposal of discontinued operations of $3,523,000. c-After loss on discontinued operations of $2,052,000.

title: MOFFETT DISMISSED AS DIRECTOR OF PLAYERS ASSOCIATION
description: The executive board of the Major League Baseball Players Association dismissed Ken Moffett as executive director yesterday and brought back Marvin Miller, who formerly held the post, to assume it on an interim basis.

title: Skip Wise Surrenders
description: Allen (Skip) Wise, a former Clemson basketball player, has surrendered to Baltimore authorities after being indicted on charges of distributing heroin. The 28-year-old Wise, who had served 2 years of a 12-year sentence after a conviction on a previous drug charge, had left Clemson after his sophomore year to join a Baltimore franchise in the now-defunct American Basketball Association, but the franchise folded before playing any games.

title: ZENITH LABORATORIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
CHIEF QUESTIONS FORCE USED BY TROOPERS AT UPSTATE FAIR
description: The superintendent of New York's state police said yesterday that some troopers might have used ''excessive force'' in arrests at the State Fair in Syracuse last summer.

WILEY, JOHN, & SONS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Synthetic Fuels Corp. Is at the Crossroads
description: The United States Synthetic Fuels Corporation, set up by the Government to help create a major new industry - but now struggling to justify its existence - is poised to aid a number of costly new projects and to rescue a $2 billion coal gasification plant from possible abandonment.

title: BANKS TO RESTRUCTURE TOSCO'S DEBT
description: The Tosco Corporation, a troubled oil refiner, said yesterday that its banks had agreed to restructure $754 million of debt.

title: ROHR INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Judge Plans Study on Bell
description: A Federal judge today took under advisement the question of how the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will pay the Bell companies next year for handling its long-distance telephone traffic.

description: The Wine? Bipartisan

AT LEAST SEVEN DIE IN SHOOTOUT AFTER HIJACKING OF A SOVIET PLANE
description: An attempt by a group of Soviet Georgians to hijack a jetliner to Turkey ended in a fire fight in which at least seven people died, according to reports reaching here.

title: 8 Die in Philippine Battle
description: At least seven Communist guerrillas and a military officer were killed in a one- hour gunbattle in the southern Philippines over the weekend, military headquarters said today.

title: KELLWOOD CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results for the year-ago second quarter include a credit equal to 40 cents a share for LIFO inventory liquidation.

title: AT LEAST 15 KILLINGS ARE LINKED TO A 40-MEMBER GANG IN THE CITY
description: Manhattan police officials said yesterday that they had learned of a 40- member gang linked to at least 15 deaths, including the slaying last week of the key witness in a Manhattan murder trial. They said eight members of the Harlem-based gang, known as the Vigilantes, were under indictment for murder.

title: SAGE-ALLEN & CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
SEARCH FOR KILLERS PRESSED AMID PROESTANT OUTCRY IN ULSTER
description: Britain canceled all leaves for its troops in Northern Ireland today and ordered 240 soldiers into areas near here to joint in the hunt for gunmen who raided a small church on Sunday, killing three people and wounding seven.

title: Muskie Continues Recovery
description: Former Senator Edmund S. Muskie, who suffered a mild heart attack a week ago, was moved out of a special care unit at Webber Hospital today and may be discharged by the end of the week, a hospital spokesman said.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES

Gadomski vice president and general manager of the manufacturing division, Chemicals Group, and james F. Strecansky vice president and general manager of the process gas division.

title: Iraqis Reportedly Sank Greek Merchant Ship
description: An Iraqi rocket sank a Greek merchant ship in the Persian Gulf on Monday, the ship's owners said today.

title: REPUBLIC CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After a loss of $41,000 from discontinued operations.

title: No Headline
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: CONCERT: JULIAN BREAM
description: JULIAN BREAM has been a regular visitor to Town Hall over the years, but Tuesday night's appearance by the British guitarist and lutenist was something out of the ordinary. Not only did the recital mark the 25th anniversary of Mr. Bream's American debut, but it also served to introduce to New York a new work by his compatriot, Michael Tippett. Mr. Tippett's piece, ''The Blue Guitar,'' draws its name from a Wallace Stevens poem of that title, which was itself inspired by Picasso's famous painting. It proved to be a sometimes affecting, often febrile piece in one unequivocally tonal movement that sent the guitarist plunging through a frightening series of technical obstacle courses.

title: TEVA PHARMACEUTICAL INDUSTRIES LTD reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The exchange rate during 1983 averaged 29.80 Israeli shekels equal to $1.00 and in 1982 the average rate was 14 shekels equal to $1.00.

description: The dissident group of shareholders seeking control of the Condec Corporation has apparently won its proxy fight, according to the preliminary vote count released yesterday.

title: FROM A CAMPUS ROMANCE TO A $160 MILLION LIBEL SUIT
description: From its very beginnings the saga of Lisa Springer and Robert Tine had a certain storybook quality. Ten years ago the two met and fell in love, shortly after Miss Springer, a psychology major, entered Barnard College and Mr. Tine, an aspiring novelist, enrolled in Columbia. For the next four years, they were a familiar couple around Morningside Heights.

description: It may seem that every television set in America is tuned to N.F.L. games on Sunday afternoon and Monday evening, but in fact football ratings have been depressed this season for all three networks.

description: TWO days out of the starting gate, how are the eight new companies created by the forthcoming breakup of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company faring in the stock market? Well, ''when-issued'' trading in these eight issues - a slimmed-down version of A.T.&T. and seven regional holding companies - has dominated market activity, accounting for more than 8 percent of total share volume.

FILM: LIDDY AND LEARY
description: ANY movie ought to be in trouble when it opens with G. Gordon Liddy, the convicted Watergate burglar and author (''Will''), singing a hearty, full- throated version of ''America'' to piano accompaniment provided by Timothy Leary, the former Harvard professor who became the spokesman for the turned-on flower people of the 1960's. What, possibly, can the movie do for an encore?

title: ARBITRATION REQUEST SET ON 4 REPRIMANDS AFTER YONKERS DEATH
description: The union representing faculty members in the Yonkers School District said today that it would go to arbitration over its demand that the district remove reprimands against four officials cited for responsibility in the death of a 17-year- old football player with heart disease.

description: Thurl Bailey tipped in a missed shot with 1:20 remaining in overtime to break a 126-all tie as Utah snapped the Lakers' seven-game winning streak.

title: Turk Is Told U.S. Opposes Cypriot Move
description: President Reagan told Foreign Minister Ilter Turkmen of Turkey today that the United States strongly opposed the proclamation of a Turkish Cypriot state in northern Cyprus last week.

description: Bill Brock, the President's special trade representative, vowed today to fight all ''significant'' efforts in Congress to restrict imports of foreign goods in the United States.

title: SATELLITE TELESCOPE QUITS AS REFRIGERANT RUNS OUT
description: An orbiting infrared telescope that has been casting a cold eye on the heavens since January, seeing stars and perhaps solar systems in birth and a host of previously undetected stellar objects, has run out of helium refrigerant and ceased to return scientific data, the project officials announced yesterday.

title: ANTHONY DEVINCENZO, A BOSS ON DOCKS PORTRAYED IN NOVEL
description: Anthony DeVincenzo, a stevedore hiring boss whose struggles against labor racketeering inspired the Budd Schulberg novel ''Waterfront'' and the motion picture ''On the Waterfront,'' died of cardiac arrest last Friday at St. Mary's Hospital in Hoboken, N.J. Mr. DeVincenzo, who had been suffering from cancer, was 74 years old and a resident of Hoboken.

title: CONCERT: 4 PERCUSSIONISTS FROM KOREA
description: -NORI created a spectacular din at the Asia Society on Friday. The four dancing percussionists from Korea played music of invocation and exorcism, most of it for two kinds of drums and small and large gongs - pieces that clanged and thundered in carefully orchestrated crescendos.

title: STAGE: NEW PRODUCTION OF 'PAINTING CHURCHES'
description: In ''Painting Churches,'' her beautifully written play at the Lamb's Theater, Tina Howe has dramatized an illuminating connection between life and art. Miss Howe believes that, in life, perspective can be everything: only with age and experience and luck can children finally see their parents clearly and whole, in the mature light that reveals all. The same, of course, can be true of the relationship of artists to their material. An artist often returns to the same subject again and again, and with time, the perspective keeps changing. Lucky artists eventually reach that state of wisdom or grace where their vision is complete. For the less fortunate, whether in life or art, the grand design remains stubbornly, even tragically, out of reach.

title: A FAMILY THANKSGIVING: AMIABLE IMAGES OF THE PAST
description: M. F. K. Fisher's first book was ''Serve It Forth'' in 1937 and her most recent is ''Sister Age,'' published earlier this year.

title: Floyd Joins Express
description: Stanley Floyd , a top collegiate sprinter who failed to win a berth with the Atlanta Falcons this year, has been signed by the Los Angeles Express of the United States Football League. ''Stanley's speed has to give him a chance to make the club,'' said Coach Hugh Campbell . ''We will tend to show more patience with him because he could give us that big-play threat that every team needs.'' Floyd, who hasn't played football since high school, was the 1980 collegiate 100-meter champion, with a time of 10.10 seconds while running for Auburn, and again in 1982 when he was clocked at 10.03 - the sixth-fastest time for an American - while competing for Houston. . . . Gary Lewis , a backup tight end for the Green Bay Packers, was among five players signed by the Chicago Blitz of the U.S.F.L.

title: GUATEMALA'S INTEREST IN REGIONAL PACT WANES
description: The recent Congressional decision to cut off nearly all aid to Guatemala has diminished the country's interest in a regional military alliance being promoted by the Reagan Administration, according to Guatemalan officials.

title: SMYSLOV-RIBLI GAME IN ADJOURNED IN LONDON
description: Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union adjourned the first game of his semifinal world championship chess match tonight holding a slight positional advantage against Zoltan Ribli of Hungary. However, the 32-year-old Ribli, who sealed his 41st move, is expected to draw when play is resumed here Wednesday at the Great Eastern Hotel.

title: Tektronix Settles
description: The Justice Department said it had reached a settlement with Tektronix Inc. over charges that the company failed to disclose complete information to the Government when negotiating contracts for the years 1977 to 1983. Under the settlement, the Beaverton, Ore., electronics concern will pay the Government $5 million.

description: The United States Justice Department, suggesting that the Long Island hospital now caring for Baby Jane Doe may not be acting medically responsibly, asked a Federal appeals court yesterday to expedite its demand for the entire medical file of the infant, which has severe birth defects.

title: THE SCREEN: 'TERMS OF ENDEARMENT'
description: ''TERMS OF ENDEARMENT'' is a funny, touching, beautifully acted film that covers more territory than it can easily manage. It's the 30- year saga of a mother and daughter; the story of a charmingly eccentric woman who, in her 50's, finally permits herself to fall in love; and the chronicle of a troubled marriage between a young professor and his whimsical bride. It's a comedy, offbeat and lighthearted, then turns painfully and unexpectedly tragic in its final half hour.

title: SOVIET STAKE IN THE P.L.O.
description: Although the Soviet Union has made no secret of its dismay over the Palestinian factional fighting in Lebanon, most diplomats here believe Moscow would rather let Yasir Arafat fall than risk its alliance with Syria on his behalf. In the Middle East, it is on Syria that the Russians have staked their missiles and their long quest for influence. And recent events suggest that the Syrians are aware of the dependence, one that has enabled them to amass Soviet arms and to pursue the hunt for Mr. Arafat over Moscow's opposition.

title: GRAND UNION CO reports earnings for 12 wks to Oct 15

title: YB: 'SCTV' COMEDY SHOW RETURNS ON CABLE
description: THE comedy show ''SCTV'' is back, but not in syndication or on NBC, where it had a short run and where it garnered a lot of Emmy Awards. This time, it's on Cinemax, a pay-cable channel that is associated with Home Box Office. SCTV stands for Second City Television Network. The show began in 1976 as a project of Toronto's Second City stage troupe, which, in turn, was a 1973 spinoff of Chicago's famed Second City ensemble. Original members of the Toronto branch included Gilda Radner and Dan Aykroyd.

title: HOUDING LEADS RISE IN REGION
description: Consumer prices in the New York- Northeastern New Jersey area rose a seasonally adjusted four-tenths of 1 percent in October as the cost of shelter, private transportation and restaurant meals increased.

title: Hearing Is Listed For Steinbrenner
description: Commissioner Bowie Kuhn yesterday set for Dec. 16 his long-delayed hearing into George Steinbrenner's actions and comments over the pine- tar affair of last summer. The commissioner acted one week after Steinbrenner, the Yankees' principal owner, had dropped his legal effort in State Supreme Court to block the hearing on the ground that the commissioner was prejudiced against him.

GLENN SHOWS GAIN IN NEW POLL
description: Former Vice President Walter F. Mondale's lead over Senator John Glenn of Ohio in the race for the Democratic Presidential nomination has narrowed, according to the latest Gallup Poll.

title: The Mixed Blessing of Low Inflation
description: What's the current rate of inflation? Pick a number between 1 percent and 6. Different yardsticks give different results, but they all yield the same message: Inflation is down sharply from the double-digit days - a great benefit to the economy. Welcome it, but don't overlook the awful cost.

title: LOUISVILLE BANQUET OF ONE-ACT PLAYS
description: Crowding 21 one-acts within two days of performance, '' '83 Shorts'' is a kind of prelude to the Actors Theater of Louisville's March marathon of new American plays. The festival, this past weekend, is a logistical exemplar as actors race among roles, stagehands perform sleight of hand with scenery and plays are served up as a banquet of appetizers that is constantly replenished.

title: THE HOMELESS: OFFICIALS DIFFER ON THE CAUSES
description: No one knows for sure how many there are, and there is sharp disagreement on how they got there. Nevertheless, there are thousands of homeless people living in the streets of New York City, and state and city officials agree that their presence has become a major political and social concern.

description: Two former union officials were convicted last night of perjury charges stemming from last year's investigation of Labor Secretary Raymond J. Donovan's activities as a construction-company official before he entered Government.

description: Last month a California appeals court blocked the Los Angeles District Attorney from prosecuting two doctors on charges that they had murdered a comatose, brain-damaged 55-year-old patient by withdrawing the life-sustaining equipment that was intravenously supplying his food and water.

description: To the Editor:

title: KENNEDY SCHOOL OF GOVERNMENT WINS PRAISE AND SOME CRITICISMS AT HARVARD
description: In a handsome brick building on the Harvard University campus near where John F. Kennedy once attended class, the School of Government named for him has grown into an important though sometimes criticized monument to the slain President.

title: GEORGE ABBOT,96, AND JOYVALDERRAMA WED
description: George Abbott, the 96-year-old Broadway producer, was married Monday in his Miami Beach home to Joy Moana Valderrama, president of a Philadelphia retail fur company. The couple met more than 25 years ago when Miss Valderrama was working as a Hawaiian dancer in a New Jersey nightclub while a student at Temple University.

title: NO THANKS TO GIVE
description: President Abraham Lincoln's Thanksgiving Day Proclamation for 1863 begins, ''The year that is drawing toward its close has been filled with the blessings of fruitful fields and healthful skies.'' As the United States observes its national holiday, 120 years later, it should be mindful that 22 drought-stricken countries in Africa have enjoyed neither fruitful fields nor healthful skies.

title: Navy Officials Disclose Overcharges for Parts
description: A review of the Navy's purchases of spare parts has turned up new instances of unjustified high prices, Navy Secretary John F. Lehman Jr. said Tuesday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think they'll come back because they must be aware as much as we are that there cannot and must not be a nuclear confrontation in the world by the only two nations that truly have the great destructive nuclear capability.

title: ISLANDERS OUTSHOT BY 51-23 BUT WIN
description: Statistically and artistically, the Islanders were embarrassed tonight. Nonetheless, backed by 49 saves from their goaltender, Rollie Melanson, the four-time defending Stanley Cup champions left the Spectrum with a 4-2 victory over the Philadelphia Flyers. That put them 1 point behind the first-place Rangers in the Patrick Division.

title: Sheep Ranchers Lose In Atomic Tests Appeal
description: A Federal appeals court today ruled against Utah ranchers who claimed their sheep died of radiation from atomic bomb tests conducted in the Nevada desert west of here 30 years ago.

title: MRS. GANDHI CITES ARMS-RACE PERILS
description: Prime Minister Indira Gandhi opened a weeklong conference of the 44 Commonwealth nations here today with a warning that ''disaster looms on the horizon'' because of the arms control impasse between the United States and the Soviet Union.

title: Soccer Signing
description: Mark Peterson , an American soccer star who played for the Seattle Sounders before the North American Soccer League team folded this year, has become the latest N.A.S.L. player to join the Major Indoor Soccer League. He signed a two-year contract with the Tacoma Stars, joining another former Seattle star, Jimmy McAlister , who earlier turned down an offer from the Cosmos to sign with Tacoma. Ricky Davis , a former Cosmos player, has also jumped leagues and has signed with the St. Louis Steamers.

title: NEW NATIONAL RATES FOR PHONE RENTALS IMPOSED FOR 2 YEARS
description: The Federal Communications Commission yesterday imposed standard national rental rates for millions of Bell System telephones and ruled that after a two-year transitional period starting Jan. 1, phone rentals and sales would no longer be subject to any regulations.

He neither admitted nor denied the charges.

The latest matter, for which the league said yesterday there would be an investigation, concerns Moe's instructions to his players near the end of their 156-116 loss to the Trail Blazers in Portland on Tuesday night.

title: A Judge Above the Battle

Though the consequences were uncomfortable for the city, he was right to order the release of jail inmates to relieve intolerable crowding. But in one small respect, the judge's involvement in the jail and prison crowding issue deserves criticism.

title: ANTIQUES SHOW WHERE DEALERS DEAL AT DAYBREAK

LTHOUGH the dawn was beginning to lighten the sky it was still dark in the parking lot behind the Westchester Marriott Hotel here last Sunday morning, but that did not prevent Chris Kirk, coat collar pulled up over his neck, a container of hot coffee steaming in his hand, from going from van to station wagon to panel truck to van, rubbing frost off windows, peering in, knocking, asking: ''Do you have any Windsors? Any Windsors? Got any Windsors?''

During the 45-second segment, which showed two players warily circling in a clinch, Crozier offered what he called the most important rule of fighting: ''Be sure you get in the first punch.''

description: Gov. James J. Blanchard today called the voters' ouster of State Senator Philip O. Mastin Jr. ''a great public tragedy.'' title: Coach's Ouster Blocked
description: Saying that ''other things than wins and losses must be considered,'' Robert MacVicar , Oregon State's president, announced yesterday that he would not dismiss Joe Avezzano , the football coach, despite a recommendation from the university's board of intercollegiate athletics that he do so. The decision allows Avezzano, who has a 4-38-2 career record at Oregon State, to complete his five-year contract, which expires after next season. ''I believe the integrity of O.S.U. is involved here,'' the president said in a statement, ''and that to terminate a member of our faculty without adequate cause would be undermining the fundamental principles of administration that I have followed throughout my career.'' Mr. MacVicar acknowledged that the university was ''disappointed with Coach Avezzano over the football win-loss record,'' but added: ''The future of football as a sport, particularly Division I football, has become a national concern, and other things than wins and losses must be considered in terms of football's impact on the essential character of the sponsoring universities.'' Mr. MacVicar cited the coach's ''positive and significant influence'' through his commitment to academics.

title: TIGHTER STANDARD ON ASBESTOS IS HELP UP PENDING HEARING
description: A Federal appeals court today barred the Reagan Administration from carrying out an emergency regulation that would require companies to tighten restrictions on worker exposure to asbestos.

title: SANDINISTA LEADER PROPOSES DEAL
description: A large number of Cubans working in Nicaragua have left the country over the last three weeks, according to a senior Government official. Diplomats and other knowledgeable sources here put the number at more than 1,000.

title: HORMEL, GEORGE A, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
OSCEOLA ADAMS, ACTRESS, DIES
description: Osceola Adams, an actress and teacher of dramatic arts, who was known professionally as Osceola Archer; and who also was a founder of the nation's largest black fraternal organization, died in her Upper West Side home Sunday. She was 93 years old.

title: KOCH GOES TO TRINITY PLACE TO FIELD RESIDENTS' GRIPES
description: Neighbors from one of New York City's newest neighborhoods turned out to meet Mayor Koch at his latest Town Hall gathering on Tuesday night - appreciative when they agreed with mayoral assertions, boisterous when they did not and eager to share their special problems with Mr. Koch.

title: SCOUTING
description: Back to Coaching

title: THE DECORATIVE, VERSATILEL, PRACTICAL FOLDING SCREEN
description: SINCE the Chinese first used the folding screen centuries ago, both to create privacy and as a surface on which to paint a picture, the screen has served a multitude of functions in the house. It is at once an architectural element, a piece of furniture, a decorative object and often a work of art. Such diverse people as the art-glass designer Louis Comfort Tiffany, the artist Marc Chagall, the photographer Ansel Adams and the architect Michael Graves have created folding screens. Today interior designers continue to use screens for decorative and functional purposes.

title: DOW DECLINES 0.20 IN HEAVY TRADING
description: Stock prices closed little changed yesterday as profit-taking and weakness in technology companies prevented the market from adding to its recent gains. Trading continued heavy.

title: Pryor Arrested On Drug Charge
description: Aaron Pryor, the World Boxing Association's junior-welterweight champion, was arrested early this morning on a cocaine-possession charge, jailed for eight hours and then freed on $2,500 bail.

title: ARAFAT AGREES TO A TRIPOLI PULLOUT PLAN
description: A spokesman for Yasir Arafat said today that the Palestinian leader had agreed in principle to Saudi Arabian and Syrian proposals that he and all guerrillas, the insurgents as well as those loyal to him, leave Tripoli and its environs.

title: A KEY WEEKEND FOR PLAYOFF HOPEFULS
description: With four weeks remaining in the regular season, contention for the 10 positions in the National Football League playoffs is so intense that the results of 12 of this weekend's 14 games will have a direct bearing.

title: FEARING LOSS OF BUSINESSES, CITY FIGHTS PROJECT IN JERSEY
description: A proposed $2 billion housing and office development in Jersey City has provoked a dispute between Koch administration aides eager to keep businesses from moving across the Hudson and New Jersey officials hoping to attract them.

title: CONSUMER PRICES RISE 0.4%
description: Despite stepped-up inflation in food prices, the Consumer Price Index rose only four-tenths of 1 percent last month, helped by a decline in gasoline and other energy costs, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported today.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Metropolitan Report on Monday about State Department travel restrictions incorrectly described the rules' application to Soviet diplomats at the United Nations. Those who work directly for the Secretariat are unaffected; their conduct is the responsibility of the Secretary General.

title: WEISFIELD'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
COMPUTER DEVICES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
STANDARD BRANDS PAINT CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
Marathon Oil
description: The Marathon Oil Company said it had agreed to sell the 41-story Marathon Oil Tower in Houston to a limited partnership and lease the building back, although it will retain title to the land under the building. Terms were not disclosed. Marathon, a subsidiary of the United States Steel Corporation, said, ''This transaction makes available to Marathon a substantial amount of cash flow which can be more profitably invested'' in oil and gas operations.

title: FIRST U.S. PERSHING MISSILES DELIVERED IN WEST GERMANY
description: Less than 24 hours after Parliament approved the deployment of American missiles in West Germany, the first battery of Pershing 2's was reported today to have been flown to an American air base in the southern part of the country.

title: MUSIC: PHILHARMONIC
description: ONE of the rewards of constant concertgoing is the opportunity it occasionally allows for watching as a naturally gifted young musician evolves into a major talent. Since Cho-Liang Lin arrived in the United States from Taiwan at age 14, just eight years ago, we have seen him grow up before our eyes. Now, at only 23, the former Juilliard student comes before us as a fullblown, world-class violinist. Mr. Lin's performance last night of the Sibelius Concerto, as soloist with the New York Philharmonic, left no doubt about his mastery, either of his instrument or of the music. He is the genuine article.

title: SYSTEM INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
JETS CUT CRUTCHFIELD AFTER DEMOTING HIM
description: The circumstances surrounding the sudden dismissal of the Jets' leading rusher, Dwayne Crutchfield, last Thursday became a bit clearer today, even as the fullback was joining his new team, the Houston Oilers.

title: CARL KARCHER ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 4
A U.S. VIEW: KEEP TRYING
description: NewsAnalysis

title: U.S. Seizes Machinery Believed on Way to Cuba
description: Customs agents seized $610,000 in high-technology machinery illegally headed for Cuba in a smuggling plot the authorities say was masterminded by the financier Robert L. Vesco, a fugitive from the United States.

title: STALKING THE SKILLED CRAFTSMAN WHO DOES SPECIAL CUSTOM JOBS
description: THE conventional wisdom about craftsmen in New York City is that they have vanished. The more accurate assessment is simply that they are less numerous than they once were - and that they do not advertise.

title: TRANS MOUNTAIN PIPE LINE CO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a charge of $18,000 relating to the Inland Natural Gas Co. c-After a similar charge of $23,000. d-After gains of $65,000 and $454,000 on the sale of assets and losses of $341,000 and $24,000 related to Inland Natural Gas, for the latest and year- earlier periods, respectively. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Brazil's Debt Is Rescheduled
description: Western nations agreed today to reschedule $3.8 billion in Brazilian debt, completing an elaborate rescue package to ease Brazil's debt problems.

title: Thanksgiving, in Theory
description: ''Freedom From Want,'' Norman Rockwell's 1943 painting for The Saturday Evening Post, is more than a magazine cover. Just as Dylan Thomas's poem about Welsh children defines one kind of Christmas, Rockwell's painting defines Thanksgiving in America. It has become part of our iconography, engraved into public consciousness as surely as Grant Wood's ''American Gothic'' or Stuart's tight-lipped Washington.

title: 2,000 MORE BEDS FOR THE HOMELESS PLANNED IN CITY
description: Governor Cuomo and Mayor Koch announced a plan yesterday to provide about 2,000 more beds over the next two years for the homeless in New York City, including use of the Creedmoor Psychiatric Center in Queens for homeless men.

title: HILLER AVIATION reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
TANDON CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
THE REAL ISSUE
description: How can we reduce the risk of nuclear war? The question was on the minds of many Americans even before television dramatized the danger. People see the hatred and violence in the world. Whatever their politics, they worry that tension may someday escalate into disaster.

title: EUGENE S. HOOPER
description: Eugene S. Hooper. a former president of the Manufacturers Trust Company, now Manufacturers Hanover Trust, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Englewood, N.J. He was 85 years old.

title: 2 RUSSIANS RETURN TO EARTH SAFELY
description: Two Soviet astronauts returned safely to the earth late Wednesday night after a 150- day flight marked by real and rumored problems. The Russian people learned of their return just after midnight but were not told of any trouble.

title: SYRIA REJECTS U.S. BOMBING CHARGE
description: Government-controlled newspapers here published statements today rejecting a United States charge that Syria sponsored a truck-bomb attack on the Marine compound in Beirut last month.

title: 'NO CHILDREN' LANDLORDS SAY. STOP IT.
description: This Thanksgiving, while most of us sit in our homes among relatives and friends, many families with children have little cause to celebrate. They are needlessly facing housing problems that may leave them homeless as winter approaches.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST THURSDAY, NOVEMBER 24, 1983
description: The Economy The F.C.C. set standard national rental rates for Bell System telephones. It also ruled that after a two-year transitional period, starting Jan. 1, price regulations for the phones will be lifted. The decision, affecting about 120 million phones now rented by consumers and businesses, clears up one of the last major uncertainties associated with the coming breakup of A.T.& T. It will have the effect of raising some rental rates and lowering others. (Page A1.) The Consumer Price Index rose just 0.4 percent in October, with declines in gasoline and other energy prices helping to offset a jump in food prices, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. It said inflation so far this year is running at a 3.9 percent annual rate, matching the rate for all of 1982, a recession year. (D1.) New York City area prices also rose 0.4 percent. (D2.)

title: PRESIDENT OF PRINTERS APPARENTLY OUSTED BY UNION MEMBERS
description: The president of the International Typographical Union has apparently been defeated in his bid for a third term.

title: SMYSLOV WINS AS RIBLI BLUNDERS IN CHESS GAME
description: Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union won the first game of his semifinal world championship chess match when Zoltan Ribli of Hungary blundered a piece in their adjournment session tonight at the Great Eastern Hotel here.

title: HERS
description: The Hers column was designed as a forum for writing by women. For the next several weeks, it will be written by Alice Koller, a philosopher and the author of ''An Unknown Woman,'' published this year.

title: OCG TECHNOLOGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a tax credit of $7,532. c-Net loss

title: MCGREGOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 30
description: b-After net losses from discontinued operations of $391,000 for the quarter and $1,210,000 for the 9 months.

title: U.S. Military Reports Best Recruitment Year
description: A decade after the draft ended, the military had its best recruiting year ever, the Defense Department said today.

title: HIS OWN PETARD
