description: The Frankenstein's monster of the Reagan Administration - an obsession with secrecy that has unleashed the so-called lie detector on 112,000 formerly trusted officials - is now rising to maul its creators.

title: 2 Men Indicted In Trooper Killing
description: Two men who have been sought for nearly a decade were indicted today for the 1981 murder of a state trooper on a highway in northwestern New Jersey.

title: Eyewitness Found InWitness'sDeath
description: The police said yesterday that they had an eyewitness in the shooting death of a man who was about to testify in a Manhattan trial, and that detectives were searching for a man who had accompanied the killer to the murder scene.

title: PEABODY INTERNATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $544,000 for the quarter and $892,000 for the year. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $221,000.

title: THURSDAY SPORTS Football
description: Detroit Lions vs. Pittsburgh Steelers , at Pontiac, Mich. The Steelers are undefeated in their five games on the road this season, and Franco Harris, their top running back, is still chipping away at Jim Brown's career rushing record.

title: HARVARD STUDENT, HURT AT YALE GAME, IS NOW ABLE TO TALK
description: An 18-year-old Harvard student who suffered serious head injuries after last week's Harvard-Yale football game when she was hit by a falling goal post is now talking coherently and has been taken off a respirator, according to a spokesman for St. Raphael's Hospital in New Haven.

title: TEXAS GENERAL RESOURCES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $975,000 for the quarter and $503,000 for the 9 months.

title: LEWIS, PALMER G, CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 25
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding have been adjusted to reflect 4 percent stock dividends distributed in September 1982 and September 1983.

title: NETS WIN AT FINISH ON WILLIAMS'S SHOT
description: The Nets snapped a two-game losing streak tonight when Buck Williams, on an alley-oop play, caught an inbounds pass from Darwin Cook with a second left and, off-balance and falling away, hit a bank shot to give the Nets a 110- 108 victory over the Phoenix Suns.

title: Goodrich Outlook
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said its per-share net income for 1983 is likely to be lower than many analysts' estimates of $1.20 to $1.25.

title: SWISS CHOCOLATES' U.S. GOURMET SALES
description: -DE-FONDS, Switzerland - Pierre Alain Moreau's chocolates travel well.

title: Continental Loss
description: Continental Airlines will probably lose $6.2 million next month despite its reorganization under Federal bankruptcy laws, the carrier's treasurer said. The treasurer, Mickey Foret, asked United States Bankruptcy Judge R. F. Wheless Jr. on Tuesday to release $30 million in cash set aside as collateral against a $650 million long- term debt. Continental officials said they needed the money to make payments on principal and interest of loans and to pay deposits, bonds and escrow funds. Mr. Foret said that despite Continental's net loss, the airline projects it will have an operating profit of $2.5 million in December.

title: ALLAN KRIEGEL
description: Allan Kriegel, a partner of Schultz Management, a real-estate investment concern, died of a heart ailment on Sunday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital.

title: STARRETT CITY: INTEGRATION THAT WORKS
description: To the Editor:

title: MONDALE-GLENN CLASHES ON ARMS DEEP-ROOTED
description: When John Glenn and Walter F. Mondale exchanged political broadsides on the nation's defense last week, their statements reflected their differences over the years. Mr. Mondale has consistently been more skeptical of big new military proposals, and Mr. Glenn has been more wary of arms control agreements.

title: SCOUTING
description: On Jim Brown

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: FOR THE BIRDS This is not a day, really, for birdwatchers who do not care to observe their feathered friends, feet up, on a festive table. But there are birds, feet down and wings up, to be seen live today for those who like to get out. There are, for instance, 1,600 of them, representing 300 species, birds in residence at the New York Zoological Society's Bronx Zoo, Fordham Road and the Bronx River Parkway (367- 1010).

title:
HELPFUL HARDWARE;
VERTICAL SHOWER HEADS
description: IN the 1920's and 30's it was

title: Unilever Retirement
description: Frans van den Hoven said today he would retire in May as chairman of Unilever N.V. and vice chairman of Unilever P.L.C. Mr. van den Hoven, 60 years old, has been chairman of Unilever N.V., the Dutch arm of the giant consumer products company, for nine years.

title: Manuel J. Asensio, 77, Air Force Comptroller
description: Lieut. Gen. Manuel J. Asensio, former deputy chief of staff and comptroller of the Air Force and former Civil Defense Director of New York State, died Sunday after surgery for an aortic aneurysm at Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. The general was 77 years old and lived in Springfield, Va.

title: Leafs 6, Stars 4
description: Bill Derlago and Bill Harris each scored twice to help lift Toronto to a three-way tie for first place in the Norris Division with the North Stars and Black Hawks.

title: QUADREX CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income. c-After a writeoff of $335,000 of interest in a French company.

title: U.S. Tightens Security
description: Security at United States embassies and diplomatic posts across Europe is being strengthened as the United States moves to deploy medium-range nuclear missiles on the continent, State Department officials said today. The move came in anticipation of street demonstrations as the United States deploys Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Western Europe.

title: SHANNON OIL & GAS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $2,065,363 on the sale of investments. c-Net loss.

title: REAGAN, DISAPPOINTED, HOPES RUSSIANS RETURN
description: President Reagan said today that he was disappointed by the Russians' decision to break off the Geneva talks on medium- range missiles. But he said he was confident that ''they'll come back'' to the negotiating table.

title: Reward for Coach
description: It was a tough schedule that included six bowl-bound powerhouses, but Coach Dick MacPherson brought Syracuse its first winning season since 1979, and for that, university officials decided, MacPherson deserved a special pat on the back.

title: CONFERENCE CALLS: SOCIAL LIFE FOR THE HOMEBOUND
description: N Douglas Brite's normally lively Queens household there is a rule against making noise on Thursday afternoons at 2. That's when Mr. Bright receives his weekly conference call - an hourlong chat with contemporaries who, like himself, are homebound because of chronic physical disabilities. The callers, seven young men and women with a variety of illnesses, among them multiple sclerosis, cerebral palsy and Meni ere's disease, are joined by a trained social worker, who often does more listening than talking. Originally the members of the group were strangers, but they have been together for a year now, and the conversations reflect an easy camaraderie.

title: MOFFETT LINKS OUSTER TO MILLER
description: Ken Moffett, the deposed executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, charged yesterday that Marvin Miller, his predecessor and interim successor, had helped orchestrate his ouster. Miller and players who were involved in the decision denied Moffett's contention.

title: MARY TYLER MOORE IS WED
description: Mary Tyler Moore, the actress, and Dr. S. Robert Levine, a physician, were married last evening in the Pierre Hotel. Rabbi Richard Chapin performed the ceremony.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Telesphere's Staff Is Cut After Loss

title: SCOUTING
description: The Countdown In the N.F.C. East

title: COMPETITION IN AD CIRCULARS
description: Armed with what analysts say is the nation's most complete mailing list, Advo Systems Inc. is emerging as a strong challenger to the newspaper industry's dominance of the $2.5 billion business of distributing advertising circulars.

title: SONOR PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
RAN ENERGY INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
UNSPOILED NATURE IN TEXTILE DESIGNS
description: ''WHAT I depict are fractured moments of history and I try to express the conflicts as well as the blending between man and nature,'' says the Montana artist Dana Boussard, whose appliqued cotton velvet ''tapestries'' are currently on view at Modern Master Tapestries, 11 East 57th Street, through Dec. 10. ''I am anxious to say something about where I live and what I see there. I want to show the communication and the passage of time.''

title: MARMON GROUP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
PENGUINS RUIN MCVIE'S DEBUT
description: Ron Flockhart, Rick Kehoe and Mike Bullard scored one goal apiece as the Pittsburgh Penguins won their first game at home and spoiled the debut of Coach Tom McVie by beating the Devils, 4-1, tonight.

title: OUTLET CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $301,000 for the quarter and $1.2 million for the 9 months. c-Including extraordinary gains of $1,333,000 for the quarter and $6.1 million for the 9 months.

title: INTERNATIONAL LAW BENT BEYOND RECOGNITION
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. WILL EXPAND HELP FOR GRENADA
description: The Reagan Administration announced a $30 million package today of long-term military and economic aid for Grenada.

title: JUDGE TO RULE IF ARIEL SHARON CAN SUE ON MASSACRE ARTICLE
description: A Federal judge heard arguments in Manhattan yesterday on whether Ariel Sharon, an Israeli Cabinet officer, was ''libel proof'' concerning a massacre in Lebanon.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Rates Up a Bit in Quiet Day;  Uncertainty On Fed Cited
description: Interest rates rose slightly in quiet trading yesterday, with many securities dealers and investors on the sidelines in advance of the Thanksgiving Day holiday. Trading activity is expected to remain subdued on Friday.

title: ALL THE COMFORTS OF HOME IN A CAR
description: For most automobile makers today, less has become more. Cars are smaller, thriftier, more efficient. Customers want them that way. But, it must be admitted, there

title: LEGAL ONE-UPMANSHIP
description: To the Editor:

title: Comings and Goings
description: Charlie Criss, the 5-foot-8-inch guard who had been the shortest player in the National Basketball Association, has been cut by the Milwaukee Bucks and replaced by Lorenzo Romar , who had been cut by the Golden State Warriors on Nov. 10... Ed Karow , a member of the United States Olympic ski-jumping team, broke both ankles in a practice jump Sunday and was in stable condition yesterday following surgery at a Denver hospital. A second operation is scheduled for today.

title: No Ban on Hormone
description: Prince Alexandre de Merode of Belgium, the chairman of the International Olympic Committee's medical commission, said that somatropin, an expensive hormone that some athletes believe promotes growth and strength, would not be banned at the 1984 Olympics.

title: Belfast Bombing Wounds 9, Including 3 British Soldiers
description: A bomb exploded in a densely populated part of Belfast tonight, wounding nine people, including three British soldiers.

title: FireSweepsHome Of Housing Chief
description: The three-story Brooklyn home of the the city's Housing Commissioner, Anthony B. Gliedman, was heavily damaged in a fire, but he and his family escaped unharmed, authorities said yesterday.

title: Britain's Falkland Harrumph
description: Britain's Margaret Thatcher, of all people, should know the power of an aroused patriotism. Responding to a sneak invasion of the Falklands, she humbled Argentina's military rulers in a bold and highly popular war. But when they thought they might succeed, Argentines, too, were swept up by war fever. One of the few courageous dissenters was Raul Alfonsin, who called the attack ''an illegitimate act by an illegal Government in a just cause.''

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Watching and Hoping

title: MUSIC: ANNE MARIE MOSS AT TEDDY'S
description: Anne Marie Moss is a genial singer, sometimes too genial for her own good. In her performances at Teddy's, 219 West Broadway, where she will be through Dec. 3, she works to establish a close, easy relationship with her audience, but this sometimes leads her to become too casual in her singing.

title: Wells Fargo Unit Is Robbed Of an Estimated $2 Million
description: Two men wearing Halloween masks forced their way into the Wells Fargo Armored Service Corporation early today and escaped with an estimated $2 million in cash and negotiable securities, the police said.

title: Financing for Ecuador
description: The International Monetary Fund has cleared $85.4 million in special drawing rights for Ecuador in compensatory financing facilities, the manager of the central bank, Abelardo Pachano, said today. The I.M.F. also told Ecuador it is disbursing $39.4 million as the third slice of a $171 million stand-by agreement signed on June 1 after reviewing the country's progress, the official said.

title: U.S. SAYS FEED CORN IN TEXAS IS NOT DETERIORATING IN SILOS
description: The Agriculture Department said Wednesday that nearly 23 million bushels of Government-owned corn that Congress recently agreed to sell to drought-stricken farmers at reduced rates was not spoiling so badly as earlier tests indicated.

title: CITY BRINGING PRISONERS TO COURT MORE QUICKLY
description: Shortly after 8 o'clock on a recent morning, a blue and white bus with metal mesh over its windows rolled up to the back of the Criminal Courts Building in lower Manhattan.

title: Roadblock Checks Drunken Drivers
description: An estimated 1,850 motorists passed through a roadblock set up today by the state police to catch drunken drivers and 9 were arrested, the police said.

title: New England Search On For Missing General
description: The authorities say they are baffled by the disappearance of a National Guard general who has not been seen since he left his Boston headquarters for his home last week.

title: CONSERVATIVE STUDY GIVES REAGAN A MIXED RATING
description: As President Reagan approaches the end of his third year in office, many conservatives remain divided over his record.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Man Who 'Lost' America
description: As the Op-Ed page reminds us today, a little holler is in order for Bicentennial II. For it was just 200 years ago that the American Revolution ended with the final departure of the British from New York.

title: Jazz a Natural In Las Vegas
description: The Utah Jazz, in the first of 11 home games that they plan to play here this season, drew 13,176 fans Wednesday night to a new arena on the campus of the University of Nevada-Las Vegas. The crowd, which saw Utah lose to the Chicago Bulls by 128-117, was the largest for a Jazz home game since the franchise moved from New Orleans to Salt Lake City four years ago. At times though, this seemed to the Jazz more like a road game, because many in the crowd had come to cheer two former Nevada-Las Vegas players, Reggie Theus and Sidney Green, both of whom play for the Bulls.

title: Son Jazzbata Concert
description: The Cuban percussionist Daniel Ponce will lead his Latin jazz group, Son Jazzbata, featuring the Yoruba rhythms of the bata drum, tomorrow at Soundscape (581-7032), 500 West 52d Street. The group also includes Mario Rivera on saxophones, Nicky Marrero on timbales, Michael Camillo on piano, Steve Turre on trombone, Joe Santiago on bass and the singers Orlando (Puntilla) Rios and OluFemi Mitchell. The concert begins at 9 P.M., and tickets are $7.

title: IN GERMANY, MISSILES ANGST
description: Parliament this week approved the stationing of new American-made missiles, but it did not end a far-reaching debate about West Germany's national identity and the Atlantic alliance. Chancellor Helmut Kohl, whose conservative coalition has lately been strained by sharp bickering but pulled itself together for the two-day session that ended Tuesday night, stoutly defended NATO positions and carried the day. With the Government holding a solid and disciplined majority in Parliament, there had never been any doubt about a mathematical victory.

title: WILLIAMS SPRAWLS BUT GETS WINNER
description: PHOENIX Although they were surrounded by

title: RIBLI DEFEATS SMYSLOV TYING CHESS MATCH, 1-1
description: Zoltan Ribli of Hungary today bounced back from yesterday's defeat to take revenge on Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union in the second game of their semifinal world championshp chess match. The match is now tied at 1-1.

title: SCOUTING
description: Connors Fighting $10,000 Fine

title: A Bomb Explosion Damages Bolivian Parliament Building
description: A bomb exploded early today in the Bolivian Parliament building, causing extensive damage but no injuries, radio reports said.

title: THE DANGEROUS MYTH OF AN ANDROPOV ERA
description: To the Editor:

title: Quartet at Jazz Center
description: The tenor saxophonist George Coleman will lead a quartet tomorrow, featuring Harold Mabern on piano, at the Universal Jazz Coalition's Jazz Center of New York (924-5026), 380 Lafayette Street at Great Jones Street. The concert begins at 8 P.M., and tickets are $5.

title: Illinois Cracking Down On Drunken Driving
description: People arrested for drunken driving in connection with serious accidents would face immediate revocation of drivers' licenses under a new policy urged by Jim Edgar, the Illinois Secretary of State.

title: Nordiques Win, 6-3; Bruin Streak Ends;  N.H.L.
description: Two of the Stastny brothers, Peter and Marian, scored two goals each tonight and led the Quebec Nordiques to a 6-3 victory over the Boston Bruins.

title: MEASURE ON HOUSING SIGNALS NEW DIRECTION IN U.S. POLICY
description: In late 1982, Samuel R. Pierce, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, saw the realities of fiscal conservatism crush a social spending program he supported. Mr. Pierce was on the losing side in arguments within the Reagan Administration over financing for new Federal housing.

title: photos of people eating dinner; DINING LATE AT NIGHT: ELBOW ROOM ONLY
description: At 11:30 P.M. the crush begins in earnest at the Cafe Luxembourg. Even on the rainiest nights, when umbrellas seem to turn inside out from the sheer anxiety of it all, the number of people squeezing into the restaurant at 200 West 70th Street is staggering to behold.

title: PRIVATE-SCHOOL PARENTS TO MONITOR BUS SERVICE
description: A group of parents, concerned about the bus companies that take their children to various New York City private schools, have joined together to monitor the safety and responsibility of the carriers.

title: COMMONWEALTH NATIONS DEBATE GRENANDA INVASION
description: A debate opened today at the meeting of the Commonwealth nations over the United States-led invasion of Grenada, a member of the Commonwealth.

title: CORRECTION
description: Because of an editing error, the Market Place column in Business Day on Wednesday incorrectly described the stock that shareholders in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company will receive after its divestiture of seven regional phone companies. For every 10 shares of A.T.& T. now held, shareholders will receive one new share of each regional company. They will also retain their existing Telephone shares.

title: JERSEY UTILITY FAULTED ON ATOMIC-PLANT COMPETENCE
description: The New Jersey Public Advocate has told a Federal licensing board that the state's largest utility lacks management competence to operate the $3.8 billion Hope Creek nuclear plant being built in the southwest part of the state.

title: A FILIPINO VETERAN DELIVERS HIS 'SWAN SONG' TO THE U.N.
description: Carlos P. Romulo, the 84-year-old Foreign Minister of the Philippines, who took part in the founding of the United Nations in 1945, delivered this week what he called ''my swan song'' at the world organization.

title: Centrowitz Wins
description: Matt Centrowitz of the New York Athletic Club overtook Sosthenes Bitok of Kenya with half a mile to go and went on to win the Port Washington Thanksgiving Day five- mile run by 5 seconds today in the record time of 23 minutes 23 seconds. Centrowitz bettered the mark of 23:27 set two years ago by Craig Virgin. Marilyn Hulak of the Atalanta Track Club was the first woman to finish, in 27:52.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Classical Coincidence

title: SCOUTING
description: A Hockey Gem

title: PAUL J. POWERS
description: Paul J. Powers, former chief law assistant of the New York County Surrogate's Court, died Tuesday at St. Vincent's hospital after a heart attack.

title: SCOUTING
description: Swedish Bowler

title: EXAMINING THE BANK EXAMINERS
description: Two recent Government reports have raised what many experts see as disturbing questions about the ability of Federal banking regulators to identify certain types of bank mismanagement and to compel wayward banks to mend their ways.

title: New Research Disputes Link Between Valium and Defects
description: The tranquilizer Valium, until recently the most prescribed drug in the United States, probably does not cause certain birth defects in babies of mothers who took the drug, doctors said this week.

title: STROEK REHABILITATION, EAST AND WEST
description: To the Editor:

title: ADVERTISING ; 2 Business Publications Due in New York City
description: As business publications for individual cities continue to increase throughout the country, New York is suddenly in line for at least two of them.

title: Shift at Lever Brothers Part of Unilever Change
description: The executive realignment kicked off by H. F. van den Hoven's decision on Wednesday to retire his chairman posts at Unilever next May will leave a quintessential company man in charge of the concern's troubled North American operations. Mr. van den Hoven is stepping down as chairman of the giant consumer company's British arm, Unilever P.L.C., and as vice chairman of the Dutch arm, Unilever N.V.

title: North Korean Envoys Linked to Burma Blast
description: A Foreign Ministry official testified today that North Korean Embassy employees had sheltered three army officers accused of a setting a bomb aimed at South Korea's President, Chun Doo- Hwan, and his top leaders.

title: Mt. St. Michael Sets Back Hayes
description: David McLaughlin scored the winning touchdown on a 7-yard run in the fourth quarter yesterday as host Mount St. Michael beat Cardinal Hayes, 20-12, and took a 19-17 lead in a holiday series that began in 1943.

title: JAZZ: NAT ADDERLEY LEADS HIS QUARTET
description: The Nat Adderley Quintet, which is appearing through tomorrow at Sweet Basil, has the spunk and assurance that comes only from steady work as a group. Mr. Adderley, a trumpeter, has kept his current band intact for the last three years, and its first set Tuesday was graceful, exploratory and insatiably aggressive.

title: ART: PAULA MODERSOHN-BECKER'S EXPRESSIONISM
description: In turn-of-the-century Germany, Paula Modersohn-Becker (1876-1907) was something new and strange, a woman painter of high ambition - and talent, to boot. By the time of her early death, she had produced enough (more than 500 paintings) to make clear her increasingly strong role in the wedding of French modernism with German realism. As can be seen in the show of her work that is at the Galerie St. Etienne, 24 West 57th Street, through Jan. 7, she had absorbed the ideas of the Paris Post-Impressionists - notably Cezanne and Gauguin - before they were well known in Germany, fusing with them her own breed of Teutonic Romanticism. Today, she is regarded as a kind of proto-Expressionist.

title: Shooting for No. 700
description: Clarence (Bighouse) Gaines , who has sent Earl Monroe and Cleo Hill to the National Basketball Association in his 37 years as coach at Winston- Salem State College in North Carolina, will be seeking his 700th career victory tonight when the Rams face Barber-Scotia College of Concord, N.C. Gaines might have reached the milestone last season, except that he spent parts of it away from the team while tending to his dying mother. Gaines's 1967 team, led by Monroe, won the National Collegiate Athletic Association college-division title, and the 60-year-old coach looks forward to another title.

title: WIDE DISPARITY FOUND IN HOW 4 STATES HANDLE FELONY CASES
description: A Justice Department survey released today has found a wide disparity in how states deal with people charged with felonies, with one state prosecuting 97 percent of them and another only 8 percent.

title: G.I.'S IN SINAI TAKE A BREAK FROM THEIR BOREDOM
description: Pvt. Richard Gaona of San Antonio took a bite of turkey and peered out of his tiny sentry house at the sparkling blue waters of the Gulf of Elat.

title: Sea Gull Encounter Forces Jet to Turn Back
description: A Florida-bound jetliner leaving Midway Airport was forced to turn around and land today after a sea gull was sucked into one of its engines, shutting it down shortly after takeoff, officials said.

title: Gemayel and Reagan Will Thursday
description: The White House announced today that President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon will visit President Reagan next Thursday to ''explore alternative approaches'' to the withdrawal of foreign troops from Lebanon.

title: IOWA DEMOCRATS SY ONLY MONDALE'S MARGIN OF VICTORY IN DOUBT
description: Leading Iowa Democrats say they are taking it for granted that Walter F. Mondale is well ahead in the nation's first battle for Presidential nominating delegates.

title: DEFENSE CITES GUNPOWDER TESTS IN MOURNER'S TRIAL
description: Gunpowder tests conducted on a man now on trial for attempted murder, kidnapping and robbery could not determine whether he fired a gun in a confrontation between black mourners and two white police officers, a state expert testified for the defense today,

title: DANCE: RINA SCHENFELD IN THREE SONGS SOLOS
description: SOMETHING different even within a series designed to be different is what the Israeli dancer Rina Schenfeld is presenting this weekend as part of the Brooklyn Academy of Music's experimental ''Next Wave'' programs.

title: Diner's Journal
description: NOT long ago, restaurants in most of the city's large department stores fell somewhere between diners and neighborhood ''family restaurants.'' They served simple soups, sandwiches and always a ''dieter's special,'' that ubiquitous igloo of cottage cheese mounted on lettuce with fruits (usually canned) scattered about. In recent years, some of the stores have upgraded their restaurants, partly because it is a trend, and they are moneymakers in their own right, but also, according to a spokesman for one leading store who requested anonymity, ''If we can keep customers from leaving the store for lunch, they are more likely to stay around longer and make more nonfood purchases.''

title: CRITICS' CHOICES: BEST IN THE ARTS FOR THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Music

title: REPORT RECCOMENDS JERSEY INSURANCE BOARD
description: Insurance commissioners travel between the insurance industry and New Jersey's regulatory office through a ''revolving door,'' according to a report released this week by the state's Department of the Public Advocate.

title: PUBLISHING: PROTECTING BOOK RIGHTS
description: Book publishers are still trying to sort out the implications of last week's ruling upholding the right of the magazine The Nation to publish information from former President Gerald R. Ford's memoirs, but they agree almost unanimously that the ruling will have a substantial effect on the way they do business - especially on the sale of serialization rights.

title: ADVER
description: People

title: THE DANCE: 'LET HER'
description: rate in ''Let Her,'' the hourlong work that was presented Monday night at the Bessie Sch"onberg Theater. Yet, for all its virtues, ''Let Her'' seemed inconsequential.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Chance to Save

title: OF HALF-CENT KILOWATT-HOURS AND A QUESTIONABLE YARDSTICK
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1983

title: FRAZIER, UNDERDOG, IS NOT UNDERSTATED
description: Joe Frazier's kid, still believing father knows best, really and truly believes he can beat Larry Holmes here Friday night.

title: Mediator in Pilots' Strike
description: Benjamin Aaron, a specialist in labor law who teaches at the University of California at Los Angeles, has agreed to mediate the pilots' strike against Continental Air Lines that began nearly two months ago after the airline filed for bankruptcy reorganization. Mr. Aaron said the two sides met this week in Los Angeles and agreed to meet again next week.

title: An East German Flees
description: A 20-year-old East German frontier guard fled across the border into West Germany Wednesday night, the Bavarian police said today. The soldier crossed at a section of the frontier that is not mined, the police said, and was unhurt.

title: 5 Winners for Apprentice
description: Jose C. Ferrer, an apprentice jockey, set a Meadowlands thoroughbred-racing record for riding the most victories in a program when he won five races today, including four in a row. Ferrer, a 19-year-old native of Puerto Rico who lives in Long Branch, N.J., increased his meet-victory total to 45, putting him in second place in the standing.

title: 2d Korean Child HasHeartSurgery
description: The second of two South Korean children brought to the United States for open-heart surgery was operated on yesterday at St. Francis Hospital in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Musical Video Montage
description: ''Three Million Years of History in Two Minutes,'' a video montage set to music, can be seen free through tomorrow in an exhibition sponsored by the National Geographic Society at the Market in the Citicorp Building, Lexington Avenue and 53d Street. The installation, ''Peoples and Places of the Past,'' also features artifacts, photographs and a 28-foot time chart. Open daily, 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. Also in the Market on Sundays at noon this month, free classical concerts are being given by students from the Mannes College of Music.

title: Dr. Shangold Wed to Dr. Gabe Mirkin
description: Dr. Mona Shangold, assistant professor of obstetrics and gynecology at Cornell University Medical College and director of the sports gynecology center at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, was married yesterday to Dr. Gabe Mirkin, a radio commentator on fitness and a syndicated columnist. Rabbi Aaron Chomsky performed the ceremony at the Richfield Regency in Verona, N.J.

title: BIG APPLE'S MINI-CIRCUS PITCHES TENT
description: ABRIGHT blue tent has engulfed part of Lincoln Center, a sign that the Big Apple Circus is back in town for its third holiday season in Damrosch Park.

title: CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION CALLS REAGAN'S YEAR OF THE BIBLE' ILLEAGAL
description: President Reagan's proclamation of 1983 as ''The Year of the Bible'' illegally recognizes Christianity as the official religion of the United States and gives it ''God's imprimatur,'' according to arguments made in Federal District Court by a lawyer for the American Civil Liberties Union.

title: BROADWAY
description: ALEXANDER H. COHEN was pleased. Business, he said, has been ''fantastic'' at the Vivian Beaumont, since last Friday's reviews of ''La Tragedie de Carmen,'' Peter Brook's adaptation of the Bizet opera. In fact, lots of people have been unable to get through to CenterCharge at Lincoln Center.

title: SUCCESSION PLAN STIRRING NEW ATTACKS ON MARCOS
description: Many businessmen and political opponents say a plan by President Ferdinand E. Marcos's ruling party to restore the vice presidency, abolished 10 years ago, will not end their demands that Mr. Marcos resign.

title: Required Reading 'Creative Writing'
description: Representative Gerald B. H. Solomon, Republican of New York, in remarks on the House floor, Nov. 1, 1983:

title: Saints Reported Under Inquiry
description: Several players for the New Orleans Saints have been questioned in two Federal investigations into drug use and distribution, a television station here reported Wednesday.

title: B-52 Is Damaged In Upstate Protest
description: Seven antinuclear protesters broke into a hangar at Griffiss Air Force Base today and apparently battered a B-52 bomber with hammers, damaging its bomb-bay doors, a base spokesman said.

title: CRITICS'S CHOICES: BEST IN THE ARTS FOR THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Dance

title: CRITICS'S CHOICES: THE BEST IN THE ARTS FOR THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: To no one's surprise, ''The Big Chill'' has emerged as one of the big hits of the fall season. Lawrence Kasdan's film about former college friends may not examine the psyches of its characters in much depth, but it uses their midlife anxieties to generate humor, warmth, camaraderie and enormous fun. No other film of the season has a more appealing cast, a friendlier ambience or a hotter score. The soundtrack of 1960's hits provides both a clever commentary on the action and a visceral energy that keeps the film on its toes. ''The Big Chill'' is at the Paramount, Loews New York Twin and other theaters.

title: COWBOYS BEAT CARDS BY 35-17
description: Tony Dorsett ran for two touchdowns and became the National Football League's eighth-leading career rusher today, leading the playoff- bound Dallas Cowboys to a 35-17 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

title: FRIDAY SPORTS
description: Basketball Nets vs. Los Angeles Lakers, at Inglewood, Calif. The next game on this long trip is against Kareem Abdul- Jabbar and his teammates.

title: ALABAMA VOTES PLAN TO EASE JAILS' OVERCROWDING
description: The Alabama Legislature, prodded by Gov. George C. Wallace, is seeking to comply with a Federal court order by its approval of two bills designed to alleviate overcrowding of state inmates in county jails.

title: AROUND THE WORLD
description: 2 White South Africans Jailed for Aiding Rebels

title: A BANQUET OF GIVING AND CHEER
description: Thanksgiving dinner at the Advent Lutheran Church was, as usual, a bountiful and madcap affair, prepared by community workers in honor of their 350 guests - men and women who live in bleak welfare hotels on Manhattan's Upper West Side.

title: Laurie Levander Bride Of Paul Finn in Jersey
description: Laurie Larson Levander, daughter of Mrs. Carl Luckerath of Seattle and the late Leslie M. Larson, was married yesterday to Paul J. Finn, son of Mrs. John F. X. Finn and the late Mr. Finn of New York. The Rev. John Caufield performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert E. Ferdon in Alpine, N.J.

title: PRESIDENT OF FISK UNIVERSITY RESIGNS AS SCHOOL STRUGGLES
description: Fisk University's president resigned Wednesday as supporters scrambled to avert the financial collapse of the school, one of the nation's most prestigious historically black colleges.

title: Turk Is Charged With Slander In Implication of a Bulgarian
description: An Italian magistrate has charged Mehmet Ali Agca, the Turk who was convicted of shooting Pope John Paul II in 1981, with slander for saying a Bulgarian was involved in a purported plot to murder Lech Walesa, the Italian news agency Ansa reported today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Stress on Growth At Bank of Boston

title: BAND'S REUNION RECALLS ITS 'LAST WALTZ'
description: WHEN the Band reconvenes at the Beacon Theater tonight and tomorrow for a 2 1/2-hour show, the timing of the event will have poignant overtones for anyone who has followed the group's fortunes.

title: AUCTIONS
description: MOST of the major Latin American artists of the 20th century are represented in sales next week at New York's two major auction houses. Diego Rivera's paintings of women and children, Wilfredo Lam's Surrealist and abstract studies, and Fernando Botero's outrageously plump people and his appetizing still lifes are expected to command the highest prices.

title: DANCE: JOEL HALL TROUPE PRESENTS JAZZ REPERTORY
description: -based company that opened Tuesday at the Joyce Theater, is something of a surprise. Billed as performing jazz dance, the 17-member troupe has more to offer than the hard-sell hips, shoulders and pelvic thrusts and spinning turns that identify the style.

title: THE NUCLEAR APPLE
description: Pacifism, the editor of Le Monde said recently, never prevented a war. That is true. Of course, neither did militarism.

title: Mother Teresa Is Honored
description: Queen Elizabeth II today presented Britain's Order of Merit to the Nobel Prize-winning missionary Mother Teresa for her work among the sick and destitute. ''I accept it for the glory of God and also our work,'' the 73-year- old Roman Catholic nun said. The Order of Merit is the highest award a British sovereign can bestow personally.

title: DERMATOLOGY EXPERT HELD POST AT N.Y.U.
description: Dr. Marion Baldur Sulzberger, a physician who helped establish the modern field of dermatology in the United States, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in San Francisco. He was 88 years old.

title: PRETORIA ISSUES NEW POLICY ON BLACK SCHOOLS
description: The South African Government pledged this week that it would move to improve educational standards for the country's black majority.

title: Advertising; Cable's Traveling Teacher
description: NOW that he has steeped himself in the mysteries of the new electronic media, Richard L. Gilbert, an ad agency president for 25 years, is preparing to take to the road to spread his knowledge.

title: BIG AIRLIFT TO A WESTEN FRONT
description: When Rolfe Arnhym throws a party, he does it in a big way.

title: REAGAN DISMAYED AT MOSCOW'S MOVE
description: President Reagan said today that Yuri V. Andropov's announcement of plans to counter NATO missile deployment with new Soviet weapons was at ''sharp variance'' with previous Russian calls for arms agreement.

title: RISKY GROWTH IN CATALOGUES
description: The companies whose Christmas catalogues inundate the mails every fall, in anticipation of strong retail sales over the holidays, have churned out a record number this year. So many, in fact, that some merchandisers are talking about an ''over-catalogued'' market and a shakeout in the industry.

title: STAGE: CIRCLE REP OFFERS 'SEA GULL'
description: It's a mystery why Chekhov is so consistently manhandled in the New York theater. Not only do we have an abundance of talented actors, but we also have theatrical institutions willing to commit time and care to the mounting of the plays: this year alone we've seen major stagings of ''The Three Sisters,'' at the Manhattan Theater Club, and of ''Uncle Vanya,'' in Andrei Serban's radical reinterpretation at La Mama. Yet, in these and other recent productions, the Chekhov spirit eludes most of the cast and the audience. The writer so aptly described by Vladimir Nabokov as ''the genius of the casual'' is quickly buried under either heavy melodrama or busy farce.

title: Turks Bar Cyprus Statement
description: A meeting of foreign ministers of the Council of Europe ended in uproar today after Turkey vetoed publication of a final communique condemning the declaration of independence by the Turks in Cyprus. For the first time in the 34-year history of the 21-member Council, the ministers failed to agree on a final joint communique. Turkey vetoed publication of the statement despite the fact a draft version had been issued to reporters.

title: The U.N. Today Nov. 25, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: EXECUTIVES
description: -P-A Transport Corp., North Bergen, N.J., has named Armand Pohan president, succeeding Arthur E. Imperatore, who continues as chairman and chief executive officer.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Every mother is happy today.'' - Umm Bassam, a Palestinian whose son was freed by Israel. (A12:6.)

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday FROM ANDES AND BEYOND

title: HOLLYWOOD'S LIMITS
description: To the Editor:

title: NEW YORK, TODAY IS EVACUATION DAY
description: Today is Evacuation Day, one of the most important dates in the history of New York City. And yet it appears that it will pass without so much as a little holler, let alone a ticker-tape parade, from residents.

title: ART: SONIA GECHTOFF'S NEW DIRECTIONS
description: Sonia Gechtoff has taken another giant step. For some time, her flat, discreet, collagelike paintings have contained shadowy but recognizable architectural forms. Invariably, however, those forms were little more than the starting point for a passionate exploration of composition and color.

title: VISHNIAC'S LOST WORLD OF THE JEWS
description: ROMAN VISHNIAC sat in his West Side apartment, amid piles of photographs, showcases of Oriental art objects and bookcases of leather-bound scientific tomes in many languages, and filtered from aching memory a saga of danger and triumph in which he outraced the Nazis to make a gripping photographic record of Jewish life and culture before it was obliterated by the Holocaust.

title: BISHOPS TO DRAFT ECONOMIC MESSAGE
description: A committee of Roman Catholic bishops has completed two years of hearings in preparation for writing a pastoral letter on the relationship between Catholic social teaching and the American economy. The bishops said they would not discuss the contents of the letter until after the Presidential election next year, to avoid its possible use for partisan political purposes.

title: The Chinese in Photos
description: Photographs of Chinese-American communities can be seen in two exhibitions at the Central Research Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street.

title: Dome Debt Disclosed
description: Dome Petroleum Ltd. disclosed in its regular quarterly filing to the United States Securities and Exchange Commission that it owes $96 million to a Dow Chemical Company unit.

title: THE BUDGET PROCESS? WHAT'S THAT?
description: When Congress adjourned and slipped off into the night last week, it left its once-vaunted budget process in tatters.

title: Money Fund Assets Decline;  Money Fund Assets Drop
description: Assets of the nation's money market mutual funds declined for the second consecutive week in the period ended Tuesday, the Investment Company Institute said.

title: ACCESS TO WHITE HOUSE IS IMPEDED BY DUMP TRUCKS IN SECURITY MOVE
description: Unusual security surrounded the White House today as the Secret Service stationed dump trucks loaded with sand at most of the gates. A few blocks away, cars and trucks were used to block the driveways and garage doors at the State Department in response to a reported bomb threat.

title: NICARAGUA GIVES CRITICS PROMISE OF CONCESSIONS
description: The Nicaraguan Government has made a series of conciliatory gestures to its domestic critics in an effort to ease tensions and to respond to criticism by some Western European and Latin American nations.

title: RESTAURANTS
description: THE frenetic pace of the city recedes as you

title: FOR YALE EDITOR, 50 YEARS OF WALPOLE
description: For nearly 50 years, Warren Hunting Smith sat in a room of Yale University's Sterling Library and wrote footnotes to another man's letters.

title: L.S.U. Triumphs, 20-7
description: Dalton Hilliard and Garry James, Louisiana State tailbacks, broke open a sloppily played game in the third quarter with a touchdown apiece in a 20-7 victory tonight over Tulane.

title: A GOLF COMPETITION FOR TAKING SKINS
description: ''Skins'' is a stakes game played by golfers, and this weekend four of the world's most successful professionals - Jack Nicklaus, Arnold Palmer, Tom Watson and Gary Player - will play an event billed as ''The Skins Game'' for a purse of $360,000. Theoretically, one player could win it all.

title: Ira A. Schur, Former Partner InNewYorkAccountingFirm
description: Ira A. Schur, former senior partner of the Manhattan accounting firm of S. D. Leidesdorf & Company, died Tuesday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: CAMDEN MAKES HOUSE CALLS FOR TAXES
description: Taxpayers in financially troubled Camden who owe more than $2,000 can expect a knock on the door rather than just a mailed notice to pay up. The house calls will be unannounced.

title: 'THE QUIET DUEL' BY AKIRA KUROSAWA
description: Students of the work of Akira Kurosawa may want to make a trip to the Thalia theater, where a double bill of ''Rashomon'' (1950) and ''The Quiet Duel'' (1949) opens a two-day run today. ''Rashomon'' is an acknowledged Kurosawa classic. ''The Quiet Duel,'' which is, I'm told, having its New York theatrical premiere, is a footnote to a great career.

title: BIGGER ROLE IN LENDING FOR JAPAN
description: The Western trading partners have tentatively agreed to a Japanese request that it become the second-largest shareholder in the World Bank after the United States, according to diplomatic sources.

title: BEGIN ISSUES RADIO WELCOME
description: Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin, emerging from months of reclusive silence, spoke to the nation twice on radio today to welcome home six freed Israeli prisoners.

title: PALESTINIANS AND ISRAELIS WELCOME THEIR PRISONERS FREED IN EXCHANGE
description: Six Israeli soldiers, held prisoner for more than 14 months by the Palestine Liberation Organization in Lebanon, returned home today to a tumultuous, passionate welcome.

title: Report on Packer Back
description: Eddie Lee Ivery , a running back with the Green Bay Packers, has checked into the Hazelden Foundation Drug and Rehabilitation Center near Minneapolis, according to a report in yesterday's issue of The Green Bay Press Gazette. Ivery, on the National Football League's four-week nonillness reserve list since Oct. 29, did not return to active duty this week as expected, but Coach Bart Starr declined comment on the newspaper report.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: THE Film Forum, 57 Watts Street, is playing through Dec. 6 a program of two short movies about theater. ''Rockaby,'' the D. A. Pennebaker-Chris Hegedus picture, shows the progress of a Samuel Beckett work from its first rehearsal to its world premiere, on Mr. Beckett's 75th birthday in 1981, while ''Joe Chaikin Going On'' is a portrait of the director-actor- teacher who founded the Open Theater.

title: 'WATCHDOG' OVER M.T.A. STIRS WORRY
description: Behind a steel door with a hand-lettered paper sign that reads ''M.T.A. Inspector General,'' Sidney Schwartz is systematically assembling a force of 93 lawyers, auditors, investigators and support workers to find out what, if anything, is wrong with the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

title: AN UNUSUAL ARRAY OF SMALL ARCHITECTURAL SHOWS
description: If the major museums are relatively quiet on the architectural front this season - only the Cooper-Hewitt has had an active schedule of major exhibitions - smaller institutions and galleries have more than taken up the slack. There is an unusual array of small architectural exhibitions in New York this autumn, ranging from a celebration of the work of the architectural metalworker who designed all the ornamental iron at the Federal Reserve Bank in Lower Manhattan to a homage to the eclectic architecture of Brooklyn.

title: CHAIRMAN OF IBH RESIGNS
description: Horst- Dieter Esch resigned today as chairman of IBH Holding A.G., the big construction equipment manufacturer that was at the center of a recent banking crisis here, acknowledging defeat in his efforts to salvage the company.

title: MUSIC: 5 CONTEMPORARY COMPOSERS
description: Tuesday evening's concert by the Group for Contemporary Music at Symphony Space was introduced by a sour polemic from Ruth Dreier, who prefaced her program notes with the derri ere-garde's assumption that it alone can lay claim to seriousness.

title: SCREEN: 'WILD STYLE,' A BRONX VIEW
description: ''Wild Style'' was shown as part of the 1983 New Directors/New Films Series. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times last March 18. The film opened Wednesday at the Embassy 46th Street, on Broadway.

title: MUSIC: YUVAL WALDMAN PLAYS
description: YUVAL WALDMAN'S violin recital at the 92d Street Y on Tuesday night was intelligently played. Accompanied by his wife, the pianist Cathy Waldman, the Russian-born violinist exhibited qualities associated with the violin schools of his native land.

title: MONEY BROKERS UNDER FIRE
description: When the First National Bank of Midland in Texas collapsed last month in the second-biggest failure in United States banking history, Federal investigators discovered that about 13 percent of its deposits had come from money brokers.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan How Analysts View Kodak
description: EASTMAN KODAK's stock has been rising lately, but the giant photographic and chemical company is still getting mixed reviews from the investment community.

title: Moe Makes a Point
description: The Denver Nuggets, who purposely stopped playing defense at their coach's order in the final moments of Tuesday's 156-116 loss to the Portland Trail Blazers, asserted themselves Wednesday night and beat the San Diego Clippers by 133- 114.

title: Gen. Sir Evelyn Barker; Led Troops in Palestine
description: Gen. Sir Evelyn Barker, the former commander of British troops in Palestine, died Wednesday. He was 89 years old.

title: MANAGUA ASKS SALVADOR REBEL CHIEFS TO LEAVE
description: The Nicaraguan Government has asked Salvadoran rebel leaders in Managua to leave the country, according to well- placed leftist political figures in Central America.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES: BEST IN THE ARTS FOR THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Nine New York Times critics offer their choices for the city's best in entertainment on this long holiday weekend. It is generally a good idea to telephone ahead to make sure everything is on schedule.

title: Queens Man Tries To 'Arrest' Driver
description: A Queens man was arrested yesterday and charged with posing as a police officer. The authorities said he had stopped a woman driving an auto and tried to order her into his car.

title: NEW CONDOMINIUMS ARE ON THE RISE IN STATEN ISLAND
description: The low-rise condominium market is thriving in a western corner of Staten Island known as Graniteville.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Cuomo's Personal View

title: Shari Rubin and T. M. Steinberg Wed
description: Shari Beth Rubin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Morris Rubin of Cedarhurst, L.I., was married yesterday to Thomas Mills Steinberg, son of Geraldine and Goodwin P. Steinberg of Los Altos Hills, Calif. Rabbi Ephraim Buchwald performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth Sholom in Lawrence, L.I.

title: Peru Checking Report Linking Police to Killings
description: The antiterrorist military command said today that it was investigating reports that police forces were involved in the massacre of 32 peasants on Nov. 13.

title: WILLIAM H. PUTCH
description: William H. Putch, a director and the husband of the actress Jean Stapleton, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Crouse-Irving Memorial Hospital here. He was 60 years old.

title: CORRECTION
description: A picture caption on Tuesday, with an article on Dallas, misidentified the site of an inscription commemorating the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. It was Dealey Plaza.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article in Sports Pages on Wednesday about Bruce Kuczenski of the New Jersey Nets misidentified the University of Connecticut basketball coach. He is Dom Perno.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE OIL FOLLIES OF 1970-80: How the Petroleum Industry Stole the Show (and Much More Besides). By Robert Sherrill. 590 pages. Anchor Press-Doubleday. $19.95.

title: Man, 20, Stabbed to Death In Midtown by a Passer-By
description: A 20-year-old man was stabbed to death outside his family's apartment on Ninth Avenue at 52d Street yesterday while his father watched, the police said.

title: Dollar Surges in Light Trade
description: Backed by higher interest rates, the dollar surged to record highs against the Italian lira and French franc today in light European trading. Gold prices were virtually unchanged.

title: PARADE'S STAR QUALITY UNDIMMED BY RAIN OR MICKEY MOUSE MISHAP
description: Kermit the Frog floated high and green, waiting for Macy's 57th annual Thanksgiving Day Parade to begin. Olive Oyl, wearing her usual bun and high-button shoes, was ready to go. But between these two towering balloons, there was an empty piece of tarpaulin reserved for a perennial favorite - Mickey Mouse.

title: Coast City Settles a Bias Case ; City on Coast Settles With U.S. in Bias Case
description: A city accused by the Justice Department of discriminating against employees' pregnant wives has agreed to pay $35,000 to $40,000 in retroactive benefits for medical bills it had refused to pay.

title: OPERA: 'SNOW WHITE' REVIVAL
description: ''LOVING is a lot like indifference - when you love a lot you learn not to care,'' goes one of the many aphorisms in the libretto of Al Carmines's 1971 opera, ''The Journey of Snow White.'' In the T.R.G. Repertory's spirited revival at the Wonderhorse Theater, the opera, for which Mr. Carmines wrote words and music, suggests a Jungian ''Midsummer Night's Dream'' by way of ''Hair.''

title: Passaic Tops Montclair
description: Craig Heyward, the senior tailback, ran for two touchdowns and gave Passaic a 13-9 victory over Montclair before 9,000 fans yesterday in Montclair. Passaic improved its record to 10-0.

title: Howell Upsets Ocean
description: Tom Papa, a senior fullback, ran for two touchdowns to help Howell score a 26-12 upset victory over Ocean (9-1) in Ocean yesterday. Papa broke 91 yards in the first period for the first touchdown of the game and capped the scoring in a 20-point fourth quarter for Howell with a 4-yard run. Howell (5-4) had come back from a 12-7 deficit when Mike Barnes ran 25 yards and Steve Lubach ran 9 yards for touchdowns.

title: AIRLINE DEREGULATION STRANDING SOME TOWNS
description: They used to call it the ''Merced Milk Run,'' the United Airlines Boeing 737 jet that stopped several times a day here and in nearby Visalia, Modesto, Stockton and Bakersfield. But the Milk Run doesn't stop at any of those places anymore.

title: BITTER FLAREUP AT GETTY OVER CONTROL OF TRUST
description: A fleeting truce between the Getty Oil Company and a son of its founder, the late billionaire J. Paul Getty, has erupted into an acrimonious legal clash over the future of the $12 billion company.

title: Pine Tar Special
description: The Hillerich & Bradsby Company, the manufacturer of the Louisville Slugger baseball bat, knows a good promotion when it sees one, and it is introducing a Pine Tar Special model to commemorate George Brett 's famous off-again, on-again home run. Brett was using a T-85 model bat on July 24 when he hit the homer against the Yankees that spurred weeks of wrangling.

title: SOVIET TO BOLSTER NUCLEAR ARSENAL AT SEA AGAINST U.S.
description: Statement by Andropov, page A18.

title: MUSIC: LIONEL HAMPTO AND BAND
description: UNTIL two years ago Lionel Hampton, who was then 73, seemed to be easing off in his career as a big-band leader. For some time the vibraphonist and drummer had been dividing his time between a small group and, when the occasion arose, a big band that could be drawn together from a pool of musicians who performed with him frequently.

title: No Headline
description: Traveling America's highways is a very black-and- white experience in ''100 Views Along the Road,'' a stunning show of watercolor landscapes by Alfred Leslie, which is at the Oil & Steel Gallery, 157 Chambers Street, through Dec. 3. Using a black watercolor palette on white paper, Mr. Leslie gives us a driver's-eye view of roads leading from California to Massachusetts, replete with the geological, climatic and man-made scenery that attends them. We see, for instance, a rainbow born in a black sky, the dunes outside of Provincetown, Mass., a vast coal pile near the Ohio River, beaches, drive-in theaters, full moons and rising suns over mountains and deserts. The idea comes from the multiple-view prints of such subjects as the Tokaido Road and Mount Fuji by the 19th-century Japanese artists Hokusai and Hiroshige, but Mr. Leslie has made it very much his own.

title: CONSORT WITH ISRAEL WITHOUT ANY SHAME
description: The Administration should abandon its failed policy of placating the Arab world while avoiding any supposedly embarrassing identification with Israel.

title: THE RACE GOES ON
description: That was an ironic coincidence - the Bundestag voting on the 20th anniversary of John Kennedy's murder to give final approval to the deployment of Pershing 2 missiles on West German soil, six minutes from Soviet targets.

title: Don't Reject the Shipping Windfall
description: ''I never thought it would be so hard to give back tens of millions of dollars in Government subsidies,'' says one shipping company executive. But a company willing to pay back the subsidy for international shipping gains access to the lucrative domestic Alaskan oil trade. Those who fear the added competition are pressuring the Reagan Administration to reject the paybacks.

title: IRAQIS FACING NEED TO WIN IN GULF SOON
description: Senior military analysts and diplomats say they believe that Iraq, fearful of losing a war of economic attrition with Iran, may try to widen the war by forcing Iran to take military action to close the Persian Gulf. A senior official of the Baghdad Government said recently that Iraq had already fired Soviet-made surface-to-surface missiles at Kharg Island, the Iranian oil terminal at the head of the gulf, and neutral military analysts believe that there will be further attacks from missile sites in Iraq.

title: PRESS LAWYERS SAY IMPACT ON NATION RULING WILL BE LIMITED
description: Lawyers who represent news organizations say a court decision upholding The Nation magazine in publishing an article about Presidential memoirs does not open the door to wholesale use by the press of other works by public figures.

title: P.L.O. AIDE SAYS EXCHANGE IS VICTORY FOR ARAFAT
description: Yasir Arafat's senior military aide said today that the exchange of 6 Israeli soldiers for 4,500 Palestinians represented a victory for Mr. Arafat.

title: JAPANESE TACKLE AN AMERICAN GAME
description: A spirited chant of ''De-fense, De-fense'' rose from one side of the stadium on a recent Saturday afternoon, but to no avail. The red-clad men on offense, undefeated this year and ranked No. 1 among the nation's college football teams, scored again. As usual, they went on to win by a lopsided margin.

title: City Ends Inquiry In Navy Yard Case
description: The City Investigation Department, citing a lack of any evidence, has ended its inquiry into a charge of criminal conduct by an official of the Brooklyn Navy Yard Development Corporation.

title: Bridge:American Contract League Opening Its Fall Nationals
description: Enthusiasts from all parts of North America were gathering here tonight, ready to battle in the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals for the next 10 days.

title: OFFICIAL ASSESSES THE EFFECT OF UTAH FALLOUT RULING
description: An appeals court decision against Utah ranchers who believe thousands of their sheep died as a result of atomic bomb testing in the 1950's will have no bearing on a large-scale radiation suit now pending before a Federal judge here, United States Attorney Brent Ward said today.

title: E.E.C. Tariffs May Increase
description: European Economic Community governments have agreed to impose extra tariffs on imports of United States chemicals and plastics if they fail to get satisfaction at steel talks in Geneva on Friday, Community diplomats said today.

title: Pope to Visit South Korea
description: Pope John Paul II will visit South Korea next May at the invitation of President Chun Doo Hwan, the first visit by a Pope to this country, a presidential spokesman said today.

title: SOVIET FOOD STORE OFFICIAL SENTTENCED TO DEATH
description: The former director of Moscow's best food store, once purveyor of delicacies to the Soviet elite, has been sentenced to death for corruption.

title: CRITICS' CHOICES: BEST IN THE ARTS FOR THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Jazz

title: Prisoner Accuses Officer of Assault
description: Assault charges have been filed against an Atlantic City police officer accused of using an electric cattle prod on a prisoner, authorities said.

title: Economic Scene; The Outlook In Other Lands
description: THANKSGIVING is a time for stock-taking, even in the sphere of macroeconomics. With the United States economy recovering and unemployment coming down, we have much to be thankful for. But what about the rest of the world? The picture is highly uneven.

title: A.T.& T.'S LUCRATIVE '900' NUMBERS
description: When ABC News's nightly news show ''Nightline'' asked viewers to phone in their opinions on last month's American invasion of Grenada, President Reagan was not the only one pleased with the response. The results of the unscientific survey backed American involvement by a margin of 502,358 to 63,812, providing a lift to the White House.

title: CRITICS'S CHOICE: BEST IN THE ARTS FOR THIS HOLIDAY WEEKEND
description: Museums

title: Mirrors, Voodoo and Candor
description: ''How do you balance the budget, cut taxes and increase defense spending at the same time? It's very simple. You do it with mirrors.'' That's what John Anderson said when he was running for the Republican Presidential nomination in 1980. In the same campaign, George Bush used to call it ''voodoo economics.''

title: SCHOOLS ASKING FOR $80 MILLION IN EXTRA MONEY
description: City school officials, citing the largest midyear budget shortfall since 1979, have told the city they need an extra $80 million by the end of the school year. Most of the money is needed to meet higher-than-expected costs for special education of handicapped children and all-day kindergartens, a school official said.

title: Lyndhurst Posts 10th in Row
description: Joe Carnevale completed three long touchdown passes and gave unbeaten Lyndhurst its 10th victory, an 18-6 defeat of Harrison in Harrison yesterday.

title: SWEDES AWAIT 1984: THE LAUGH'S ON BIG BROTHER
description: A couple of weeks ago, an aerial photograph, the kind that usually reveals missile silos in the Urals, or Soviet-style volleyball courts in Nicaragua, was spread across the centerfold of Expressen, Scandinavia's largest-circulation newspaper. Its focus of attention: the Stockholm neighborhood where Claes Florin, a tax collector, lives.

title: Justin Joining Generals
description: Kerry Justin , a starting cornerback for the Seattle Seahawks, has joined the parade of National Football League players signing contracts to play next season for the United States Football League. Justin, the first Seahawk to switch leagues, said that he had accepted a four-year guaranteed contract from the New Jersey Generals, ''to provide security for my family.'' Seattle's general manager, Mike McCormack , said that the Seahawks had never considered a guaranteed contract during the course of their negotiations with Justin.

title: ; AMERICAN OPINION MAKERS' MIDEAST ERRORS
description: To the Editor:

title: ART PEOPLE
description: MARCIA TUCKER, director of the New Museum of Contemporary Art, has submitted the winning proposal for the official United States exhibition at the 1984 Venice Biennale. Miss Tucker will organize the exhibition with the title of United States commissioner to the Biennale. The decision was announced last week at the New Museum by Juliet Antunes, director of Arts America, a branch of the United States Information Agency, which organizes the agency's overseas fine- and performing-arts and exhibition programs. The U.S.I.A. has been responsible for selecting the United States commissioner and sponsoring the American exhibition at the Biennale since 1980.

title: U.S. TOWNS IN EXCHANGE WITH SOVIET
description: Residents of more than 800 cities and towns across the United States sent off packages to cities in the Soviet Union this week in an effort to establish a measure of good will and personal contact with Soviet citizens.

title: SCOUTING
description: His Own Ideas

title: TURKISH PARLIAMENT MEETS FOR FIRST TIME IN 3 YEARS
description: In what was seen as another step toward the restoration of democratic government, Turkey's new Parliament reconvened today for the first time since the armed forces took over the country in a coup more than three years ago.

title: STEPHEN C. LYRAS
description: Stephen C. Lyras, a New York architect and developer of apartment buildings, died Wednesday at White Plains Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Rye, N.Y.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Another Breed of Turkey

title: U.S. MISAPPREHENSION ABOUT A 'BACKYARD'
description: To the Editor:

title: MEDICAL RESEARCHERS URGE CAUTION IN USE OF CAMBRIDGE DIET
description: The Cambridge Diet, marketed as a ''breakthrough'' for overweight people, can lead to dangerous loss of lean body tissue, according to researchers on obesity.

title: THE EVENING HOURS
description: ''COME now,'' David Redden said to the 200 people sitting in the New Dramatists upstairs theater the other evening. ''Can I not get something higher than $100? This is

title: LIONS ROUT THE STEELERS
description: (AP) Eric Hipple threw two touchdown passes to Ulysses Norris, and Billy Sims ran for 106 yards and 2 touchdowns as the Detroit Lions rolled to a surprisingly easy 45-3 victory over the Pittsburgh Steelers today.

title: Florence Beth Seigel Weds Ralph Belkind
description: Florence Beth Seigel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel E. Seigel of Elmont, L.I., was married yesterday to Ralph Belkind, son of Mr. and Mrs. Max Belkind of the Riverdale section of the Bronx. Rabbi Samuel Z. Glazer performed the ceremony at the Cresthollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I.

title: DECISIONS FACE JACKSON ON KEY CONTESTS AND WORKERS IN FIELD
description: Three weeks after announcing his candidacy for the Democratic Presidential nomination, the Rev. Jesse Jackson has yet to hire key members of his field staff or make a final decision on whether to enter the Iowa caucuses or the New Hampshire primary.

title: SWEDES SIEZE 2D SHIPMENT OF EQUIPMENT
description: Swedish customs officials have found a second consignment of goods believed to be part of a highly advanced American-made computer system that the Reagan Administration says was being smuggled to the Soviet Union.

title: Jet Engine Blows Apart
description: An engine on a United Airlines jetliner blew apart this morning in the course of acceleration for takeoff.

title: WROTE 'MOUSE THAT ROARED'
description: Leonard Wibberley, a journalist and author of more than 100 books, including the comic novel ''The Mouse That Roared,'' died of a heart attack Tuesday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 68 years old.

title: Joseph H. Kler, 80, Physician AndPreservationistinJersey
description: Dr. Joseph H. Kler, a physician in New Brunswick, N.J., for more than half a century and a leader in architectural preservation, died Monday at St. Peter's Medical Center in New Brunswick. He was 80 years old and had lived in Bound Brook, N.J.

title: ADVERTISING ; BBDO Direct Is Picked For Hasbro Toy Work
description: Hasbro Industries, the Providence, R.I., toy company that has its regular advertising done by Griffin Bacal Inc., has brought in BBDO Direct to work up a plan for using direct marketing techniques to sell its products.

title: ST, JOHN'S SPORTS NEW LOOK
description: In the early evening on the day before Thanksgiving, Coach Lou Carnesecca kept his St. John's basketball team a little late in practice.

title: 26 Aboard Air Canada Plane Reported Hurt in Turbulence
description: An Air Canada L-1011 on a flight from Trinidad hit severe turbulence and suddenly dropped 1,000 feet in altitude, injuring 26 people, officials said.

title: KAREEM'S LIFE AND A FOOTBALL NOVEL
description: It would be hard to find a greater

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Doing Civilized Battle

title: ROMEO ,JULIET AND A RINKFUL OF ICE
description: -TV is slipping a ''Festival of Lively Arts for Young People'' program onto its schedule this afternoon. The production, taped in Canada at least six months ago, is nothing less than ''Romeo and Juliet on Ice.'' The star is Dorothy Hamill, the former Olympics gold medalist.

title: Ex-Worker Held In Slaying of Boss
description: A West New York man, recently dismissed from his job, fatally wounded his former employer during a break in an arbitration hearing at the State Office Building in Newark, authorities said.

title: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 25, 1983 International
description: A deployment of seaborne missiles against the United States was announced by Yuri V. Andropov. The Soviet leader said the action would counter the threat to his country that he said was posed by new American nuclear missiles being based in Western Europe. (Page A1, Column 6.) The President was ''dismayed'' with Moscow's plan to counter NATO missile deployment with new Soviet weapons and said it was at ''sharp variance'' with previous Soviet calls for arms agreement. In a four-sentence statement, Mr. Reagan said, ''We are determined to renew our efforts to entirely do away with the land-based intermediate-range nuclear missile systems.'' (A1:6.)

title: AN OLD HOLIDAY REBORN
description: The Fraunces Tavern Museum is bringing back a patriotic American tradition this weekend that went out of practice 67 years ago. That tradition is the celebration of a holiday called Evacuation Day, which marks the departure of British troops from New York 200 years ago today. The museum is a suitable place for such a revival because it sits atop the tavern where Gen. George Washington celebrated the British evacuation with a festive dinner Nov. 25, 1783.

title: Musical Dickens 'Carol'
description: A musical adaptation of Charles Dickens's ''A Christmas Carol'' will be presented tomorrow at 2 P.M. at the Colden Center for the Performing Arts at Queens College, Long Island Expressway and Kissena Boulevard.

title: ADVERTISING ; Ted Bates Restructures Operations in Europe
description: Ted Bates International has consolidated its British and Continental European operations into Ted Bates Europe and has brought back G. Bruce McLaren to run it as president and chief operating officer. He will be based in London, working with Armand de Malherbe, head of operations on the Continent since 1970 and now chairman of the consolidated unit.

title: Transactions
description: COLLEGES

title: New Hyde Park Wins Title Again, 17-0
description: New Hyde Park, for the second time in two years, defeated Oyster Bay to win the Nassau Conference C title yesterday. This year, both coaches agreed, the overall size and weight of New Hyde Park's individual players made the difference in a 17-0 victory.

title: Ex-Employee Sought In Fatal Motel Fire
description: An employee dismissed from a motel will be questioned about a fire there that killed one guest and injured 22 people, the authorities said today.

title: NORMAN HOSS
description: Norman Hoss, the editorial director of Times-Mirror Magazines' Book Clubs, died last Friday at Cabrini Medical Center. Mr. Hoss, who was 60 years old and lived in Manhattan, had been ill for some time.

title: TEXT OF ANDROPOV'S STATEMENT ON MISSILE DISPUTE
description: Following is the text of the statement issued today by Yuri V. Andropov as reported by Tass, the official Soviet press agency:

title: Garnett Paces Shutout
description: Angelo Garnett highlighted the 87th Thanksgiving Day meeting between the teams when he threw three touchdown passes to lead East Orange to a 38-0 rout of Barringer before 1,000 fans yesterday at Schools Stadium in Newark.

title: Police End Strike on Coast
description: The police were back on the job today after settling a six-day strike in which 48 officers below the rank of captain fled 225 miles across state lines to Lake Havasu, Ariz.

title: Carolers at the Seaport
description: Strolling carolers in Victorian dress will be among those in the South Street Seaport area tonight for a free outdoor choral concert to mark the beginning of holiday concerts at the Seaport.

title: DYING FOR WORK
description: Richard Loo died for the last time in Los Angeles the other day. He was 80, had acted in some 150 films over a 50-year career and had died in a fair proportion of them. Though his roots were Chinese, he was in great demand for roles as Japanese villains during World War II and, as his daughter said, ''was always either stabbing himself or committing hara- kiri or kamikaze . . . because he never got the best of the Americans.'' Forty years ago and thereabouts I saw Mr. Loo die many times and, though it may seem shameful nowadays, cheered each death without the slightest sensation of unseemly behavior. Revisers of history may clutch at this confession as proof that I was besotted with anti-Asian racism cooked up by American propagandists to promote the war effort against Japan. To which I say, ''Poppycock!'' American love of all things Chinese was as irrational and deep then as its hatred of all things Japanese. What made Mr. Loo's deaths so easy to cheer was much simpler than racism. First, you always knew he would be back at this devilish business of tormenting American G.I.'s before the month was out at the movie theater. Second, he always died in good taste. Even when committing hara-kiri, he was neat about it. I wish present day movie actors would study his work. When a movie actor faces a violent end nowadays, the audience has to put up with a mess so gory that only the strongest stomach can go on digesting the popcorn.

title: JACKSON HONES HIS POSITION ON ISSUES
description: In nearly 16 years as a civil rights leader, the Rev. Jesse Jackson has amassed a voluminous record of positions on traditional civil rights concerns, ranging from busing for school integration to affirmative action. He has also touched on issues such as economic development, education philosophy and financing of domestic programs, and even some foreign policy issues.

title: SYMS CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $690,000 of nonrecurring expenses relating to its recent public offering.

title: SCOUTING
description: Eason Will Start

title: Your MoneyLeonard Sloane F.H.A. Change On Mortgages
description: IN the near future, home buyers who obtain

title: Kansas Reactor
description: The Kansas Gas and Electric Company said the cost of the Wolf Creek generating unit had been raised to $2.67 billion from the $2.45 billion projected last year.

title: ; 42D STREET TROLLEYS: LET'S DO IT-LET'S NOT
description: To the Editor:

title: CONCERT: CHAMBER SOCIETY
description: The famous reaction of an early critic of Arnold Schoenberg to the composer's ''Verkl"arte Nacht'' - ''It sounds as if someone had smeared the score of 'Tristan' while it was still wet'' - is actually an acute bit of criticism. That is exactly how this score should sound, as if the infinite melody of Wagner had become moist in an early Expressionist hothouse, its endless desire turned a bit sickly in the humidity.

title: COMMONWEALTH DEBATE OVER GRENADA FLARES AGAIN
description: Discord among some Commonwealth nations over the United States-led invasion of Grenada flared again today, with Dominica defending the action and Guyana denouncing it.

title: FOR BRITISH WOMEN, THE GAINS COME, BUT SLOWLY
description: Marching soldiers, enthusiastic models waving from colorful floats and bands belting out the show tune ''There's Nothing Like a Dame'' led a parade past half a million onlookers earlier this month. The occasion was London's official welcome for its first female Lord Mayor.

title: MONENCO LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income. c-After a special loss of $3.5 million from discontinued operations of McCullough Associates Inc.

title: NETS ARE DEFEATED BY LAKERS, 147-123
description: The Nets, playing their sixth game of a 16-day, 7-game road trip, were routed by the Los Angeles Lakers, 147-123, tonight before 14,264 fans at the Forum

title: RAPE SENTENCE: CASTRATION OR 30 YEARS
description: A sentence for rape that gave three men a choice between surgical castration and 30 years in prison has become the focus of an emotional debate here.

title: AIR RIGHTS BOUGHT AT GRAND CENTRAL
description: Most of the two million square feet of unused air rights that remain over Grand Central Terminal are being acquired by a real-estate partnership that plans to use them for development near, but not above, the landmark depot.

title: SYM-TEK SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Dr. Sabin Suffers Paralysis
description: Dr. Albert Sabin, who developed an oral vaccine that helped conquer polio in most of the world, is paralyzed and unable to walk. Dr. Sabin, 77 years old, said he was suffering from an ascending paralysis, which affects nerve cells in the upper and lower parts of the body, brought on by complications of surgery Aug. 5 for a compressed spinal cord in the neck. He is hospitalized at the National Institutes of Health in suburban Bethesda, Md.

title: PLAYERSMalcolm Moran; Lovely Day to be Able to Run The rain was falling hard enough
description: to make umbrellas necessary at

title: RUMANIA DEPLORES MISSILE DECISIONS
description: Rumania's Communist Party leaders said today that they deplored the Soviet decision to speed deployment of new nuclear missiles as much as NATO's deployment of American missiles in Europe.

title: A Step Forward in Queens
description: Hunters Point is a depressed stretch of Queens waterfront that faces midtown Manhattan and commands a spectacular view of its skyline. The location - only one subway stop from Grand Central - and the vistas have long stimulated the imaginations of planners and developers. Why can't this desirable site, now home only to tennis courts, cement bins and under-used industrial buildings, be developed with housing, parks, commerce and non- polluting industries?

title: Virginia Cowles And Jon Kurtis Have Nuptials
description: Virginia Cowles, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gardner Cowles of New York and Indian Creek Island, Fla., and Jon Miles Kurtis, son of Donald Kurtis of Old Saybrook, Conn., and Mrs. Walter H. Manley of New York, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Justice Theodore R. Kupferman of the New York State Supreme Court, Appellate Division, at the New York home of the bride's parents.

title: KORCHNOI AND KASPAROV IN A DRAW
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland drew the third game of their semifinal world championship chess match in 18 moves tonight.

title: JUSTICE DEPT. SUPPORTING A.T.& T. RIVALS ON FEE
description: The Justice Department today opposed a proposal by the Federal Communications Commission to sharply increase the ''access fees'' paid by those companies that provide long- distance phone service in competition with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: 1984 SUMMER OLYMPICS A HURDLE FOR HOLLYWOOD
description: Because of the 1984 Olympic Games, Hollywood will reluctantly start summer a month early next year.

title: BEAUTY AT HOME: HOUSE CALLS BY EXPERTS
