description: In the comfort of your home, a hairdresser will cut and style your hair, a makeup artist will redo your face, a manicurist will polish nails, a facial expert will cleanse the skin or a massage therapist will knead away tensions. And if stretching and strengthening the body is what is wanted, an exercise coach will be happy to help. All the customer has to do is telephone New York's growing number of beauty and health specialists who make house calls.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE
description: THEATER Luigi Pirandello, best known for his ''Six Characters in Search of an Author,'' was an Italian playwright who found what was then new ways of approaching drama with a talent that won him the Nobel Prize in 1934. New York's own Classic Theater is now performing ''The Life I Gave You,'' a piece in the best Pirandello tradition of soul-searching.

title: K.G.B. Chief, in a Rare Trip, Meets With Poland's Leader
description: The head of the Soviet K.G.B. met with the Polish leader, Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, in Warsaw today, the Soviet press reported.

title: JERSEY TRIPLETS SCORE POINTS PLAYING SINGLES AND DOUBLES
description: Terri, Patty and Christine. They sound like a female singing trio, perhaps on the order of the Andrews Sisters or the Supremes. They are a trio all right - identical 15-year-old triplets - and they are often called ''triple trouble'' by their opponents at tennis tournaments.

title: Prospect of Buyout At Dorchester Gas
description: The Dorchester Gas Corporation of Dallas said yesterday that a private company was attempting to arrange financing for a possible leveraged buyout of Dorchester. It did not identify the company.

title: DEAN OF INTERIOR DECORATORS
description: Billy Baldwin, the dean of American interior decorators, whose taste and sense of elegance enabled him to become the greatest influence on a generation of post-World War II designers, died of a heart ailment yesterday at Nantucket (Mass.) Cottage Hospital. He was 80 years old and had lived in retirement on Nantucket for the last decade.

title: DIET INSTITUTE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After charges of $63,000 for the quarter and $127,000 for the 6 months for goodwill amortization.

title: NORTH EUROPEAN OIL ROYALTY TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Share earnings represent units.

title: JESUIT CHIEF AFFIRMS ORDER WILL CONTINUE TO PROMOTE JUSTICE
description: The new head of the Society of Jesus said today that the order would continue to promote justice throughout the world, but that Jesuits must stay out of politics under normal circumstances.

title: PLENUM PUBLISHING CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes unrealized gains on marketable securities of $537,199, or 31 cents a share, for the quarter and $173,625, or 10 cents a share, for the 9 months.

title: SATURDAYSPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Cleveland Cavaliers, at Madison Square Garden, 7:35 P.M. The Knicks have won nine straight home games against the Cavaliers, a streak that is almost four years old. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M., live, and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.)

title: Nkomo Backer Loses Appeal in Zimbabwe
description: The Supreme Court today upheld the Government's refusal to release Dumiso Dabengwa, the top military aide to Joshua Nkomo, the opposition leader. Mr. Dabengwa was acquitted of treason charges in April but has remained in detention under stringent emergency powers.

title: HOLMES STOPS FRAZIER IN FIRST
description: Marvis Frazier, wearing the same style of green-and-gold embroidered knee- length trunks and hooded robe that his father wore in 1971 when he beat Muhammad Ali, did not fill his father's shoes tonight.

title: TRANSCONTINENTAL ENERGY CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $771,000 for the quarter and $4,231,000 for the 9 months and a charge of $285,000 for the 9 months from an accounting adjustment. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: MCGREGOR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-After net losses from discontinued operations of $391,000 for the quarter and $1,210,000 for the 9 months. Corrected from Thursday's editions.

title: BOSTON COLLEGE WINS BY 20-13
description: The subject was mistakes, and Ricky Moore, Alabama's junior fullback, could speak with authority, for he made the fumble that led to the winning touchdown by Boston College in a 20-13 victory today at Sullivan Stadium.

title: CRAIGMONT MINES LIMITED reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
AMERICANS AT OXFORD GET 'STARES AND SNARLS' OVER U.S. POLICIES
description: You have begun your graduate studies at Oxford University, the renowned home of rational confabulation and distinctive political sentiment, nested in a country still clinging (at least until recently) to the post-World War II enchantment of Anglo-American accord and a shared vision of international freedom and democratic rectitude.

title: Storm Washes Oil Away
description: A severe storm that swept in from the Pacific early Thursday may have washed away the last oil from the wreckage of a Japanese freighter off the coast here, Coast Guard officials said, and the rough water should wash all the oil on the beach back to sea. About 70,000 gallons of crude oil and diesel fuel was on board the 350-foot Blue Magpie when it ran aground outside Yaquina Bay in a storm Saturday.

title: ARKANSAS EDGES FORDHAM
description: Ricky Norton sank a free throw with five seconds remaining to help Arkansas score a 62-61 victory over Fordham tonight in the opening round of the Great Alaska Shootout.

title:
PATENTS ;
Hand Is Improved For Industrial Robot
description: An improved hand for an industrial robot was patented this week by two Japanese inventors for Fujitsu Fanuc Ltd., a Tokyo company that manufactures the machines. The hand, patent 4,416,577, is intended primarily for applying and removing work pieces from a machine tool. Two sets of graspers are provided, one for moving the work pieces and the other for simultaneously getting rid of the chips and other foreign matter that have been a bother in the past.

title: TERRAMAR CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $1,016,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Stenmark Out of Games
description: Ingemar Stenmark of Sweden and Hanni Wenzel of Liechtenstein, each of whom won two skiing gold medals in the 1980 Winter Olympics, will not be allowed to compete in the 1984 Games at Sarajevo, Yugoslavia. The executive board of the International Olympic Committee upheld the decision of the International Ski Federation that declared them ineligible because they hold special licenses that allow them to receive direct payments, either in prize money or from sponsors.

title: REALLOCATE CAPITAL, IMPROVE ENERGY SAVINGS
description: Although the level of oil imports last year was the lowest since 1970, America's dependence on energy resulted in more than $60 billion in capital going abroad. A reallocation of some of this capital to investments in energy efficiency would profoundly benefit national security, the economy and individual firms.

title: FIGHTING ERUPS NEAR BEIRUT BASE
description: Gunfire between Lebanese troops and Shiite Moslem militiamen erupted throughout the night near the United States Marine base south of Beirut.

title: KOHL AND MITTERRAND RESPOND CALMLY
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl and President Francois Mitterrand reacted in tones of studied calmness today to the Soviet Union's decision to break off the Geneva talks on medium-range missiles. Both expressed hope that the negotiations would eventually be resumed.

title: SCOUTING
description: Old-Fashioned

title: Sea Galley Stores
description: Sea Galley Stores Inc. said it would probably not earn the 10 cents to 15 cents a share that analysts had projected for the fourth quarter and that it could report a loss.

title: William Shields, 70, Ex-Head OftheBarberSteamshipLine
description: William J. Shields, who was president of the Barber Steamship Line from 1974 until he retired in 1978, died Monday at his home in New Milford, N.J. He was 70.

title: HUGH B. HESTER, RETIRED GENERAL WHO OPPOSED COLD WAR POLICIES
description: Hugh B. Hester, a brigadier general in the United States Army who after retirement became a fervent opponent of America's stance in the Cold War, died of cancer yesterday at the Oteen Veterans Administration Hospital in Asheville, N.C. He lived in Chapel Hill, N.C., and was 88 years old.

title: GIANT FOOD INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 5
description: b-Including a pretax gain of $944,000 from the sale of stores.

title: Conviction in Draft Case Overturned by Court
description: An appellate court, saying that singling out vocal draft resisters for prosecution ''clearly violates the First Amendment,'' today overturned the conviction of a man who refused to register for the draft.

title: Youth Symphony Concert
description: The Youth Symphony Orchestra of New York will open its 21st season in Carnegie Hall tomorrow at 3 P.M.

title: Sony Layoffs in France
description: Sony France S.A., a subsidiary of the Sony Corporation of Japan, may soon lay off a number of its employees, an official of the parent company said today.

title: SURPRISE SNOW PUTS CHILL ON SHOPPING
description: The season's first snow, which surprised forecasters, drivers and package-laden Christmas shoppers, fell throughout the metropolitan area yesterday.

title: Mystery in Houston
description: Wilson Whitley , a 28-year-old defensive lineman for the Houston Oilers, was hospitalized after he was found unconscious Thursday at a Houston bank with an inchlong gash on the back of his head. His wife, Norma , said Whitley had collapsed near an automatic cash machine and had suffered a severe concussion. ''I don't really know what happened,'' Mrs. Whitley said.

title: FULL-TIME EDUCATION
description: To the Editor:

title: UNIWEST FINANCIAL reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The 1982 results do not reflect the acquisition of United Savings Bank of Wyoming in June 1983.

title: Chinese Leader Speaks To Japan's Parliament
description: Hu Yaobang, the head of China's Communist Party, today became the first leader of a Communist country to address Japan's Parliament. He said Peking would continue to welcome foreign investment in its drive to modernize its economy.

title: ACCORD REPORTED IN P.L.O. FIGHTING BUT DOUBTS ARISE
description: The Foreign Ministers of Syria and Saudi Arabia announced today that rival Palestinian factions had agreed to stop fighting here and withdraw from the area within two weeks. But the Palestinians later cast doubt on whether the agreement would be put into effect.

title: PERSONAL COMPUTER PRODUCTS reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Bid to Acquire First People's
description: The First People's Bank of New Jersey said its directors had voted to recommend to shareholders an acquisition offer by the New Jersey National Corporation. The offer, announced in August, has been valued at about $33 million.

title:
PATENTS ;
Internal Balloon Used To Help Treat Obesity
description: An internal balloon for treating obesity was patented this week by Dr. Lloyd R. Garren, a gastroenterologist in Wilmington, Del., and his wife, Mary L. Garren.

title: CHADIAN PEACE TALKS WILL BE HELD SOON
description: A reconciliation meeting among all factions in Chad's civil war will soon take place in Ethiopia, the Government of Chad announced today.

title: 2 Dead in Burned House
description: The bodies of two women, apparently beaten to death, were found in their burned-out duplex Thursday. Shortly after the fire at the home of Lourdes Villegas, 24 years old, and Mirian Mejides, 31, a car belonging to one of the women was involved in an accident on Interstate 95. The driver's head was bleeding as he fled, according to the police.

title: Spinks Retains Title
description: Michael Spinks scored a 10th-round technical knockout over Oscar Rivadeneyra and retained his undisputed world light-heavyweight title tonight. Spinks knocked Rivadeneyra down twice in the 10th round, the last time for a standing-8 count, after which Referee Joe Cortez stopped the bout at 1:42.

title: WICHITA INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Santas Hit the Street

title: Cubo-Futurist 'Opera' From 1913 Being Staged
description: ''Victory Over the Sun,'' a re-creation of a 1913 Cubo-Futurist ''opera,'' is being presented by the Brooklyn Academy of Music this weekend as part of its ''Next Wave'' festival. The text is by Aleksei Kruchenykh, music by Mikhail Matiushin, and stage and costume designs by Kazimir Malevich.

title: U.S. ENVOY REACTS TO SOVIET POSITION
description: The American nuclear weapons negotiator, Paul H. Nitze, said today that Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, had hardened the Soviet position by declaring that Moscow would no longer take part in the Geneva talks on medium- range missiles.

title: Soviet-Sweden Ferry Service
description: The Soviet Union said today that car ferry service would start soon between Leningrad and Stockholm. The official press agency Tass said the weekly service would be run by the Soviet Baltic Sea Shipping Line and the Skansov company of Sweden.

title: MATAGORDA DRILLING & EXPLORATION reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $1,980,000 from discontinued operations.

title: BOWIE RESUMES SEARCH FOR DREAM
description: There was a time when he was compared favorably with Ralph Sampson, and college basketball fans envisioned a day when Sam Bowie would play against the former University of Virginia center, perhaps in a game to decide the national championship.

title: 7 Are Arraigned In Damage to B-52
description: Seven protesters accused of damaging a B-52 bomber and spare aircraft engines at Griffiss Air Force Base were arraigned today on charges of destroying national defense material.

title: WEDGESTONE REALTY INV reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After a loss of $176,900 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting.

title: JURY WEIGHS CONFRONTATION CASE
description: A jury deliberated five hours tonight without reaching a verdict in the trial of a black man over a confrontation here with two white police officers after a funeral. The jury was to resume its work Saturday morning.

title: CORNELL'S FANS ARE A NOT SO SECRET WEAPON
description: Lock up your chickens. Lay in a new supply of sieves. It's ice hockey season at Cornell.

title: STEEL PAYMENTS ACCORD ELUDES E.E.C. AND U.S.
description: The likelihood that the European Economic Community would order retaliatory trade measures against the United States has grown following the failure of both sides yesterday to reach agreement on the community's demands for compensation for the restrictions Washington has placed on specialty steel imports, Common Market representatives said.

title: WHITE HOUSE SECURITY STEPS RETAINED AFTER BOMB SCARE
description: Reagan Administration officials declined today to say how long tighter security would remain in effect at the White House and State Department, or to elaborate on what had prompted the move.

title: GROWING DEBATE OVER CABLE
description: With nearly 40 percent of the nation's homes wired for cable television, lawmakers in Washington are trying to come up with a policy that will affect how much the estimated 31 million households will have to pay for the service and, ultimately, what they will see.

title: St. John's Romps In Lapchick Event
description: St. John's showed a new personality last night, individually and as a team, in defeating Siena College, 73-40, in the opening game of the Lapchick Basketball Tournament at Alumni Hall.

title: Bridge:Fall Nationals to Culminate In Reisinger Board-a-Match
description: The Fall National Championships of the American Contract Bridge League began here this afternoon with play in the four-session national mixed pairs. There will follow other major pair events - the life master men's, the life master women's and the blue ribbon.

title: Crowd Lifts Car To Rescue Boy, 4
description: A crowd of men lifted a four-door sedan to free a 4-year-old boy who had been struck and pinned under the vehicle, the police said today.

title: NEWSPAPER IN NICARAGUA TO HALT PUBLICATION
description: The newspaper La Prensa, an important voice of opposition to Nicaragua's Sandinista Government, will suspend publication indefinitely Dec. 7 for lack of paper, its publisher said today.

title: McKesson Settles F.T.C. Charges
description: The McKesson Corporation has agreed to pay a $300,000 civil penalty to settle Federal Trade Commission charges that it violated an F.T.C. order, the agency said.

title: Soviet Tells Liberian Envoy To Leave in Retaliatory Move
description: The Soviet Union today ordered the Liberian Ambassador to leave the country in retaliation for Liberia's expulsion of Moscow's Ambassador this week.

title: KEY TO WINNERS
description: To the Editor:

title: MCCULLUM CUT RULED ILLEGAL
description: In a ruling with broad implications for both players and club owners, an administrative law judge for the National Labor Relations Board has held that the Seattle Seahawks unlawfully cut Sam McCullum, a veteran wide receiver, in September 1982 because of his union activities.

title: POP: DOC JOHNSON IN MANY MOODS
description: A pianist and/or singer who works in a cocktail lounge is usually pushed into some category - keeping up with pop tunes or going the show-tune route with Gershwin, Porter and Kern.

title: STATE SUPREME COURT'S BARGAIN FOR PLAINTIFFS
description: To the Editor:

title: SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1983 International
description: An end to the fighting in Tripoli and a withdrawal from the area were agreed to by rival Palestinian factions, the Foreign Ministers of Syria and Saudi Arabia announced in Damascus. But subsequent statements by the Palestinians made it doubtful that the agreement would be carried out. Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, said the forces opposing him had sent in reinforcements overnight. (Page 1, Column 6.) Caution marked the response of the Reagan Administration to reports that Nicaragua has been making conciliatory gestures toward domestic opponents and reducing its support for the guerrillas in El Salvador. Both White House and State Department officials questioned whether the Nicaraguan leaders were seriously seeking a political settlement of the conflict in Central America or making token gestures intended to ease pressures on the Sandinista regime. (1:4.)

title: 700th Victory For Gaines
description: Clarence (Bighouse) Gaines, the Winston-Salem State basketball coach, achieved his 700th victory tonight as the Rams beat Barber-Scotia, 100-72, in the Bighouse Gaines Classic.

title: 'Telephone' Helps Lift Dow 1.83
description: Prices of American Telephone and Telegraph stock, old and new, advanced smartly yesterday and accounted for nearly 17 percent of all the shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Books of The Times
description: BRECHT. By Ronald Hayman. Illustrated. 423 pages. Oxford University Press.

title: IRAQ AGAIN WARNS SHIPPING TO AVOID END OF GULF
description: Iraq has issued a new warning to international shipping companies to keep their vessels away from what Iraq has declared to be a war zone at the northern end of the Persian Gulf.

title: OBJECT RECOGNITION SYSTEMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BRIEFING
description: Grand Illusion?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's not good snow, it's just rain that's white.'' - Ben Hindale, 7 years old. (27:5.)

title: PENNSYLVANIA ENTERPRISES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Interest in Bradshaw
description: Terry Bradshaw , the injured Pittsburgh Steeler quarterback who has been upset over remarks made by Coach Chuck Noll , has received a nibble of sorts from his suggestion that it might be better if the Steelers traded him or gave him his release. Paul Martha , the president of the Pittsburgh Maulers, the new United States Football League franchise, said the team would have an interest in Bradshaw, ''if and when he might become available.''

title: FORECHECKING CAPITALS TOP RANGERS, 3-1
description: The Washington Capitals have begun to make robust forechecking a house specialty at the Capital Centre, and when they dished it out in quantity to the Rangers tonight, it produced a 3-1 victory.

title: SYMBOL TECHNOLOGIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company noted it had changed its fiscal year-end to June 30 from Aug. 31.

title: Con Edison Asks To Speed Refund
description: The Consolidated Edison Company has asked permission from the State Public Service Commission to make all of a $10 million refund to natural- gas customers in the first three months of 1984.

title: MOSCOW ENVOY TO U.N. SAYS MISSILES INCREASE RISK OF WAR
description: The Soviet Union's deputy chief delegate to the United Nations said today that the decision to proceed with the deployment of new American missiles in Western Europe had greatly increased the risk of nuclear war.

title: Singles and Doubles
description: Ivan Lendl has been seeded first for the Australian Open men's tennis singles, which begin Monday in Melbourne. . . . Peter Fleming and Fritz Buening , known for their hot tempers, have received a warning from Patrick Deuchar , the tournament director of the World Doubles Championships.

title: Fouts Ready to Play
description: Dan Fouts , recovering from a torn shoulder muscle, has been cleared by the Chargers' team physician to return to action against the Denver Broncos tomorrow. But Coach Don Coryell may keep Fouts on the bench anyway, perhaps to save him for next Thursday's game against the Los Angeles Raiders.

title: 'YELLOW SNOW DRIFTING TO THE FLOOR'
description: Americans are great conservationists. Consider the public outcry when buildings of historical significance are threatened with destruction. Think of the painstaking efforts to restore works of art and the millions of dollars spent to protect and preserve our natural environment.

title: Colombian Kidnappers Make Political Demands
description: Guerrillas who say they are holding the kidnapped brother of Colombia's President today demanded wage increases for workers, a freeze in consumer prices and reductions in the price of public services.

title: PatentsStacy V. Jones Reducing Morphine Addiction
description: WASHINGTON ACOMPOSITION containing morphine, patented this week for the Department of Health and Human Services, promises to reduce addiction to the drug. Users can get relief from pain without developing tolerance to or physical dependence on the morphine, the developers say.

title: ADVANCED INPUT'S I.B.M. COUP
description: Virtually overnight, Advanced Input Devices Inc., a manufacturer of electronic keyboards in Coeur d'Alene, Idaho, has become an industry star.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 26, 1983
description: International Brazil's deep economic troubles are being increasingly blamed on the nation's technocrats, the planners who borrowed huge sums to industrialize the nation in the 1960's and 70's. Many of them, appointed by the military Government, are still in top positions. Critics in Brazil say the planners saddled the nation with huge debts for impractical projects. The planners, meanwhile, pin the nation's problems on factors outside their control, such as the soaring price of oil over the past decade. (Page 1.) Poland, eager to earn hard currency, is reselling Libyan oil on the open market at a loss, industry sources say. Polish officials confirmed that they are reselling $230 million worth of oil bought from Libya on credit, but would not say at what price. The Polish economy is heavily dependent on Western raw materials and spare parts, but has been cut off from Western credit. (1.)

title: Picture Lost 42 1/2 Minutes
description: A transformer failure at Sullivan Stadium during the Boston College-Alabama game caused a 42 1/2-minute blackout in the stadium and surrounding area. However, the audio portion of the nationally televised broadcast was not affected.

title: Linda C. Reynolds Is Bride Of Denver D. Frederick 3d
description: Linda Christine Reynolds, daughter of Norma O. Reynolds of Rochester and the late Robert E. Reynolds, was married yesterday to Denver Dale Frederick 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick 2d of Scarsdale, N.Y. The Rev. Eugene J. O'Brien performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Heart of Mary Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale.

title: NICKLOS OIL & GAS CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: Miss Cole Weds E. Grant Gibbons
description: The marriage of Kathryn Hart Cole, daughter of Jane Dunlap Cole of Delray Beach, Fla. and the late Kenneth Hampton Cole, to E. Grant Gibbons, son of Mr. and Mrs. E. Graham Gibbons of Tucker's Town, Bermuda, took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents. The Rev. Thomas Anderson, a Lutheran minister, performed the ceremony.

title: NEVADA RESOURCES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including a gain of $322,316 for the quarter and 9 months on the sale of assets and gains on the sale of marketable securities of $19,355 for the quarter and $201,162 for the 9 months. c-Net loss.

title: RISKY NUCLEAR TRADE
description: President Reagan is weakening America's ability to slow the spread of nuclear weapons to other countries. He has allowed nuclear exports to go to the most threatening nations without obtaining in return a single open commitment to foreswear nuclear explosives. This encourages an open season in nuclear trade that could unravel the global consensus against nuclear proliferation.

title: Article 069987 -- No Title
description: The International Business Machines Corporation yesterday filed a $7.5 billion lawsuit against the National Semiconductor Corporation in the latest chapter its continuing fight to protect what it says are its trade secrets.

title: THE WALKOUT BY MOSCOW
description: News Analysis

title: No Getting This Goat
description: The Pasadena Humane Society, which was responsible for the security of Navy's mascot this week, took some extraordinary steps to make sure that the 6-month-old goat, Charlie Bill, made it to the game today against Army. ''Nobody, nobody is getting this goat,'' Steve McNall, assistant executive director of the Pasadena shelter, said Thursday. Mr. McNall said naval officials had put the facility through a thorough military inspection before Charlie Bill arrived Tuesday and was placed in an isolation pen.

title: Letter: On Turkish Diplomacy ; For One Cyprus Under a Federal Roof
description: To the Editor:

title: WASHINGTON WARY ON PEACE FEELERS FROM SANDINISTAS
description: The Reagan Administration took a cautious stance today toward reports that Nicaragua had been making conciliatory gestures toward domestic opponents and reducing political support for the guerrilla movement in El Salvador.

title: PIONEER ELECTRONIC CORP reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Computer in Real Error

title: STORE DESIGN CAN BE DICTATED BY BUDGET, WHIM, ACCIDENT - AND PIGEONS
description: It could have been a neon sign, a plastic sign, a blue sign or a wooden one, but it isn't. It could have flashed on and off and matched the one outside the men's clothing store next door, but it doesn't.

title: SEARCH ON AT THE FEDERAL RESERVE
description: There is none of the obsessive gossiping of a year ago, when the speculation began as to whether Paul A. Volcker, chairman of the Federal Reserve, would be reappointed.

title: KLEIN PLANS TO PURSUE PURITAN BID
description: The designer Calvin Klein threatened yesterday to initiate a tender offer for the Puritan Fashions Corporation at $15.50 a share if Puritan rejects his existing offer at $16.50 a share.

title: SCHOOL FOOD: TOO MUCH IS FRIED
description: The odor of grease that had been used more than once for deep-fat frying assaulted us long before we arrived at the exhibition floor. All the exhibitors were there to convince those attending the conference - food-service personnel from schools, hospitals and nursing homes - that their products were superior.

title: NAVY, LED BY MCCALLUM, DEFEATS ARMY
description: Seventeen seconds after the start of the Army-Navy game today, Navy led, 7-0. After 2 minutes 30 seconds, Navy led, 14-0. After 3 minutes 57 seconds, Navy led, 21-0.

title: JAMAICA PREMIER, BERATED ON FISCAL ISSUE, SEEKS EARLY VOTE
description: Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga announced tonight that he had asked the Governor General to dissolve Parliament and to prepare for new elections.

title: UNESCO APPROVES A COMPROMISE ON WORLD COMMUNICATIONS PLAN
description: A 161-nation Unesco conference approved a compromise program on world communications today. It sidesteps the third-world demands that the Western nations have argued could have led to an international code for journalists.

title: SAUL, B F, REAL ESTATE INVESTMENT TRUST reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Including gains on the sale of properties of $1,424,000 for the quarter and $10,068,000 for the year. c-Net loss including gains on the sale of properties of $245,000 for the quarter and $858,000 for the year.

title: DESPITE FANS' APPEALS, NBC'S 'OVERNIGHT' TO GO
description: It started two weeks ago, the night the NBC switchboard lit up, just minutes after the network had announced over the air that ''NBC News Overnight,'' the critically acclaimed late-night news program, was being canceled.

title: 4 Groups Are Interested In The Globe-Democrat
description: The publisher of Key magazine and about 50 newspaper employees apparently represent the only local parties interested in buying The St. Louis Globe-Democrat, a lawyer for the newspaper's owner says. Two other organizations are also reported interested.

title: U.S. ENVOY CASTIGATES SALVADORANS ON TERRORISM
description: The United States Ambassador to El Salvador said tonight that the unwillingness of the Salvadoran Government to take action against the right-wing death squads ''runs an extremely serious risk'' of provoking a cutoff of aid. The Ambassador, Thomas R. Pickering, added that such intransigence could call into question the capacity of the United States to support democracy in El Salvador. The Ambassador made his remarks in a question and answer period after delivering a speech in which he said that ''extremist terror'' is the ''essential stumbling block to democracy in El Salvador.'' He called the work of the death squads ''another case of fascists serving the Communist cause.''

title: MERCURY IN FISH IN CALIFORNIA LAKE CREATES TURMOIL AMONG INDIANS NEARBY
description: There are two signs at the fork in the road, signs of an unanswered question that boils and fumes like the water where Clear Lake meets the abandoned Sulfur Bank Mine.

title: ; 42D STREET TROLLEYS: LET'S DO IT-LET'S NOT
description: To the Editor:

title: WARSAW SELLS OIL BOUGHT ON CREDIT
description: Poland is so eager to earn hard currency to prop up its battered economy that the Government is taking a loss of as much as $9 million by reselling Libyan oil on the open market, according to industry sources.

title: Rebuilding the Aid Weapon
description: When in doubt, reorganize. Does that old bit of Washington cynicism apply to the proposed new reorganization of foreign aid, pulling it back together into a single agency? No. Perhaps no Federal activity has been reorganized so often, but this consolidation now makes sense.

title: SPEED-O-PRINT BUSINESS MACHINES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes gains on the sale of assets of $202,000 for the quarter and $252,000 for the 9 months.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Tuneful Gossip in Brooklyn

title: Comings and Goings
description: Warren Moon , the Edmonton Eskimos' free-agent quarterback who is considering a jump to the National Football League, has been named the recipient of the Schenley Award as the Canadian Football League's most valuable player. . . . Alan Trammell , shorstop for the Detroit Tigers, will undergo arthroscopic surgery on his left knee today in San Diego. Trammell, injured in a fall at his home, will remain in California for rehabilitation, the team said.

title: PROSECUTORS INCREASE EFFORTS TO MAKE PRESS NAME SOURCES
description: Prosecutors and criminal defendants are increasingly demanding the names of confidential informants who lead journalists to news stories.

title: Flynt Indicted on Charge Of Desecrating the Flag
description: The sex-magazine publisher Larry Flynt was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of desecrating an American flag and illegally wearing a military decoration. He is scheduled to be arraigned Dec. 5.

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: Notre Dame 104 St. Joseph's 56
description: Notre Dame, which got off to an 11-0 lead, was led by Tom Sluby's 17 points.

title: DANCE: CITY BALLET BILL, A VARIED THREESOME
description: The New York City Ballet's programs are currently chock full of debuts, and Thursday night's highly varied bill at the State Theater was no exception.

title: BALLET: ARTISTS MAKE 'JEWELS' DEBUTS
description: George Balanchine's ''Jewels'' may be a three-act plotless ballet evoking emeralds, rubies and diamonds. But it is far from being as cold as stone.

title: Miss Wheeler Marries Dr. Richard L. Wagner
description: At St. Margaret's Episcopal Church in Washington yesterday Elizabeth Eustis Wheeler, daughter of Mrs. Henry West Suydam of Washington and George Yardis Wheeler 2d of Hobe Sound, Fla., and Watch Hill, R.I., was married to Dr. Richard Laverne Wagner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Victor Gustave Wagner of Indianapolis. The Rev. Stephen T. Arpee performed the ceremony.

title: Ship Collision on Elbe Kills 1
description: A Liberian ship loaded with 200 tons of fireworks collided with a Brazilian freighter today on the Elbe and erupted in flames, killing one sailor and injuring five, officials said.

title: 6 Flee Maryland Prison; Two Are Recaptured
description: Six inmates, described by the authorities as dangerous, cut the bars on a bathroom window, scaled two wire fences and escaped early today from the Maryland Correctional Institution.

title: Repairs to Affect SubwayLineStops
description: Some subway stations on three lines will close next week while crews make track and structural repairs, the Transit Authority announced. The affected stops are along the A, No. 4 and M lines.

title:
PATENTS ;
Nuclear Advances By Foreign Concerns
description: Patent protection in the United States for methods of producing nuclear power was granted this week to a number of foreign interests.

title: GRANT SUITER
description: Grant Suiter, secretary-treasurer of the Watch Tower Bible and Tract Society, the corporate name of the Jehovah's Witnesses relgious sect, died Tuesday at the group's world headquarters in Brooklyn.

title: British Reject Claim By Mauritius on Islands
description: Britain has rejected claims by Mauritius to the Chagos Archipelago in the Indian Ocean, which includes Diego Garcia, the site of an important United States military base.

title:
PATENTS ;
System to Automate Trademark Search
description: The Systems Development Corporation of Santa Monica, Calif., has been tentatively selected to supply an automated trademark search system for the Patent and Trademark Office.

title: PRINTERS AT BRITISH NEWSPAPERS STRIKE
description: Printers at Britain's national newspapers walked off the job tonight in a labor dispute, forcing the cancellation of the Saturday editions.

title: Tasks for Transit
description: Some New York subway riders were so angered when their train was taken out of service recently that they refused to get off until the police came. Others who found themselves on a chilly day last week in a car whose air conditioning could not be turned off just sat and shivered, too demoralized even to try moving to another car. These and a million more bus, train and subway riders surely welcome a chance to tell the new chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Agency, Robert Kiley, how to manage the job he assumes on Monday.

title: SECURITY BREACH, NOT RIVALRY, SPURRED INQUIRY, MEESE SAYS
description: President Reagan's counselor, Edwin Meese 3d, said today that the current investigation into unauthorized disclosures by Administration officials was a move against a potential criminal violation of national security laws and ''absolutely not'' a result of rivalries among the President's aides.

title: BRAZIL'S ECONOMIC 'MIRACLE' AND ITS COLLAPSE
description: Brazil is the country that might have become another Japan. Instead, it is flat broke, with a broken spirit and an empty treasury.

ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 28

title: Interest Rates Down Slightly
description: Interest rates fell slightly yesterday in extremely light post-holiday trading. By late in the day, rates for outstanding Treasury bills had declined about two basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point, with three-month and six-month issues bid at rates of 8.80 percent and 8.95 percent, respectively.

title: 'Black Images on Film'
description: A ''Black Images on Film'' series is at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street, this weekend and next.

title: Denktash Is Adamant On New Cypriot State
description: The Turkish-Cypriot leader, Rauf Denktash, returned home today from visits to the United Nations and London and said nothing would make the newly-proclaimed Turkish-Cypriot state in the northern one-third of the island reverse its widely condemned proclamation of independence.

title: GOAL-LINE STAND IN LEARNING
description: The questions ''Why can't Johnny read?'' and ''Why

title: 76ers Win; Malone Outplays Sampson
description: Moses Malone scored 24 points and outrebounded Ralph Sampson, 13-7, as the Philadelphia 76ers broke away in the third quarter for a 115-101 victory over the Houston Rockets tonight.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: About Time

title: REFLECTONE INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income after income from discontinued operations of $44,118 for the quarter and $57,082 for the 6 months.

title: Pioneer Posts Profit for Year
description: The Pioneer Electronic Corporation, a leading maker of audio equipment, said today that its consolidated profit for the year ended Sept. 30 totaled $9.55 million, compared with a $13.1 million loss in the previous year.

title: CHAMBER: WORKS BY BERGMAN
description: In New York's new-music concerts, programs that expand beyond our normal diet of familiar local composers should always be encouraged. Thus the concert Monday night at Carnegie Recital Hall by the Washington Music Ensemble - a repeat of the same program heard two days earlier in Washington - was of special interest.

title: Couple on L.I. Adopt 5BrothersandSisters
description: A Long Island couple, looking for some company for their adopted daughter, today adopted five children, all from the same family.

title: CONSUMER SATURDAY
description: PEOPLE often feel helpless when

title: CHINESE COURIER'S BID FOR ASYLUM PROMPTS JET LANDING IN CHICAGO
description: A Pan American Airways transcontinental flight made an unscheduled stop here today after one passenger, a diplomatic courier for China, asked for political asylum.

title: WITNESS IN CO-OP CITY CORRUPTION INQUIRY IS SLAIN
description: A witness in a state and Federal investigation into allegations of corruption in a $10 million repair program at Co-op City was slain earlier this month, the Bronx District Attorney's office said yesterday.

title: SALARY GAINS BY POLICE WORRY JERSEY MAYORS
description: Recent salary increases awarded through binding arbitration to police officers and firefighters here have set the stage for increased demands from police unions in New Jersey's other major cities.

title: CORRECTION
description: An announcement of the marriage of Laurie Larson Levander and Paul J. Finn yesterday misstated the date of the wedding. The wedding took place last night.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article about Unilever in the Business People column of Business Day yesterday incorrectly identified H.F. van den Hoven in some editions. He is chairman of Unilever N.V. and vice chairman of Unilever P.L.C.

title: SUIT BRINGING A MURDER SUSPECT TO CIVIL TRIAL
description: Two and a half years after the April day when Kathy Kohm's parents last saw her alive, their civil suit is coming to trial against a man who was listed as a suspect but was never charged with murdering the 11-year-old girl.

title: THE TREASURY'S BIASED VIEW OF INDUSTRIAL DEVELOPMENT BONDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Melissa Moore Bride Of Kurt Kendell Look

Look of Peoria Heights, Ill. The Rev. Rodney Jay Barnes, pastor of the Hidden Valley Church (Universal Life Church) in Lawrence, Kan., performed the ceremony at the Moore home.

title: South African Visits Europe
description: Foreign Minister Roelof F. Botha left tonight for a two-week tour of Europe to discuss South-West Africa, a Government spokesman said. The spokesman said Mr. Botha would visit West Germany, Britain, Portugal, Italy and other countries. Britain and West Germany, along with France, Canada and the United States, are trying to negotiate independence for South-West Africa.

title: WESTCHESTER JOURNAL
description: FOR the last 12 years, mile marker ''NY 19'' has peeked out from beneath a pile of dirt and debris, not far from its original resting spot along the northbound tracks of the former New York Central Railroad. The huge granite column had been erected in about 1843 near the Scarsdale railroad station, to alert engineer and traveler alike that Grand Central Terminal was 19 miles to the south.

title: IF THERE WERE A HEISMAN, THEY MIGHT HAVE WON IT
description: AS every college football fan knows, Jay Berwanger of the University of Chicago was the first winner of the Heisman Trophy and the year was 1935. But football had been played many years before then; in the preceding decade, the sport had known a golden age unmatched before or since.

title: THE ARCHIVES ALSO COLLECTS LAWSUITS
description: The National Archives, staid repository of the Declaration of Independence, the Constitution and perhaps three billion other historical items, finds itself at the center of several very current controversies. First there are the Nixon tapes, the disputes over which seem destined to provide lifetime employment for a quarrel of lawyers. The latest development is a suit to compel the Archives to keep them secret. Then there are the Martin Luther King Jr. tapes. Senator Jesse Helms, Republican of North Carolina, tried to gain access to them in his unsuccessful attempt to raise doubts about the late civil rights leader and thereby block a national holiday memorializing him.

description: Jean M. Harford, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Harford of Darien, Conn., was married there yesterday to Eduardo L. Cortes, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jose A. Cortes of Bogota, Colombia. The Rev. Edward Howley performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church.

title: DEALING WITH A SLAM
description: For half a century or more there have been dealing machines, and someone even developed a table that did the dealing for you. But since most people were quite happy to do their own dealing, these remained curious toys.

title: NATURE WATCH SEA GOOSEBERRY Pleurobrachia pileus
description: Size: Three-quarters to one and one-eighth inch.

title: KAZAN EXAMINES VIOLENCE
description: ''THE Chain,'' the playwriting debut of Elia Kazan at the Hartman Theater in Stamford, Conn., deals with the perpetuation of violence that began with the fall of the House of Agamemnon, continued through centuries of war and now encompasses the threat of nuclear war.

title: GERMANY, UBER ALLES
description: The news is about new American missiles in Europe, threats of new Soviet deployments and the Soviet walkout from negotiations to regulate this phase of the arms race.

title: NAVY BIDDING CASE STIRS U.S. INQUIRY
description: The Justice Department has opened a preliminary investigation into allegations raised in a civil lawsuit that the Navy rigged bidding procedures last year to favor the Navy over civilian contractors in the manning of Government vessels, according to Administration officials and information presented in open court this week.

title: TIMES HAVE CHANGED, AND OYSTERS ARE YEAR-ROUND FARE
description: -round fare, the restrictions on consuming them only in months containing the letter ''R'' having become unnecessary in these days of controlled cultivation. The months that used to be avoided made up the summer spawning season. Some connoisseurs claim oysters are still less plump and flavorful during those months.

title: POLL SHOWS SUPPORT FOR POLITICAL GAINS BY WOMEN IN U.S.
description: The American public is generally committed to a greater political role for women, a New York Times Poll indicates, with half saying Congress would be improved by having more women as members.

title: HOLMES SEEKS BOUT AGAINST COETZEE
description: Larry Holmes said today that he was ''semiretired'' and that only a meeting with Gerrie Coetzee would make him fight again.

title: Turkish Cypriot Urges Review of U.N. Role
description: Rauf Denktash, leader of the self-proclaimed Turkish Cypriot republic, called today for a review of the deployment of United Nations troops in Cyprus and said United States coercion had stopped Islamic nations from recognizing his state.

title: ;  Behind Osborne

title: LYNN SUTLEY TO BE BRIDE
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jack R. Sutley of Al- legany, N.Y., have made knowth the engagement of their daughter, Lynn Marice Sutley, to Anthony William Hartmann, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wil- liam Edward Hartmann of Bethpage, L.I. Miss Suttley and her fiance, fourth-year medical students at the State University of New York Upstate Medical Center in Syracuse, plan to marry in May.

description: What happens if a Mitchell-Lama co-op pays off its mortgage? . . . G. M., Forest Hills, Queens

description: Roswitha Steiner of Austria, who was sidelined for a month this fall with a back injury, won the women's special slalom today at the ski world series.

title:
LONG ISLAND GUIDE;
 GREAT ESCAPE
description: On one of its recent voyages to protest commerical whaling, the Rainbow Warrior, a Greenpeace Foundation ship, confronted the Spanish Navy and lost, with the crew ending up in detention and the Warrior under harbor arrest. How the sailors and their ship escaped and the repercussions of the encounter are the subject of ''The Return of the Rainbow Warrior From Spain,'' a documentary that will be given its world premiere today at 1 and 3 P.M. at the Whaling Museum in Cold Spring Harbor. The museum is on Main Street, and admission is $1 or 75 for the elderly and 50 cents for children. READING NATURE

title: IN VIRGINIA, FREE RIDERS DO DRIVES A FAVOR
description: Before the sun rises, commuters are standing in the parking lot of a suburban restaurant, seeking or offering rides into Washington.

title: FUND FOR NEEDIEST OPENS 72D APPEAL
description: The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund opens its 72d annual appeal today in behalf of the poor and distressed in the New York metropolitan area.

title: GIANTS' SHAW EAGER TO WORK
description: Pete Shaw will return punts again for the Giants Sunday when they play the Raiders in the Los Angeles Memorial Coliseum. And that leaves him with mixed feelings.

title: D. K. Drake Wed To Susan Means
description: Susan Zimmerman Means, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Hammond Means of New Canaan, Conn., was married yesterday to Daniel Kenly Drake, son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Daniel Drake of Villanova, Pa. The Rev. William A. Eddy Jr. of St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan performed the ceremony in St. Michael's Lutheran Church in New Canaan.

title: PREZIOSO REFLECTS ON HIS YONKERS YEARS
description: YONKERS EARLY last year, Dr. Sal J. Prezioso came down from a campus in White Plains to run Yonkers - to close a budget gap, to negotiate labor contracts, to fix sidewalks.

title: IRISH FARRE IN COUNTY CORK--OR IN PARIS
description: ERICA BROWN is a writer based in London.

title: Article 071308 -- No Title
description: The Skins Game, a two-day television golf match among four of the game's most successful professionals, ended its first segment today with a two- hole carry-over. This means that when they tee off tomorrow, the 10th hole will be worth $60,000 to the winner.

title: ECONOMY GIVES SAUDIS GROWING PAINS
description: When the oil bonanza got under way a decade ago, not all Saudis welcomed it. Some warned that the mad rush to develop would lead to cultural disintegration. Petrobillions, they argued, would erode the country's puritanical values and its religious and political foundations. Cadillacs would replace not only camels but also the Koran.

title: DEFINING MARXISM
Metro-North Urged To Spur Ridership
description: The M.T.A. is now again talking about a substantial fare increase on the Metro-North Commuter Railroad's lines. Increased patronage, especially when services are underutilized as on weekends and holidays, would increase income yet little effort is being made to increase off- peak ridership.

title: ACCORD OR NOT, HOBOKEN PRESSES ON WATERFRONT
description: HOBOKEN SMILES abounded across the Hudson River last week as one of the messier disputes of the political season - funds for waterfront projects here and in the Hunters Point section of Queens - seemingly was resolved.

description: THE RIGHT TO LIFERS

title: HONDURAN WANTS A U.S. COMMITMENT
description: The chief of the Honduran armed forces says he hopes the close relations between Honduras and the United States will lead to a ''formal commitment'' by the United States to the security of Honduras.

description: Bessie Wheless Mercer, daughter of Mrs. George A. Mercer 3d, of Savannah, Ga., and the late Mr. Mercer, was married yesterday to Charles Day Halsey 3d, son of Sandra MacRae Halsey and Mr. Halsey Jr., both of New York. The Rev. George Maxwell performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church in Savannah.

title:
THE WORLD;
SALYUT CREW SAFELY BACK
description: It's been a bumpy year for the Soviet space program, but last week, astronauts Vladimir Lyakhov and Aleksandr Aleksandrov stepped safely from their descent module in Kazakhan after 150 days in Salyut 7, an orbiting laboratory.

title: COLLEGE SURVEY FINDS END TO DECLINE IN STUDENTS' ACHIEVEMENT
description: A survey of college officials aroundthe country indicates that academic achievement has stopped its decline of the 1960's and 1970's and may even be improving, particularly among students majoring in engineering and science.

title: SURGING PROFITS FILL CORPORATE TILLS
description: The nation's businesses continued to pile up profits in the third quarter - heartening news for economists worried that the recovery would stumble at the vital second stage of recovery, capital investment. After- tax profits rose 11.6 percent, to a $141.9 billion annual rate in the July- September period. This followed a 17.6 percent rise in the second quarter. The surge in earnings will help corporations avoid going further into debt to pay for new plants and equipment, plus reduce the chances that the heavy levels of Government borrowing will crowd out private borrowing and push rates higher. Economists have feared that business would balk at going deeper into debt and that after the current wave of strong consumer spending dies down there will be little economic vitality to keep the economy expanding.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: THE LAW GIVETH

title: VERMONT MAN SAYS POLICE IGNORED PLEA TO SEE DYING CHILD
description: A local man has filed an official complaint with the police over their treatment of him in a drunken-driving arrest as he rushed to be with his choking 2-year-old daughter, according to his attorney.

title: Evicted Laotians Leave A West Virginia Farm
description: Forty-one Laotian refugees evicted from a West Virginia farm where they had been offered a 99-year lease have traveled to Alabama to join other members of their tribe.

title: Supreme Court Hears Appeal Of Ex-Governor of Tennessee
description: Former Gov. Ray Blanton of Tennessee, citing prejudicial publicity, has asked the Supreme Court to review his conviction for awarding state liquor licenses to political friends in exchange for cash payments.

title: Robin Ruderman To Be Wed Jan. 7
description: Dr. and Mrs. Arthur L. Ruderman of Englewood Cliffs, N.J., and the Dutch portion of St. Martin in the Caribbean, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Robin Dale Ruderman, to Richard Bruce Landsberger of New York, son of Mrs. Daniel Loventhal of Roslyn, L.I., and Murray Landsberger of Fort Lee, N.J.

title: NEW FOR EMPTY NESTERS
description: Although cooperatives and condominiums are not entirely new to Lawrence, L.I., they have come about only through conversion of existing buildings: Developers who wanted to build them often met resistance in the upper-middle-class village, part of the Five Towns area in the southwestern corner of Nassau County. Work is now nearing completion, however, on the Carlyle, a 71-unit condominium at 376 Central Avenue whose developers, the Bluestone Organization, believe is the village's first newly constructed condominium.

title: 2 ARE KILLED AND 24 HURT AS BLASTS RIP THROUGH L.I. FIREWORKS PLANT
description: A series of explosions tore through the Grucci fireworks plant here today, heavily damaging the nation's largest fireworks factory and 100 nearby homes. Two people were killed and 24 were injured, the Suffolk County police said.

title: FILIPINO BISHOPS WARN MARCOS OF CHAOS
description: This country's Roman Catholic bishops issued a pastoral letter today warning of chaos and anarchy and appealing for an end to repressive measures that they said violated the law and basic rights.

title: BASKETBALLL COACH AIDED BY HUSBAND
description: JUST before Fairfield University's women's varsity basketball team was scheduled to meet Ireland's national squad in an exhibition game recently, Dianne Nolan, the Fairfield team's head coach, tried to get her 15 players to enjoy their meal at a restaurant - without tension.

title: CORRECTION
description: An article last week about the sale of property in Garden City for a condominium project incorrectly indicated that Myron Nelkin, builder of the Garden City Hotel, was the builder of The Hamlet, a luxury condominium project in Jericho. The developers and builders of the 440- unit Hamlet project are Gerald and Elliot Monter.

title: NETS TOP CLIPPERS, 104-102
description: Behind a game-high 30 points from Otis Birdsong - including 13 of his team's final 19 - the Nets ended their longest trip of the season tonight with a stirring 104-102 triumph over the San Diego Clippers before 7,236 fans here at the Sport Arena.

description: To the Editor:

title: THE HOLIDAY ENGINE AND THE NEEDIEST
description: Thanksgiving starts the holiday engine; it'll soon be spinning at full speed. People who promised themselves, again, that this year they'd do their shopping right after Labor Day are starting to crowd the stores. At this very moment, other provident souls may be correcting last year's mailing list for Christmas cards. Some party invitations have already gone out, and families plan to come together for festive dinners lit by the glow of candles and by prayers for peace and prosperity.

title: CONSUMER JOB ISSUE
description: RICHARD M. KESSEL is No. 2 now on the state's Consumer Protection Board, but if he tries harder, he may be No. 1 - much to the chagrin of many Republicans and even some of his fellow Democrats.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Starch-blocker RulingWhen is a kidney bean derivative a drug, not a food? When it is a popular diet aid known as a starch blocker, according to Federal District Court Judge Abraham Sofaer in Manhattan. The Food and Drug Administration has already ordered the pills off the market until it can test their safety and effectiveness.

title: RESTORATION ALMOST FINISHED ON SISTINE ART'S FIRST PHASE
description: Art experts have almost completed the first phase of a $3 million project to restore the frescoes by Michelangelo in the Sistine Chapel of the Vatican, an official of the Vatican Museum has announced.

title: PENNSYLVANIA DUTCH FARMER'S MARKETS
description: ROBERT MEYERS is a writer who lives in Alexandria, Va.

title: THE RETURN OF ENCHANTMENT Kathleen Agena, a contributing editor of Partisan Review, is writing a book about Western culture today. By Kathleen Agena
description: NCE UPON A TIME, THERE WAS a land across the seas that grew rich and mighty because its people were hard-working and ingenious. In fact, the country became so strong, with its machines and its awesome weapons, that the people felt they could abandon their gods and temples and rely altogether on their wealth and their reason. But then, one day, the people began to worry that their machines and their weapons were getting out of control, and they began to ask questions their reason could not answer. They felt helpless, and they began to long for the old gods and ancient mysteries. . . .

title: RECYCLING MILLS
description: Having outlived their usefulness, old mill buildings common to many Northeastern industrial communities are often valued mostly as cheap storage facilities. But now many of these urban white elephants are being sought after and recycled as fashionable office and retail buildings.

title: MIDEAST CAPTIVES GEET TO GO HOME
description: Yasir Arafat's branch of the Palestine Liberation Organization found a way to reach an agreement with Israel last week - on a prisoner exchange - but whether the Palestinians could agree among themselves was in doubt. Both Mr. Arafat and the Syrian-backed rebels' chief of staff, Col. Abu Khaled al-Omlah, questioned the reported terms of a cease-fire and withdrawal agreement. The rebels had said that unless there was agreement and Mr. Arafat left Tripoli, they would resume attacking his forces in the heart of the Lebanese city, where he is beseiged. Yesterday, however, there were only minor exchanges of fire in Tripoli.

title: TERROR FINDS A NEW TARGET
description: In Northern Ireland, where nearly everything is defined by religion, last Sunday's attack by nationalist gunmen on a Protestant church congregation was a new kind of horror. Seventy members of the Mountain Lodge Pentecostal Church in Darkley, a town near the border with the Irish Republic, were singing hymns when two masked men burst in firing automatic weapons.

title: NONFICTION IN BRIEF
description: CHANNELS OF POWER

title: NEW DISKS EMBODY THE SPIRIT OF CHRISTMAS
description: Many great artists have recorded Christmas music. Enrico Caruso gave us a fine version of Adam's ''Cantique de N"oel,'' John McCormack offered ''Away in A Manger'' and ''Adeste Fideles,'' among others, while Ernestine Schumann-Heink's radio performances of ''Silent Night'' became a holiday tradition. Now Marilyn Horne, Leontyne Price, Elly Ameling and Ivan Rebroff have joined these august ranks, with new albums specifically created for a holiday audience.

title: REAGAN TURNS TO ISRAEL
description: Bernard Gwertzman, a Times correspondent, has been reporting on foreign policy from Washington for the past two decades. By Bernard Gwertzman FTER FAILING FOR more than a year to make much headway with its Middle East initiatives, the Reagan Administration has decided to turn to Israel for help. That is the word today in a White House candidly frustrated over the continuing impasse in Lebanon, increasing tension in the whole region and conspicuous lack of support from most Arab governments. To break out of its predicament, the United States, it is felt, must take more resourceful advantage of the political and military power base represented by the Jewish state. A senior American official puts it this way: ''If we don't have good, close relations with Israel, we will have no anchor in the region. We will be alone with a battleship and 2,000 marines.'' To secure this anchor, President Reagan has secretly authorized a new effort to convince Israel's leaders that the two countries should put aside their recriminations and enter into a degree of ''strategic cooperation'' that would go far beyond anything tried before. It is a potentially controversial policy. There is little enthusiasm for it in the Pentagon, which would have to play the leading role in the largely military measures envisaged in the plan. If carried out, the new policy could further damage America's standing as mediator between Arabs and Israelis. It could even split the Middle East into Israeli-American and Syrian-Soviet spheres.

title:
STAMPS;
FOR HUMAN RIGHTS
description: For the first time, the U.N. Postal Administration has turned to a world-famous artist, Friedensreich Hundertwasser, to create an issue for the world organization, instead of having a competition by designers from U.N. nations. This new policy starts with the issue of six commemoratives on Dec. 9 to mark the 35th anniversary of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

title: Circus Of Misfortune
description: The 18th-century philosopher Jeremy Bentham's watch-word was the greatest number. One corollary of this is that a practice that might be extremely beneficial for a small group could not be considered good if it did harm to a great many.

title: MUSIC: DEBUTS IN REVIEW
description: Could it be this writer's imagination or has New York been getting a better class of debut recitalist lately? This season's performers seem older, better prepared and, in general, possessors of solid professional talents.

title: Miss Jordan Extended
description: Kathy Jordan had to play two hours today to beat Elizabeth Sayers of Australia in the semifinals of the New South Wales tennis tournament, 6-2, 6-7, 6-0.

title: BARBER'S LONG WAIT ENDS AS HE BECOMES JET STARTER
description: Some time last year, the fog lifted for Marion Barber. But the cloud remained.

The Rev. Barry Miller performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church.
description: Theresa Margaret Krupp, Donna Marie Krupp and Maura Elizabeth Krupp, the bridegroom's daughters from a previous marriage that ended in divorce, attended the bride. Joseph DeAngelis served as best man.

description: Chris Mullin, a 20-year-old junior, scored 21 points last night as St. John's University easily defeated Canisius, 71-45, in the final of the ninth annual Joe Lapchick Memorial Tournament last night at Alumni Hall in Jamaica, Queens.

title: KEVLAR SAIL CURB CAUSING TURMOIL
description: Grand prix ocean racing has been thrown into a turmoil because of the decision to ban in part the use of Kevlar in sails. Although details of the ban have not yet been worked out, it takes effect Feb. 1. That leaves owners and sailmakers who had anticipated a rescinding in a quandary as to what type of sails they should build now for next season.

title: PRACTICAL TRAVELER: WHEN AN AIRLINE DEFAULTS
description: The failure of the travel industry to help thousands of holders of useless tickets on Continental Airlines illustrates how vulnerable consumers can be to financial loss and how weak are the measures to protect them.

title: Debra Zimmerman Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ronald F. Zimmerman of Laurel Hollow, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Debra Beth Zimmerman, to Dr. Robert Mark Kotloff, son of Dr. and Mrs. Leon Kotloff of Wynnewood, Pa.

title: MARCOS YIELDS A BIT, FOES DEMAND MORE
description: Philippine President Ferdinand E. Marcos made a major concession to his political opponents last week, but rather than easing the pressures on the faltering leader, it seemed only to intensify them. As the week ended, 110 Roman Catholic bishops released a pastoral letter - to be read in church today on what would have been the 51st birthday of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the assassinated opposition leader - urging Mr. Marcos to end his ''repressive decrees'' and call new elections.

title: A NEW MUSEUM HAS AN INSTANT IMPACT
description: Five years ago the need for a museum of contemporary art in Los Angeles was no more than a subject of conversation. One conversation, however, happened to be between Mayor Tom Bradley and a prominent Los Angeles collector, Marcia Weisman, and it eventually led to a blue- ribbon committee, a museum site, a museum staff, a proposed building, and finally to last Sunday, when the Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles opened its doors with an extensive exhibition called ''The First Show: Painting and Sculpture From Eight Collections, 1940-80.'' The long- anticipated, much publicized, already controversial museum of art was opened - and its impact on Los Angeles is beginning to be felt immediately.

title: FROM ACROPOLIS TO ZAPPION
description: DAVID PLANTE, an American writer, has lived in London for 20 years. His book, ''The Secret,'' will be published by Atheneum.
