description: WANTED: Young person to train for skilled job in the technology field. No experience, no college needed. Job security and potential high pay.

title: THE REGION
description: Shoreham PanelWeighs WhereTo Send the BillLike the nuclear reactor it was impaneled to study, Governor Cuomo's Commission on Shoreham has been plagued by problems and delays. The fact-finding panel appeared last week, however, to have reached a consensus on some critical issues and was expected to finish its work ahead of the Long Island Lighting Company, whose almost completed nuclear power plant is now 10 years behind schedule and 10 times over its original budget. The commission's findings could make it more difficult for Lilco to open its $4 billion reactor.

title: HUMPHREY DANCERS TO OPEN SEASON
description: THE first fall season for the Humphrey Dance Ensemble of Tarrytown is to get under way Thursday and continues Friday, Saturday and next Sunday at the Masters School in Dobbs Ferry. Original dance works will be presented by the seven-year-old troupe, which till now has performed on an irregular basis and has been seen thus far this fall in a lecture-demonstration program at public and at private schools in Westchester, Rockland and Putnam Counties.

title: FARMERS IN 12 JERSEY COUNTIES ELIGIBLE FOR DROUGHT AID
description: The Government has declared that farmers in 12 New Jersey counties are eligible for Federal emergency loans to help them recover their losses from last summer's drought.

title: CUTS IN DAILY NEWS LAID TO PRINTING PROBLEMS
description: The Daily News has reduced the space it gives to general news, sports, business and feature coverage by 10 percent because of problems with printing the paper that have also contributed to a 10 percent drop in circulation, according to its editor, James G. Wieghart.

title: Conflict Charged
description: George Steinbrenner , principal owner of the Yankees, has been sent a letter by the Florida Division of Parimutuel Wagering, charging him with conflict of interest, according to a published report. Steinbrenner, who owns thoroughbred horses, often races them at Tampa Bay Downs, in which his wife and children hold 50 percent of the stock.

title: AUTHORS SOMETIMES PUBLISH AND PERISH
description: One rainy afternoon shortly before Christmas 1972, Isaac Asimov, George Plimpton and Judith Rossner joined other writers in setting up a pushcart and bookstalls on Manhattan's Fifth Avenue at 60th Street. They were protesting the publishing industry's ''antiquated'' and ''unimaginative'' book selling methods. Nowadays, authors still bridle at the way publishers handle their books, but they are taking to the courts, rather than the streets. The result so far has been a few wins, one draw and a great deal of industry soul searching.Last year, a writer named Bill Starr won a suit in Municipal Small Claims Court in Los Angeles against Pinnacle Books, which Mr. Starr accused of failing to market and advertise in good faith his novel ''Chance Fortune.'' ''The defense asked whether I knew there were writers of different quality,'' said Marvin Gevurtz, who presided over the hearing. ''My response was that if you feel a person is untalented or unworthy of a full-faith effort, you shouldn't enter into a contract with him.'' Last month, in an out-of-court settlement of another suit, Harcourt Brace Jovanovich paid $100,000 to Deborah Davis, author of ''Katharine the Great,'' a 1979 biography of Katharine Graham, chairman of the Washington Post Company. Miss Davis had sued Harcourt Brace for $6 million charging breach of contract; the publisher, she said, had recalled the book and pulped copies. (Harcourt Brace denied the charge, but said it had returned the publication rights to the author after belatedly discovering extensive factual errors in the book.)

title: PRETORIA MOVES TO ERASE 'BLACK SPOT'
description: Elizabeth Katitswe runs the Swartkop General Dealers Store here.

title: AT THE END OF A TROUBLED TERM
description: Fisk University, one of the oldest and most prestigious of black institutions of higher learning, has for several years also been one of the most financially troubled. Last week, its president, Dr. Walter J. Leonard, took apparently the only remaining step within his power to aid the Nashville school: He resigned.

title: No Headline
description: State Senator Philip O. Mastin Jr. angered some of his constituents when he voted to raise taxes earlier this year, they returned the favor last week. They made him the first state official in Michigan history to be turned out of office in a voter-initiated recall election.

title: PROSPECTS
description: Inflation Storm Warnings

title: HAROLD STERN
description: Harold Stern, a labor lawyer in New York City for 50 years until he retired last year, died Friday at New York Hospital.

title: CHINESE ARTIST, FREED FROM PEKING JAIL, JOINS FIANCE IN PARIS
description: A Chinese dissident artist jailed in 1981 for living with her fiance, a French diplomat, was reunited with her fiance here today.

title: ATHENEUM GETS A NEW LOOK
description: THE Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford calls itself the oldest continuously operating public museum in the country, but soon it will look like one of the newest.

title: HIS PAINTINGS STRESS THE PAINT
description: THE first in a series of exhibitions by invited artists is now on view at the Dan Flavin Art Institute in Bridgehampton, and it is evident that Mr. Flavin has chosen a kindred spirit to share his space.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Church TakesStrong PositionOn Family RightsAt a time when many nations are trying to limit population growth and when many industrialized countries have seen an increase in women working outside the home, the Vatican last week sent out a strong reassertion of older values. Parents should be allowed to have as many children as they wish, the church said, while women should not only be encouraged to stay home and take care of their families but should be paid for their efforts.

title: STATE PURCHASES 10,723 ACRES IN FOREST PRESERVES PROGRAM
description: New York State has purchased 10,723 acres in the Adirondack and Catskill Mountains to add to the state forest preserves in the 18- month period ended Sept. 30, the State Department of Environmental Conservation has announced.

title: GRANDMOTHER'S CASTLES IN THE AIR
description: AHOPE chest is a special place, a corner here, a cranny there, a pile in the attic, an item in a cabinet, for the dreams of tomorrow. Hand- knitted in the finest and thinnest of wools, a white baby-carriage cover, in gosamer feather-stich pattern, with pillow cover to match, nestles in an oblong box, waiting to be used again. Carefully wrapped in tissues, how well it has kept these many years. Beribboned the bootees, the mittens, the sacque to match. What joy it will be to hand them down for the child of my child.

title: SHOREHAM: MARSHALING THE FIGURES
description: THE battle over Shoreham has entered a new and esoteric phase - computer combat. The Long Island Lighting Company on one side and the Governor's special commission on Shoreham on the other have been working late, entering into their computers long lists of figures on future oil prices, reactor performance, electric consumption and other variables. They have been pumping out precise predictions of rates, and calculations of just how much it would cost to operate Shoreham and how much to abandon it.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: YOUTHS IN DISTRESS

title: THEATER: 'PUPPETPLAY,' WITH NEGRO ENSEMBLE
description: Pearl Cleage's ''Puppetplay'' is a look at a futuristic world that turns people into robots and allows puppets to become a kind of silent ruling class. The play could be taking place in a windowless room on a side street in ''Blade Runner,'' but it lacks, among other things, that film's pulsating sense of authenticity and environment. ''Puppetplay,'' which opens the Negro Ensemble Company's current season in the attractively refurbished Theater Four, is brief but languid.

title: MUSIC: SOUTH AMERICAN FESTIVAL
description: Folklore and show business came together Friday at Carnegie Hall for the South American and Andes Festival '83. It included dancers from Argentina, a harpist from Ecuador and an Andes folk quartet, Sukay.

title: B. D. Smith Betrothed To Donna R. Dyckman
description: Mr. and Mrs. Samuel A. Dyckman of Briarwood, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Donna Robyn Dyckman, to Brian David Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Smith of Woodbridge, N.J.

title: LEPZIG
description: To the Editor:

title: IRONY, CRUELTY AND LYRICISM

DINING OUT;
COUNTRY CHIC IN ARMONK
description: ESTABLISHING themselves near corporate parks, conference centers are beginning to dot the county's many sprawling verdant acres. More than a hotel and very little less than a resort, the center offers enough of both, plus an astonishing assortment of conference and dining rooms, to attract not only businessmen but also those in the mood for a minivacation not too far from home. Golf courses, stables, riding paths, indoor and outdoor pools and tennis courts, fishing and boating ponds, garden walks and woodland trails are typical of the facilities at many of these places.

title: A TOUCH OF HOME IN HOSPITAL CARE
description: Barbara Berg's most recent book, ''Nothing to Cry About: The Story of One Woman's Quest for Motherhood,'' was released in paperback last August. By Barbara Berg

title: SOME MADE-FOR-TV FILMS ARE MORE THAN FLUFF
description: The TV movie is here to stay, but, as one of the newer kids on the entertainment block, it will have to take its knocks, especially from those who toil in the presumably loftier levels of ''film.'' As just about everybody knows, TV movies are made on relatively low budgets and, in terms of rehearsal and shooting time, almost on the run. There is usually little time for subtlety or artistic imprint. In fact, that's how most of the early Hollywood films were made, the same films that are now viewed as classics in tiny theaters, museums and on public television. But no matter. The TV movie, notorious for its preoccupations with inspirational fluff and the disease of the week, has become today's easiest target of ridicule.

title: Wendy Villa Married To Charlton Robinson
description: Wendy Lippincott Villa, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony L. Villa of Peapack, N.J., and Charlton Peter Robinson, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Bernard T. Robinson of New Bedford, Mass., were married yesterday. The Rev. Vincent Dwyer performed the ceremony at St. Brigid Roman Catholic Church in Peapack.

title: THE ARTS AND CABLE: AN UNEASY MARRIAGE?
description: Art isn't dead on cable, exactly. But after the demise of CBS Cable and The Entertainment Channel, there are doubts whether viewers will support both - or either - of the two surviving culture channels, Bravo and ABC ARTS.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN MIAMI
description: Miami Beach is still the first choice of millions of snowbirds, despite its loss of some luster and charm. And what it lacks these days might be made up by including Miami in the visit. But there are several things a visitor should know to fully appreciate the sprawling international community of Miami and Miami Beach, which only a few years back was basically a vacation and retirement resort for white Americans from the North. Some things haven't changed, while others have.

title: Sachem Wins Title on Last-Second Play
description: It took until the last play of the final game of the playoffs, but Sachem High School ended East Islip's 21- game winning streak yesterday as it upset the defending champion, 20-14, in the Suffolk Division I final.

title: HOW TO PREPARE A GARDENB FOR THE LONG, COLD WINTER
description: Lois B. Himes is a professional gardener and freelance writer.

title: APPEALS COURT VOIDS AWARDS TO TEACHER HURT BY STUDENT
description: A teacher who said he suffered a disabling injury while breaking up a fight in a junior high school cannot recover damages from New York City, the State Court of Appeals has decided.

title: Texas Police Officers Build a New Station
description: The Police Department had no headquarters, but with $13,000 from the town and a lot of donated time on weekends, the force built its own.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Joe Polowsky saw that no one nation is the center of this world.

title: Jill Terry Deane and Wayne S. Groh Are Married
description: Jill Terry Deane, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice A. Deane of Kings Point, L.I., was married yesterday to Wayne Stephen Groh, son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Groh of Ramsey, N.J. Rabbi Stephen Pinsky of Temple Israel in Minneapolis performed the ceremony at the Plaza Hotel, assisted by Rabbi Jerome Davidson of Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, L.I.

title: Georgia Prevails,27-24
description: Georgia needed a last-minute interception by the sophomore cornerback Tony Flack to insure a 27-24 victory over Georgia Tech today.

title: CHILDE HASSAM'S LEGACY CONTINUES TO FLOWER
description: Atrue believer in American art was the painter Childe Hassam (1859-1935), one of the best known - though perhaps not the best - of the polite breed known as American Impressionists. ''Our own art is as good as any other in the world today,'' he told a reporter for a New York daily in 1932, ''and it certainly should be the most important to us, in spite of all the little snobs who come out of college and litter the land with encomiums on every dab of paint that comes out of dressmaking Paris.''

title: THE HIT-AND-RUN EXPRESS
description: NICK YAPP is an English short story writer, broadcaster and the author of numerous stories for children.

title: SKIING VAIL, FAMILY STYLE
description: CRAIG R. WHITNEY is an assistant managing editor of The New York Times.

title: Wine Enthusiasts: Assurance on Future
description: I wish to set the record straight regarding the Westchester Wine Enthusiasts Chapter of Les Amis du Vin, the second-oldest chapter in Westchester, continuously holding monthly tastings for the last three years in various southern Westchester locations.

title: The Male Myth
description: HERE IS A PATHETIC SEN tence in the chapter ''Fetishism'' in Dr. Norman Cameron's book ''Personality Development and Psychopathology.'' It goes: ''Fetishists are nearly always men; and their commonest fetish is a woman's shoe.'' I cannot read that sentence without thinking that it is just one more awful thing about being a man - and perhaps it is the most important thing to know about us.

title: 'I CAN PLAY A PRISONER, BELIEVE ME'
description: SOME actors are cast according to type, and some are cast according to ''hype.'' While, superficially, it may seem that the selection of Billy Hayes for the leading role in ''Bent,'' which opened Friday at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst, fits neatly into the latter category, it also appears to be a rare case of casting inspired by comparable experience. The director, Roy Siegel, hopes that, in the final tally, Mr. Hayes's talent will be the thing people will talk about.

title: Arnsparger Interested
description: Bill Arnsparger , the Miami Dolphins' defensive coordinator and a former head coach of the Giants, is looking to move back to the head coaching ranks, this time in college football. Arnsparger said yesterday that he had had ''exploratory'' talks with Louisiana State's athletic director, Bob Brodhead , about the possibility of replacing L.S.U.'s coach, Jerry Stovall , if Stovall is dismissed.

title: BUSINESS NOTES
description: -P-A Transport Corporation of North Bergen, Arthur E. Imperatore, has surrendered a former title, that of president, to his stepson, Armand Pohan, so that he might turn his attention to the development of 350 acres of waterfront property that he owns in Weehawken and West New York.

title: Engineers Recommend Against Bridge Barrier
description: Even though a barrier could prevent head-on collisions on the Golden Gate Bridge, an engineering study says, it would cause so many problems that it should not be built.

title: New Jersey Journal
description: WITH cold weather approaching, New Jersey officials are becoming concerned about the 10,000 to 20,000 homeless men, women and children wandering the streets. The Governor and a legislator have put forth proposals to cope with the problem.

title: COAST JUDGE TRAINS APPRENTICE LAWYERS
description: By day, Charles Porter presides over East Kern Municipal Court. On Wednesday nights, in the same courtroom, he is the lone faculty member of a four-year law school.

title: FOR N.Y.U., MEMORIES AND A VICTORY
description: When New York University resumed varsity basketball last night after a 12-year hiatus, only one player on the Violet roster had any collegiate experience, and he was nursing a sprained ankle.

title: WHAT PRICE GLORY?
description: How much competition is enough for a regular on the international tournament circuit depends on what generation he belongs to and also his own life and career style.

title: PROTECTING THOSE WHO BUY CO-OPS
description: ON Sept. 1, James M. Morrissey was appointed chief of the Attorney General's Real Estate Financing Bureau, which regulates offerings of real-estate securities in the state, including cooperatives, condominiums, homeowners' associations, time shares and syndications.

title: CAN DEMOCRACY SURVIVE THE SALVADORAN DEATH SQUADS?
description: As the national preoccupation with the seemingly successful invasion of Grenada faded, President Reagan had to turn back last week to problems of a more lasting nature, such as what to do about Lebanon and the breakdown of the medium-range missile talks with Moscow. The Grenada decision was mostly a test of Mr. Reagan's instincts. The Middle East and arms control negotiations pose a tougher test of his decision-making system.

title: No Boycott Envisioned
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, today reaffirmed his belief that there would be no boycott by the Soviet Union of the 1984 Summer Games in Los Angeles.

title: CONSUMER RATES
THE MIND AND WORKS OF A GUERRILLA
description: THE DEATH OF CHE GUEVARA THOUGHT By Jay Cantor. 578 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $17.95.

title: Court Rejects 3 Life Terms
description: The South Dakota Supreme Court, in its first ruling reflecting the United States Supreme Court's ruling on cruel and unusual punishment, on Friday struck down three life sentences given to Kenneth Weiker for three counts of distributing drugs. Mr. Weiker was sentenced under the state's habitual offender law because he had been convicted three times before of third-degree burglary. The South Dakota court said the sentences did not fit the crime and ordered that Mr. Weiker be resentenced.

title: NATURAL GAS AND INSURANCE AMONG BIG-SPENDING LOBBYISTS

Biglin of Weehawken, N.J. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York. He was assisted by the Rev. Peter Colapietro, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: 'TO ALL YE PILGRIMS'
description: After 48 years of wedded bliss - one wife, three sons and three grandchildren - I've finally come up with a better way to spend Thanksgiving.

title: Liberian General Reported Shot to Death
description: A top Liberian Army general has been shot dead, apparently by accident, during preparations for an attempted coup against the Liberian President, Samuel K. Doe, the Monrovia radio reported today.

description: century inn here that catered to stagecoach travelers and once belonged to an Italian prince, is being rehabilitated.

The play ''Full Hookup,'' by Conrad Bishop and Elizabeth Fuller, will begin previews on Dec. 13 at the Circle Repertory Theater, 99 Seventh Avenue South.

title: CELEBRITY ISN'T MUCH TO CELEBRATE IN THESE MOVIES
description: ''You look familiar,'' the cab driver said, turning around to speak to his fare, a woman who, by chance, has written some of the greatest words ever heard spoken from the American stage and screen. ''Should I know you?'' The woman, who later admitted to feeling some pleasure at the question, told the fellow her name. There was a moment's silence. Then, ''I never heard of you.'' End of conversation.

title: PRESERVE PLANNED FOR RARE PUPFISH
description: The rare Devil's Hole pupfish, which survived 20,000 years before being threatened by humans, may get a permanent preserve if a conservation group can raise $500,000 to buy a 13,000- acre oasis in the Mojave Desert.

title: CHOICES ON SALVADOR
description: The United States faces two stark choices in El Salvador. It should try first to persuade the armed forces to discipline officers involved in the assassination squads that have killed thousands of civilians over the past three years. Should it fail to do so, it must withdraw military and economic aid, even if this means carnage on the right or a victory by the left.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article Nov. 13 on the proposed breakup of Gulf Oil misstated the status of two companies' holdings. Du Pont did not sell the coal holdings of its Conoco unit, and Marathon Oil did not have any major chemical operations when acquired by United States Steel.

description: A jury said today it could not agree on a verdict in the trial of a black man accused of attacking two white police officers, but Judge Randall Thomas of Montgomery County Circuit Court ordered the jury to continue deliberations.

Kohn of Stamford, Conn., were married yesterday at the New Haven Lawn Club. Rabbi Robert Gelberman and the Rev. Thomas Sievel, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated.

title: SHORTAGES ARE A STAPLE IN POLAND
description: ''We eat some meat about three times a week,'' said the middle-aged man with the droopy blond mustache and tired eyes. ''I find it hard to talk about the kind of meat we are eating, just about how lucky we are to get it.''

title: BRINGING UP BABY, OR VICE VERSA
description: Daniel Menaker is an editor of The New Yorker. By Daniel Menaker NTIL A FEW weeks before our son - William; 4 months; doing very well, thanks; yes, that is quite a double chin he has there; no, I don't think he's too warm with that blanket; yes, I know I look tired - arrived, my wife and I neglected to read the books on child care and development that we had bought or had been lent or given by friends. We had the standards - like Penelope Leach's ''Your Baby and Child,'' and, of course, Dr. Spock's ''Baby and Child Care'' - and some more-abstract, theoretical works concerning infants' ''sophisticated cognitive capabilities'' and ''spatial conceptualizations'' and ''neurosensory maturation.'' They all sat around in our apartment looking serious. I think it was the fear that reading these books would overwhelm other interests that kept us from starting in on them. But finally, the larger fear of complete parental amateurism took over, and we devoured the experts like spies who have only the last 10 minutes before dawn to pore over some secret code books they've just stumbled upon.

title: PORTRAITS FROM VERSAILLES ANIMATE FRENCH HISTORY
description: WASHINGTON, D.C. The most inventive new exhibition in Washington, D.C., is called ''Masterpieces From Versailles: Three Centuries of French Portraiture.'' It deserves to be full to overflowing, and it can be seen through Jan. 8 at the National Portrait Gallery.

title: CHILDBIRTH AFTER 35: DISPELLING MYTHS
description: A paper on older mothers, presented at the national conference of the National Association of Social Workers here last week, concludes that some of the stereotypes and misconceptions about being parents after the age of 35 are unfounded.

description: LEO J. GALLAGHER JR., a Stamford funeral director, says some of his colleagues in the funeral industry have told him they want ''nothing to do with'' him since he became a partner in a low-cost cremation service.

description: FOLLOWING is a partial listing of Connecticut's shelters for the homeless. Some provide meal service, and all accept donations of food and clothing. ANSONIA - Naugatuck Valley Interfaith Housing Project. First Congregational Church, 44 South Cliff Street. 734-0544. 14 beds for men, women and families. Covers Ansonia, Derby, Shelton, Seymour and Oxford.

description: A sampling of Social Security records shows that nearly one in five Americans who receive retirement or survivors' benefits was paid the wrong amount at least once in a 55-month period, officials say.

title: Kidnapped Baby Girl Found In Basket by a Sicilian Road
description: An 18-month-old girl who was kidnapped 40 days ago has been found unhurt in a basket on a roadside, officials said today.

title: Forecaster Calls Storm 'Dangerous' to Travelers By The Associated Press
description: The second dangerous snowstorm in a week lurched toward the Plains yesterday after it dropped up to a foot of snow on the central Rockies overnight. Highways were iced from Arizona to South Dakota, and drifts forced the closing of Interstate 70 for 200 miles.

title: CHARISMATIC MANIPULATOR
description: BRECHT By Ronald Hayman. Illustrated. 423 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: Boston Puzzler
description: It was just two years ago this week that Joan L. Webster, a 25-year-old graduate student at Harvard University, disappeared shortly after landing at Logan Airport in Boston. And it was only two months ago that the police got what they thought might be the first break in the case: a powerboat that they had raised from the bottom of Boston Harbor.

title: ON BACH'S 'CHA CONNE' AND OTHER BAFFLING TIDBITS
description: Every so often, I'm sure, we all come across tantalizing bits of information that strike us at the moment as terribly significant in some way that we can not immediately pin down. Sometimes such flashes lead somewhere important. When Archimedes jumped out of his famous bathtub and ran into the street screaming ''Eureka!'' he was actually onto something. The apple that hit Newton on the head also proved provoked further, fruitful thoughts. It is only the geniuses, however, who are able to detect a larger point in such vagrant ideas. If I, rather than Galileo, had noticed one day that the earth rotated around the sun, I probably would have made a quick note of it and dropped it into a manila folder for inclusion in a column of odds and ends such as this.

title: DOES THE CONSTRUCTION FREEZE LEAVE PATIENTS IN THE COLD?
description: Early this year, Governor Cuomo and State Health Commissioner David Axelrod ordered a one-year freeze on new hospital construction in the state, saying discipline had to be imposed on the rising cost of health care. The city's voluntary hospitals - private, not-for-profit facilities that include some of the nation's top medical research and teaching centers - were hardest hit by the freeze. Their proposals accounted for $3.5 billion of the $5 billion in new projects now on hold throughout the state.

description: MUSICALLY the Yuletide activity begins as early as this Thursday, when the University of Connecticut's Opera Workshop raises the curtain on Gian Carlo Menotti's ''Amahl and the Night Visitors.

title: ARE THERE MORE OF THOSE WITH LESS?
description: WASHINGTON FEW statistical tasks are charged with more political significance than the definition and measurement of poverty. Liberals who want to spend more on antipoverty programs cite Census Bureau data showing that the official poverty rate has risen in each of the last four years and that there are nearly 10 million more poor people now than in 1978.

title: ALLAIRE: RICH IN HISTORY AND WILDLIFE

title: RAPE LAW: ENDING THE OLD LOOPHOLES
description: THE recent decision by a County Court judge to acquit two of four defendants for the ''gang rape'' of a 15-year-old Yonkers girl has called into serious question the nature of the state's rape laws and their enforcement in the county. Members of the Westchester County Family Violence Committee, in public meetings and in Friday's conference on ''Rape: 1983'' have called for legislative reforms and the monitoring of judges to prevent a recurrence of the tragedy in which a county judge acquitted two defendants he found had had sexual intercourse with a young girl who had been drugged and did not consent.

title: WHALES HEAD DOWN THE COAST OF CALIFORNIA
description: From time immemorial, the journey has been the same: 8,000 to 10,000 miles round trip, from icy Arctic waters to the warm lagoons of Baja California and back again. The travelers are barnacle-encrusted baleen whales, known as California gray whales, with their huge flukes and mottled gray backs and the plumes of water discharged when they blow.

title: MUSIC: WELSH MEN'S CHORUS AT ST. JOHN THE DIVINE
description: The concert given by Cor Meibion De Cymru - a 500-member Welsh men's chorus - at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Friday night was a celebration of a national and cultural heritage. An outsider looked on, appreciating what was heard, but also felt, even in the most familiar of music, a style that was just slightly alien. It was just alien enough, in fact, so its contrasts with the familiar became provocative.

title: FIFTH GRADERS TAKING OPERA ROLES
description: ''THE idea is to fool the audience,'' the veteran opera singer Llyanna Lynch-Huls advised a group of 16 fifth graders at the Wading River School. ''You'll have to walk on stage quietly - no shuffling. Feel as though you are those gingerbread children.''

title: ONE BOXING TRAINER'S TRIANGLE
description: LAS VEGAS, Nev.

title: IT ALL BEGAN WITH BEING GAUNT
description: ''It's impossible to mow the grass without harming it. We believe grass has some sort of consciousness, that it has feelings.'' - Quote from a member of the Fruitarian Network, a vegetarian lobbying group.

title: Couples Shares Lead
description: Fred Couples of the United States and Bernard Langer of West Germany shared the lead for the second straight day today after shooting 74's in the third round of the Casio world golf tournament. Their 54-hole totals of 216, even par on the 6,979-yard, par- 72 Ibusuki Country Club course, was a stroke ahead of Masahiro Kuramoto of Japan.

title: 'RIGHT TO KNOW' RULE IS READY
description: When the Carter Administration proposed that workers should be told if they were handling hazardous chemicals and how their health might be affected, industry spokesmen complained. Telling all would be expensive and blabbing about ''secret ingredients'' would be bad business, they said.

title: INSIDER'S GUIDE TO GREEK CUISINE
description: NICHOLAS GAGE, a former correspondent of The New York Times, is the author of ''Eleni'' (Random House). He was assisted in the preparation of this article by Joan Gage.

title: CAMERA COVERAGE OF COURTS TO EXPAND
description: TRENTON UNDER an expansion of the current experimental program that permits cameras in the courts, New Jersey residents will soon be able to view, on television and in their local newspapers, what goes on in their municipal courtrooms.

title: CAUGHT TWICE
description: THE FLIGHT OF THE FALCON

title: TALKS ARE OFF, DEPLOYMENT IS THE WATCHWORD
description: The Soviet Union delivered punches last week telegraphed long in advance and therefore not surprising, even though dismaying, to Western leaders. The West German Bundestag, ignoring street demonstrations and warnings from Moscow, voted to proceed with the stationing of American-made, medium-range missiles. When this was almost immediately followed by the arrival of the first nine of 108 Pershing-2's, Moscow broke off the negotiations in Geneva indefinitely, then announced its own deployment.

title: Mary Wilensky Betrothed
description: The engagement of Mary F. Wilensky to Stuart J. Kahn has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Albert Wilensky of Baldwin Harbor, L.I., parents of the future bride. Her fiance is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Fred N. Kahn of Asheville, N.C. An April wedding is planned.

title: ATTACKS IMMUNE TO SPACE DEFENSES
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Gains Final by 23-21
description: Union College of Schenectady, N.Y., behind the passing of Dan Stewart and three field goals from Greg Sticka, built a 23-7 lead today and then held off Salisbury State for a 23- 21 victory to advance to the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division III championship game.

title: WHEN SUBSCRIBERS PULL THE PLUG
description: As long as millions of new homes were subscribing to cable each month, most cable operators were unperturbed by the fact that some households dropped their subscriptions after a brief run. But as growth slows, cable companies are becoming more concerned about the problem of ''disconnects'' - as they are known in the industry - and are trying to do something about them.

title: COURSE EASES COMPUTER FEARS
description: ''Yesterday I dealt with a patient having a massive hemorrhage,'' Dr. Jane O'Shaughnessy said. ''That didn't rattle me, but sometimes the idea of working with a computer does.'' Dr. O'Shaugnessy is chairman of the department of emergency medicine at St. Barnabas Medical Center in Livingston, N.J. ''What I do in my work is scientific and I do that routinely. So I am surprised about my fears of the computer.''

title: BORN TO FULFILL FATHER'S DREAM OF BEING A WORLD CHAMPION
description: THE dream from the beginning

title: POSTINGS;
description: Using an auction house to find a buyer for a piece of real estate often indicates that it is a problem property and that the owners anticipate a difficult sale. This was not the expectation, however, of the owners of a seven-story building in the heart of Manhattan's Upper West Side, one of the city's hottest commercial territories.

title: TWO BUS LINES PRESS FOR SUBSIDIES
description: SYLVAN TIEGER, a Riverdale resident who commutes by express bus to Manhattan, was asked the other evening as he stepped off the bus why he paid $5 a day to commute, when he could pay $1.50 and take the subway instead.

title: STORIES WITHOUT SIGNPOSTS
description: AN AMATEUR'S GUIDE TO THE NIGHT

title: SAVING AGING HOUSING: A COSTLY CITY TAKEOVER
description: The biggest landlord in the five boroughs - a landlord with a growing inventory of aging, unmarketable housing that will cost $150 million to run this year and probably more in the future - is now the City of New York.

title: TOPICS
description: that step into someone else's home that exudes comfortable elegance.

title: WHETHER TO MOVE OR STAY PUT
description: MOST people feel compelled to reevaluate their housing needs as retirement draws near. A rambling house that suited a family when the children were growing up may now seem to big, and many couples are tempted to move to something smaller and easier to manage. On the other hand, 20 years or more under the same roof build an emotional tie that resists a move.

title: SAGA OF THE MERCHANT FLEET
description: NORMALLY a showcase for nautical artifacts, the American Merchant Marine Museum in Kings Point is also now featuring contemporary sea paintings, watercolors and photographs by Bruce Elfast. The presence of Mr. Elfast's work, said Frank O. Braynard, museum curator, is appropriate on several counts.

title: BLASTS SHATTER PEACEFUL CALM OF A SATURDAY
description: The day began like any other Saturday morning in this town on the shore of the Great South Bay.

title: UNIVERSITY OF TEXAS ACQUIRES ARCHIVES ON ASSASSINATION
description: The University of Texas has acquired a 1,700-piece collection documenting the assassination of President Kennedy. Officials say the acquisition was coincidental to the 20th anniversary of the shooting.

title: A NEW FACE FOR INDUSTRIAL PARKS
description: DURING the 1950's and 60's, hemmed in by narrow, congested streets and 19th- century manufacturing buildings, many of New Jersey's most prosperous enterprises found the state's large cities oppressive and lit out for places where there was room to expand.

title: LOVED FOR HIS DIPHTHONGS
description: WISE VIRGIN By A. N. Wilson. 186 pp. New York: The Viking Press. $13.95.

title: Recess Appointment Made To the Legal Services Panel
description: President Reagan has appointed a former White House aide, Ronald B. Frankum, of Delmar, Calif., to be a member of the Legal Services Corporation.

title: MET OPERA: 'CARMELITES' IN PRODUCTION BY DEXTER
description: Poulenc's ''Dialogues of the Carmelites'' returned to the Metropolitan Opera Friday night, and again it was the simple elegance of John Dexter's production that won our hearts.

title: LASERS MAY MAKE THE KINDEST CUTS
description: Surgeons who take pride in their deftness with scalpels and sutures may soon find themselves equally comfortable with magnetic pencils and video display screens. Some medical experts believe that the profession, whose purpose has not changed fundamentally during the last century, is heading on a revolutionary course based on laser and computer technologies.

title: GRENADIAN SAYS ISLAND WOULD PROBABLY RE-ELECT MAN OUSTED IN '79
description: Alister Hughes, a Grenadian journalist, said last week that if the Caribbean island's voters had to choose now, they would probably re-elect former Prime Minister Eric M. Gairy, whose regime in Grenada was overthrown in 1979. .

title: Elizabeth D. Gelfand Marries in California
description: Elizabeth Dawn Gelfand, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marshall M. Gelfand of Palm Springs, Calif., formerly of New York, and Richard Jeffrey Stearns, son of Mr. and Mrs. David G. Stearns of Binghamton, N.Y., were married yesterday. Rabbi Joseph Hurwitz performed the ceremony at the Ranchos Las Palmas Resort in Palm Springs.

title: THE CHANGING FACE OF BANKING
description: AN AUTOMATIC teller machine in the lobby of a bank in Jersey City or in a storefront in Caldwell may hint that change is under way in the banking industry, but it does not begin to indicate the extent of the revolution that bankers say is taking place.

title: A TRIP INTOADLAND
description: For years, the big complaint of television viewers has been the frequent interruption of programs by commercials. Now, cable has a solution: program- free advertising.

title: Egypt Receives Bids For Nuclear Plants
description: Egypt, which plans to generate 40 percent of its electricity from nuclear energy by the year 2000, received five bids today, including two from American companies, to build its first two nuclear power plants, the Electricity Minister, Mohamed Osman Abaza, said.

title: A MAZE IN MIAMI
description: LABRAVA By Elmore Leonard. 283 pp. New York: Arbor House. $14.95.

title: CELEBRATED STATUE IN NEW HAVEN IS REMOVED
description: NEW HAVEN AFTER a monthlong celebrated stay here, ''Playmates,'' a sculpture of three teen-age boys looking at a Playboy magazine centerfold, is back in New Jersey at its artist's foundry, waiting to be sold or placed in an exhibit.

title: Future Events
description: Fun With a Purpose BY ROBERT E. TOMASSON

title: CANDIDATES AVOID POLITICAL FORUM
description: All but one of the Democratic Presidential candidates will be staying away from the annual National League of Cities convention, which begins today in New Orleans.

title: South Africa
description: To the Business Editor:

title:
BUSINESS FORUM;
BLOCK MODELS AND SELF-DEFENSE
description: SUPPOSE you're an official of the Indianapolis chapter of a prominent national conservation group. Your organization's activities, along with those of 70 other diverse concerns, are being studied by a new computer programming technique called block modeling. This sophisticated technology studies your cash transactions, communications patterns and other recorded financial and social interactions. Unexpectedly, the computer says that your organization's financial and social profile is like that of the Ku Klux Klan; the John Birch Society; another environmental group; an emergency assistance association, and the American Legion.

title: IDEAS & TRENDS
description: Rent ControlFor Phones

title: Boardwalk Walk
description: The Coney Island Walk, the oldest continuous walking race in the United States, may not be for everybody, but for the 73d walk today, age is apparently not a barrier. Among the entrants for the series of three races are Dr. Ed Doran , who is 87 years old, and Michael Gottfried , who is 6. The first race, a 10-mile handicap, starts at the Boardwalk and Coney Island Avenue at 10 A.M.

title: P.L.O. REBELS DELAY ATTACK ON TRIPOLI
description: Palestinian rebels opposed to the leadership of Yasir Arafat postponed a threatened assault on this city today to allow time for a Syrian-Saudi peace plan to be put into place.

title: 60-YEAR TRADITION OF COOKING BURGERS
description: THE customer walked into the squat brick building in New Haven with the Louis' Lunch sign on it, could not find a menu, but saw everyone else getting cheeseburgers and asked for one with ketchup.

title: GETTING THE BEST FOR THE LEAST IN STEREO COMPONENTS
description: The first ground frost is making the grass crunchy - a sure sign that Christmas is closing in. The season calls for shopping aids, and in the case of sound equipment the choice is so ample as to be practically harrowing. The problem is that so many competing products are so similar that specific recommendations run the risk of being arbitrary. Still, some models give you more for your money than others, and within each price category it is possible to pinpoint the exceptional. That is what the next few columns will attempt, starting today with budget components.

title: SELLING VIEWERS A PACKAGE PLAN
description: One way the cable industry is fighting ''disconnects'' is by packaging, or bundling together one or more pay services with basic cable. Package buyers are less likely to drop a pay service, operators say, because they might actually end up paying more for fewer separate parts. As a result, ''packaging has swept the cable industry in recent months,'' said Dennis Leibowitz, an analyst with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS MASS MARKET Mass market paperbacks are soft-cover books sold at newsstands, variety stores and supermarkets, as well as in bookstores. This listing is based on computer-processed reports from bookstores and representative wholesalers with more than 40,000 outlets across the United States.
description: 1 MISTRAL'S DAUGHTER, by Judith Krantz. (Bantam, $4.50.) The art world of the 20's and the fashion business of the 80's: fiction.

title: A GIFTED STUDENT SPEAKS OUT
description: AS far as she's concerned, Moira Walsh, a student at the School of the Holy Child in Rye, is a normal 14-year- old ninth grader.

title: SHUTTLE WITH A EUROPEAN-BUILT SPACELAB IS SET FOR LAUNCHING TOMORROW
description: The countdown began today for launching the most expensive and complex science research facility ever put into space.

title: IN THE MEXICAN MANNER
description: LA FONDA DEL SOL in Hicksville serves the typical tortilla-based specialties that have become the most popular representatives of the Mexican kitchen in the United States. But here they do not have the mass- produced quality often evident in Mexican restaurants, especially the chains. There are a number of more elaborate dishes as well.

title: ABOUT LONG ISLAND
description: AT the best of times, Tanya is not one of your placid, docile dogs. While her pen was in ruins, it was the worst of times.

title: SHORTCUT TO TAX SAVING
description: To the Editor:

title: CONNECTICUT JOURNAL
description: THE commercial began with a Roman Catholic priest saying, ''While we live in a day before, we still have time to pray.'' He then asked to be joined in prayer, beseeching the Lord to prevent a nuclear holocaust.

title: TURNING EMPTY OFFICES AND CHEAP LEASES INTO A WINDFALL
description: In 1982, Ted Bates Advertising made $15 million before it produced a single ad. The company had originally planned to grow into its generous office space at One Astor Place in midtown Manhattan but decided instead to acquire satellite agencies housed in separate buildings. So, capitalizing on its excessively roomy quarters, it gave up an option on the extra space at One Astor Place and collected a note for $15 million from the owner of the building. ''We were not looking for a profit,'' said Donald Zuckert, Bates's executive vice president responsible for real estate. ''It was just a question of timing. We no longer needed the space.'' Rising commercial real estate rents in the last several years have given a growing list of companies the chance to realize such profits. The companies are subletting or selling back leases on office space they contracted for in the late 1960's and early 70's, when the recession had caused a glut in the market and rents were relatively low. Traditionally cash-poor service companies such as advertising agencies are finding that long-term leases - usually thought of as liabilities - can be the source of enormous windfalls. In the Ted Bates case, a combination of circumstances led to the agency's enviable position: In 1968, it signed a 25-year lease on 300,000 square feet in One Astor Place, a building in the Times Square area, and took an option to rent 500,000 more, at the low price of $8 a square foot.

title: ABOUT CARSMarshall Schuon
description: ONE way to look at Honda's new Civic CRX is to figure that it will cost you $3.40 a pound, about $1 less per pound than the company's all-new Prelude sports car. The Prelude may well be the best car ever to come out of Japan, but the little Civic is no slouch either, and it breaks new ground in defining what a car can be.

title: THIRD GAME OF CHESS MATCH DRAWN BY RIBLI AND SMYSLOV
description: Zoltan Ribli of Hungary and Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union disappointed the spectators by agreeing to a draw in a complex position after 16 moves of the third game of their semifinal world championship chess match here tonight.

title: TRIBAL ART AT AUCTION
description: Ben Heller, the New York collector turned art dealer, is selling most of his African, Oceanic, Southeast Asian and Pre-Columbian art in an evening sale on Thursday at Sotheby Parke Bernet, York Avenue at 72d Street. Mr. Heller reported in a recent interview that the 111 sculptures, vessels and artifacts up for bidding are from a collection he began 30 years ago when he was a textile producer. He said he is auctioning these art works to raise money for his real estate ventures.

title: DETROIT BRANCH LIBRARIES IN TROUBLE
description: Detroit, still suffering from the recession, may be forced to absorb another blow, the possible closing of 14 of its 24 neighborhood libraries.

title: ABOUT MAMMALS AND PEOPLE
NEW CASSETTES OF OLD FAVORITES
description: The Days of Wine and Roses Starring Cliff Robertson, Piper Laurie and Charles Bickford. Written by J.P. Miller; directed by John Frankenheimer. MGM/UA 89 minutes.

title:
NUMISMATICS;
MEDAL HONORS POET
description: Many tributes are being prepared for the Statue of Liberty as the nation and New York City make plans to mark the shrine's centennial. Now a signal honor has also been bestowed on Emma Lazarus, the noted New York poet who helped her fellow-Americans fully discern the purpose of the monument. Miss Lazarus, author of the so-called ''Statue of Liberty Poem,'' has been chosen for induction into the Jewish-American Hall of Fame in Berkeley, Calif. To mark the occasion a special new medal has been issued in her honor.

title: TV'S QUEST FOR THE MAN CALLED WASHINGTON
description: In the historic district of Philadelphia

title: 'ANGEL DUSTING' GRIZZIES
description: Last summer, a grizzly bear dragged a young man from his tent at Hebgen Lake near Yellowstone National Park, killed and ate him. Wildlife biologists, who knew this bear to be a particularly peaceful animal, were at first at a loss to explain the attack. Then it was discovered that the bear had been sedated at least 11 times with Sernylan, which is the trade name for phencyclidine or, in drug lingo, ''P.C.P.'' or ''Angel Dust,'' and which is known to produce violent and unpredictable behavior in humans.

title: PLAYING HOUSE
description: She broods. He crows.

WHY GIVE LONG DISTANCE A FREE RIDE?

title: DEVILS BEATEN, 6-2, BY BRUINS
description: Rick Middleton's 12th goal of the season broke a 1-1 tie early in the second period today as the Boston Bruins skated to a 6-2 victory over the New Jersey Devils. It was the 20th loss in 22 games for New Jersey.

title: KOCH IS TO TESTIFY AT HEARING ON POLICE TOMORROW
description: Mayor Koch is to be the leadoff witness tomorrow when a Congressional hearing into accusations of police brutality reconvenes in Brooklyn.

description: To the Editor:

title: Sandra Brown Married to John Wayt 3d in Raleigh
description: Sandra Westbrook Brown, daughter of Bruce M. Brown of Raleigh, N.C., and Mrs. Walter M. Brady of Raleigh and Morehead City, N.C., was married yesterday to John Augustus Wayt 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Wayt Jr. of Atlanta and Cumming, Ga. The Rev. Dr. Edwin Pickard and the Rev. Leslie Tucker performed the ceremony at the White Memorial Presbyterian Church in Raleigh.

title: IS IT REALLY CENSORSHIP?
description: MANY librarians on Long Island recently celebrated the American Library Association's National Book Banning Week. The association has been in the forefront of groups defending ''the right to read.'' It has also campaigned to make the public aware of what it calls the rising tide of censorship, particularly in the public schools.

description: Nearly a century after the City of Los Angeles outraged northern farmers by grabbing water sources nearly 300 miles away, the conflict continues on two fronts.

description: or perhaps because of it - two neighboring institutions have coincidentally mounted exhibitions of garden photography. Wave Hill in Riverdale, the Bronx, is the host to ''Portrait of an Era in Landscape Architecture: The Photographs of Mattie Edwards Hewitt,'' while at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers is ''Gardens of the Gilded Age: New York State Victorian Gardens.''

title: AQUINO PANEL MAKES LITTLE HEADWAY
description: A five-member civilian board of inquiry looking into the August slaying of the opposition leader, Benigno S. Aquino Jr., made little headway this week, according to a lawyer observing the proceedings.

title: Data Update
description: Conventional mortgages have fixed rates and terms, with payments that amortize the debt by the end of the term. Rollovers have short terms, do not completely amortize the debt and usually commit the lender to renew at the prevailing rate of interest.

description: Mrs. Blair L. McKillip Jr. of Hollidaysburg, Pa., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Rebecca McKillip, to David Bradford Thornburgh, son of Gov. and Mrs. Dick Thornburgh of Harrisburg, Pa. A late-summer wedding is planned.

title: Miss Kalantzopoulos to Wed in Athens
description: Orsalia Kalantzopoulos, a senior economist for the General Motors Corporation in New York, plans to be married in Athens Dec. 30 to Dr. Christos Mastroyannis, a chief resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the State University of New York Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn.

title: WASHINGTON, OPEC AND BIG OIL
description: FIASCO TTAVA By Jack Anderson with James Boyd. 386 pp. New York: Times Books. $17.50. THE OIL FOLLIES OF 1970-1980 By Robert Sherrill. How the Petroleum Industry Stole the Show (and Much More Besides). 590 pp. New York: Anchor Press/Doubleday. $19.95.

title: Guatemalan Professor Slain
description: A professor was shot dead at the University of San Carlos on Friday by two men who escaped on a motorcycle. He was identified as Leonel Carrillo Reeves, 54 years old, secretary of the pharmacy school.

title: T. R. Walsh Wed To Miss Douglass
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in High Point, N.C., yesterday, Elizabeth Ann Douglass, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Donald Perry Douglass of High Point, was married to Thomas R. Walsh, son of Dr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Walsh of Darien, Conn. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Dr. Scott Woodmansee, minister of the church, and the Rev. Edward Sheridan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: TRIMMING THE CHRISTMAS LIST
description: SOME people cut down their Christmas trees and trim them. This year I'm cutting down and trimming my Christmas-card list. The number of names hovers around 150. I'll winnow down by buying fewer cards, 100 maybe, or if I become really violent, 50. Slash out the deadwood! Scourge the list of people who haven't sent me a card in 40 years! No more dallying for days at the dining room table over phantom friends and dropout acquaintances.

title: SOUTH AFRICA
description: To the Business Editor:

title: U.D.C. LOOKING TO SUBURBS AND RURAL AREAS
description: In what its chairman described as ''a fundamental shift'' from a downstate and big-city orientation, the New York State Urban Development Corporation has begun a campaign in search of possible development projects in suburbs, smaller cities and rural areas.

title: A PROFILE OF COUNTY'S QUALITY OF LIFE
description: SOCIAL and economic problems spread throughout greater portions of the county during the last decade, affecting populations once thought to be more resistant and creating new constituencies for various human-services programs.

title: Miss Winters Has Nuptials
description: Wendy Pamela Winters, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Everett Winters of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to James Alden Van Vechten, son of Dr. and Mrs. Courtlandt Churchill Van Vechten of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. Kevin Bean performed the ceremony at St. Luke's Episcopal Church in Darien, Conn.

description: Peter W. Kaplan has written extensively about television and film.

description: AFTER three years of litigation and Federal court orders to reduce the overcrowding at the Nassau County jail, the problem is getting worse, according to court officials.

title: TEACHER WORKS WITHOUT PAY IN A DISPUTE ON LOYALTY OATH GROVE, Okla., Nov. 26 (AP) - A fourth-grade teacher has been discharged for refusing to sign an oath of loyalty to the State and Federal Constitutions but has continued to work, teaching without pay.
description: Under state law, the teacher, Russell Turley, may not be paid because he refused to sign the oath. But nothing prevents him from teaching without pay until his appeals are exhausted or he is reinstated if the oath is ruled unconstitutional.

title: JAPAN POLITICS IN A QUANDRY OVER MORALITY
description: He will probably never make it into Bartlett's ''Familiar Quotations,'' but Akira Hatano may have earned himself a niche in Japanese political lore with a recent comment on political morality.

title: Susan Weisburgh Is Wed To Robert R. Glasspiegel
description: Susan Weisburgh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Weisburgh of Stamford, Conn., was married there yesterday to Robert R. Glasspiegel, son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Glasspiegel of Milwaukee. Rabbi Stephen H. Pearce performed the ceremony at Temple Sinai.

title: TEXAN ACCUSED OF AIDING BOYFRIEND'S SUICIDE
description: A teen- age student who, his mother said, ''died for love'' when he shot himself last year has left behind puzzled friends, a grieving mother and, after a long investigation, a girlfriend facing the unusual charge of aiding a suicide.

title: HOME CARE FOR ELDERLY STIRS DEBATE OVER COSTS
description: After 55 years in her tiny walk-up apartment on Spring Street in Greenwich Village, Maria Di Pierro, who is 85 years old and in fragile health, wants to stay put. ''I want to stay in my own house,'' she said. ''I don't want to go into a nursing home.''

title: SYRIA SAYS IT TURNED BACK U.S. JETS OVER LEBANON
description: Syria said today that it had intercepted and turned back a flight of United States F-14 jets over its positions in Lebanon.

title: TAKING THE HIGH RENT INTO ACCOUNT
description: The National Association of Accountants, a nonprofit group representing about 100,000 financial professionals, has had its home in Manhattan since it was founded in 1919. But when the organization learned that the cost of space at 919 Third Avenue would more than double when its 15-year lease expired in 1985, it decided to build a home of its own.

title: AILEY'S TROUPE EXPLORES ITS ROOTS
description: The theater district has begun its weekend hum of excitement. Children push their way through the arcade that runs mid-block between West 44th and 45th Street, headed for Saturday morning classes in the well-appointed studios of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center. Young dancers arrive there for rehearsal with the Ailey apprentice companies that serve to hone them as performers and bring new choreography to the public eye. Upstairs, in handsome offices high over Times Square, Mr. Ailey sits in his dance company's board room, a great bear of a man whose comments are punctuated with dives for cigarettes.

title: NEW ZEALAND AUTO RACERS MAKE MARK
description: Rod Millen came to the United States from New Zealand in 1978, and soon became one of the top rally drivers in this country. Now he's been joined by his younger brother, Steve, who is drawing attention not only for his rally performances but also in other forms of motor sport.

title: S.S. Hot Sauce Wins
description: S. S. Hot Sauce, a Maryland-bred 2-year-old colt, won the $100,000 Maryland Juvenile Championship by a half-length at Laurel Race Course today and paid $27.80 for $2 to win. The favored Pied A'Tierre was second in the field of eight and Me Darlin Anna B., the lone filly in the race, was third, 1 1/4 lengths farther back.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES

title: IRRADIATED FOREST SUSTAINS UNUSUAL DAMAGE

It was he who named the five foot positions with which every ballet student begins a class today. As a dancer, he performed with the King in court ballets, specializing in the ''solemn dance'' category, the ''danse grave.''

title: BELGRADE REPORT SUGGESTS SOVIET MIGHT DEPLOY MISSILES IN BULGARIA
description: Soviet countermeasures to NATO missile plans might mean the eventual installation of Soviet nuclear rockets in Bulgaria, according to a report here.

title: 5,000 in Marathon
description: Bill Scholl and Jan Yerkes will attempt to defend their titles Sunday among a field of about 5,000 runners in the Philadelphia Independence Marathon. The run begins at Temple Unviersity's Ambler campus, winds through the countryside and finishes in front of Independence Hall.

title: DUCKING FOR COVER OVER THE HOMELESS
description: When aides to Governor Cuomo leaked a report three months ago claiming that there were malnourished children living in hotels for the homeless inspected regularly by the city, city officials cried ''ambush.'' Last week, it was Mayor Koch's turn. In a stingingly worded rebuke of the state's mental health policies, Mr. Koch linked the release of the mentally ill from psychiatric hospitals in the 1960's and 1970's with the growing numbers of homeless now consigned to a life on the city's streets. It was, he said, ''the shame of the State of New York.''

title: AROUND THE GARDEN
description: This Week:

title: No Headline
description: Susan Stapley a Bride

title: NEW JERSEYANS
description: ''HAPPY BIRTHDAY, WOMANSPACE'' will be the theme song of a New Orleans jazz brunch at the Masonic Temple in Trenton next Sunday.

title: ALISON M. ANDDERSON, ENGLISH TEACHER, MARRIES JOHN W. DRAPER JR. AT STAMFORD Alison Nelson Anderson, daughter of Mrs. Wallace S. Jones of Essex Fells, N.J., and the late Donald Wallace Anderson, was married yesterday to John William Draper Jr., son of Dr. and Mr. Draper of New York and Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. Dr. Donald Caughey, an Episcopal priest, performed the nondenominational ceremony at the Leland Stanford Jr. Memorial Church at Stanford University.
description: Jennifer Draper, the bridegroom's daughter from his previous marriage, which ended in divorce, was the maid of honor. Douglas A. Draper was his father's best man.

title: New Haven Celebrates American Crafts
description: THROUGH the years, the annual Celebration of American Crafts sponsored by the Creative Arts Workshop in New Haven has beocome a staple on the Fairfield County scene and a popular source of seasonal gifts. There is more to the exhibition and sale of an array of crafts than that though. It has a triple purpose, explained Roz Schwartz, originator and perenial chairman of the event, now in its 15th edition. First of all, to raise money for the workshop and secondly, to show people where crafts are today. We have things we know we'll never sell, but we want people to be aware of them.

title: Mercury Concentration Found in Tennessee
description: Land around a downtown building, where sediment from a creek near a nuclear weapon plant was dumped 25 years ago, contains high levels of radioactivity and 72 times the mercury in ordinary soil, officials say.

title: FEDERAL AGENCY PLANS ARMED FORCES TO GUARD LAND IN WEST
description: The Bureau of Land Management, aroused over armed marijuana growers and timber rustlers, is planning an armed force to patrol its 119 million acres of isolated Western land.

title: Salvadoran Military Shakes Up Command
description: Defense Minister Eugenio Vides Casanova has ordered a sweeping shake-up of the military command.

title: NEW CASSETTES OF OLD FAVORITES
description: It's a Wonderful Life Starring James Stewart, Donna Reed, Lionel Barrymore, Henry Travers, Beulah Bondi, H. B. Warner; directed by Frank Capra, 1947 NTA 130 minutes. $39.95

title: COLLEGE DEAN SEEKS GRANTS TO TRAIN TEACHERS ALBANY, Nov. 26 (AP) - A coalition of university deans in the state has urged the Legislature to create a $20 million program to produce better- trained teachers.
description: At the center of the program, recommended by the Council of University Deans, is a proposal to award special scholarships and grants to graduate students hoping to make teaching a career.

title: POLICING HIGH-TECH EXPORTS
description: Jon Zonderman, a contributing writer to The Boston Business Journal, reports frequently on business and technology. By Jon Zonderman EARLY THIS MONTH, A FEDERAL grand jury indicted two Californians, two Bulgarians and a Dutchman on charges that they had conspired to export ''nonexportable'' computer equipment. The equipment - machinery for the manufacture of computer disks - had left Yorba Linda, Calif., for the Netherlands, where it was immediately diverted to Bulgaria. That the Californians had not applied for an export license was the first problem. That the machines were destined for an Eastern bloc nation, where, because of their sophistication, they constituted a ''national security concern'' was the second (and the larger) one.

title: THE REGION
description: The TroubleWith Attica

title: ANTON DOLIN, 79, BALLET STAR AND CHOREOGRAPHER, IS DEAD
description: Sir Anton Dolin, whose early career in Serge Diaghilev's Ballets Russes led him to become the first internationally acclaimed British male ballet star and who was a founding member of major ballet companies in Britain and the United States, died Friday in Paris.

title: CONTENDERS' STANDINGS
description: The candidates who will be voted on in Iowa - save one - aren't so worried about who's first either. Most leading Democrats there now take it for granted that former Vice President Mondale will take the caucus. The issue for them is who will be No. 2 and No. 3, and how close they will come. They are mindful of 1972 and the surprise second-place showing of former Senator George McGovern, who took the nomination from former Senator Edmund Muskie that year and who is tryng again this time around. Like Mr. Cranston, they have been moving reinforcements into Iowa, and assiduously courting local leaders.

title: POLITICAL DISPUTE IN CHICAGO WIDENS
description: Since Harold Washington became Chicago's first black Mayor last April, he has been involved in a running feud with Alderman Edward R. Vrdolyak, who is leader of the City Council majority and chairman of the county Democratic organization.

title: Data Bank; November 27, 1983
SUNDAY OBSERVER
description: Candidate Comforter PATRICK MCDONNELL

title: ALCOHOL'S PROVEN DANGER TO THE FETUS
description: To the Editor:

title: AS THEATER, 'DOONESBURY' LACKS TRUE SATIRICAL BITE
description: The theatrical season has at long last produced a work that simultaneously touches head, heart and those parts of the mouth and throat given to emitting little whistling and humming noises. Unluckily for those with an emotional (or, indeed, financial) investment in the prosperity of the American musical, those responsible for this prodigy are Georges Bizet, the librettists Henri Meilhac and Ludovic Halevy, and the novelist Prosper Merimee, none of whom are to be seen regularly on Broadway. It is, I suppose, a bit unjust to compare even the best of the genre with ''Carmen,'' and especially with Peter Brook's starkly mythic version of the opera. Yet there it indisputably, excitingly, exhilaratingly is at the Vivian Beaumont, exposing by its mere existence the dereliction of those of its distant cousins who have just shambled from their pods.

title: Pamela C. Donley Is Wed to Banker
description: Pamela Curran Donley, daughter of Mrs. Ray Donley of Pittsburgh and the late Mr. Donley, was married yesterday to Joseph Anthony Buongiorno Jr., son of Carol S. Buongiorno of Pittsburgh and Mr. Buongiorno of New York. The Rev. William R. Coats performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Pittsburgh.

title: ;  Behind Osborne
description: To the Business Editor:

title: CRIME
description: The book jacket calls HURRICANE SEASON by Mickey Friedman (Dutton, $13.95) ''a novel with murder.'' It is a fairly accurate description of Mrs. Friedman's first novel. She is a reporter for The San Francisco Examiner, but her book has nothing to do with the West. The locale is an out-of-the- way town in Florida when Eisenhower was running for President.

title: Q/A
description: Question:

title:
ANTIQUES;
HOLIDAY BAZAAR IN GREENWICH
description: THE annual Christmas Antiques Bazaar in Greenwich, a glittering, eclectic show of all sorts of furniture and decorations, will open Friday morning at 11.

title: TEXAS RALLIES TO WIN BY 45-13
description: Rick McIvor, a third-string senior who had completed only 3 of 12 passes in 8 games this season, came off the bench to throw for 4 touchdowns and lead Texas to a 45-13 victory over Texas A&M today in a Southwest Conference game.

title: SOVIET SEEMS TO PRESS EXPANSION OF ATOMIC POWER
description: The Soviet Union has disclosed several key appointments that appear to be intended to give greater priority to what has been a lagging nuclear-power program.

title: AN OASIS OF PRIVILIGE IN CHINA
description: ORVILLE SCHELL is the author of ''Watch Out for the Foreign Guests!'' (Pantheon).

title: BOULEZ PLANS VISITS TO U.S.
description: Pierre Boulez, who last performed in America on May 14, 1977, his final concert with the New York Philharmonic as its music director, is planning a two-pronged return to American musical life. First, he will be appearing at a Boulez Festival in Los Angeles next May and June, conducting the Los Angeles Philharmonic, overseeing performances of many of his scores and working with student composers and conductors. He will then - if all plans fall into place - return to this country in February and March 1986, leading his Ensemble InterContemporain of Paris in works by himself and other major 20th-century composers. The concerts are supposed to take place in five cities, and in some of them, Mr. Boulez will also conduct their orchestras - including the New York Philharmonic.

title: Drs. Anita Parnes and Patrick A. LaSala Are Wed
description: Dr. Anita Lynn Parnes, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Irving H. Parnes of New York, and Dr. Patrick Anthony LaSala, son of Mrs. Anthony LaSala of Cedar Grove, N.J., and the late Mr. LaSala, were married at the Church Center for the United Nations yesterday. Rabbi Roy Rosenberg of Congregation Daat Elohim performed the ceremony.

title: WATERBURY LOOKS TO FUTURE
description: WATERBURY HISTORICALLY, this has been a city of ethnic neighborhoods and three-story houses, a place where blue-collar workers lived and worked and walked to their jobs in the brass mills.

title: BOTH SEXES PLAY ON SOCCER TEAM
description: UNDER conventional soccer rules, a penalty can be called when a team has too many men on the field. In the Huntington Y.M.C.A. Adult Soccer League, there is a penalty for not having enough women on the field.

title: 28 Food Places Listed For Health Violations
description: The New York City Department of Health cited 28 food establishments last week for violating the health code.

title: BROOKLYN TECH BUILDS TRADITION ON TEAMWORK
description: From the first P.S.A.L. girls' indoor track championship in 1977 through the seventh one held last season, Brooklyn Tech has come up a winner. In the process of taking seven consecutive titles, Tech has established itself nationally, as well: Its girls' mile relay team was ranked seventh in the country last year.

title: STUDYING TASTES OF 'NEW' CONSUMER
description: ''THE consumer,'' said Joseph G. Smith of Lido Beach, ''is no longer the loyal, predictable robot that he or she was once thought to be.

title: WHO'LL BE FIRST IN NEW OFFICE SPACE?
description: WHEN construction is completed at Mitchel Field, developers and public officials believe, the vast corridor of commercial development planned will transform what historically was known as the Hempstead Plains into the largest concentration of quality office space on Long Island. However, before this comes to fruition, they project that it will take years to develop the remaining several hundred acres set aside for construction, because, they say, not everybody wants to be a pioneer.

title: HEAD-TRAUMA VICTIMS GET AID
description: EDISON ACOGNITIVE rehabilitation program that is designed to aid victims of head trauma, many of whom have difficulty acknowledging the problems that grow out of such traumas, is in full swing at the Robert Wood Johnson Jr. LIFEstyle Institute here.

title: CITY BALLET: URBAN DRIVE
description: The New York City Ballet dances no ballets specifically titled ''Broadway,'' ''Grand Central'' or ''Rush Hour Traffic.'' Yet several works in its repertory manage to evoke the nervous energy of New York City. Two of them were presented on Friday night at the New York State Theater.

title: FASHION
description: The Great White Way The Great White Way PHOTOGRAPHS BY ALEXANDER AGOR hite, or a creamy variation, continues as a favorite shade in resort wear.

title: CASINO TAX CHANGE IS SOUGHT BY KEAN
description: The Kean administration proposed today that Atlantic City casinos pay 1.5 percent of their gross revenues each year for 20 years into a fund for housing and other urban redevelopment projects in Atlantic City and other areas of southern New Jersey.

title: RAPE LAWS, 'MYSTHS' ASSAILED

title: WITNESS TESTIFIES ON PLANNING OF SENTRY THEFT
description: A witness has testified in a Manhattan trial that he took part in discussions about the planning of the $11 million theft from the Sentry Armored Courier Corporation in the Bronx.

title: RUSSIANS AND AMERICANS BURY G.I. BY THE ELBE
description: Borne to his grave by Russians and Americans, Joseph Polowsky was buried today in this town by the Elbe River that he helped liberate when the United States and the Soviet Union were allies in 1945.

title: D
description: Dominic S. Rinaldi, a retired justice of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack Friday at his home in Oakdale, L.I. He was 76 years old.

title: GOLD BULLION BARS WORTH $40 MILLION STOLEN IN LONDON
description: Six masked gunmen stole almost $40 million in pure gold from a security depot near Heathrow Airport before dawn today. It was the largest theft in British history.

title: DRAMAS AND CONFESSIONS
description: TAR By C. K. Williams. 65 pp. New York: Random House. Cloth, $10. Vintage Books. Paper, $5.95.

title: JAZZ: ELLA FITZGERALD SINGS WITH COUNT BASIE GROUP
description: There are few sights more unsettling than watching a great performer begin to falter in old age. When that artist is a musical Rock of Gibraltar like Ella Fitzgerald, one is reminded that all things, including even our most cherished symbols of permanence, must indeed pass.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Votes in Congress table last Sunday incorrectly described votes by Representative Mario Biaggi, Democrat of the Bronx, and Representative Bob Edgar, Democrat of Pennsylvania. Mr. Biaggi voted yes on the proposed equal rights amendment to the Constitution. Mr. Edgar voted yes on the proposed amendment and voted no on a conference report on a supplemental appropriations bill.

title: GAUGING THE IMPACT OF DEREGULATION
description: Mention ''deregulation'' at a party and chances are good that the eyes of your audience will quickly glaze over. Start talking about ''the deregulation of cable television'' and your listeners will surely mingle away. Yet, deregulation eventually could directly affect most Americans who own television sets.

title: ISLANDERS MOVE INTO FIRST PLACE
description: The Islanders moved into first place for the first time this season with a 9-3 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks at Nassau Coliseum tonight.

title: FOOD
description: VER THE years, we have been amused by various foods that home cooks - even those of special accomplishment - find intimidating or inhibiting. Among them are snails and eel and innards and, most puzzling of all, wild game.

title: Dowdeswell Gains Final By Upsetting Gerulaitis
description: Unseeded Colin Dowdeswell of Britain took only 50 minutes today to defeat seventh-seeded Vitas Gerulaitis, 6-2, 6-0, and reach the final of the $375,000 South African Open tennis championship.

title: RX FOR RISING HEALTH COSTS
description: THE cost of food, clothing and housing keeps rising. But medical expenses still outdistance everything else the general population is faced with, and no group of people feel this problem more than low-income families and the retired and elderly.

title: PATERSON'S SCHOOLS GET PRIVATE HELP
description: PATERSON BUSINESS and community leaders here are trying to do what the New Jersey Supreme Court declared must be done and what the State Legislature vowed would be done: improve the schools.

description: The Nov. 13 article on the state's loss of trees is a warning that could be turned into a constructive program. For those who care for survival, embarking on a tree-planting program is the solution.

title: CAREFUL SHOPPER
description: All Sorts of Gear, All Sorts of Sports Indoor, outdoor and underwater sports equipment for the whole family, and competitor and referee uniforms and shoes are available at Allen Sport Shops in New Rochelle, which opened in 1920. Racing flats for indoor track are in stock at $33.99, for instance, when most shops do not provide them at any price. Custom fishing poles are made on the premises; and rugby shorts and shirts are available.

description: SOLANA BEACH, Calif.

title: 8 DIE IN TEXAS CRASH OF PLANE CARRYING TV CREW
description: A private plane carrying a television crew on its return from covering high school football games crashed while trying to land early today at a regional airport. The accident killed eight people, the authorities said.

title: COMMONWEALTH NATIONS NEAR ACCORD ON GRENADA
description: The Commonwealth nations were reported today to be close to a compromise agreement on what to do about the situation in Grenada, the Caribbean island invaded last month by United States-led forces.

description: ''HAMS have fetishes about distances,'' said Dan Grabel, an amateur radio operator who lives in Scarsdale. ''They all want to send signals far off. Well, space is about as far off as you can get.''

description: In his letter of Nov. 13, W.F. O'Connell said that the proposed Amtrak passenger service to Atlantic City ''runs within 20 feet of the existing PATCO high-speed line between Philadelphia and Lindenwold.''

title: PAPERBACKS: NEW AND NOTEWORTHY
description: 'SUBTLE IS THE LORD . . . ': The Science and the Life of Albert Einstein. By Abraham Pais. (Oxford University Press, $12.95.) Abraham Pais, who knew Einstein at Princeton, emphasizes the great physicist's scientific research in this 1983 American Book Award winner. ''To see how Einstein arrived at the relativity theory or the quantum principle of light is something like knowing just why Shakespeare drafted his sonnets,'' our reviewer, Timothy Ferris, pointed out, noting that Mr. Pais tries hard to make technical material intelligible and that his nontechnical chapters constitute ''a superlative general biography.''

title: China
description: To the Editor:

title: FLORIDA CENTER IS A CROSSROADS FOR RUNAWAYS
description: When northeasters start blowing in from the Atlantic and nippy air displaces the summer heat, a seasonal change occurs at the Transient Youth Center.

title: TRAINING IS SOUGHT FOR MENTAL HEALTH AIDES
description: OF the $14 million the state spends annually on workers' compensation for state employees, close to half, or $6 million, goes to 5 percent of the workers, the 2,300 employees of the State Department of Mental Retardation, state figures show.

title: FINANCIAL RELIEF FOR BRAZIL
description: Brazil, the world's biggest debtor, won some relief from the International Monetary Fund last week but only on the basis of an austerity program that may aggravate political and social tensions.

title: PRINCETON IS STAGING A NEW 'OEDIPUS'
description: PRINCETON USING as its script a new translation by a member of the Princeton University faculty, a combined cast of undergraduates and professionals will present, beginning Thursday, a version of Sophocles's ''Oedipus the King'' that will not be ''depressing,'' but ''positive,'' according to the play's director.

title: Nadia Zilkha, Broker, to Wed in April
description: Announcement has been made by Selim Zilkha of Los Angeles and Lady Lever of London of the engagement of their daughter, Nadia Zilkha, to Dr. Tadeusz Wellisz, son of Prof. Stanislaw Wellisz of New York and Isabel Wellisz of Bennington, Vt. They plan an April wedding in New York.

title: THE VOLATILE WORLD OF MEDICAL IMAGING
description: ALTHOUGH the stocks of most major corporations continue to ride the back of the bull market, those of many smaller corporations traded over-the-counter seem to have been trampled under foot. One group still struggling to get up are the medical diagnostic imaging companies, most of which are at the forefront of technology that goes beyond the X-ray machine in early detection of life-threatening illnesses.

title: PLANS FOR HOSPITAL'S LAND STIR DEBATE
description: THE last large tract of land in White Plains, the 235-acre property of the Westchester division of the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center on Bloomingdale Road, is under study for development, with possibly as many as 600 houses or apartments to be built on it.
