title: STATE'S MANUAL GOES ON SALE
description: FOR $8.60, just about anything anybody wanted to know about Connecticut, although a bit outdated, could be found in the little blue book. And last Monday Julia H. Tashjian, the Secretary of the State, went to Stamford to personally sell a few copies.

title: ALASKAN NATIVES' COMPANY FOUND DEFRAUDED
description: A modern tale of white man's exploitation of native Americans has begun to unfold here when the former manager of a subsidiary of the Sealaska Native Regional Corporation pleaded guilty in Federal court to a charge of mail fraud.

title: NEBRASKA BEATS OKLAHOMA, 28-21
description: Nebraska rallied from 7 points behind twice today and then held inside its 10-yard line in the last minute before finally beating Oklahoma, 28-21, in a heavy rainstorm. The victory gave the Cornhuskers their first undefeated regular season in Tom Osborne's 11 years as head coach.

title: WISE USE OF APPLIANCES CAN RESULT IN WORTHWHILE SAVINGS
description: Last week's column told how to save energy by reclaiming some of the heat used by a clothes dryer during the winter. This week's column covers ways to save on energy consumed by various household appliances.

title: A WAYWARD TURTLE SHOWS UP IN BAY
description: BRIGANTINE MARINE scientists are trying to determine how and why a lone Atlantic Ridley turtle found its way through New York Harbor, and some of the busiest shipping channels in the world, and into Raritan Bay, a body of water not known to be a sea turtle's delight.

title: PRINCETON BELATEDLY HONORS A GRADUATE
description: PRINCETON IN CONNECTION with an exhibition of his art at the Princeton

title: Disputed Grant
description: Senator William Proxmire, the Wisconsin Democrat who has often complained that the Government gives grants to colleges for frivolous research, was accused last March of abetting the practice. Administration officials suggested that he present his Golden Fleece Award to himself for getting Congress to approve $1.4 million for continued studies by the Institute for Research on Poverty at the University of Wisconsin.

title: OUTDOORSJanet Nelson; Eastern Ski Areas Upgrade Facilities
description: BLAME it on the El Nino winds in the Pacific, volcanic eruptions in the Northwest or worldwide earthquakes, but for skiers, last winter was one of the East's worst. Early in the season it was balmy, later it was soggy and finally, about the time people were ready for golf, tennis and sailing, it snowed.

title: Sarah Mathews, Paralegal, Weds
description: Sarah Kohler Mathews, daughter of Dr. Rita W. Mathews of New York and Sidney Mathews of Palm Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to William L. Renfro, son of Mrs. Ernest Leonard Renfro of West Palm Beach and the late Mr. Renfro. The Rev. John G. Gaskill performed the ceremony at the United Church of Christ in Southfield, Mass.

title: Correction
description: The illustration accompanying an article on military spare parts in The Week in Review of Nov. 20 incorrectly identified the company that offered to sell radar antenna parts to General Dynamics for resale to the Air Force. A Senate report identified the company as the Westinghouse Electric Company.

title: Camp All-Americans
description: Continuing a tradition begun by the former Yale player and coach Walter Camp in 1889, the Walter Camp Football Foundation has announced its 1983 all-America team, and the selections provide further evidence that top teams and top players tend to go hand in hand.

title: Sampson Scores 29 In Loss to Hawks
description: The Atlanta Hawks held off a late rally led by Ralph Sampson and defeated the Houston Rockets, 115-109, in a National Basketball Association game tonight.

title: BRITISH NEWSPAPER OWNERS TO SUE PRINTERS' UNION OVER STRIKE
description: As a printers' strike against Britain's national newspapers went into a second day today, the publishers announced that they would each sue the strikers' union for damages.

title: SABIN, PARALYZED, TELLS OF DEATH WISH
description: Albert B. Sabin, the developer of a vaccine that helped to conquer polio, is now paralyzed from the waist down after suffering 10 days of such excruciating pain that he says he wanted to die and began to curse the mores of his own medical profession.

title: CRAFTING A CREATIVE TAKEOVER
description: LONDON ALONG with its growing international reputation for creativity,

title: Car Crash Kills 5 Japanese
description: Two automobiles carrying Japanese tourists collided head on in a blizzard near the Grand Canyon and five of the tourists were killed, the Arizona Department of Public Safety reported today.

title: SEAFOOD MARKETS THAT SERVE MEALS
description: GOOD seafood markets are always in demand. Unfortunately, most are near the shore and many close during the winter months.

title: Eddie Johnstone Hurt
description: Eddie Johnstone , the Detroit Red Wing forward, shattered his right cheekbone in a collision during a game against the Pittsburgh Penguins Friday night and will be out of the lineup indefinitely. Johnstone, who went to Detroit from the Rangers in a six-player trade last summer, suffered the injury in the third period when he slammed into a teammate after falling over a Penguin defenseman. Johnstone, 29 years old, was reported in good condition yesterday at Henry Ford Hospital, where a spokesman said surgery would be scheduled for early next week.

title: Owner Criticized
description: Rene Lachemann , former manager of the Seattle Mariners and new manager of the Milwaukee Brewers, has criticized George Argyros , the owner of the Mariners, for failing to ''spend money'' on players. Argyros dismissed Lachemann on June 25 and Dan O'Brien , the club's president and general manager, on Oct. 7 after the Mariners finished with a 60-102 record, worst in the major leagues.

title: RICKY SKAGGSTHRIVES ON PURE COUNTRY
description: Don Shewey is a regular contributor to Arts and Leisure.

title: Boy, 7, Sees Mother Killed
description: A 7-year-old boy watched as his mother was shot and killed shortly before Thanksgiving dinner, the authorities said.

title: Beth D. Kershaw Is Married in R.I.
description: Beth Diane Kershaw, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Thomas Kershaw Jr. of Providence and Matunuck, R.I., and Homer Clifton Shirley Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Shirley of Falfurrias, Tex., were married yesterday at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church in Providence. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Ronald Parks Conner, assisted by the Rev. Dr. Robert J. Bull, a Methodist minister.

title: SUNDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. Pacers, at Indiana, The Knicks beat the Pacers twice in five days earlier this month, 99-91 and 94-87. (Television - Channel 9, 6 P.M. ) Los Angeles Lakers vs. Chicago Bulls, at Inglewood, Calif., (Television - ESPN, 10 P.M.)

title: Mary Ellen Gardner to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Gardner of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Ellen Gardner, to James Duehr ing Spang, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Spang of Rye, N.Y., and Naples, Fla. An April wedding is planned.

title: PETER BROOK'S 'CARMEN' STIRS LIVELY DEBATE
description: To the drama critics the Peter Brook adaptation of Bizet's ''Carmen'' was a revelation, and the raves were as lusty as the ''Toreador'' aria. To the music critics the adaptation was a hybrid that, whatever points of interest it might have had, missed the point of the work. To musical purists the presentation was almost sacrilegious. To other musicians ''La Tragedie de Carmen'' not only had points of interest but was even successful - with some reservations, mostly involving the singing.

title: MUSIC PLAYS ON FOR GOULD AT 70
description: ''IF I was retired, maybe I'd have time to enjoy it all more, but I'm so busy, so involved with making deadlines, there's little time to glow in my own shadow.''

title: THE INTRICACIES OF INITIATING DEVELOPMENT PROJECTS
description: THE DAILY NEWS made it. Joshua

title: HOUSTON DEFEATS KANSAS
description: Houston broke away in the second half behind the shooting of Michael Young and the sparkling play of a freshman, Greg Anderson to defeat Kansas, 91- 76, this afternoon.

title: KENTUCKY EASILY BEATS LOUISVILLE, 65-44
description: For the time being, blue and white have been reaffirmed as the commonwealth's official colors and the best team resides in what many basketball fans believe is its rightful place, Lexington. But in the rush of excitement following Kentucky's convincing 65-44 victory over Louisville tonight, it was the players who cautioned against anyone making too much of what was only the first game of a season that is long enough to allow Louisville ample time to recover.

title: Sharon Rinehart Wed To Bennett Hammond
description: The marriage of Sharon Bonner Rinehart of Annapolis, Md., and Bennett Hammond of Naguabo, P.R., and Old Greenwich, Conn., took place yesterday at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Patterson in Stonington, Conn. Justice of the Peace E. Simms Gray performed the ceremony.

title: HELPING PEOPLE COPE IN HISPANIC AREAS
description: AWOMAN telephones to say that she has no heat in her apartment and that her landlord does not understand her. A family in which the father suffers from emphysema needs to move from their unheated basement apartment, where there is no hot water, but they don't know how to apply to public housing officials for better housing. A woman wants to move an aging parent from Puerto Rico to the county, but she does not know where to get the immigration forms.

title: Some Failures Of the N.A.S.L.
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: A CREAKY BUT TELLING 'FIDDLER'
description: MILLBURN FIND an empty slot in a theater's season and fill it with ''Fiddler on the Roof.'' Assuming that all goes well with it, what could be safer?

title: FOLLOW UP ON THE NEWS
description: 'Child Substitute'

title: FORMER HOTEL NOW A CHURCH
description: ABUILDING is not made of wood and stone alone. It begins as a seed in someone's mind and finds its reality in the hard work and care of its carpenters. With its first inhabitants it takes on the characteristics of those who live in it.

title: FEARFUL MANAGUA OFFERS A DEAL
description: The United States invasion of Grenada and the fear of being next appeared to contribute to unusual conciliatory moves last week by Nicaragua's leftist leaders. Cuba, one of the principal targets of the Grenada operation, also seemed to be taking a cautious approach to its role in the Central American state.

title: CHARITABLE TRUSTS AND THE TAXMAN
description: FOR donors considering deferred gifts to charity that will pay them an income, Dec. 1 is

title: WHITETAIL DEER BECOMING MAJOR PEST
description: There are so many whitetail deer in the Altamont Orchards here that a wildlife official estimated that 90 percent of the trees in a 180-acre plot had been chewed by the animals - even after the farmer shot 40 of them.

title: THE REGION
description: Scales TiltedAgainst Women

title: AN ALTERNATIVE IMAGE OF NEWARK
description: Absent from Paula Span's litany of the ills of Newark was any perceptive analysis of the ''principalities and powers'' - both seen and unseen - which rule Newark. The Mayor is black and six of the nine members of the City Council are black. But the real and pervasive power is a handful of banks and corporations which, under the banner of Renaissance Newark, are concentrating on the commendable effort to rebuild and refurbish downtown Newark. Their labors are creating office space which, as the writer points out, is 40 percent lower in price than in nearby New York City. But no mention is made of the fact that, as an inducement to firms to locate in Newark, liberal tax abatements have been granted; and to make up for the resulting loss in revenues, the city must increase tax rates on houses and apartments.

title: VOTE TALLY DUE AT GREYHOUND
description: If leaders of the Amalgamated Transit Union have their way, the Greyhound strikers who are voting on a new contract proposal will decide to keep on leaving the driving to the bosses.

title: Ann B. Schube, A Banker, Wed
description: Ann Beth Schube, daughter of Corinne F. Schube and Dr. Daniel D. Schube of New York, was married yesterday to Paul Alan Katzenstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan W. Katzenstein of Larchmont, N.Y. Rabbi Reuven Siegel performed the ceremony at the East 55th Street Conservative Synagogue in Manhattan.

title: NEW CASSETTES OF OLD FAVORITES
description: Horowitz in London Sony Beta 116 minutes. $39.95

title: Magdelaine A. Cullen Weds R. G. Broughton
description: Magdelaine Anthony Cullen of Plandome, L.I., widow of Charles Clifford Cullen, was married yesterday to Richard Glover Broughton, headmaster of the Buckley Country Day School in Roslyn, L.I. The Rev. Frank N. Johnston performed the ceremony at the Christ Episcopal Church in Manhasset, L.I.

title: Boat Sailing to Coast Found Crippled With Captain Dead
description: A sailboat that left Honolulu in October for a one-month trip to Newport, Ore., was found crippled Friday about 700 miles off San Francisco with her captain dead and the only other occupant exhausted, according to the Coast Guard.

title: HANDICAPPED LEARN COMPUTER SKILLS
description: GRADUATION ceremonies in Stamford Friday evening will be simple as such things go, with members of the Class of '83 in business suits rather than caps and gowns. There will, of course, be the obligatory speech or two and proud families will be on hand to applaud as the graduates receive their diplomas and pose with them for pictures.

title: THE WIRING OF WALL STREET
description: While it is reassuring that the New York Stock Exchange has taken measures to reach a daily trading capacity of 250 million shares, it is disconcerting to see that the ''wiring of Wall Street'' also is adding to the volatility of the equity markets, thereby making them less attractive to the small investor. The example of the drop in price of the Warner Communications stock is a case in point.

title: THE REGION
description: Shots AcrossThe River

title: Security Tightened on Road Past Oak Ridge Parts Plant
description: The Department of Energy has set up two identification checkpoints on a road that leads to a plant where parts for nuclear weapons are made.

title: FROM THE KREMLIN, THE VIEW IS BLEAK ON MANY FRONTS
description: MOSCOW TWO of the most important messages in Yuri V. Andropov's statement last week on the missile standoff with the United States emerged between the lines. One was that whatever measures or threats the Soviet leader made, the Kremlin had suffered a serious political setback. The second message was contained in the fact that the statement was read by someone else, prolonging uncertainty about the standing of a man who has not been seen in public for three months.

title: Colgate Overcome In Playoff by 24-23
description: Jeff Gilbert passed for 376 yards and 3 touchdowns, including a 27- yarder early in the fourth period, as Western Carolina defeated Colgate, 24-23, today in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I-AA playoffs.

title: U.S. UNITS RAID ISLAND HIDE-OUT
description: United States troops raided a house where six armed Grenadian soldiers were hiding, an Army spokesman said Friday.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: A SOLITARY BLUE

title: SUNDAY, NOVEMBER 27, 1983;  International
description: $40 million in gold and diamonds was stolen from a security depot near Heathrow Airport near London. Six masked gunmen overpowered security guards in a warehouse belonging to Brinks-Mat Ltd. They poured gasoline over the guards and threatened to set it afire it they did not cooperate. It was the largest single theft in British history. (Page 1, Col. 6.)

title: SPANO ASKS FOR INQUIRY INTO COUNTY CLERK CUTS
description: RUMBLINGS of unhappiness over the county's proposed 1984 budget began to grow last week. Perhaps the most strident came from County Clerk Andrew J. Spano, who called for an impartial panel to determine whether scheduled cuts in his department were justified.

title: U.S. REVIEWS CASE OF CHINA DEFECTOR
description: The White House said today that it was reviewing the case of a Chinese courier who requested political asylum in the United States after an argument aboard a passenger jet over possession of diplomatic documents.

title: STEVENS TO EVALUATE BEACH-BARRIER IDEA
description: HOBOKEN ENGINEERS at the Stevens Institute of Technology here are ready to test what they believe are the strongest barriers yet developed against flooding and beach erosion.

title: Miss Dempsey Becomes Bride
description: Margaret Sanford Dempsey, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Shanley Dempsey of Wilmington, Del., and Steven Peter Frey, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis J. Frey of Hilton Head Island, S.C., were married yesterday. The Rev. Richard Reissmann performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's on the Brandywine Roman Catholic Church in Wilmington.

title: Article 063950 -- No Title
description: An Alternative Image of Newark

title: YALE'S MASCOT RETIRES
description: HANDSOME DAN, the English bulldog that has been Yale University's mascot since 1975, has retired. The dog, Bingo to her friends, was 12th in the line of Yale bulldog mascots, and the first female.

title: IN THE ARTS: CRITICS' CHOICES
description: ART

title: AN ALTERNATIVE IMAGE OF NEWARK
description: In ''Newark's Failing Dream,'' I am quoted so that I seem to offer no hope for Newark. In fact, I believe future prospects are both more gloomy and less gloomy than might have been discerned from the article.

title: FOLLOW UP ON THE NEWS
description: The year was 1978, and Joseph A. Califano Jr., then Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, set a health goal: the elimination of domestic measles in the country in four years. In October 1982 the National Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta, acknowledging that the goal had not been met, indicated that success was near.

title: BRAND-NAME HORROR
description: A couple of years ago, while riding a train on Metro-North's Hudson Line, I overheard a conversation among a group of commuters. The topic was Stephen King. One woman mentioned that she had read all his books in their hard- cover editions and would not lend her copies to friends because she liked to reread them from time to time. The others nodded in agreement. During the following week, I noticed two other commuters engrossed in hard-cover copies not of Mr. King's tales of terror, but of ''Danse Macabre,'' a collection of his critical essays on horror books and movies. Now, I have never seen anyone on the train reading Edmund Wilson (even in paperback), and I've often wondered why Mr. King, whose latest novel, ''Pet Sematary,'' has soared to the top of the best-seller list, is so popular.

title: DATA HINT JOBLESS GET HEALTH CARE
description: A new study by the Federal Government says that only a small proportion of unemployed workers have lost health insurance or access to health care as a result of unemployment.

title: GETTING A JOB CAN OFTEN BE A JOB IN ITSELF
description: ''THE two most important things in life are lead time and largesse. Beyond that, everything else is froth and soil.''

title: Team USA Loses
description: Gord Sherven scored twice and had one assist as Team Canada defeated Team USA, 5-4, in an Olympic hockey exhibition game Friday night. The victory improved Canada's overall record to 13-10-7. Team USA dropped to 25-9-7.

title: THE TWILIGHT OF THE INDUSTRIAL RUHR
description: OBERHAUSEN, WEST GERMANY ALONG Essenerstrasse, a highway

title: Trudeau Plans to Visit China Seeking Nuclear Arms Curb
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau plans to go to Peking on Sunday in connection with his effort to organize a meeting of the five major nuclear powers, a Canadian spokesman said today.

title: ABOUT BOOKS AND AUTHORS
description: Worship in Occupied Lyons

title: HEADLINERS With a Little Help
description: Editha Merrill learned to wing it last week. Mrs. Merrill, who is 78 years old, was one of three passengers in a four-seat plane when the pilot suffered a heart attack 7,500 feet above Arizona. With the help of ground controllers and the wife of the pilot, who had had some flight training but couldn't get to the controls of the cramped cockpit, Mrs. Merrill flew the plane 100 miles to an Air Force base near Phoenix and made what one officer there described as a ''magnificent'' landing.

title: WHALERS DEFEAT RANGERS
description: The Rangers and the Hartford Whalers, with 11 seconds to play in overtime tonight, stood toe to toe in a face-off in the Ranger end.

title: PARTY SQUABBLES OVER WHO'S FIRST AND FOREMOST
description: With a conflict between Democrat National Committee chairman Charles T. Manatt's principles and several states' pride turning into a small war, Senator Alan Cranston last week made sure local chieftains would have no question where his affections lie. Mr. Cranston called on Mr. Manatt to concentrate on the problem, which revolves around scheduling, and not on the national party's needs. To dramatize his point he pulled out of the ''Presidential Sweep,'' a flying fund-raiser Mr. Manatt organized for early December.

title: No Headline
description: Rosetta Milardo Is Wed

title: Andrew Lindseth And
description: Katherine Gibson Sullivan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Dwight Sullivan of Coconut Grove, Fla., was married there yesterday to Andrew MacDonald Lindseth, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jon A. Lindseth of Shaker Heights, Ohio. The Rev. Robert Godley performed the ceremony at St. Stephen's Episcopal Church.

title: THE ART OF PUTTING A CO-OP BOARD TOGETHER
description: MARK SHERNICOFF and his eight fellow directors run a $1.4 million-a-year corporation with 16 employees and 170 shareholders. He and his colleagues, however, receive not a penny for their trouble: The corporation is an apartment-house cooperative, and as members of the board of directors, they do for their building what the directors of General Motors or I.B.M. do for their companies on a more grandiose and better-paid scale.

title: VOTING: THE NEW BLACK POWER
description: Paul Delaney is deputy national news editor of The Times. By Paul Delaney PAINE COLLEGE, IN Augusta, Ga., is one of those small, perennially troubled black schools that seem somehow to survive, if not thrive. Its weather-beaten, red- brick buildings contrast sharply with the modern structures across the street at predominantly white Georgia Medical College - striking symbolism given the history of inequities between blacks and whites in the South.

title: THE D.A.'S RIGHT ARMS
description: Jonathan Barzilay is a third-year student at Columbia Law School. By Jonathan Barzilay

title: AID FOR HANDICAPPED YOUNG
description: OLD BRIDGE IN A CLASSROOM of four children here, progress is measured

title: 55 in Tanzania Reported Dead As Lake Victoria Ferry Sinks
description: An overloaded ferryboat on Lake Victoria capsized and sank in a storm this week, killing at least 55 people, the Tanzania radio said today.

title: The Wiring of Wall Street
description: In Desmond Smith's article ''The Wiring of Wall Street'' (Oct. 23), the changes referred to deal with the new technology which enables money managers to make instantaneous and simultaneous responses to news releases and announcements concerning economic and financial matters. No mention is made of traditional investment techniques founded on such time-proven fundamentals as the acquisition of undervalued stocks based on comparative analyses of yields, price-earnings ratios, earnings trends, book value, debt-equity ratios, return on equity, etc.

title: INDIANS GET MEETING PLACE
description: WESTHAMPTON TWP. CHIEF ROY CRAZY HORSE of the Powhatan-Renape Nation is pleased that the 400 to 500 Indians from South Jersey and the Philadelphia area who belong to the organization now have a natural area in which to meet, as their ancestors did in the 18th century.

title: STATE FUNDS TO AID SHELTERS FOR HOMELESS
description: EMERGENCY shelter for the homeless will be provided this winter with help from a new state law. The statute permits the Department of Income Maintenance to reimburse nonprofit agencies that establish and operate local shelters.

title: CORRECTION
description: The photographic credits on pages 34 and 35 of The New York Times Magazine today are incorrect. The photograph on page 34 was taken by Thomas S. England. The picture on page 35 should be credited to Eric Smith/Gamma-Liaison.

title: BOOK CONFRONTS INDIAN TANGLE
description: SOUTH ORANGE AN ARCHEOLOGIST and author from Seton Hall University has been unraveling the history of Indians in New Jersey, a history that has several versions among both academicians and the Indians' descendants.

title: 3 WESTCHESTER CITIES' TAX SYSTEM FACING TEST
description: A State Supreme Court justice says he will rule within two weeks on the constitutionality of a state law that permits three Westchester County cities to keep a portion of the county sales tax in exchange for a higher county property tax on the cities.

title: No Fan Of Jane Austen
description: In her article on the 75th anniversary of the Mark Twain Library in Redding (''Diamond Jubilee for Twain Library,'' Oct. 23), Alberta Eiseman mentions that the library has some of Twain's own books, including ''works by writers he admired, such as Jane Austen.''

description: To the Business Editor:

title: Taiwan Expels Head Of U.S.-Based Group
description: The president of the New York-based Taiwan Human Rights Association was expelled from Taiwan today for engaging in improper political activities, a police spokesman said.

title: IN THE PALESTINIAN SPLIT, IT'S EVERY ARAB LEADER FOR HIMSELF
description: Something besides the lives of guerrillas and innocent civilians was lost in the past few weeks of intra-Palestinian fighting here. It was the essence of the Palestine Liberation Organization itself. Its epitaph could read: ''P.L.O. - founded in Jerusalem by Arab leaders and Palestinians in May 1964. Died in Tripoli at the hands of Arab leaders and Palestinians in November 1983.''

description: In the beginning they were a bunch

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: WHEN the Huntington Historical Society put out an S O S for help recently, it wanted people to wield paint brushes, pound hammers and even supply some old-fashioned elbow grease to wash windows.

title: KAZAN'S 'CHAIN' IS A SORRY MUDDLE
description: ''THE CHAIN,'' the playwriting debut of Elia Kazan at the Hartman Theater in Stamford, deals with the perpetuation of violence that began with the fall of the House of Agamemnon, continued through centuries of war and now encompasses the threat of nuclear war.

title: HEADLINERS Purely CoincidentalIn the opinion of
description: Lisa Springer, Robert Pine not only kissed and told, but also told in a libelous fashion.

title: THE FACT-FACSIMILE FILM FESTIVAL
description: There was a moment last Sunday night when someone flipping television channels could have done an honest double take. On NBC's ''Kennedy'' mini-series, an actor was playing Robert McNamara in action as Secretary of Defense. On ABC, there was the real Robert McNamara in an animated debate about nuclear war. The double take was a sign of things to come.

title: HOW THE POLL WAS CONDUCTED
description: The latest New York Times Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted between Nov. 11 and 20 with 1,309 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii. The sample of telephone exchanges called was selected by a computer from a complete list of exchanges in the country.

title: ILLINOIS AIR CRASH THAT KILLED 10 IS THE SUBJECT OF A SPECIAL INQUIRY
description: The crash of Air Illinois Flight 710 commanded modest public attention when it happened Oct. 11. The airline was a smallish regional operation. All 10 people who were on the 44-passenger plane were killed, but the toll was not shockingly huge.

title: Dragon Data's Leader Seeks Sales Assurance
description: Brian Moore, appointed two months ago as managing director of Dragon Data Ltd., the Welsh manufacturer of home computers, has no illusions about the stability of the industry. The company, which takes its name from the mythological national mascot for Wales, is still holding its breath after being saved from a cash flow crisis in September by a $6.75 million loan and equity injection from its major shareholders.

title: 1 HELD AND 1 MISSING
description: A group of angry Queens residents chased two men suspected of being arsonists into Jamaica Bay Saturday night, and authorities said yesterday that one of them may have drowned.

title: THOUSANDS HONOR SLAIN FOE OF MARCOS
description: Tens of thousands of Filipinos took to the streets here today to mark the birthday of Benigno S. Aquino Jr., the slain opposition leader who would have been 51 years old.

title: U.S. HOPES SOAR WITH MAHRES
description: ''You don't have to motivate them,'' Kelly said, with a smile, recalling the episode during a recent training camp at this resort high in the Rockies. ''They've got the experience, and they're gonna go that extra mile to make it.''

title: DEATH TOLL IN THE CRASH OF 747 JET NEAR MADRID AIRPORT RISES TO 183
description: The known death toll in the crash of a Colombian Boeing 747 here today has risen to 183, officials said. The toll made it one of the 10 worst crashes in aviation history.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be reported this week. Monday

title: Missing Hunter Is Found Dead
description: The body of a young hunter who had been missing for two days was found today in marshes near the Great South Bay, the Suffolk County Police said.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Contaminated Fairways

title: Thailand Boxer Captures Title
description: Payao Poontarat of Thailand won the World Boxing Council super flyweight championship from Rafael Orono of Venezuela on a majority 12- round decision tonight.

title: Question Box
description: QUESTION: Who was the sculptor and who was the model for the original Heisman Trophy statue?

title: NEW 150-SEAT JET STIRS DEBATE
description: The official decision earlier this month by the McDonnell Douglas Corporation not to produce an all-new 150-passenger airliner leaves the field to the Boeing Company and Airbus Industrie, the European consortium, but it has also stepped up the debate over whether the plane is needed at all.

title: Judge Accepts Gifts To Pay for a Police Van
description: The county sheriff's new surveillance van was a present from a man who pleaded guilty to a drug charge, and the equipment inside will be the gift of an admitted drug trafficker.

title: Stanerra of Ireland First in Japan Cup
description: Stanerra, a 5-year-old Irish mare ridden by the British jockey Brian Rouse, won the third Japan Cup in a tight three-horse finish today at the Fuchu race track.

title: Ontario Brokers Assail Stock Panel's Chairman
description: Peter Dey, chairman of the Ontario Securities Commission, finds himself at the center of a fierce controversy in the Canadian investment community.

title: NICARAGUA'S CRITICS SENSE NEW AIR OF GIVE AND TAKE
description: A Nicaraguan business leader who is also a prominent critic of the Sandinista Government is reading a book called ''Getting to Yes: Negotiating Agreements Without Giving In.''

title: West German's 71 Earns Golf Title
description: West Germany's Bernhard Langer shot a 1-under-par 71 today to win the $297,900 World Golf Open by two shots over Tsuneyuki Nakajima of Japan, who also shot a 71.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Shared interests, common goals and similar suffering have drawn us even closer together.

title: ECONOMISTS HAIL LEANER RECOVERY
description: This economic recovery, like many before it, is slowing from the vigorous growth it showed at its start, economists say with pleasure. For the time being, at least, they are looking for a more modest, but solid, upturn.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Accounts

title: GLENN NARROWS MONDALE'S LEAD IN RACE FOR FUNDS
description: Walter F. Mondale has outdistanced his Democratic Presidential rivals in fund raising and expects to amass $9 million this year, but Senator John Glenn is rapidly gaining in funds, according to aides to both candidates.

title: MEDICAL HELP DUE AT OFFICE TOWERS
description: A program designed to speed emergency medical services in Manhattan's tall office buildings is to begin early next year.

title: THEATER: 'NIGHTINGALE,' WORLD WAR II BRITAIN
description: THE word ''bittersweet'' was invented for plays like C. P. Taylor's ''And a Nightingale Sang . . .'' In this gentle reminiscence about life on England's homefront during World War II, bad news and good news always come hand-in-hand. Let a lonely young war bride fear that an extramarital fling has left her pregnant, and we'll soon be told that her warning signals were actually ''false alarms.'' Let the Germans bomb the play's setting, the community of Newcastle-on-Tyne, and we'll soon learn that no one on stage has been seriously injured. The balancing act continues throughout the evening: It's as if the author were forever adjusting hot and cold faucets to find an emotional temperature that's the theatrical equivalent of a warm bath.

title: IT DID HAPPEN HERE
description: There are odd things in the life of Citizen K. He has trouble getting a passport; government appointments and awards that he was told were his do not come through. Then he finds out that, 30 years ago, he was secretly labeled a ''security risk.'' He was not told that he was under suspicion; he was not told the charges or who made them. And when he tries to correct the record now, he meets evasion and obscurity.

title: GARY PLAYER WINES $170,000 IN 'SKINS'
description: In a Hollywood-like scenario, two professional golfers well past their competitive prime walked away with nearly all the money today in the second half of The Skins Game, a stakes match devised for television.

title: People
description: * Blaine D. Colton has been appointed vice president, sales for Bonneville Satellite Communications, Salt Lake City.

title: PACERS END KNICKS' WINNING STREAK
description: With the exception of Ray Williams, who scored 36 points, there was little Knick offense tonight and the defense couldn't do enough to stop the Indiana Pacers from scoring a 101-91 victory at the Market Square Arena.

title: Washington WatchPeter T. Kilborn Unitary Tax Under Fire
description: WASHINGTON EUROPE'S biggest multinational companies are escalating their pressure on the 12 American states that have enacted the unitary approach to the income tax, in which they assess companies with operations within those states on the basis of their worldwide operations. Last week about 50 members of the House of Commons filed a motion with the Thatcher Government proposing that it consider retaliatory action against American companies in Britain, and British officials in Washington contend that the odds for such action are strong.

title: THE VILLAGE VOLUNTEERS MAKE A GIFT OF FRIENDSHIP
description: Mary Mulry arrived 20 minutes later than usual for her weekly two- hour visit to Rose Wimmer's cozy apartment in Greenwich Village the other afternoon, but Mrs. Wimmer had kept the kettle on and the cookies covered with waxed paper.

title: Bishop Says Confession Seal Impedes Clearing a Convict
description: A man who is scheduled to be executed Tuesday for murder might have an alibi in a Boston man who reportedly said the two were together at a homosexuals' bar the night of the crime, a Roman Catholic Bishop says.

title: LACK OF PLAYING TIME DISTURBS O'KOREN
description: Patience has always been a virtue of Mike O'Koren. From his days at Hudson Catholic High School in Jersey City, to his all-America years at the University of North Carolina, and, finally, through his first three seasons as a pro, he was content to wait and learn.

title: 107 Left Homeless By Fire in Newark
description: A 75- year-old man was injured and 107 people were left homeless Sunday after a two-alarm fire damaged a four-story apartment building at 1 Milford Avenue, fire officials said.

title: TOOL ORDERS UP, BUT ARE STILL LOW
description: Machine tool orders, a guage of business plans to increase production, rose 70 percent in October over levels of a year earlier, an industry trade group reported yesterday.

title: 3 MILLION CHICKENS DESTROYED IN BID TO HALT SPREAD OF VIRUS
description: Five hundred Federal and state officials and aides have been pursuing a grim assignment here in south-central Pennsylvania, killing millions of chickens that are the livelihood of many of the area's farmers.

title: COMPONENTS OF THE CRUISE ARRIVE IN ITALY
description: The first components of 112 cruise missiles have arrived in Sicily, the Defense Ministry said today. Italy is the third country to begin receiving the NATO nuclear weapons.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST MONDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1983
description: The Economy The pace of the recovery has slowed after a vigorous, initial rebound from the recession. Economists are hailing the slowdown, saying a modest recovery is more sustainable. (Page D1.)

title: GERMAN BANKS IN UNEASY MOOD
description: The bailout of a major private bank this month has injected a mood of nervousness into West Germany's banking industry.

title: Phyllis M. Furman Wed to Jonathan M. Wagner
description: Phyllis Marsha Furman, daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Isaac Furman of Cherry Hill, N.J., was married there yesterday to Jonathan Mark Wagner, son of Mr. and Mrs. David Wagner of Great Neck, L.I. The bride's father performed the ceremony at Congregation Beth El, where he is the educational director and her mother, Molly Furman, is a Hebrew teacher.

title: PROVIDENCE MAYOR UNDER NEW FIRE IN RECALL DRIVE
description: When Mayor Vincent A. Cianci Jr. was indicted last spring on charges of beating a man he said was having an affair with his estranged wife, the city didn't react. A private matter, many people said.

title: SCOTLAND YARD BAFFLED BY GOLD THEFT
description: Scotland Yard said tonight that it was baffled by the theft Saturday of about $40 million worth of gold bullion and a quantity of diamonds from a security company's warehouse near Heathrow Airport.

title: MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: Huey Lewis and News Plays Rock at the Ritz

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: HERE, in roughly ascending order of expensiveness, is a roundup of books published in the last year that are unusual in one way or another, and therefore might be considered as a gift in this season of giving and grabbing. Hiparama of the Classics, by Lord Buckley (City Lights, 37 pages; paper, $3). The texts of seven routines - including ''The All-Hip Mahatma'' (also known as ''The Hip Gan''), ''The Naz'' and ''The Religious History of Alvar Nunez Cabaza de Vaca'' - by Richard (Lord) Buckley, the ''bop'' comedian who got his start in Chicago speakeasies during the 1920's, became famous in the 1960's and is said to have influenced Lenny Bruce. It's not easy to convey Mr. Buckley's peculiar appeal to anyone who hasn't heard him live or recorded (''Four big hits and seven licks ago,'' goes the start of his ''Gettysburg Address''), but with this little volume in hand, fans can finally figure out what he was saying in some of his more manic passages.

title: MACLEAN HUNTER TAKES A CAREFUL STEP INTO U.S.
description: When The Toronto Sun Publishing Corporation bought The Houston Post last month, the company insisted that it had handled and financed the $100 million-plus deal by itself. But many media executives saw in the transaction the hand of Maclean Hunter Ltd., Sun Publishing's half-owner and Canada's biggest communications company.

title: U.S. TO SCAN 8,000 URANIUM SITES FOR TRACE F LOW-LEVEL RADIATION
description: The Energy Department is starting a three-year survey of 8,000 sites in nine Western states that may be contaminated with low-level radioactivity from the use of uranium mill tailings in construction materials.

title: COPY/Dividend Meetings for Monday's paper/McCue/Fin News
description: Dividend Meetings

title: COLUMBIA TOPS FAIRLEIGH, 1-0
description: Columbia defeated Fairleigh Dickinson, 1-0, on a goal by Steve Pratten with 4 minutes 24 seconds left at Baker Field yesterday and reached the semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association Division I soccer tournament.

title: TV: 'THE GAMBLER' GETS A SEQUEL
description: NEVER let it be said that the television-movie form doesn't strive for variety. Just tonight at 9, for convenient example, CBS is offering ''The Gambler - The Adventure Continues,'' a slick illustration of show business packaging, while NBC is going with ''Girls of the White Orchid,'' a fascinating exercise in pure sleaze.

title: Jamaica Calls Election 2 Years Ahead of Time
description: Jamaica is to hold a general election Dec. 15, two years ahead of schedule, Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga announced Saturday night.

title: Browns Win, 41-23
description: The Cleveland Browns continued their late-season drive for a playoff position yesterday when they defeated the Baltimore Colts, 41-23, in Cleveland.

title: Article 072095 -- No Title
description: After today's regular auction of three- and six-month bills, the Treasury plans a sale tomorrow of five- year, two-month notes due Feb. 15, 1989. The notes will raise $6 billion in cash for the Government. That is only $500 million less than all the corporate debt securities sold publicly in the last three months.

title: FOUR BRITISH PAPERS TO PUBLISH DESPITE STRIKE
description: Four of Britain's struck national newspapers announced tonight that they would publish Monday after some printers returned to work. But six other papers ousted their printers, setting the stage for a prolonged struggle over the impact of the union's refusal to comply with restrictive labor laws passed by the Conservative Government, or with court orders enforcing them.

title: EXCERPTS FROM 'SETTING MUNICIPAL PRIORITIES '84'
description: Following are excerpts from the introduction of ''Setting Municipal Priorities, 1984,'' the fifth in a yearly series of volumes written by urban specialists that present policy options for New York City. Local Economy

title: OUTDOORS: UPSTATE PRESERVE OFFERS EXCITING DEER HUNTING
description: HORTON, N.Y.

title: THE GREAT CHASE IN NETWORK NEWS
description: Beginning this evening, ABC's ''World News Tonight'' will originate in Chicago instead of New York for the entire week. The move is just one of the ways in which the nightly newscasts on ABC and NBC are trying to differentiate themselves as they seek to become more competitive with ''The CBS Evening News with Dan Rather,'' the most widely watched of the three.

title: OPERA: LEADS CHANGE IN 'LA TRAVIATA'
description: THE leads changed hands in ''La Traviata'' at the Metropolitan Opera Saturday night. Rosario Andrade, the Mexican soprano, made her debut at the house as Violetta, and Dano Raffanti became the Met's Alfredo.

title: DANCE: JOEL HALL TROUPE FROM CHICAGO
description: TO its credit, the Joel Hall Dancers of Chicago brought to New York a large repertory of works by several choreographers in several different styles. But what made the company's performance at the Joyce Theater on Saturday night disturbing was the unpredictable quality of both the choreography and the dancing.

title: Protesters Win a Halt In Planned Deer Hunt
description: A deer hunt at the Crane Memorial Reservation was canceled today less than 12 hours before it was to begin, because protesters vowed to stand between the hunters and their game.

title: LAM JONES KEEPS SCORE
description: FOR the last four seasons, a number of fans in the stands and more than a few critics in the press box have kept track of Lam Jones's receiving statistics the way accountants balance the books: number of catches, number of drops, net total.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Sleepy Hollow's Spirit

title: CHICAGO PHILANTHROPY BALKS AT SALE OF ASSETS
description: The MacArthur Foundation of Chicago, after months of dispute among its board members, has suspended plans to sell its multimillion-dollar insurance assets to the First Winthrop Corporation of Boston.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: Rifle Auctioned

title: MusicNoted in Brief; Pete Seeger in Concert On a Banjo and Guitar
description: Few singers are better than Pete Seeger at stirring up a sense of familial camaraderie in an audience without rabble-rousing or making a sentimental pitch. In his annual holiday concert at Carnegie Hall on Saturday, Mr. Seeger established a palpable sense of community from the moment he strolled onto the stage in his work shirt and overalls.

title: Strike Figure Dies in Crash
description: Keith Raymond Tallant, a copper miner whose 3-year-old daughter was wounded by gunfire after he crossed picket lines, was killed today when his automobile went off a highway here, the authorities said. ''There is no indication of foul play whatsoever,'' Cindy Patterson, a duty officer for the Arizona Department of Public Safety, said of the crash. Mr. Tallant, 25 years old, had crossed picket lines at the Phelps Dodge Corporation mine in Ajo since a strike began there July 1.

title: Putnam's Names; Phyllis E. Grann
description: Phyllis E. Grann has been named president of G.P. Putnam's Sons, the adult hardcover and trade paperback division of the Putnam Publishing Group. She has also been elected to the board of directors of the corporation.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 28, 1983
description: GENERAL ASSEMBLY

title: Nicaragua Will Enable Newspaper to Publish
description: The Nicaraguan Government said Saturday it would provide the opposition newspaper La Prensa with enough dollars to buy the newsprint it needs to continue publishing.

title: MUSIC: DEBUT AT GOODMAN
description: BRUCE WOLOSOFF, a pianist, took his Bachelor of Arts Degree from Bard College and later studied at the University of Indiana and the New England Conservatory. On Saturday evening, he made his formal New York debut at Abraham Goodman House.

title: The Editorial Notebook; The Embarrassment of 'Yellow Rain'
description: President Reagan and his Secretaries of State have repeatedly drawn the world's attention to ''yellow rain,'' their physical evidence of the chemical warfare they say has been waged in Southeast Asia under Soviet direction. Whatever the truth about Vietnam's use of chemicals in Laos and Cambodia, the evidence grows that the gathered ''yellow rain'' is no weapon but almost certainly the pollen-laden excrement of bees.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: The Newest Elixir

title: VOICE OF AMERICA SAYS IT REACHES MORE LISTENERS IN THE SOVIET BLOC
description: More East Europeans are listening to the Voice of America, including in Poland where an estimated 11.5 million people hear the broadcasts, despite jamming by the Russians, the United States Information Agency said today.

title: SELF-HELP FOR TROUBLED LABOR
description: Never in 50 years as a unionist have I seen organized labor as beleaguered as it is today. It seems everybody is against us.

title: BRIEFING
description: Democrats on the Road

title: Feast Day for Salley, S.C.
description: The hearty of spirit and stomach packed this town of 580 people for the annual ''Chitlin Strut,'' eating, hog-calling, foot-stomping and strutting. About 44,000 people turned out Saturday for a celebration of the Southern delicacy known as chitterlings, or ''chitlins'' - hog intestines boiled, battered, cut into strips, fried and eaten. They ate 20,000 pounds of them.

title: Israel Warns Syria on Safety Of 5 Prisoners in Damascus
description: Israel warned Syria tonight that it was responsible for the safety of five Israeli prisoners held in Damascus jails.

title: NEBRASKA-TEXAS STAYS A DREAM GAME
description: Nebraska and Texas completed undefeated and untied regular seasons Saturday to preserve their positions as the No. 1 and No. 2-ranked teams in The Associated Press and United Press International polls. Most college fans, and even some people associated with the Longhorns, would relish a Texas-Nebraska match to settle the final top ranking on the playing field.

title: Arnsparger Offer Denied by L.S.U.
description: Louisiana State's athletic director, Bob Brodhead, denied a report that he has offered Bill Arnsparger, the Miami Dolphins defensive coordinator, the Tiger head football coaching job now held by Jerry Stovall.

title: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS
description: A Sharp Collection

title: CURRENT INTEREST RATES
description: Tax-Exempt Bonds*9.74

title: Waldheim Seeks Discretion
description: Kurt Waldheim, former Secretary General of the United Nations, called on the United States and the Soviet Union today to return to quiet diplomacy.

title: No Headline
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be reported this week. Monday

title: IN MILITARISTIC EAST GERMANY, THE FACIFISTS MOBILIZE
description: The prayer for peace, read aloud from a pew, floated through the darkened, 800-year-old St. Nicholas Church. Then a trumpet sounded, a spotlight washed suddenly over the apse, and about 70 young people left their pews and walked to the altar.

title: Employees May Reject Bus Contract, Chiefs Say By The Associated Press
description: Greyhound union leaders were predicting yesterday that bus drivers and other employees who have been on strike for 26 days will reject the company's latest contract offer when votes are counted today.

title: Lebanese Say Shuf Villagers Are Facing Severe Shortages
description: Up to 30,000 Lebanese Christians are being besieged by Druse forces in the town of Deir al Qamar in the Shuf Mountains and face severe food and fuel shortages, former residents said today.

title: VARIATIONS IN PRICING SCUBBERS FOR UTILITIES
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Shared interests, common goals and similar suffering have drawn us even closer together.

title: CELTICS HOLD OFF PISTONS
description: Kevin McHale's 21 points in the fourth quarter frustrated a Detroit rally tonight as the Boston Celtics held on for a 114- 99 victory over the Pistons.

title: WAREHOUSE DISCOUNTERS GROW
description: Under the high, vaulted ceilings of warehouses in out-of-the-way areas of Seattle, Oklahoma City, Dallas, San Diego and many other cities, bargain-hunting shoppers cheerfully dodge forklift trucks and packing crates in search of a wide variety of merchandise.

title: TRIPOLI GROUP IS GOING TO SYRIA TO MEET ON ACCORD
description: A group of Lebanese from this city are to travel to Syria Monday to work out details of an agreement for the departure of rival Palestinian factions from this area, one of the group said today.

title: MOSCOW AIDE SAYS SOVIET PEOPLE SUPPORT ANDROPOV'S MISSILE POLICY
description: The Soviet Union's Deputy Ambassador to the United Nations sidestepped a question today about President Yuri V. Andropov's health but said his country ''as a whole'' supported Mr. Andropov's policy of further deployment of nuclear missiles.

title: KORCHNOI AND KASPAROV ADJOURN
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union and Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland adjourned the fourth game of their semifinal world championship chess match tonight in a rook-and-pawn ending that figures to be a draw.

title: ISRAEL'S TALKS WITH THE U.S.
description: News Analysis

title: REDSKINS BEAT EAGLES, 28-24
description: The Washington Redskins qualified for the playoffs by defeating Philadelphia, 28-24, yesterday in Washington.

title: A.T.&T. Stock Warrant Price
description: The exercise price for A.T.& T. stock warrants attached to a $150 million issue of Prudential Funding Corporation 10 1/8 percent Eurobonds due in 1993 was set on Friday at $75.25, according to Prudential- Bache Securities. Each warrant, which is good for five years, entitles the holder to buy 10 shares of the new A.T.& T. plus one share in

title: Semiconductor Suit by I.B.M.
description: Officers of the National Semiconductor Company could not be reached by telephone yesterday to comment on the $7.5 billion suit filed against the company Friday by the International Business Machines Corporation.

title: REPORT SAYS CITY'S UPTURN IS INCOMPLETE
description: Excerpts from report, page B4.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Citizens Utilities Co., Stamford, Conn., has appointed Peter A. Howley vice president of the Citizens Utilities Rural Company.

title: Galeotti Wins Walk Event
description: Bruno Galeotti, a former distance runner and soccer player in his native Italy, won the 73d annual Coney Island 10-mile race walk yesterday in 1 hour 51 minutes 39 seconds.

title: BRIEFS
description: Double R Fast Foods Inc. said it had agreed to sell certain assets of its Roy Rogers fast food restaurants to a Marriott Corp. subsidiary for $750,000, plus forgiveness of certain debt owed Marriott and the assumption by Marriott of all secured debt, totaling $800,000.

title: Spanish Rightists March
description: Thousands of ultrarightists, their hands raised in the fascist salute, staged a show of strength against the Socialist Government today and paid homage to the late dictator Francisco Franco.

title: Turkey Plans to Build NATO Military Air Base
description: Turkey will build a new military air base in Thrace, to the south of the Bulgarian border, for the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, according to official Turkish sources.

title: NEW YORK STATE STEPPING UP FREE SURPLUS FOOD PROGRAM
description: New York State is expanding its program for distributing free surplus food to the poor, state officials have announced.

title: FEDERAL AGENCIES GET PLANS FOR IMPROVING MANAGEMENT
description: Complicated Federal bureaucratic procedures kill initiative among Government workers and hamper service, but they could be changed with different management attitudes, says a study of Government operations.

title: CREDIT MARKETS Forecasts of Drop In Rates Persisting;  Recovery Pace Cited
description: Forecasts of lower interest rates are still circulating, even though rates have been higher than some had expected. The prediction of lower rates have persisted because the pace of the economic expansion seems to be slowing, and money supply growth has dropped to within or below the targets set by the Federal Reserve.

title: 2 Afghans Executed For '82 Murder
description: Two Islamic rebels who were convicted of killing a senior Afghan official a year ago have been executed in Kabul, the Afghan capital, the Kabul radio said today.

title: William S. Perry, 78, Is Dead; Retired Corporate Executive
description: William S. Perry, a retired manufacturing executive and investment banker, died Friday at Oil City Hospital in Oil City, Pa. He was 78 years old and lived in Oil City.

title: Mark Jeffry Heller Marries Constance J. Forchheimer
description: Constance Joan Forchheimer, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Forchheimer of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Mark Jeffry Heller, son of Dr. and Mrs. Jerome M. Heller of Johnstown, Pa. Rabbi Jack Stern Jr. performed the ceremony at the Westchester Reform Temple.

title: IRISH SUSPECT DENIES CHURCH RAID
description: The fugitive leader of the Irish National Liberation Army, who is a suspect in last Sunday's machine-gun attack on a Pentecostal church in Northern Ireland, denied responsibility for the attack in an interview published today.

title: A MONK IN SOUTH AFRICA PAYS FOR HIS SILENCE
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. AND CANADA AGREE TO STUDY DAM PROJECT
description: United States and Candadian officials met here last week and agreed to set up a joint commission to try to resolve Canadian ecological concerns over a dam construction project in North Dakota.

title: U.S. Debt Collection Doubles
description: The Justice Department collected $477.8 million in debts and civil and criminal fines in the fiscal year 1983, more than double the previous year's amount, Attorney General William French Smith said today. The department collected $200.1 million in the fiscal 1982, he said.

title: Protect Steel, Damage All
description: ''This is a hydra,'' as Bill Brock so well put it. ''New heads,'' said the President's special trade representative, ''come up every day.'' The latest is Bethlehem's bid for more protection against steel imports. The nation's second largest steelmaker is understandably aroused by competition from efficient foreign producers, notably South Korea and Brazil. But it's hard to see how additional protection for American steel will benefit the public - or the long-term prospects of the domestic industry. As Mr. Brock concluded, there are strong reasons to hold out for open world trade in steel.

title: THE GOLF HOLE NOBODY WILL FORGET
description: SCOTTSDALE, Ariz.

title: WHAT PREVENTIVE DETENTION CANNOT ACCOMPLISH
description: To the Editor:

title: POP RECORD BUSINESS SHOWS SIGNS OF RECOVERY
description: After four years of sharply declining sales, the pop record business is showing signs of recovery. But the lean years and a changing technology have left a permanent mark on this $3 billion industry. And some executives warn that a handful of extremely popular records does not spell security for the industry as a whole.

title: CORRECTION
description: An investing column about medical technology stocks in the Sunday Business section incorrectly identified one of the companies in the group. It is the Matrix Corporation of Northvale, N.J., a maker of cameras used in diagnostic equipment.

title: CONCERT: A LIEDER RECITAL WITH BARBARA HENDRICKS
description: CONCERT managers tell us that lieder recitals are no longer salable to a general musical audience, some going so far as to say that the medium - in its professional sense at least - is dead. Barbara Hendricks, on the other hand, sang a program of classic lieder-recital proportions Sunday afternoon that filled most of Alice Tully Hall and filled it with an audience that obviously knew the literature and expected much from it.

title: ADVERTISING
description: Computer Account

title: AMONG THE STAFF, THE MOOD IS TESTY
description: President Reagan may be riding high in the opinion polls, but his staff at the White House continues to be plagued by bickering, second-guessing and a general restlessness among some of the key players.

title: GIANTS FALL, 27-12, TO RAIDERS
description: The season that might have been flashed in front of the Jets yesterday: long spirals by Richard Todd finding their mark to Wesley Walker and Lam Jones, the slanting runs of Freeman McNeil, sacks by the defensive line and intimidating tackles.

title: THE RACE GOES ON (II)
description: Presid ent Reagan may be ''dismayed'' by Yuri V. Andropov's announced plans to counter NATO missile deployment in Europe with new Soviet deployments, but what did he expect? Moscow had made it plain that it would not accept medium-range U.S. missiles ''near the borders of the Soviet Union'' without taking strong measures in response, including direct threats to the U.S. mainland.

title: ; TO END DRUG TRAFFIC, END FEINT EFFORTS
description: To the Editor:

title: ASSAD SEEN ON TV FOR FIRST TIME SINCE ENTERING A HOSPITAL NOV. 14
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria appeared on television tonight for the first time since Nov. 14, when officials said he entered a hospital with appendicitis.

title: DEBRIS OF L.I. BLASTS SEARCHED FOR CLUES
description: Federal and Suffolk County investigators combed a scorched plain of twisted rubble at Bellport, L.I., yesterday for clues to the explosions that destroyed the Grucci fireworks plant Saturday, killing 2 people, injuring 24 others and damaging 100 nearby homes.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Chief Adds a Post At Main Hurdman

title: THE DANCE: PLAYERS' PROJECT
description: APROGRAM note for the performance Saturday night by Anna Sokolow's Players' Project defined Miss Sokolow's vision of dance as ''movement impelled by truth.''

title: Mazzola Joins Embassy Pictures
description: John W. Mazzola, the former president and chief executive officer of Lincoln Center, has been named executive vice president of Embassy Pictures.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Lost in Translation

title: CORRECTION
description: An investing column about medical technology stocks in the Sunday Business section incorrectly identified one of the companies in the group. It is the Matrix Corporation of Northvale, N.J., a maker of cameras used in diagnostic equipment.

title: BEIRUT, THE CITY OF DESPAIR
description: A man committed suicide in a parking lot the other day.

title: Memphis Loot Estimate Is Raised to $6.5 Million
description: The police have tripled, to $6.5 million, their estimate of the money two armed men took in a Thanksgiving morning holdup of an armored car company.

title: POPULARITY: FEARS OF AN ADOLESCENT
description: FEW words have the capacity to

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Bell-Ringer Of a Week
description: THE American Telephone and Telegraph

title: PRESSURE ON GREEK INDUDTRY
description: When Andreas Papandreou's Pan Hellenic Socialist Movement came to power in Greece two years ago, George A. Tsatsos, one of the country's leading industrialists, tried to establish cordial relations with the new administration.

title: LANDING GEAR LINKED TO CRASH
description: Stuck landing gear may have led to the crash of a private plane in which six television station employees, another passenger and the pilot died, says an official with the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: MONDAY, NOVEMBER 28, 1983 International
description: Future Israeli-U.S. cooperation in the Middle East and more aid to Israel are expected to be the prime topics discussed in Washington this week by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and Defense Minister Moshe Arens. Mr. Shamir is to meet Monday and Tuesday at the White House with President Reagan. Mr. Arens will hold separate meetings with Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger. (Page A1, Column 6.) Benigno S. Aquino Jr.'s birthday was observed in the streets of Manila by tens of thousands of Filipinos, carrying signs demanding the resignation of President Ferdinand E. Marcos, whose Government is suspected of havcing had a role in Mr. Aquino's murder last Aug. 21. (A3:4.)

title: FLOATING-RATE WORLD BANK BONDS
description: The World Bank, which borrows more than $10 billion a year in international markets to support its third world lending activities, is about to adopt new ways to tap fresh sources of money and possibly lower its charges on loans to the poor, according to bank officials.

title: Debt Issues
description: * British Columbia announced that it would offer in European markets $125 million of 12 percent bonds due in 1993.

title: MISTRIAL IS DECLARED IN BLACK MAN'S TRIAL OVER CONFRONTATION
description: A mistrial was declared today in the case of a black man accused of attempted murder in the shooting of a white policeman.

title: Man Shot Dead On Jersey Street
description: A 23-year-old Plainfield man was killed and a companion was injured when they were struck by bullets fired from a passing motor vehicle early this morning, the police said.

title: A 'DIALOGUE' PLEA BY COMMONWEALTH
description: The Commonwealth nations, expressing alarm at what they said was a rising level of violence and confrontation in the world, called on the United States and Soviet Union today to resume ''a genuine political dialogue.''

title: S.M.U. Turns Back Houston in Tokyo
description: Southern Methodist, led by Lance McIlhenny's two touchdown passes and aided by Houston mistakes, gained an easy 34-12 victory today in the seventh Mirage Bowl.

title: MONDAY SPORTS Football
description: Dolphins vs. Cincinnati Bengals , at Miami. The Dolphins are 12-3 at home on Monday nights, the best record in the league, and 15-9 over all on Mondays, second to the Raiders' 20-2-1.

title: LATIN NATIONS' PROSPECTIVE BACKYARD UP NORTH
description: To the Editor:

title: OILER LOS MAY MEAN '84 GAIN
description: The Houston Oilers finally lost a game that meant something.

title: Lakers 103, Bulls 100
description: Kareem Abdul-Jabbar hit a sky hook to break a 99-99 tie with 2:37 remaining in the game.

title: Tennessee Dog in the Uranium Manger
description: Supplying enriched uranium to fuel the world's nuclear reactors is a lucrative business that until recently was a monopoly of the United States Department of Energy. But its poor management has lost two-thirds of the business abroad, and foreign competitors are making ready to invade the American market.

title: Live Coverage Is Set For Liftoff of Shuttle
description: The launching of the space shuttle Columbia, scheduled for 11 A.M., Eastern standard time, is to be covered live on the CBS, NBC and ABC News television networks, and on CNN, the Cable News Network.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Holism in a Hotel

title: Tax Surcharge in City Is to Lapse Next Year
description: City officials said yesterday that they would not seek to extend a two- year income-tax surcharge, because it had achieved its goal - tiding the city over during Federal cutbacks and economic hard times.

title: The Calendar ;  Monday
description: The President and Mrs. Reagan are back in the White House following a West Coast Thanksgiving holiday; the Supreme Court returns from a two-week recess, and Capitol Hill remains quiet with Congress not back in town until late January.

title: CUOMO, IN PULPIT, TALKS OF ETHICS AND RELIGION
description: Standing in red robes in the ornate pulpit of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, Governor Cuomo talked yesterday of hunger, Darwinian theory and how his Roman Catholic faith affects his politics.

title: Uruguayans Rally Against Military Rulers
description: More than 300,000 Uruguayans staged an antigovernment demonstration here today to press for a quick return to democracy.

title: MUSIC NOTED IN BRIEF;
description: Reunited Band Evokes Nostalgia at the Beacon

title: Peter Brandon, 57, Is Dead; Acted on Broadway and TV
description: Peter Brandon, the Broadway and television actor, was found dead yesterday in Rochester, Mich., where he was appearing at the Meadowbrook Theater as Oliver Wendell Holmes in ''The Magnificent Yankee.'' He was 57 years old and lived in Beverly Hills, Calif.

title: REGAN ADVOCATES CONTROL BY CITY OF M.A.C. SURPLUS
description: The state's top fiscal official said yesterday that New York City, and not the state, should decide how to use an expected $1 billion in surplus funds from the Municipal Assistance Corporation.

title: DARTMOUTH STUDENTS SEARCH FOR A BETTER FLAG TO RALLY 'ROUND'
description: The Talk of Dartmouth

title: IRAN REPORTS TWO RAIDS BY REBELS IN BAGHDAD, BUT IRAQ ISSUES DENIAL
description: Iran's official press agency said Iraqi ''revolutionaries'' had detonated an explosives-laden truck at the headquarters of Iraq's intelligence services in Baghdad, killing more than 100 Iraqi officials. It added that a second bombing at an Iraqi military headquarters had killed ''tens'' of military personnel.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: ROMAN HOLIDAY A dozen Italian films made during the last two years are getting their American premieres in one eight-day series, starting today at Cinema II, 1001 Third Avenue, at 59th Street (753- 0774). This bumper film crop is sprinkled with such well-recognized talent as Marcello Mastroianni and Tom Berenger (in ''The Secret Beyond the Door,'' a thriller set in North Africa), Virna Lisi (as an older woman in ''A Time for Loving''), Jean-Louis Trintignant (''Blow to the Heart,'' a family tragedy) and Maurice Ponzi (director of ''The Pool Hustlers'').

title: SPORTS HISTORY: HOW GAMES TELL US WHO WE ARE
description: AMERICAN sport heroes and the games that made them famous have long fit snugly between book covers. Many a newspaperman has moonlighted by writing as-told-to books and rush biographies. Then there are the books by the more thoughtful journalist-artistes.

title: Advertising; Ho Ho Ho, Bamberger Trying TV
description: BAMBERGER'S, the Newark based department store chain, this year is replacing its usual Christmas catalogue with a three- week television advertising campaign with the help of Lord, Geller, Federico, Einstein, a medium-size New York advertising agency.

title: Israeli Chief Justice Sworn In As Supreme Court President
description: Chief Justice Meir Shamgar was sworn in today as President of Israel's Supreme Court, succeeding Yitzhak Kahan, who retired.

title: BLUEPRINT FOR EASING STRAIN ON PRISONS
description: To the Editor:

title: Midair Collision Kills 4 Upstate
description: Four people were killed today when two single-engine airplanes collided over this Chautauqua County town, the state police said.

title: JAMES M. ROBBINS
description: James M. Robbins, professor emeritus of engineering at the New Jersey Institute of Technology, died Nov. 20 at his home in Salisbury Mills, N.Y. He was 81 years old and a former resident of Maplewood, N.J.

title: WOMEN STUDY ART OF POLITICS
description: The Republicans call theirs leadership forums. The Democrats call theirs ''Impact '84.'' Whatever the name, both are conferences for female party activists that are being held in cities throughout the nation.

title: TILT TOWARD IRAQ
description: For three years, the United States has myopically maintained neutrality in the Iran- Iraq war. Our self-interest requires a tilt toward Iraq.

title: STUDY BY CONGRESS FINDS MORE SMALLER CITIES WITH BUDGET DEFICITS
description: A Congressional study has found that medium-sized cities and towns are increasingly struggling with budget deficits, as the largest cities did in the past.

title: Sleeping Student Dies in Fall
description: Benjamin Weber of Mason, a 19-year-old student at Michigan State University student, was found dead Saturday afternoon after he apparently fell from a 6-foot-high homemade loft as he slept in his dormitory room, Lieut. Jay Jensen of the campus security police said today. Results of an autopsy today were not immediately available.

title: TORONTO TAKES GREY CUP
description: Joe Barnes, a backup quarterback, ended 31 years of frustration for the Argonauts today by throwing a 3-yard touchdown pass with 2 minutes 44 seconds left to lead Toronto to the Canadian Football League championship with an 18-17 victory over the British Columbia Lions.

title: SHUTTLE'S MISSION SEEN HERALDING NEW U.S.-EUROPEAN COOPERATION
description: American and European space officials said today that the partnership that produced the Spacelab, scheduled to fly aboard the space shuttle Columbia Monday, is likely to be extended to other cooperative space ventures.

title: HOUSTON SPAWNS A THRIVING UNDERGROUND MARKET IN SEWER RIGHTS
description: Ron Curry is a town house developer, and as often as not these days, when he has a new project on the drawing board, the first thing he does is scout the neighborhood, looking for a cemetery.

title: CommoditiesElizabeth M. Fowler Differing Outlooks For Cotton
description: THERE is always something

title: Tennis Postponed
description: The start of the Australian Open tennis championships was called off today after heavy weekend rains left the grass courts at Kooyong Stadium unplayable. Officials will inspect the courts late today to see how many will be fit for play Tuesday, Colin Stubs, the tournament director, said. Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia is seeded No. 1 and John McEnroe is the second-seeded player in men's singles.

title: Italy Pledges Aid to Jordan
description: Italy has agreed to a $60 million aid package to Jordan for loans and technical assistance, the official Jordanian press agency reported today. Foreign Minister Giulio Andreotti of Italy signed an agreement during President Sandro Pertini's three-day visit to Jordan, the Jordanian agency said.

title: PHONE WORRIES IN RURAL AREAS
description: When the telephone rang one recent Sunday afternoon at the home of John Benedict Ackley, president and general manager of the Taconic Telephone Company, it was a subscriber complaining that she had been cut off during a long-distance call to Kansas City.

title: Chicago Team Wins in Frisbee
description: Chicago's Windy City team won the national championship of ultimate frisbee today by defeating San Diego's Spin-Off in the final game of a tournament, 20-17. Ten amateur teams, winners and runners-up in five regions, competed for three days at the University of New Orleans.

title: AFTER BLASTS, SHOCK ON L.I. AMID RUBBLE
description: Just west of the Grucci fireworks factory here, through a tangle of trees in what had been a buffer zone between the plant and the surrounding suburban neighborhood, Norma Havern stood in the debris inside her house today trying to pick up the pieces.

title: Bridge:2 Unknown Players Capture National Mixed Pair Crown
description: One of the world's great players thought he had won a major title at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals here Saturday, but found he had been overtaken by some unknowns from Iowa.

title: BIKINI RADIOACTIVE CLEANUP PUT AT $100 MILLION
description: A committee of American scientists has concluded that the island of Bikini, a site of nuclear tests after World War II, can be made safe again for human habitation but that it would probably require replacing all contaminated topsoil with fresh soil. The operation would cost about $100 million.

title: Basement Rifle Range Asked in Grade School
description: Recreation officials want to set up a rifle range in a school basement to teach youths the proper way to use guns, but school officials say such a program would create a public relations disaster.

title: Seattle Trust
description: The Seattle Trust and Savings Bank said it had received a tentative proposal under which its 984,000 common shares outstanding would be acquired and Seattle Trust would continue to operate as a separate bank.

title: Ad Hall of Fame Picks 4 More Industry Giants
description: John Elliott Jr. of Ogilvy & Mather, Howard J. Morgens of Procter & Gamble, the late Clarence E. Eldridge of General Foods and the late Owen Burtch Winters of the Erwin Wasey agency will be the latest additions to the Advertising Hall of Fame of the American Advertising Federation, the selection committee announced last week. The committee is headed by Barton Cummings, chairman emertius of Compton Advertising.

title: Fordham Takes 5th in Shootout
description: Dave Roberson's 18 points and clutch free-throw shooting by Steve Samuels enabled Fordham to hold off the University of Alaska-Anchorage, 69-68, today and capture fifth place in the Great Alaska Shootout.

title: Required Reading
description: Like Father, Like Son

title: ISRAELI OFFICIALS IN U.S. FOR TALKS ON JOINT ACTIONS
description: President Hafez al-Assad of Syria met with party leaders in his first publicized appearance since he was reported ill two weeks ago. Page A10.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Reunion and a New School

title: BUILDING'S ALTERED PLAN IMPERILS ITS TAX BREAK
description: The city engineer had a problem with the building he was inspecting. It was nothing like the one in his plans. Where there were supposed to be 35 stories, 26 were being built. Where the floors should have been 23,900 square feet, they were 30,660.

title: Superior Oil Offer Of Stock for Debt
description: The Superior Oil Company filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a stock-for-debt offer combined with a public offering.

title: Carcinogen in Illinois Fish Brings a Warning on Eating
description: A cancer- causing pesticide ingredient, chlordane, has been found in significant numbers of Lake Michigan trout and salmon, prompting conservation officials to warn against eating the fish.

title: 'ADOPTABLE' DOLLS AREN'T HAVING ANY TROUBLE FINDING HOMES
description: After two months of searching and getting up early and standing in lines with others on the same mission, Michaline Perez of Passaic Park, N.J., was in luck yesterday. She was able to buy a Cabbage Patch Kids doll.

title: CORRECTION
description: A report in New York Day by Day on Nov. 8 about the mourning period for Terence Cardinal Cooke incorrectly accounted for the four red hats suspended from the ceiling of St. Patrick's Cathedral. Three belonged to Cardinal Cooke's predecessors; the fourth belonged to no one but represented the fourth Cardinal, Francis J. Spellman.

title: Bonn Trade Data
description: West Germany's trade surplus in October expanded to 4.18 billion marks - about $1.5 billion - from 3.59 billion marks in September, the Federal Statisitics Office said today. This swung the current account into a surplus of 2.9 billion marks - about $1.07 billion - from a revised month-earlier deficit of 800 million marks, the office added.

title: Debt Issues
description: * Alcan Aluminium Ltd. said its Alcan Australia Ltd. unit would issue $100 million of floating rate notes due in 1993, through Swiss Bank Corp. International. The notes will bear interest at a quarter of a percentage point above the London interbank offered rate.

title: HARVARD, BIOGEN IN PATENT DEAL
description: Harvard University said yesterday that it has obtained United States and European patents on a new genetic engineering process, and that it had granted an exclusive license to the technique to Biogen N.V., a Netherlands-based biotechnology concern whose chairman, a former Harvard professor, invented the process.

title: BIO-RESPONSE reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
BOLAR PHARMACEUTICAL CO reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Lysiak Drops Suit
description: Tom Lysiak , the center for the Chicago Black Hawks, agreed yesterday to drop his Federal court suit against the National Hockey League after the league said it would let him appeal his 20-game suspension for tripping a game official. Lysiak will be granted a hearing on his case when the league's board of governors convenes Dec. 8 in West Palm Beach, Fla. . . . Nick Fotiu, the left wing for the Rangers, drew a three-game suspension for his part in a bench-clearing brawl last Saturday with the Hartford Whalers. Ray Neufeld of the Whalers also drew a three-game suspension for being the first player to charge over the boards once the fight began.

title: The Search Goes On For Explosion Clues
description: Arson investigators continued to search through the rubble of the Grucci fireworks factory here today for clues to the cause of the explosions and fires that leveled the complex on Saturday.

title: FELDSTEIN PRESSES ANEW TO REDUCE THE DEFICIT
description: Martin S. Feldstein, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, today stepped up his campaign to shrink the Federal budget deficits.

title: GENERAL DEFENSE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Schering-Plough Head Wears Yet Another Hat

title: STAGE: MISS CHANNING HAS A LEAD ROLE IN 'LADY'
description: IT'S often said that the best actors can keep us riveted even

title: A GREAT LOST RIVER GETS ITS DUE
description: GEOLOGISTS now believe that one of the great master rivers of world history once flowed west from the eastern portion of the United States and was responsible for much of the land and stream formation as far west as the Mississippi valley.

title: Soviet Tennis Lag
description: Tennis in the Soviet Union has suffered from neglect over the last decade and shows no signs of improving, according to three former national champions.
