In an article in Pravda, the Soviet Communist Party newspaper, on ''the failures Soviet tennis often suffers on the world scene,'' they said that a growth plan adopted in 1974 never materialized. The three, Sofiya Maltseva , Tatyana Nalimova and Eduard Negrebestsky , said that tennis equipment remains scarce and that few facilities are being added.

title: SFN COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
REAGAN SIGNS BILL PROVIDING '84 FUNDS FOR LEGAL SERVICES
description: President Reagan, who had proposed that the Legal Services Corporation be abolished, signed legislation today extending the life of the agency but imposed restrictions on its operations.

title: Heart Patient Celebrates
description: Emmanuel Vitria, said to be one of the world's longest surviving heart transplant patients, celebrated on Monday the 15th anniversary of his life-saving operation.

title: EAGLE STAR ATTRACTS 2D ROUND OF BIDS
description: Allianz Versicherungs A.G. and B.A.T Industries, competing for Eagle Star Holdings, Britain's sixth-largest insurance company, raised their bids today within 15 minutes of each other. Both valued Eagle Star at just over $1.3 billion, meaning the takeover would be the biggest ever in Britain.

title: Drop in Farm Workers Found in U.S. Survey
description: An Agriculture Department survey of farm workers in the United States shows a 47 percent decline from 1979 to 1981 in the number of migrant laborers traveling to harvest fruit, vegetables and other crops.

title: CONCERT: YOUTH SYMPHONY
description: David Alan Miller, the music director of the Youth Symphony Orchestra of New York, is only 22 years old, but as he demonstrated on Sunday afternoon in Carnegie Hall his youth is tempered with an admirable discipline and musical understanding. He often managed to mold his players, who range in age from 12 to 20, into a mature-sounding musical organization.

title: The Correct Answer
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES:It is rare to find errors in your Questions and Answers column, but there was a mistake in the column for Sept. 27, 1983, on adiabatic expansion.

title: PLAYERSIra Berkow; THE EDUCATION OF AN APPRENTICE RIDER
description: Under the soft lights in the paddock at the Meadowlands Saturday night, a few of the eight horses being readied for the fifth race were skittish, tossing their heads and rearing. It was a race for 2-year-old maidens and some had never raced before.

title: Charlotte Curtis Honoring Douglas Dillon
description: THE China Institute of America, long the territory of those who supported Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek and the Kuomintang Party that ruled Nationalist China before Mao Zedong's Communist takeover, finally opened its arms to the People's Republic, and its diplomats were on hand the other night at a black-tie dinner honoring C. Douglas Dillon.

title: HORMEL, GEORGE A, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
INTERNATIONAL STRETCH PRODUCTS INC reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $8,000 for the current year and $59,000 for previous year.

title: Yanks Hold Price
description: The Yankees announced yesterday that ticket prices next season will remain the same as they were this year. Prices are $9 and $7.50 for box and reserve seats, and $4 for general admission. The price of season tickets will also remain the same.

title: ERROR IN SITING REACTOR PLANT IN SOUTH RUSSIA IS DISCLOSED
description: The problems at the giant Atommash reactor-manufacturing plant that brought censure from the Politburo last summer and evidently set back the nuclear power program apparently stemmed from siting the factory too close to a manmade lake, Soviet sources said today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Altos Computer Systems said it had introduced a computer, the Altos 986, to compete with business minicomputers and that it had cut prices on its other computer products.

title: Topics Troubled Relationships
description: Good Marriage

title: Reagan Signs Measure Killing Satellite Plan
description: President Reagan signed a bill today that kills his plan to sell Government weather satellites to private industry.

title: NICARAGUA CHALLENGED ON CUBANS
description: The State Department said today that if Nicaragua was serious about asking Cuban military advisers to leave the country, it should step up negotiations with other Central American countries for a regional peace settlement.

title: ALERT FALCON STEALS TWO PACKER PASSES
description: When new coaches put in new defensive schemes, the benefits are sometimes long in the making. One of Dan Henning's first acts as the new coach of the Atlanta Falcons this year was to change the defense from a 4-3 alignment, with four linemen and three linebackers, to a 3-4. Other, less noticeable changes were made in the secondary.

title: The U.N. Today; Nov. 29, 1983
description: SECURITY COUNCIL

title: ADVERTISING
description: Addenda

title: PETRIE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: Carson Pirie Scott & Co., Chicago, has named Neil A. Ramo president of its department store division.

title: RATES UP AMID A POLICY FOG
description: Interest rates rose yesterday as market participants struggled to interpret recent clues to Federal Reserve policy. The Fed's late-afternoon announcement of a $300 million decline in the nation's basic money supply measure for the week ended Nov. 16 did little to ease the extreme uncertainty, leaving rates basically unchanged.

title: Naming Stars for Fee A Fraud, Group Says
description: An astronomical society is warning consumers not to fall for ads offering to name a star after them or their loved ones for a fee.

title: Ford and G.M. Profit Sharing
description: Autoworkers at the General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company will receive the industry's first profit- sharing checks early next year, the companies said today.

title: THE PROPER ROLE FOR GOVERNMENT IN AN INDUSTRIAL POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: NEEDED: A NEW WESTERN POLITICAL STRATEGY
description: The Reagan Administration believes it has achieved a victory by beginning to deploy new intermediate-range nuclear missiles in Western Europe. In fact, it may be a Pyrrhic victory, as the North Atlantic Treaty Organization drifts further and further apart. A new political strategy for the West is badly needed. The United States should reaffirm its commitment to Europe by taking a serious, far-reaching initiative to reduce East-West tensions.

title: Seiko Watch: Computer Link
description: The HattoriSeiko Company, Japan's largest manufacturer of timepieces, said it plans to market the world's first wristwatch-type computer system.

title: Panasonic Introduces Computer
description: The Panasonic Company, a division of Japan's Matsushita Electric Company, yesterday introduced a portable computer that some analysts said could be the most successful Japanese entry to date in the American market.

title: THE NEW ADAM ARRIVES FOR A TEST
description: AS the Friday-after-Thanksgiving dinner conversation turned to personal computers, the new name ''Adam'' came up. So I suggested meeting Adam, the new personal computer from Coleco Industries, awaited by consumers for months in the expectation of high capability at a very good price.

title: NBC COMEDY 'CHEERS' TURNS INTO A SUCCESS
description: The scene is a Boston bar, where the regulars hoot, back-slap and dissolve into giggles when somebody makes a joke about sex. Diane Chambers (Shelley Long), a former graduate student working as a waitress, once again is offended. She begins to lecture the customers in her most professorial tone.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: SCOUTING
description: Repus Bowl I

title: Duke Power
description: The Duke Power Company said it had filed for an electric rate increase of $213 million, or 13.6 percent, with the North Carolina Utilities Commission.

title: What's Negotiable With Nicaragua
description: Is there, finally, a bargain to be struck with Nicaragua? The Sandinista leftists are broke and beleaguered by rebel forces supplied by the United States. In piling offer upon promise, the Managua regime seems to be asking that it be allowed to survive. What terms, then, should Washington ask for calling off the rebels' ''secret'' war?

title: COLUMBIA SAVINGS & LOAN ASSN reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Joseph Petnel, Inventor Of Automobile Heater
description: Joseph Petnel, inventor of the first practical automobile heater and the three-way lightbulb and a developer of the dial telephone, died here Wednesday. He was 89 years old.

title: Unesco Will Survive, Its Director Pledges
description: The United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization will survive by taking out loans if the United States carries out its threat to cut off funds, the organization's Director General said today.

title: Reagan Honors the Disabled
description: President Reagan, in a ceremony at the White House today, proclaimed the next 10 years the National Decade of Disabled Persons, setting ''a clear national goal - to increase the economic independence of every disabled American.'' He criticized current Federal programs for the handicapped as too often fostering ''unjust, unwanted and nonproductive'' dependence.

title: The Castration Option
description: Some years ago a graffito was stenciled on many New York sidewalks: ''Castrate all rapists.'' Last week in an Anderson, S.C., courtroom, a similar suggestion was heard from the bench.

title: MR STEAK INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 2
description: b-Net loss The latest quarter and year consisted of 14 weeks and 53 weeks, respectively, compared to 13 weeks and 52 weeks for the year-earlier quarter and year, respectively.

title: JUDGES FAULT PROSECUTOR IN VOIDING CONTEMPT FINDING AGAINST BEATTY
description: A state appeals court yesterday threw out a contempt-of-court finding against former State Senator Vander L. Beatty of Brooklyn because of a blunder by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office.

title: Anger at L.S.U.
description: After fans shouted profanities at him, the athletic director of Louisiana State University requested that a policeman escort him and his family out of a basketball game in New Orleans on Saturday.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Nature's Hare Deterrent

title: MASSEY-FERGUSON LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
NORTH KOREA REPORTED TO STEP UP ARMS SALES AND TRAINING ABROAD
description: North Korea is stepping up its arms sales and military training in other countries, according to diplomats and other experts on the region.

title: Article 075582 -- No Title
description: The Treasury announced plans yesterday to sell $10 billion of additional bills in three auctions this week.

title: Advertising; Magazine's Target: Big Farmers
description: WHAT do physicians and farmers have in common? For one thing, many companies will pay to get their attention. So a lot of magazines spring up to carry ads that will reach the people who influence the purchase of whatever it is the advertisers are selling.

title: CURRENCY MARKETS Gold Price Up Sharply After London Robbery
description: The price of gold on international markets climbed $18 an ounce yesterday, to its highest level in more than a month, sparked by the weekend theft of three tons of bullion.

title: AMERICAN QUASAR PETROLEUM CORP reports earnings for 9mo to Sept 30
description: b-Net income.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Pendulum Swings In the Weather

title: Prices Climb in Sweden
description: Producer prices in Sweden rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in October from September and 11 percent from October 1982, the Government said today. In September, producer prices had risen six-tenths of 1 percent from August and 12.7 percent from a year earlier.

title: NORTHEAST UTILITIES reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
Defining Education
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES:I read with interest ''Time to Use Schools For the Very Young'' by Fred M. Hechinger (Nov. 15). Today, day- care and after-school programs are a much needed service. However, the services being provided for in these programs do not have to be called educational.

title: SYSTEMS ASSOCIATES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The share earnings reflect a 30-for-1 stock split in April 1983.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Drunken-Driving Watch

title: POLYSAR LTD reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss After provision for preferred dividends there weren't any earnings applicable to common shares in the latest quarter.

title: NAKASONE CALLS AN ELECTION IN JAPAN FOR MID-DECEMBER
description: Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone dissolved the House of Representatives today to clear the way for a general election in mid-December that will be the most significant test of his leadership since he took office late last year.

title: GEARHART INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income.

title: L.I. VILLAGE JOINS IN GRIEF FOR ITS LEADING FAMILY
description: In this small village of 3,000, everyone knows a Grucci.

title: Jamaica Election Boycott
description: Jamaica's opposition People's National Party announced today that it would boycott an election Dec. 15 unless electoral changes, including the updating of voter lists, were made. Prime Minister Edward P. G. Seaga announced the special election this weekend.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE ;
description: CHOO CHOO Seasonally bedecked shop windows often have a train or so running through them, but one of the more unusual small-railroad aggregations operates segmentally in a half-dozen large display windows in the big lobby of Park Avenue Plaza, at 55 East 52d Street.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I have indicated today, as I have stated time and time again both before and after these hearings, that I will stand behind police officers when they are right and condemn them when they are wrong.

title: Cam Fella Picked As Horse of Year
description: Cam Fella has been selected as the harness horse of the year for the second straight time, beating out another pacer, the triple crown winner Ralph Hanover.

title: Tape-RepairedTicket WinsJersey'sLottery
description: A 28- year-old Union Township man has taped together the lottery ticket he mistakenly ripped up and has claimed his $1.6 million prize.

title: U.S. CURBS THRIFT UNITS THAT ENTER NEW FIELDS
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board adopted stringent standards today for deciding whether to insure deposits of newly chartered savings and loan institutions.

title: HITACHI GAINS SEEN DESPITE I.B.M. FEES
description: Hitachi Ltd., despite a costly civil suit settlement with the International Business Machines Corporation, will continue to post strong profit gains over the next few years, analysts here predicted.

title: Judge Is Challenged In Use of Books in Exam
description: Justice John Todd of the Minnesota Supreme Court has been accused by a state judicial board of consulting books and using a telephone while taking a bar exam this year.

title: THE CITY ;  The Police Blotter
description: Angela Solla, 57 years old, of Brooklyn, was seriously wounded yesterday in a quarrel with a neighbor, who then accidentally shot himself to death as he fled. His identity was withheld until his family could be notified.

title: Japan Growth Stabilizes
description: Japanese industrial production and exports rose in October from a year earlier, but declined from a strong showing in September, according to Government and industry reports today.

title: ARGENTINA'S BLOW TO U.S. NONPROLIFERATION POLICY
description: To the Editor:

title: GAUGING ADOLESCENTS' STRESS
description: Psychologists and teachers are in danger of misunderstanding the sort of events that are most traumatic in the life of a teen-ager, according to a study of adolescents' concerns just completed by Dr. Alexander Tolor, a professor of psychology at Fairfield (Conn.) University.

title: COMCOA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Louise Ansberry Marries an Architect
description: Louise Diane Ansberry, daughter of Louise Steinman Ansberry of Alexandria, Va., and the late T. Peter Ansberry, was married yesterday to Andyan Rahardja, son of Subur Rahardja of Bogor, Indonesia, and Linarti Rahardja, also of Bogor. The Rev. Stanley Imboden, rector of St. James Episcopal Church in Lancaster, Pa., performed the ceremony at Conestoga House, a family home of the bride's mother in Lancaster.

title: More Lawlessness in Legal Services
description: President Reagan, who has nursed a grudge against poverty lawyers ever since they whipped him in court when he was Governor of California, continues his lawless effort to destroy the national Legal Services Corporation.

title: Detectives Pursue Lead In London Gold Theft
description: Detectives concentrated on London's underworld today, trying to track down three tons of gold bullion stolen from a warehouse near Heathrow Airport.

title: Alcoholic's 'Cop-Out'
description: TO SCIENCE TIMES:Alcoholism is a progressive disease. There can be short-term remissions and exacerbations, which must be puzzling for scientists to scrutinize.

title: A FRESHMAN WITH CHARISMA
description: The air is abuzz here, with expectation about the Syracuse basketball team, an enthusiasm that seems to exceed the material at hand.

title: South African Rates Up
description: South African interest rates will be allowed to rise greatly in the Government's anti-inflation effort, Gerhard De Kock, governor of the Reserve Bank, said today. Banks raised their prime rate to 19 percent last week.

title: Realism in Houston
description: Chuck Studlex , the interim coach of the Hnuston Oilers, yesterday said the 33-24 loss last Sunday to the Tampa Bay Btccaneers probably ended his chances of keeping the job next season.

title: Comings and Goings
description: Chuck Noll, the Pittsburgh Steeler coach, said yesterday that Terry Bradshaw does not plan to play this season, but would rejoin the club this week for practice. The quarterback, who has been undergoing treatment for an arm injury in Shreveport, La., has had strained relations with Noll and has suggested he might be better off being released or traded next season. . . . The suspension of the trainer Philip Johnson for having allowed Naskra's Breeze to race with a tranquilizing drug in his system was upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court. The State Racing and Wagering Board had imposed a 60-day suspension, saying a tranquilizer was administered to Naskra's Breeze less than 48 hours before he ran in the ninth race at Saratoga on Aug. 10, 1981.

title: Budget Imperils Wheelchair Play
description: The World Wheelchair Games are in financial difficulty, according to published reports.

title: MISS LAVELLE TAKES THE STAND TO DEFEND ACTIONS AT E.P.A.
description: Rita M. Lavelle testified today that public health and environmental risks, not political considerations, governed her actions at the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: McDonnell in Pact to Buy Tymshare
description: The McDonnell Douglas Corporation, one of the nation's leading aircraft makers, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement in principle to buy Tymshare Inc., the operator of one of the nation's largest data transmission networks, for $378 million in cash.

title: FESTIVAL OF DANCE FILMS SURVEYS NINE DECADES
description: ''Top Hat'' won't be shown at the FilmDance Festival, which opens tonight at the Public Theater. Nor will ''The Turning Point,'' or ballets filmed for television. Instead, the emphasis of this ambitious retrospective will be on works in which film and dance are integral elements, rather than films that record independently created dance. Eighty-nine years of film-dance will be represented, from footage shot head-on with a fixed camera in ''Annabelle the Dancer,'' made in 1894 by the Thomas Edison Company, to the fast-moving traffic of pedestrians and beams of lumber through TriBeCa in ''Sticks on the Move,'' made this year by Elisabeth Ross and Pooh Kaye.

title: Computer Programs Headed For Soviet Seized by Swedes
description: Two shipments of United States computer programs that were believed to be intended for use with computers illegally headed for the Soviet Union have been intercepted here, customs authorities said today.

title: COMMONWEALTH CRITICIZES U.S. OVER NAMIBIA
description: Leaders of the 44-nation Commonwealth said today that efforts to win independence for South- West Africa were being obstructed by United States insistence that there should be a parallel withdrawal of Cuban troops from Angola.

title: GUILT: OR WHY IT'S GOOD TO FEEL BAD
description: GUILT, long blamed by comedians as well as therapists for countless cases of emotional misery and psychological crippling, is being increasingly viewed as a valuable and uniquely human feeling that is essential to social order, moral behavior and ultimately the survival of the species.

title: PRESIDENT OF G.P.U. UNIT RESIGNS
description: In a series of management changes intended to blunt the widespread criticism of its handling of the nuclear accident at Three Mile Island, the General Public Utilities Corporation yesterday announced the resignation of R. C. Arnold, the president of its nuclear power subsidiary, and the expansion of the subsidiary's board to include three outside directors.

title: Baby Jane Doe Is Put O t C L
description: Baby Jane Doe, the Long Island infant born with multiple defects and the subject of a legal battle over whether she should have some corrective surgery, was placed on the critical list yesterday at University Hospital in Stony Brook.

title: Missouri Argues Its Case In Desegregation Suit
description: The state of Missouri was left footing most of the costs for a voluntary metropolitan desegregation plan although no one has determined that the state created the problem, a lawyer said today.

title: Business and the LawTamar Lewin Legal Claims Against China
description: ONE of the last acts of the imperial regime that ruled China in 1911 has come back to plague not only the modern Peoples Republic of China but America's State Department and Federal courts as well. Depending on how it is resolved, it could become a serious obstacle to trade between the United States and China.

title: SCIENCE WATCH
description: Stripping Uranium Nuclei

title: Israeli Shopper Is Hurt By Assailant in Nablus
description: An Israeli shopper was assaulted by a man with an ax this morning in the wholesale market in Nablus, the authorities said.

title: Detroit Edison
description: The Detroit Edison Company said it had raised the cost estimate for its Fermi 2 nuclear power plant near Monroe, Mich., to $3.08 billion, from $2.7 billion. The projected date for the plant to go into commercial operation was pushed back to December 1984, from next June. The company also said it had lowered to $1.95 billion, from $2.05 billion, the cost estimate for its two-unit Belle River coal-fired power plant near Port Huron, Mich.

title: COLE NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
; YOUNG HACKERS RISKING FUTURE CAREERS
description: To the Editor:

title: LOTTE H. EISNER
description: Lotte H. Eisner, the film historian and former archivist for the Cinemath eque Fran,caise, France's national film institute, died Friday. She was 87 years old.

title: AMES DEPARTMENT STORES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: Share earnings adjusted for a 3-for- 2 stock split distributed in September 1983.

title: WOMEN'S LEADERS DENOUNCE REAGAN STANCE IN BIAS CASE
description: Women's rights leaders said today that their cause could be undermined along with the barriers against all discrimination if the Supreme Court accepted the Reagan Administration's narrow interpretation of a law banning sex discrimination in colleges.

title: LOCAL OFFICIALS URGE HARD LINE ON BILLS IN CONGRESS
description: As the National League of Cities opened its convention today, some delegates urged tougher positions on several issues now before Congress.

title: A CONCILIATORY CUOMO ACTS TO SHORE UP WEAK SPOTS IN HIS BASE OF SUPPORT
description: During his first year in office, Governor Cuomo has angered or disappointed a number of the groups and individuals who helped elect him, and the Governor has embarked on what his aides describe as an effort to restore good relations.

title: TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1983 International
description: U.S. military cooperation with Israel is being increased, according to Reagan Administration officials. They said the President had agreed to lift a suspension of delivery of American cluster-bomb artillery shells and had agreed to ease Israel's financial problems by not requiring it to repay any American military aid in the next fiscal year. (Page A1, Column 6.) Washington-Peking ties were stressed by the White House, which took pains to declare that recent Congressional support given to the Chinese Nationalist Government in Taiwan was contrary to Administration policy of recognizing the Communist regime in Peking as the sole legitimate Government of China. (A1:5.)

title: CITY AFTER A SHIFT OF EMPLOYEES, TO REVIEW MEDICAL AID PROGRAM
description: A review of the city's Medical Assistance Program was announced yesterday by city officials, three weeks after Mayor Koch reinstated a city employee who had been dismissed for reporting improper practices in the program. The program determines eligility for Medicaid and sends recipients their monthly Medicaid cards.

title: DOW DROPS BY 7.62 ON PROFIT TAKING
description: Stock prices fell moderately yesterday on profit taking after climbing sharply last week.

title: Cabbage Patch Craze Leads to TV Cutback
description: Reacting to demands from consumers and the television networks, Coleco Industries, marketer of the tremendously popular Cabbage Patch Kids, is going to begin substituting other products on the commercial time that it was planning to use for the dolls, Richard Schwarzchild, president of Richard & Edwards, Coleco's ad agency, said yesterday.

title: Production Up in Italy
description: Italy's State Economic Study Institute said today that the country's gross domestic product grew in real terms by nine-tenths of 1 percent in the third quarter from the second quarter, to about $81.4 billion - but fell four- tenths of 1 percent from the third quarter of 1982. The institute also said consumer prices were an average 13.9 percent higher in the third quarter than in the year-earlier quarter.

title: 'MARCUS GARVEY DESERVES MORE THAN A PARDON'
description: To the Editor:

title: Honda Studies New U.S. Plant
description: The Honda Motor Company is studying the possibility of building a second automobile plant in the United States, possibly by 1986, the company said today. But a Honda spokesman, Shoichi Amamiya, would not confirm the details of local published reports that Honda plans to build a new plant adjacent to the one in Marysville, Ohio, capable of producing 200,000 cars a year, at an estimated cost of $200 million.

title: Puritan Fashions To Answer Klein
description: The directors of Puritan Fashions Corporation are expected to announce today their decision on a $60 million offer by designer Calvin Klein to purchase the company, which makes Calvin Klein jeans. Mr. Klein late last week said that if Puritan rejected his offer of $16.50 a share, he would begin a tender offer at $15.50 a share. The lower price, he said, reflects the cost of pursuing an unfriendly tender offer.

title: SCIENCE LAB CULMINATES MAJOR EUROPEAN EFFORT
description: For the European Space Agency the first flight of the Spacelab marks the completion of the second of its two major engineering projects over the last decade. In contrast to Spacelab, a cooperative venture with the United States, the other project, the Ariane rocket, was a bold bid to compete with Americans in the space-launching business.

title: Consolidated Oil
description: The Appalachian Company said it had ended its tender offer for 1.9 million shares of Consolidated Oil and Gas Inc. and reached agreement to sell back to Consolidated the 424,500 shares it holds for $10.25 each, or nearly $4.4 million.

title: JOB UPTURN BARELY FELT IN SHELTERS
description: Nearly a year of rising economic hopes, with declining rates of unemployment, is apparently leaving one category of American outside the recovery. According to reports from around the country, the number of Americans without homes shows no sign of abating.

title: TUESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Knicks vs. San Antonio Spurs , at Madison Square Garden, 7:30 P.M. The Iceman, George Gervin, cometh to the Garden for his only visit of the season as the Knicks try to get back on the winning track after their loss Sunday to Indiana. (Television - MSG Cable, 7:30 P.M., and 1 A.M., tape. Radio - WNEW, 1130; 7:30 P.M.).

title: WOMEN'S STYLES BY MEN'S WEAR DESIGNERS
description: They began as men's tailors or haberdashers. They have expanded their repertory to include women's clothes. With fashion heading once again toward a cleaner, more tailored look, they may be into something big.

title: Comp-U-Card Hires Its First Ad Agency
description: Comp-U-Card International of Stamford, Conn., which provides an electronic shopping service, has retained Ally & Gargano as its first advertising agency.

title: PARISIAN INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
SCOUTING
description: Gossage Unsure About Next Year

title: Kandinsky Show to Open
description: The second in a three-part exhibition on the Russian artist Vasily Kandinsky will open on Dec. 9 at the Guggenheim Museum. The display, titled ''Kandinsky: Russian and Bauhaus Years, 1915-1933,'' contains more than 300 paintings, drawings, designs and other works.

title: NEW DRUG PROPOSED FOR TREATING ADDICTS
description: ANEW drug, heralded as the first nonaddictive alternative to methadone for treating drug addicts, is expected to receive approval from the Food and Drug Administration early next year.

title: Ballast-Nedam Groep
description: The Ballast-Nedam Groep said today that it had received a $1.4 billion order from the Saudi Arabian Government to construct airfield facilities and related works. The contract will be carried out in conjunction with the Manil Development Company of South Korea. The work will take about 4 1/2 years.

title: Turk Says He Expects No Cutback in U.S. Aid
description: Foreign Minister Ilter Turkmen said today that Turkey ''is not expecting any cut in United States military and economic aid'' because of the recent Turkish Cypriot declaration of independence.

title: Holmes vs. W.B.C.
description: Larry Holmes made a triumphant return yesterday to his home in Easton, Pa., but he was still sparring with the World Boxing Council over its insistence that he defend his heavyweight title next against Greg Page instead of Gerrie Coetzee . ''I don't want them to try to dictate to me two days after the fight,'' he said, referring to his first-round knockout of Marvis Frazier on Friday in Las Vegas, Nev.

title: SCOUTING
description: Sunday Night Off

title: Reagan Appointee Decides Not to Serve
description: A member of the new Presidential Commission on Organized Crime has decided not to serve even though the Justice Department found no basis for charges that he has had relationships with underworld figures, the department said today.

title: American Negotiator Briefs Italian Leaders on Arms Talks
description: Paul H. Nitze, the American negotiator in the medium-range arms talks, told Italian leaders today that the United States believed that the Soviet Union had only suspended, not broken off, the talks.

title: EARNINGS Massey Cuts Loss Sharply
description: Massey-Ferguson Ltd. said yesterday that it narrowed its loss to $11.9 million in the fiscal third quarter ended Oct. 31, from $227 million a year before. It cited stringent cost- cutting and improved productivity.

title: SCOUTING
description: A Great Mystery

title: LOBBY VIEWS SUCCESS AS BEING OUT OF FAVOR
description: If gaining access and influencing friends in high places is the keystone of the savvy Washington lobbyist, then some would say that Randall Robinson, who heads a lobbying group called TransAfrica, is a resounding failure.

title: SALAMANDERS HAVE A SENSE OF MAGNETISM
description: IF a salamander were blindfolded, could it find its way home?

title: COLUMBIA CARRIES SPACELAB TO ORBIT WITH 6-MAN CREW
description: The space shuttle Columbia carried a European-built research laboratory into orbit today to begin nine days of scientific tests and observations by the crew of six men, including a West German physicist.

title: RAYMOND G. BROWN
description: Raymond G. Brown, a former economist for the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, a member of the organizing staff of the Amalgamated Clothing Workers of America and a professor of economics at Cooper Union, was found dead Sunday at his home in Manhattan. He was 56 years old and had apparently suffered a heart attack.

title: Senator Denied Polish Visa
description: Senator Carl Levin, a Michigan Democrat, says he has been refused a Polish visa because he declined to promise he would not meet with Solidarity leaders. The Senator flew to West Germany on Sunday aboard a military plane and is to meet with United States and Soviet arms negotiators in Geneva.

title: Europe-China Deadlock
description: The European Economic Community and China have failed to negotiate an increase in Chinese textile exports to the 10 European nations, a spokesman for the trade bloc said today.

title: STATUES MAY SHED LIGHT ON STONE AGE WORSHIP
description: MYSTERIOUS Stone Age statues of humans unearthed in Jordan may have been used in ancestor worship or a death cult, scientists suggest, or in a primeval faith that spread across the Middle East before the dawn of history.

title: REAGAN APPROVES MORE COOPERATION WITH THE ISRAELIS
description: President Reagan has approved steps to increase American military cooperation with Israel, including resumption of delivery of American-made cluster-bomb artillery shells, Administration officials said today.

title: MODERN CONTROLS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct. 31
description: b-Includes tax credits of $33,281 for the quarter and $78,861 for the nine months.

title: Harlem Dance Theater Schedules Open House
description: Dance Theater of Harlem will hold its monthly open-house performance Sunday at 3 P.M. at the dance company headquarters, 466 West 152d Street.

title: Todd Recalls Remarks By Colts
description: Richard Todd permitted himself the luxury of anger today as he contemplated facing the Colts at Baltimore next Sunday.

title: P.L.O. PEACE TALKS BEGIN
description: Artillery shells fell near United States Marine positions at the Beirut airport today and in the harbor area. Talks began in Damascus, Syria, to gain the withdrawal of rival Palestinian factions that have been fighting in the northern Lebanese city of Tripoli since early this month.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: A Better Car for DelBello

title: SCIENCE WATCH X-Ray Excess Reported
description: A survey of 624 student health services in American colleges and universities has shown that as recently as 1979, 723,000 incoming students received routine chest X-rays, despite a growing belief in the medical profession that such radiation exposures cannot be justified in terms either of economics or health.

title: MANHATTAN FIGHTS JURY DUTY EVASION
description: Manhattan is moving against residents who fail to answer calls for jury duty.

title: HIGH COURT TAKES CUBA TRAVEL CASE
description: The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Reagan Administration had a legal basis for the restrictions on travel to Cuba that it imposed in 1982.

title: CHAMBER: ANDRE AND THE Y SYMPHONY
description: IN the program notes to the concert of Baroque music last

title: CITICORP IN THE SUPERMARKET
description: Citicorp is joining forces with leading supermarkets in Florida and California to give its credit card holders easy access to cash. The nation's largest bank holding company also expects similar accords soon in the New York-New Jersey-Connecticut area. The move is seen as a further dilution of Federal laws that prohibit interstate banking.

title: Mesa Increases Stake in Gulf
description: The Mesa Petroleum Company said it and other members of an investors group that it leads acquired 608,200 shares of the Gulf Oil Corporation yesterday for about $27 million. Mesa said the shares were purchased with voting rights for Gulf's special shareholders' meeting on Friday.

title: BURNS SEES TROUBLE IN RUTGERS SCHEULE
description: Rutgers must make a stronger commitment to its football team than it has in the past if it is to succeed against some of the powerful teams it has scheduled, according to Frank Burns, who was dismissed Nov. 20 as the Scarlet Knights' head coach.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Computers and the Sublime

title: FABRI-CENTERS OF AMERICA INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The share earnings were adjusted for 3-for-2 stock split of November 1982.

title: By Any Name
description: When the Jets move to the Meadowlands next year, how about changing their name to the New Jersey Flowers? If they want to retain some identification with their former city, how about Not-So-Far-From- New York Jets? Or Just-Over-the- Bridge-From-New York Jets?

title: TUT ENTERPRISES reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-The year-earlier figures were not provided as the company acquired its manufacturing units earlier this year.

title: KOHL HOPES ANDROPOV MAY EASE ARMS STAND
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that he had received a letter signed by Yuri V. Andropov, the Soviet leader, expressing the view that the situation arising from the stationing of American missiles in Western Europe was not ''irreversible.''

title: IS HISTORY STILL A VALID GUIDE?
description: NOT to know the past, history teachers say, is to move blindly into the future. Since history repeats itself, students are told, we ignore its lessons at the risk of reliving past mistakes. Yet, students of military history are also warned that strategists, precisely because they know the past, get themselves and their countries into trouble by always fighting past wars, ignoring new conditions.

title: U.S. Will Limit Price Arguments
description: The Justice Department said this evening that Assistant Attorney General William F. Baxter had agreed not to make an argument before the Supreme Court next week that would have put him at odds with Congress.

title: RUSTY PELICAN RESTAURANTS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 23
No Headline
description: Bridge:NewYorkall Nationals

title: DOLPHINS DEFEAT BENGALS BY 38-14
description: Dan Marino threw for three touchdowns, two to Mark Duper, and the Miami defense forced four turnovers tonight as the Dolphins scored a 38-14 victory over the Cincinnati Bengals.

title: BLUES MAY FADE FROM CHICAGO BAR
description: R. SHIPP

title: Hofstra Defeats Lehigh, 60-58
description: Hofstra, the preseason choice of coaches in the East Coast Conference to win the title, struggled to a 60-58 victory over Lehigh in the league opener for both schools tonight at the Hofstra Physical Fitness Center.

title: NOTES ON FASHION
description: IS it accidental that at every turn

title: ARTS HIGH SCHOOLS' REUNION EVOKES PAST DREAMS
description: The crowds were packed so tightly it was nearly impossible to thread one's way through the throng, and between the shrieks of ''Oh my

title: Dance Seminar Series Continues at St. Mark's
description: Bill T. Jones and Steve Paxton will participate in ''The Studies Project: Presentation and Discussion'' on Sunday in St. Mark's Church, Second Avenue and 10th Street.

title: Market PlaceVartanig G. Vartan Whittaker's Saudi Troubles
description: ASURPRISE announcement about the possible loss of its principal health care contract sent the Whittaker Corporation's stock plunging 7 3/4 points yesterday, to 24 1/4. This was the biggest point loss of any issue on the New York Stock Exchange for the session, and reduced the market value of Whittaker's stock by more than $100 million.

title: U.S.I.A. TAILORS TOURS FOR FOREIGN JOURNALISTS
description: American journalists, who have generally been given a long leash to do battlefield reporting, ran into many difficulties while trying to cover the invasion of Grenada Oct. 25, not the least of which was the Reagan Administrations's effort to restrict news coverage in the early days of the operation.

title: ANTI-RACKET CIVIL SUIT IS ALLOWED
description: The Supreme Court today passed up its first opportunity to decide when the Federal anti-racketeering law, which is typically invoked in criminal prosecutions against organized crime, may provide the basis for a private civil lawsuit over allegations of business fraud and mismanagement.

title: STOP & SHOP COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 5
description: All shares outstanding and share earnings have been adjusted to give effect to a 2-for-1 stock split paid June 30, 1983.

title: Copper Prices Up
description: Five copper producers raised prices following the increase of 1.2 cents a pound in trading on the Commodity Exchange of New York.

title: A DIFFERENT APPROACH TO GOLF
description: When the label ''made for television'' is attached to sports programming, it usually identifies events commonly called ''junk'' sports. But a made-for-television golf event this past weekend on NBC Sports was unusual in two respects: It had some legitimacy as a competition, and it was not produced by the network itself.

title: JOCKEY, SHOT IN ROBBERY, DIES
description: A jockey who was shot in the head in an apparent robbery and left beside the New Jersey Turnpike last week has died, officials said today.

title: Jersey Issues Yield Up to 10.75%
description: A $110 million issue of New Jersey Mortgage Finance Agency revenue bonds was tentatively priced with a maximum yield of 10 3/8 percent for interest paying bonds due in 2007 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: KOCH DEFENDS POLICE AT HEARING ON BRUTALITY
description: Testifying for almost two hours yesterday before a Congressional committee, Mayor Koch defended the Police Department but acknowledged that charges of illegal use of force represented a problem that ''cannot be dismissed merely as one of perception.''

title: 53 Killed in Crash Of Nigerian Airplane
description: At least 53 people were killed today when a Nigeria Airways airliner with 74 people on board crashed 300 miles east of here as it made a landing approach, news reports said.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: NEW NICARAGUA ISSUE: SOCIALIST LINKS
description: A document reportedly discovered during the invasion of Grenada shows that left-wing Latin American and Caribbean parties sought ways to ''neutralize'' forces within the Socialist International opposed to them, Jamaican and United States government officials say.

title: 'PINK BILLS' NOT IN U.S. PLANS
description: A Treasury Department spokesman said tonight that the Government was considering changes in the dollar bill, but that printing money in colors is not one of the options now.

title: Lawyer Gets Work Sentence
description: A defense lawyer was sentenced yesterday to three years of probation and 350 hours of community service for his contempt of court in the recent Federal Brink's trial in Manhattan.

title: General Dynamics
description: The General Dynamics Corporation was awarded a $520 million contract to build two nuclear-powered attack submarines at its Electric Boat division in Groton, Conn., the Navy said. A $278 million contract for a third such submarine was awarded to the Newport News Shipbuilding and Drydock Company in Newport News, Va.

title: Conwest Purchase
description: The Conwest Exploration Company said it had purchased interests in 783 oil and natural gas wells in Alberta from a company associated with Dome Petroleum Ltd. for $51.5 million. A Conwest spokesman would not identify the Dome associate except to say it was a private company owned by the Dome group.

title: GORDON HAVENS
description: Gordon Havens, head of the foreign copy desk of The New York Times for 10 years during more than 40 years with the newspaper, died Friday at his home in Center Moriches, L.I. He was 80 years old.

title: MEN IN THE NEWS: WILLIAM J. BROAD
description: When the National Aeronautics and Space Administration let it be known that it was looking for scientists to perform experiments in space, bells went off. That was how Dr. Byron K. Lichtenberg of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology described his own reaction to the NASA announcement. Dr. Lichtenberg, who is 35 years old, and Dr. Ulf Merbold, a West German scientist, have opened a new era in the history of the space age as the first non- astronauts to fly in space. The event marks the beginning of a time when anyone, not just pilots turned spaceship operators, can hope to soar outside the earth's atmosphere to the edge of the rest of the universe.

title: ITALY SEEKING A PARLEY TO SPUR LEBANESE CONCILIATION TALKS
description: Italy is hoping to arrange a meeting of four Western powers to try to advance reconciliation talks between Lebanon's warring factions, Prime Minister Bettino Craxi told President Amin Gemayel of Lebanon today.

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: Levi Strauss Organizes A Marketing Subsidiary

title: BUYING FOR BLOOMINGDALE'S
description: For Susan M. Davis, the 28-year-old buyer of ''traditional gifts'' for the 13 department stores in the Bloomingdale chain, the holiday season is the biggest test of whether she has guessed right.

title: FAMILIAN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss.

title: TEST MISUSE IS CHARGED
description: IN a rebuff to politicians and school officials

title: TURKISH CYPRIOTS WANT MORE THAN THEIR DUE
description: To the Editor:

title: CHICAGO'S MERCANTILE EXCHANGE MAKES ITS MOVE
description: Amid the usual fanfare and the ordinary vexations, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange today moved back across the Chicago River to a new 40-story headquarters - its third trading floor in the past 12 years.

title: U Conn Is Host To Columbia
description: Columbia will play at Connecticut and Virginia at Indiana in the semifinals of the Division I soccer tournament Sunday, the National Collegiate Athletic Association said yesterday.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 29, 1983
description: Companies General Public Utilities announced management changes meant to blunt criticism of its handling of the Three Mile Island nuclear accident. The company said that the head of its nuclear power subsidiary had voluntarily resigned and that the subsidiary's board would be expanded to include three outside directors. (Page D1.)

title: Fannie Mae Plans $250 Million Issue
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association said it plans to sell $250 million of 12 1/2 percent mortgage-backed securities on Wednesday, at a price to be announced that day.

title: AMERICAN STORES CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-Reflects the company's 3-for-1 stock split effective July 8.

title: President Resigns At Zurn Industries
description: David M. Zurn has resigned as president and chief executive of Zurn Industries to pursue other interests, the maker of antipollution equipment said yesterday.

title: 7 BRITISH PAPERS BACK ON STREETS
description: Seven of Britain's nine major national newspapers were back on the streets tonight after a three-day printers' dispute. But the two others - The Sun and The Times - said they would not resume publication until the printers promised to work normally.

title: RIBLI-SMYSLOV GAME ENDS IN DRAW
description: Zoltan Ribli of Hungary and Vasily Smyslov of the Soviet Union agreed to a draw on the 45th move of the fourth game of their semifinal world championship match tonight. Smyslov and Ribli are deadlocked at 2-2.

title: Battered Brunner Still No. 1
description: Scott Brunner survived the pounding from the Los Angeles Raiders Sunday and will be the Giants' quarterback in their next game, against the St. Louis Cardinals here on Sunday, according to Coach Bill Parcells.

title: NEW YORK CITY AS AN APARTMENT OWNER: CASE HISTORIES
description: The low point, Mary Blassingame says, was when she and her neighbors armed themselves with knives to prevent their landlord from smashing the plumbing and thus forcing the tenants out.

title: OSHMAN'S SPORTING GOODS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Shula Signs New Miami Pact
description: Don Shula signed a new contract today with the Miami Dolphins, ending speculation that he would join the New Jersey Generals of the United States Football League.

title: VARLEN CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: The latest periods include the results of the Forsyth Engineering and Machine Corporation acquired on June 16, 1983, accounted for under the purchase method of accounting from the effective date.

title: East German Trip Is Planned By France's Foreign Minister
description: Foreign Minister Claude Cheysson of France will meet with East German leaders on a visit to East Berlin on Thursday and Friday.

title: PRESIDENT SAYS U.S. IS BACKING PEKING REGIME
description: The White House and the State Department are considering the case of a Chinese diplomatic courier who

title: Key Rates
description: * Nuveen index, John Nuveen & Company Salomon Brothers estimates for bellwether issues

title: A.P. NAMES OPERATING CHIEF
description: Louis D. Boccardi, the executive editor and a vice president of The Associated Press, has been named to the new position of executive vice president and will function as chief operating officer of the news service.

title: Kohlberg Lawsuit
description: A class action suit was filed in state court in Delaware against Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company and the management of the Amstar Corporation in connection with their proposed leveraged buyout of the big sugar refiner. The deal calls for the buyers to purchase all of Amstar's common stock for $47 a share and all of its preferred stock for $8 a share. The plaintiff is demanding that the defendants pay Amstar stockholders the fair value of the company's $500 million in borrowing power that would allow the acquisition to occur.

title: AIDS NOW SEEN AS A WORLDWIDE HEALTH PROBLEM
description: GENEVA ACQUIRED immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) has become a worldwide problem with cases now being reported in 33 countries and all inhabited continents.

title: Lung Cancer Still Rising
description: Lung cancer will surpass breast cancer as the top cancer killer of women next year, the director of the National Cancer Institute said Monday.

title: Trail Blazers Fall To Kings, 113-104
description: Larry Drew scored 26 points, recorded a career-high 17 assists and had five steals tonight to lead the Kansas City Kings to a 113-104 victory over the Portland Trail Blazers.

title: BOB EVANS FARMS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 28
DE LA SIERRA NAMED COSMOS' CHAIRMAN
description: The Cosmos, faced with a financial loss last year that front-office sources say was in excess of $5 million and with a decline in attendance since 1978 of nearly 20,000 fans per game, are making drastic changes in their top management.

title: NEXT MOVE ON A POSSIBLE DEFECTOR IS UP TO WASHINGTON, OFFICIALS SAY
description: A State Department official here said today that a Chinese diplomatic courier had asked for asylum, but the Immigration and Naturalization Service would not confirm that such a request had been made, and officials here said that officials in Washington must make the next move in the case.

title: HIGH COURT TO HEAR CASE ON JERSEY CASINO UNION
description: The Supreme Court today agreed to decide whether New Jersey may regulate the labor unions representing employees in the Atlantic City gambling casinos.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: -Term Notes

title: ESTABLISH A SECURITY PANEL
description: The half-century of United States-Soviet relations has seen many ups and downs, but never have relations been more dangerous and never has the need for bipartisanship been more urgent. Instead of applying palliatives such as the Scowcroft and Kissinger commissions to the fringes of the problem, the Government needs a permanent blue-ribbon commission to deal with the central issues and to take our nation's survival out of politics-as- usual.

title: Syndication for Top Colt
description: The syndication of Devil's Bag, the unbeaten 2-year-old who is a leading contender for horse of the year, will be announced in a few days, according to a spokesman for Claiborne Farm, where the colt will stand at stud starting in 1985. James Frieze, the financial administrator of Claiborne, said yesterday from Lexington, Ky., that ''other details are confidential at this time,'' and refused to confirm published reports that the syndication price could reach a record $50 million.

title: CLASSICAL RECORD SALES ARE SURGING
description: Americans are buying classical music recordings in greatly increased numbers. While the pop record business is only now pulling out of a slump, aggressive marketing has brought a new audience to classical music, which has doubled its share of the record market in the past four years.

title: LESSER POLLUTERS
description: To the Editor:

title: Frederick Heymann, 82, Dies; Specialist on the Reformation
description: Frederick G. Heymann, a journalist, teacher and author, died of Alzheimer's disease last Thursday in Calgary, Alberta. He was 82 years old.

title: FOR HAITI'S TOURISM, THE STIGMA OF AIDS IS FATAL
description: -AU-PRINCE, Haiti - Two years ago, many of Haiti's low-paid workers were still building and staffing new luxury hotels and nightclubs, evidence of the widening circle of Americans drawn by the conviviality, art and grace of the people of this preindustrial Caribbean land.

title: Required Reading
description: Headlines From 1900

title: BIEGENWALD, ON TRIAL, DESCRIBED AS 'HUNTING FOR SOMEONE TO KILL'
description: Richard F. Biegenwald, who has been linked to five murders, was described as a man ''hunting for someone to kill'' as his trial for one of the killings opened today.

title: BRITAIN GIVES GRENADA $1 MILLION GRANT
description: Britain announced today its first steps to aid in the restoration of civil government in Grenada following the United States- led invasion of the Caribbean island last month.

title: CORRECTION
description: A table in Business Day on Saturday misstated the volume of trading last week in the shares of the new regional telephone companies and the ''new'' and the ''old'' American Telephone and Telegraph Company stock. A corrected table appears today on page D5.

title: BOYS BETTER THAN GIRLS IN MATH TEST
description: SCIENTISTS who caused controversy in 1980 by reporting that far more boys than girls were gifted in mathematics have found more evidence supporting their conclusions.

title: DEVELOPER SEEKS TO TEAR DOWN TIMES SQ. TOWER
description: The company that was designated to build four office towers as part of the plan to redevelop Times Square is trying to buy the building at 1 Times Square Plaza and replace it with a plaza, a spokesman for the developer said yesterday.

title: JACKSON ASSAILS LABOR'S SUPPORT FOR MONDALE AS MOVE BY 'BOSSES'
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson today renewed his criticism of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s endorsement of Walter F. Mondale's Presidential candidacy, saying it represented an ''undemocratic'' decision by union ''bosses.''

title: AILING RANGERS TIED BY CANUCKS
description: The Rangers, forced to play with four defensemen for the greater part of the game because of injury and illness, salvaged a 3-3 tie with the Vancouver Canucks at Madison Square Garden last night.

title: IN CHINA, TRUDEAU TALKS OF ARMS
description: Prime Minister Pierre Elliott Trudeau met today with China's Prime Minister, Zhao Ziyang, and said he was ''very encouraged'' by the response to his plan for the five nuclear powers to hold a summit meeting on nuclear proliferation.

title: MORE MIDEAST MUDDLING
description: Fighting in Tripoli for control of the Palestine Liberation Organization has distracted attention from Lebanon's crisis. But the crisis hasn't gone away, nor have negotiations made progress.

title: DRUG ENFORCER PLEADS GUILTY TO EMBEZZLING AND RESIGNS
description: An official of the Drug Enforcement Administration pleaded guilty today to embezzling over $4,000 from the agency, according to Robert H. Feldkamp, its director of public affairs.

title: Sports of The Times; Nostalgia Night at N.Y.U.
description: Barry Kramer, the former New York University star, is thrilled that his alma mater is playing at Skidmore College in upstate New York tomorrow because he will have a chance to take his two children to an N.Y.U. game for the first time.

title: NATIONAL TECHNICAL SYSTEMS reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $30,000 for the quarter and $255,000 for the 9 months.

title: A.T.& T. TO OFFER CREDIT CARD SYSTEM
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that it would offer credit cards for use in charging calls at new, coinless telephones.

title: BROWNING-FERRIS INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Figures were restated to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split effective January 1983.

title: BRIEFING
description: A Day at the Opera

title: White House Alert Explained
description: Security was heightened at the White House last week in response to intelligence reports that pro-Iranian terrorists were planning to attack a major American installation here or abroad, Reagan Administration officials said today.

title: BRIGHT, T G, & Co reports earnings for 6mo to Sept 30
BUS LINE STRIKERS VOTE DOWN PACT
description: Striking employees of Greyhound Bus Lines have voted overwhelmingly to reject the company's proposal for a 7.8 percent cut in wages and a reduction in benefits, the Amalgamated Transit Union announced in Phoenix yesterday.

title: WELDED TUBE CO OF AMERICA reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss

title: TV: VIEW OF HIGH SCHOOLS
description: THE nation's 16,000 high schools and their 13 million students have an uncounted number of problems. ''High Schools,'' a film essay based on a report by the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, offers some of the solutions. It also offers a look at institutions straining against the demands of both education and bureacracy, while failing to meet the needs of either. ''High Schools'' will be seen on Channel 13 at 9 tonight.

title: Princeton Downs Rutgers by 52-40
description: There was an extra element of pleasure for the Princeton basketball team tonight as it got its first victory of the season. The Tigers won, 52-40, but, more importantly, the victory came against Rutgers, their New Jersey neighbor.

title: S.E.C. INVESTIGATING POWER SYSTEM
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission told New York State legislators yesterday that its staff has been investigating the sale of bonds issued by the Washington Public Power Supply System since late September.

title: 15th Arson Fire Strikes U. of Massachusetts
description: Dozens of women, some clad in bathrobes, fled today from the 15th arson fire this semester in a University of Massachusetts dormitory and stood in a chilly drizzle as the small blaze in a student's room was extinguished.

title: Careers; 'Plodders' Versus 'Job Hoppers'
description: MIDDLE managers with a hankering to change jobs might do well to stop a minute and consider the varying opinions of some experts. There has always been an argument as to whether managers fare better by spending most of their careers with one company or by moving several times to progressively more desirable jobs.

title: State Loses Round In Birthing Case
description: The rights of a Kingston physician whose practice included delivering babies at home were violated when the State Health Commissioner extended a 60- day suspension of his medical license, the State Court of Appeals ruled today.

title: 20-Game Suspension
description: Warren Skorodenski , the goalie for the Sherbrooke Jets of the American Hockey League, was suspended yesterday for 20 games for shoving Referee Dave Lynch in a game Nov. 20 against the New Haven Nighthawks, according to Gordon Anziano , vice president of the league.

title: A Dream Dies
description: He won 13 national wrestling titles and competed in two Olympics and four World Games, but that was a long time ago, and at the age of 46, Russ Camilleri thought it was time for a comeback. So this fall Camilleri went to Iowa City, where he joined the Hawkeye Wrestling Club, which trains with the University of Iowa wrestling team under Coach Dan Gable , who is also the coach of the United States Olympic Team.

title: High-Technology Index
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today voted to approve the Pacific Stock Exchange's proposal for a stock index option based on 100 high-technology stocks. The S.E.C. said the index would be subject to the same regulatory requirements as the other narrowly based stock index options to prevent the index from being manipulated or gaining a competitive advantage over stock options trading.

title: RANGAIRE CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
ALBERTSON'S INC reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: Share earnings adjusted for a 2-for- 1 stock split effective June 17, 1983.

title: CONE MILLS PLANNING TO GO PRIVATE
description: The Cone Mills Corporation, a textile company that has been the target of a takeover attempt by Western Pacific Industries, yesterday announced an agreement for Cone to be bought by management, employees and institutional investors.

title: BOGOTA'S MISSING $13.5 MILLION
description: The Colombian Government is embroiled in an angry dispute with Chase Manhattan bank over the mysterious disappearance of $13.5 million from Colombia's account with the bank's London branch.

title: Chess Game Postponed At Kasparov's Request
description: Gary Kasparov of the Soviet Union today asked for a postponement of the fifth game of his semifinal world championship chess match with Viktor Korchnoi of Switzerland.

title: Zimbabwe Says It Freed Women Held in Raids
description: All the women arrested in Zimbabwe's monthlong roundup of suspected prostitutes have been released on orders from Prime Minister Robert Mugabe, the Government announced today.

title: Computer Animator Names a New Chief
description: Warren Weinberg has been named president and chief executive of Mathematical Applications Group Inc., a small company in Elmsford, N.Y., with four lines of business, including computerized animation for films.

title: DECOY MAKING: AN AMERICAN FOLK ART
description: FRED MUHS of Westhampton Beach, L.I., spends hours painstakingly carving decoys that look realistic enough to lure game birds out of the sky and within a hunter's range. But few hunters would dare put his birds in the water; some cost $9,000.

title: MAN IN THE RIGHT PLACE FOR GEORGIA
description: Standing by the nose of the F4-D Phantom jet in the photograph, Terry Hoage appears as intended. ''Like a fighter,'' said his coach, Vince Dooley. ''A proper all- American, a proper candidate for the Heisman Trophy.''

title: BUSINESS PEOPLE
description: National Gypsum President Retiring The National Gypsum Company, a major producer of building products, said yesterday that its president and chief operating officer, Edward J. Killian, planned to retire early next year for health reasons. Mr. Killian, 63 years old, has been with the company since 1948 and was named president in June 1982.

title: BUS LINE IS TRYING EXPANDED SERVICE
description: John Teets, the chairman of the Greyhound Corporation, said today that the bus company would move ''full bore'' toward resuming service with replacements for striking workers. He also said the corporation would consider franchising the bus operations to to nonunion carriers.

title: National Medical
description: National Medical Enterprises said it would add through acquisition or new construction 1,183 acute-care hospital beds.

title: PETRIE STORES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
FOOD NOTES
description: Chopped Liver, by Hand

title: NORTHWEST ORDERS 20 757 JETS
description: Northwest Airlines, in a major move to upgrade its fleet of planes, announced yesterday that it was buying 20 Boeing 757 aircraft valued at about $800 million.

title: PARIS OPERA: THE DEBUT OF MESSIAEN 'FRANCOIS'
description: Olivier Messiaen, who will be 75 years old Dec. 10, is the most venerated French composer of his generation. But he had never attempted an opera, an omission that, after eight years of effort, he has now rectified. Monday night at the Paris Opera, a dazzling assemblage of French society, musicians and intellectuals greeted the nearly six-hour result of his labors, ''Saint Francois d'Assise.''

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES
description: Intermountain Markets $600 Million of Bonds

title: E.E.C. Delays Steel Tariffs
description: Ministers of the European Economic Community decided yesterday in Brussels to postpone until Jan. 15 any retaliation against the United States for restrictions it ordered last July on specialty steel imports.

title: U.S. GREENBACKS ARE TO STAY GREEN
description: More people are making money, and the Treasury and the Secret Service officials are worried.

title: SHELLING RENEWED IN BEIRUT REGION
description: Shelling broke out today in the mountains east of here and spread to the outskirts of the city in some of the worst fighting in two months.

COMPO INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 1
Accounting Standard on Debt
description: The Federal Accounting Standards Board said yesterday that it had adopted a new statement under which companies could reduce their debt outstanding by placing Government securities in an escrow account.

title: SIZZLER RESTAURANTS INTERNATIONAL INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
CARRYOUT FOOD: THE CURE FOR HECTIC HOLIDAYS
description: -so-simple side dish of cranberries, buttered pecans and Cognac to a chicken rollatini stuffed with mozzarella and prosciutto, specialty food carryout shops are helping to ease the burden of the holiday season. Between Thanksgiving and New Year's, when most free time is devoted to Christmas shopping and holiday entertaining, something has to give. Like dusting. Or sleeping. Or cooking.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This bill allows the seizure of these particularly dangerous weapons prior to their being used.

title: DRAMA: 'VICTORY,' 1913 FUTURIST WORK
description: ''HOW extraordinary,'' says a character in ''Victory Over the Sun,' the 1913 Futurist stage work that was presented at the Brooklyn Academy of Music over the weekend, ''life without the past is dangerous.'' A Revolution has taken place. The Sun, source of natural life and illumination, has been stolen from the sky by the Futurists. The world is in darkness. But all is not lost, and indeed, the Revolution is celebrated: ''The world will die,'' are the closing words of the survivors, ''but we will live forever.''

description: Wishful Thought

title: Arabs Protest in West Bank
description: -Occupied West Bank, Nov. 29 (AP) - Israeli policemen fired in the air to drive off 30 stone- throwing Palestinians today, the 36th anniversary of a United Nations resolution advocating the partition of Palestine between Jews and Arabs. The Palestinians threw stones and smashed the window of an Israeli vehicle in Nablus, a military spokesman said. Policemen responded by firing in the air, and no injuries were reported, he added.

title: GRENADA DOCUMENT DEBATED AT SOCIALISTS' PARLEY
description: Reports of a ''secret regional caucus'' in Nicaragua, involving cooperation between Socialist and Communist parties of Latin America, have become a source of controversy and debate within the Socialist International, according to participants in a meeting of the organization in Brussels last week.

title: BLACK INDUSTRIES reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
NEW CRIME GROUPS ASSAILED BY SMITH
description: Attorney General William French Smith told a Presidential commission today that a ''new phase in the history of organized crime'' had been created by the growth of motorcycle gangs, prison gangs and foreign-based organizations growing rich on drug trafficking.

title: U.S. Arms Negotiator Says He Feels Andropov Isn't Well
description: Paul H. Nitze, the American arms negotiator, said today that he has the impression that the Soviet leader, Yuri V. Andropov, is ''not well.''

description: Lines written by Christine Merkl and Martin Klapper while standing in line for an art exhibit:

title: Holmes to Announce Retirement
description: Larry Holmes said yesterday that he would announce his retirement next Wednesday, ending the longest reign of a heavyweight champion since Joe Louis held the title from 1937 to 1949.

title: RECITAL: RODNEY HARDESTY
description: THE countertenor Rodney Hardesty neatly bisected his Sunday afternoon concert at the Abraham Goodman House into two distinct sections. The first half of the program was devoted to early music by Bach, Handel, Dowland and several other composers; the second to music of our time.

title: BANK BOARD'S SEIZURE OF BISCAYNE IS UPHELD
description: The bitterly contested seizure of the Biscayne Federal Savings and Loan Association by bank regulators was upheld today in a ruling that could clear the way for the sale of the insolvent thrift institution.

title: DR. FRANCIS HARDESTY
description: Dr. Francis P. Hardesty, professor of psychology at City College, who was responsible for the standardization of the Hamburg-Wechsler intelligence test for children widely used in East and West Germany, died of a heart attack Sunday at his home in Leonia, N.J. He was 56 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * AC Biotechnics Inc. has elected David L. Rainey president and chief executive.

title: DEVILS END LOSING STREAK AT 8
description: The Devils ended an eight-game losing streak and made the home debut of Coach Tom McVie a rousing success tonight with a 3-2 victory over the Chicago Black Hawks at Byrne Meadowlnds Arena.

title: TREASURY NOTES IN DEMAND
description: Good investor demand for a new $6 billion issue of five-year Treasury notes helped the bond market end the day yesterday with price gains of about half a point. Short term interest rates declined slightly.

description: One of the many silly things about this so- called Age of Communication is that the leaders of hostile nations seldom use the new inventions to speak to one another.

title: $45,000 Painting Is Stolen, Briefly
description: A $45,000 painting was stolen from the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island today, but it was recovered just two minutes after an alarm went off, the police said.

title: DYNEER CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
200,000 Dogs Slain, Peking Official Says
description: About 200,000 dogs have been drowned or clubbed to death in a drive to rid Peking of the animals, a city official said today.

description: MCI Seeks Tests Of European Calls

title: Poland Says Mrs. Walesa Can Accept Nobel Prize
description: Lech Walesa's wife, Danuta, will be allowed to travel to Norway to receive his Nobel Peace Prize on Dec. 10, the Government spokesman, Jerzy Urban, said today.

title: AT 13, HE IS RUNNING A WEATHER DATA BANK
description: When 13-year-old Tei Gordon types on a computer keyboard, some 50 corporate clients await his product.

title: DOW JUMPS TO RECORD 1,287.20
description: The Dow Jones industrial average surged 17.38 points yesterday to a record closing high of 1,287.20. Analysts said heavy volume - 100.5 million shares traded, up from 78.2 million the day before - indicated that many cash-laden institutions had returned to the market.

title: Israeli Calls for Court-Martial Of Six Soldiers in Exchange
description: The former Chief of Staff, Lieut. Gen. Rafael Eytan, has called for a court-martial of six soldiers who were exchanged Thursday for some 4,500 Arabs.

title: Baseball Meetings on Drugs Canceled
description: Meetings of baseball's owner- player drug and alcohol committee scheduled for today and tomorrow in Los Angeles have been canceled, raising a question about the future of the committee in the wake of the dismissal of Ken Moffett, the players union leader. However, both sides said yesterday they were prepared to meet again.

title: EXILE FROM THE EAST IN A VINEYARD
description: Joseph Novitski, a former New York Times reporter, is the author of ''A Vineyard Year'' (Chronicle Books, 1983).

title: GEMAYEL VISIT: PLEA FOR U.S. ACTION TO BREAK IMPASSE
description: While President Amin Gemayel's visit to Washington on Wednesday is being billed as a routine discussion between allies, the trip has a much greater urgency and will most likely have sweeping implications for the future of Lebanon and the Gemayel Government. The Lebanese President is going to Washington, according to his aides, to tell Mr. Reagan one thing: ''I am in an impossible bind and you have to help get me out of it.''

title: DESPITE GERVIN, KNICKS WIN
description: The Knick defensive strategy last night was not to worry about George Gervin. The reasoning was that he was going to get his points anyway, and he did, 30 of them.

title: OLD CLOCK IN SENATE IS ALIVE AND TICKING
description: Soon after a bomb exploded outside the Senate chamber several weeks ago, reports began circulating that one of the casualties was a 166-year-old grandfather's clock.

CUOMO HOLDS A FORUM TO PROMOTE '84 BUDGET
description: Governor Cuomo began preparing the people of New York today for next year's battles over the state budget.

title: Hanukkah to Begin ATo
description: The Jewish holiday of Hanukkah, which commemorates the successful fight for freedom of Judas Maccabaeus, begins at sundown today with the lighting of the first candle.

title: PUERTO RICANS WERE KNEELING WHEN KILLED BY POLICE, OFFICER SAYS
description: In videotaped testimony broadcast tonight, a police detective said two young advocates of Puerto Rican independence were shot dead while on their knees by five police officers on an isolated mountaintop five years ago.

title: RHODESIA'S WANDERING WHITES: HEARTSICK FOR THE PAST
description: In the catalogue of white self-perceptions in Africa, there are, by way of social distinction, many categories.

description: IDIL BIRET, a Turkish pianist

ISLANDERS, UP BY 4-1, ARE TIED BY BLUES
description: The Islanders played a first period tonight that was good enough to leave the Blues speechless. But after wasting a 4-1 lead and finishing in a 5-5 tie with St. Louis, the Islanders were the ones nearly left without words.

title: Dutch Mail Service Resumes
description: Mail to the Netherlands was resumed today after a labor dispute there had caused the Dutch to suspend mail service, the United States Postal Service said. The suspension began Nov. 9 for International Express Mail and the next day for all mail. Mail to the Netherlands had been returned to senders and postage had been refunded.

title: SUPREME COURT REJECTS PLEA TO DELAY FLORIDA EXECUTION
description: The United States Supreme Court and the United States Court of Appeals for the 11th Circuit tonight cleared the way for Florida officials to execute 36-year-old Robert Sullivan, who is scheduled to die in Florida's electric chair Wednesday morning.

title: BRITISH POLICE AND PICKETS CLASH IN PRINTER DUSPUTE
description: The challenge to Britain's labor laws by the printers union that shut down national newspapers over the weekend gained violent momentum early today as pickets and policemen clashed outside a nonunion printing plant here.

title: GENETIC ENGINEERING reports earnings for Yr to Aug 31
HIGH COURT WEIGHS CASE ON SEX BIAS
description: A Government lawyer argued before the Supreme Court today for a narrowed interpretation of the Federal law barring sex discrimination in education.

title: DEFINING THE WORD SOCIALIST
description: Few political definitions have engendered so much dispute as the meaning of the word Socialist.

title: GERALD GOODE
description: Gerald Goode, a writer who had been a press agent for the late Sol Hurok, the theater and concert impresario, died Monday at New York Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: 6 Are Reported Killed In Bangladesh Rioting
description: Six people were reported killed and 500 injured Monday in rioting against the martial law Government.

title: Ally & Gargano Is Still on a Roll
description: Continuing its hot streak, Ally & Gargano, on the verge of going public, yesterday was named the agency for the SFN Electronic Publishing Company, a recently formed subsidiary of the SFN Companies of Glenview, Ill. It is the third piece of new business in November for the agency.

title: RANGEL AND 4 OTHER BLACKS IN STATE BACK MONDALE
description: Representative Charles B. Rangel, the state's top-ranking black politician, and four other black leaders in the state endorsed Walter F. Mondale for the Democratic Presidential nomination yesterday.

title: SHUTTLE SCIENTISTS IN ELABORATE TESTS
description: Scientists aboard the earth-orbiting shuttle Columbia hopped, jumped and spun in weightlessness today as part of the most elaborate series of experiments ever done in space to determine its physiological effect on the human body.

title: REAGAN AIDE HINTS AT HELP FOR CITIES
description: President Reagan's aide for liaison with state and local governments today raised, and then tried to back away from, the idea that the Administration could consider special Federal assistance for economically distressed areas.

title: JOHN V. SCHAFFNER
description: John V. Schaffner, head of John Schaffner Associates, a literary agent in Manhattan, died of cancer Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 70 years old and lived in Manhattan and East Hampton, L.I.

title: New York Overture
description: Chet Simmons , the commissioner of the United States Football League, said yesterday the league is very interested in placing an expansion team in New York City as early as 1985. ''I have spoken to the Mayor and his people about the availability of Shea Stadium,'' Simmons said during an interview in the office of the Washington Federals' owner, Berl Bernhard .

description: To the Editor:
