title: 2 Oil Companies Sign China Pacts
description: The Phillips Petroleum International Company Asia and the Pecten Orient Company, a Shell Oil Company subsidiary, were awarded jointly a 1,095-square-mile block in the Pearl River Basin east of Guangdong Province in China.

title: KOCH SUGGESTS USE OF M.A.C. SURPLUS TO REDEEM BONDS
description: Mayor Koch said yesterday that a potential $1 billion surplus that could be generated by the state's Municipal Assistance Corporation should be used for a combination of capital projects, daily city expenses and long-term economic development, possibly including paying for cost overruns for the Convention Center.

title: VAST REFORM NEEDED TO SAVE MEDICARE, STUDY SAYS
description: The Congressional Budget Office said today that modest, step-by-step changes could not prevent bankruptcy foreseen for the Medicare trust fund and that Congress must consider a sweeping revision of the program to save it.

title: BEFORE INDUSTRIAL POLICY
description: Do we need an industrial policy to restore the competitiveness of United States manufacturers in world markets? Looking at our economic performance in the last two years, we might be tempted to say yes. But before taking the irreversible step of conferring enormous benefits on big business and labor, we should be sure that we are not confusing transitory economic troubles with long-term trends.

title: WEDNESDAY SPORTS Basketball
description: Nets vs. Knicks, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, 7:35 P.M. After a 3-4 trip, the Nets are home for their first game against the Knicks this season.

title: SCOUTING
description: Bronx Cowboy

title: TV: 'UNCOMMON LOVE,' MOVIE OF A PROSTITUTE
description: FOR whatever practical or psychological reasons, prostitution seems to be one of television's more prominent preoccupations this season. A couple of months ago, a made-for-television movie called ''Sessions'' offered a sympathetic portrait of a high-priced call girl as she revealed all to her analyst. Tonight at 9 o'clock on CBS-TV, ''An Uncommon Love'' tells the story of a young woman who earns her living in a rather dumpy California massage parlor.

title: South African Trial Delayed
description: The trial of a South African journalist accused of violating the country's press laws was postponed today for five months. Allister Sparks, 50 years old, a correspondent for The Washington Post and The Observer of London, faces charges of breaking censorship laws by quoting a ''banned'' person in overseas publications. At the request of his lawyers, the trial was put off until April 25.

title: THE MEDIA WHAT AM
description: I've given up asking, ''Did President Reagan call?'' For a long time, arriving at the office, that was the first thing I said. ''Did President Reagan call?''

title: SALVADORAN IMPASSE
description: As the military stalemate in El Salvador drags on, many in the United States have begun to wonder what if anything we can do to break the impasse. In fact, there may be very little we can do. We may have pushed the Salvadoran military as far as it is able or willing to go - and, indeed, it may be time to cut our losses and accept the revolutionaries' repeated offers to negotiate.

title: Debt Issues
description: * The Canadian Department of Finance priced its four-part $1 billion bond issue to be offered in Canada: The 10 percent bonds due in 1986 were priced at 99.50 to yield 10.20 percent, the 10.75 percent bonds due in 1988 were priced at 99.75 to yield 10.81 percent, the 11.50 percent bonds due in 1993 were priced at 99.25 to yield 11.63 percent and the 12 percent bonds due in 2005 were priced at 98.75 to yield 12.16 percent.

title: SOVIET AT SESSION ON STRATEGIC ARMS
description: The United States and the Soviet Union met today at a session of the strategic arms limitation talks and agreed to continue negotiations on Thursday.

title: MOHAWK DATA SCIENCES CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
$75 Million Issue For Philadelphia
description: A $75 million issue of Philadelphia general obligation bonds was offered with yields ranging from 6.75 percent for bonds due in 1985 to 9.75 percent in 1993, 10.75 percent in 2003 and 11 percent in 2009, through underwriters led by Citibank.

title: U.S. PUTS OFF ASPIRIN WARNINGS
description: The Department of Health and Human Services has postponed part of an educational program intended to warn parents about Reye's Syndrome, a rare children's disease that has been associated with the use of aspirin in treating chicken pox and influenza.

title: BONN PROSECUTOR MOVES TO INDICT CABINET MINISTER
description: The Bonn prosecutor's office announced today that it intended to indict Economics Minister Otto Lambsdorff on charges of taking bribes. The prosecutor asked the West German Parliament to lift Mr. Lambsdorff's parliamentary immunity.

title: SPICY, ROBUST FARE OF SOVIET GEORGIA
description: Darra Goldstein is the author of ''A La Russe'' (Random House, 1983).

title: SHIFT IN CATALOGUE DELIVERY
description: In the last two months, in an important marketing experiment, two 48-page Sears, Roebuck & Company catalogues were distributed to residents of Santa Clara County, Calif., as inserts to their local newspapers. Customers elsewhere received the catalogues by mail.

title: RITA LAVELLE ANSWERS CHARGES
description: Rita Lavelle, testifying for the second day in her defense, said today that she never lied in nine hours of Congressional testimony about the role of politics in the Environmental Protections Agency's cleanup of chemical waste.

title: NEW SNOW STALLS DENVER RECOVERY
description: It snowed again today in Denver, bringing a little icing for the two feet of snow that dropped on the Rockies over the weekend and nudging Becky Semeyn's yellow Camaro a little closer to invisibility.

title: GERMANY'S VOICE OF FREE ENTERPRISE
description: ''I am neither dishonest nor stupid enough to jeopardize my personal, political and professional existence by sticking money into my pockets like that.''

title: CORRECTION
description: The Charlotte Curtis column yesterday, on a dinner in honor of C. Douglas Dillon, misidentified the firm of Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette. It is an investment banking house.

title: ASSOCIATED HOSTS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 29
description: Share earnings reflect a 3-for-2 stock split in July.

title: GOODHEART-WILLCOX CO INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Rangers' Sick List Continues to Grow
description: Don Maloney has a broken finger on his right hand, Barry Beck and Willie Huber have strained thigh muscles, Dave Maloney has a sprained left knee, Scot Kleinendorst has a swollen elbow, Ron Greschner has a bruised tailbone and Reijo Ruotsalainen is just getting over the flu.

title: KOCH ASKS IT RIDERS TO KEEP CARS CLEAN
description: A spotless and shiny subway train went into operation on the IRT division yesterday morning with Mayor Koch aboard exhorting passengers to help maintain the train in its spotless and shiny condition.

title: Modigliani Show Planned
description: The National Gallery of Art said today that it would open an anniversary exhibition to mark the centenary of the Italian painter and sculptor Amedeo Modigliani. The exhibition, which will feature 25 paintings, 26 drawings and 2 sculptures, will open Dec. 11 and close March 18.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1983
description: Markets Stock prices soared to a new closing high, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 17.38 points, to 1,287.20. Analysts attributed the surge to growing participation by institutional accounts. Over all, the market's gain was not as strong as that of the Dow, however. Other, more broadly based indexes rose only modestly, remaining behind highs set in October. (Page D1.) Strong demand for new Treasury notes helped raise bond prices by about half a point. Short-term interest rates declined slightly. (D9.) The dollar fell in the U.S. after hitting new highs in Europe against the French franc and the Italian lira. Gold prices rose $2.50 an ounce, to $396.50, in New York. (D14.) Cocoa and orange juice futures prices were higher. (D14.)

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Mondale Meets 'the 'Press'

title: FUEL LEAKS CALLED THREAT TO WATER
description: Millions of gallons of gasoline leaking from storage tanks each year poses a potentially serious threat to underground water supplies, the Environmental Protection Agency warned today.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aluminum Co. of America said it had agreed to sell its insulated conductor plant in Marshall, Tex., to a group of former employees for an undisclosed price.

title: JAMES B. ALLEY, 91, LAWYER AND OFFICIAL IN NEW DEAL, IS DEAD
description: James B. Alley, a corporation lawyer who had been general counsel to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in the administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 91 years old.

title: Hope Seen for Whale Breed
description: The birth of a second calf to a right whale has given scientists new hope for the future of the breed, the most endangered of the large whales, says Scott Kraus, head of a New England research group that has monitored the whales for three years. A 45-ton female seen with a calf in 1979 off the Georgia coast was seen this summer with a calf off Massachusetts. Scientists estimate only four or five right whales are born in the North Atlantic each year.

title: LITTON INDUSTRIES INC reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Includes a currency adjustment of $424,000 for the latest quarter and $548,000 for the year-ago period.

title: ISRAELIS AND ARABS: BARRIERS CRUMBLE
description: Israel no longer seems as isolated and cut off from Arab neighbors today as it once did.

title: Ship's Crew Guilty InDrugSmuggling
description: The 15- man crew of a Panamanian freighter seized in Delaware Bay two months ago pleaded guilty today in a plot to smuggle eight tons of marijuana into the United States.

title: DAVID F. EDWARDS
description: David F. Edwards, a partner in the Morristown, N.J., law firm of Edwards & Antholis and an officer of Resorts International Inc. for more than 25 years, died Friday, apparently of a heart attack, at his home in Spring Lake, N.J. He was 75 years old.

title: Treasury Resignation
description: Marc E. Leland, Assistant Secretary of the Treasury for International Affairs, said today that he planned to resign in January. Mr. Leland, who joined the department three years ago, said he has no specific job plans. On Monday, the White House said W. Dennis Thomas, the Treasury's Assistant Secretary for Congressional Liasion, would become the deputy chief of Congressional relations. Also, a Treasury spokesman said Cora P. Beebe, Assistant Secretary for Administration, would be leaving soon for the Environmental Protection Agency.

title: Continental Resumes Talks With Pilots
description: Continental Airlines has resumed negotiations with striking pilots with the help of a mediator, but it has rejected talks with its stewardesses.

title: COAST OIL LEASES SALE BLOCKED
description: A Federal district judge today blocked the scheduled sale of leases for 770,000 acres of oil and gas-bearing lands off the central California coast, just hours before the Federal Government was to auction the leases.

title: Bridge:2 Titles in the Fall Nationals Won by East Coast Players
description: Two major titles were decided here Monday night at the American Contract Bridge League's Fall Nationals, and both went to East Coast players.

title: AUTHOR AND LECTURER WARNED OF THE NAZIS
description: James Waterman Wise, an author, art dealer and lecturer who warned against Nazism before Hitler came to power, died in his sleep Monday at his home in Nice, France. He was 81 years old.

The Other Ominous Deficit
description: The idea that foreign trade is vitally important to America's welfare is, well, alien to most Americans. If they think of trade at all, it's mostly about imports - little cars from Japan and unemployed workers in Detroit. It's time to raise the nation's consciousness about imports and exports.

title: POLICE DEPT. HONORS CIVILIAN HEROES
description: Chris Roman, 13 years old, is still unsure why he acted as he did. He only remembers that he was ''scared.''

description: Many people see a facial resemblance between Herb Brooks, the Ranger coach, and Bill Beutel, the Channel 7 newscaster.

title: Regan Chides Feldstein
description: Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan said today that people who are blaming the Government's budget deficit on President Reagan's tax cuts and defense buildup are ''big spenders'' who are attempting ''to justify their push for tax increases.''

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: WITH the onset of winter and the holidays at the year's end, numerous requests come in for special or festive foods that fit the season. They are for dishes that can be made in a hurry, and be suitable for special menus.

title: COUNCIL VOTE BARS CARRYING KNIVES WITH LONG BLADES
description: Publicly carrying a knife with a blade more than four inches long or openly wearing a knife of any size would be illegal under a bill passed yesterday by the City Council.

title: SURINAME SAYS IT FOILED COUP AND SEIZED 10 PARAMARIBO, Suriname, Nov. 29 (AP) - The left-wing military Government said today that it had foiled a coup attempt and had arrested 10 people.
description: Sgt. Maj. Marcel Zeeuw, the deputy commander of the military police, said at a news conference that the suspects, arrested last week, had distributed pamphlets to stir unrest and had set a Government radio station, office building and warehouse on fire.

title: Article 078397 -- No Title
description: The Puritan Fashions Corporation announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell the company to Calvin Klein, the fashion designer, for $17.50 a share, a dollar more than Mr. Klein had offered two weeks ago.

title: THE POP LIFE
description: ALL over Africa, the Zairian guitarist, singer and bandleader Franco is known as ''the sorcerer of electric guitar,'' or the ''grandma^itre.'' Since 1956, Franco has led T.P.O.K. Jazz, based in Kinshasa and known not just in Zaire, but throughout Africa, in Europe and in the Caribbean - particularly Haiti, where Franco's French lyrics are understood. Friday, Franco and T.P.O.K. Jazz will make their New York debut at the Manhattan Center, 34th Street and Eighth Avenue.

title: GOING OUT GUIDE;
description: -year-old Japanese-American recounts his life, and the characters appear on stage as they are remembered in ''A Song for a Nisei Fisherman,'' which will open the seventh season of the Pan Asian Repertory Theater tonight at 8 o'clock.

title: Indiana Wins
description: Marty Simmons, a freshman, scored 22 points tonight, including 8 during a 28-4 spurt in the second half that carried Indiana to an 80-72 victory over Notre Dame.

title: SCOUTING
description: Lacrosse Time

title: ; SCIENTISTS' INDIVIDUAL 'GUILT' IN THE ARMS RACE
description: To the Editor:

title: COMMONWEALTH CAUTIOUS ON GRENADA
description: A one-week Commonwealth conference ended here today with a final declaration saying this is a time for ''reconstruction, not recrimination'' in Grenada.

title: PAULEY PETROLEUM reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-After a loss from adjustment to 1983 income tax provision of $2.7 million. c-After an extraordinary gain of $266,000. d-Net loss. The 1983 results include a pre-tax gain of $10.8 million from the sale of a portion of the company's interest in an oil and gas lease in the Santa Barbara Channel and a gain of $1.8 million from real estate operations primarily from the sale of 244 acres of undeveloped land during the year.

title: JOE THEISMANN LIKES NEW YORK
description: When the elevator doors opened on the seventh floor of the Macy's store yesterday, Joe Theismann, in a soft-brown sports jacket, was standing at a microphone in books, across the aisle from Christmas cards and not far from toys, picture frames, puzzles, stamps and coins.

title: Ex-Dynamics Aide Held
description: James H. Gilliland, a former executive at the General Dynamics Corporation, was arrested in Britain yesterday, Federal officials said in New York. He was indicted in September on charges of accepting kickbacks from executives of the now-defunct Frigitemp Corporation.

title: GEORGIA PLANE CRASH KILLS 6
description: Six people returning from a Thanksgiving trip to New York were killed in a twin-engine plane that slammed into a fog-shrouded mountain in a rain storm. The authorities said the plane was beginning its approach to the Richard B. Russell Airport at 10:30 P.M. Sunday when it crashed on foggy John's Mountain, 14 miles north of the field.

title: Inflation in France
description: Retail prices rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in October, the same gain as in September, bringing the rate of increase over the past 12 months to 10.4 percent, the French National Statistics Institute said today.

title: NEW-VOTER DRIVE IS AIMED AT POOR WHO SEEK BENEFITS
description: A campaign has been started to register as many as five million poor people as voters when they go to Government agencies to apply for benefits such as food stamps, unemployment compensation and health care.

title: Q&A
description: Q.

title: BANKRUPTCY LAW ROBBED OF ITS 'LANGUAGE'
description: To the Editor:

title: Topics Up in Arms
description: Silent Verdict

title: 'MILD' WHISKIES: WHAT'S IN A NAME?
description: Calorie-conscious Americans are downing light beer by the barrel and light wine by the case, so why not ''light'' whisky?

title: NEWLY SOCIALIST COUNTRIES STAY CLOSE TO U.S.
description: For the first time in history, Socialist and Socialist-led Governments have come to power in every country in southern Europe.

title: Hint on Reagan Campaign
description: In yet another sign President Reagan will seek a second term, an aide asked New Hampshire election officials today what Mr. Reagan must do to get into the state's Presidential primary.

title: WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1983 International
description: A new high level U.S.-Israeli panel will be established to coordinate military planning, joint military exercises and a stockpiling of American weapons in Israel. The plan to create the political-military committee was announced by President Reagan and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir after two days of talks in Washington. (Page A1, Column 6.) Strategic arms talks continued in Geneva. American officials took Soviet attendance at the session as a sign that Moscow will continue the talks next year despite having walked out of the negotiations on intermediate-range missiles. (A15:1.)

title: Eagle Star Bid
description: The London Takeover Panel has told Allianz Versicherungs A.G. that is has until Dec. 5 to decide whether to increase its bid for Eagle Star Holdings P.L.C., a panel spokesman said.

title: DREW NATIONAL CORP reports earnings for Qtr to Aug 31
description: b-Net income which included extraordinary credits of $838,000 for the quarter and $1,002,000 for the year.

title: EAST GERMAN TO RUN DETROIT SYMPHONY
description: An East German conductor, Gu"nther Herbig, was named music director of the Detroit Symphony Orchestra today. The appointment is to take effect Sept. 1, 1984. Until then, Mr. Herbig will hold the title of music director-designate.

title: Dayton Hudson
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation plans to establish a $2.5 billion, five- year capital investment plan, three- quarters of which will pay for new stores, the company's president, Kenneth A. Macke, told securities analysts.

title: 3 ACCUSED OF SETTING FIRE TO 19 BUILDINGS TO COLLECT INSURANCE
description: An insurance adjuster and two landlords were charged in Manhattan yesterday with being members of an arson ring that set fire to 19 buildings to collect $1.2 million in insurance.

title: Advertising; Grey's Corporate Survey
description: EVEN though advocacy advertising has become a bit of a buzzword of late, the vast majority of corporate leaders in a recent survey strongly rejected the concept.

title: Merchandise Trade Gap at a Record
description: Another drop in exports and an 11.7 percent jump in imports widened the nation's merchandise trade deficit to a record $8.97 billion last month, the Commerce Department said today.

title: SHIP INSPECTORS' COSTS PAID DIRECTLY
description: A requirement that shipping companies pay back the Government for the costs of inspecting their vessels overseas has grown into a system in which the shipping lines often directly provide Coast Guard inspectors with plane tickets, hotel rooms and meals.

title: Dunlop Plans Changes
description: Sir Campbell Fraser, the 60-year-old president of the Confederation of British Industries, is stepping down as chairman of Dunlop Holdings, Britain's largest tire manufacturing company, at the end of September 1984, it was announced today. Sir Campbell will become president of Dunlop, and will be succeeded as chairman by Sir Maurice Hodgson, 64, the former chairman of Imperial Industries.

title: Official Is Upheld On Power Plant
description: The New York Court of Appeals today upheld the denial of a certificate needed for the construction of a $556 million power plant in Prattsville by the State Power Authority.

title: REAGAN, IN SHIFT, SIGNS BILL TO PAY U.S. FARMERS NOT TO PRODUCE MILK
description: President Reagan, yielding to political appeals from key allies in Congress, today signed a bill that for the first time would pay farmers not to produce milk.

title: HAZEL BRYANT REMEMBERED AT HARLEM CANDLELIGHT CEREMONY
description: Hazel Bryant once said of her fellow black artists, ''The church has been our Carnegie Hall.'' And so, on Monday night, when Miss Bryant's friends remembered her with a candlelight ceremony, they gathered in Harlem, in a church.

title: Honduran Delegation in U.S. With an Urgent Aid Request
description: A Honduran delegation flew to the United States today to ask for prompt economic aid, according to a local newspaper.

title: NEW YORK DAY BY DAY
description: Recalling 1948 Vote in U.N.

title: What the Police Hearings Produced
description: Voices were raised again at Monday's Congressional hearings on police brutality in New York. But there's no longer much reason to fear, as there was last summer when the hearings began, that the issue might tear the city apart. In fact, the intense debate has had some constructive results.

title: NICARAGUA SAYS VISA DENIAL IS PART OF 'HARD-LINE' POLICY
description: Interior Minister Tomas Borge said today that he believed the decision to deny him a United States visa had been made personally by President Reagan as part of a 'hard-line' policy.

title: Praise for Mrs. Cuomo
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: MORE TOP ACTORS OPTING FOR OFF BROADWAY ROLES
description: It was the first run-through of ''The Human Comedy,'' which is in rehearsal for a scheduled opening at the Public Theater on Dec. 20, and Rex Smith got to a particularly emotional scene in the script. He was amazed at his own reaction.

title: CHINESE VEGETABLES: AVAILABLE, DELICIOUS
description: Eileen Yin-Fei Lo teaches cooking in New York and is the author of ''The Dim Sum Book: Classic Recipes From the Chinese Teahouse.''

title: DANGEROUS EMOTIONS ABOUT NUCLEAR WAR
description: To the Editor:

title: DONALD C. HAYS
description: Donald C. Hays, a senior partner of Gifford, Woody, Carter & Hays and a retired partner of Sage Gray Todd & Syms, New York law firms, died of cardiac arrest Nov. 10 at University Hospital.

title: AFGHAN OFFICIAL CALLED TARGET
description: Afghanistan's Defense Minister, Gen. Abdel Qader, reportedly escaped an assassination attempt in Kabul on Nov. 10, a Western diplomat in Pakistan said today.

title: 2 DANGEROUS MENTAL PATIENTS ESCAPE
description: Two inmates described as dangerous escaped from a high-security ward at a state psychiatric hospital on Wards Island on Monday by sawing through a barred window and clinging to 25 bed sheets as they climbed down nine stories, state officials said yesterday.

title: PLAYSMichael Janofsky
description: Quickness has its advantages,

title: EVICTION AWAITED BY SOUTH AFRICANS
description: Several hundred black villagers refused today to heed an edict ordering them off lands that they have owned for 70 years and that are now termed a ''black spot'' to be excised from the surrounding white area.

title: PAINE WEBBER TO MOVE INTO ROCKEFELLER CENTER AREA
description: ANTHONY DePALMA

title: O'NEILL NOW FAVORS REVISION OF IMMIGRATION LAWS
description: Thomas P. O'Neill Jr., Speaker of the House of Representatives, now supports a sweeping revision of immigration laws, his top aides said today.

title: Petition for Rose
description: The owner of the Cincinnati Reds may have his doubts, but Ken Kuresman, a 38-year-old Cincinnati food broker, wants to make up his mind for him. Kuresman has begun a drive for a petition to get the Reds to bring Pete Rose home to Cincinnati to end his career.

title: WESTERN MARINE ELECTRONCS INC reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Includes a gain of $1,533,000 from sale of building for the quarter and year.

title: WICKES COMPANIES reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
description: b-After net from discontinued operations and an extraordinary credit of $9,585,000. c-Net loss after losses from discontinued operations of $79,201,000 for the quarter and $106,763,000 for the 9 months. d-After net from discontinued operations of $2,913,000 and an extraordinary gain of $10,154,000. The extraordinary credits in latest periods are tax credits. The latest quarter and 9 months net include pretax gains of $10.3 million from sale of the company's 35 percent investment in Canwest Financial Services-U.S.-Inc. The year-ago quarter loss from discontinued operations includes $75 million from disposition of the company's catalog operation and results from operations of the company's leasing business and the catalog operations. The year-ago 9 months net loss includes writeoff of debt discount and expense of $52.2 million and provision for store closing reserves of $8.7 million. The year-ago figures were restated to reflect operations discontinued after Oct. 30, 1982. The company is listed on the Pacific, Philadelphia and Midwest stock exchanges.

title: Diet Stand Disputed
description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: Economic Scene; Effect of Rising Military Costs
description: THE biggest growth sector in the world economy is military spending. Unlike other growth sectors, however, the rapidly growing military production and international arms trade does not nourish economic growth but retards it.

title: WAY BEYOND WESTWAY
description: The desperate fervor with which Governor Cuomo and New York's two Senators have been attempting to manipulate Westway through and around the law, the courts and the Congress is worthy of a better cause.

title: Superior Oil Is Suing Keck
description: The Superior Oil Company went to court because it wants to pay a stock dividend. It filed a suit in Nevada against Howard B. Keck, its former chairman, who opposes the dividend, and Willametta Keck Day, his sister.

title: A TINY CATFISH ON IMPERILED LIST
description: The smoky mad tom, a tiny catfish known to live in one stream in the Cherokee National Forest of Tennessee, should be put on the endangered species list, Fish and Wildlife Service officials have reported.

title: Tea Snobs and Coffee Bigots
description: In a recent letter to this page, Elaine Cogan of Portland, Ore., complained about New York's lack of civility concerning the serving of tea. Whenever she ordered tea during a visit here, restaurants uniformly brought her a cup of hot water and a tea bag. ''There seems to be no understanding,'' she said, ''that a decent cup of tea needs to be brewed in a pot. . . . What a relief to be back in the Pacific Northwest, where even the most modest diner not only serves tea in a pot but often offers the patron an assortment of flavors.''

title: A RESURGENCE FOR SHIPPERS IN BURGUNDY
description: BEAUNE, France ONCE upon a time, the Burgundy wine business was a study in simplicity. Rough- hewn peasants made the wine. Worldly shippers from Beaune bought it from them, blended it, aged it, bottled it and, finally, sold it, all over the world. Some shippers owned vineyards of their own, and a few growers were also shippers. But they were exceptions.

title: RYKOFF, S E, & CO reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 29
Businessman Enlarges Aid for Disease Study
description: The Potamkin Award for distinguished contributions toward the understanding of Alzheimer's disease, a $25,000 grant given for the first time in 1982, has been expanded and restructured to become the Potamkin-Lerner Fellowship in the Neurosciences, the founder, Victor H. Potamkin, announced yesterday.

title: TANDY COMPUTER'S HARD TEST
description: The Tandy Corporation, the world's largest retailer of consumer electronic products and one of the most profitable, got that way emphasizing price, distribution and service.

title: BOOKS OF THE TIMES
description: THE groping for gimmicks in the world of children's illustrated books seems to be growing steadily more delirious. This year, there is even a picture-book of ''Old MacDonald Had a Farm'' that, through the wonder of miniaturization, will actually play the tune when you open its covers. When this project was put to the acid test, he asked what we would do with the book while the music was playing. To the suggestion that we might read it, he responded, ''Yes, but the musi c'll be bothering us.'' Precisely.

title: SALVADORAN RIGHTIST AND KEY SANDINISTA ARE BARRED BY U.S.
description: The Reagan Administration today rejected visa applications from Nicaragua's Interior Minister and the leading right-wing political figure in El Salvador.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: ''The loss of a mind is too terrible for conscious contemplation. Dementia mercifully protects the individual against the horrible effects of this loss. Hence it is the family member who must face the terrible reality of the illness process.'' - Barry Reisberg, M.D., gerontologist.

title: IN POLAND, STANDING IN LINE ISN'T TOTAL LOSS
description: To the Editor:

title: BROAD EFFECTS EXPECTED FROM CASE OF BABY DOE
description: Since the Reagan Administration instituted rules for the care of handicapped infants in hospital nurseries 19 months ago, Federal Government officials have investigated 49 cases across the country. In each case, the hospitals voluntarily turned over the baby's medical records.

title: Cleveland Electric
description: The Cleveland Electric Illuminating Company sold 500,000 shares of $100 preferred with an initial dividend rate of $11.36 a share. Underwriters were led by Salomon Brothers. The dividend rate on the stock, rated A-3/ BBB, will be adjusted quarterly to half a percentage point below either the bond equivalent yield for three- month Treasury bills, the 10-year Treasury note yield or the 20-year Treasury bond yield, whichever is higher.

title: JERSEY MOTHER HELD IN DROWNING OF TWO OF FOUR MISSING CHILDREN
description: A 25-year-old woman from Camden, N.J., was charged yesterday with the murder of two of her four young children, all of whom have been missing for more than two weeks and are believed by the police to have been drowned in the Cooper River.

title: U.S. ISRAELI PANEL WILL COORDINATE MILITARY PLANNING
description: President Reagan and Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said today that a United States- Israeli political-military committee would be set up to coordinate military planning, maneuvers and the stockpiling of American arms in Israel.

description: TO THE LIVING SECTION:

title: SCURRY-RAINBOW OIL LIMITED reports earnings for Yr to Sept 30
description: b-Restated Share earnings reflect a 5-for-1 stock split in July.

title: BUDDING LAWYERS ON WALL STREET TAKE NEW APPROACH TO TRADITION
description: Within the last few years, Paul Risko studied Welsh nationalism at Oxford. Betty Lawrence was a librarian, Barbara Nims was an Army nurse and George Newhouse played on the Harvard football team.

title: A BRUSH FOR BASTING
description: FOR most home cooks the holiday season is a time for preparing large roasts to feed hungry gatherings of family and friends. Anyone who has endured a roast chicken that has the texture of cotton balls or parched, stringy turkey can appreciate how essential it is to baste roasts often and to keep an eye on a meat thermometer.

title: FILIPINO COMMUNIST REBELS PRESS ATTACKS ON ARMY AND CORRUPTION
description: The New People's Army, the military arm of the outlawed Communist Party, periodically attacks soldiers, policemen, suspected government informers and rural officials whom it considers corrupt, but usually does not harm ordinary villagers.

description: b-Net income c-Net loss

title: DESPITE LEAD IN POLLS, MONDALE AND BACKERS ARE WARY ON NEW HAMPSHIRE
description: An icy rain dripped from Christmas lights near Callahan's Bar in Concord late Monday when Walter F. Mondale stepped in to speak to more than 100 schoolteachers and their families.

title: SCOUTING
description: Murcer on Rise

title: COURT REINSTATES FEDERAL RULES AFFECTING 'INDUSTRIAL' HOME WORK
description: Rebuffing a Reagan Administration deregulation effort, a Federal appeals court today reinstated a longstanding Federal ban on commercial knitting of outerwear by people working at home.

title: BATTLE LINES DRAWN OVER 1985 MILITARY SPENDING
description: President Reagan has made ever-upward military spending a mark of his Administration, but the President and his senior advisers on national security are now heading into a critical decision on his military program.

title: CONCERT: MUTI CONDUCTS PHILADELPHIA ORCHESTRA
description: -GOING is largely a matter of expectations, some fulfilled, some not. The perpetual uncertainty surrounding live musical events is part of what keeps true melomaniacs coming back for more, and more, and more. Last night at Carnegie Hall, for instance, we were offered the Philadelphia Orchestra under its musical director, Riccardo Muti, playing Wagner, Brahms and Bartok. The expectation, at least in this reviewer's mind, was that the Wagner and Brahms would go well. Long experience suggested that this was the sort of repertory in which the the Philadelphians would revel. But the Bartok? Well, that might present problems.

description: IT would be nice to say that no
